title: Who, Said Sue, Said Whoo?; By Ellen Raskin. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum. $4.95. (Ages 4 to 8)
description: A familiar guessing game receives fresh and funny treatment in Ellen Raskin's little teaser about a small girl and her unlikely hitchhikers. Sue, fashionably 1930ish moppet drives a roadster of comparable vintage through a maze of stylized vegetation that hides an assortment of animals making a corresponding assortment of sounds. What's the animal, and can you find it? And who's making the offstage chitterchatter? Therein lies the game. Miss Raskin's departure, however, lies in the art. In a delightful variation on the old joke about fitting elephants into a Volkswagen, the tiny twoseater and its diminutive driver pick up a zoofull of riders, ranging from a small black shrew to a huge orange gnu. (My favorite is a gentle yellow cow obviously in search of mother.) As the passengers increase in this unlikely ark, so does the ingenuity of Miss Raskin's design, a blend of visual elegance and pure slap

title: Liberal in Queens Fighting Leaders
description: When Democrats in New York City set out to gather signatures on nominating petitions, it's a massproduction operation. Card tables at street corners. Mass swoops. through apartment houses.

title: Danish School Children Stage a OneDay Strike
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 31 (UPI)Thousands of school children went on strike yesterday in protest against a government proposal to cut each class by five minutes and extend teachers hours.

title: Teachers Moving To Verdon Steps By LOUISE SAUL
description: EAST BRUNSWICKOne night a week for the next five weeks, Bethany Chapple, Bayonne High School's 280pound football coach, will attend a moderndance course taught by Gwen Verdon.

title: MIAMI DIVER WINS PLATFORM CROWN
GREECE'S PRIMATE IS SAID TO RESIGN
On the go
I.T.T./C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON  Two separate though interrelated threads emerged last week from the inquiry into the role played by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in the formulation of American policy toward the Chilean Presidential election of 1970.

title: New York
description: Out of the chaos of the New York mayoral campaign came more chaos last weekalong with the first glimmerings of some order.

title: Milestone in Verona
description: VERONA  The Verona Public Library is in the process of marking both the 80th anniversary of its founding and the 50th year at its present location in the Civic Center complex. The story of the library over those years is one of growth and development from a collection of books owned by its founder to the modem facility that borough residents know today.

title: Schaeffer of St. John's Voted Haggerty Award
description: The Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association has named Bill Schaeffer of St. John's winner of the Haggerty Award, symbolic of outstanaing player in the metropolitan area.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I feel that the publication of items like the lamentof the anonymous brownstone owner ["No Need to Worry About the Tenants, the Brownstone Agent Said, March [8] is a disservice both to the real estate community and to the public at large. detnned area: needless destruction and removal from the new and improved neighborhood.

title: Pop
description: AFTER the release of an exceptionally strong debut album and a subsequent year and a half of triumphant concert appearances and critical acclaim, John McLaughlin's Mahavishnu Orchestra has continued its steadfast march to the sea of joy with the unleashing of its latest offering, Birds of Fire (Columbia KC 31996). The title is taken from a poem, reprinted on the album cover, by Sri Chinmoy, McLaughlin's Indian spiritual teacher, which includes the lines Above the toil of life my soul is a Bird of Fire winging the Infinite. The title is an appropriate one, for in this new work much emphasis is placed on showcasing individual expression, with almost every piece serving as a framework for the solo flights

title: Photography
description: THE death of Edward Steichen a few days before he would have been 94 brings to an end one of the most interesting careers in photography. Steichen was that rare creature, a photographer of genius who was equally at home in art, commercial and documentary photography. In addition, he organized exhibitions of photography, painting and sculpture that had a deep and listing influence on modern taste.

title: Legacy of the War
description: If the future of South Vietnam remains obscure, the impact of the American intervention is clearly visible to anyone who has lived in the country's cities and moved about its countryside. What did the American decade mean to the South in terms of political, social and other changes?

title: History Buffs Seek to Save 1800's Communal Living Site
description: COLTS NECK TOWNSHIP  If what remains of a 19thcentury experiment in communal living here is preserved, it will be because of the efforts of a handful of dreamers who refuse to give up, even when events seem to demonstrate that their cause is lost.

title: Nigerian N.Y.U. Instructor Seized in Rape and Bribery
description: A visiting instructor at New York University was arrested yesterday and charged with beating and raping a 28yearold law student Friday night Wand attempting to bribe an ar. Testing detective with $1,020; the police said.

title: Yorty Is Expected to Gain Runoff Spot
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31Mayor Sam Yorty is now a solid favorite to survive strong challenge in the primary election next Tuesday as he bids for his fourth consecutive term at the helm of the nation's third largest city.

title: PRIEST TO RECEIVE NOTRE DAME MEDAL
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 31The Laetare Medal, the highest honor bestowed by the University of Notre Dame, will be awarded this year. to a priest for the first time since its establishment in 1883.

title: GEORGIA TORNADOES KILL1, HURT SCORES
description: ATLANTA, Ga., March 31 (AP)At least one person was killed and scores Were injured today when tornadoes cut across portions of central Georgia.

title: Day Care Cuts
description: The issue of child daycare has been on liberal agendas since the 1820's when New England reformers established dozens of infant schools to serve the children of working Mothers. But not until recently, when the Federal Government threatened sharp reductions in support of social services, has the daycare movement begun to look like a children's crusade.

title: Sweden Plans Paper Plant For Hanoi for $68Million
description: STOCKHOLM, March 31 (Reuters)  The Swedish International Development Authority today announced the largestever Swedish project in a forelmu country, a $68million paper factory in North Vietnam.

title: Increase in Inflation Cited, as Japanese Raise Discount Rate
description: TOKYO, March 31  Japan decided today to raise the official discount rate by threequarters of a percentage point to 5 per cent effective Monday.

title: Todd Graham to Marry Miss Gore
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  Mrs. Atkinson Gore of Washington and the Onteora Club in Tannersville, N. Y., and Henry Grady Gore Jr. of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Courtney Cleveland Gore, to Todd Hackney Graham of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs., Lee P. Graham of Glen Cove, L. I. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Governor Is Back From Trip
description: Governor Rockefeller arrived in the state at 2 A.M. yesterday after a weeklong European trip and immediately went to his estate in Pocantico Hills, spokesman for the Governor said. The Governor's first public appearance was expected to be tomorrow morning in Albany.

title: Movies
LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.F.O.'s in Pennsylvania May Have Been Fireworks
description: FLEETWOOD, Pa., March 31 (AP)A rural Pennsylvania police chief says he may have discovered the source of nightly sightings of unidentified flying objects that have excited this hill country region for several weeks.

title: U.A.W. TO REGAIN MICHIGAN CENTER
description: BLACK LAKE, Mich., March 31This is mortgage burning time at the Walter and May Reuther Family Education Cen ter on the wooded shore of Black Lake in northern Michigan.

title: NASSAU SIX TO TRY FOR PEE WEE TITLE
description: Having taken the title of New York State Pee Wee hockey champions (ages 1112), the Nassau County Long Island Athletic Club Pee Wees are set to enter the United States championships to be held in Superior, Wis., on April 6 to 8.

title: Carvers of Decoys To Compete on L.I.
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I.  Joseph H. Wetherell stopped duck hunting a decade ago, but he is still calving duck decoys.

title: Medical School Cuts
description: Bathed by an everrising tide of Federal dollars granted for research, happy in their laboratories, lords to their small numbers of students and to their patients, the nation's medical educators were a happy lot in the years after World War IIcontent to leave the outside world to itself.

title: City Favors More Supervision For Marshals and Their Duties
description: Emphasizing better service for Small Claims Court claimants who have had difficulty in collecting on judgments, the city's Consumer Affairs and Investigation Departments have joined in proposing more stringent regulations for city marshals.

title: Glamour and Theatrics Fight Spiritual Genocide
Dogwood 500 Rained Out
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., March 31 (AP)  Heavy rain and wet grounds forced postponement of the $42,000 Dogwood 500 Classic, sc:leduled for tomorrow at Martinsville Speedway. The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing doubleheader250 laps for modifieds and 250 laps for late model sports cars  has been rescheduled for April 15.

title: Delaware &
description: ALBANY, March 31  The oldest established permanently still operating transportation system in the United States, the Delaware & Hudson Railroad, is celebrating its 150th birthday in April.

title: Union College, at 40, Is Still Growing
description: CRANFORD  Forty years after a modest start as a Depressionera W.P.A. project, Union College is completing a $4.5million expansion program that includes a new library and a humanities building with 17 classrooms.

title: The lonely voice of dissent
description: As Under Secretary of State during both the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, George W. Ball played a major role in shaping the nation's foreign policy. But with regard to Vietnam he often provided a lonely voice of dissent. David Halberstam, in his recently published book, The Best and the Brightest (Random House), deals at length with the role Ball played of arguing vigorously against the Government's policy while remaining in the Government. When he read the [Gen. Maxwell D.] Taylor cables calling for a small, oh so small, commitment, 8,000 men, he immediately told [Presidential adviser McGeorge] Bundy and [Secretary of Defense Robert S.] McNamara that if they went ahead with the Taylor proposals, the commitment would not stay small. They would have 300,000 men in there within five years. When Ball himself made exactly the same point to Kennedy, the President laughed and said,  George, you're crazier than hell, writes Halberstam. And Johnson would study a Ball antiescalation memo all night and then question him carefully, citing page and paragraph without looking at it: George, here on Page 18...

title: When It's Too Wet...
description: ATER, water everywhere. We certainly had it last year. Our normal precipitation is somewhere between 40 and 50 inches of rainfall a year. Almost this much rain fell by the end of July. August was dry. Then the rains came again. The year 1972 ended with a recordbreaking total of 67 inches of precipitation in New York City. This was almost 10 inches more than the previous record year.

title: Japanese Culture
description: The student, teacher or traveler who wants a reliable and uptodate guide to Japanese history is beginning to have. some choice. He can look to E. O. Reischauer's Japan: The Story of a Nation (1970), two thirds of which treats the modern century. He can turn to J. W. Hall's Japan: From Prehistory to Modern Times (1970), in which the proportions go the other way; or he can choose Mikiso Hane's recent Japan: A Historical Survey (1972), in which the division is roughly even.

title: Law Confining Cats To Owner's Home Sets Off Protests
description: ROSWELL, N.M., March 31 A new city ordinance requiring all cats to be confined to their owners premises has brought bitter protests from catlovers in this southeastern New Mexico community.

title: Minority Fellowship Plan Named for Black Journalist
description: The inauguration of the Michele Clark Fellowship Program for Minority Journalists was announced yesterday by the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

title: Marcos Honors War Foe
description: CALIRAYA, the Philippines, March 31 (UPI)President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the Philippines most decorated soldier in World War II, dedicated a Japanese war memorial this week. The memorial honoring Japanese soldiers killed in the Philippines in the war is 60 miles southeast of Manila.

title: Tax Credit for Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Representative Robert F. Drinan, Democrat of Massachusetts, has sponsored legislation to give individuals 65 years an dolder whose annual income is less than $6,500 a Federal income tax credit to offset state and local taxes on their homes.

title: State Urged To Make All Vehicle Bids Competitive
description: PATERSON  A Passaic County grand jury has urged the State Legislature to change the law to require competitive bidding on the purchase of motor vehicles by county freeholders.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Just as he was the most controversia sports figure in the United States during the Vietnam conflict, Muhammad Ali was the most debated athlete in the prisoner of war camps.

title: Toward a National Railway System
description: In the Penn Central's struggle to gain viability, the roadblocks that exist because it is a, railroad and not an industrial company are fairly well understood.

title: Down on the Farm
description: TOURISTS have a way of spoiling things. The first tourist is tolerated, and so is the second. Then come the horde. The prices rise. Next come the corrupt waiters, the grinning beach boys, the sleazy, imitated manners, the night spots, the obsequious tourist police, The old man can hardly bear to meet the visitor eye to eye....

title: Anne C. Maclin, David E. Cripps Plan Wedding
description: RINGOES, N.J., March 31 Mr. and Mrs. Luttrell Maclin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Clarissa Maclin, to David Ernest Cripps of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I. He is a son of Mrs. Willmond E. A. Cripps of Flint, Mich., and the late Mr. Cripps.

title: Triple Crown Entries
Canterbury Club Named Again as Golf Day Host
description: CLEVELAND, March 31 (AP)  Canterbury Golf Club in suburban Beachwood has been named host for National Golf Day for the second straight year.

title: SHANGHAI GIVING JAPANESE COURSE
description: SHANGHAI, March 31 (Reuters)The city of Shanghai, which pioneered Immensely successful radio courses in English throughout China a year ago, has started broadcasting language lessons in Japanese twice daily.

title: Television
description: WHEN it comes to images on television, the policeman's lot is hardly a sorry lot. The range is broad enough to include the good and the bad and the beautiful and the ugly. And the plots are generally constructed to contain a little consolation for all observers of the police scenethe critics and supporters at either extreme, and the uncommitted curious in the wide, wide middle.

title: The Man Behind Watch on the A.E.C.
description: ALLENDALE  Larry Bogart, a barrelchested, grayhaired man in his late 50's, is the president of a 12state coalition of antinuclear power plant organizations.

title: U.S. SEXTET WINS AND CLINCHES 2D
description: GRAZ, Austria, March 31 (AP)The United States hockey team broke out for five goals in the second period and went on to a 10.4 rout of Switzerland that clinched second place for the Americans on the final day of competition in the Group B world championship.

title: The Piano Saved Him
description: HE name of Robert Starer is encountered with some regularity in the music world. His choral, orchestral and chamber works are performed from time to time. He has written many dance scores, for people like Martha Graham, Anna Sokolow and Herbert Ross. Next Saturday and Sunday, his first fulllength opera, Pantagleize, based on the Michel de Ghelderode play, will be staged by the music department of Brooklyn College in its premiere. He teaches at the college and at the Juilliard School. But what of Starer himself?

title: Legacy of the War
description: This is probably the most capable and highly educated generation of veterans in history, with powerful latent motivation to contribute to the rebuilding of America, and their own society thinks of them as dregs and dropouts, dehumanized killers and drug addicts, or pitiful victims of a hated war to be avoided or shunned.

title: Jennifer Kayle Wed To Jeffrey L. Posner
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 31  Miss Jennifer Paula Kayle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton P. Kayle of New Rochelle, was married here this evening to Jeffrey Lee Posner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Posner of Scarsdale. Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman performed the ceremony at the White Plains Hotel.

title: Classical RockWhat Is It?
description: WHEN rock and roll started to grow up, people stopped calling it rock and roll. The need ror a new name was a subtle one at first, accepted tacitly without definition or discussion. Suddenly, the roll dropped out; the new forth was called rock, and rock it has been ever since.

title: CHEYENNE OPPOSE STRIP MINE DEALS;Indian Council Tells Federa Agency to Cancel Leases
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Indian leaders on the Northern Cheyenne Reservation in eastern Montana, have instructed the Bureau of Indian Affairs cancel billons or dollars worth of strip mining leases. granted in recent years to four the country's largest energy corporations.

title: Washington Will Pass Up I.R.A.'s Regatta in May
description: SEATTLE, March 31 (AP) The university of Washington crew will pass up the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta in Syracuse this year, but may go to the Henley in England.

title: 2 EXAIDES NAMED SADAT ASSISTANTS
description: CAIRO, March 31 (Reuters) The former Premier, Dr. Aziz Sidky, was appointed tonight as assistant to President Anwar elSadat, who took over the premiership on Monday. Sayed Marei, the former Secretary General of the Arab Socialist Union, the country's only political party, also was given the title of assistant.

title: Measles Toll in Upper Volta
description: OUGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, March 31 (AP)Almost 800 persons have died in a measles epidemic in Upper Volta since the beginning of the year, Foreign Minister Joseph Conombo said today. Mr. Conombo expressed regret that the United States had stopped sending antimeasles vaccine and antibiotics to Upper Volta at the very moment of the country's greatest need. There was no comment from the United States Embassy here.

title: HIRAI, PIANIST, PLAYS IN NEW YORK DEBUT
description: Takejiro Hirai, a Japanese pianist completing doctoral studies at the Juilliard School, made his New York debut at Tully. Hall on Thursday night. His program consisted of a Haydn Sonata in C, Schumann's Sonata in F sharp minor, Prokofiev's Sonata No. 4, and Chopin's Scherzo in E.

title: Porsche First in 2 Races In Nuerburgring Openers
description: NUERBURGRING, West Germany, March 31 (UPI)  The first day of competition of the Nuerburgring's 300kilometer races turned into a Porsche festival today in both the Inter serie and GT European championships.

title: Deserted Village Dusts Off Welcome Mat
description: ALLAIREStarting this weekend, and continuing through October, the Deserted Village in Allaire State Park will be open daily. The park, which attracted nearly 125,000 people last year, is one of the state's most unusual historic landmarks; among other things, it is the site of the oncefamous Howell Iron Works.

title: MILWAUKEE BUYS LAND FOR RESERVE
description: MILWAUKEE, March 31 Three years ago when the owners of Lumaside, Inc., decided to expand into manufacturing steel house siding, they shut down their sales office in suburban Shorewood and. built a factory in Milwaukee.

title: Smuggling in West Africa Disrupts Nations Trade Balances
description: LAGOS; Nigeria, March 31 Two men. dressed like ordinary fishermen were paddling canoe recently, through one of the many mangroveshrouded creeks outside this city when customs officials in a powerboat ordered them to stop for inspection.

title: Heading Off the Protest on Meat
description: Secreiary Agrictilture Earl L. Butz was asked on Tuesday why, there was talk in Government circles about possible controls on meat prices. That's because, he replied with a laugh, there are still some damned fools in. the Administration who don't agree with me.

title: Custom Service ls Key To Flatbush Decorator
description: In 1933, Ralph Cowen, master finisher and cabinetmaker, opened a small upholstery shop on Church Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, ending a 10year odyssey that took him from his native England to Montreal, Detroit and finally Brooklyn.

title: ARMS LABORATORY ROBBED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland March 31 Armed terrorist: held up security guards at Government ballistics testing laboratory near here today and stole an unspecified number of guns and 1,000 rounds of am. munition.

title: A Bit of Mexico Is Brought to L. I.
description: VALLEY STREAM, L.I.Outside, it was just another peudoColonial red brick building, but inside the Brooklyn Avenue elementary school was a miniature Mexico.

title: New Novel
description: By Russell H. Greenan. 246 pp. New York: Random House. $5.95.Outwardly unmarked by a wartime head injury, the title character of this novel spends his days quietly in a Beacon Street town house, selling off heirlooms and listening to inner voices. His hobby is creating intricate sculpture out of human bones  an inoffensive pastime that gives Algernon almost as much pleasure as talking to Eulalia, his favorite porcelain pitcher.... But isn't that a fresh grave in the adjoining cemetery? And where exactly is the corpse of greatgrandfather Pendleton, a 19thcentury Egyptologist who stashed away a fortune in funerary artifacts? hero's antiquarian pad in order to hunt for his greatgrandfather's remains. Grave matters, elegantly dispatched.

title: Wider Use of Machines Set in Bid to Increase Lottery Sales
description: TRENTONNew Jersey, a pioneer in the development of the legal lottery, is finding it increasingly difficult to exploit the public's appetite for gambling.

title: Gardens Twelve Crops I Couldn't Be Without
Lacroix Wins Scoring Title; Blazers Clinch Playoff Spot
Water Plan Iniperils Homes
description: RINGWOODEarlier this year; 20 families hiring along Route 511 in Ringwod and West Milford read in a newspaper that, in the not too distant future, their properties could be lying under millions of gallons of water.

title: Lacrosse Gains Popularity
description: MAPLEWOOD  Lacrosse, which is said to be North America's oldest sport, has taken some time to catch on among New Jersey high school athletes. But now that it apparently has, what promises to be One of the busiest seasons is about to get under way.

title: VERSAILLES LENDS GUTTER TO OPERA
description: PARIS, March 31The Paris Opera was launched into the Lieberman Era last night with a gala perrormance of Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro that was cheered by an audience including President and Mrs. Pompidou, in the 700seat Theatre Louis XV of the Versailles palace.

title: Harriet Roach Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony C. Locastro of Port Richmond, S. I., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Locastro's daughter, Miss Harriet N. Roach of New York, to Bernard E. Landry, also of New York. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Landry of St. Johnsbury, Vt. Miss Roach is the daughter also of the late Thomas P. Roach. The couple will be married April 28.

title: Maria De Ferrari to Be Married
description: The engagement of Miss Maria Laura De Ferrari, daughter of Mrs. Armando De Ferrari of Tacna, Peru, and the late Mr. De Ferrari, to John Sinnott 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sinnott Jr. of Rumson, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's mother.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT NIXON imposed a price ceiling on meat, effective immediately and for an indefinite period....A consumer boycott of meat planned for this week was expected to go ahead as scheduled.

title: Nicklaus Again Man to Beat in the Masters, Starting Thursday
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., March 31 (UPI) Jack Nicklaus has a date with golf immortality at this week's Masters tournament.

title: Railroads
description: WASHINGTON  There is healthy rail system trying to crawl out of the northeastern wreck, Secretary of Transportation Claude S. Brinegar said last week. All of us working together can help it escape.

title: RANGERS SUBDUED BY CANADIENS, 51
Judge Backs Female Guard
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, March 31 (UPI)  Federal District Judge William Hanson, dismissed yesterday a suit dialenging the right of Mrs. Joan Wyatt, of Burlington, to hold lob as the first and only female guard in a maximum security prison for men at Fort Madison. Iowa. Her position was challenged In a suit filed by eonald Brown, 31 years old, an inmate at the penitentiary, who charged that Mrs. Wyatt's presence inflames the passions of prisoners who are deprived of any female coinRun ionship.

title: If you want to understand our predicament
description: George Lichtheim has written books on many political subjects, and now in a fertile volume this learned skeptic offers wellripened themes from recent years in personal and dogmatic essay form. As a Berliner who has taken fond root in England, Lichtheim is fascinated by English political culture; its traditions glitter greatly in the eye of one who has had to abandon his own. On France and wider European themes including Russia he writes with feeling and familiarity, and his prose is always thick and full like a good country stew.

title: Lynda Jean Montoya Betrothed
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, and Mrs. Montoya of Washington and Santa Fe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynda Jean Montoya, to Luke John Haran Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haran of South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs EASTERN CONFERENCE Knicks vs. Baltimore
description: March 30Knicks 95, Balt. 83. April 1At Madison Square Garden, 2:05 P.M. April 4At Baltimore, 8:15 P.M. April 6At Baltimore, 8:15 P.M. April 8At Madison Square Garden. Time to be announced. April 11At Baltimore, 8:15 P.M. April 13At Madison Square Garden, 8. P.M.

title: Complaints Persist That Black Sailors Accused in Carrier Incidents Did Not Receive Equal justice
description: SAN DIEGO, March 27 Just after the racial disruption, aboard the Navy carriers Kitty Hawk and Constellation last fall, black sailors listed many complaints. Foremost among them was the charge that they did not get equal treatment under the Navy's system of jus. tide.

title: Federal Post Filled
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Stanley B. Thomas Jr., 30 years old, was appointed today as Acting Assistant Secretary for Human Development in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. In the newly created position, he will be responsible for a wide range of programs affecting the mentally retarded, youths, students, the elderly and Indians.

title: Cultural England in the eighteenth century
description: As far as most cultural historians and the general public are concerned, the 18th century in England was a dim version of the French Enlightenment. The stress on realism in the novel was the English equivalent of Encyclopedist clarity, rationality and interest in daily life. David Hume and Samuel Johnson could be considered the only worthy competitors to Voltaire, Diderot and Rousseau because they at least wrote inexpository prose.

title: Study Says Harassment, Not Wanderlust, Keeps Europe's Gypsies on the Move
description: LONDON, March 31 (Reuters) Europe's four million gypsies are confronted with neglect, misunderstanding, ingrained social prejudice and outright police harassment, according to a report published here this week.

title: Sooth About Lon Nol Bad Omen for Sayers
description: PHNOM PENH, March 31 (Reuters)Acting in anger, the Cambodian Government has rounded up and jailed 55 of the country's top astrologers, according to police sources.

title: Miss Gale Steves Is Married In Wilton to David B. Stocker
description: WILTON, Conn., March 31 Miss Gale C. Steves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Harry Steves of Ridgefield, was married here this afternoon to David B. Stocker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Crawford H. Stocker Jr. of Swampscott, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Z. F. Bednar performed the ceremony in the Wilton Congregational Church.

title: Central America
description: Museums from Texas to Cologne and suburban coffee tables are sprouting lovely vases, jades and sculpture from preColumbian America these days. It is all part of the boom in primitiveart collecting, and no museum or $100,000 mansion in Greenwich, Conn. is quite complete without a Maya figurine or an Olmec mask in a wall niche. What the buyers perhaps do not realizeor do not want to knowis that their demand has stimulated a heavy illicit traffic in antiquities, which, in turn, is irreparably damaging the fragile and precious record of Indian cultures that flourished centuries before the Spanish Conquest.

title: Suit Protests Construction Moratorium
description: BERKELEY TOWNSHIPOne of New Jersey's largest builders has filed suit attacking one of the newest weapons against developmentthe construction moratorium. The outcome could have statewide ramifications and almost instant repercussions.on the increasing number of localities trying to hold the line against expansion.

title: CAMBODIA REBELS SEVER A KEY ROAD
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 31 (Reuters)  Communistled rebel forces mounted armored attacks today on Cambodia's main southern highway and hammered the nearby provincial capital of Takeo with mortar fire as United States B52 bombers carried out more strikes near Phenom Penh.

title: STATE DRAFTS BILL TO REGULATE DOGS;Passage Seen in Doubt$10 License Fee Asked
description: ALBANY, March 31  A series of changes in the law that regulates all dogs in New York State, except those in New York City, has been drafted here, but faces and uncertain fate because of its controversial nature and the lateness of the legislative session.

title: FRENCH STUDENTS SET DRAFT ACTION
description: PARIS, March 31 nationwide strike by French highschool students is taking root, with a general Day Action set for Monday the support of France's powerful labor unions.

title: Johncock Is Assigned Pole For the Atlanta 500 Today
description: HAMPTON, Ga., March 3 (AP)  Bad weather at the Atlanta International Raceway today forced officials to assigr starting positions for tomor row's $111,225 Atlanta 500 mile stock car race.

title: The Inspector
description: Fifty years from nowor perhaps only 27  when some clearsighted critic, freed from the politics and confusions of the 1973 art world, gets around to writing the history of 20thcentury American art, he is going to pick out Saul Steinberg as the great artist.of the postWorld War II quartercentury and maybe, for all we know now, the whole latter halfcentury. Jackson Pollock, who would get the vote at the moment, will by then seem not an innovator but only logical historical step in a selflimited direction where the artist, doubly hamstrung by his respect for the past and his fear of being fettered by it, settles for a compromise between tradition and revolution.

title: Temple Marks 125 Years
description: SHORT HILLSCongregation B'nai Jeshurun is celebrating its 125th anniversary this year with a series of events ranging from a lecture by Philip Hoffman, national president of the American Jewish Committee, to a benefit concert by Benny Goodman and his sextet.

title: Keystone Pat Pays $3
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., March 31 Keystone Pat, driven by John Hayes Jr., was an easy winner of the $15,000 Redminster Pace at Freehold Raceway today. Keystone Pat led all the way in a 2:02 35 mile to win by three lengths and pay $3 to win.

title: AROUND THE
description: Spring is a tricky time for trees. If this one is comparable to last year's in rainfall, the fungustype tree diseases will be rampant since they spread in splashing rains. Spraying with a good generalpurpose fungicide such as maneb, zineb or ferbam will help to head them off. The materials should be applied just as the buds are breaking. A good signal is forsythia bloom.

title: PETITION SIGNING UNITES NEIGHBORS
description: Behind the cool facade of the city, where rule No. 1 is Mind Your Own Business, neighborliness is blooming all over the place. It budded March 12, eight days before the arrival of spring, and will be noticeable in the hallways and foyers of thousands of apartments and homes in the city until April 12, as men and women ring doorbells in search of signatures on designating petitions.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayDrag racing at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N. J. Gates open 8 A.M., eliminations start at 1 P.M.

title: White House Kitchen Is Being Modernized
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The family kitchen on the second floor of the White House is being modernized and airconditioned for the first time in 10 years.

title: RYUN, KEINO TAKE PRO TRACK EVENTS
Letters To the Editor
description: In his commentary on the Death of a Bookstore, Irving Howe expresses dismay at the disappearance of Columbia University's fine old bookshopwhich has been replaced by a new store sublet to Barnes & Noble.

title: 15 Republicans in House To Study Problem of Age
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) Representative Robert H. Steele, Republican of Conaecticut, has been named to lead a 15member Republican: House study group to formulate policies on aging.

title: A New St. Benedict's Prep Is Due
description: NEWARKOne year after its closing last June, St. Benedict's Preparatory School one of the state's bestknown private institutions, will reopen, but only the address will remain the same.

title: Alternate Transit Set Up
description: The strike against PATH, the Port Authority TransHudson commuter system, means that 45,000 New Jersey commuters and an additional 50,000 singletrip riders will be looking for alternatemeans of travel tomorrow morning.

title: On the Riviera
description: There's something very reassuring about watching a really professional writer at work again, especially veteran like Irwin Shaw, who knows his way around in many worlds literature, publishing, movies, theater, international society, velvetroped restaurants and Third Avenue saloons  and who can handle the details of a business deal, an ulcer operation and a bedroom scene with equal aplomb and economical nonexploitation.

title: CHARTER DECISION DUE IN PHILIPPINES;Lawyers Cite Justice Holmes and Also Pragmatism
description: MANILA, March 31After reams of memorandums liberally supported with citations from American jurisprudence, the long fight before the Philippine Supreme Court between the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos and its opposition is headed for close.

title: HORSE SHOW TITLE WON BY CASCADE
description: READINGTON, N. J. March 31Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Firestone's Cascade, who left his Southern Pines, N. C., training grounds just three weeks ago, won the junior working hunter championship today at the opening session of the twoday Four Seasons Farm indoor horse show.

title: A NEW DIPLOMACY FOR NEW ZEALAND
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 25New Zealand, conKIM that her principal cultural and trade links have been with distant Britain, has long behaved like an island in the North Sea instead of the Southwest Pacific, a senior ofliar of this country's small but rapidly growing diplomatic service said recently.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told a Congressional committee recently of a trip he made to Europe in early January, before the latest international currency turmoil began.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Feitl
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Feiti of Bergenfield, N. Z., on March 7 in Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N. J. The child, the couple's second son, is named Marc Bradford.

title: Second Craft Ready for Jupiter Shot
description: A second spacecraft designed to explore Jupiter, the twin one approaching a rendezvous with the giant planet this December, is scheduled to be launched next Thursday night from Cape Kennedy, Fla.

title: MILWAUKEE BUYS LAND FOR RESERVE
description: MILWAUKEE, March 31 Three years ago when the owners of Lumaside, Inc., decided to expand into manufacturing steel house siding, they shut down their sales office in suburban Shorewood and built a factory in Milwaukee.

title: Machine; By Lore Shoberg. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: McGrawHill Book Company. $3.95. (Ages 4 to 7)
description: The hero of Lore Shoberg's Machine might be Groucho Marx's nephew or Mr. Natural's only son. He wears a formal tuxedo jacket with rumpled tails, a bow tie, a peace button, hornrimmed glasses and frazzled hair. He has great style, but no name. Uncle Sal from TV land gives him a machine that starts out looking like a minirobot. After mimicking all manner of gadgets and gears, it ends up an Everymachine on a menacing power trip. The dimwitted adults (Mad Magazine rejects?) immediately decide to elect it king.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Thank Heaven for a late Easterso say apparel manufacturers who are having difficulty delivering a variety of goods to retailers for the spring season. Stores throughout the country are running out of merchandise and reordering for Easter.

title: Social Workers Charge Fiscal Waste in City Welfare Procedures and Ask Meeting to Discuss Changes
description: A group of social workers, echoing a recent state commission's findings of chaos in the delivery of city social services, has documented alleged instances in which unwieldy administrative procedures have caused fiscal waste and has asked to meet with welfare officials to discuss changes.

title: A Tour Honoring John Hanson, Our First President
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.Spring is here, bringing to the nation's capital cherry blossoms and joyous celebrations of the April 14 birthday of the first President of the United States, John Hanson.

title: Understanding the New Black Poetry
description: Stephen Henderson's provocative essay and Jean Wagner's matchless study should elicit hurricane of elation (to borrow Margaret Danner's phrase) from contemporary black poets. Their books are alarms, serving notice that not only have they entered the fray, but that they have also found the contest to be a satisfying and heuristic encounter. Both works will hopefully encourage further thorough studies of black and black

title: New Mexico Projects Set By Indian Health Service
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 31Plans for three new health centers to serve 20,000 Indians in northern New Mexico were announced this week by Harold Savage, chief of the program and planning division for the Indian Health Service here.

title: Not written to be writing poetry
description: The word poetry was so meaningless to the poet William Carlos Williams that he wouldn't use it, and enjoined others to drop it from their vocabulary. Nor would he have thought of his other vocation, the delivery and care of babies as practicing obstetrics. Abstractions alienate us from realities.

title: In the Schoolyard, Rucker Means More Than Fun
description: Just mention the name Rucker now and the picture that comes to mind are those free weekend basketball extravaganzas during the summer before overflow crowds in that schoolyard opposite the Polo Grounds houses on 155th Street and Eighth Avenue in Harlem.

title: Poll Says That Half Of Workers Believe They Could Do More
description: Fifty per cent of the nation's workers think that they could be more productive, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: DETENTE CREATES A BERLIN PROBLEM
description: BERLIN, March 31  The sudden wave of recognition for the Communist regime of Erich Honecker has confronted But Germany with the difficult task of finding suitable accommodation for the hundreds of foreign diplomats expected to flood the city this year.

title: Meredith Sings BalStrode In Peter Grimes at the Met
description: Morley Meredith added another strong opera characterization to his Metropolitan list Friday night, taking the important role of Captain Balstrode in the season's final Peter Grimes. Mr. Meredith's powerfully etched performance was all the more remarkable in that he had just been called upon in the afternoon to deputize for the indisposed Donald Gramm.

title: CONSUMERSHOLD RALLIES AT SHOPS ONEVE OF BOYCOTT
description: Protests and rallies by housewives and politicians blossomed in front of many supermarkets in the Metropolitan area and elsewhere yesterday on the eve of what consumer groups hope will be a weeklong nationwide meat boycott.

title: The Lessons of Vietnam
description: Now that the guns have fallen officiallyif not actuallysilent in Vietnam, there will be endless arguments as to whether we could not have made a better settlement or made it sooner. Since that debate will produce few useful insights, we would do better to focus on two other questions: how can we avoid making the same mistakes again and, if, by misjudgment or misadventure, we should get into another such mess, how can we extricate ourselves at minimum cost?

title: SMITH AND LAYER TO MEET IN FINAL
Budget Pleases L.I. Politicians
description: ALBANY  Two fiscal items politicians consider dear to the large middleclass heart of Long Islandmore school aid and a crimp in welfare aidwere major parts of the Legislature's anmial budget action this week.

title: Jane Ann Littell Wed
description: CHATHAM, N. J., March 31  Miss Jane Ann Littell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Patterson Littell, was married here this afternoon to Philip Walter Meyer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Meyer of Hooper, Neb. The Rev. Wesley A. Mafiery performed the ceremony in the Stanley Congregational Church, United Church of Christ.

title: PERSONABLE PARROT STEALS DANCE SHOW
description: A personable parrot stole the show at Friday night's opening of the new Choreographers Theater series at the American Theater Lab, 219 West 19th Street. Fourteen human performers and a vulture shared the billing in the same work, Songandance.

title: Soccer Title to Whites In So. African Games
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 31 (AP)An allwhite South African soccer team won the gold medal in the multiracial South African Games today by defeating an allblack team of countrymen, 31.

title: A Soviet Shift?
description: WE are, ft seems, about to witness another shift In the attitude of the Soviet Government toward the modernist art that flourished for a few years in the immediate aftermath of the Russian Revolution. Although no less melancholy than some of the earlier manifestitions of Soviet policy toward the Russian avant garde, this latest gyration in official attitudes does add something new in the way of historical

title: Widow and Daughter In a Double Ceremony
description: HIGGANUM, Conn., March 31Mrs. Alena V. Chromick, a widow, and her daughter, Alice, who work together five days a week in the kitchen at the Middlesex Convalescence Home in Middletown, were married here today in a joint ceremony in the Higganum United Methodist Church. Mrs. Chromick was married to Bernard E. Hartig and her daughter to Charles G. Prenderville of Middletown. The Rev. Norma A. Rust performed the ceremony.

title: Mrs. Elizabeth Higley Is Married to Sidney Homer
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, March 31  Mrs. Elizabeth Parrott Higley, widow of Dr. Charles S. Higley, an internist, was married here this afternoon to Sidney Homer of New York, a limited partner of the securities firm of Salomon Brothers.

title: Relay Events Are Highlight Of St. Francis Prep Track
description: Excellent early season performances highlighted the St. Francis Prep relays yesterday at St. John's track in Jamaica.

title: Food: A Taste of Istanbul in Leonia
description: LEONIA  Tliis Bergen County town is a long haul from both Greece and Turkey, but one would think, on browsing through the International Food Mart on Broad Avenue, that he was in either or both of those count tries.

title: Reeordings ChopinThe Ultimate Pianistic Testing Ground
description: No music reveals mo through its perform ante how much a ianist knows aboc his instrument than does Chopin's. An artist can create the structure of Beethoven sonata with the highest intelligence an awareness and have no sense of what a Chopin sonata All about. He may have in hi fingers the percussive color ation of a 20thcentury masterpiece and be unable to re produce the vocal colora tion in the melody of Chopin. nocturne. These an truisms that sprang to mind while listening to six recent albums devoted to solo piano works by the composer.

title: Judge Backs Female Guard
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, March 31 (UPI)  Federal District Judge William Hanson, dismissed yesterday a suit challenging the right of Mrs. Joan Wyatt, of Burlington, to hold a job as the first and only female guard in a maximum security prison for men at Fort Madison. Iowa. Her position was challenged in a suit filed by Ronald Brown, 31 years old, an inmate at the penitentiary, who charged that Mrs. Wyatt's presence inflames the passions of prisoners who are deprived of any female companionship."

title: Canoe Racing Bound To Hit Rock Bottom
THAILAND POLICY ON CHINA IS WARY
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 30Despite serious misgivings, Thailand is cautiously moving toward increased dealings with mainland China.

title: Packers Put In the Middle
White House Turns Against Husband, Mrs. Mitchell Says
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell, asserting that the Nixon Administration had turned completely against my husband, insisted late yesterday in a telephone call to Helen Thomas of United Press International that the former Attorney General had met James W. McCord Jr., the convicted Watergate conspirator, only once.

title: Headliners
description: Hollywood's annual Oscar night last Tuesday, brought out the usual low necklines and high hopes. Dyan Cannon won the decolletage sweepstakes and Cabaret, a musical evocation of decadent, preNazi Germany, collected eight Oscars. Among them: Liza Minnelli, best actress; Bob Fosse, best director, Joel Grey, best supporting actor. But the Mafia legend, The Godfather, was acclaimed 1972's best picture and its star, Marlon Brando, provided the evening's dramatics. Mr. Brando declined the best actor award voted him and sent a comely Apache maiden to explain why. She said Mr. Brando was protesting Hollywood's making a mockery of Indians and suggested he would join the protest at Wounded Knee, S. D.

title: Letters to the Editor
Speyers Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Jerry I. Speyer of New York on March 16 in the Harkness Pavilion. Mrs. Speyer is the former Miss Lynne Tishman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Tishman of New York. Mr. Tishman is president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Co., Inc., where the in fant's father is a senior vice president. The child, the couple's third, is named Holly Ann.

title: Pilot Recalls Bad Attitude Made Him Suffer in Hanoi
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., March 31To the North Vietnamese, Capt. James A. Mulligan Jr. had a bad attitude. As a result, he suffered heavily during his seven years in Hanoi prison.

title: Braves Will Use Gentry As OpeningDay Pitcher
PUZZLES
Margaret Mahler, Banker, to Be Bride
description: WILMINGTON, Del., March 31Mr. and Mrs. John A. Mahler have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret A. Mahler, to J. H. Tyler McConnell, president and chief executive officer of the Delaware Trust Company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Federal jobtraining programs should not try to square pegs into round holes, according to a Columbia professor who studied jobtraining programs for the Government. Training programs that try to turn easygoing, undisciplined persons into organized, motivated, timeconscious workers are bound to fail, Dr. Amitai Etziono said yesterday. It costs too much, hurts too much, and will not work, he said.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Mrs. Pollifax, meet Miss Seeton; Miss Seeton, meet Mrs. Pollifax. You have so much in common. You two nice old ladies should really have got together long before. Why don't you both sit here, on this nice comfy sofa, and tell each other how you dispose of dangerous spies with your bare hands, bring your own secretservice agenci6 to desperation, confound international crime and do what James Bond and the Eliminator rolled together would not think of trying? Nobody would ever believe it.

title: Angel Fire;By Joyce Carol Oates. 62 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $4.95.
description: Joyce Carol Oates's third volume of verse arrives on the scene when her achievements in fiction have brought her popular fame and critical praise. With her torrent of words, her absorption in feeling and her pitch of drama, why shouldn't she succeed as a poet too? Melville did; Hardy did; Lawrence did; Emily Bronte did; it is possible; it even, on the face of it, seems natural.

title: JOHN BRENNAN
description: John Brennan, a sales manaber with the Ocean Press division of United Press International, died Friday of cancer at the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at the Columbia University Club, 4 West 43d Street.

title: ExRep. Hays and Wife Are Robbed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Former Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat of Arkansas, and his wife were accosted within a block of their Capitol Hill home last night by two young men who took Mrs. Hays's pocketbook.

title: Music: New Encounters
description: Ordinarily, any contemporary composer chosen by Pierre Boulez for major attention in the New York Philharmonic's Prospective Encounter concerts at Loeb Student Center could count himself lucky. Milton Babbitt, however, may not be feeling so good about his inning. in the event held Friday night. The other composer whose music was performed was Gyorgy Ligeti, and, to be blunt, Ligeti won easily.

title: Miss Thomas Is Bride of John Jolly
description: In the chapel of St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Bernerdine H. Thomas was married to John R. Jolly. The rector, the Rev. John Andrew, performed the ceremony.

title: New and Recommended
description: THE DIGGER'S GAME, by George V. Higgins. (Knopf, $5.95.) A fast, gripping story about some pettyand on upcriminals with the focus on Digger Doherty, saloonkeeper and born loser who reached too far. GRAVITY'S RAINBOW, by Thomas Pynchon. (Viking, $15; paper, $4.95.) This apocalyptic comedy by the author of V. takes off V2 rockets, paranoia, the love of death and modern historyone the longest, most difficult, most ambitious American novels in years. SURFACING, by Margaret Atwood. (Simon & Schuster, $6.95.) Victimization and how to avoid it is one of the themes of this novel about the fifties that, draws comparison with Sylvia Plath's The Bell Jar.

title: PuzzlesOne That Pays Off, Two That Don't
description: MORE and more often our newer plays refuse to tell us where they are going until they get there. We are meant to be teased, puzzled,.questioning for two hours and upwards. Then, in a flash of blinding light at the finish, we are to, see how the pieces fit. Sometimes we do.

title: ADDICTAID HOUSE IN ELLOFF AREA
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 Curing drug addicts in the slums is like curing alcoholics in a bar, said John Maher, the selfdescribed exjunkie who runs the Delancey Street Foundation, a selfhelp residential program for former drug addicts, alcoholics and criminal offenders. The foundation is headquartered in Pacific Heights, an elegant neighborhood.

title: Martin Cools Off, Returns to Tigers
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 31 Billy Martin ended one day of selfexile at 7 o'clock this morning when he returned to the fold as manager of the Detroit Tigers as abruptly as he had left it yesterday.

title: Now the 10th man
description: For eight dreary decades they plodded along in nearobsCurity, mere oddments in the game of baseball's great geometric design. They were vulgar necessities, people rushed into the lineup to save situation somebody else had already fouled up. They were walking, talking, tobaccochomping, beerbloated anomalies, specialists in a sport that prides itself on the flawless versatility of its athletes.

title: White House Reaffirms That It Supports Gray
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 31 (AP)The Western White House reaffirmed today President Nixon's support for his nomination of L. Patrick Gray 3d as F.B.I. director, rejecting reports that the job had been offered to Henry E. Petersen, a Justice Department official. We support the Gray nomination, responded the deputy White House press secretary, Gerald L. Warren. He described as totally false any suggestions that Mr. Nixon had decided to abandon Mr. Gray.

title: N.Y.A.C. Matmen Capture 13th Straight Eastern Title
description: The host New York Athletic Club captured nine of the 10 final matches last night and easily secured its 13th consecutive Eastern Amateur Athletic Union wrestling title.

title: Florence W. Foster Plans Nuptials
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 31  Mrs. Wilder Foster of Darien and Howard Foster of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Wardwell Foster, to Raja Bhupal Arwade, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bhupal Anant Arwade of Sangli, India.

title: Iris Berger Betrothed
description: ATLANTA, March 31Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Berger have announced, the engagement of their daughter, Miss Iris Berger, to Jerome Ira Silver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Silver of Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Philippines
description: Heavy fighting between Moslem rebels and Government troops on Mindanao and other southern Philippine islands broke out late in February and since then the rebels have by all reports more than held their own. But last week one Philippine army commander on the scene suggested new tactics were in order. I have secret weapon, said the officer, Mosquitoes. There is lots of malaria down there, so we have stopped spraying. Sooner or later the rebels will be too weak to fight.

title: Miss Evert Crushes Soviet Foe, 62, 61
description: If Gene Shue needed any basic pointers on how to beat the New York Knicks, he could have got them last night from Chris Evert at the $30,000 Lady Gotham tennis tournament.

title: Bowne Park Gets City Boost
description: Frederic Bowne can tract his family tree back over more than 300 years of New Yorkand Americanhis tory. It is heritage that he carries with pride, and Iasi week, after the city announced that it would spend 8430,000 to rePair a Part oasis once donatelby his ancestors in Flushing, Queens, his face took on a special glow.

title: Midwood High School Wins Flatbush Relay Carnival
description: Wingate High School won three events yesterday in the Flatbush relay carnival at the South Shore Field in Brooklyn.

title: Stewart Mills Reid Will Marry Vivien Green, Wellesley Student
description: Miss Vivien Green, a student at Wellesley College, and Stewart Mills Reid, who attends the Columbia Law School, plan to marry in June.

title: Advice for a Gubernatorial Candidate
description: HILLSDALE  A woman who has sat in the Gover nor's chair believes that Ann Klein would have no particular problems because, of her sex if she succeeded in her:quest to become the next Democrat to. hold the state's highest office:

title: CHURCHES EXPAND FOR HOMOSEXUALS
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31A rapidly expanding denomination of homosexual churches founded here four and a half years ago has helped to establish the first gay synagogue and plans to apply next year for membership in the National Council of Churches.

title: GODMAN IS VICTOR IN AKRON BOWLING
description: AKRON, Ohio, March 31 (AP) Jim Godman of Lorain, Ohio, won professional bowling's $125,000 Tournament of Champions today and earned $25,000.

title: Letters: Overbooking Reaction
description: A Jorge number of letters were received in response to the airline overbooking article by Al Marlens, editor of the Travel Section (A HowNotTo Story: Flying, on One Bounce, to St. Thomas), which appeared March 11. Except for three of the lettersincluding one by a travel agent and another by a Pan American pilot who said he used to be a newspaperman himself but asked that his name not be usedthe reaction was one of unqualified condemnation of overbooking. Many of the letter writers were moved to recount in detail their own problems with airlines other than Pan Am, the one mentioned in the article, and with hotels, travel agencies, car rental agencies and the Civil Aeronautics Board. Some made suggestions, or commented on those in the article, to remedy the overbooking situation. Since in their intent most of the letters were similar, only brief excerpts from representative ones are printed below. The article was in the form of an open letter to William T. Seawell, the president of Pan American World Airways, and several readers inquired about his response. A reply was solicited, but the airline said it preferred

title: Mrs. Marshall Is Wed to Douglas Lamb
description: SIMSBURY, Conn., March 31  Mrs. Emily Janeway Marshall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lawrence Marshall Jr. of Carlisle, Mass., was married here this afternoon to Douglas Leason Lamb of Boston, son of Mrs. Julia Lamb of Marblehead, Mass., and the late Francis Lamb.

title: Prices Nixon Tightens The Reins
description: Iikely to develop? And are not shortages likely to bring back scenes reminiscent of World War II when millions of Americans paid blackmarket prices for underthecounter meat?

title: Notes:
The Muggers of Old England, a Hippie Parson and Other Oddities
description: BUDE, EnglandThe average guidebook dealing with Cornwall and Devonshire probably mentions King Arthur's alleged castle at Tintagel, old fishing ports like St. Ives, the cathedral at Exeter, and, of course, Land's End, the very tip of England. It would be safe to wager a pint of Cornish cider or a Devon cream tea that it does not say anything about the cutthroats, freaks and eccentrics who are, at least to those with a taste for the macabre and offbeat, as much a part of the heritage of this corner of England's West Country as historic sites and monuments.

title: This Way to ANIGOP And the Mink Eyelashes
description: AST week, in a mood of gentle melancholy, I went up to the Metropolitan Museum to see whether or not it was yet possible to look at the Euphoontos vase as a work of art rather than, as Thomas Hoving puts it, a hot pot, a designation in line with the generally ddclassd image the museum has taken on under his direction. Spending an afternoon at the Metropolitan these days is like visiting an old mistress whose behavior has alienated your affections but whose charms you are unable to forget. Caught flogrante delicto with one shady character after another all the way across Europe, not to mention her conduct on 57th Street, she shows no convincing signs of repentance. You know perfectly well that she is only biding her time until your attention wanders, and that as soon as it does, she will be up to her old tricks

title: GEORGE B. CORTELYOU
description: RUMSON, N. J., March 31 George Bruce Cortelyou, a retired executive of the New York Life Insurance Company and a l'ormer'president of Distributors Group, Inc., died today at his estate here. He was 84 years old.

title: Reagan Intensifies Drive for Mansion For Next Governor
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 31 (AP)Gov. Ronald Reagan is still pressing for the construction of a mansion for California Governors, a decadesold I dispute in this state.

title: PROFESSORS FACE BELGRADE DRIVE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia March 3I A mood of political showdown is mounting at Belgrade University as Communist authorities intensify pressures against professors accused of opposing the of Communists drive orthodoxy and discipline.

title: Device. Will Test Bicycles for Safety
description: TEANECKWith the arrival of spring, more and more bicyclistsadults and youngsters alikeare thronging the roadways. And this year, thanks to a new testing program, many more of the cycles on the road hopefully will be in the safest working condition possible.

title: Drop in Mortgages On L.I. Is Feared
description: An economist warned last week that if shortterm interest rates continued to rise over the next few months there would probably be fewer home mortgages available on Long Island.

title: Deborah Bunn To Be a Bride
description: SPRINGFIELD, III., March 31  Mr. and Mrs. George Regan Bunn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Heidrich Bunn, to William Rene Swecker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Zwecker of Oak Park and Bethany, W. Va. The wedding is planned for late summer.

title: Fort Schuyler Takes Regatta
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., March 31The New York State Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, scored its first victory of the season today on the Orchard Beach Lagoon. The Privateers were forced to rally from last place in the final 500 meters as Manhattan and Iona led most of the way on the cairn and foggy course.

title: Population Shifts Upsetting the Planning and Use of Suburban Schools Here
description: Dozens of school districts throughout the suburban areas of New York City faced with shifts in student population unforeseen as recently as two to five years ago, are being confronted with prospects of either drastic shortages of surpluses of educational facilities.

title: Gimbel Executive Is Named To High Post at Dropsie U.
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31David Arons, a business executive, will assume the post of executive vice president of Dropsie University here, Dr. Abraham I. Katsh, president of the institution, announced today.

title: Dance
description: IT was an interesting week for dance. We had in town the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, Henryk Tomaszewski's Polish Mime Ballet Theater and, first and foremost, the City Center Joffrey Ballet giving the American premiere of Diaghilev's 1918 collaboration, Parade. The latter was the most important event but it can wait until next week. This time I am going to talk about Cunningham and the Poles.

title: Remember Tommy Tucker?
description: WEST LONG BRANCHTommy Tucker doesn't want to set the world on fire, he just wants to enjoy the calm and casual life on the campus of Monmouth College. The former, orchestra leader has been a music teacher here for more than a decade.

title: Long Island
description: BETHPAGE, L.I.It was a bust and boom week, in that order, for Long Island's ailing body economicand more specifically, for the aerospace industry that is its backbone.

title: SCHOOLAIDLOSS.FEARED BY STATE
description: An examination of the Nixon Administration's bill for education revenue sharing has convinced state officials that if the bill became law, New York would lose $36million in Federal school aid in its first full year of operation.

title: CHURCH PREPARES FOR THE 2D COMING
description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31Believing that the Second Coming of Jesus Christ may well be in this generation, members of the First Assembly of God here have changed the church's bylaws to provide continued leadership if its officers are suddenly taken to heaven.

title: INDIANS SEEKING TO BUILD MOTEL
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 31A group of Indians from the northeastern tip of Minnesota wants to build a $5million motel cornplex on the shores of Lake Superior.

title: Resorts Eye Rain Insurance
description: ASBURY PARK Communities along the 120mile strand from Sandy Hook to Wildwood are looking into the possibility of taking out rain insurance to protect their vital bathing fees.

title: PREMIER IN TAIPEI RUNNING REGIME
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 31President Chiang Kaishek has not taken an active role in Government afffairs since his hospitalization about eight months ago. Undisputed control of the Government now rests with the President's elder son, Premier Chiang Chingkuo.

title: Ecuadorian Pottery on View
description: MONTCLAMAn unusual collection of ancient Ecuadorian pottery is on display it the Montclair State College library.

title: Housing Bias Law Yields Conviction
description: The State Division of Human Rights and the Westchester County District Attorney have Avon what they said was the first prosecution under a state law barring racial discrimination in apartment rentals.

title: Mets Get Rangers McNulty As Final Sudakis Payment
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 31 (UPI)The Texas Rangers completed two trades made earlier this month today by sending a third baseman Bill McNulty to the New York Mets and sending a pitcher, Mike Thompson, to the St. Louis Cardinals Tulsa farm club. McNulty was the final payment for Bill Sudakis. Thompson was the last payoff for the acquisition of a relief pitcher Charlie Hudson.

title: Symphony Hall Seeks to Charm Young
description: NEWARK  The roof, the stage and the Children's Program at Symphony Hall will all benefit when the internationally known Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performs there Wednesday evening.

title: City Housing official Irked by Hogan's Refusal to Prosecute RentFraud Case,
description: A top city housing official said last week that he was terribly disappointed that the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan had decided not to prosecute two major realestate concerns accused by the city of falsely certifying that they were entitled to rent increases.

title: The World
description: SAIGONIt came to an end in a welter of contradictory emotions, acts and gestures thatin a manner so characteristic of the whole Vietnam experienceleft nothing clearly defined.

title: PoliceBeat Class For Law Students
description: NEWARKA group law students here has covered that it takes than books and precedents established in other cases make a practicing attorney.

title: Tony Jenkins to Captain 7374 Harvard Quintet
description: Tony Jenkins, a junior forward from Detroit, has been elected captain of the 197374 Harvard varsity basketball team. Jenkins was Harvard's leading scorer this past season with a 16.9 scoring average. He was named to the second allIvy League and allNew England teams. He was also voted Harvard's most valuable player by his teammates.

title: Garrido Wins Madrid Golf
description: MADRID, March 31 (AP)German Garrido of Spain won the sixth Madrid international open golf tournament today with a finalround 73 that gave him a 287 total for the fourday tournament. Emilio Perera of Spain was second with 288.

title: Turf Honor for Galbreath
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)  John W. Galbreath, master of the Darby Dan Farm and owner of the Pittsburgh Pirates, was named winner of the National Turf Writers Association's Joe Palmer Award today for meritorious service to racing. Galbreath will receive his award at the N.T.R.A. annual dinner at Louisville, Ky., on May 2 during Kentucky Derby week.

title: Cardinals Trim to 25 Limit As Nagy Goes to Rangers
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 (UPI)The St. Louis Cardinals reduced their roster to the 25player maximum today by trading a pitcher, Mike Nagy, to the Texas Rangers for Mike Thompson, a pitcher who was sent to the Cardinals Tulsa farm club of the American Association.

title: Kathy Wolff Affianced
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 31  Dr: Jerome L. Wolff, a dentist, and Mrs. Wolff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathy Sue Wolff, to David Berkowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Berkowitz of Lake Hiawatha, N. J.

title: ALGERIANS AND U.S. APPROVE GAS PLANT
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (Reuters)  Officials of the United States and Algeria gave final approval today to the construction of the world's largest facility for the production of liquefied natural gas, at Arzew, Algeria, a Mediterranean port.

title: 5,924 Postal Workers Added Since February
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The United States Postal Service, which has been subjected to public and Congressional criticism about poor service, added nearly 6,000 employes across the nation since February, a spokesman reports.

title: Thousands Here Honor Vietnam Veterans
description: Bands thundered, bagpipes skirled, forests of American flags Waved wildly, and large sidewalk crowds roared their approval yesterday as tens of thousands of marchers paraded up Broadway in an outpouring of tribute to the men who served the nation in Southeast Asia during the war in Vietnam.

title: Sonnabend Dance Series
description: There was one occasion when Trisha Brown strapped a group of dancers to harnesses, suspended them on walls and sent them dodging one another 10 feet in the air. Such movement fascinates her. Currently at the Sonnabend Gallery, she is using props and rules to create a series of provocatively repetitive dances.

title: MRS. F. C. LAUBACH
description: SYRACUSE, March 30Mrs. Effa E. Laubach, the widow, of Dr. Frank C. Laubach, a literacy expert, died Thursday evenine at the age of 90.

title: Auto Show Will Open on April 7
description: Some of the most exotic and expensive automobiles the world, both past and present, will be on display the 17th International Automobile Show, which will run from April 7 through 15 at the New York Coliseum.

title: Karen Kaufmann Bride of P. L. Richards
description: ITHACA, N. Y., March 31 Miss Karen Eileen Kaufmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Kaufmann of Spring Valley, was married here today to Preston Lee Richards, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ashby Turner Richards of Alexandria, Va.

title: The Fruits of War by Peace
description: HONG KONGThe policy of Japan, perhaps unprecedented in history, is to gain the fruits of war without recourse to war or, put another way, to achieve by peace all to which mistaken militarism aspired before the 1945 defeat. And, because Japan is a sagacious, remarkably disciplined and homogeneous nation, this peaceful policy is well along the road to success.

title: The stingy cook's guide
description: Every kitchen, every once in a while, finds itself with either too many egg whites or too many yolks. Here are two recipes to use up the surplus. The chocolate chinchilla, a quaint cinnamon flavored pudding souffl, will take care of the whites. And the zabaglione will use up extra yolks.

title: ExBritish Prisoners Visit Bridge on the Kwai
description: KANCHANABURL, Thailand, March 31 (AP)Some of the British prisoners of war who helped build the bridge on the River Kwai for their Japanese captors during World War II returned to the bridge this week as tourists.

title: The Tibetan Terriers Scale a New Horizon
description: Two new breeds, the softcoated wheaten terrier and the Tibetan terrier, are being added to the American Kennel Club studbook. Starting May 1, their registrations will be accepted. On Oct. 3, the newcomers are eligible to compete for breed, group and bestinshow awards.

title: Columba Knows the Butler Didn't Do It
description: THE popularity of Columbo is as intense as it is puzzling. Dinner parties are adjourned, trips to movies postponed, and telephone calls hastily concluded (It's starting now, I gotta go. Migod, it's 8:40, what did I miss?), an for a detective show that tells us whodunit, howhedunit, and whyhedunit all before the first commercial.

title: Wizard Crystal; By Manus Pinkwater. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $3.95. (Ages 4 to 7)
description: In this bog, ah, book, there's a wizard  unhappy for 307 years; some happy frogs caring for a magic crystal at the bottom of their pond. Wizard takes crystal. Now unhappy frogs follow now happy wizard, surround house and sing gunk, gunk, gagunk which, in frog talk means think hard... what to do. Crystal works its magic, and frogs end singing same song, different words apparently gunk,. gunk, gagunk now meaning this pond... warm sun. And the whole thing sinks slowly into the illogical swamp.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: PATH Talks Fail; Strike Under Way
description: The carmen's union struck the PATH train service early this morning after Federal mediators failed to resolve the contract dispute between the union and the Port Authority, which operites the service between Manhattan. and New Jersey.

title: Two Types of Drugs Are Found to Prevent Viruses From Transforming Normal Cells Into Cancerous Ones
description: NOGALES, Ariz., March 31A California pharmacologist and his colleagues have found two classes of drugs that can lock the transformation of normal cells into cancer cells even after the cells have been infected by cancercausing Viruses.

title: Prince Astro Wins by Head At Oaklawn, Pays $23.40
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 31 (AP)Prince Astro overtook Barbizon Streak entering the stretch and held off Herbalist's late charge to capture today's 20th running of the Oaklawn Park Handicap by a head.

title: Mild Winter May Help Trout Anglers Today
description: The trout season in New York State opens today with greatly improved stream conditions.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: A17DAY photographic trip to Brazil will be led by Alfred Eisenstaedt, starting on May 26. Described as a traveling seminar on travel photography techniques, the group will fly from Kennedy Airport via yang Brazilian Airlines and will visit Rio de Janeiro, Brasilia, Salvador and a town called Ouro Preto. Designed. for people who are serious about photography, the trip will also tinclude sightseeing trips and will give participants an opportunity to meet the people of Brazil, as well as relaxing and having fun. The package price for the trip will be $916. per person for single occupancy, and $799 per person for twin. This includes air fare, hotel accommodations, breakfast each day, five lunches and one dinner. For details and reservations write to Mr. Alfred Eisenstaedt c/o *Varig Brazilian Airlines, 485 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.

title: Up to the President
description: The prolonged campaign of espionage and sabotage directed against the Democratic party on behalf of the Nixon Administration reached a sorry climax last June in the Watergate burglary. The truth about these shadowy activities is now becoming available but it is still difficult for the public to sort out fact from rumor.

title: Sebring, Under IMSA, Is Off to Smooth Start
description: The chief steward drove a Volkswagen rather than a Mercedes, there was no hierarchy of blazered snobs harassing participants, the rentacops were well behaved, there were no hassles in the pits, no feeling of pervasive crisis or chaos, and although English was the only language spoken, it was a fine 12hour race. In sum, the Se bring of 1973 was a pleasant experience all around and everyone made a bunch of money. This is the substance of the appraisal of two experienced professionals in motor racing, Brad Niemcek and Chris Economaki.

title: Thieu Seen Off by 50,000 On U.S.T rip to Visit Nixon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31President Nguyen Van Thieu left today for the United States to seek assurances of continued American military and economic aid from President Nixon.

title: ASBURY PARK WALK TO BE STAGED TODAY
description: The eighth annual Capt. Ronald Zinn Memorial 10mile walking race will be held today on the Asbury Park (N. J.) boardwalk.

title: E. 49TH ST, BLOCK FIGHTS EVICTION
description: The forsythia is blooming on the roofs of Nos. 142 and 146 and the garden at No..150 is beginning to sprout buds, but the tenants, in those buildings on East 49th Street are afraid that next spring their efforts will be buried under tons of debris.

title: ARREST IN BRONX A RELIEF TO AREA
description: Residents in the Norwood section of the Bronx were calling it a nice quiet section yesterday and shaking their heads in relief following the capture Friday afternoon of a man suspected of killing an elderly woman and mugging three other women in the neighborhood.

title: Katherine Albert Wed to Reporter
description: RYE, N. Y., March 31Miss Katherine Marie Albert was married here this morning to R. Paul Westpheling 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Westpheling Jr. of Fulton, Ky. The Rev. Robert Poveromo performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: A Show in Trenton Surveys State's Art
description: TRENTONArt From New Jersey, the State Museum's eighth annual survey, went on view in the museum yesterday. The exhibition will continue until June 3.

title: Miss Stiebel Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Christian G. Stiebel of La Varenne, France, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss JeanneMarie Stiebel, to Joel Dean Jr., son of Dr. Dean, of HastingsonHudson, N. Y., emeritus professor of business economics at Columbia University, and president of Joel Dean Associates, Inc., and the late Mrs. Dean. The prospective bridegroom's marriage ended in divorce.

title: Blacks Match Whites On College Enrollment
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The Government said this week that in 1972, for the first time, the percentage of black and other minority race high school graduates who enrolled in college was roughly the same as for white graduates.

title: Brazil's Military Seizes Wife of American Official
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 31The Brazilian wife of United States official has been imprisoned on charges of subversive activities, the military authorities said here today.

title: Harbour Village Sponsors File. $2Million Claim
description: A $2.5million damage suit has been filed against the city by the sponsors of Harbour Village, the proposed MitchellLama housing development hi Brooklyn that the Board of Estimate killed last September.

title: Even When They've Lived Together, Honeymoon Still Matters
description: In a time when a growing number of young people live together before marriage, the honeymoon might seem irrelevant. But it isn't, according to those who take it those who sell it and those who study it.

title: After two years, OTB's in the money; Howie! What's good today?
description: It is late on a dank afternoon on the eastern edge of Chinatown. The bottlegreen compact sedan pulls up in front of 18 Bowery, a building of ancient painted brick, and Howie gets out.
