title: Football Transactions AMERICAN CONFERENCE
description: BALTIMORESigned Dave Taylor, guard and No. 5 draft choice from Catawba (N.C.) College; Guy Falkenhagen, tackle and No. 17 draft choice from Northern Michigan; Dick Murphy, Amherst quarterback and Brian Newlands, Southern Illinois linebacker, free agents

title: Towboat Rams a Pier
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., April 1 (AP)One man was killed today and one missing after the towboat Lady Ree struck a pier of an old bridge over the Mississippi River here. The police said that four men were injured and at least six others pulled from the river unharmed.

title: Smith Captures $10,000 Prize, Topping Laver, 64, 36, 64
description: ST. LOUIS, April 1 (UPI)Stan Smith broke service at love against topseeded Rod Laver today in the final game of the championship match to win, 6.4, 36, 64, and take the $10,000 top prize of the, Holton tennis tourney.

title: MRS. MARTIN HIRSCH
description: Mrs. Loretta Jacobs Hirsch, sister of the late boxing promoter Mike Jacobs and widow of Martin Hirsch, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital in Redbank, N.J. She was 81 years old and lived at 67 Ridge Road in Rumson, N. J.

title: Some Sales Reported Off Drive to Last a Week
description: Leaders of the diverse consumer groups making up the meat boycott movement said yesterday that their projected weeklong effort to drive down prices had gotten off to a good start.

title: Bridge:
Ellsberg Principals Prepare for Windup
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1In recent days, there has been a feeling in the courtroom that the Pentagon papers trial is perhaps nearing an end. This may not be true, but nonetheless the feeling is there.

title: Study Finds 30,000 Get Flight Pay Without Flying
description: WASHINGTON April 1 (UPI)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, released today the results of a study by the General Accounting Office that found that nearly 30,000 military officers were receiving flight pay though they held nonflying jobs.

title: Consumer Advocates, in Private, Cite Failures and Frustrations
description: NEWARK, April 1When consumer advocates take off their public faces and relax informally with one another, they voice the discouragement and the frustration, the fears and the difficulties of their work that the public is seldom privy to.

title: Lisa Max Is a Bride
description: SALEM, N. Y., April 1Miss Miss Lisa Max and John Alexander Macdonald Jr., son of Mr and Mrs. John Macdonald of Wellesley, Mass., were married here today in Rexleigh Mill, a historical building. The Rev. Fergus Cochran, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of Samuel W. Max and Mrs. Abraham L. Bauman, both of New York, is a potter and her husband, a sculptor.

title: SPAIN OVERHAULS COTTON INDUSTRY
description: BARCELONA, March 23 The Spanish cotton industry, a mainstay of this region for more than a century, has just completed a major restructuring in what has been one of the most antiquated sectors of Spain's economy.

title: NEWARK MUSEUM MAY LOSE MOSAIC
description: The Newark Museum is pondering the surrender of a fourthcentury Roman mosaic that, it has been told, was stolen from an archeologicl site in Syria. It was sold to the museum two years ago by an unidentified New York dealer.

title: 7 Die as Blast Razes Cincinnati Building
description: CINCINNATI, April 1 (UPI)An explosion killed at east seven persons, injured 25 others and demolished a threestory building housing a tavern and apartments here last night.

title: U. S. Sets Diet Drug Recall In Drive on Amphetamines
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs and the Food and Drug Administration have decided to recall diet drugs that contain amphetamines, with the objective of eliminating them from the market by June 30.

title: Opera: Devlin's 4 Villains
description: With Norman Treigle absent from the New York City Opera's roster this season, other basses have been stepping into his shoes, and sometimes rattling around a bit. Taking over a role associated with another singer always presents a problem for later artists, however, and, under the circumstances Michael Devlin's success in assuming the four villainous parts in Les Contes d'Hoffmann" cannot be seriously questioned.

title: JEWS ASK MEMORIAL ON WARSAW UPRISING
description: Survivors of the Warsaw ghetto uprising that occurred 30 years ago this month proposed yesterday that one day in April be set aside each year as International Holocaust Day.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: PHILADELPHIASent Darrell Brandon, Mike Fremuth, Mike Wallace, pitchers; Craig Robinson, infielder; Ron Stone, Mike Rogodzinskl, outfielders; Pete Koegel, Jim Essian, catchers; to minor league camp for reassignment.

title: Borden Plans Acquisition
description: The Borden Corporation and Alex Colman, Inc., a Los Angelesbased women's sportswear and dress company, announced over the weekend an agreement had been signed, following approval by directors of both companies, for the acquisition by Borden of Alex Col, man, Inc. through an exchange of stock valued. at $14.8million.

title: U.S. to Revise Oil Imports
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)The Interior Department announced today that it was revising its oilimport regulations to carry out the President's recent proclamation making additional oil available to hardship cases.

title: Wings Tie Rangers, 33, In RegularSeason Finale
A Common Bible, Out Today, Is for 3 Parts of Christendom
description: A new edition of the Bible, the first to be approved for use by Roman Catholics, Protestants and Eastern Orthodox, will be published in this country today.

title: Urban Adminicide
description: A word was used at a recent public hearing in New York City to describe the impact of Federal spending cutbacks in antipoverty programs. The word was adminicide. It was used in reference to the killing of some programs by administrative fiat without concurrence of the Congress. While there have been numerous announcements of freezes, curtailments and cutbacks throughout the Federal budget, hearings in this city and elsewhere have revealed a special relationship among them all.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson yesterday defended the continuing United States bombing of Cambodia as necessary to keep alive the antiCommunist Government of President Lon Nol and to press Communist forces into accepting a ceasefire, as they have in Vietnam and Laos. Mr. Richardson, who spoke on the Meet the Press television program, said that it would be very difficult for the Cambodian Goyernment to survive without United States air support because of a massive threat by wellarmed, wellorganized guerrilla forces, which include forces from North Vietnam itself. [Page 1, Column 8.]President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam arrived in Los Angeles for two days of meetings with President Nixon at his home in San. Clemente, 60 miles south of Los Angeles. Mr. Thieu's visit, his first since he became President in 1967, is intended mainly to enhance his stature at home, but also to change the minds of at least some American critics who regard him as a petty dictator. [3:4.8.]Capt. Robert T. White of the Army, the last United States war prisoner in Indochina, arrived at Clark Air Base in the Philippines after a release that until the last minute he feared might be a trick. Captain White, 32 years old and from Newport News, Va., was flown from Saigon after his release in a Mekong Delta village. Meanwhile, the last group of American war prisoners arrived at Travis Air Force Base in California, ending Operation Homecoming, which brought back 587 men freed from Communist prison camps. [2:46.]Under James R. Schlesinger, its new director, the Central Intelligence Agency is apparently planning to curtail some of its old activities, notably clandestine military operations, and undertake new ones, including action against political terrorism and the international drug traffic. [1:67.]NationalSenator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut and a member of the Senate committee investigating the. Watergate bugging case, said that James W. McCord Jr., one of the men involved in the bugging, ordered that the Capitol offices of certain Senators and Representatives be kept under visual surveillance. [1:67.]

title: 100% Phone Rise Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The dime for the public pay telephone call should be raised to 20 cents, John D. deButts, chairman of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, said in an interview in U. S. News & World Report.

title: School Boycott Ending in Canarsie
description: White parents in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn voted almost unanimously yesterday to end their monthlong boycott of district schools and accept a Board of Education plan that would zone out of the district black Brownsville students.

title: METROPOLITAN RUGBY
description: Columbia Business 13, New York Club 8.

title: Bacallao Conquers Holmes To Win U.S. Squash Tennis
description: Pedro Bacallao of the Princeton Club won the United States squash tennis championship for the fifth straight year defeating Joe Holmes, 1514, 159, 159, lat the Yale Club yesterday.

title: Stage: lonesco's Latest
Louisiana Offers Audubon. Society 2,006 Alligators
description: The National Audubon Society, which last January criticized Louisiana for reopening an alligatorhunting season, has received an unexpected answer an offer of 2,000 free alligators.

title: Garelik, Short of Money, May Quit Mayoral Race
description: I just can't raise the kind of money to do the job, City Council President Sanford D. Garelik said yesterday, suggesting that he was about to abandon his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

title: Crown Heights Renewal Is Dealt Blow
description: One of the city's most ambitious efforts to revitalize deteriorating neighborhoods has been dealt a stunning blow with the denial of an expected Federal grant to begin a prototype project in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: LEGAL AID DRIVE OPENS AT PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Poverty lawyers and supporters of the Legal Services Program, hoping to halt its gradual elimination, found little encouragement here in a twoday conference this weekend.

title: Robber Cycles Away
description: HOUMA, La., April 1 (UPI)A teenage youth reached over a counter, grabbed a bag containing $3,600 and pedaled furiously away from the South Central Bell Telephone business office on a green bicycle yesterday, the police found the getaway bike abandoned in a yard several blocks away, but did not find the culprit or the money.

title: Mrs. Carlson, Melvin Nambn Wed in Jersey
description: CLIFTON, N. J., April 1Mrs. June M. Carlson and Melvin J. Narnori were married )sere this morning by Rabbi Edwin Soslow in his study at Temple Beth Sholom.

title: Morocco, With Texas Aid, Sets Up Innovative Ranch
description: RABAT, Morocco  In the foothills of the Atlas Mountains, the King Ranch of Texas and the Moroccan Government have established the largest and most innovative cattle ranch in North Africa.

title: Some Sales Reported Off Drive to Last a Week
description: Leaders of the diverse consumer groups making up the meat boycott movement said yesterday that their projected weeklong effort to drive down prices had gotten off to a good start.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: JACKSONVILLE (SeaLand), San Juan April 6; sails from Elizabeth, N.J.

title: AliFrazier Match Goes Way of Devalued Dollar
description: SAN DIEGO, April 1 (UPI) First Joe Frazier, now Muhammad Ali. Boxing's two glittering heavyweight names glitter no more. They were in line for a $6million rematch only three months ago. Now a rematch isn't worth much.

title: To Emily Post Kin, Proper Etiquette Is Still a Way of Life
description: RYE, N. Y.A gray cat named Exxon leaped up on one of the chairs in the formal dining room of a rambling, 12room, creamcolored house here the other day. He then put his paws on the table and watched while three humans lunched on Eggs Benedict.

title: RICHARDSON CALLS RAIDS ON CAMBODIA VITAL TO LON NOL
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson today defended the continuing American bombing of Cambodia as necessary to keep the antiCommunist Government of President Lon Nol alive and to presstire Communist forces into accepting ceasefire there, as they have in Vietnam and Laos.

title: Hackett and Dickenson Provide Joyful Listening Joyful Dancing
description: Bobby Hackett and. Vic Dickenson, whose gently lyrical cornet and dryly humorous trombone formed the basis of a delightful jazz quintet several years ago, have been reunited at the Royal Box of the Americana Hotel, whew they are supported by the Hank Jones quartet.

title: From Paris: Higher Prices, Lower Hemlines
description: PARIS, April 1The French call it a circus. The Americans say, Meet me at the convention. The Japanese go around silently buying up everything in sight. It's the mammoth semiannual entertainment at the exhibition hall at the Porte de Versailles, where the producers of ready to wear gather together to show their wares. And, the French insist, to establish the styles women will be wearing all over the world six months from now.

title: Mrs. Campbell, 103, Recited On an Early Edison Record
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., April 1(UPI);Mrs. Maria L. Campbell, who recited a nursery rhyme on one of Thomas A. Edison's first experimental phonograph records in 1877, died yesterday at Community Memorial Hospital. She was 103 years old and lived in Beachwood in Ocean County.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FREEHOLD, N. J.One of the busiest racing plants in America has to be Freehold Raceway. Its daily schedule of 11 races affords patrons the chance to wager on 10 exactas and a daily double as well as the more conventional bets.

title: Betsy Cullen's 218 Wins Alamo Open By Two Strokes
Cheryl E, Rosenfelt. Bride of Gene Ehrens
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 1Miss Cheryl E. Rosenfelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Rosenfelt of East Paterson, N. J., was makried here today to Gene G. Eh rens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ehreris of Ardsley. Rabbi Paul Siegel performed the ceremony in Temple Beth Abraham.

title: Senator Jackson Says Nixon Leads U.S. Into Recession
description: Senator Henry Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said yesterday that the Nixon Administration was heading the nation toward a recession by declaring war not on poverty but against ordinary people and families.

title: 15,000 Attend a Preview Of Soviet Art in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The wide popularity of the impressionist and postimpressionist French painters was dramatically underscored yesterday when some 15,000 persons turned out on a damp day for a preview at the National Gallery of Art.

title: 6 Senators, Seldom in Spotlight, Emerging Into Prominence in Watergate Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Senate's select committe that is investigating the Watergate affair, which is likely to occupy the center stage of na tional politics for the rest of the year, is composed of a group of Senators who have rarely been in the spotlight.

title: Flood, Now Bartender, Says Fight Was Useful
description: Curt Flood, who unsuccessfully challenged baseball's reserve clause before the Supreme Court, says his efforts made people aware of what the ballplayer is up against.

title: Foreign Language and Area Studies in Colleges, Faced With End of U.S. Aid, Have Uncertain Future
description: Foreign language and area studies at American universities, after a dramatic expansion in the late fifties and early sixties with the infusion of Federal funds, now face an uncertain future as President. Nixon's first peacetime budget calls for the elimination of Federal support for the program.

title: P.O.W. Who Made Antiwar Statements In Hanoi Recalls Pressure of Conscience
description: WASHINGTON, April 1A former prisoner of war who has been threatened with courtmartial for his behavior in captivity, said tonight that the pressure of conscience and morality made him change his mind on the war while in captivity.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Bows, 70
description: ROME, April 1 (AP) Lazio of Rome routed the United States national soccer team, 70, in an exhibition game today.

title: PACERS TROUNCE ROCKETS, 10693
Candidate Seeks Notice, Not Notoriety
description: FORT LEE, April 1Vito A. Albanese, one of six candidates for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, believes his campaign is suffering from too little publicity and too much notoriety.

title: Driver Cited in Fatal Crash
description: READING, Mass., April (AP)Jack R. Wilson, 19, years old, of Reading was charged yesterday with manslaughter after a truck that police said he had been driving crashed into a utility pole, killing one occupant of the truck and injuring two others.

title: U. of Michigan Marijuana Party Attracts 4,000 Young People
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 1 About 4,000 young people held an outdoor marijuanasmoking party today at the University of Michigan.

title: Elbow Macaroni Drafted In War on Meat Prices
description: You can't even buy elbow macaroni in Brooklyn, they were saying yesterday at the Women United for Action office, one of the groups coordinating the planned meat boycott in the city. So many housewives had purchased it as the base for inexpensive casseroles that they had emptied the grocers shelves.

title: Acceptable Compromise
description: Paranoia is no substitute for planning. Although suspicion is a justifiable way of life in New York, the changes made in the city's air rights agreements with the York Avenue medical, educational and research institutions that caused an uproar at a recent Board of Estimate meeting were in favor of the community, not a secret plot against it. But neither can one deny that community pressures, added to the city's careful negotiations, brought about some of these changes, and that the community dialogue, while it ranges from extremely knowledgeable to hysterical, is a useful and necessary planning tool.

title: Israel's RefugeeResettling Project Is Transforming Gaza Strip
description: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza Strip, March 29During the last three weeks, the members of 128 Palestinian refugee families have been moving beds, odd bits of furniture and cooking equipment into a newly constructed settlement on the outskirts of this Arab coastal town.

title: Gunmen in Marseilles Kill ExConvict and 4 Others
description: MARSEILLES, France, April 1 (AP)A former convict of Corsican background was fatally wounded today when gunmen with automatic weapons shot up his rented car in the heart of Marseilles, and escaped.

title: Tugboatmen Ratify ThreeYear Pact
description: Members of Local 333, United Marine Division  of the A.F.L.C.I.O. National Maritime Union, voted 3 to 1 yesterday to ratify a threeyear contract and ended the threat of a strike by tugboatmen in New York harbor and adjacent waters. The pact covers 3,000 in the crews of more than 250 tugs, small tankers and oil barges that are vital to the movement of heating oil, gasoline, bulk food supplies, building materials and other cargo in the thetropolitan area.

title: Knicks Take 20 Playoff Edge, Beating Bullets, 123103, Here; Guards Excel: Monroe (32), Frazier (29)
OLDFIELD SHATTERS RECORD IN SHOTPUT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (UPI)  Brian Oldfield set an unofficial world indoor record of 69 feet 11 inches in the shotput tonight and Kip Keino won the.mile run in 4 minutes 4.4 seconds at the third meet of the professional International Track Association. A crowd of 6,365 turned out at the Cow Palace.

title: Nixon Signs a Bill Aiding School Lunch Programs
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif, April 1 (UPI)President Nixon signed legislation yesterday requiring the government to give cash grants to school lunch programs if the supply of surplus food ran short.

title: Heavy Rains Fall in Area Some Drivers Are Stranded
description: Heavy rains lashed much of the New York metropolitan area yesterday afternoon and evening, stranding a number of automobiles on a flooded stretch of the Harlem River Drive and causing highway delays and electric power interruptions in scattered communities.

title: Progress with Peking
description: The Chinese Peoples Republic waited until American troops had left South Vietnam before announcing the head of its liaison office in Washington, who, practically speaking, will be Communist China's first tunbassador to the United States. Now that the choice is known, it must be recognized as a distinguished appointment, comparable to President Nixon's naming of David K. E. Bruce for the corresponding post in Peking. Huang Chen is China's highest ranking dipldmat, the only active envoy who is a full member of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party. Moreover Mr. Huang is highly experienced, having served abroad in Europe and Asia.

title: Tugboatmen Ratify ThreeYear Pact
description: Members of Local 333, United Marine Division of the A.F.L.C.I.O. National Maritime Union, voted 3 to 1 yesterday to ratify a threeyear contract and ended the threat of a strike by tugboatmen in New York harbor and adjacent waters. The pact covers 3,000 in the crews of more than 250 tugs, small tankPort ers and oil barNotes ges that are vital to the movement of heating oil, gasoline, bulk food supplies, building materials and other cargo in the metropolitan area.

title: PATHless Commuters
description: The shocking inadequacy of existing statutory safeguards against crippling transportation strikes is underscored for the thousandth time by the PATH shutdown that is forcing many New Jersey commuters to scramble for alternate ways to get to their jobs this morning.

title: Panasonic Will Leave the City For Site in Jersey Meadowland
description: The Panasonic. Corporation, one of the world's largest producers of radios, television sets and electric appliantes, will shift its East Coast distributing center from Long Island City, Queens, to an asyetunfinished facility in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Red Smith
description: While Ken Norton was punching a limp effigy of Muhammad Ali around the ring in the 12th round, Joe Frazier offered the most sensible comment that the American Broadcasting Company carried out of San Diego Saturday. Wonder what Clay's gonna say now, he said to Howard Cosell. That I took all the fight outta him? After Frazier lost the heavyweight championship of the world to George Foreman in January, both Howard Cosell and the man Joe calls Cassius Clay suggested that the champion had been softened up in his bout with All nearly two years earlier. If that explains what happened in Jamaica, then theof reason All came up empty this time was that he left his fight in Las Vegas with Joe Bugner in February. Nobody can really believe what they have teen, Cosell declared after Saturday's performance. Speak for yourself, Howard. On March 21 it was reported in this space that there are people who believe firmly that Norton will bat the former heavyweight champion of the world bugeyed, and Robert Biron, who owns a piece of Norton, was quoted: We are not smoking opium. We really think Ken has a great shot.

title: Islanders Tie Flames, 4 to 4, On Nystrom and Harris Goals
Readington, N. J. Show
description: MAIDEN WORKING HUNTER CHAMPION. SHIPChampion, Tewksbury Farms Hawkeye, 8 points. Reserve, Mimi Zaukaikas's Aristocracy, 5.

title: CANCER OUTLAYS TO BE INCREASED
description: NOGALES, Ariz., April 1The director of the National Cancer Institute said today that he had been given official word that his institute would get $54million. additional to spend between now and June 30.

title: Psychosurgery Case in Middle West Poses Complex Questions in Medicine and Law
description: DETROIT, April 1While a panel of three judges listened patiently, medical experts last week began to grapple with the complex questions and dilemmas posed by the use of psychosurgery to treat mental patients committed in state institutions.

title: Opera: Devlin's 4 Villians
description: With Norman Treigle absent from the New York City Opera's roster this season, other basses have been stepping into his shoes, and sometimes rattling around a bit. Taking over a role associated with another singer always presents a problem for later artists, however, and, under the circumstances Michael Devlin's success in assuming the four villainous parts in Les Contes d'Hoffmann cannot be seriously questioned.

title: Six TeenAgers Seized Trying to Steal Meat
description: While many of their elders vowed to abstain from meat for a few days, six teenagers were caught last night in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn as they tried to steal what the police estimated at more than 100 pounds of steaks, chops and assorted other meats from a local store.

title: U.S. Cautious on Marcos Arms Appeals
description: MANILA, April 1The United States has reacted with extreme caution to increasingly frequent appeals by President Ferdinand E. Marcos for more military assistance to put down Mosierm guerrillas in Mindinao.

title: CorporateResponsibility Groups Broaden Tactics
description: Public interest groups are pressing a record number of proposals for corporate action at the annual stockholder meetings that are now beginning. But at the same time the corporate socialresponsibility movement is broadening tactics.

title: Full Impact of the Strike Against PATH Expected to Affect Commuters Today
description: Port Authority TransHudson service was halted yesterday as railroad carmen went on strike, but the walkout was not expected to start hurting in earnest until this morning, when thousands of New Jersey commuters have to find alternative routes into Manhattan.

title: MAAAZEL LEADS THE BOSTONIANS
description: Israela Margalit's collaboralion with Lorin Maazel and the Boston Symphony Saturday night at Carnegie Hall did not produce a really outstanding performance of the Prokofiev Piano Concerto No. 3. Miss Margalit, who is Mrs. Maazel had

description: WASHINGTON, April 1Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson today defended the continuing American bombing of Cambodia as necessary to keep the antiCommunist Government of President Lon Nol alive and to pressure Communist forces into accepting a ceasefire there, as they, have in Vietnam and Laos.

title: F. C.C. AgainRefuses to Judge A Petition on News Objectivity
description: The Federal Communications Commission again refused to act, as a judge of broadcastnews objectivity when it declined to require an Idaho radio station to add to its network news coverage.

description: LOS ANGELES, April 1President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam arrived here to day for two days of meeting with President Nixon.

title: Hendrik van Dam, Headed Jewish Council in Germany
description: Hendrik G. van Dam, Berlinborn lawyer and exile under Hitler who returned to Germany after the war and had been secretary general of the Central Council of Jews in Germany since 1950, died Thursday following hospitalization for brain tumor in Diisseldorf, where the council had its headquarters. He was 66 years old.

title: 2 Newcomers Head Cast of La Boheme With the City Opera
description: A new Mimi, a new Marcello and a returned Rodolfo headed the cast of Puccini's La Boheme in the perform ance given by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater on Saturday night.

title: Schiaffo Declines To Seek Third Term As a State Senator
description: CLOSTER, April 1Alfred D. Schiaffo, the State Senate majority leader, announced yesterday that he would not seek a third term in the Legislature.

title: The Fitzgerald Affair
description: The investigation into the dismissal three years ago of A. Ernest Fitzgerald from his post as Air Force Deputy Assistant Secretary calls for speedy resolution. Mr. Fitzgerald deserves public exoneration and reinstatement if he was fired for entirely political reasons, as the evidence strongly suggests. The American people have a right to demand that public servants who fight against waste of the taxpayers money are rewarded rather than punished for their efforts.

title: Guide GOINGOUT
description: NEW HALL The Manhattand Symphony Orchestra is one you have probably never listened to unless you caught it at a street festival or in a community center, school or hospital. Tonight it's playing at Lincoln Center, just as any orchestra might. It was founded in 1971 to let young musicians, especially those who are poor or otherwise suffering from lack of traditional music advantage, get a chance to perform symphonically under a professional conductor, who now happens to be a young man from Mexico, Alejandro Kahan.

title: Bound for Kentucky
description: SANTA ANITA PARKSham won the $124,400 Santa Anita Derby.

title: Miss Kates Bride Of Marc Garnick
description: Miss Barbara Anne Kates, daughter of Arnold D. Kates and Mrs. Jean A. Kates of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Marc Bennett Garnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Garnick of North Andover, Mass. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

description: WASHINGTON, April 1The wide popularity of the impressionist and postimpressionist French painters was dramatically underscored yesterday when adme 15,000 persons turned out on a damp day for a preview at the National Gallery of Art.

title: Trout Season Opens: Many Hook Few
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 1Anglers are a silly lot, fit targets for the slings and arrows of outraged wives who for centuries haVe watched them drop house and garden chores and wander forth to outwit fish At various points in his fishing career every perceptive angler finds himself engaged in some ludicrous aspect of the sport that even his childlike enthusiasm cannot surmount.

title: State Reports Prices Peaked Weeks Ago
Two Butchers, Caught Between Costs and Consumer Wrath, Tell of Troubles
description: Bernard Braunschweiger, Part owner of Endicott Meats et 2273 Broadway, had time to ruminate bitterly about rising overhead and other difficulties that have befallen the, neighborhood butcher.

title: Charles Rosenbloom, 74, Dead; Played a Role in Birth of Israel
description: PITTSBURGH, Aprii 1 Charles J. Rosenbloom, a philanthropist and president of the Rosenbloom Finance Company who played a role in the creation of the State of Israel, died today in Jerusalem. He was there to celebrate his 75th birthday on April 17 and to attend a harp recital by his wife, Mrs. Lucile Johnson Rosenbloom.

title: Soccer Results
description: New York Hota 3, GreekAmericans 2.

title: Pope Condemns Curbs In Communist Countries
description: ROME, April 1 (Reuters)Pope Paul VI made one of his rare attacks on Communist countries today and called for prayers for oppressed Roman Catholics.

description: Jules Chender, a specialist and consultant in the copper trade and former vice president of Philipp Brothers, died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 271 Central Park West.

title: Pedlar, a Westie, Named Best at 3,095Dog Show
Two Ecologists Canoe a River
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 1 Two men looked happily at the stormy skies here yesterday, said, Let's go, launched a canoe in the shallow Five Mile River and headed downstream for Long Island Sound, seven miles away.

title: India Opens Drive to Save Her Tigers
description: NEW DELHI; April 1India opened a big campaign today to save her tigers from extinction.

title: The Vietnam Pact Is Closing Sweden To U.S. Deserters
description: STOCKHOLM, April 1 (AP)American military deserters can no longer expect automatic asylum in Sweden, a high Government official said today.

title: Mississippi Churchmen Honor Man and Woman
description: Mississippi Churchmen Honor Man and Woman JACKSON, Miss., April 1A churchwoman and a Baptist layman, each of whom now heads a national religious group, were honored here last night by a biracial organization of Mississippi religious leaders.

title: Revival of Coal Mining in Energy Crisis Divides West
description: BILLINGS, MontThe discovery by Lewis and Clark that coal lay right on the surface throughout the high plains they explored produced 60 years later the beginnings of the Western coal mining industry that burgeoned as the young nation pursued its manifest destiny. The black earth heated homes of settlers, fired blacksmith's hearths and fueled steam locomotives, then was eclipsed in the postWorld War II era by the expanding use of petroleum and natural gas and the replacement of the steam engine by the diesel.

title: THEFTS ARE LAID TO BLACK LEADER
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, the advocate of black capitalism, was arrested yesterday on 121 counts of grand larceny and conspiracy that charged him with taking money from his Queens hospital and investing it in several of his other enterprises.

title: Badillo: Mayoral Hopeful Dogged by Problems
description: Conversations about Representative Herman Badillo of the Bronx tend to begin in the same way: He is a man of great ability, but...

description: WASHINGTON, April 1Under its new director the Central Intelligence Agency is apparently planning to curtail some of its old activities, notably clandestine military operations, and undertake some new ones. These include action against political terrorism and the international drug traffic.

title: Spring Comes to the Russian Countryside and Isolates Villages in a Sea of Mud
description: IVANONO, U.S.S.R., March 31 Every year around this time melting snows begin to turn much of the Russian plain into sea of mud and traffic in the countryside comes to a virtual halt.

title: British Post Office Safe Cracked for $1.5Million
description: LONDON, April 1Safecrackers took cash, stamps and negotiable postal orders worth about $1.5million during the weekend from the main post office at Twickenham, a London suburb.

title: Chris Evert Wins Final Of Lady Gotham Here
description: Chris Evert lost her cool yesterday, if only for an instant, but she won the championship natch and the $8,000 first prize in the Lady Gotham tennis tournament.

title: Juvenile Justice: A City Crisis
description: The juvenile justice system of New York City has slipped into confusion and despair, caught in a crisis so severe that judges and jailers alike often say they are harming more children than they are helping.

title: N.F.L. Owner Meetings Open Today in Scottsdale
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 1 (AP) The National Football League opens its annual meetings here tomorrow with rules changes and selection of postseason game sites the major items on the agenda.

title: Monroe Earns Plaudits,
description: When he was rested with about four minutes remaining, Earl Monroe was. accorded a roaring, standing ovation yesterday at Madison Square Garden after having scored 32 points, his career high with the New York Knicks.

title: SPAIN COMBATING CONSUMER FRAUD
description: MADRID, April 1 Spain's consumer society has developed to the point where the consumers are starting to talk back to the producers.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Susan Sung turned to jewelry when her steel sculptures got out of hand at 1,000 pounds and her husband, Jesse, suggested she think small.

title: ELIAS GOODMAN
description: Elias Goodman, a partner in the real estate concern of Tishman & Goodman, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 6 West 77th Street.

title: My Baseball Years
description: In one of his essays, George Orwell writes that though he was not very good at the game, he had a long hopeless love affair with cricket until he was sixteen. My relations with baseball were similar. Between the ages of 9 and 13, I must have put in a fortyhour week during the snowless months over at the neighborhood playfieldsoftball, hardball, and stickball pickup gameswhile simultaneously holding down a fulltime job as a pupil at the local grammar school; as I remember it, news of two of the most cataclysmic public events of my childhoodthe death of President Roosevelt and the bombing of Hiroshimareached me while. I was out playing ball. My performance was erratic; okay for those easygoing pickup games, but lacking the calm and the expertise that the naturals displayed in stiff competition. My taste, and my talent, such as it was, was for the flashy, whizbang catch rather than the towering fly ball; running and leaping I loved, all the doordie stuff somehow I lost confidence waiting and waiting, for the ball lofted right at me to come down. I could never make the high school team, yet I remember that in one of the two years I vainly (in both senses of the word) tried out, I did a good enough imitation of a baseball player's style to be able to fool (or amuse) the coach right down to the day he cut the last of the dreamers from the squad and gave out the uniforms.

title: Divorce Is Down in Italy
description: ROME, April 1 (AP)  Requests for divorce fell sharply in Italy last year, the National Statistics Bureau announced. It said 20,410 divorce requests were filed during 1972, compared to 55,615 the year before. But applications for legal separation increased, from 21,514 in 1971 to 22,692 last year.

title: Juvenile Justice: A City Crisis
description: The juvenile justice system of New York City has slipped into confusion and despair, caught in a crisis so severe that judges and jailers alike often say they are harming more children than they are helping. A fiveweek study by The New York Times, involving visits to courtrooms and jails and interviews with scores of judges, lawyers, probation workers and others, found that the system is marked by high recidivism, inefficiency, muddled policies, inadequate resources, and almost total inability to rehabilitate.

title: C.U.N. Y. FineArts Degree Plan Hit
description: A group of the city's leading private colleges and performing arts conservatories are deeply disturbed over City College's recently announced plans to initiate a new academic program in the performing arts.

title: Rival Greek Cypriotes Toss Bombs on National Holiday
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April (AP)Supporters of the rival Greek Cypriote leaders, President Makarios and Gen. George Grivas, tosssed bombs in two separate incidents today as the island marked the 18th anniversary of its independence struggle.

title: Prospect for Arizona Election To Recall Governor Uncertain
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 1 Forces seeking to recall Arizone's Gov. Jack Wiliams, a Republican, filed their petitions this week, but prospects for an election remain cloudy.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson yesterday defended the continuing United States bombing of Cambodia as necessary to keep alive the antiCommunist Government of President Lon Nol and to press Communist forces into accepting a ceasefire, as they have in Vietnam and Laos. Mr. Richardson, who spoke on the Meet the Press television program, said that it would be very difficult for the Cambodian Government to survive without United States air support because of a massive threat by wellarmed, wellorganized guerrilla forces, which include forces from North Vietnam itself. [Page 1, Column 8.1President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam arrived in Los Angeles for two days of meetings with President Nixon at his home in San Clemente, 60 miles south of Los Angeles. Mr. Thieu's visit, his first since he became President in 1967, is intended mainly to enhance his stature at home, but also to change the minds of at least some American critics who regard him as a petty dictator. [3:48.]Capt. Robert T. White of the Army, the last United States war prisoner in Indochina, arrived at Clark Air Base in the Philippines after a release that until the last minute he feared might be a trick. Captain White,. 32 years old and from Newport News, Va., was flown from Saigon after his release in a Mekong Delta village. Meanwhile, the last group of American war prisoners arrived at Travis Air Force Base in California, ending Operation Homecoming, which brought back 587 men freed from Communist prison camps. [2:46.]Under James R. Schlesinger, its new director, the Central Intelligence Agency is apparently planning to curtail some of its old activities, notably clandestine military operations, and undertake new ones, including action against political terrorism and the international drug traffic.
