description: MONTREAL, April 3 (UPI) Talks on a possible merger between the National Hockey League and the World Hockey Association have been held by team owners in both leagues, it was disclosed today.

description: A negligence award of $1.75million, said to be one of the highest in the history of New York State, was handed up yesterday in State Supreme Court, Queens, in favor of Antonio Morales, a former prize fighter.

title: Boycott in 3d Day, But Prices of Meat Remain the Same
description: Shoppers here and across the country, still irate at the high prices of meat, gave no indications yesterday of waning enthusiasm for the threedayold boycott, which has sharply curtailed business at'thousands of butcher shops and meat counters.

description: Interest rates bobbed about indecisively yesterday, finishing with scattered increases in some sectors and declines in others.

description: PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., April 3 (AP)Maj. Floyd H. Kushner the only physician who survived a Vietnam prison camp, said today that 45 per cent of all captured Americans failed to survive mainly because of bad food and lack of medical treatment.

description: The Chemical New York Corporation announced yesterday that the State Bank of Hilton, N. Y., situated 13 miles northwest of Rochester, had become a subsidiary of the holding company. The Hilton bank had $9.5million in assets at the yearend.

Ottenstein, Washington businessman, by affirming a January, 1972, ruling by the Adams County Court.

The first question involves the basic fairness of the law under which Mr. Lennon has been ordered to leave the United States within sixty days; the second question is whether that law is being used deliberately to penalize Mr. Lennon for his political views.

description: The Equity Funding Corporation of America, once tie darling of institutional investors, signed a consent decree with the Federal Government yesterday in the wake of a widening scandal that may involve the sale of millions of dollars of fraudulent insurance policies.

title: Stern Subpoenas Records Of Bergen County Officials
description: HACKENSACK, April 3 United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern, in what may be an extension of an investigation into the affairs of some suppliers to the Bergen County Republican organization, has subpoenaed at least eight of the county's major administrative officers to appear before a Federal grand jury.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Yankees, preseason, at Norfolk, Va.

title: Books of The Times
description: Proud Flesh  William Humphrey's third novel and, first to be published since The Ordways appeared in 1965is hands down the worst piece of fiction I've read so far this year. It's so dreadful that I'd like to begin a review of it with a few sneeringdescriptive linessomething like Psychology by Rose Franzblau tricked up as a parodp of William Faulkner, or The Southern gothic imagination gone rococoexcept that I see that among its many other ill effects, it has absolutely anesthetized my mind. I am dumbfounded. I simply can't believe that the author of Home From the Hill, The Ordways, and The Spawning Run, which was a charming little book about the sex lives of salmon and fishermencould have produced such an awful mess as this. Even the title stinks a little, as I'll explain by and by. Well, at least Mr. Humphrey doesn't toy with us. Right from the start, one can see he is in trouble. It's not the cheap sightandsound effects in his opening segment I'm referring tosights like old Doc Metcalf's hair, which at the touch of the sunappears to flare into incandescent white ash like the mantle of a lamp (Gadzooks! It must be Gabby Hayes); or sound effects like the mournful chant of Negroes picking cotton that comes drifting up from the fields (no doubt a medley of old Stephen Foster favorites). These are suspicious, to be sure, but, after all, Mr. Humphrey may be kidding.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Eastyern Standard Time
description: LIGHTNING (American Export), Bremerhaven April 15 and Felixstowe 17; sails from Howland Hook, Staten island.

title: Equity Financing
description: An initial offering of 190.000 shares of Identicon Corporation, Waltham, Mass., common $6.50 a share was made, yesterday by underwriters managed by Faherty & Swartwood, Inc. The company designs, develops and sells data acquisition and control systems. Net proceedi of the offering will be used to repay a bank loan incurred for working capital and other corporate purposes.

title: Dave Hill Gets an Ace In Masters TuneUp
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3 (AP)Dave Hill wished he could have saved the No. 7 iron shot he made on the 190yard, par3 16th hole today in a practicer round for the Masters golf tournament.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Corp. Reports Profit Rise at Meeting
description: Operating earnings of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation climbed some 25 per cent in the first quarter of 1973 from the comparable three months last year, Gabriel Hauge, chairman, told a gathering of nearly 400 shareholders yesterday morning at the WaldorfAstoria.

title: People and Business
description: The last two executives at the International Controls Corporation who were originally identified with the administration of Robert L. Vesco, its former chairman, resigned from their remaining positions yesterday. The company had been named, along with Mr. Vesco, in a fraud suit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission last year, but was severed from the suit after it signed a consent decree a few weeks ago.

title: Lawyer Is Killed in Court After Brandishing a Gun
description: DETROIT, April 3 (AP)A Detroit lawyer was shot and killed in a Detroit courtroom today after he pulled out a gun without warning, the judge sitting on the bench said.

title: JOSEPH D. EPSTEIN
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., April 3 Joseph D. Epstein, a lawyer in Elizabeth and former law partner of the late Nelson Stamler, judge of the Union County Court, died yesterday at his home, 67 Forest Drive. He was 64 years old.

title: Truman Stamp Ceremony
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., April 3 (UPI)Firstday ceremonies marking issuance of the Harry S. Truman eightcent commemorative stamp will be conducted May 8 at the Truman Library, it was announced today. E. T. Klassen, Postmaster General of the United States, will be the principal speaker.

title: LIDDY SENTENCED FOR DEFYING JURY
description: WASHINGTON, April 3G. Gordon Liddy, a key participant in the Watergate conspiracy, was found in contempt of court today and sentenced to up to 18 months for refusing to answer a grand jury's questions about the case.

title: Football Transactions
description: SASKATCHEWANSigned Bruce Unshorn, Arizona quarterback.

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Regulate Fund Sales to Foreigners
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The Securities and Exchange Commission moved today to plug a hole in its regulatory structure and stimulate venture capital resulting from offshore mutual fund sales of United States securities to foreign investors.

title: Art: Winslow Homer Show at Whitney
description: Sunrise is not the primary ingredient of the best art exhibitions; indeed, the effort to manufacture it has produced some of the worst. But just a teensyweensy bit of surprise would certainly help the Winslow Homer show that opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum.

title: STATE PLAN ASKS LIBERAL PRISONS
description: ALBANY, April 3The diversification of the state's prison population so that only 20 per cent of inmates would be under maximum security instead of the present 80 per cent was urged by correction officials in a $276.9million construction master plan released by Governor Rockefeller.

title: WAGE CUT RESCINDED FOR JERSEY MAILERS
description: George E. McDonald, president of Mailers Union No. 6, said yesterday that he had recaved a ruling from the Cost of Living Council rescinding rollback, from 15 per cent to 8 per cent, of a wage increase in the first year of a contract for 43 mailers employed by the Alco Gravure Division of the Publications Corporation, in Hoboken, N. J.

title: City's Vacancy Decontrol Is Upheld in Albany Vote
description: ALBANY, April 3An attempt to repeal New York City's vacancydecontrol rent law was defeated by the Republican majority in the Senate late today after lengthy, sometimes caustic, debate and despite the fact that the measure had the support of all of the city's Democratic and Republican Senators.

description: WASHINGTON, April 3  In the growing controversy over the President's war powers, American military involvement in Cambodia is once again raising the question of the Commander in Chief's authority to make war without the specific approval of Congress.

description: ALBANY, April 3 The chairmen of the Senate and Assembly Education Committees criticized as unworkable today a new proposal by Gover'or Rockefeller's staff for reducing the substantial disparities in spending between school districts.

title: TV. C.B.S. Shows Hollywood's Salute to John Ford

The occasion was built around the veteran movie director's receiving the American Film Institute's first Life Achievement Award.

title: Radical, 27, Is Elected Mayor In Madison in Biggest Vote Ever
description: MADISON, Wis., April 3Paul Soglin, 27 years old, who describes himself as a radical, was elected the youngest Mayor in Madison's history today, defeating the twoterm incumbent, William Dyke.

title: Ban on Cigar Ads Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (Reuters)The Senate Commerce Committee approved a bill today that would ban all television advertisements for little cigars.

title: House Panel Backs Food Price Rollback
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The House Banking Committee voted today for a freeze on prices and interest rates at their March 16 levels but approved a rollback in food prices to May 1, 1972.

title: CAR OUTPUT REACHES NEW 3MONTH MARK
description: DETROIT, April 3 (Reuters) United States auto production set a three  month record of 2,708,337 in the JanuaryMarch period of 1973. This erased the previous quarter record of 2,624,451, posted in OctoberDecember, 1965.

title: 1DAYE IS PUSHING TERRITORY PLANS
description: JERUSALEM, April 3Defense Minister Moshe Dayan has begun, an intensive public campaign in recent weeks to force the governing Labor party to adopt his controversial ideas on administering the occupied Arab territories as part of its 1973 election platform.

title: Garelik Edges Closer to Pullout With Petitions for Council Chief
description: City Council President Sanford D. Garelik moved a step closer to withdrawing from the mayoral race yesterday when he authorized his supporters to circulate nominating petitions for his present job.

title: Text of Joint Communique Issued After NixonThieu Talks
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 3  Following is the text of a joint communiqu issued today by President Nixon and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam after their meetings at the Western White House here:

title: Big Board Cites Sale Of Two $92,000 Seats
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of two seats for $92,000 each, down $3,000 from the previous sale on March 22.

title: Judge Urges Razing For All Buildings In Newark Project
description: NEWARK, April 3The presiding judge of the Essex County Court recommended today that extreme measures be taken with the deteriorated (Stella Wright public housing project here which could include complete demolition of all existing buildings.

title: BRITISH BANKS CUT BASE LENDING RATE
description: LONDON, April 3 (Reuters)Britain's four largest banks moved today to dampen mounting protests over the high cost of borrowing money by lowering their base (prime) lending rates from record levels.

title: Fannie Mae Auction Yield On 4Month Pledges Is Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (Reuters) The average auction yield on fourmonth commitments to purchase 7 per cent Federal Housing Administration and Veterans Administration mortgages rose to 7.860 per cent from 7.810 per cent in the previous auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association reported today.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Prices of Commodity Futures

title: N.B.C. to Offer 9 New Series For Prime Time Next Season
description: The National Broadcasting Company will present nine new series, four of them halfhour situation comedies, in its prime evening viewing time schedule next season.

title: Trevino Makes Wet Blanket Prediction,
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3If it rains, Jack Nicklaus could be stopped from winning the Masters golf tournament here this week, Lee Trevino said today.

title: Protestant Is Slain in Ulster; Bomb Explosion Wrecks an Inn
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 3 (Reutets)Policemeri in the fishing village of Portavogie, 25 miles east of Belfast, found the body of a 28yearold man this morning. He had been shot several times in the head, stomach and back.

title: Mississippi Is Swollen by Fresh Rains
description: Fresh rains and storms raising the Mississippi River to what was feared would be its highest crest since 1844 left at least 7 Million acres of land under water yesterday. Sixteen deaths have been linked to the floods.

title: Astros Rader Injured
description: HOUSTON, April 3 (UPI) Doug Rader of the Houston Astros, the National League's Golden Glove third baseman, suffered a badly bruised right shoulder when he was struck by line drive in last night's game against the Minnesota Thins, Rader was hit by a smash by Danny Walton in the ninth inning.

title: U.S. STEEL TO LIFT STAINLESS PRICES
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would raise prices on stainless sheet and strip products by an average of 6 per cent, beginning May 1. The increases are in line with those posted last month by Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., and the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, among others.

title: Carborundum In Contract To Supply Soviet Factory
description: The Carborundum Company signed a contract here yesterday with Metallurgimport, Soviet Union trade organization, to supply $10million worth of shotblasting equipment for the Kama River truck factory. According to officials of Metallurgimport, the contract raises to a total of $170million, the value of orders placed in this country to outfit the plant.

title: College Graduates' Job Outlook Found the Best in Four Years
description: The job outlook for this June's college and university graduates is the best in four years in most fields, the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education reported yesterday.

title: MRS. LEE GRIMES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3Mrs. Eve Brueser Grimes, the widow of Lee Grimes, with whom she had been in the display manufacturing business in New York, died at her home here today. She was 69 years old.

title: Auction
description: The United States, as most foreigners know, is an extraordinary country with picturesque customs. Every four years, for example, it auctions off its embassies Western Europe and in a few other agreeable areas the highest bidders. The cash goes not to the United States Treasury but to the Republicans or Democrats, whichever party is in power. No other country follows this curious custom. But then no other country is as rich as the U.S.A.and it is well known that the very rich usually practice odd little economies.

title: SENATE SUSTAINS NIXON FUND VETO BY A MARGIN OF 4
description: WASHINGTON, April 3President Nixon won a stunriling victory today as the Senate refused to override his veto of a politically popular bill to supply vocational aid to the handicapped.

title: Watkins Glen: 25 Great Years
description: If there has been a theme to the history of Watkins Glen, it has been this fascination with excellence, its refusal to settle for anything less than firstclass is the way Brock Yates, the narrator, concludes the new film, Twentyfive Years at Speed the Watkins Glen Story. The same is true of the film itself, an engaging review of a quartercentury of racing in the charming upstate village that runs the United States Grand Prix and all the other major racing series. The film will be shown at 3:30 to 4 P.M. Saturday on WABCTV (Channel 7).

title: FtIBRIGIIT SEEKS END TO ARMS AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Senator J. W. Fulbright introduced a bill today to phase, out foreign military grants and military assistance missions over a twoyear period.

title: Radio
description: Talks, Sports, Events

title: ShortSighted Economy
description: To save a few tens of millions of dollars during each of the next several years, the White House has proposed ending the Federal research training grants for graduate students in the biomedical sciences. What apparently neither the Administration nor the general public realizes is that these grants have been the seed money from which have come many of the world's outstanding medical researchers.

title: N.F.L. Sites are Picked For 75, '76 Super Bowl
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 3The new Superdome stadium in New Orleans and the Orange Bowl in Miami will be the sites of pro football's Super Bowl games in 1975 and 1976.

title: Juvenile Justice: Failures in the System of Detention
description: In the basement of the jail, in a large if airless gym, 20 boys are lined up for a relay race.

title: As Birth Rate Drops, So Does Interest in It

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by; MARINE INTERNATIONAL CORPORATION, holding company for fishing, fish processing and marketing companies, 41 E. 42 St., N.Y. Total consolidated debt $10,500,000; net worth $3,339,000.

title: Woman, 28, Killed in a Fire Laid to Dispute Over Rent
description: A 28  year  old woman was killed and another slightly injured yesterday during a fire at 71 Brooklyn Avenue in the Bedford  Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. The police later arrested two men, and charged them with having set the blaze with gasoline after a quarrel with the building manager over rent payments.

title: LEARY IS CONVICTED OF ESCAPING PRISON
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., April 3 (AP)A Superior Court jury convicted Timothy Leary tonight of escaping from a California prison where he had been sent on a marijuana conviction.

title: ChinaWatchers Still
description: HONG KONGWhen Franklin Roose, velt recognized the Soviet Union in 1933 and sent the Bullitt embassy to Moscow, this action set the seal of doom on the profession of Russiawatching then being practiced at the American legation in Riga, Latvia, during the hiatus in relationships between the two great powers.

title: In 10th Year, Brazil Regime Gives No Sign of Restoring Civil Rule
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 3Brazil's military leaders have entered their 10th year in power with a satisfied show of accomplishment but with no sign that they are ready to restore civilian rule.

title: Soviet Farms Complain on Machinery
description: MOSCOW, April 3The Soviet campaign to bounce back from last year's disastrous harvest with a record yield in 1973 is reportedly being jeopardized by inefficiency and shoddy work in the centralized maintenance system for farm machinery.

title: Transit Strike Hits 35,000
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (AP) A strike by Red Arrow employes shut down commuter buses and trolleys affecting part of the city and its western suburbs today, leaving some 35,000 riders without public transportation.

title: Aaron Rabinowitz Is Dead at 89; Pioneer in Housing Development
description: Aaron Rabinowitz, a pioneer in public and private housing and real estate development, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at the Westbury Hotel, Madison Avenue at 69th Street, and in Westport, Conn.

title: HOUSE UNIT REJECTS HIGHWAY FUND SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The House Public Works Committee rejected today an attempt to open the Highway Trust Fund for use by urban mass transit systems.

title: OneMan Rule?
description: Renewed tragedy, for Americans and Vietnamese alike, could follow if President Thieu is allowed to depart this land under certain mistaken impressions, perhaps nurtured by his own wishful thinking. Beyond the noncommittal rhetoric of their final communiqu, we cannot know what President Thieu has been told in his two days of talks with President Nixon in San Clemente. But his travels across the country in the days to come, the South Vietnamese leader will meet a variety of other Americans, in and out of office, and certain points should become clear to him.

title: State Bail System Upheld in Challenge By Legal Aid Group
description: The Appellate Division, ruling that we do the best we can in an imperfect world, upheld the constitutionality of the state's bail system and rejected charges that the system was antipoorpeople and inconsistent.

title: COMMODITY GROUP TO STUDY OPTIONS
description: Several of the nation's largest commodity and brokerage firms announced yesterday the formation of a group to study the use of commodity options and to suggest ways to safeguard purchasers.

title: SENATE APPROVES STIFF DRUG TERMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The Senate voted today to set stiff mandatory prison sentences for nonaddicted persons convicted on Federal charges of selling hard drugs or anyone convicted of using firearms to commit a Federal felony.

title: Cahill Sees Ruling as Proving the Need To Find a New Way to Pay for Schools
description: TRENTON, April 3  Governor Cahill said this evening that the State Supreme Court's ruling against reliance on local property taxes for financing New Jersey's public schools translated into reality the need for state tax reform.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fireman Rescues Harlem Invalid Fireman James Dooley of Ladder Company 28 defied heat and thick smoke at a burning Harlem tenement at 111 West 137th Street to lower himself from the roof of the sixstory building and rescue a 200pound arthritic cripple whom he had noticed straddling a fourthfloor window. Fireman Dooley, tied to a rope, secured 69yearold Francis Peterson and brought him safely down to the sidewalk as other firemen fought their way through the flames inside to rescue other members of the family.

title: Icelandic Patrol Boat Cuts British Ship's Trawl Wires
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 3 (Reuters)An Icelandic patrol vessel this morning cut both trawl wires of the British trawler St. Leger, after she refused to obey orders to leave the fisheries area inside Iceland's 50mile limit.

title: When Children Talk, Scientists Listen
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  I goed there, said the child.

title: ETHEL EVERETT
description: Ethel Everett, an actress who started in radio in 1931, the year she graduated from Hunter College, died Monday at her, home, 180 West 58th Street. She was 63 years old.

title: Sixkiller Accepts Invitation For a Tryout With Rams
description: SEATTLE, April 3 (UPI)The University of Washington quarterback, Sonny Sixkiller, said today he had accepted an Invitation to try out with the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, April 3 (AP)The Soviet Union took a firm grasp on first place in the world hockey championships tonight with a 93 triumph over Poland for a 30 wonlost record in the sixteam tournament.

title: Mexico Will Be Host To U.S. in Davis Cap
description: MEXICO CITY, April 3 (UPI)The Mexican Tennis Federation said today it had won an appeal and would play the Davis Cup North American zone final against the United States in Mexico beginning May 12.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 3Making a comeback in any sport is difficult, but Clarence A. Ross, of Upper Montclair has done it after an absence of 43 years. What's more incredible is that Ross is now 73 years old.

title: INDIA ACTS TO END P.O.W. DEADLOCK
description: NEW DELHI, April 3 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, under increasing pressure to release the Pakistani prisoners or war, has abruptly sent a special envoy to Bangladesh in an attempt to break the political deadlock on the subcontinent.

title: Governor Chides Cousin on Jobs; Aldrich Affirms Aid by G.O.P.
description: Governor Rockefeller issued a onesentence statement on hiring policy that appeared to be a rebuke to his cousin, State Park Commissioner Alexander Aldrich, but Mr. Aldrich serenely reaffirmed the policy that provoked it and replied with a onesentence statement of his own.

title: New Isolated Virus May Provide Link To Cancer in Man
description: NOGALES, Adz., April 3A Minnesota surgeon announced here today the isolation of mystery virus from human cancers of the urinary tract, a finding that he believes may be the strongest evidence to date of a virus that causes cancer in man.

title: The Opera
description: For a while, at the Metropolitan Opera's first performance this season of Il Barbiere di Siviglia on Monday night, one seemed to be hearing things. The overture,remarkably mellifluous and lilting in the relaxed tempo set by the conductor, James Levine, also seemed slightly askew. And from there on, oddities abounded.

title: Acrimony Marks Campaign In Fuentes School District
description: Shouts and insults filled the air of the auditorium of Public Schbol 61 as Claudio Tavarez stood at the microphone waiting to complete his speech. The occasion was the monthly public meeting last Wednesday night of the District 1 Community School Board, which presides over 20 public elementary and junior high schools on the Lower East Side.

description: AUTHORITY BONDS* OTHER BONDS

title: Firemen Save 2 Children From Blaze in South Bronx
description: Two firemen in the South Bronx entered a smokefilled burning fourthfloor apartment by means of an aerial ladder last night to rescue two children left behind when their mother and two other children fled to the fire escape.

title: LAOTIANS CANCEL WEEKLY MEETING
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 3For the first time in 25 weeks, Laotian Government and Communist negotiators did not meet today for their regular Tuesday session, and there were signs that efforts to form a coalition government had entered a critical phase.

title: Wesleyan University Gets A Bequest of $2.1Million
description: Wesleyan University has received a bequest of $2.1million from the estate of an alumnus, the college announced last night.

title: Capitalism, for Better or Worse Land of Opportunity? Damned Right!
description: YONKERS, N. Y.Today I met man who asked, Do you really believe that the opportunities in this country are the same as they were in your youth?

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (Reuters)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today expressed opposition to legislation proposed by President Nixon to cut import tariffs on goods in short supply in the United States.

description: YESTERRDAY'S GAMES

title: FRANCIS J. KENNEDY
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 3Francis J. Kennedy, who retired in 1964 as assistant regional commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, died of a heart attack yesterday in Nassau Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 163 Weyford Terrace.

description: BASEBALL GOLF LACROSSE

title: Researchers Identify Cells That May Destroy Cancer
description: NOGALES, Ariz., April 3Two leading cancer researchers said here today they believed they had identified the key cells in the immunological system that can destroy cancer in the human body.

title: KNICKS MIMING WITH CONFIDENCE
description: BALTIMORE, April 3Now the New York Knicks take their playoff show on the road, where it has been distinctly less successful in the past. They came here today, after a light workout in New York, for games against the Baltimore Bullets tomorrow night and Friday night, leading 20 in the fourofseven first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs. Both games will be televised in New York by Channel 9 at 8:15 P.M.

description: ACROSS

title: JOHN MIMES, SCULPTOR, DIES
description: John Hovannes, an instructor of sculpture at the Art Students League of New York since 1946, died on Monday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 140 East 58th Street.

title: Dividend Increases Up For Quarter and March
description: Dividend increases in the first quarter of 1973 outnumbered those of a year ago by 47 per cent and 43 per cent for the month of March, the Standard & Poor's Corporation reported yesterday.

title: Sharp Reduction in Quotas; Of Amphetamines Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs proposed today a sharp reduction in manufacturers production quotas for amphetamine and methamphetamine in a further effort to reduce the illicit use of the powerful stimulants.

title: A.A.U. ASKS USE OF COLLEGE STARS
description: The Amateur Athletic Union applied to the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday for permission to use undergraduates on the United States basketball team that will meet the Soviet Union in an eightgame series beginning April 26.

title: Bacallao, Oddy Win Title
description: Pedro Bacallao of the Princeton Club and Roland Oddy of the New York Athletic Club won the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's doubles championship yesterday. They beat Vic Elmaleh and Mel Sokolow of the City Athletic Club, 1511, 1513, 615, 158, at the Racquet and Tennis Club courts.

title: Maryland Legislator Held In Distribution of Heroin
description: BALTIMORE, April 3 (UPI)Bail of $30,000 was set today for a recently appointed Maryland legislator who was indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of distributing millions of dollars in heroin.

title: Cost of Living Unit Blocks Wage Rise Of Machinist Union
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) In the first action of its kind under the Phase 3 wageprice control program, the Cost of Living Council has blocked part of a new labor contract involving the International Association of Machinists.

title: Soviet Industrial Reform Patterned on U.S. Practice
description: MOSCOW, April 3The Soviet Union, while preserving its basic centrally controlled and planned economy, has borrowed heavily from American corporate practice in its new threeyear reform of industrial management.

title: MUSEUM IS MISSING 8 GEORGIAN PIECES
description: Eight Georgian 18thcentury candlesticks on loan to the Brooklyn Museum were reported missing last night by the police, who said the silverware could be worth as much as $50,000.

title: JUDGE TEES A CITY TO BUILD ROUSING
description: DETROIT, April 3A Federal judge ordered the City of Hamtramck today to build housing and change its fair housing and zoning laws to give 4,000 black residents, forced out of the community by urban renewal, a chance to move back.

title: Despite Charges, Interfaith Patients Laud Dr. Matthew and His Program
description: Inside Interfaith Hospital yesterday, the eight remaining chronically ill patients were eating chopped meat and resting on clean sheets and one man was playing checkers with a woman in a nurse's uniform.

title: Marcel E. Wagner, Head of American Eastern Corp.
description: Marcel E. Wagner, president of the American Eastern Corporation and its affiliated companies in the Middle East, died Monday at his home in Gstaad, Switzerland. He was 70 years old.

title: Presidial, With Belmonte, Pays $11 in Coast Victory
description: Presidial, With Belmonte, Pays $11 in Coast Victory

title: Iphigene Sulzberger to Become Director Emeritus of The Times
description: Mrs. Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, who has been a director of The New York Times Company since 1917, will become a director emeritus effective with the annual stockholders meeting on April 24.

title: Dr. John S. Whitehill, 75, Surgeon and Rutgers Athlete
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., April 3 (AP)Dr. John S. Whitehill, dental surgeon and former star athlete at Rutgers University, died yesterday in St. Peter's Hospital, New Brunswick. He was 75 years old.

title: Britain's Reserves Rose in March
description: LONDON, April 3 (Reuters)  British reserves rose $118million to $6.04billion in March, the Treasury reported today. This was after receipts of $115million from foreign borrowings by public agencies.

title: Cambodia Rebels Mount New Attacks
description: PHNOM PENH, April 3 (Reuters)  Communistled rebel forces today struck at Government positions in southern Cambodia and tightened their stranglehold on. Phnom Penh.

title: HURRICANE KILLS 10 IN WESTERN EUROPE
description: THE HAGUE, April 3 (Reuters)A hurricane that swept across Western Europe last night left at least 10 dead, scores injured and caused damage estimated at millions of dollars.

title: Stock Prices Drop Again As Volume Remains Low
description: The stock market sagged again yesterday in moderate trading as the malaise afflicting investors continued to hang like a shroud over Wall Street.

title: METAL WORKERS IN ACCORD IN ITALY
description: ROME, April 3Unions representing 1.1 million wage earners in the metalworking and automotive industries reached agreement with management early this morning on a new threeyear nationwide contract that is expected to ease the labor unrest and spur recovery from Italy's protracted economic slump.

title: Nixon Pledges Aidto Thieu But Not U.S. Intervention
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. April 3President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam left the Western White House today with a promise of continuing economic aid but without a specific pledge of American military action if his country is imperiled.

title: U.S. and Indians Reach Accord On Most Wounded Knee Issues
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D., April 3Agreement has been reached on nine of the 10 points at issue in the 35dayold dispute here, negotiators for both the Justice Department and the militant Indians occupying Wounded Knee reported today.

title: Debre, Defense Chief, Is Leaving Pctris Post
description: PARIS, April 3  Defense Minister Michel Debre disclosed today that he was leaving his post and would not be a member of the new Cabinet to be announced Thursday.

title: COMMUTING EASES IN TIEUP ON PATH
description: The strike against PATH, the Port Authority's rail commuter service, went into its third day yesterday, and for most regular riders the going was a little easier than it was on Monday.

title: Two Million Lack Power for 4 Hours On Florida Coast
description: MIAMI, April 3 (AP)A short but massive power failure affected some two million residents along an 80mile stretch of Florida's southeast coast today, but most people made the best of it while waiting for the airconditioning to come back on.

title: Europe Urged to Consider Ties to U.S. in Trade Talks
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 3Sir Christopher Soames, conunissioner for external affairs of the European Economic Community, said today that the Common Market should consider the technical details of coming trade negotiations with the United States within the political framework of European relations with the United States.

title: Spanish Plane Exchanges Fire With Morocco Frigate
description: RABAT, Morocco, April 3A Spanish warplane and a Moroccan coast guard frigate exchanged fire yesterday in the Atlantic Ocean. No casualties were reported.

title: SOVIET LAUNCHES 2D SPACE STATION
description: MOSCOW, April 3The Soviet Union launched today an unmanned orbital space station, Salyut 2 which is expected to be boarded by astronauts in a few days.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, APRIL 4, 1973
description: President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam ended two days of talks yesterday with President Nixon with a promise of continuing economic aid, but without a specific pledge of American military action if his country was imperiled. A joint communique issued at President Nixon's home in San Clemente, Calif., where the meetings took place, said a full consensus had been reached, and that the talks were held in very cordial atmosphere. [Page 1, Cols. 23.] The text of the communique is on Page 12.

title: Renault Strife Worries France
description: PARIS, April 3They say here that when Renault sneezes, France has the flu.

title: Knoedler Pays 5Million For Robinson Collection
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3 (UPI)The art collection of the late acto. Robinson was sold today for $5,125,000 to a New York art gallery and dealer.

title: I.C.C. Nominees Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The Senate Commerce Committee approved today the nominations of Daniel O'Neal, Willard Deason and Alfred MacFarland as members of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Kenzo Displays His Imagination With a FunFilled Fashion Show in Paris
description: PARIS, April 3It was back to the Bourse du Commerce for fashion enthusiasts last night. The commodities exchange is a favorite staging area for fashion shows and Kenzo Takada, the resident Japanese designer who bills himself as Jap, filled the place with his fall and winter presentation and left a few hundred wouldbe viewers pushing and straining at the gate.

title: INSURANCE FRAUD CHARGED BY S.E.C. TO EQUITY FUNDING
description: The Equity Funding Corporation of America, once the darling of institutional investors, signed a consent decree with the Federal Government yesterday in the wake of a widening scandal that may involve the sale of millions of dollars of fraudulent insurance policies.

title: VOLKSWAGEN PACIFIC GIVES UP FRANCHISES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3 (Reuers)Volkswagen of America, Inc., announced today that its principal distributor for the Southwest and Coast areaVolkswagen Pacific, Inc.had given up its franchises held for 20 years.

title: Theater: Beatrice Straight in Ghosts
description: Is there an Ibsen revival? Probably. Certainly his works are being performed more frequently in the AngloAmerican theater nowadays than in the recent past. This is largely because we have deserted the loyal but fustian translations of William Archer for English versions that breathe more life. As a result, Ibsen is emerging in his true colors, as a playwright of grace and passion in addition to being a paragon of dramatic rectitude.

title: Discriminatory Wine Tax
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) A bill to block states from imposing discriminatory taxes on outofstate wines was approved by a House Commerce and Finance subcommittee today.

title: N.F.L. Tosses Ball Back to the Giants
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 3The burning issue of where the Giants are to play their last five home games this fall after they leave Yankee Stadium will not be resolved at the current meeting of the National Fo'tball League's owners here this week.

title: Cougars Beat Nets, 10191, for 21 Playoff Lead
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 3The Nets returned to their bad habit of too many turnovers tonight and were beaten by the Carolina Cougars, 10191, in the third game of the American Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoffs at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Smuggling of Drugs In False Legs Laid To Two Colombians
description: Two Colombians hobbled into Federal Court in Brooklyn on crutches yesterday, each with a leg missing and each charged with smuggling cocaine and marijuana stored in the hollowedout parts of their confiscated artificial limbs.

title: BOY AND SISTER DIE IN FIRE IN BASEMFNT
description: POMPTON LAKES, April 3 (UPI)A 7yearold boy and his 5yearold sister were killed today when fire broke out in the basement of their home while they were playing, according to the police.

title: SPANISH POLICE KILL PROTESTING STRIKER
description: MADRID, April 3A construction worker was killed and another badly wounded when the police opened fire on a group of demonstrators this morning near Barcelona.

title: Senate RollCall Vote Sustaining Nixon Veto
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)Following is the vote by which the Senate failed today to achieve the necessary twothirds vote to override President Nixon's veto of a $2.6billion vocational rehabilitation bill:

title: Sham Fight on Rents
description: With consumers expressing their rightful anger against skyrocketing living costs by boycotting meat, it was perhaps inevitable that electionconscious members of the City Council would try to rack up political points by demagogic little antiinflation exercise of their own.

title: Mistrial Is Declared for Magee in 1970 Killing and Kidnapping at Courthouse
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 (AP)Judge Morton C. Colvin ordered a mistrial in the Ruchell Magee murderkidnapping trial today after the jurors, who had deliberated eight days, announced for the fifth time that they were hopelessly deadlocked.

title: T.W.A. Prepays Borrowing
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday it had prepaid $46.9million borrowed under a special credit agreement entered into in 1971 with group of 16 banks. The borrowing was originally scheduled to be repaid in 1974 as certain air craft were delivered.

title: British Football
description: British Football

title: Westbury Track to Cite Two ExWar Prisoners
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 3 Racing's first tribute to returning prisoners of war will be held Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway with a salute to Air Force Senior Master Sergeant Arthur Cormier and Army S. Sgt. Richard Perricone.

title: SCHOOL FINANCING BY REALTY TAXES UPSET IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, April 3  The New Jersey Supreme Court struck down the state's system of financing public school education today on the ground that it failed to fulfill an 1875 mandate in the state's constitution for equal educational opportunity.

title: NEW SAIGON PLEA ON OUTPOST FADS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 4A fresh effort to arrange an end to the siege of a South Vietnamese ranger outpost failed yesterday when South Vietnamese delegates to the TwoParty Joint Military Commission walked out of a meeting and accused the Vietcong of not negitiating seriously.

title: Red Smith
description: Slim Sully was a horse trainer who, like all rightminded people, revered James E. Fitzsimmons. In 1954, Slim came down from Saratoga simply bubbling with enthusiasm about the colt Nashua that Mr. Fitz had sent out to win the Hopeful Stakes, about Mr. Fitz himself, about the whole sport of racing. By then Mr. Fitz had given more than 65 years to the game, had ridden or trained or owned winners on tracks named St. Asaph and Alexander Island and Brighton Beach, not to mention Churchill Downs, Hialeah and Washington Park. He had swept the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and Belmont Stakes with Gallant Fox and had taken the Triple Crown again with Gallant Fox's son, Omaha. In fact, just about the only thing he had never accomplished before that summer was to train a winner of the Hopeful. That's what I mean about racing, Slim Sully told Frank Graham. In what other game could a man 80 years old win his first Hopeful?

title: Patterns of Wage Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Although most of the major labor negotiations still lie ahead and conditions could change abruptly, contracts already signed and talks already under way offer glimpses of collective bargaining patterns that may be emerging this year. The few big contracts already signedby the International Ladies Garment Workers with New York dress makers, by the oil, chemical and atomic workers with the oil companies, and, surprisingly, by the rail unions with the railroads contain wage and benefit packages in the 7 to 8 per cent range.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of the Seabed, subcommittee on conference on law of the sea3 P.M.

title: Notes on People
description: A lawyer for Eldildge Cleaver, the expatriate Black Panther leader, said in Paris that his client was seeking political asylum in France. The lawyer, Roland Dumas, said the petition for asylum, addressed to Premier Pierre Messmer cited the French Constitutional provision that any man persecuted because of his action in favor of liberty has the right to asylum in the Republic. There were unconfirmed reports that the Panther leader had already arrived in Pais from Algeria, where he had been living in recent years. He fled the United States in 1968 after allegedly being involved in a shootout with the police in Oakland, Calif.

title: Pepsico Is Allowed to Run Rheingold, With a Proviso
description: Pepsico, Inc., which had been restrained temporarily from exercising control over the Rheingold Corporation, got conditional permission yesterday to go ahead with its newly acquired business, but it was told to maintain the Rheingold beer business without change pending proceedings by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: London: Moliere Brightens a Gray Theater Season
description: LONDON, April 3It was a mild, gray winter, especially in the theater. Oniy a pretty revival of Private Lives, an astringent Macbeth at the Old Vic, and John Arden's threeandahalf hour retelling of the Arthurian legendthere are parts in it, as in Tristan, where you wake up convinced you were Arts dreaming someAbroad thing fine disturbed the general lassitude. Things brightened up in the last few weeks. Appropriately, with the British looking about for some reason to celebrate their entry into the Common Market, one of the most interesting events was French.

title: Juvenile Justice: Failures in the System of Detention
description: In the basement of the jail, in a large if airless gym, 20 boys are lined up for a relay race.

title: STOLLE TRIUMPHS, PLANS TO RETIRE
description: HOUSTON, April 3 (AP)Fred Stolle, with a good serve and service return, scored a 63, 76 upset over secondseeded Roger Taylor in the first round of the River Oaks tennis tournament, then announced he would retire after this year.

title: Architects and Planners Debate Government's Impact on Design
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The most provocative moments of the first Federal Design Assembly, which ended here today, came occasionally when questions were raised and criticisms voiced.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Report Extension Sought
description: Jerome Dansker, board chairman of Investors Funding Corporation of New York, said yesterday that the company had requested an extension to file its annual report form 10K. Mr. Dansker stated that he expects the form 10K to be filled in about two weeks.

title: Boycott in 3d Day, But Prices of Moat Remain the Same
description: Shoppers here and across the country, still irate at the high prices of meat, gave no indications yesterday of waning enthusiasm for the threedayold boycott, which has sharply curtailed business at thousands of butcher shops and meat counters.

title: Market Place:
description: It was a busy day on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 5 Saved in Copter Crash
description: HONOLULU, April 3 (UPI)Five Navy men were resuced from the sea yesterday after their helicopter crashed into the water while conducting minesweeping operations in Haiphong Harbor in North Vietnam. A Navy spokesman said the helicopter had been towing a magnetic minesweeping hydrofoil south of the main Haiphong channel when it made a controlled landing in the sea.

title: Places to Take the Youngsters
description: SASKATCHEWAN (1954 In color) with Alan Ladd at 1:30 P.M. Saturdayat Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at 73d Street. Admission, 50 cents. 2888920.

title: Five Women Are Selected As Matrix Award Winners
description: Eileen Shanahan, a member of staff of the Washington bureau of The New York Times, has been selected as one of the five outstanding women to receive the annual Matrix award, which is given by the New York Chapter of Women in Communications, formerly known as Theta Sigma Phi. Miss Shanahan was honored for her excellence in reporting economic news during 197273.

title: Garden Offers Foreman $1Million to Risk Title
description: George Foreman was offered a guarantee of $1million to defend the world heavyweight championship against Jerry Quarry in Madison Square Garden on June 20, the Garden announced yesterday.

title: Japanese Puppeteers Are Extraordinary
description: Bunraku, the National Puppet Theater of Japan, which began a twoweek New York engagement last night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, elevates puppetty to an art form. It is like no other puppet theater. Nor, for that matter, is it like any other theater, although it does bear some relationship in choice of plays and style of actingto other classical Japanese forms.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fireman James Dooley defied heat and thick smoke at a burning Harlem tenement at 111 West 137th Street to lower himself from the roof of the sixstory building and rescue a 200pound arthritic cripple whom he had noticed straddling a fourthfloor window. Fireman Dooley, tied a rope, secured 69yearold Francis Peterson and brought him safely down to the sidewalk as other firemen fought their way through the flames inside to rescue other members of the family.

title: Kerner Sentencing Put Off
description: CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) Federal Judge Robert L. Taylor postponed the sentencing today of former Gov. Otto Kerner and Theodore J. Isaacs until April 19. They were convicted Feb. 19 of conspiracy, fraud, bribery and income tax evasion.

title: Final Scoring Leaders
description: WORLD HOCKEY ASSN.

title: BURK ENVISIONS VISIT BY BOLSHOI
description: Sol Hurok had a dinner paxty last night for 45 of his friends, one of whom was Yekaterina A. Furtseva, the Minister of Culture for the Soviet Union.

title: Gerald F. Norman, Taught At Long Island City High
description: Gerald F. Norman, a teacher for 47 years, the last 33 at Long Island City High School, died Monday in Flushing (Queens) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 13762 Juniper Avenue, Flushing.

title: Parents Accused of Beating Baby Into Unconsciousness
description: An Army staff sergeant at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, and his wife were arrested yesterday on charges that they had beaten their adopted 18monthold son into insensibility.

title: College Graduates Job Outlook Found the Best in Four Years
description: The job outlook for this June's college and university graduates is the best in four years in most fields, the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education reported yesterday.The commission's 331 page report, Graduates and Jobs: Adjusting to a New Labor Mar ket Situation, says that newly graduated engineers, scientists with specialties related to engineering, and persons trained in health care will be in greatest demand this year.On the negative side, persons with degrees in education, and new Ph.D.'s will continue, to have the least salable skills, owing to stable school enroll ments and an oversupply of persons in their fields.And after a copious review of the job market for American college graduates from 1900 to 1970, the commission concludes that a college degree can no longer be considered a sure ticket to a good job that makes use of collegetrained skills. By 1975, the report says, there will be more college graduates than Will be needed, but this will not necessarily mean that college graduates will be unemployed; rather, the report says, there will more likely be underemPloyment of talent than unemployment of the collegeeducated person.

title: COURT SETS PRICE FOR BREEZY POINT
description: A State Supreme Court justice set $31million yesterday as the price the city must pay for the 340acre Breezy Point tract of land at the western top of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens.

title: Equity Financing
description: A special offering of 177,100 shares of Metromedia Inc. at 17 per share was completed yesterday, Bear Stearns & Co. said. The company's stock closed at 17, up  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Senators Approve Move to End Ban On Gold !hidings
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) The Senate voted, 68 to 23, today to permit Americans to buy, sell or own gold for the first time since 1934 when Congress banned the private possession of gold at the request of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Concern to File Action TodayBanks Find Loans in Default
description: The Equity Funding Corporation of America, caught up in a multimillion dollar scandal over bogus insurance policies and besieged by bankers for the immediate repayment of $50million in loans, disclosed last night that it would petition the court today to file for reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal bankruptcy law.

title: In Brooklyn, the Splendid Art of Africa
description: The Brooklyn Museum's new exhibition, African Art of the Dogon, which opened yesterday, represents a new stage, a kind of rounding out, in our understanding of primitive art.

title: Hogan Is Recipient Of Richardson Award
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4Ben Hogan received the William D. Richardson Award tonight from the Golf Writers, Association of America. The award, given for contributions to golf, is named for the late sports writer of The New York Times.

title: Weaker Sex Under Law
description: DUBLIN, Ireland (AP)New Irish laws limit women workers to lifting 35 pounds, while men are allowed to lift 121 pounds.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Memphis March Marks Murder of Dr. King
description: MEMPHIS, April 4 (UPI)About 1,000 people marched quietly past the Lorraine Motel to City Hall Wednesday on the anniversary of the assasination of the Rev, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. five years ago.

title: N.C.A.A. Dragging Out Approval of A A U.'s Basketball Bid
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's council has postponed until tomorrow or Saturday action on a request by the Amateur Athletic Union to use undergraduate players on the United States basketball team that will play the Soviet Union in eight games starting April 26. The 18 members of the council  collegiate athletic directors and faculty adviserswill probably approve the use of freshmen, sophomores and juniors on the squad. But they want the A.A.U. request in their hands before making the decision. The N.C.A.A. sent copies of the request to council members yesterday.

title: Panel Finds No Evidence That Implicates Haldeman
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 The Senate committee investigating the Watergate conspiracy said today that it had no evidence of any nature implicating H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, in any illegal activities.

title: Louisianians Move Aside for the Raging Mississippi
description: MONTZ, La., April 4The Mississippi River has not been kind to the people of Montz.

title: Buffalo Mayor Due to Name A New Police Commissioner
description: BUFFALO, April 4 (AP) Mayor Stanley Makowski is expected to appoint Thomas R. Blair Police Commissioner on Friday, two papers said today.

title: F.D.A. Letter Discounts Drug's Link With Deaths
description: ST. LOUIS, April 4 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration has received reports of 19 deaths among patients whb have received the anesthetic drug Innovar, but the cause of death was either unrelated to the drug or not established, the agency said yesterday in a letter to Representatives James W. Symington, Democrat of Missouri.

title: Restaurant Diners Here Going Easy on the Meat
description: Steak houses and restaurants known for their juicy cuts of beef are reporting a slight falloff in business this week and a dramatic reduction in the number of customers ordering meat dishes:

title: MayorElect of Madison, 27, Vows to Put Everythin Together
description: MADISON, Wis., April 4Mayorelect Paul R. Soglin, at 27 years of age the youngest Mayor ever elected in Madison, told dancing, singing and shouting crowd of partisans at his victory celebration at the Labor Temple last night, We're going to put everything together now.

title: Records: On Mandolin, Wakfield
description: Last Monday evening Channel 13 presented a half hour program by an unusual virtuoso of stringed instruments named Frank Wakefield. Mr. Wakefield is primarily a mandolin playera bluegress mandolinist. He also plays guitar, autoharp and banjo.

title: Last Prisoner Freed Feels Same as First
description: PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., April 4 (AP)  The last American prisoner of war to leave Vietnam said today, after reunion with his wife, that he felt just about the same as the first man who got out there's nothing like freedom.

title: Bill on Premarital Sex
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April (UPI)The House, by a vote of 118 to 69, approved yesterday an amendment to outlaw premarital and extramarital sex in Pennsylvania. A final House vote is expected next week on the bill, which makes malicious mischief in cases a misdemeanor.

title: RECEIVERSHIP IS SET FOR OPTIONS BROKER
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4 (AP) A receiver appointed by a Federal bankruptcy court will take control of Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc., a commodity options dealer, after a temporary receiver finishes his final accounting.

title: Corpus Christi Drops Sport
description: CORPUS CHRISTL, Tex., April 4 (AP)  Corpus Christi University decided to drop basketball today after Head Coach Bill White was hired by Pan American University as an assistant to Abe Lemons.

title: PRICE RISE MED TO CROP DECLINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 A Congressional staff study released today has concluded that retail food prices could rise by 10 per cent in 1973 even if the Administration's best hopes for farm price stability are realized.

title: Woman Is Mayor, but Lib Doesn't Get Her Applause
description: The newly elected mayor and police chief of Cold Spring, N.Y., is something of an anachronism in American politics, circa 1973.

title: The Vatican Knew Of Nazi Pogroms, Its Records Show
description: ROME, April 4Secret World War II documents published by the Vatican today prove that aides to Pope Pius XIIand probably the Pope himself knew of the Nazi slaughter of millions of Jews.

title: G.M. Proxy to Include Disclosure Resolutions
description: Two shareholder resolutions calling for full disclosure of the corporation's efforts to support political campaigns and to influence governmental actions and policies will be included in the proxy statement of the General Motors Corporation for its 1973 annual meeting, the auto maker announced yesterday.

title: Al. S. Official, on Way to Peking, Sees Steady Expansion of Ties
description: HONG KONG, April 4Alfredles. Jenkins, the American official who will be in charge of preparations in Peking for the opening of a United States liaison mission there, predicted here today that there would be steady development in United StatesChinese relations from now on.

title: WESTCHESTER PRISON WILL CLOSE APRIL 25
description: The male division of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, in Westchester County, will be closed effective April 25, the State Department of Correctional Services announced yesterday.

title: Brandt Announces Visit to Nixon in May
description: BONN, April 4  Chancellor Willy Brandt announced acceptance today of an invitation to consult with President Nixon in Washington on May 1 and 2 only 10 days before he is to receive the Soviet party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, in Bonn.

title: Recycling Center Started
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 4 (AP)Reynolds Metals Company officials broke ground here today for another aluminum recycling center, bringing the total number of centers to 14.

title: Market Place: Story of Leasco And Far West
description: It is ptobably safe to say that investors were stunned by the news that Far West Financial would not be acquired by the Leasco Corporation.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by: BONDATEX MILL INC, $70 7th Ave., N.Y. Liabilities, $1,950,587; assets, $613,587.

title: Atoms Appoint Ehlinger
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (AP) Tom McCloskey, the owner of Philadelphia Atoms pro soccer team, appointed Bob Ehlinger as general manager today of the expansion franchise in the North American Soccer League.

title: POLICE GET POWER TO QUIZ PASSERBY
description: TRENTON, April 4  The State Supreme Court ruled today that policemen may interrogate anyone on the street even though his conduct is not suspicious.

title: Rangers Scoring
description: FIRST PERIOD1, Boston, Roberts (1) Shepyard, Marcotte 14:21. 2, Rangers, Park (1) Ratelle 15:59. PenaltiesAwrev, Boston (1:13); Tkaczuk, Rangers 0:13); Vadnals, Boston, (1:39); Hodge, Boston (3:54); Irvine, Rangers (3:54); Vadnals, Boston (14:56); Irvine, Rangers (17:42); Hodge. Boston (18:32); Rolfe, Rangers (19:42).

title: Patient in Psychosurgery Ethics Case Says That He No Longer Wants Operation to Alter Behavior
description: DETROIT, April 4Mr. L., the patient whose case has led a court here to examine the ethics of psychosurgery, took the stand today, and said that, after reading and thinking more about the technique, he did not now want to go ahead with a brain operation.

title: PUBLIC COMPANIES ADOPT A PROGRAM
description: A growing alliance of publicly held companies yesterday announced a program to bring changes in the securities industry and focus attention on the problems of corporations of moderate size.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Stephen H. Lockton said in his March 20 letter, The American consumer has to learn to stop complaining. Let the farmer do his job, for otherwise prices will only be sustained indefinitely at high levels.

title: Stanley Cup Playoffs
description: Stanley Cup Playoffs

title: Manipulation Charged
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that five firms and 14 individuals violated Federal securities laws in furthering a stockmanipulation scheme in shares of, the Imperial Investment Corporation.

title: Brooklyn Couple Charged In Beating Death of Girl, 5
description: A Brooklyn man, 6 foot 5 inches tall, and a woman he was living with were charged yesterday in Criminal Court with homicide in the beating death of the woman's 5yearold daughter.

title: S.E.C. Plans Intensive Inquiry Into Methods Used by Company
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of fraud charges it has brought against the Equity Funding Corporation of America promises to be the most intensive undertaken by the agency since its creation in 1933, officials reported today.

title: Giants Sign Four Rookies, Including Wash. State Back
description: Four more rookie draftees have signed contracts with the Giants, the National Football League club announced yesterday.

title: AIRLINES ACCUSED OF OVERCHARGING
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Enforcement filed complaints today against seven major airlines, contending that they had overcharged passengers on trips in which two or more airlines had been involved. In a few cases, it said the lines did not charge passengers enough.

title: Ungaro  The Liveliest Styles So Far
description: PARIS, April 4  Somebody must find a way to make modern, contemporary clothes or we shall end up boring people to death, said Emanuel Ungaro just before his readytowear show today.

title: Bashful Tax Collector
description: In 1971 Congress approved an amendment to the Treasury Act which would allow every taxpayer direct the Internal Revenue Service to allocate one dollar of his Federal income tax payments to a Presidential campaign fund. Now, in 1973, the evidence points a deliberate effort to keep that provision a deep dark secret.

title: Farewell to Lewisohn: It Gave New Yorkers a Lot of Night Music
description: On a gentle summer evening, a boy sat in the upper reaches of Lewisohn Stadium, waiting for the concert to begin. A stout man sat down close by and blew clouds of smoke from a freshly lit cigar. This cigar bother you? the man asked and the boy answered: No, I'm used to it. My father smokes all the time. There was more chitchat and the man rose. Goodby son, he said. Enjoy the music. It's a nice night for a concert.

title: State Realty Commission Will Study Blockbusting
description: TRENTON, April 4  The State Real Estate Commission announced plans today to expand its staff and step up its investigations into complaints of blockbusting and other practices by real estate agents that violate state or local antidiscrimination regulations.

title: MANILA PLANNING AID FOR MOSLEMS
description: MANILA, April 4  President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that am engineering battalion composed of Moslem Filipinos had been sent to help pacify the southern Mindanao region by working on electrification projects for Moslem communities there.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Oldcrop soybean and soybean meal futures rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade for the third straight session.

title: A New Japanese Fabric To Be Marketed by Beaunit
description: Fabrics made of a new textile fiber with the characteristics of silk will be marketed in this country later this year by the Beaunit Corporation, Robert E. Smith, the company's president said yesterday.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: Notes on People
description: Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will become the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union when he goes to Kiev in September for the European equestrian championship. Buckingham Palace confirmed that the Prince would go, but his daughter, Princess Anne, has not decided whether she will make the trip. The royal family has stayed away from the Soviet Union partly, it is said, because the Prince's first cousin, once removed, Czar Nicholas II, was murdered by Russian revolutionaries.

title: Yale Symphony to Present Bernstein's Mass in Vienna
description: NEW HAVEN, April 4The first production of Leonard Bernstein's Mass outside the United States will take place June 23 in Vienna. The work wil be performed by the Yale Symphony Orchestra and members of the company that presented it at the school, along with the Vienna Choir Boys and the Wiener Singverein.

title: Springtime in Gary With Nureyev
description: GARY, Ind., April 4Last night, Rudolf Nureyev and the National Ballet of Canada found themselves doing Swan Lake in the unlikely setting of a predominantly black high school in this domain of big steel and smog.

title: Senle's RollCall Vote On Proposal by: Ervin
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)Following is the 70to24 rollcall by which the Senate approved today that part of Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr.'s amendment that would curb Presidential impoundment of funds appropriated by Congress:

title: Edison Electric Picks Chief
description: Alvin W. Vogtle, Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Southern Company, was elected chairman of the. Edison Electric Institute yesterday at the trade association's annual convention at Dallas. He succeeds Frank M. Warren, presi dent of the Portland General Electric Company. Mr. Vogtle had been vice chairman of the group.

title: Penn Central Proposes Rail TaxRelief Program
description: The Penn Central Company, the corporate shell that owns all the stock of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company, proposed a plan yesterday in Philadelphia under which Congress would relieve all the railroads in the nation of local real estate taxes. The plan would also subsidize onequarter of the annual maintenance, costs of all transportation.

title: PEARSE MEAGHER, POLICE INSPECTOR
description: Inspector Pearse P. Meagher, who retired in February after one of the most versatile careers in the New York Police Department, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 11 West 192d Street in the Bronx. He was 54 years old.

title: Eisenhower School Closed
description: ABILENE, Kan., April 4 (AP) Abilene residents voted 911 to 608 yesterday to close the Lincoln School, where former President Eisenhower enrolled as a firstgrader. The site will be cleared and the Federal Government plans, to construct a visitors reception.building for the Eisenhower Center.

title: FRANKLIN NEW YORK LISTS RISE IN INCOME
description: The Franklin New York Corporation, parent of the $4.25billion Franklin National Bank, reported yesterday that consolidated income for the first quarter  after preferred dividends and before securities transactionsrose 6.5 per cent to $3,038,000, or 66 cents a share, from $2.88million, or 62 cents, in the 1972 period.

title: Lewisohn Stadium, Center for. Culture, to Be Razed
description: A $90million academic center is planned to replace Lewisohn Stadiumthe amphitheater and athletic field of City College that served as the city's summer cultural center for about half a century.

title: Voluntary Agency Hailed
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)Mrs. David Eisenhower tonight saluted Rehabilitation International U.S.A., a clearing house for activities that help the handicapped in 63 countries. At a State Department reception for the group, President Nixon's daughter said the independent voluntary agency was helping to meet a worldwide problem.

title: 2 Arabs Seized Near Rome
description: ROME, April 4The police here announced tonight they had arrested two Arabs at the nearby international airport at Fiumicino because they had been found in possession of six grenades and two revolvers. The Arabs were not identified, but the police said that they had been traveling with Iranian passports.

title: Ungaro The Liveliest Styles So Far
description: PARIS, April 4  Somebody must find a way to make modern, contemporary clothes or we shall end up boring people to death, said Emanuel Ungaro just before his readytowear show today.

title: Price Debate Spurs Congress Dispute With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 4Six days after President Nixon ordered a ceiling on meat prices as his latest step to stem inflation, the national debate over rising prices was at a higher pitch than ever. The President's supporters were continuing to defend the ceiling, not only as assurance that runaway meat prices would rise no higher but also as a psychological, deterrent against general rises and against wage settlements far above the Government's guidelines, Mr. Nixon's critics were branding the ceilings as virtually worthless; and Congressional determination to write specific controls into law appeared to be heightened rather than deflated by the President's actions. The House Banking Committee voted 26 to 2 today to roll all prices back to the Jan. 10 levels.

title: Federal. Loan Aide Resigns
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 14 (UPI)  President Nixon accepted today with regret and with deep gratitude for his contributions the resignation of Thomas H. Clarke as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: New Zealanders, Enjoying a Strong Boom, Are Trying to Preserve a Handsome Environment Too,
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand In one of the many new homes in a middleclass Wellington residential section the silverware is American, the stereo German, the toaster British and the shiny sedan in the carport Japanese.

title: Otherwise, Everything Is the Same
description: The crudely lettered sign on the pushcart at Third Avenue and 29th Street says: The hot dog man is in the candy stand. Correct; he is don't know why anyone should take a quizzical attitude toward that simple statement of fact. But several things in my neighborhood puzzle me. In the A & J supermarket at Second Avenue and 30th Street, Jake Rabinowitz says: I work the halfday shiftfrom 12 to 12. Absolutely correct; twelve hours is half of twentyfour.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Carolina Cougars, A.B.A. Eastern Division semifinal playoff, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 7:35 P.M. (Television Channel E (cable), 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 7:35 P.M.)

title: Theater: Entertainment
description: A very hardworking and rather talented cast (see listing) last night brought a musical entertainment by Hugo Peretti, Luigi Creatore and George David Weiss to the Eastside Playhouse.

title: Administration Retreats on $689Million Cut in Welfare Aid to States
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI)In the face of stiff op position from Governors, the Nixon Administration said today that it was postponing its plan to begin withholding $689million in Federal welfare aid from states that make payments to ineligible recipients.

title: Hong Kong Doctors Use Acupuncture to Relieve Addicts Withdrawal Symptoms
description: HONG KONG, April 4A medical team here has reported some initial success in experiments with electrified acupuncture as a treatment for drug addicts withdrawal symptoms.

title: Harlem Four Are Freed After Manslaughter Pleas
description: In the final chapter.of a long and complicated murder case that began nine years ago, the young men known as the Harlem Four pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday in State Supreme Court here in return for suspended sentences.

title: DR. MATTHEW MEETS WITH NADJARI AIDES
description: Dr. Thomas M. Matthew met yesterday with two assistants to the special deputy state attorney general Maurice H. Nadjari, to protest the tactics of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens last Sunday.

title: MAX BORGENICHT
description: Max Borgenicht, cofounder in 1928 and retired president of Borgenicht Brothers, manufacturer of children's dresses, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 and lived at 936 Fifth Avenue.

title: Panel Finds No Evidence That Implicates Haldeman
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Senate committee investigating the Watergate conspiracy said today that it had no evidence of any nature implicating H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, in any illegal activities.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: BOSTONSent Ken Tatum and Don Newhauler, relief pitchers, to Pawtucket of International League.

title: MRS. JAMES J. MATLES
description: Mrs. Esther Matles, wife of James J. Matles, general secretary of the United Electrical Workers, an independent union, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at 303 West 66th Street.

title: Nicklaus Choice in Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4Jac: Nicklaus, the overwhelming favorite of his colleagues to repeat his Masters victory of last year, said today: I'm flattered by their selection. It's a nice position to be in, and it will make me play harder.

title: Sikkim's Ruler Appeals to India For Troops to Quell Violence
description: Sikkim's Ruler Appeals to India For Troops to Quell Violence

title: New Justice Office to Seek Uniform Drug Prosecutions
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that a new division would be created in the Justice Department to speed the prompt and effective prosecution of narcotics offenders.

title: F.B.I. Wants to Retain Records of Reporters Calls
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation wants to keep for its permanent files the long distance telephone records seized from the syndicated columnist, Jack Anderson, and his associate, Leslie Whitten, the Government told the United States District Court today.

title: Transit Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Representative Philip M. Crane, Republican of Illinois, introduced a bill today that would provide up to $3billion in special Federal revenuesharing funds for mass transportation projects.

title: Nets Play Hosts to Cougars Tonight, Roping for a Happier Ending
description: The Nets went to the movies yesterday to see what they did wrong in the closing minutes of Tuesday night's game that cost them victory in the third game of the playoff series with the Carolina Cougars.

title: GAINS REPORTED BY HOME BUILDER
description: Kaufman and Broad, Inc., a leading builder of popularpriced housing, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28 with increases of 25 and 41 per cent, respectively, over a year earlier.

title: TURCO IS INDICTED BY FEDERAL JURY
description: NEWARK, April 4  Louis M. Turco, president of the City Council, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on 10 charges of mail fraud and four charges of income tax evasion.

title: The Vatican Knew Of Nazi Pogroms, Its Records Show
description: ROME, April 4Secret World War II documents published by the Vatican today prove that aides to Pope Pius XIIand probably the Pope himselfknew of the Nazi slaughter of millions of Jews.

title: Why Costs of Meat Soar Confounds Butcher, Too
description: If the housewife is confused about the reasons for the high cost of meat, she has nothing on Nicolo (Nick) Ottomanelli, who manages the Joseph Ottomanelli Meat Market on Manhattan's upper east side.

title: Toledo Sewer Pipe Breaks
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 4 (AP) An estimated 2.5 million gallons of untreated sewage was running into the Maumee River, each hour here today after an 18inch sludge pipeline ruptured at the Toledo waste water treatment plant. Toledo officials said the plant probably would not resume operation until this weekend.

title: ASSEMBLY ALTERS ITS VOTING RULES
description: ALBANY, April 4After several recent challenges by the Democratic leadership to the accuracy of bill votes the Assembly approved a Republicansponsored rules change today that still left the Democrats unhappy.

title: Dean, Nixon's Counsel, Was Dismissed From First Law Job in 1966 in Disagreement
description: WASHINGTON, April 4President Nixon's chief legal counsel, John W. Dean 3d, was dismissed from his first job with a Washington law firm in 1966 for what his employer first termed unethical conduct but later described as a basic disagreement over the firm's policies.

title: 2 Major Business Units Make Merger Final Here
description: The merger of the 205yearold New York Chamber of Commerce and the 75yearold Commerce and Industry Association was formally completed yesterday, and David L. Yunich, chairman of the board of the new New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, declared that from now on business will speak with a unified voice.

title: That Airline Meal Was Awful? Blame the System. Not the Chef
description: Welcome aboard, said a stewardess to a coach passenger on American Airlines flight four from Los Angeles to New York, We've got a movie, stereo and a fantastic gourmet meal.

title: Chess Spassky Joins the Victims As Tal Blasts Fischerward
description: The Tallinn International Tournament evoked great interest because it was the first event Boris Spassky entered since he lost the world title to Bobby Fischer last summer in Iceland. As punishment for that loss, the Soviet Chess Federation had refused to let him play in the San Antonio and Palma de Majorca tournaments. Spassky's showing a littlemorethanmediocre 4 victories, 10 draws and 1 loss, giving him a fourway tie for third placedid nothing to spark the hopes of his fans that he might return to wrest the world championship back from Fischer.

title: Events Today
description: Theater Film Operas Concerts Dance

title: Fitzgerald Asserts Air Force Isolated Him Alter Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  A. Ernest Fitzgerald told a Civil Service Commission examiner today that he was ostracized and isolated socially and professionally after he testified before Congress in 1968, on the large cost overruns on the C5A military transport plane.

title: FERLY CAPTURES DISTAFF BY A NOSE
description: The most remarkable thing about the racing at Aqueduct yesterday was that a crowd of 19,013 attended the program.

title: Corporate Profile
