description: The Equity Funding Corporation of America, once the darling of institutional investors, rode high, wide and handsome through 1972 as a sort of financial services conglomerate.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: A Hollow Victory
description: After the Senate sustained his veto of the vocational rehabilitation bill, President Nixon issued a victory statement which, like his original veto message, had a curiously abstract and arid quality. Both documents addressed themselves very much to ideological dogma and very little to the human realities of this society 1973.

title: Taxes and the Schools
description: TRENTON, April 4The New Jersey Supreme Court did not say when it would happen, nor did it say how it would occur. But the inevitable consequence of its historic decision here yesterday on public school financing is a state tax reform program that most likely will embrace a state income tax coupled with a dramatic shift in local property tax, burdens. In a unanimous decision, the state's highest court struck down New Jersey's system of financing public school education, based as it is primarily on local property taxes. The court held that the system did not fulfill a 100yearold constitutional mandate that the states uarantee equal educational opportunity to all, including poor people in poverty stricken urban schools. News Analysis

title: Fertilizer Sold to China
description: The Agricultural & Industrial Corporation announced that it had made the first sale of fertilizer by an American company to the People's Republic of China.

title: F.D.A. Asks Changes in Some Antacids
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Food and Drug Administration proposed changes today in the content, advertising and labeling of some antacid preparations, but generally supported the use of many of such widely taken patent medicines.

title: Juvenile Justice: Search for Reform
description: Over tuna fish and coffee, at a table in the hallway outside their chambers, the judges of the Brooklyn Family Court are trading horror storiesa psychotic child, sent home because the mental hospital had no place for him, a stabbing in the courthouse stairwell, a child who is an addict and another child whose mother doesn't want her.

title: Pupils Strike for Principal
description: COHASSET, Mass., April 4 (AP)  Students at Cohasset junior and senior high school walked out of their classes today in support of the school's principal, Richard T. Streeter, who was denied tenure by the School Committee.

title: SID GARY
description: Sid Gary, who danced, sang and doubletalked his way through the vaudeville circuits and was teamed with George Burns in 1917, died of a heart attack Tuesday while walking at Central Park West and 60th Street. His age was 72 and he lived at 20 West 72d Street.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: den, 8:05 P.M.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Cleveland vs. Philadelphia

title: Handel Group Sings Saul
description: The beauty of a good many highly praised Handel oratorios is hidden behind 18thcentury musical convention and can be uncovered only with much studious analysis. For this the average listener or even the contemporaryminded musician seldom has patience. So it is not surprising when a yawn greets the notion that Handel's Saul is comparable to the Oresteia and King Lear.

title: Television
description: Television

title: Astros Purchase Torres, An Infielder, From Expos
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 4 (AP)  The Montreal Expos announced today the sale of an infielder, Hector Torres, to the Houston Astros, the team he played for during the 1968, 1969 and 1970 seasons.

title: 5 U.S. Wrestlers Win In So. Africa, Face A.A.U. Ban
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 4 (AP)  Five Oregon State University wrestlers, defying expulsion from future international events, including the Olympics, competed today in the South African Games.

title: Soviet Publicizes Brezhnev Bonn Visit
description: MOSCOW, April 5The Soviet press today demonstrated the delicacy of Leonid I. Brezhnev's forthcoming visit to West Germany by beginning the official publicity about it even before the date of the trip is fixed.

title: TV: N.B.C. Specials Punctuate a Season of Repeats
description: The National Broadcasting Company does, I suppose, deserve credit. In this season of repeats, it turned out two original specials last night. One, from 8:30 to 10, was Elvis: Aloha From Hawaii. The other, from 10 to 11, was AnnMargretWhen You're Smiling. Trivia collectors will immediately pounce upon the fact that Elvis Presley and AnnMargret were costars in a midsixties movie that had something to do about Las Vegas.

title: Argentine Intelligence Officer Is Shot and Killed by Terrorists
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, April (AP)  Two young terrorists killed an army intelligence chief outside his home here today, after apparently failing to steal his briefcase or perhaps kidnap him, police reported.

title: RCA Elects Board Member
description: George H. Fuchs, executive vice president of industrial relations, was elected yesterday to the board of directors of the RCA Corporation. He is responsible for RCA policies and programs,in labor relations, organization development, employment and other industrial relations areas.

title: Park, Tkaczuk Set Pace With 2 Goals Each
description: BOSTON, April 4Jacques Plante, who has the haggard look of a 44yearold goalie, played like one tonight. He was beaten into submission as the Rangers trounced the Bruins, 62.

title: PATH Commuters Utilize Other Carriers Fourth Day
description: The carmen's strike against the Port Authority TransHudson rail system entered the fourth day yesterday with New Jersey comuters to Manhattan employing alternative means of transportation more smoothly than the previous three days, according to PATH officials.

title: College Job Is Accepted By Scribner
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, now on terminal vacation from his post as Chancellor of the city school system, will become a professor at the University of Massachusetts School of Education at Amherst.

title: Travelers Corp. Expects 10 to 15% Earnings Rise
description: The Travelers Corporation, parent of the Travelers insurance companies, expects a 10 to 15 per cent increase in earnings this year over 1972, Morrison H. Beach, president, said, at the annual meeting in Hartford, Conn., yesterday.

title: Stiffer Enforcement of Rules on Gypsy Cabs Ordered
description: Deputy Mayor Edward IC. Hamilton ordered the police and the Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday to crack down on unlicensed limousines or gypsy cabs after a group of licensed drivers complained that weak enforcement was unfair to drivers who voluntarily complied with new regulations.

title: S.E.C. Plans Intensive Inquiry Into Methods Used by Company
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of fraud charges it has brought against the Equity Funding Corporation of America promises to be the most intensive undertaken by the agency since its creation in 1933, officials reported today.

title: CLARK T. CHAMBERS, REAL ESTATE MAN, 93
description: SARASOTA, Fla., April 4 Clark T. Chambers, a New York real estate broker until his retirement in the late nineteenfifties, died at his home here today. He was 93 years old and formerly lived in Plandome, L. I.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Governors Dedicate Trade Center Here; World Pole Is Cited
description: The $700million World Trade Center, its two 1,350foot towers the largest buildings in the world, was dedicated formally yesterday by Governors Rockefeller and Cahill.

title: House Unit Closes Session Despite New Reform Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI)The House Appropriations Committee, in its first test of the new House praftice of holding open committee meetings unless the panel involved votes in public to close them, voted today to close a billdrafting session.

title: 900 to Be Affected By Matsushita Plan To Move to Jersey
description: SECAUCUS, N. J., April 4 The Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, makers of Panasonic electrical equipment, said today that 900 employes would be affected by its plan to move its headquarters and distribution facilities from New York to a 50acre site here in the Meadowlands.

title: Perfect Clarification
description: Impressions of what happened in the Watergate affair, recorded after eight months of relatively diligent struggle with the newspapers One night last spring three patriots named Hunt, Liddy and McCord fell to talking about what a terrible blow America would suffer if the U.S. Government should ever fall under the sway of a political party that recognized Fidel Castro's regime in Cuba.

title: SENATE APPROVES A SPENDING LIMIT UNDER NIXON GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Senate voted today to set a $268billion spending limit$700million below the amount asked by President Nixonand to insist that the President adhere to the spending priorities ordered by. Congress.

title: 15 FOOD PLACES CITED AS CODE VIOLATORS
description: The Health Services Administration said today that the following 15 foodprocessing establishments had violated the city's Health Code:

title: $2,600 in Equipment Stolen From C.C.N.Y. Radio Studio
description: More than $2,600 worth of electronic equipment was stolen early yesterday morning from the studio of WCCR, the City College radio station. The studio is on the fourth floor of the Finley Student Center, on the campus at 133d Street and Convent Avenue.

title: Federal Court in Atlanta Orders Desegregation Plan Into Effect
description: ATLANTA, April 4 (AP)A Federal District Court ordered today that a compromise desegregation plan be implemented for the Atlanta public school system.

title: Mrs. Gandhi to Visit Canada
description: OTTAWA, April 4 (Canadian Press)  Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India will visit Canada in June, it was announced today. Mrs. Gandhi is also scheduled to visit Ottawa in August for a Commonwealth conference.

title: TeenAgers Clip 4 Marks In National A.A.U. Swim
description: CINCINNATI, April 4 (AP)Teenagers smashed four national records today, on the opening day of the Amateur Athletic Union's indoor shortcourse swimming championships.

title: Jailed BlueLaw Violator, One of State's First, Freed
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., April 4A Long Island woman said to be one of the first two shop owners in the state being jailed for being open on Sundays walked out of the Nassau County jail today after serving a threeday sentence.

title: Screvane, an ExDeputy Mayor, Picked to Run Beame Campaign
description: Paul R. Screvane, who was Deputy Mayor under Robert F. Wagner and who once opposed Abraham D. Beame for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, was introduced by Mr. Beame yesterday as his campaign manager in the current race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

title: U.S. Aide Is Hopeful of Reaching Accord Today at Wounded Knee
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., April 4Government spokesmen said tonight that one or two minor legal points stood in the way of an agreement that would end the 36dayold occupation of the village of Wounded Knee by militant Indians.

title: U.S. Credits Seen Linked To Flow of Russian Data
description: MOSCOW, April. 4Henry Kearns, chairman of the United States ExportImport Bank, indicated today that he had told high Soviet officials that Moscow would have to give Washington more facts if it wanted massive American credits for joint development of Siberian natural gas.

title: STRASBOURG POLICE AND STUDENTS CLASH
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 4 (AP)  Policemen and students battled until early this morning at Strasbourg University in a fivehour clash that left 75 persons injured, five seriously.

title: Big but Not So Bold Trade Center Towers Are Tallest, But Architecture Is Smaller Scale
description: The towers are pure technology, the lobbies are pure schmaltz and the impact on New York of two 110story buildings and auxiliary structures with a projected population of 130,000 workers and visitors using a citysize amount of services is pure speculation. These are the three areas in which an undertaking of the size and scale of the World Trade Center must be evaluated: engineering, design and planning.

title: BRIBERY LAID TO 8 IN CITY PROGRAM
description: The acting director of the Harlem Model Cities Program, two subordinates and five others, including a candidate for the City Council, were indicted yesterday on Federal charges growing out of an investigation of Model Cities contracts.

title: 413 GREEK COINS SOLD FOR $700,000
description: GENEVA, April 4An auction sale of 413 ancient Greek coins belonging to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York brought about $700,000 in Zurich today.

title: Northwestern Hires Winter
description: EVANSTON, Ill., April 4 (AP) Tex Winter, former coach of the Houston Rockets in the National Basketball Association, was named coal at Northwesterm University today. He succeeded Brad Snyder, who resigned.

title: Cournoyer Tallies
description: MONTREAL, April 4 (AP)A powerplay goal by a right wing, Yvan Cournoyer, at 4:27 of the third period tonight gave the Montreal Canadiens a 21 victory over the Buffalo Sabres and a 10 lead in their Stanley Cup playoff.

title: Brewer Wins Little Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4 (UPI)  Gay Brewer won today's Masters golf tournament par3 preliminary with a sevenunderpar 20. The event took place on the miniature course adjacent to the Augusta National course.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Eastern railroads by a 16 to 3 vote decided yesterday to join with the Western and Southern railroads seeking a freight rate increase.

title: U.S. Journalists Held 2 Days By Vietcong and Then Released
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 (AP)Two American journalists reported today that they had been held prisoner by the Vietcong for two days and released today in a hamlet near the northern provincial capital of Quang Ngai.

title: Hextall Ends Deadlock
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (AP) The Minnesota North Stars stole the home  ice advantage from the Philadelphia Flyers with a 30 victory tonight in the opening game of a National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoff.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Atlanta

title: Peruvian Landslide Kills 12
description: LIMA, April 4 (Reuters)  A landslide crashed on Huatun, a Peruvian village about 450 miles northwest of here, early yesterday killing 12 persons, injuring 10 severely and sweeping away a dozen houses, the police said here today.

title: Leftists Forced From Frankfurt House After a Year
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, April 4Shortly after 4 A. M. today a police detail of 700 menalmost half of the Frankfurt forceremoved 10 leftist students from a large house that they hadoccupied a year ago.

title: Vigorous Reactions
description: Presidents Nixon and Thieu are agreed on the need for appropriate vigorous reactions to continuing violations of the ceasefire agreements by North Vietnam. But the question remains whether President Nixon was appropriately vigorous in reacting also to the continuing violations of the truce terms by President Thieu.

title: Eight, Including City Council Candidate, Indicted on Bribery and Other Charges in Harlem Program
description: The acting director of the Harlem Model Cities Program, two subordinates and five others, including a candidate for, the City Council, were indieted yesterday on Federal charges growing out of an investigation of Model Cities contracts.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the police have the right to question anyone on the street even though their conduct is not outwardly suspicious. The 6to1 ruling reinstated a heroinpossession conviction that had been overturned when the suspect, Samuel Sheffield of Newark argued that Newark detectives had no cause to suspect him if criminal activity or to question him. The state's high court held, however, that the police were not acting unconstitutionally when they questioned an outwardly unsuspicious individual and the contraband that was found could be used as evidence.

title: Woman Is Mayor, but Lib Doesn't Get Her Applause
description: The newly elected mayor and police chief of Cold Spring, N.Y., is something of an anachronism in American politics, circa 1973.

title: 1972 Major League Standings
description: American League EASTERN DIVISION

title: Vietcong Welcome U.S. Visitors Guardedly
description: KIEN HOA PROVINCE, South Vietnam, April 2The small open boat chugged slowly down the Mekong River, the three of us straining our eyes in the blazing sun for any sign of life in the dense foliage on the bank.

title: LON NON SAID TO QUIT CAMBODIAN CABINET
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 4 (AP)  President Lon Nol's younger brother, Brig. Gen. Lon Non, has resigned his Cabinet post, informed sources said today. This is expected to have little effect on his domination of the Government.

title: House in Massachusetts Urges U.S. Judge Retire
description: BOSTON, April 4 (AP) The Massachusetts House formerly requested yesterday the retirement of Federal District Court Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr.

title: World Trade Institute Is Labeled Heart of Center
description: This is the heart of the World Trade Center, said Jack Zwick as he escorted visitor through the 55thfloor offices of the World Trade Institute. The rest of it, that's just real estate, remarkable real estate and fascinating engineering, but just real estate.

title: STOCK PRICES FALL ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices continued to move mostly downward yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market in slow trading.

title: Air Force Sentences Pacifist Doctor
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 4A pacifist Air Force physician who refused to perform his military duties was sentenced today to one and a half years at hard labor and fined $25,000 in a oneday courtmartial.

title: Nevada Chooses the Sheep
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., April 4 (UPI)The desert bighorn sheep won out over the mustang yesterday, and will become Nevada's state animal.

title: People and Business
description: Ways and means of succeeding in international joint ventures were outlined yesterday by Sol E. Flick, exec utive vice president of the Bulova Watch Company.

title: Rain Sets Record for Date, With 1.35 Inches in City
description: Heavy showers poured 1.35 inches of rain on New York City yesterday afternoon, breaking the old record of 1.31 inches for the date, set in 1911.

title: Take 30 Playoff LeadBradley, Defense Excel
description: BALTIMORE, April 4The New York Knicks kept right on rolling tonight and took a 30 lead in their fourofsevengame series with Baltimore by, beating the Bullets, 10396, before a capacity crowd of 12,289 at the Civic Center.

title: Hawaii Teachers Ask Talks
description: HONOLULU, April 4 (UPI)Hawaii's strikingschool teachers turned to the Legislature today in an effort to obtain resumption of talks. The Hawaii State Teachers Association assigned more than 600 teachers to urge lawmakers to bring the school's administration to the bargaining table. The walkout, called to back demands for higher pay, began Monday.

title: Volcano Gas Kills Icelander
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 4 (AP)The volcanic eruption on the island of Heimaey off Iceland's southern coast has claimed its first victim. The body of Sigurgeir Orn Sigurgeirsson, 30 years old, was found today in the cellar of a drugstore, where he died of poisonous gas. He had been missing since Friday when his boat put into Heimaey harbor for shelter.

title: SCHOTTEN PLEASES IN RECITAL ON VIOLA
description: Smooth technical equipment and a restrained, sensitive style will command a listener's attention in the music of most composers. This was the reason that Yizhak Schotten's second New York recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night was largely rewarding. Unaccompanied, the Boston Symphony violist played Bach's Suite No. 2 in D minor and Hindemith's Viola Sonata (Op. 25, No. 1) with those small propulsive accents that give a work rhythmic and harmonic shape.

title: CERVICAL CANCER LINKED TO MALES
description: NOGALES, Ariz., April 4A Florida scientist has found that the male genital tract can harbor a virus that is suspected of causing cancer of the cervix in women.

title: The winning. New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all live numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Ellsberg Trial Told Data Did No Harmi
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4 Donald S. Luce, who along with two American Congreessmen discovered the tiger cages in a South Vietnam prison in 1970, told the jury at the Pentagon papers trial today that disclosure of information about the strategic hamlet and pacification prograihs in Vietnam did not damage those programs.

title: Cyprus Police Attacked
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 4 (Reuters)  Armed groups attacked two police stations last night, destroying one, the police announced here today. No, casualties were repotted. The raids were attributed to supporters of Gen. George Grivas, who seeks union with Greece.

title: CutRate Butcher Reports Boycott Has Cut Deep
description: NEW. BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 4  Support of the meat boycott by patrons of a highpriced store here appeared substantially less than among customers of a highvolume, Iowpriced store.

title: Bonavena Sued for $15,000
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 4 (UPI)  An architect who accused the Argentine heavyweight, Oscar Bonavena, of breaking his jaw in a hotel bar brawl last summer, sued the boxer today for $15,000. Norberto Bombicino alleged Bonavena hit him for personal reasons which, the police said, they did not understand. The $15,000 damages the architect seeks includes disfiguration, surgical and medical treatment and the fact Bombicino was unable to work for four months.

title: Sharp Increase in Measles Is Reported in. Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, April 4 (UPI)The State Health Department is reporting a sharp rise in the number of measles cases in several areas throughout Connecticut.

title: Dance: The Art of Indrani
description: The particulars of Indrani's art, her enormous range of dramatic characterization and complex rhythmic pure dances are well known to Indian dance audiences, and so it was with some delight to see her honored formally with the key to the City of New York. The presentation was made at her concert Tuesday evening at the Teresa L. Kaufmann Concert Hall.

title: BRADLEY BRACING FOR YORTY RUNOFF
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4Fresh from a solid triumph in yesterday's primary, Thomas Bradley opened today the second round of his campaign to become the first black mayor of Los Angeles by declaring that race was an irrelevant factor in the election.

title: P.O.W. COMPLAINTS BRING RED THREAT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 (AP)North Vietnam and the Vietcong said today that torture charges by former American war prisoners threatened to interfere with return of the bodies of prisoners who died in captivity and the search for United States servicemen listed as missing.

title: PLANECRASH VICTIMS FOUND BY WRECKAGE
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., April 4 (AP)The bodies of two New York State men were recovered by state police divers early today near the wreckage of their light plane, which crashed into Bantam Lake late Tuesday night.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES JAN. 10 ROLLBACK
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 The House Banking Committee voted today to roll back prices and interest rates to their level of last Jan. 10, but the vote gave no real clue to what Congress will ultimately do about price, wage, interest and rent controls.

title: Prof. John Pick Dead at 61; Taught Accounting at L.I.U.
description: Dr. John Pick, professor of accounting and a member of the faculty since 1961 at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, died in his sleep yesterday at his home, 2038 East 23d Street, Brooklyn. He was 61 years old.

title: ROZELLE FAVORS OVERTIME PERIOD
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 4 (AP)  Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today he favored a suddendeath playoff over a 2point conversion if any changes were made in National Football League rules.

title: Biaggi Misses. Lambs Basting; Arrives at Club 2 Hours Late
description: Mario Biaggi made history of a sort last night at the Lambs, the theatrical club. The Bronx Representative and mayoral candidate and the intended victim of the club's monthly satirical Lambasting, arrived two and a half hours late and was ushered into a darkened hall being emptied of chairs and glasses.

title: Thieu Is Welcomed by Agnew On His Arrival in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam was greeted by Vice President Agnew and a friendly demonstration when he arrived today from Los Angeles.

title: Indemnification Is Set
description: The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it has incurred charges totaling $19.7million so far under its agreement to indemnify Merrill Lynch against certain losses arising out of the brokerage firm's acquisition of Goodbody & Co.

title: JERSEY TOMS WIN ON RENT CONTROL
description: TRENTON, April 4  The State Supreme Court ruled today that municipalities have the right to enact their own rentcontrol ordinances.

title: STARS DOWN Q'S 2D TIME IN ROW
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 4 (AP)  Willie Wise pumped in 29 points tonight to spark the Utah Stars to a 10392 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors in the second game of their American Basketball Association playoff. Utah now has a 20 lead.

title: U.S Grand Jury Indicts Head of Newark Council
description: NEWARK, April 4  Louis M. Turco, president of the City Council was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on 10 charges of mail fraud and four charges of income tax evasion.

title: Baccalaureate Service Out
description: HUNTINGTON W. VA., April 4 (UPI)Marshall University has eliminated baccalaureate services as part of its commenccement because of poor attendance, it was announced yesterday. Marshall's president, John G. Barker, said individual churches planned to hold special baccalaureate services for graduates.

title: SMITH, LAYER WIN IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 4 (AP)Rod Laver and Stan Smith powered their way into the round of 16 with straightset victories in the $50,000 Group A World Championship Tennis tournament today.

title: That Airline Meal Was Awful? Blame the System, Not the Chef
description: Welcome aboard, said a stewardess to a coach passenger on American Airlines flight four from Los Angeles to New York, We've got a movie, stereo and a fantastic gourmet meal.

title: European Champion Wins
description: CAGLIARI, Italy, April 4 (AP)  Antonio Puddu of Italy retained his European lightWeight title by knocking down Dominique Azzaro of France five times and stopping him in less than two minutes of the first round tonight.

title: Winner of $1Million In Lottery Is Stunned
description: TRENTON, April 4 (UPI)Mrs. Audrey Warner, the mother of two married children, was incredulous when she received a call from the State Lottery Commission, today.

title: Property Loss Along Mississippi Nears $25Million
description: Property damage estimated from the floodwaters of the Mississippi River systemswelling to 129year record crestsclimbed toward $25million yesterday.

title: MeatCutting Lesson
description: ORANGE, April 4A butcher will cut up a side of beef at the public library here on Monday to show which cuts are the most economical. There will be demonstrations at 11 AM., 7 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. Tickets are free, but must be obtained in advance at the library, Main and Essex Streets. The date of the demonstration was erroneously reported in The New York. Times last Monday.

title: Suit by N.A.A.C.P. Aims to Upset Plan In Canarsie Schools
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People brought suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday in an effort to prevent the exclusion of children living in the largely black Tilden Houses in Brownsville from schools in Canarsie and East Flatbush.

title: The Scribner Years
description: Harvey Scribner came to New York a little short three years ago to become the first Chancellor to preside over the newly decentralized school system. He leaves that difficult task with honor; he deserves the respect and thanks of the people of this city.

title: Film: 'The Mack' Opens:Max Julien Stars in a Black Melodrama
description: "The Mack" is a very noisy, very exploitative black film about the rise and the peaceful retirement of a pimp who, according to the film's program notes, is known in West Coast street language as a mack, an apparent corruption of "mec" of French argot.When Goldie (Max Julien) gets out of jail, he finds that his brother has become a militant black nationalist, that his middle-class mother still wants him to go to church on Sundays, that two crooked, psychotic white cops hope to put him back in jail, and that the only thing he can do is pimp. "I'm going to be the meanest mack there ever was!" Goldie vows. He then adds: "They're going to talk about me the way they used to talk about Jesus."That doesn't make much sense, but nothing does in this essentially sentimental melodrama. The screenplay by Robert J. Poole uses lines that seem to have been saved from a sophomore's notebook. "Truth," says a white cop, "is pimples, garlic and armpits." Says Goldie to a hooker whom he'd known when both were children: "I thought you'd become a nurse or a lawyer or something heavy." Or, and this is my favorite wisdom of the week: "A pimp is only as good as his productand his product is women!"Even as action melodrama of a "Shaft" sort, the film is inept, so confused that occasionally it seems surreal???. ???lieve that Goldie, with five girls out hustling on what looks like Skid Row, could clear $3,000 a day.Max Julien seems vaguely uncomfortable impersonating another fantasy-fulfilling movie superblack, but he's genuinely funny in a couple of scenes with Richard Pryor, a first-rate comedian who plays his sidekick. Michael Campus directed the film in a manner that suggests that much of the time he must have sat in his canvas chair, afraid to look.

title: RIDIE J. GUION
description: Ridie J. Guion, a retired teacher, died here yesterday at the home of a niece, Dr. A. Parks McCombs. She was 85 years old and had lived in Wilton, Conn., since her retirement.

title: IcelandBritish Talks Set
description: LONDON, April 4 (AP)Iceland has accepted a proposal by Britain to resume highlevel talks in their fishing disputethe Foreign Office said today.

title: Judicial Reforms Proposed in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 4 The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, reversing his earlier go slow attitude, proposed a series of court reforms today for initial legislative action this year.

title: Advertising. CATV and Agencies
description: Back in 1947, recalls Frank Herman of the Cable Television Division of Teleprompter, the big, established ad agencies with all the money to spend were so locked in with radio they all but ignored that newfangled television. They left it up to new swinging agencies to take the plunge.

title: A Battle Congress Could Win
description: The Senate's failure to override President Nixon's veto of a bill to aid the handicapped amply demonstrates that Congress, as now organized and led, cannot seriously compete with the White House on the spending issue. But the expanding executive dominance over the legislative branch can be slowed or reversed in other waysand the continuing battle over L. Patrick Gray 3d is the best opportunity.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: Nixon Creates Panels to Foster Sale Products and Labor Peace
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 4President Nixon announced today the formation of two commissions, one to promote safety in consumer products, Ithe other to promote harmony in industrial relations.

title: 14 Black Seniors Awarded College Scholarships Here
description: Fourteen seniors in the city's high schools have been named among the 325 winners of college scholarships under the National Achievement Schblarship Awards program for outstanding black students.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: To gain a full measure of enjoyment from his journeys afield, the outdoorsman must be eternally inquisitive.

title: LAWYER SEES LIMITS TOEXECUTIVESILENCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) The Justice Department said today that executive privilege probably would not apply if Congress wanted to ask a White House aide if he had committed a crimebut that the decision on its application would be made by the President.tive privilegeswas criticized by several committee members.

title: IRAQKUWAIT TALK ON BOUNDARY DUE
description: KUWAIT, April 4Iraq has pulled back military forces that crossed the border with Kuwait on March 20, and Foreign Minister Murtadha Said AbdulBaqi of Iraq will come here Friday for negotiations, it was officially announced today.

title: Thomas Armstrong to Direct Whitney
description: Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, director of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia, has been named the new director of the Whitney Museum of American Art. Although he will not take office until Sept. 1, 1974, succeeding John I. H. Baur, the current director, he will join the Whitney staff on Oct. 1 of this year as associate director.

title: 2,000 in Barcelona Protest Police Shooting of Striker
description: BARCELONA, Spain, April 4 (AP)Two thousand to 3,000 people demonstrated in Barcelona today in protest against the death of a construction worker shot by the police.

title: Meat Group to Shoppers: Please, Buy Something
description: Retailers and wholesalers wooed disgruntled shoppers yesterday in an effort to revive sales diminished by the fourdayold nationwide meat boycott.

title: The Buck Starts Here
description: I am afraid none of us, and I include the representatives of the various Governments, have yet probed deeply enough into the interrelations between any comprehensive new approach on the monetary level and the nature of the changes taking place in the underlying economic process.

title: BOMB TAKEN OFF BUS IN TERMINAL
description: Acting on an anonymous phone call, the police removed a live bomb from a Greyhound bus yesterday, Just as the bus was about to leave the Port Authority Bus Terminal for Cape Cod.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A man about to go on trial for the attempted murder of three policemen notified the judge by telephone yesterday that he would not appear, that he was in a state of shock because he had learned that he could be imprisoned for a minimum of 15 years, if convicted.

title: Defendant Calls Judge Before Fleeing
description: A man about to go on trial for the attempted murder of three policemen telephoned the judge in his chambers yesterday, saying he was on his way to Puerto Rico in a state of shock.

title: U.S. Would Discuss Amity With Albania
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 The United States called today for an end to the longstanding chill in relations with Albania as part of a more vigorous American effort to improve ties with all the Communist governments of Eastern Europe.

title: New New Editor for the Week in Review
description: The appointment of Al Marlens as editor of The New York Times Week in Review was announced yesterday by Max Frankel; Sunday editor of The Times.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, April 6

title: Southeast Florida Blacked Out 2d Time as Reactor Shuts Off
description: MIAMI, April 4South Florida today suffered its second massive power failure in two days. The blackout was more extensive but slightly shorter than the one yesterday.

title: DONALD G. DOWNING
description: WORCESTER, Mass., April 4 (AP)Donald G. Downing, a former professor of mechanical engineering, who was also dean of admissions and students at the Worcester Polytechnic Institute, died today at Fairlawn Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Vietcong Welcome U.S. Visitors Guardedly
description: KIEN HOA PROVINCE, South Vietnam, April 2The small open boat chugged slowly down the Mekong River, the three of us straining our eyes in the blazing sun for any sign of life in the dense foliage on the bank.

title: Reds Play Giants Today In Opener at Cincinnati
description: Cincinnati, baseball's oldest franchise, will open the 1973 campaign today against San Francisco.

title: Mets, Yanks Fly United (on One Plane)
description: NORFOLK, Va., April 4For two teams that constantly battle each other for fans and prestige in New York, the Mets and the Yankees ended spring training with a display of togetherness that was as cozy as a family of bears hibernating in a winter den.

title: Fannie Mae Reports Rise In 4Month Commitments
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters)  The average yield on fourmonth commitments to purchase conventional mortgages rose to 8.113 per cent from 8.029 per cent In the previous auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association reported today.

title: House Approves Extension Of InterestEqualizing Tax
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill extending to June 30, 1974, President Nixon's power to tax investment by Americans in foreign securities.

title: SENATE APPROVES A SPENDING LIMIT UNDER NIXON GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Senate voted today to set a $268billion spending limit$700million below the amount asked by President Nixonand to insist that the President adhere to the spending priorities ordered by Congress.

title: JERSEY TOWNS WIN ON RENT CONTROL
description: TRENTON, April 4The State Supreme Court ruled today that municipalities have the right to enact their own rentcontrol ordinances.

title: Govirnors Dedicate Trade Center Here; World Role Is Cited
description: The $700million World Trade Center, its two 1,350foot towers the largest buildings in the world, was dedicated formally yesterday by Governors Rockefeller and Cahill.

title: Voters in Wisconsin Reject Women's Rights Amendment
description: MADISON, Wis., April 4 (AP)  Only hours after voters rejetted a state constitutional amendment that would have guaranteed equal rights for women, a group of State Senators moved today to rescind Wisconsin's ratification of the Federal equal rights amendment.

title: WILD AND IOUREL HAIL ROMANTICS
description: Music of the high romantic school was given very special treatment Tuesday night in Town Hall by Jennie Tourel and Earl Wild. It would be difficult to find two artists better suitto the occasion: Mr. Wild has long been in the vanguard of the romantic keyboard revival, and Miss Tourel illuminates anything she sings, no matter what the era.

title: People in Sports: Duran Barred
description: Roberto Duran of Panama, recognized by New York and the World Boxing Association as the lightweight champion of the world, had his license suspended yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission. The commission also warned the young fighter that his title recognition would be withdrawn if he did not defend against Ken Buchanan of Scotland in Madison Square Garden within 90 days.

title: Work or Else Program On Coast Called Failure
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 4 (Reuters)Gov. Ronald Reagan's work or else program aimed at providing job training for welfare recipients is a failure, a legislative committee reported today.

title: Personal Finance
description: The Happy Appliance Company telephoned Mary Jones, a secretary for an advertising agency, and asked if she would be a guarantor on an installment contract. Her brotherinlaw, Joseph Smith, wanted to buy a $600 color television set, payable over two years. Joe had a good job but had been with his company only six months.

title: Bengalis Held in Pakistan Long for Home
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April, 2  They are huddled in the straw shacks of Musa Colony, in guarded military camps, in bare city apartments where families sit in lonely anguish.

title: Harlem Four Are Freed After Manslaughter Pleas
description: In the final chapter of a long and complicated murder case that began nine years ago, the young men linown as the Harlem Four pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday in State Supreme Court here in return for suspended sentences.

title: Two Nominees Supported
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) The Senate Agriculture Committee approved today two Presidential nominees for posts on the 13member Federal Farm Credit Board. They are Luther W. Jenneiahn of Hilton, N.Y., and Alfred Underdahl of Hebron, N.D.

title: Bridge:
description: A recent development of interest to the devotees of the most modern of the strongclub systems is what might be called the Precision Club Club. In less than a month, the club built up a membership of more than 500 enthusiasts, who receive a bimonthly newsletter edited by Steven Altman and a copy of a recent book on the system.

title: Concern to File Action TodayBanks Find Loans in Default
description: The Equity Funding Corporation of America, caught up in a multimillion dollar scandal over bogus insurance policies and besieged by bankers for the immediate repayment of $50million in loans, disclosed last night that it would petition the court today to file for rearganization under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: FRED J. GAERTNER
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., April 4 Fred J. Gaertner, a retired partner in Jabel, Inc., a jewelry manufacturing concern in Irvington, died today in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 79 years old and lived at 305 Hartshorn Drive.

title: Calf With Heart Device Dies
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April (UPI)  A calf with an artificial heart died today, almost 19 days after the device was implanted by University of Utah scientists.

title: SLAVERY CITED IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 4 (AP) Slavery existsand we are the slaves, said Pat Robinson, a psychiatric social worker and one of several black women testifying at a hearing here on women's rights.

title: Arthur Daley
description: When I'm gone, boxing will be nothing again, once said Muhammad Ali, soaring off into a flight of fancy that usually accompanied each ego trip in earlier and better years. We shall soon see. If the former heavyweight champion of the world is not already gone, it's obvious that he is on the way.

title: Sleuth Matinee Marks 1,000th Performance
description: Sleuth the Tony Awardwinning thriller by Anthony Shaffer, gave its 1,000th performance, yesterday at the Music Box Theater.

title: Dow Chemical to Close Unit
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that its Canadian unit, Dow Chemical Canada, Ltd., would close its chlorine caustic plant in Thunder Bay, Ontario, next October because the company had been unable to completely eliminate mercury discharges from the plant. The 40 employes at the facility will be offered alternate jobs.

title: STANTON WILL GET FREEDOMS AWARD
description: Dr. Frank Stanton, who retired as vice chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System last Friday after 38 years with the company, will receive the annual award of the Four Freedoms Foundation, it was an, nounced yesterday.

title: Louisianians Move Aside for the Raging Mississippi
description: MONTZ, La., April 4The Mississippi. River has not been kind to the people of Montz.

title: StockPrice Indexes Dip To Lows as Volume Falls
description: The stock market plodded through another listless session yesterday and some of the major indicators of price action on the New York Stock Exchange slipped to new lows for the year.

title: GRAND JURY QUERIES MACKELL A 4TH TINE
description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens yesterday made his fourth appearance before a special state grand jury investigating corruption in the criminal justice system of New York City.

title: S.B.A. LETS BANKS LIFT LOAN RATES
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Small Business Administration, in an action apparently in conflict with Nixon Administration policy, this week increased by onehalf per cent the interest rate that banks can charge on smallbusiness loans.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, April 14 (UPI)Inge Hammarstroem's three goals led Sweden to an 82 rout of West Germany today in the world ice hockey championships as Sweden kept pace with the Soviet Union as theonly Unbeaten teams in the twoweek tournament. Harnmaistroem scored his goals in just over 13 minutes of play. Finland downed Poland, 50, in today's other game.

title: Juvenile Justice: Search for Reform
description: Over tuna fish and coffee, at a table in the hallway outside their chambers, the judges of the Brooklyn Family Court are trading horror storiesa psychotic child sent home because the mental hospital had no place for him, a stabbing in the courthouse stairwell, a child who is an addict and another child whose mother doesn't want her.

title: Radio
description: Talks, Sports, Events

title: No Business Like Dog Show Business
description: The dog show world was paid a high tribute by Pedro Rivero, when he said at a recent show: Everything have in the United States owe to the sport.

description: Knick's Box Score

title: Books of The Times
description: The Nixon Administration's broadsides against television news have had at least one encouraging effect. Active and broad public attention is finally being generated about an important aspect of mass medium that notoriously encourages passivity. While the quality of TV news remains a popular target for critics, professional and armchair, various polls continue to compile rising figures that find most Americans consider television to be both the main and most trusted source of their news.

title: Times Sq. Pickets Protest Nixon's Flaunting of Thieu
description: A group called the Vietnam Peace Parade Committee demonstrated in Times Square late yesterday against the visit to this country of President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam.

title: CONNECTICUT RULE ON ABORTIONS UPSET
description: NEW HAVEN, April 4 (UPI) Judge John O. Newman ruled in Federal district court today that Connecticut must pay for a welfare recipient's abortion if a doctor certifies that it is necessary.

title: SURVEYS FIND ao.p. IS STILL A MINORITY
description: President Nixon's landslide victory last November has not changed the Republican party's national status as the minority party in American politics, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: March Car Sales at Peak; Consumer Credit Climbs
description: DETROIT, April 4Americans bought more than 1.1 million new cars in March, more than in any previous month, reports from the manufacturers disclosed today.

title: Brazil Censors a Report By Paper on Censorship
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April, 4 (AP) A lengthy report describing press censorship in Brazil made by Julio Mesquita Neto before the InterAmerican Press Association was censored today in his newspaper, 0 Estado de sao Paulo.

description: British Football

title: Control Data Signs Agreement For a Joint Venture in Runumia
description: The Control Data Corporation announced here yesterday that it had signed a joint manufacturing agreement with a unit of the Rumanian Ministry of Machine Tools and Electro Techniques to build peripheral computer equipment in Bucharest.

title: Bomb Removed From Bus At Port Authority Station
description: Acting on an anonymous phone call, the police removed a liye bomb from a Greyhound bus yesterday, just as the bus Authority Bus Terminal for was about to leave the Port Cape Cod.

description: Exhibition Baseball

title: PENTAGON DOUBTS CAMBODIA'S ARMY IS NEARING DEFEAT
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Pentagon said today that it foresaw no immediate Cambodian military defeat but held out the possibility that the United States would have to mount an airlift to the besieged Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh.

title: Amin, Calling Nixon Brilliant, Asks Good UgandaU.S. Ties
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 4 In what appeared to be an attempt to improve strained relations with the United States, President Idi Amin of Uganda sent a message to President Nixon today praising him as one of the most brilliant leaders in the Western world for his efforts to end the Vietnam war.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: IN A BIND That's what the New York Public Library is in these days, and that's what the Antiquarian Booksellers Association of America is going to try to alleviate during its International Antiquarian Book Fair, which will run from today through Saturday in all the mezzanine public rooms of Carlton House, Madison Avenue and 61st Street. Proceeds from the $1.50 admission price will go to the library.

title: Highway Act Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) The House Public Works Committee rejected today an effort to repeal the Highway Beautification Act of 1965. The committee voted 27 to 8 against the repeal and defeated by voice vote another proposal to strike from the proposed bill a twoyear moratorium on removal of billboards.

title: Leader of New Business Group
description: A businessman for 33 of his 55 years, a former professional baseball player and career merchant, David Lawrence Yunich, chairman of the newly created New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, allowed an edge of resentment to harden his voice yesterday as the remarked: There has been a tremendous breakdown in business confidence in the way this city is being governed and administered. That confidence will only be restored when we get a better management of the city.

title: L.I.R.R. Train Kills Youth; Conductor, Stricken, Dies
description: BELLMORE, L. I., April 4 (AP) A high school youth working out with his track team was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train at an unguarded crossing today.

title: Victor Dolan, 45, Principal Of P.S. 298 in Ocean Hill
description: Victor Dolan, principal of Public School 298 in the Ocean Hill  Brownsville section of Brooklyn, died Tuesday in Deepdale Hospital in Little Neck, Queens, after a long illness. He was 45 years old and made his home in Little Neck.

title: Mandatory Sentence Proposed For 2dFelony Drug Offenses
description: ALBANY, April 4  The chairman of the Assembly Codes Committee, along with 11 other committee members, today proposed sweeping changes in the state's penal law that would include, but not be limited to, harsher penalties for traffickers in dangerous drugs.

title: Soprano Gets 2d Chance
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) (AP)  Mary Costa, the Metropolitan Opera soprano who missed a chance to sing at the White House last month because of, an injury, is back on the schedule to entertain at next Tuesday's state dinner to be given by President Nixon for Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Massachusetts authorities were given permission yesterday to perform an autopsy on the body of Ellen Reich of Hackensack, one of seven women slain last year the eastern part of Massachusetts. When Miss Reich's body was found last September authorities said she had been strangled. However, it was reported in Boston yesterday that new evidence showed she might have been shot.

title: Two Soldiers Are Wounded By Snipers in Ulster Cities
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 4 (AP)  Guerrillas wounded two British soldiers in sporadic sniping in Northern Ireland tonight and tried to blow up one of their favorite targets, a temporary customs post near Londonderry.

title: DR. ABRAHAM RIEGER, PHYSICIAN 68 YEARS
description: Dr. Abraham Rieger, who had spent 68 years as a general practitioner in this city, died Monday at the age of 91.

title: PENTAGON DOUBT CAMBODIA'S ARMY IS NEARING DEFEAT
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Pentagon said today that it foresaw no immediate Cambodian military defeat but held out the possibility that the United States would have to mount an airlift to the besieged Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh.

title: CELTICS TROUNCE HAWKS BY126113
description: ATLANTA, April 4  With Dave Cowens and Paul Silas combining for 30 rebounds in the first half when the game was decided, the Boston Celtics routed the Atlanta Hawks, 126113, tonight for a 20 lead in their fourofsevengame National Basketball Association playoff.

title: Credit Markets: Prices of Bonds Advance in a Dull Session
description: Bond prices wriggled higher yesterday in another lackluster trading session, with investors still finding little incentive to buy longterm issues while given very attractive shortterm alternatives.

title: HIGH AIDE OF PARK IS HELD IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 4 South Korean officials have disclosed that one of President Park Chung Hee's most trusted officers, Maj. Gen. Yoon Pil Yong, has been arrested and is in prison awaiting indictment before a courtmartial.

title: Kleindienst Disagrees With Ervin on Arrests
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst disputed today Senator Sam J. Ervin's contention that the Senate could have Presidential aides arrested for refusing to testify in the Watergate affair.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 5, 1972 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SKYLAB SHOT SET FOR NEXT MONTH
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., April 4 Skylab, the first American space station for longduration manned missions, is now set for launching on May 14, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

title: Gravel Urges Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, urged today that Senate Hearings be held on the environmental impact of the proposed transAlaska oil pipeline. A dispute over the effect of the 789mile pipeline on the ecology remains unresolved despite court rulings holding up construction of the $3.5billion project.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Cleveland vs. Philadelphia

title: SOME PRICES CUT BY MEAT BOYCOTT
description: The fivedayold nationwide meat boycott gave its first evidence yesterday of whittling prices at the retail level.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: F.D.A. Calls for Tight Curbs To Fight Sedative Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration recommended today tighter controls for the sedative methaqualone, which the agency said is being widely misused by American youth.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: THIEU MAKES VOW ON TROOP RETURN
description: WASHINGTON, April 5President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam pledged todayin his first American public appearance  that he would never, never ask the United States to send troops back to Vietnam.

title: Guide
description: BIRTHDAY MUSIC The Greenwich Music School is celebrating its 68th birthday, a ripe old institutional age, particularly in the changing Village. The schoolwhich has 500 students from 3 to 63 years of age, taking private instruction or in classes for music or dancehas been offering a series of free concerts this seasonindeed, it has done so ever since it was founded as a function of the Greenwich House settlement.

title: Suicide Thought to Have Been Fugitive in U.S. Fraud Case
description: NEWARK, April 5  Federal officials said today they hoped to establish soon whether an apparent suicide found aboard a Trans World Airlines plane in Honolulu was a former Passaic electronics manufacturer sought by the Government for the last three years.

title: Amtrak Drops a Train
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Amstrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, announced today it was dropping its train services between Washington and Parkersburg, W. Va., effective May 5.

title: Rail TonMileage Rose 10% From YearAgo Level
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.3 billion tonmiles, 10 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Cumulative volume for the first 13 weeks of 1973 was an estimated 204 billion tonmiles, an alltime high for a single quarter of any year. Sales to the Soviet Union have resulted in the largest movement of export grain in United States history. A year ago, 299,520 cars of grain were loaded in the first quarter. The figure rose to 420,264 this year.

title: Cards of the Leaders
description: PAR FOR THE COURSE

title: Negotiator of Accord
description: When Assistant Attorney General Kent Frizzell arrived in Wounded Knee, S. D., last week to take over Government negotiations with insurgent Indians, the situation seemed hopelessly deadlocked and edging toward violence. Two other Justice Department officials had made no headway with the insurgents, and Richard Wilson, the the president of the Oglala Sioux, was impatiently threatening an attack on the rebel camp by, his own armed followers. Unflustered, the 44 year  old Mr. Frizzell plunged into the task of conciliation and compromise. He first pacified Mr. Wilson, then began the delicate talks that led yesterday to an agreement that is to end the militants occupation of the historic village.

title: Lament for the Language Training Centers
description: There is an old Russian story about a manse who dived into a hole in the wall for safety from a pursuing cat. Waiting for the cat to go away, the mouse heard a dog barking, and came out, confident that the cat would not remain in the vicinity of a barking dog. Whereupon the cat, as he pounced upon the emerging mouse, said exultingly: How useful it is to know a foreign language!

title: Price Skyrocket
description: The error of President Nixon's premature decision to relax mandatory pricewage controls is no longer open to serious debate. The astronomic rise of wholesale prices in the second full month of Phase 3even sharper than their alarming jump in the first monthbetokens imminent collapse of the antiinflation offensive the President initiated so effectively twenty months ago.

title: Report Backs Fuentes
description: A special report to School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner on charges of antiSemitism against Luis Fuentes, the controversial superintendent in Manhattan's School District 1, has found that MrFuentes is at the present time neither a bigot nor a racist. Details on Page 27.

title: Bridge:
description: According to recent hews reports, a Moscow committee has imposed a Soviet veto on organized bridge, along with other undesirable activities, such as women's soccer.

title: G.O.P. Panel Fills Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) Robert R. Rousek, Assistant State Treasurer of California since 1969, has been named director of communications for the Republican National Committee. Mr. Rousek, who was in charge of legislative and public information activities under California's Treasurer, Ivy Baker Priest, was a news agency executive before entering public relations work.

title: Phone Call Set Off Equity Funding Case
description: By ROBERT J. COLE The mammoth financial scandal at the Equity Funding Corporation of America began to come to light with a telephone call early last month frpm disgruntled former executive, according to Raymond L. Dirks, the man who took the call.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ROSCOE, N. Y.A few tenacious anglers were still in the bar of Douglas Bury's Antrim Lodge the afternoon of April 2, the day after the opening of New York State's trout season, but most had been driven home by rain that began to fall Sunday afternoon.

title: Cuite Stands, if Invisibly, At City's Center of Power
description: When troops of Girl Scouts and gradeschoolers go to watch the City Council, and sit in the balcony to peer silently at the proceedings in the ornate chamber below, there is something they do not know.

title: AMEX PRICES HIT A 16MONTH LOW
description: In steppedup trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange fell yesterday to the lowest level in more than 16 months.

title: Recently Published Books
description: A Family of Peoples: The U.S.S.R. After 50 Years, edited by Jessica Smith (New World Review, $1.95 paperbound).

title: Kaufman Due to Succeed Friendly on U.S. Bench
description: One of the country's most important judgeships will change hands on May 28 when Irving R. Kaufman succeeds Henry J. Friendly as chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Paribas Organizes Holding Company With British Bank
description: PARIS, April 5The Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas,Paribas  already one of the most powerful banks in France, today announced a series of financial operations to strengthen and extend its holdings.

title: Equity Financing
description: EXCEL INVESTMENTS COMPANY, a mortgage insurance holding company, yesterday, said it had postponed indefinitely a proposed offering of 310,000 shares of its common stock because of market conditions. The company stock was up 1 at 18 on the American Stoak Exchange.

title: Rod Steiger to Wed
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 5 (AP)Rod Steiger, the actor, and Sherry Nelson, a secretary, have applied for a marriage license. Mr. Steiger, 47 years old, and Miss Nelson, 36, submitted the application at the Santa Monica County Building yesterday. The marriage will be Mr. Steiger's fourth and Miss Nelson's third.

title: FOE OF ABORTIONS OFFERS NEW BTUS
description: ALBANY, April 5Senator James H. Donovan, Republican of Chadwicks and a major opponent of abortion, held a public hearing today on a package of bills he is sponsoring that he hopes will provide women with alternatives to abortion.

title: GOLD PRICE RISES AS DOLLAR EASES
description: LONDON, April 5 (AP)Gold closed steady on European markets today after a volatile session. The United States dollar weakened.

title: McCord Plans News Conference to Break His Public Silence on Watergate Plot
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 James W. McCord Jr., who has refused for nine months to talk, to reporters about the Watergate conspiracy, said today that he would hold a news conference on the subject in the next few days.

title: Amtrak Drops a Train
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, announced today it was dropping Its train services between Washington and Parkersburg, W. Va., effective May 5.

title: MESSMER NAMES CABINET IN PARIS
description: PARIS, April 6The new French Cabinet, announced today, contains a number of changes but few real surprises.

title: UPTURN EXTENDED BY BOND MARKET
description: The bond market extended its modest upturn yesterday, shrugging off another sharp increase in wholesale prices during March and reports of intensified fighting in South Vietnam.

title: People and Business
description: Thomas R. Bomar, a 35yearold executive in the real estate and mortgage fields, has been selected by President Nixon to be chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The President said yesterday in San Ciemente, Calif that he will nominate Mr. Bomar for a term on the board expiring in June, 1974, and will designate him as chairman when his nomination is confirmed.

title: U.S. Trust Company Net Up
description: The United States Trust Company reported yesterday that net operating earnings for the first quarter rose 32.5 per cent to $1,888,185, or 90 cents a share, from $1,425,058, or 68 cents a share in the first quarter last year. Total operating income increased to $15,732,211 from $12,832,659, a rise of 22.6 er cent.

title: Mrs. Doris S. Corwith, Led American Legion Auxiliary
description: CENTERPORT, L. I., April 5 Mrs. Doris Sweet Corwith, who was national president of the American Legion Auxiliary in 193940, and later a radio producer, for the National Broadcasting Company, died yesterday in a Huntington nursing home. She was 76 years old and lived here.

title: Melchior Rites in Denmark
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 5 (AP)  An organist played the funeral march from Wagner's Gotterdlimmerung as the ashes of Lauritz Melchior, the Wagnerian tenor, were carried down the aisle of Copenhagen's Cathedral of Our Lady today. The hourlong service followed specifications in the will of the Danishborn singer who died at the age of 82 on March 18 at Santa Monica, Calif. 1b Melchior, the singer's son, brought the ashes here for interment at the family burial site.

title: Mississippi Close to Record Crests in Two States
description: The floodwaters of the Mississippi River inched toward record crests yesterday, claiming six lives, leaving thousands homeless and bringing estimates of expected damage in Missouri and Illinois to $41million.

title: Business Briefs
description: Darrell M. Trent, acting director of the Office of Emergency Preparedness, said yesterday in Washington that if industry does its part, there should be no major national gasoline shortage this year, and that the Federal Government holds the possibility of gasoline rationing as highly unlikely.

title: Unity for Civic Progress
description: The merger of the city's two most prestigious business associations into a unified New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry reflects a recognition by the leaders of the business community of the need for much more active involvement on their part in helping to solve New York City's monumental problems.

title: John J. Kenny Is Given a 6Year Term for Extortion
description: TRENTON, April 5  John J. Kenny, former Freeholder and political power in Hudson County, was sentenced to a maximum of six years in state prison today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: One of the country's most important judgeships will change hands on May 28 when Irving R. Kaufman succeeds Henry J. Friendly as, chief judge of the United; States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judao Friendly will step down as chief judge as he approaches his 70th birthday, but he will remain an active member of the court. Judge Kaufman, who is 62, will take over the administration of the busy Federal appeals court that covers all of New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

title: NIXON WITHDRAWS GRAY NOMINATION AS F.B.I. DIRECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 5President Nixon accepted today a request from L. Patrick Gray 3d that his nomination to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation be withdrawn.

title: Moroccans Refuse Entry To a Times Correspondent
description: RABAT, Morocco, April (Reuters)  Moroccan authorities refused entry yesterday to Henry. Giniger, the Madrid correspondent of The New York Times, who arrived by air from Paris.

title: Behind the Metropolitan Boycott, a Militant Union
description: On the second floor, a printing press nicknamed Big Apollo churns out 20,000 Boycott Meat leaflets an hour. On the third floor, cartons containing 5,000 leaflets each are stacked on dollies along the hall, to be taken quickly from there down to the cars doubleparked on Broadway.

title: Kazuo Kikuta, 65, Playwright And Producer, Led Toho Troupe
description: TOKYO, April 5 (AP)Kazuo Kikuta, managing director of the Toho Company, one of the giants of the flourishing Japanese entertainment industry and a leading producerplaywright, died here today of a stroke. He was 65 years old.

title: Report Backs Fuentes
description: A special report to School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner on charges of antiSemitism against Luis Fuentes, the controversial superintendent in Manhattan's School District 1, has found that Mr. Fuentes is at the present time neither a bigot nor a racist. Details on Page 27.

title: Concert
description: Richard Dufallo conducted a student ensemble in an appetizing concert of relatively recent music at the Juilliard Theater on Wednesday night. Mr. Dufallo, music director of the Juilliard School's 20th Century Music Series, drew poised performances from his players in Varese's Integrales, Ruggles's Angels and, in its New York premiere, Messiaen's Couleurs de la Cite Celeste.

title: F. Alou on First for Yankees in Boston, With Blomberg dh
description: BOSTON, April 5  Undaunted by their failure to win New York, the Yankees prepared today to put into effect Phase II of their 1973 operationwinning the American League pennant.

title: Shellfish Contaminated
description: BOSTON, April 5 (AP) Nearly 41 per cent of all shellfish that reached Massachusetts markets exceeded allowable limits of fecal coliform bacteria from human waste according to a 1971 General Accounting Office test.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: PATH riders using special trains and buses provided because of the fivedayold carmen's strike continued to commute with little difficulty yesterday, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Authority officials said 1,400 more riders used the alternative transportation arranged because of the strike, bringing the total to 41,400. The Port Authority TransHudson rail line usually carries 145,000 riders a day, including 40,000 regular commuters, the officials said.

title: OffDuty Policeman Is Wounded Trying to Prevent IND Mugging
description: An offduty patrolman was seriously wounded last night whe he intervened in a mugging in a subway passageway at 33d Street and Eight Avenue.

title: The Other Side of the Oil Thing
description: Endless words have been written about the world oil shortage, the dependence of the Western world on Middle East oil, and the alarming political leverage gained by Mideast governments over future oil prices, Western industrial growth and world monetary stability.

title: Israeli Reports a Dead Sea Scroll Contains Puritanical Injunctions
description: JERUSALEM, April 5 (AP) The archeologist Yigal Yadin reports that one of the Dead Sea scrolls just deciphered in Israel contains a new, hitherto unknown version of God's commands to Moses and is far more puritanical than Biblical injunction.

title: PENTAGON RECALLING TAINTED MUSHROOMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) At least 800 cases of canned mushrooms sold to the Defense Department are being revelled because of deadly botulism contamination, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.

title: Foundations Resist U.S. Aid to States for Regulating

title: BUCKS TAKE 21 LEAD AS ROBERTSON STARS
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 5 (AP)Oscar Robertson made 10 straight fieldgoal attempts during one span, scored 34 points and led Milwaukee to a 11393 victory over the Golden State Warriors tonight as the Bucks took a 21 lead in their National Basketball Association playoff series.

description: WASHINGTON, April 5Governor Rockefeller declared tonight that the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound between Rye and Oyster Bay, L. I., would be built despite opposition from the Interior Department and many local officials.

title: HAROLD TUCKER, 58, OF QUEENS LIBRARY
description: Harold W. Tucker, director of the Queens Borough Public Library, 8911 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, died Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 60 Brixton Road in Garden City, L. I.

title: Equity Funding
description: Did the top, executives of Equity Funding Corporation of America borrow an idea from Nikolai Gogol's nineteenthcentury novel, Dead Souls? In Gogol's classic, the adventurer Pavel Ivanovich Chichikov tours the countryside of feudal Russia, buying ownershipat very low pricesof deceased serfs. His eventually frustrated scheme was to get rich by mortgaging these dead souls with a financial institution which believed they still lived.

description: For the first time in the 17year history of the International Auto Show here, advocates of mass transportation will have an exhibit urging visitors to the show to leave their cars home, and take a train or bus The show opens tomorrow at the Coliseum.

title: MOZART ENHANCED BY BACHAUER FLAIR
description: Gina Bachauer's performance of the Mozart Piano Concerto No. 9 in E flat (K. 271) Wednesday night at Philharmonic Hall was a magisterial one, and it went a long way toward redeeming what had been a rather plodding evening up to that point. Miss Bachauer combines all the elements of a superb Mozart style in her playing: strength, wit, clarity, singing tone, artful simplicity. It was the work of a mature artist who hasn't forgotten about youthful vigor and high spirits.

title: Brokers Value Collateral Stock at Zero Chapter X Bankruptcy Action Filed
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday ordered its member firms to settle transactions in shares of the Equity Funding Corporation of America that were entered into by their customers before trading was suspended just after noon on March 27. The exchange's order was one of several developments yesterday in the tangled affairs of Equity Funding and its insurance subsidiary, the Equity Funding Life Insurance Corn pany, the center of a massive scandel involving the alleged creation and sale to reinsurers of bogus insurance policies. At a news conference yesterday, James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, was asked to comment on the situation at Equity Funding, whose shares were suspended from trading on the Big Board on March 27.Protecting MarketWe did everything we could to protect the integrity of the market, Mr. Needham stated. All trades that we know about will be honored and this will not cause any member firm to have a capital problem, as far as we can determine.He said the exchange made its first inquiry into Equity Funding on March 19, when an automatic kickout in our stock watch program aroused our interest.There were subsequent inquiries over the next several days and on March 23, when the exchange called in the company president, he said there was no truth to the rumors, according to Mr. Needham. On March 27, we had something and put the suspension into effect, the exchange chairman added.

title: Truman Highway Backed
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 5 (AP)The Florida Senate votec today to rename a portion of U.S. Highway 1 in the Florida Keys the Harry S. Trumar Overseas Highway. The bill which now goes to the House notes that, as president, Mr Truman spent many vacations at Key West.

title: Books of The Times
description: In several ways, the publication of Revolutionary Suicide, by Black Panther party cofounder Huey P. Newton, is a climactic event. To begin with, rumors of its contents have been circulating for several years nowone had heard as long ago as, 1970 that Mr. Newton was at work on a major study of suicideso the sheer pressure of waiting has raised expectations. Second, Mr. Newton is the last of the Panther leaders to be heard from with a major statement  Eldridge Cleaver, Bobby Seal e, George Jackson (who was appointed a general and field marshal of the party before his death in 1971), and several minor figures have all written books so, in a way, the appearance of Revolutionary Surcide represents an ultimate revelation, a collapse of last barriers, a closing of the circle. But the disappointing, almost terrible news is that Revolutionary Suicide isno other way to put ita bore.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Absolutism in human affairs prevents the intellectual discrimination necessary to further both the imperatives of justice and the needs of public security. This is apparent in the argument of those who take contrary positions on whether the death sentence should be mandatory. title: The Changing Midwest
description: ST. PAUL, April 5The land in the upper Middle West still looks a little bleak and winterweary these early April days, but a hungry world is crying for fodder, and the outlook for the farmers out here is unusually bright.

title: The Screen:A Comedy, 'Come Have Coffee With Us.'
description: Alberto Lattuada's 1970 Italian comedy, "Come Have Coffee With Us," which opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room, has a terrible title and it pursues  for more time than the subject may deserve  a phobia that is seemingly shared by all Italian men over the age of 40. That is, that a middle-aged man's sexual satisfaction is quite as dangerous as the coronary it will lead to.Are Italian menfor all of their eyeball-rolling when a pretty girl walks by a sidewalk cafe, and for all of their appreciative pinches in crowded busesso guilt-ridden that only death can offer true relief? It would seem that way according to the subcategory of Italian comedy to which "Come Have Coffee With Us" belongs. It's, not something that most American men think much about, possibly because we are being constantly reassured of our inexhaustible energy by everything from television commercials to porno films.Yet even if the fear does lurk somewhere within us, it's probably not the reason that "Come Have Coffee With Us" seems quite as funny as it does, or, for that matter, why Marco Ferreri's "The Conjugal Bed" and Pietro Germi's "The Climax" also were so amusing (some years ago). The reason, principally, is Ugo Tognazzi, a fine, very comic actor who, for approximately 20 years now, has been defining the pitfalls of middle-aged passion so eloquently.As in the Ferreri and Germi films, the really ageless Mr. Tognazzi is again impersonating a man whose desires are bigger than his ventricles. This time he plays a petty tax official, assigned to a small town in southern Italy, where he decides to settle down as the husband of a well-to-do but no longer young bourgeoise and finds himself also the lover of his two equally over-age sisters-in-law. It all works beautifully until his roving eye falls on the unattended serving girl.The idea is not terribly funny, but Mr. Tognazzi, and the small town setting provided by Mr. Lattuada, are. The actor is a model of what I can describe only as a thoroughly masculine but dainty self-assurance, whether he is carefully placing a toothpick in an ashtray (after cleaning one ear and one fingernail) or pompously explaining to the three sisters, on an early meeting, how an old war wound has left him with a troublesome (but not incapacitating) deviated rectum. The three women are so smitten that not even a stroke cools their devotion.The sisters are admittedly grotesque (especially the tall one with a huge mole at the side of her mouth), and Mr. Lattuada treats them with a certain comic awe, if not fear. Never for a moment do they suspect their capacity to wound with love. This fantasy, I should emphasize, is not only a man's, but also an Italian man's, and all objections should be directed to him in Rome, where, according to my fantasy, he is at this very minute, sitting in a cafe enjoying the passing parade and the exquisite guilt pangs the parade prompts.
