Mr. Durant, retired bureau chief of Tass, the Soviet press agency, died last Nov. 29 at the age of 83. At the service, Bach's Sonata No. 1 in B minor and Mozart's Quartet in D major will ho played.

title: Saint Laurent Is a Favorite Of Rivals, Too
description: PARIS, April 5The French readytowear showings have a new star. It's the same as the old star: Yves Saint Laurent. You can tell he's the favorite of the other designers here. They do him the ultimate homage of copying his styles right and lefteven his couture collection of two years ago, which was vilified for looking tarty. The look is all over the runways these daysthe hennaed hair, the skinny skirts, the fluffy chubby jackets.

title: Member of Hell's Angels Conyioted in Coast Murder
description: MARTINEZ, Calif., April 5 (AP)A member of Hell's Angels was found guilty today in the strangulation death of Georgia motorcyclist and not guilty in the torture death of another. The bodies of both victims were found in the motorcycle club's reputed burial ground near Ukiah, Calif.

title: MANES IS ENDORSED BY G.O.P. IN QUEENS
description: The Queens Republican organization, which met strong tankandfile resistance when it endorsed Robert F. Wagner, a Democrat, for Mayor, has now endorsed another Democrat, Borough President Donald R. Manes, for reelection.

title: INDIANS AND U. S. SIGN AGREEMENT AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., April 5The 37day confrontation between armed Indian insurgents and Federal agents at Wounded Knee ended this afternoon.

title: Soviet Seen Stalling on Troop Cuts to Break Link to Security Talks
description: MOSCOW, April 5The conviction is growing among Western diplomats that the Soviet Union is stalling talks in Vienna on force reductions in Central Europe to break the linkage that the United States sought to establish between those talks and separate prepalations in Helsinki for a European security conference.

title: LUTHER R. FOIE, MISSIONARY, DIES
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 5  Luther it. Fowle, a retired missionary in Turkey for what is now the United Church Board of World Ministries, died today in the Courtland Gardens Convalescent Home. He was 86 years old and lived in Thetford, Vt., and West Dennis, Mass., until a stroke two years ago.

title: Mrs. Kate Butler Righter Wed To Bruce E. Wallis in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, April 5Mrs. Kate Butler Righter of New York and Buffalo was married here this afternoon to Bruce Exton Wallis, a vice president of the Price Paper Corporation in New York. The Rev. Thomas P. Stewart, minister of the Westminster Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Edward H. Butler, mother of the bride and president and publisher of The Buffalo Evening News. Only members of the immediate families and a few outoftown guests were in attendance.

title: Events Today
Democrats Plan a Fight on Nixon's Proposed Defense Information Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Democratic Senators are preparing a strong counterattack next week against the Nixon Administration's new proposal to impose restrictions on the dissemination of Governmentb information on national defense and foreign relations.

title: ChurchSchool Aid Banned in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 5A threejudge Federal Court struck down New Jersey's $19.5million program of state aid to private and parochial schools on the ground that it violated First Amendment guarantees in the United States Constitution for the separation of church and state.

title: Firm Congress Stand on Jews in Soviet Is Traced to Efforts by Those in U.S,.;
description: WASHINGTON, April 5At a tirne when the Nixon Administration is dominating Congress on most domestic and international issues, Congress seems to have gained the upper hand on a key question of foreign policythe linking of a trade agreement with the Soviet Union to the problems of Russian Jews.

title: Private Fence Bars Access to State Park
description: WOODSTOCK, N. Y. A sixfoothigh fence made of chain link and barbed wire with a locked gate has been erected and maintained here by private landowners, blocking public access to 500 acres of state park land atop Overlook Mountain.

title: City Considers Fencing Washington Square Park
description: ?? plained that their renowned park, a magnet for the city's cultural underground on sunny Sunday mornings, has been swamped with derelicts, narcotics addicts and sexual perverts. Some residents say they have stopped going intd the park, even during the day.

title: Advance Party of U.S. Officials Arrives in Peking
description: PEKING, April 5, (Reuters) An advance party of Amep Ican officials headed by Alfred le S. Jenkins arrived in Peking tonight to establish the first formal American presence here for more, than 20 years.

title: Xuan Thuy, in Paris Farewell, Charges U. S. With Stalling on Pact
description: PARIS, April 5Xuan Thuy, who was North Vietnam's representative in Paris for more than four years of formal and secret Vietnam talks, said tonight that the United States was trying to stall on applying provisions of the ceasefire agreement.

title: A Bill on Campaign Funds Is Passed by State Senate
description: TRENTON, April 5The Senate today passed a strong campaign disclosure bill that promises criminal penalties and forfeiture of office for all elected state and local officials who wilfully fail to report all sources of funds spent on their campaigns.

title: Hospital Solution Recalled
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 5 (AP)  Hospitals around the country are being asked by Cutter Laboratories, Inc., to return millions of bottles of intravenous solutions manufactured at its Chattanooga, Tenn., Plant. In Washington, the Food and Drug Administration said that it had initiated the recall because, while there was no proof that the Cutter products were contaminated, there also was no assurance that sterility would be established and maintained.

title: His Uncle Sam Helped Curb Hot Temper, J. C. Snead Says
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5A man named Snead was among the leaders today after the first round of the Masters Golf Tournament, but it was J. C. Snead, not Sam.

title: Brooklyn Postal Workers Threatening a Job Action
description: The 4,000member Brooklyn local of the American Postal Workers Union warned yesterday of possible job action that could halt the mails in Brooklyn on Monday.

title: 10 Baseball Openers Today; Seaver vs. Carlton at Shea
description: Surrounded by the sounds of playoffs in hockey and basketball, the baseball seasib wukk return to the sporting scene in force today with 10 opening games from Boston to San Diego.

title: Wednesday Fights
description: Cagliari, ItalyAntonio Puddu, Italy, knocked out Dominque Azzaro, France, 1 round, lightweights.

title: Report to Scribner Denies Fuentes Is Bigot
description: A report to School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner on charges of antiSemitism against Luis Fuentes, the controversial superintendent in Manhattan's School District 1, has found that Mr. Fuentes is at the present time, neither a bigot nor a racist.

title: Hamburger May Climb Over the Price Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  The Cost of Living Council raised the possibility today that the price of hamburger could rise above the meat price ceilings imposed by the Nixon Administration.

title: Marmalade Inside the Nut Torte
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: U.S. Anger Over P.O.W.'s Imperils Aid, Brooke Says
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 5Senator Edward W. Brooke, who is on a tour of Indochina, said today that the anger in the United States over mistreatment of prisoners of war by the Communists could jeopardize future aid to North Vietnam and to other countries of Indochina.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly yesterday to require President Nixon to get specific Congressional approval before giving foreign aid to North Vietnam. The 88to3 vote was also a warning that the Senate would be unlikely to approve such aid, which the President favors. As one of the limitation's three opponents put it, This is telegraphing the punch that there ain't gonna be no aid.  [Page 1, Columns 23.]

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 2 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 2 P.M.)

title: COMPANIES RUSH TO BUY OWN STOCK
description: The unprecedented rush by corporations to acquire their own shares picked tip momentum in the closing days of March and is continuing strong so far in April.

title: Roads Bill Barring Transit Aid Gains
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The House Public Works Committee set the stage today for one of the first big floor battles in the House this year by approving a twoyear, $13billion highway construction bill that would forbid any of the money to be used for mass transit systems.

title: Desalting Extension Voted
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) The House Water and Power Resources Subcommittee voted today to continue operations of Government desalting plants at Roswell, N. M., and Freeport, Tex. President Nixon's budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 calls for closing of both plants now being operated by the Office of Saline Water.

title: DR. ROBERT A. TURNER
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 5 Dr. Robert A, Turner, who headed Turner Associates, a consulting pharmacologist organization, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford. He was 56 years old.

title: Protection Is Seen for Policyholders
description: The Life Insurance Institute said yesterday it believed that holders of insurance policies issued by subsidiaries of the Equity Funding Corporation of America would be pretty surely protected, even if the company goes bankrupt.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and Ameriean Stock Exchange this week issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following.

title: Strike Set at Ohio Jeep Plant
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 5 (UPI) The United Automobile Workers announced today that it would strike the American Motors Jeep Corporation facility here tomorrow, calling 4,000 workers off the job. The strike, the first authorized walkout at the plant in more than 30 years, was reportedly called because of numerous unresolved grievances.

title: Hurnan Blood and Marrow Cells Produced Inside a Living Mouse
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory have developed way of producing human blood and bloodforming cells inside a living mouse.

title: Lada, a Soviet Car, Planned for Sale in U.S.
description: The Satra Corporation announced here yesterday that it would offer a Sovietbuilt passenger car in the United States.

title: 66 JOURNALISTS BACK WBAI IN LETTER ISSUE
description: Sixtysix editors, reporters and writers and the Office of Communication of the United Church of Christ have filed an miens curiae brief with the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, defending the right of radio station WBAIFM to keep its news sources confidential.

title: Cost of Renovation At Yankee Stadium Climbs $7Million
description: The estimated cost of rebuilding Yankee. Stadium has jumped almost $7million to $27.9million in less than a year and before construction has started, Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday.

title: Senate Votes to Give Veto To Congress on Hanoi Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to forbid any reconstruction aid to North Vietnam unless President Nixon obtained specific and prior approval of Congress. The 88to3 vote represented an effort by members of the Senate to hold Mr. Nixon to his ledge to consult with Congress before carrying out his plan for postfar assistance in Indochina. More important, however, the vote constituted a w'rning 'a message to the Administration, a's several Senators described itthat aid to Hanoi would not be likely to win Senate approval in any event.

title: Pacers Move Ahead, 3 to 1, By Topping Rockets, 97.95
description: DENVER, April 5 (UPI)Billy Kellerhit a 3point basket with 14 seconds remaining tonight to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 9795 triumph over the Denver Rockets and a 31 lead for the defending American Basketball Association champions in the fourofsevengame playoff series.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: International Fare, Vigorously Spiced
description: Put a Thai chef named Tu in the kitchen, a Latin American name on the dockside door and a smart collection of international dishes on the inexpensive menu and you have one of the best cheap restaurants in the city.

title: SuddenDeath Rule, 2Point Play Voted Down by N.F.L. Owners
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 5The National Football League's owners, at their annual meeting here today passed up two chances to make their game a more dramatic one, but did aprove four minor rule changes. Proposals to reinstitute the 2point conversion rule used in the old American Football League and to make mandatory suddendeath overtime play at the conclusion of tie games were voted down.

title: EL DIARIO'S SALES HALTED BY STRIKE
description: El DiarioLa Prensa, the Spanish language daily, failed to reach the city's newsstands yesterday as a result of a strike by pressmen and stereotypers.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1973, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: For Vietnamese, Pleasant Days at the Seashore Again
description: VUNG TAU, South Vietnam, April 1The traffic from the city grinds bumper to bumper on weekends. The long, white curve of beach disappears beneath the crush of bathers, Coke bottles and beer cans. And the strains of Jesus Chrik Superstar echoing from thousands of cassette tape recorders rend the air.

title: Westbury Track to Show Rangers, Knicks on TV
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 5 Roosevelt Raceway will carry the home playoff games of the New York Rangers and Knicks via cable color tel vision during the nights of harness racing at the Westbury track.

title: Iowa State Moves to Front In N.C.A.A. Gymnastics
description: EUGENE, Ore., April 5 (AP) Favored Iowa State moved into the lead with a solid 161.90 score today as the 30th National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastics championships got under way on the University of Oregon campus.

title: Nixon Election Unit Enlarging Its Staff As Rebuttal Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) Five months after its original mission was accomplished, the Committee for the Reelection of the President is still in business and about to enlarge its staff.

title: Ban on Atomic Power Plants Urged by Senate Energy Unit
description: TRENTON, April 5  A special State Senate Committee on Energy and the Environment called today for a ban on the operation in New Jersey of any nuclear power plant not now under construction until a thorough, safe and permanent system of radioactive Waste disposal is available.

title: Virtuoso, at 44, Recalls Mostly Sunny Career
description: At 44 and in his pianistic prime, Gary Graffman might seem an odd candidate for nostalgia. If anything, he is still regarded by the public as a senior member in that loosely defined category of young American pianists. But there he was, giving a recital Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall celebrating the 25th anniversary of his concert debut.

title: Japan Will Clamp Down On Hoarding of Key Goods
description: TOKYO, April 5Japan's Justice Ministry said today that the Government would invoke its pricecontrol ordinance to clamp down drastically on speculations in, and hoarding of key consumer goods by major Japanese trading houses.

title: Soviet Eye Surgeon Tells of Using Laser To Treat Glaucoma
description: A Soviet eye surgeon has reported success with a laser beam treatment for glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness.

title: ANTIU.S. CHARGES STIR BONN DEBATE
description: BONN, April 5The lower house of Parliament spent good part of the day today debating whether a wave of antiAmericanism was sweeping West Germany, as Opposition conservatives assert.

title: Theater: Wosmersizolm
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 5. It is curious how tastes change from generation to generation. In its day, Ibsen's Rosmersholsn was an illregarded pieceits premiere production ran only 10 performances, which was particularly unhappy for Ibsen who was working for 10 per cent of the gross instead of his customary flat fee. Nowadays Rosmershoim is surely one of the most immediate of Ibsen's plays, yet paradoxically it is also one of the most neglected in the Englishspeaking theater.

title: Cosmetics: Wrinkles Weren't a Problem
description: The famous red door of the Elizabeth Arden salon opened to an unusual group of clients the other morning. Six members of the Girls Club of New Yorkthe youngest 11, the oldest 16had come to be beautified. Since it was unlikely that they would return as paying customers for awhile, the girls were shown how to do their own hair and nails.

title: EL DIARIO'S SALES HALTED BY STRIKE
description: El DiarioLa Prensa, the Spanish language daily, Ailed to reach the city's newsstands yesterday as a result of a strike by pressmen and stereotypers.

title: Shane Gould Sets Medley Mark
description: CINCINNATI, April 5 (AP)Keena Rothhammer, a 16yearold from Santa Clara, Calif., scored her second victory in two nights, and Shane Gould of Australia broke an {tmerican record tonight in theAmateur Athletic Union's national indoor shortcourse swimming championships.

title: Calling Central Park Neglected, Clurman Issues Plea for Funds
description: The city's Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator went before a Brooklyn audience last night to seek support for what he said would be a campaign to save Central Park from widespread deterioration.

title: CITY AIDES DEFEND EASERENT SYSTEM
description: The Lindsay administration's top housing officials declared yesterday that local bills to repeal or suspend the controversial maximumbaserent formula of the rentcontrol law were illconceived and potentially disastrous as well as illegal under state law.

title: SADIE E. BROWN, 82, OF COLLEGIATE, DEAD
description: Sadie E. Brown, who founded the Collegiate Secretarial Institute, now the Collegiate Institute, in 1922, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived at 12 East 86th Street.

title: FUTURES STRONG IN BEEF AND HOGS
description: Cattle and hogs brought prices a penny a pound lower Than Wednesday's levels at major terminals yesterday, but in futures trading live beef cattle contracts and live hog contracts showed price strength on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: PATH riders using special trains and buses provided because of the fivedayold carmen's strike continued commute with little difficulty yesterday, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Authority officials said 1,400 more riders used the alternative transportation arranged because of the strike, bringing the total to 41,400. The Port Authority TransHudson rail line usually carries 145,000 riders a day, including 40,000 regular commuters, the officials said.

title: Donald Tober Weds Ms. Donovan
description: Mrs. Barbara Starkey Donovan, editor in chief of Bride's Magazine, and Donald Gibbs Tober, president of the Sugar Foods Corporation in Brooklyn, were married here yesterday afternoon by Judge Shanley Epeth of the Civil Court of the City of New York, in his chambers.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: A.B. C. to Drop Six Shows, Including Mod Squad
description: Six American Broadcasting Company television shows will not return next season, but the stars of two of them, The Julie Andrews Hour and The Paul Lynde Show, will be back under different circumstances.

title: TEACHERS WIN SUIT OVER MEETING RAN
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn awarded a total of $5,000 yesterday to eight white teachers who had sued the African American Teachers Association Inc., charging that they were barred from a public meeting at a BedfordStuyvesant school.

title: CURB ON SCHOOL AID IS UPSET IN FLORIDA
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 5 (AP)The Florida Supreme Court ordered state education officials today to stop withholding school aid from counties where real estate is underassessed.

title: F.C.C. LICENSE, BILL OPPOSED BY BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The chairman of the Association of Minority Broadcasters, told the House Communications and Power subcommittee today that a number of black owners of radio stations oppose the Federal Communication Commission's proposed license renewal legislation.

title: GROWTH RATE OFF FOR MONEY SUPPLY
description: Growth in the nation's money supply is continuing to slow, the Federal Reserve System disclosed yesterday.

title: Legal Cliffhanger
description: In his message on human resources, President Nixon said that the O.E.O.'s legal services program had done much in its sevenyear history to breathe new life into the cherished concept of equal justice for all. The President promised legislation to perpetuate legal services for the indigent through an independent corporation with safeguards against politicization.

title: TV Series Asks Pupils to Solve Crises
description: Plans were disclosed here yesterday for a series of television programs that are to be broadcast into classrooms in at least 30 states to help elementary school pupils deal with emotions and attitudes involving death, love, responsibility and other subjects not usually addressed in the schools.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt. Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 2 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 2 P.M.)

title: Notes on People
description: James B. Irwin, the retired astronaut, was at the Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center in Aurora, Colo., after suffering chest pains while playing handball. The concern here is that he had a heart attack, a hospital spokesman said of the 43yearold former Air Force officer who traveled to the moon on the Apollo 15 flight in 1971. Mr. Irwin, who was said to be resting comfortably at the medical center's cardiac unit, is now president of High Flight, an evangelist organization.

title: A.T.&T. IS HONORED BY INTERRACIAL UNIT
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company and Mrs. Ernesto. G. Procope, president of the E. G. Bowman Company, 1424 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, were honored last night by the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity at its 10th anniversary dinner at the Americana Hotel.

title: CHURCH SCHOOLS LOSE JERSEY AID
description: TRENTON, April 5A threejudge Federal Court struck down New Jersey's $19.5million program of state aid to private and parochial schools on the ground that it violated First Amendment guarantees in the United States Constitution for the separation of church and state.

title: Cost of Renovation At Yankee Stadium Climbs $7Million
description: The estimated cost of rebuilding Yankee Stadium has jumped almost $7million to $27.9million in less than a year and before construction has started, Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday.

title: Nixon Orders Maximum Effort on Alaska Pipeline
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 5President Nixon today ordered a maximum effort by the administration to push through congress legislation necessary lor the construction of the Alaska pipeline.

title: ONION WINS MILE FOR 2D STRAIGHT
description: The Hobeau Farm's Onion did the expected at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4yearold gelding won the feature event of a mile by a big margin, and the crowd of 18,191 backed him so heavily that he paid $3.20, $2.80 and $2.20 for $2 across the board.

title: Thailand Credit Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) A $5.5million credit for financing an irrigation project in Thailand was announced today by the International Develop, rent Association. The project is intended to increase rice proauction in the northern Chat Phya Plain by providing improved water control.

title: Possible Cancer Link. Spurs Food Color Ban
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)  The Government banned today the use of Violet No. 1, a food color widely used in drugs, cosmetics and to stamp meat grade marks, on the ground that it may cause cancer.

title: Major League Baseball
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Nikon Urges O.A.S. Nations To Form New Relationship
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)President Nixon, declaring that the days of paternalism have ended, today urged the members of the Organization of American States to seek a strong new relationship.

title: Blackout Laid to Defect
description: MIAMI, April 5 (AP)Defective equipment at a nuclear generating plant south of Miami and an oilfueled plant at Port Everglades caused the massive power blackouts that affected millions of residents in south Florida this week, a power company spokesman said today. Gene Autrey, a Florida Power and Light Company vice president, told a news conference that the trouble began with a defective inverted device in the nuclear unit at Turkey Point.

title: Mail Worker Killed, 2d Is Hurt In Downtown Hijacking Effort
description: A Federal postal employe was killed and his partner was injured near the financial district yesterday evening as two men attempted to hijack the mail truck, they were driving, the police reported.

title: Federal Agents Prepare To Monitor Meat Prices
description: Will there be a grace period? Ted Konopolin, assistant meat buyer for Pioneer supermarkets, asked the Internal Revenue Service agent examining the meat counter at 205 Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village.

title: THIEU MAKES VOW ON TROOP RETURN
description: WASHINGTON, Apia 5President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam pledged todayin his first American public appearance  that he would never, never ask the United States to send troops back to Vietnam.

title: Armco to Raise Prices
description: The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise base prices and size extras on stainless steel bar and wire products by 6.5 per cent, effective with shipments Monday.

title: NIXON WITHDRAWS GRAY NOMINATION AS F.B.I. DIRECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 President Nixon accepted today a request from L. Patrick Gray 3d that his nomination to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation be withdrawn.

title: Brennan Moves to Shut 2 Camps For Sugar Harvesters inflorida
description: WASHINGTON, April 5Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan called today for the closing of two sugar cane labor camps in Florida, saying that conditions reported to me yesterday by my investigative team were deplorable and disgusting.

title: Pakistan's Agile Dancer
description: Politics is like dancing, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan told a recent visitor. You have to be nimble on your feet.

title: Mercantile Splits Stock
description: Directors of Mercantile Stores Company, Inc., declared yesterday a split in the common stock, twoforone, subject to stockholder approval May 23. The board plans to place the new stock on a dividend basis of 80 cents a year. The first quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share on the new stock is payable June 15 to stockholders of record June 1.

title: INDIANS AND U. S. SIGN AGREEMENT AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., April 5The 37day confrontation between armed Indian insurgents and Federal agents at Wounded Knee ended this afternoon.

title: Lynn Expects No Cutback In HousingStart Total
description: James T. Lynn, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said here last night that the Federal Government would implement fiscal policies to sustain housing starts for 1974 at about the same rate as in 1973.

title: Ancient Mariner, Dance Piece, Given A Premiere Here
description: Dance of the Ancient Mariner,based loosely on Coleridge's poem, is an ungainly albatross of a ballet, fraught with portents of disaster. Before the evening was over, its dire promise had been fulfilled. The Company of Man presented the New York premiere of the work Wednesday at La Mama.

title: Western Oil Interests Draft Nationalization Letter in Iran
description: TEHRAN, Iran, April 5 (AP) An 18man delegation of experts from the Western oil consortium comprising British, American, French and Dutch interests left here today after three weeks spent drafting a complicated and detailed letter of understanding on the handing over to Iran of the group's multibilliondollar oil operations, oil company officials said today.

title: Phone Call Set Off Equity Funding Case
description: The mammoth financial scandal at the Equity Funding Corporation of America began to come to light with a telephone call early last month from disgruntled former executive, according to Raymond L. Dirks, the man who took the call.

title: DAYLIN INCREASES A 6MONTH PROFIT
description: Improved consumer attitude and an expanding economy were reflected in the reports yesterday of two merchandising chains.

title: Needham biscloses Member Firms Loss
description: Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange broke even at best and may have lost money in March after losing a total of $51million in January and February, James J. Needham, chairman of the Big Board, said yesterday.

title: Rangers Win, 42, Lead 20 in Series
description: BOSTON, April 5Unable to adjust to a Ranger team that went through its paces as if programed through a computer, the Boston Bruins bowed tonight, 42, and the New Yorkers took an overpowering 20 edge in their Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: NEW CABINET ELUDES A DUTCH SOCIALIST
description: THE HAGUE, April 5 (AP)Hope for solution of the Netherlands 128day Cabinet crisis was dashed today when Jaap A. W. Burger gave up his attempts to form a new government.

title: State Housing Chief Told Resignation Is Accepted
description: The State Housing Commissioner, Charles J. Urstadt, learned last night that a resignation he had offered three weeks ago had been accepted by Governor Rockefeller.

title: SAIGON REPORTS BIG NEW ATTACKS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 6  The South Vietnamese Government reported several big Communist attacks last night.

title: Commodity Pride Index Up 5.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 151.6 from 146.4 last week.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES SECOND FUND BILL
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 5President Nixon opened a new phase of the battle of the budget today by vetoing a bill that would have forced him to spend $120million for a rural water and sewer grant program.

title: Deaths
Theater: The Naming
description: The Iowa Theater Lab is heavily indebted to Jerzy Grotowskis Polish Laboratory Theater, not just in its choice of name but in its method of performing. The group's The Naming, the second in the Chelsea Theater Center's minifestival of plays by visiting United States companies (Fly Chelsea to Brooklyn is the overall title of the series) is an exercise in nonverbal gestural theater.

title: Human Blood and Marrow Cells Produced Inside a Living Mouse
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory have developed way of producing human blood and bloodforming cells inside a living mouse.

title: Farm Nominee Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Luther. W. Jennejahn of New York as a member of the Federal From Credit Board for a term expiring March 31, 1979. He replaces Jonathan Davis, whose, term, expired.

title: Charles E. Lawall, 81, Dies; ExHead of West Virginia U.
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., April 5 (UPI)  Charles E. Lawall, president of West Virginia University from 1939 to 1945, and later a top vice president of the Chesapeake & Ohio Railway, died last evening. He was 81 years old.

title: Chris Short Joins Brewers
description: MILWAUKEE, April 5 (AP)The Milwaukee Brewers today added Chris Short as a relief pitcher by buying the exPhillie's contract from the Brewers Evansville farm club and optioning Lloyd Gladden, a pitcher, to the minors.

title: N.B.C. Signs Sammy Davis
description: Sammy Davis Jr. has signed a longterm contract with the National Broadcasting Cornpany that will give the television network exclusive use of his talents in all major TV appearances. Mr. Davis will be seen as a frequent guest star on the new N. B. C. Follies musical variety series next season and will appear in madeforTV movies, specials and The Tonight Show.

title: LUTZ, SMITH GAIN IN MUNICH TENNIS
description: MUNICH, West Germany (UPI) April 5Bob Lutz of the United States reached the quarterfinal round of the Group A World Championship Tennis event today with an easy 63, 61 victory over Phil Dent of Australia.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES SECOND FUND BILL
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 5President Nixon opened new phase of the battle of the budget today by vetoing a bill that would have forced him to spend $120million for a rural water and sewer grant program.

title: College Baseball
CROSSWORD PUZZLE
CAUTION IS URGED PSYCHOSURGERY
description: DETROIT, April 5Dr. Earl Walker, a leading authority on neurosurgery, said today that it was possible to carry out a careful study on human beings to determine whether brain surgery could help them with abnormal aggressive behavior.

title: NEWS UNIT DEPLORES APATHY OVER CURBS
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 5 (AP)The InterAmeriban Press Association said today that public reaction to attacks on the press throughout the Western Hemisphere had been shockingly mild.

title: Federal Panel Considering Shift In the Definition of Who Is Poor
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 A Federal interagency committee is quietly examining the possibility of doing away with Federal use of the word poverty and of recomputing the income figures used to define the poor.

title: PRICES ON BONDS SHOW INCREASES
description: Bond prices soared yesterday on published reports that Arthur F. Burns, head of the Federal Reserve Board and the Committee on Interest and Dividends, is pressing for a new wageprice freeze to head off Congressional action that might force rollbacks and include interest rates. Adding fuel to the rally  which began to take shape about midweek were Federal Reserve purchases of Treasury securities yesterday in the open market.

title: Bill Offered to Centralize State Regulation of Waste
description: ALBANY, April 6  Governor Rockefeller submitted bill to the Legislature today that would empower the Department of Environmental Conservation to regulate solidwaste facilities throughout the state.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: U.S. Sub Base Off Sardinia Drawing Residents Protest
description: LA MADDALENA, Sardinia, April 6 (AP)  A United States submarine tender, the Gilmore, arrived today to set up a permanent base on this island north of Sardinia,. despite protests from residents.

title: Murphy Forms Unit To Combat Attacks On City's Policemen
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday the formation of a Police Attack Prevention Unit to gather information from other cities and study means of reducing planned attacks upon policemen. The unit will operate under the chief of detectives office.

title: Toledo Jeep Pant Struck
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 6 (UPI) The nearly 4,000 members of Local 12 of the United Automobile Workers struck the American Motors Corporation Jeep plant here today over charges of production speedup and other grievances.

title: Fuentes Delighted by NoBigotry Report
description: Luis Fuentes, superintendent of the troubled School District 1 on the Lower East Side, said yesterday that he was delighted with a report released Thigsday that had said he was at the present time, neither a bigot nor a racist.

title: Music: Ceccato Leads Philharmonic
description: A new face at the Philharmonic: Aldo Ceccato, young Italiin conductor, handsome, exquisitely tailored. He got a few subdued wolf whistles from a pair of women in the audience when he came to thq stage on Thursday night. Mr. Ceccato has previously conducted the Philharmonic, but this was his first appearance of the season. He will be here for the month.

title: Way Found to Improve Links in Computer
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Three scientists for the International Business Machines Corporation have discovered a way to improve the life and performance of the many millions of interconnections that go into even a medium  sized computer. Patent 3,725,309 was granted this week to Irving Ames, Francois M. d'Heurle and Richard E. Horstmann of the research center at Yorktown Heights, N. Y., for thin aluminum strips alloyed with copper, which carry current through the tiny solidstate devices called chips.

title: Theatrical Memorabilia on View to Aid Actors Fund
description: Sir John Gielgud has contributed two scenic designs he did at the age of 20 when he was contemplating a career on the other side of the footlights.

title: U.S. Advance Party in Peking Goes ApartmentHunting on First Day
description: PEKING, April 6The first American officials to be stationed in mainland China in a generation, spent their first full day on the job today making courtesy calls at the Foreign Ministry and inspecting possible quarters for the liaison office that will officially open here early next month.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (Canadian Press)The State Department said today that the United States, in a diplomatic note, had agreed to a Canadian Government request for bilateral talks on special duties imposed on Michelin tires manufactured in Nova Scotia plants built with Government assistance as part of Ottawa's regional development program. The parent Michelin company is in France.

title: Esquire's Publisher and Editor Dispute the Latter's Departure
description: Harold T. P. Hayes said today that he had been dismissed from his posts as editor and assistant publisher of Esquire magazine, but Arnold Gingrich, the publisher, said Mr. Hayes had resigned.

title: Swedish Nurses Have Assumed a Role Usually Assigned Doctors
description: STOCKHOLM, April 6 Nurses in the coronary care unit of Sweden's oldest hospital have assumed a key role that has traditionally been reserved for doctors.

title: Recognition of North Korea Is Announced by Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, April 6 (UPI) Sweden today became the first nonCommunist European country to recognize North Korea. She called on other nations to follow suit.

title: Bees and Buds Return to Life With Spring in the Cumberlands
description: MILLSTONE, Ky., April 6 Mabel Kiser was cooking breakfast in her modest little home down the hollow here the other morning when she realized something special was happening.

title: MERGER PUT OFF BY PROTESTANTS
description: MEMPHIS, April 6Representatives of eight major Protestant denominations voted unanimously today to shelve for the time being efforts to reach agreement on a detailed plan for their merger into a 22millionmember Protestant church.

title: GIANTS TO RESUME SEARCH FOR HOME
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 6  The National Football League's annual owners meeting ended here today on a quiet note with no drastic changes in store for the coming season.

title: After Five Years, Cooke Still Relishes His Pastoral Role
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke was doing what he likes to do best  mixing with people.

title: HERBERT GRLIF, 69, OF THE MET, DIES
description: GENEVA, April 6Herbert Graf, former stage director of New York's Metropolitan Opera House, died here yesterday of cancer. He would have been 70 on Tuesday.

title: HANOI TELLS BROOKE HE CAN'T VISIT NOW
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 6Senator Edward W. Brooke, who had hoped to make an assessment of Norths, Vietnam's postwar reconstruction needs, was informed by Hanoi today that he could not visit for the time being.

title: Hammermill Paper Raises Net For 12 Weeks to 35c a Share
description: The Hammermill Paper Company continued its recovery in profits in the first 12 weeks this year with net earnings up 360.2 per cent to $2.4million from $522,000 made in the corresponding period last year, it was reported yesterday. The earnings equaled 35 cents share in contrast to six cents in the 1972 opening quarter and were the best since mid1970

title: Garden City Braces Itself For BranchBanking War
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 6This tiny, affluent bedroom suburb of New York, nestled in the heart of the urban sprawl of central Nassau County less than half an hour from the Queens border, is bracing; itself for an allout branchbanking war its residents fear is about to be fought within its 5.3 square miles.

title: ANTIPOVERTY AIDE DISPUTES CHARGES
description: William Del Toro, director of a $1.5million East Harlem antipoverty agency, charged yesterday that a Federal grand jury had indicted him along with three Model Cities officers and four businessman because he would not point the finger at two codefendants.

title: South Vietnamese Now Worry About Prices and Lack of Jobs
description: DALAT, South Vietnam, April 6Many South ese are as concerned these days about rising prices, increasing unemployment and the social ravages of corrupity of their army to cope with tion as they are about the abilnew military pressure from the Communists now that the Americans are gone.

title: TWO POLICE HELD IN COCAINE THEFT
description: Two New York policemen were being held yesterday for allegedly trying to steal $80,000 worth of cocaine, and the office of Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's anticorruption prosecutor, said it was investigating reports of similar robberies by other policemen.

title: A Briton's Memories Of a Stateside Tour
description: This is the last time I shall write my daily chronicle from America. And it's time for reflection.

title: 2d Autopsy Finds Bullet in Body Of a Coed Killed in Boston Area
description: PARAMUS, April 6 (UPI)An autopsy performed today on the body of a Hackensack girl, one of seven young women killed in the Boston area since last summer, disclosed she had been shot as well as stabbed and strangled.

title: Kerry Harris, Mrs. Hunt Post Pro Tennis Upsets
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 6 The hills and valleys of the women's tennis tour were dramatized vividly tonight with vietories by a pair of unseeded young Australians, Kerry Harris and Mrs. Lesley Hunt, in the $50,000 Max Pax tournament.

title: Destroyers for Taiwan
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 6 (AP)  Three United States destroyers will be turned over to the Government of Taiwan this month, the Navy says. The destroyersthe Hanson, James E. Kyes and Sheltonall were built in the mid1940's and were used in Korea and Vietnam, a Navy spokesman said yesterday.

title: Iowa State and Penn State Lead N.C.A.A. Gymnastics
description: EUGENE, Ore., April 6 (AP) Iowa State, Penn State and Indiana State appeared headed for berths in the finals after six of nine teams completed the second round of the National Collegiate gymnastics championships today.

title: COURTS FAULTED ON DIRECTORSHIP
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that courts acted contrary to the public interest in applying the same broad civil liability to all persons serving as directors of corporations.

title: Bergen Bids Court Quash Subpoenas on County Data
description: NEWARK, April 6  Bergen County filed in Federal Court here today a motion to quash or modify subpoenas issued by the United States Attorney for a broad range of documents covering such items as purchase orders, contracts and canceled checks dating to Jan. 1, 1967.

title: DOCTORS TO IMPLANT ATOMIC PACEMAKERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Atomic Energy Commission issued two licenses today to allow surgeons, to implant in patients nuclear heartpacemakers manufactured in the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In response to your March 28 editorial and a number of articles in various publications concerning Vietnam veterans and their role in society, or lack of it, upon their return, this Vietnam veteran desires to make a few remarks of his own.

title: Airlift From Cuba Concludes; It Brought 261,000 to U.S.
description: MIAMI April 6 (UPI)  The airlift that has brought almost 261,000 Cubans to the United States since late 1965 came to an end today with the arrival of two flights from Varadero, Cuba.

title: 3 TEENAGERS SEIZED IN SUBWAY MUGGING
description: Three teenagers were arrested yesterday and charged with mugging an offduty policeman in the IND subway station at Eighth Avenue and 33d Street as he was on his way to Police Headquarters to report for duty.

title: APPLICATION FILED ON ALGERIAN GAS
description: The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation said yesterday it had filed applications with the Federal Power Commission for the importing of an average of 375 million cubic feet of natural gas a day in the form of liquefied natural gas from Algeria. The import program would begin tin 1977 on contract with the El Paso Algeria Corporation, a subsidiary of the El Paso Natural Gas Company.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: ** The Brass Bucket, Route 9 Main Street, Woodbridge, N. J. (201) 6349148.

title: Sports Today
description: Texas 200 Indianapoliscar race, at College Station, Tex. (TelevisionChannel 7, 5 P.M.)

title: Astros Dierher Kills Youth in Car Acident
description: COCOA, Fla., April 6 (AP) Larry Dierker, a pitcher for the Houston Astros, was the driver in an autopedestrian accident that killed an 18yearold New York youth last night near the Kennedy Space Center.

title: Marla Pride 4th in Trot After 16Month Absence
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 6Marlu Pride, the big black stallion who created a stir with his great speed near the end of the 1971 harness racing season, returned to action at Roosevelt Raceway tonight after an absence of 16 months.

title: Turkish Parliament Elects an Admiral President
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 6Parliament elected Senator Fahri Koruturk as Pilesident of Turkey today after a monthlong struggle between parliamentary parties and the military.

title: Both Sides in Vietnam Charge Attacks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, [Saturday, April 7 (AP)The] Saigon command and the Vietcong accused each other yesterday of landgrabbing attacks through much of South Vietnam.

title: F.B.I. Director.
description: All the storm signals and political currents in Washington during the past weeks pointed to the resignation or rejection of L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. First he became tangled in the Watergate inquiry and the issue of executive privilege for White House aides; during the hearings he demonstrated that political loyalty to the Administration was no substitute for competence in the post to which he had been assigned; finally it became clear he would not be approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: THIS SAID TO ASK $700MILLION AID EACH YEAR TO 76
description: WASHINGTON, April 6President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam was reported by his close aides today to have asked President Nixon for an American economic aid commitment of more than $700million yearly through 1975with a sharp reduction after that.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Javits Picks a Campaign Team, Citing the Need to Think Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, April 6A few days after toying with the idea of running for Mayor and with 19 months still to go before the 1974 election, Senator Jacob K. Javits disclosed this week that he was starting to put together a preliminary organization for his fourthterm reelection campaign. The 68  year  old New York Republican volunteered the information to reporters, but he denied that he was starting his senatorial campaign a little early.

title: Protestant Spared by Britain; Both Ulster Sides Hail Move
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 6 (AP)The British Govermnent today commuted the death penalty of a militant Protestant to life imprisonment and both Roman Catholic and Protestant spokesmen hailed the move.

title: Smothers Brothers Win Suit for Show Canceled by C.D.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 6 Tom and Dick Smothers were awarded $776,300 in United States District Court today by a jury that determined that the Columbia Broadcasting System had breached a contract with the entertainers when it canceled their show in 1969.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Rockefeller submitted a bill that would empower the State Department of Environmental Conservation to regulate the operation of solidwastedisposal facilities in the state.

title: Congressmen Clown Around at Circus
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, booted Representative Leo J. Ryan, Democrat of California, in the rear.

title: Hull Scores 2 Goals as Jets Beat Saints, 31, in Playoff
description: WINNIPEG, Maniroba, Aril 6 (AP)Two goals by Bobby Hull helped the Winnipeg Jets score a 31 victory tonight over the Minnesota Fighting Saints in the first game of their World Hockey Association bestof7game quarterfinal playoff series.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: April 4Rangers 6, Bost. 2. April 5Rangers 4, Boston 2. April 7At Madison Square Garden, 8:05 P.M.

title: Ellsberg Judge Accepts Hayden As Expert on Diplomacy of U. S.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 6Tom Hayden, the antiwar activist, was accepted today by the judge in the Pentagon papers trial as an expert witness on the diplomacy of the United States.

title: Plan to Integrate Building Trades on L.I. Is Approved
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., April 6The Long Island Plan for integration of the construction industry was approved today by all parties, ndhrly nine months after it was first signed, the delay being attributed to rejection of the initial plan by the Nixon Administration.

title: Athens University Senate Quitsover Barred Voting
description: ATHENS, April 6  The governing body of Athens University resigned today in protest against a decision by the militarybacked national Government to block campus elections.

title: Wealthy Developer Arrested For Refusal to Pay Taxes
description: CHICAGO, April 6 (UPI)State revenue agents today arrested Julius W. Butler, a millionaire land developer who has refused to pay state and Federal income taxes to support illegitimate children and such things as government studies on German cockroaches.

title: NETS ELIMINATED IN ARA., 136113
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 6 The season ended abruptly for the New York Nets tonight as they were crushed, 136113, by the Carolina Cougars in the fifth game of the American Basketball Association's East Ifilvision semifinal playoffs. A crowd of 3,688 watched in the Greensboro Coliseum.

title: PHILIP A. GORE
description: Philip A. Gore, a realestate and corporate lawyer who had offices at 595 Madison Avenue, before his retirement last year, died Thursday at Doctor's Hospital. His age was 69, and he lived at 128 Central Park South.

title: TASS TOLD TO PAY $15,000 IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 6 (AP)  A Lebanese court ruled today that the Soviet press agency, Tass, must pay $15,000 in fines in a defamation of character suit brought by four prominent Lebanese.

title: S. E. C. DISCIPLINES A BROKERDEALER
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the registration of Winslow, Cohu &, Stetson, a New York brokerdealer now in liquidation, and suspended its president and vice president from professional association with any broker or dealer.

title: TRIPS BY SCIENTIST BARRED BY SOVIET
description: LONDON, April 6 (Reuters), Soviet authorities have refused to allow Dr. Zhores A. Medvedev, a leading Soviet scientist and wellknown political dissenter now working in London, to make lecture visits to France and the United States.

title: Manila Hears Plea for Jailed Senators
description: MANILA, April 6The Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was asked today to restore the rights to counsel and to have visitors of two opposition Senators who have been detained since. Sept. 23 when martial law was put into effect.

title: Mrs. Heinemann Is Target
description: BERLIN, April 6 (AP)Mrs. Gustav Heinemann, the wife of the West German President, was struck by an egg and verbally abused today when she visited an educational project for problem children. At the project site in a former West Berlin hospital, children tossed eggs, shouted abuse and unfurled banners protesting what they considered inadequate city support of the project.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 6The new senior women's diving champion of New Jersey, Carol Wagner of Pennington, a student at Hopewell Valley, Regional Junior High School, is 13 years old.

title: Truck Tonnage Up 11.8%
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity trucli tonnage last week was 11.8 percent above the immediately preceding week. The A.T.A. reported that a terminal survey of 35 metropolitan areas showed 29 localities with increased tonnage over a year ago.

title: Sikkim's Royal Family Guarded As 15,000 Protest Near Capital
description: NEW DELHI, April 6Nearly 15,000 antiGovernment protesters were poised tonight outside Sikkim's capital, Gangtok, amid rising violence in that tiny Indian protectorate.

title: ALFRED R. GLANCY JR., A DETROIT FINANCIER
description: DETROIT, April 6 (AP)Alfred R. Glancy Jr., Detroit financier who was once a coowner of the Empire State Building, died today at Harper Hospital of injuries suffered when he was beaten by two, men who broke into his home, last Nov. 12. He was 65 years, old.

title: Light Opera Patience Proves a Delight
description: Gilbert and Sullivan's Patience is doubly precious. Its mockery of Victorian counterculture shares the posturing and euphuistic language of its longhaired poets. At the same time, all the foolish affectation becomes valuably endearing because of the creators humor and wit. In presenting a new production of the work on Wednesday night at the Jan Hus Playhouse, the Light Opera of Manhattan reminded the faithful of how pleasantly malicious Gilbert and Sullivan could be, and the performance was an almost unreserved delight.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RETURN In 1910, the Metropolitan Opera, with Geraldine Farrar singing the main Goose Girl role, gave the world premiere of Konigskinder (The Royal Children) by Engelbert Humperdinekthe composer, not the one who sings in Las Vegas and on TV. It has played number of places since then at least once, but its performance career since those early years has been on the lean, almost untraceable, side.

title: Spotts Today
description: Texas 200 Indianapoliscar race, at College Station,. Tex. (TelevisionChannel 7, 5 P.M.)

title: Bridge: PartScore Doubles Require More Than a Skeptical Whim
description: Some good players seem to believe in doubling the opponents in partscores at the drop of a hat and then trusting to a combination of tight defense and poor declarer play to produce a plus score. This style has its successes in pair games, in which an occasional disaster can be shrugged off, but it is decidedly unsound in a team contest.

title: ExPrisoner Lays Confession to Chinese Torture
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., April 6 (AP)Attempting to extract a confession and military information, the Chinese tortured an American flier who strayed over their territory after a combat mission against North Vietnam, the returned prisoner says.

title: Part of 14th St. to Be Closed
description: The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that 14th Street between Avenue D and the East River would be closed to traffic from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. today while an overthestreet bridge between two Con Edison Buildings was removed from the utility's East River generating station.

title: CANADA RAISES HER BANK RATE
description: OTTAWA, April 6 (Canadian Press)The Bank of canada pushed up the bank rate tonight by onehalf of one per cent to 51/4 per cent in a measure designed to curb credit.

title: City Opens Its Tennis CourtsAt Least Most of Them
description: For the city's 50,000; tennis players, the good news is that the public tennis courts open for the season today. The bad news is that not all of the 522 courts are ready.

title: Jersey Bishops See No School Closings
description: TRENTON, April 6  A spokesman for the state's Roman Catholic bishops said today that the loss of special state aid as a result of a Federal Court ruling was not expected to force the closing of any parochial schools.

title: News Summary and Index. SATURDAY, APRIL 7, 1973
description: American B52's bombed enemy concentrations in the outskirts of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, yesterday in an attempt to break the Communist hold on major highways and waterways and to stop a possible assault on the city, military sources reported. The bombers flew from nearby Thailand. [Page 1, Columns 67.]

title: New Video Player To Be Introduced By Eastman Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company demonstrated here yesterday a new super8 film video player that it expects to have ready for commercial sales by yearend at a price of $1,195.

title: Promotions of 3 P.O.W.'s To Lieutenants Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)  Secretary of the Mr Force Robert C. Seamans Jr. confirmed today the promotions of three Air Force sergeants to second lieutenant while they were war prisoners of the North Vietnamese.

title: Art: The Strange Oeuvre of Eilshernius
description: The career of Louis Eilshemius (18641941) offers one of the sadder histories in American art. Eilshemius began with everything and ended indigent and insane. Born into a wealthy, socially prominent New York family, he was allowed to take up art as a profession after an early setback from his father, who at first wanted him to become a proper businessman.

title: MONTCLAIR PLANS BID TO BAN'TANGO
description: MONTCLAIR, April 6 Responding to a flood of protests against the showing of an Xrated film in this quiet, treeshaded, imageconscious suburban community, the Town Commission will try to close Last Tango in Paris as soon as it opens here later this month.

title: London Dock Strike Ending
description: LONDON, April 6 (Reuters)  London dockworkers voted today at a mass meeting to end their unofficial strike, which has stopped most cargo from passing through the port singe last Monday.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the net asset value of a closedend Investment fund's shares as reported by the companies through The Association of ClosedEnd Investment Companies at the close of business Friday. Also shown Is the closing market price of each fund's share, with the percentage of difference discount, or premium. Where the stock is traded over the counter, the market Price Is the N.A.S.D. dealertodealer askod Price.

title: MORE FIND WORK BUT JOBLESS RATE REMAINS STEADY
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The unemployment rate remained essentially unchanged in March, for the fourth consecutive month, despite a large increase in the number of people at work.

title: Death Penalty Measure
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., April 6 (UPI)The Nevada Senate has approved a bill reinstating the death penalty for the slaying of policemen and prison guards, in contract killings and for killers already serving life terms. The measure was sent to the Assembly Thursday on a 191 vote.

title: Tough Code of Ethics Adopted For Judges in Federal Courts
description: WASHINGTON, April 6A tough and comprehensive new code of ethics covering all Federal judges except the nine members of the Supreme Court was adopted today by the Judicial Conference of the United States.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: Amnesty and Professor Whitridge
description: To the Editor: The comments by Arnold Whitridge [OpEd March 21] indicate great misunderstanding of draft boards, conscientious objector status and amnesty for deserters or draft evaders.

title: ForeignAuto Prices Up; Monetary Changes Cited
description: Several producers of foreign passengers cars announced yesterday that they had increased their prices to reflect the recent monetary changes. British Leyland Motors, Inc., said that it had raised the United States price tags of its Austin, MG, Jaguar and Triumph cars by an average of 3.9 per cent in the wake of the dollar devaluation on Feb. 12 and a sharp rise in British steel prices. A spokesman noted that the cost of steel in Britain had risen about 11 per cent.

title: Nominee for Arms Agency Chief Fred Charles Ikle
description: WASHINGTON, April 6For months the Administration has been casting around for a man to reshape and redirect the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, which had fallen Into White House disfavor.

title: TV Review
description: As might be expected, What Are Taxes All About? is another briskly informative, cheerfully packaged miniguide, like the Columbia Broadcasting System's previous halfhour documentary on Presidential balloting. Again, while the program (at 1 this afternoon) is ostensibly aimed at young people, the older folkstaxpayers shelling out the longest and heaviestprobably will dig it the most.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A group of women active in Federal, state and local politics criticized the nation's political system yesterday for its underutilization of female talent.

title: 6 Company Chiefs. In Japan to Testify On Price Charges
description: TOKYO, April 6 (UPI)The Japanese Parliament today summoned presidents of six of the country's biggest trading cornpanies to testify on charges that the concerns pushed up consumer prices through speculative buying and hoarding.

title: Avtek Unit to Close
description: Avtek Corporation of Providence, R. I., said yesterday that its Williams Craft, Inc., subsidiary faces liquidation to satisfy claims of customers. The subsidiary, it was said, failed in its attempt to have a bankruptcy petition by creditors converted into a voluntary bankruptcy, and the Federal Court in Fort Worth, Texas will proceed with liquidation.

title: ES. TRADE DEFICIT WITH JAPAN EASES
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (Reuters)The United States trade deficit with Japan narrowed to an actual $410million in the three months from December, 1972, to February, 1973, a decline from $985million in the preceding three months, the United StatesJapan council reported today.

title: AUTO OUTPUT SHOWS DECLINE FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, April 6,  Auto production dropped about 4,300 units this week, according to the industry trade paper, Automotive News although last minute Chrysler overtmie may trim the decline somewhat.

title: Aid for Peace
description: Senate action bairing any United States aid to North Vietnam without specific authorization by Congress a reasonable reaffirmation of a Congressional prerogative.

title: B52's Seeking to Break The Siege of Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 6  American B52's bombed Communist troops in the outskirts of this capital today in an attempt to break their hold on major highways and waterways and to head off a possible assault on the city itself, military sources reported.

title: Kosygin Is Back in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 6 (UPI)Premier Aleksei Kosygin turned home today from a fiveday official visit to Sweden, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Boycotters Holding Firm, But So Are Meat Prices
description: Rebellious meat boycotters held their ranks and shunned meat purchases in supermarkets across the country yesterday, but as the weeklong campaign approached its end today there was no general price retreat.

title: Dave Anderson
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6The glory of Matashi Ozaki is that nothing is lost in the translation. He has a nickname, Jumbo, that Americans understand. With his Americanmade Louisville Slugger clubs, he hits a golf ball as far as Jack Nicklaus does, distances that Americans also understand. Behind the green of the 555yard second hole at the Augusta National Golf Club today, a man was peering through binoculars at the sturdy 6foot, 190pound Japanese pro waggling a No. 3 wood in the middle the fairway after a 300yard downhill drive. He'll probably hit my binoculars on the fly, the man said. Not quite. The ball sprayed the sand a bunker fronting the green, but such was the power behind the shot that it popped up on the fringe. This guy can hit it right through the sand, another said.

title: Secretariat Pick Today Over 6 Rivals in Gotham
description: Secretariat will seek to strengthen his bid to retain his championship when he competes in the $55,800 Gotham at Aqueduct today.

title: Theater: A Funny Alice
description: On top of Ratner's on Second Avenueand if you don't know where Ratner's is, just askAndre Gregory's Manhattan Project, some kind of associate of New York University, holcis court in an antic attic, So far this season, it has been giving its controversial, idiosyncratic and beautiful version of Beckett's Endgame. Thursday night, it restored its first success, Alice in Wonderland, which is now going to play in repertory with Endgame.

title: New Labor Nominee Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (Reuters)President Nixon plans to nominate Richard F. Schubert as Under Secretary of Labor, the Labor Department said today. Mr. Schubert was executive assistant to former Secretary of Labor James Hodgson.

title: A State Tax Cut?
description: The great fiscal issue confronting lawmakers at Albany this year is a different and much happier one from that of the grim years when yawning budgetary gaps required enactment of as much as $400 million in new or additional taxes in a single session of the State Legislature. The issue now involves reduction of taxesshould there be a tax cut, when, where, by how much?

description: PHILADELPHIACertainly history buffs will find much to peruse in the exhibitin A Tribute to William Penn, opening here Tuesday at the University Hospital Antiques Show.

title: Robinson Clouts 2 Homers, McNally Blanks Brewers
description: BALTIMORE, April 6 (AP) Brooks Robinson belted two home runs and Don Baylor hit four extrabase hits, one a homer, today as the Baltimore Orioles beat Milwaukee, 100, in their 1%seball opener. Robinson and Baylor batted in seven of the runs.

title: M'CORD SAYS DEAN PASSELL ON HIS JOB
description: WASHINGTON, April 6James. W. McCord Jr. has indicated in sworn Federal Court testimony made public today that his employment by President Nixon's political organization was cleared by John. W. Dean 3d, the White House counsel.

title: Rendezvous With Spain
description: SAANEN, SwitzerlandMy next journey will not be my last journey, for I am planning several, but it will be the most sensational from the planning point of view, because the planning has been going on for nearly thirty years. Thirty years behind time, I am getting ready for my journey to Madrid.

title: Cpnservative Funds Give Beame and Biaggi Edge
description: The two moreconservative Democratic candidates for the mayoral nomination  Controller Abraham D. Beame and Representative Mario Biaggi expect to raise close to the $1million goal set by several mayoral candidates. The two liberal Contenders  Representative Herman Badillo and AssemblyMan Albert H. Blumenthalwill fall far short of even half that goal, in what will likely be the mast expensive mayoral primary in history.

title: JOHN H. MONTGOMERY
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 6John H. Montgomery, who retired in 1956 as president of Fritzsche Brothers, an essentialoil and aromaticchemical company in New York, died today at the Waterview Nursing Home in Cedar Grove, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived here.

title: Air Force Presents Papers on Analyst
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Air Force, relying on documents instead of witnesses, attempted to introduce 19 packets of letters, memos and transcripts today to rebut testimony of A. Ernest Fitzgerald at a Civil Service Commission hearing.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (Reuters)The Navy today awarded the Boeing Company, of Seattle, a $42.6million modification to a previously awarded contract for design and construction of two hydrofoil ocean going fast patrol ships to be used by the United States and its NATO allies. West Germany and Italy are sharing the total contract cost with the United States.

title: Music: Inventive Voice of the Whale
description: George Crumb's Vox. Balaenae, or Voice of the Whale, received its second performance here on Thursday night, this time by the group that commissioned the piece, the New York Camerata. The Camerata  made up of Paula Hatcher, flute; Charles Forbes, cello, and Gleen Jacobson, pianotook authoritative hold of this endlessly inventive work and hypnotized an Alice Tully Hall audience with its delicately amplified sounds and soundings.

title: Systematic Theitsby Police In Albany Hinted by S.C.I.
description: The State Commission of Investigation said yesterday that it had turned up indications of systematic and organized burglaries, larcenies and thefts of public funds allegedly committed by Albany police officers.

title: A Young but Attentive Audience
description: In a large group, the attention span of children between the ages of four and six is not noted for its longevity. A onetoone relationship can go on for a long period and a dozen children can be entranced by a story hour.

title: Oporto Army Sites Bombed
description: OPORTO, Portugal, April 6 (AP)  Time bombs shattered two Portuguese Army offices early today, but both offices were empty. One office was on tie second floor of a building next to the civil government headquarters. The other on the second floor of the regional military headquarters.

description: TRENTON, April 6  Mrs. Loretta Nolan Schroth, wife of Frank D. Schroth, publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle from 1939 to its closing in 1955, died of a cerebral vascular hemorrhage in Mercer Hospital today. She was 84 years old and lived at 301 West State Street.

description: PITTSBURGH, April 6 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Committee for 76, a group of civic leaders, will honor President and Mrs. Nixon at what it describes as the nation's initial American bicentennial observance April 26, it was announced yesterday.

description: Mrs. Lee Carson Reeves, former International News Service war correspondent, died Thursday in the Lankenau Hospital in Overbrook, Pa., after a long illness. She was 51 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 6 (AP)The foreign ministers of Iraq and Kuwait began talks today on their border dispute, the Kuwait radio announced.

description: WASHINGTON, April 6The unemployment rate remained essentially unchanged in March, for the fourth consecutive month, despite a large increase in the number of people at work.

description: WASHINGTON, April 6 The Men eri Company has stopped production of Mennen E underarm deodorant spray, which uses vitamin E as its deodorant agent, because of an unusually high number of complaints from users, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

description: The state of New York has declared war against the monk parakeet, a flamboyant invader from South America that is threatening farmers crops and suburban gardens as well as driving native birds from their nests.

title: Mississippi Hits 39.8Foot Crest At St Louis and Then Recedes
description: ST: LOUIS, April 6  The boding Mississippi River eached its crest here this morning and then started fallrg slowly. St. Louis, unlike some smaller towns and rural communi ies up and down the river, ascaped major damage. Most of the city sits on high ground. Lowying commercial areas near the river are protected by levees and flood walls built by the Army Corps of Engineers after the last great flood in 1951. A corps spokesman here estimated that the protective system had prevented $150million worth of damage. Damage was confined to the first floors of few commercial buildings along the downtown waterfront and to about 100 houses in lowlying areas in the southern part of the city. After the flood in 1951 caused several million dollars damage here, the corps upgraded the protection system with $90million worth of new Levees and concrete flood walls. Work Begun on Wall One 300foot section of flood, wallin southern St. Louis remains to be built. Work was begun on it last fall, but the heavy winter rains overtook it. The corps had to throw up temporary earthen dike covered with sheet plastic to block the rising river last week. A corps spokesman estimated that, without the new system, the river would have spread west and flooded a densely developed strip of former flood plain that is one to threequayFed ters of a mile wide. Many baggesses and industries have been milt there since the last flood. St. Louis is one of the many cities that have not taken the necessary steps to make their citizens eligible for Federal Hood insurance under the Na. tional Flood Insurance Act of 1968. Most insurance companies do not insure against flood damage.

title: City Schools Reading Programs Are Assailed as Disorganized
description: The methods used to teach New York City schoolchildren to read and the ways used to assess their reading progress came under steady criticism yesterday during a hearing at Hunter College High School.

Or making her bulky sweater jackets shorter than the pullovers they cover. Or putting the sweaters with long gaucho pants (short slacks?) or short harem pants (long bloomers?).

title: Georgia Hails Conrad Aiken
description: ATLANTA, April 6 (AP)The Pulitzer Prizewinning poet Conrad Aiken has been appointed poet laureate of Georgia, Gov. Jimmy Carter's office said today. The 84yeafold Georgia native, who was educated at Harvard University and was a confidant of T. S. Eliot, accepted the honor from his Savannah home.

title: ORDERS FOR MERGING OF SCHOOLS OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) Federal judges have no authorfty to order predominantly white suburban school systems to merge with black innercity schools, the Nixon Administration told the Supreme Court today.

title: 4 Share Shot Lead In Masters on 141's
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6Four golfers tied for the 36hole lead in the Masters tournament today but a frustrated Jack Nicklaus, who scored a 77, was not among them. He was in a tie for 19th place, five strokes back of the pacesetters.

title: After Five Years, Cooke Still Relishes His Pastoral Role
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke was doing what he likes to do best  mixing with people.
