title: A vocation for madness and art
description: In many cases, their fits came late in life. At the ages of 35, 40 and 50, they embarked on the career of mental patient, to use R. D. Laing's phrase; but theirs was a double vocation: they became madmen and artists. Some finally abandoned the second career, but many refrained productive artists the rest of their lives.

title: Stage: Nichols ForgetMeNot Lane
description: NEW HAVEN, April 7The British Empire is alive and well and living in New Haventheatrically speaking that is. After its earlier triumph with David Storey's The Changing Room, Arvin Brown's Long Wharf Theater last night offered the American premiere of Peter Nichols's ForgetMeNot Lane. This play by the author of A Day in the Death of Joe Egg's enjoyed great acclaim in London a couple of seasons ago, but I was frankly worried whether it could survive the transAtlantic crossing. I need not have cared.

title: It's Time to Open the Summer Place
description: The time has come to hustle up Route 195 to open the barnred house in Connecticut. A new season! It always rejuvenates us, though we've done this many times before. Somehow we never tire of the ritual, even after 17 seasons.

title: LEGISLATIVE NOTES
description: TRENTONThe Cahill Administration and the State Legislature could be on a collision course over a controversial program requiring automobiles to pass exhaustemission inspections.

title: If All Else Fails
description: AS suburbia takes over mores; and more of wildlife's habitat, the battles and wiles to outwit each other mount.

title: Mirrors in Use on Parkway
description: WOODBRIDGEThe Garden State Parkway, utilizing oneway spy mirrors, sophisticated electronic equipment and human nature, among other things, is engaged in a game of wits to detect thousands of motorists who attempt to avoid paying their 25cent tolls.

title: Miss McKee To Be Bride
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 7 Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. McKee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia McKee, to John Hinkle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Hinkle of Reading, Pa.

title: Mets Like Yanks and Vice Versa
description: BOSTON, April 7For the most part, the Yankees and the Mets emerged from their longest spring training series impressed with each other and liking each other's chances as a pennant contender. In general, the Mets like the Yankees hitting and depth and question only whether their starting pitching is solid enough. The Yankees, meanwhile, generally agree that the Mets strengths are the defense provided by Bud Harrelson and Felix Milian plus the hitting of Rusty Staub, Cleon Jones and John Milner. They also like Tom Seaver and Jon Matlack, half of the starting rotation, but they believe Jerry Koosman has to come through for the Mets to have enough frontline pitching.

title: Spring's Banners
description: A mild March means an early April, a springtime with a running start. You can already see it in pasture and parkland, green grass and the season's first blooming.

title: Variety Is Key To Discotheque
description: Lee Canaan, a softspoken, shaggyhaired onetime actor, director and writer, is putting his imagination and show business experience to work to give the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn a discotheque that; he ttopes, will keep people out of Manhattan.

title: Photography
description: AS IF to point up the triviality, sexism and general irrelevance of most of the glossy photographic annuals, along comes one which is everything an annual should be. The; Black Photographers Annual 1973 is by far the best such publication I have seen in the past five yearsa volume so alive and nourishing that it puts the products churned out by Popular Photography and Modern Photography to shame.

title: Let Them Eat Fish
description: Many of the nation's consumers who sought alternatives to beef, pork and lamb during the boycott of meat last week found scarce comfort at the seafood counters of supermarkets.

title: Stewart Forshay, 86, Dies; Led Real Estate Concern
description: LARGO, Fla., April 7Stewart Forshay, who retired two years ago as chairman of Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamaton, Inc., New York real estate concern, died today here while on vacation. He was 86 years old and lived In Stamford, Conn.

title: The Region
description: The issue goes to the heart of American life. Educational standards, private property, social justice, race, local autonomy, the Constitutionthey all figure in the national controversy over the financing of public schools.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: 1. In 1929. Stutz was the first oar to offer a car radio the Transitone.

title: Clean Power at Exhibit
description: Pollutionfree automotive power is the theme of this year's Wonderful World of Wheels exhibit at the New York International Automobile Show.

title: How to Rotate Radial Tires
description: DETROIT (UPI)  If your car is equipped with new radial tires, you should know how to rotate them to get the maximum mileage, which manufacturers say is 40,000 miles.

title: L.I. Thrift Shop Deals in the Best
description: LAWRENCE, L.I.  When the door at 340 Central Avenue opens each weekday morning in this affluent village, shoppers fortunate enough to be first on the scene find unheardof bargains in haute couture.

title: Crewman Hit by a Car Coming In for Pit Stop
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., April 7 (UPI)Johnny Galt; 45 years old; of Racine, Wis., a crewman on the Roger McCluskey racing team, was, struck by a stock car as he ran across the pit area at Texas World Speedway today.

title: SMITH AND RICHEY GAIN FINAL TODAY
description: MUNICH, Germany, April 7 (AP)Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., defeated John Alexander of Australia, 61, 62, today and advanced into tomorrow's final against Cliff Richey in the World Championship Tennis series Group A competition.

title: Boycott
description: The outraged housewife put a padlock on her pocketbook last week to smite down the high price of meat. Uaappeased by President Nixon's suddenswitch decision 10 days ago to fix ceilings on the price of beef, pork and lamb, millions of consumers all over the country regiitered their wrath at the steep climb in the cost of everything from steaks to hot dogs by refusing to buy meat in butcher shops, supermarkets or restaurants.

title: Sunderland Gains Cup Soccer Final, Upsetting Arsenal
description: LONDON, April 7 (UPI)Sunderland registered the upset of the season today by defeating Arsenal, 21, to become the first team from the Second Division to reach the Football Association Cup final since Preston in 1964.

title: F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTONAt 3 P.M. last Thursday, 48 days after L. Patrick Gray 3d had been nominated to head the Federal Bureau of Investigation, he picked up a telephone and asked President Nixon to withdraw his name from the Senate's consideration.

title: Michigan Man Receives 13Year Murder Sentence
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., April 7Larry Raymond Fitzpatrick, 24 years old, of Boyne City, Mich., has been sentenced to 13 to 22 years in prison for the murder of Donald E. Fettig, 24, also of Boyne City.

title: Ship's Security Is Extra Tight on Passage to Israel
description: FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus The routine is the same for the Israeli ship Nili at each port on her voyage home through the Mediterranean.

title: Hospital bffers Plan To Relocate 22 Families
description: In an attempt to relocate 22 tenant familes that have helped block its expansion plans for a year and a half, the Methodist. Hospital in Brooklyn has offered each family up to $16,500 if they will all move by July 11.

title: Elks Clubs Told to Pay Tax
description: BOISE, Idaho, April 7 (UPI)The Idaho Tax Commission has ordered county assessors to strip Elks Clubs of their property tax exemptions because the Elks have a racially discriminatory membership policy. The commission chairman, Don C. Loveland, in an order mailed Thursday to the assessors, also directed them to survey other fraternal and benevolent or charitable organizations about policies of racial discrimination.

title: Secretariat Proves Worth by Tying Track Mark in Taking Gotham
description: He equgled a track record doing it, but Secretariat's smashing victory in the Gotham Mile at Aqueduct yesterday was just another preliminary exercise of the kind made by circus acrobats as they limber up for their more spectacular maneuvers.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Helene Cixous's The Exile of James Joyce has an important subtitle. Sally Purcell, her translator, has omitted it. Julian Moynahan, your reviewer, leaves it unmentioned in an extended comment that describes the book as astonishing, eloquent, dauntingly intelligent and philosophically learned. The full French title is L'Exil de James Joyce: ou l'art de remplacement.

title: 11 Horses Killed in Fire; Cigarette Cited as Cause
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia, April 7 (AP)A fire that claimed the lives of 11 horses at Lansdowne Park was touched off by a smoldering cigarette, a fire prevention officer said today.

title: CANADIENS TAKE 3D STRAIGHT, 52
description: BUFFALO, April 7 (AP)The Mahovlich brothers, Pete and Frank, scored one goal each tonight as the Montreal Canadiens scored a 52 victory over the Buffalo Sabres in a National Hockey League playoff game.

title: A survival letter
description: Dear Mary: I am glad to hear about your new baby and pleased your mother has come to live with you. She was quite lonely and with your husband away most of the week, she will be good company for you, too.

title: 2 State Bills On Pollution Stir Debate
description: The battle against pollution on our waterways continues unabatedly these days, which is good, but sometimes what sound good on paper does more harm to boatmen than the situation merits, according to the boating industry.

title: Ft. Greene Patrolled By Youths From Area
description: Every weekday afternoon, Norris Butler puts on his uniform, grabs his walkietalkie and starts patrolling the Fort Greene projects near Myrtle Avenue.

title: Antique Sale
description: A total of 125 antique, classic, modem classic and special interest cars will be offered for auction on June 2 at the Eastern States Exposition Grounds in West Springfield, Mass.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: W.H.A. Playoffs

title: The Nation
description: Wall Street has been suffering, of late, from a crisis of investor confidence, reflected most notably in the flight of the small investor from the market. And such episodes as the Penn Central bankruptcy and the Investors Overseas Services scandals navert helped.

title: Tingley Tops 1,650,Yard FreeStyle Mark by 7 Seconds
description: CINCINNATI, April 7 (AP)lack Tingley, a 6foot7inch University of Southern California junior, broke the American 1,650yard treestyle record by more than 7 seconds tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union national indoor shortcourse swimming meet.

title: Travel Notes: The State of the Interstates
description: T HE question used to be, as the title of the Ada Louise Huxtable book put it, Will They Ever Finish Bruckner Boulevard? Today the question is, Will they ever finish the Interstate Highway System? The nationwide superhighway network, which was started in 1956, was supposed to have been completed in 1972. The new deadline is July 1, 1976, but no one seriously expects that to be met, either, even though it would be a nice birthday present for the country when it celebrates the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

title: Regional Uncertainty
description: The regional approach to economic development of backward areas of the United States is facing uncertainty as the Nixon Administration presses ahead with some opposing concepts.

title: KUWAIT BARS LEASING TWO ISLANDS TO IRAQ
description: KUWAIT, April 7 (AP)Kuwait has told Iraq she will not consider leasing two islands in the Persian Gulf to the Baghdad Government, official sources said today.

title: XEROX CORP. STRUCK FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: ROCHESTER, April 7 (AP)The first strike in the history of the Xerox Corporation began last night when 4,800 production employes walked off their jobs in the company's two plants in Monroe County.

title: Spreading the Word About Good Works
description: Almost everyone has at least a line about it. In many instances, there is a whole page devoted to it. Comoporate social responsibility has become the watchword in company annual reports this season. But what it means depends on what report is read. Many companies talk a lot about the money they spend on pollution control, efforts at hiring and promoting women and minorities and on consumer proteetion, usually concludingthat it is good and in the public interest.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Mr. Hemphill, the mailman, was around at the side of the house throwing magazines and the airmail edition of The London Sunday Times into the bushes we planted there a few years ago to conceal the mounds where the children used to bury cats when they were in their undertaker phase.

title: Machines Now Diagnose ars Ills
description: DETROIT  Sophisticated diagnostic equipment shnilar to electrocardiograms in medicine, is coming into increasing use to take the guesswork out of what is wrong with cars.

title: Miss Woolard Plans Bridal
description: ROCKLEIGH, N.J., April 7 Mr. and Mrs. Paul P. Woolard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Moira Ann Woolard, to Christopher Ely Thiele, son of Roger H. Thiele of North Tarrytown, N. Y., and Mrs. Karen Thiele of Tesuque, N. M.

title: STUDY IS PLANNED OF GUARDS IN CITY
description: There are at least twenty private guards working in the Wall Street area of Manhattan for every policeman on the public payroll. There may be one private guard for every policeman assigned to the Morningside Heights section around Columbia University And in the far less affluent Brownsville section of Brooklyn, there probably is one guard for every six policemen.

title: Debate on Psychosurgery Goes on in Detroit Court
description: DETROIT, April 7  Two months ago, Mr. L., a 36yearold mental patient confined in a state mental hospital for the last 18 years, was a willing candidate for experimental surgery on his brain to change his behavior.

title: THIEU, M. TEXAS, HONORS JOHNSON
description: STONEWALL, Tex., April 7 President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam laid a wreath of yellow lilies and red roses at the grave of the late President Lyndon B. Johnson at the Johnson family cemetery near here today.

title: A Grubby Business
description: AUGUSTA, Me., April 7George Bush, the Republican National Chairman, today called the Watergate wlnetapping incident grubby business and said, I don't think for a minute the President condoned it.

title: Rains and Tornadoes Beset Southeast
description: New rains, flash floods and tornadoes descended on the storrn beleaguered Southeast yesterday, pushing the swollen Mississippi River and its tributaries still higher and driving thousands of residents from homes.

title: Drawbridge Hours Limited
description: The Coast Guard warned boaters yesterday that the Meadowbrook State Parkway drawbridge over Sloop Channel of Hempstead Bay would be under restricted operating conditions from Tuesday through April 20 because a power cable was being installed at the bridge. The bridge will be raised on weekdays from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. only if 24 hours advance notice is given by calling the Johnson Electrical Construction Corporation, (516) 2348383. The bridge will be operated normally at other times.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: In the rolling yellow fields of eastern Washington, where political conservatism runs almost as deep as the wells that irrigate the wheat farms, women to this day use thimbles given to them more than 20 years ago by a local farmer running for the Board of Education.

title: Business Booms At Flea Markets
description: ENGLISHTOWNThe fleamarket phenomenon, fed by rising consumer prices and tight money, has boomed in New Jersey, and fleamarket operators across the state expect their busiest season ever this year.

title: Headliners
description: Four years ago, Thomas Bradley, a black, 21year veteran of the Los Angeles police force, lost in his attempt to replace Sam Yorty as Mayor of Los Angeles. But almost immediately he started running againand last week the pair faced off again in the city's nonpartisan mayoral primary. In 1969, Mr. Bradley had emerged the leader in the primary, only to lose in the runoff as Mr. Yorty raised the specter of militants and radicals trying to take over the city. This time, too, Mr. Bradley won the primary and he aims to keep race from being a major factor in the runoff next month. It remains to be seen whether the votersand Mr. Yortywill cooperate.

title: New and Recommended
description: A BOOK OF CHANGE, by Frederick Morgan. (Scribner's $7.95.) Poems written to master the emotions, as all good poetry does, and that are public, transparent and eloquent.

title: Reference Library Approved In Nassau
description: MINEOLA  The Nassau County Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a $17million bond issue last week for a new central reference library at Mitchel Field in Uniondale.

title: RUTGERS WINS MEET AND SETS 3 MARKS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK N. J., April 7Three Rutgers athletes set university records today as the Scarlet defeated St. John's and Yale in a track and field meet at Rutgers: Rutgers Scored 90 Points, St. John's 74 and Yale 28.

title: Best Seller List
description: FICTION

title: Voice from the real world
description: Professor Zimbardo's research into the psychology of prisons has put him in touch with many real prisoners. Here are excerpts from a convict's letter.

title: A.E.C. Unit Favors A 2d Nuclear Plant
description: LACEY TOWNSHIPThe regulatory staff of the Atomic Energy Commission has issued a report in which it contends that a second nuclear generating plant for the Oyster Creek area would be environmentally acceptable.

title: 5 Bank Branches Use Automatic Teller
description: CLIFTON  Branches of the New Jersey Bank serve customers from the Hudson River to the Delaware, and in five of them SuperTeller 24 quietly purrs away, making banking transactions of almost every kind 24 hours a day, every day of the year.

title: On to Mediterranean
description: Early this year Atlantic City's Commissioner of Public Works proposed an ordinance to change the names of two of that resort city's oldest thoroughfares. The proposal might well have been adopted had the thoroughfares not been Baltic Avenue and Mediterranean Avenue, because those two names also represent properties on the board of Monopoly, America's most successful board game. Commissioner Arthur Ponzio thought it would be less confusing to the tourists to change the real Baltic and Mediterranean to Fairmont and Melrose (the names of their lengthier extensions) apparently believing that nobody would really care.

title: N.Y.U. MAY BUILD SPORTS COMPLEX
description: New York University is studying plans to build an athletic field house on a oneacre plot three blocks soujh of Washington Square Park. University officials said last week that the sports complex had top priority for new construction.

title: PATH
description: The opening of the Holland Tunnel in 1927 began a long slide for the Old Hudson and Manhattan Railroad that ended in bankruptcy in 4954 and a takeover by the Port Authority in 1962. The P.A. pumped $250million into the rattletrap railroad, changed its name to PATH and began to lure back some of the motorists.

title: A Special Unit at Ft. Dix Focuses on Helping Addicts
description: FORT DIX  Directors of the Army's Alcohol and Drug Control Office, which has been in operation on this post for a year and a half, say that their experience reflects the findings and the recommendations made public last week by the National Commission and Marijuana and Drug Abuse.

title: Men Report Seeing Edge of the Universe
description: Astronomers believe they have seen the edge of the universe.

title: Heinsohn Fieriest of Celtics
description: Tom Heinsohn, the Boston Celtics coach, changes his image during a game. He lays aside his cigarettes and coffee and forgets his relaxing hobby as a painter and becomes a bundle of nerves on the bench. His antics could make him an Oscar nominee, rather than one of the leading candidates for coachoftheyear honors in the National Basketball Association.

title: Priest's Tomb Found Near Giza Pyramids
description: CAIRO, April 7 (Reuters) A team of Cairo University archeologists has discovered the tomb of the priest who mummified the body of Chephren Khafre, the Pharaoh who was buried in one of the great Giza pyramids some 4,500 years ago.

title: Two Buildings Get A Major Overhaul At Rockefeller Center
description: New York's largest buildingrenovation project in recent years is under way in Rockefeller Center.

title: 5 Students Display Grasp of Iliad in Original Greek
description: On a sunny spring day when thousands of teen  agers thronged the city's parks and open spaces, five young men submitted themselves instead yesterday to a lengthy scholastic inquisition of their knowledge of all 16,000 lines of Homer's Iliad in Greek.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A good survey of the green revolution. The green revolution, of course, is based on genetic alteration of grains, mainly wheat and rice. Dwarf strains are bred to produce a 50 per cent or even higher yield than conventional strains. The new strains are also adapted to the unseasonal agriculture of many of the underdeveloped countries in warm climates. Mr. Katz shows that the revolution worked for a time, and income of small

title: Racism Is Charged in Wrestling
description: Racism and prejudice have left deep scars on John Logan's mind, as painful as the sixinchlong welts on each of his muscular brown arms. And there are other blacks who have felt the same pain.

title: Army Lacrosse Victor, 84
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 7Army's lacrosse team defeated previously unbeaten Rutgers, 84, today. Phil Lynch and Joe Hennessey scored two goals each for the Cadets. Mike Rinck of Rutgers got three goals.

title: Armco Will Pay $125,000 To Texas in Pollution Cast
description: HOUSTON, April 7 (UPI)Harris County, the State of exas and the Armco Steel Corporation agreed this week to a $125,000. payment to the state in the outofcourt settlement of a pollution suit.

title: COPTERS SPOTTED IN HOG RUSTLING
description: AUDUBON, Iowa, April 7  Law officers in west central and southwest Iowa believe helicopters are being used in the increasingly widespread operations of hog and cattle rustlers in this day of high meat prices.

title: Robert Kennedy Memorial Maps Minority Program
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The Robert F. Kennedy Memorial is being expanded to include a program for minority youth. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has announced.

title: Dr. Beverly Winikoff Betrothed
description: Mrs. Harry Winikoff of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Beverly Winikoff, to Dr. Michael Alpert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Alpert of Desert Hot Springs, Calif. Dr. Winikoff is also the daughter of the late Mr. Winikoff. A July wedding is planned.

title: After a Week, Nation's Supply of Beef Is Sharply Cut
description: CHICAGO, April 7After week of the meat boycott and President Nixon's action putting a ceiling on prices, the nation's supply of beef was sharply reduced today. As a result, wholesale prices remained near their ceiling limits and many packing plants in the Middle West were either closed or operating at a reduced pace.

title: Steam Bus Cuts Smog
description: The final report of the nation's most ambitious effort in more than 40 years to use steam power to propel motor vehicles has concluded that steam propulsion has enormous potential for reducing urban air pollution. But the report adds that enormous technical problems Must be solved if the potential is ever to be exploited.

title: TROOPER'S ACCUSER GETS A YEAR'S TERM
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J. April 7 Earl W. Harris Jr. the man whose tale of torture in a state police barracks led to the convictions of two troopers on charges of misconduct, was sentenced to one year in the Ocean County Jail yesterday with half the sentence suspended.

title: Federal Fund Cutoff to Halt Safety Research at Laboratory
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Seven years of scientific research in, human and environmental factors that contribute to accidents on the highways and in homes and shops are scheduled to be halted here on June 30 because the Federal Office of Management and Budget has cut off funds for the program.

title: East Hampton Is Split On Plan to Halt Building
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.Fred Lester, a utilities company supervisor, can trace his roots back to the original landgrant settlers of East Hampton.

title: SkyjackingSceening Cuts Other Arrests at Airports
description: The Federal Aviation Administration says that the number of air travelers caught for possession of guns and drugs and for other crimes has declined sharply since nationwide screening of all passengers at airports began three months ago.

title: Miss Gay Whiting Is the Bride Of Harold William Schaefer 2d
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., April 7  In Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Gay Whiting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Rice Whiting 3d of Short Hills, became the bride of Harold William Schaefer 2d of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Schaefer of Bloomington, Ill.

title: The Consumer Spending Surge
description: The Consumer Spending Surge exemptions were claimed, withholding would amount to $260, and with one exemption, $410.80.

title: Pros a Hit on Track, But Not at Box Office
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 7Professional track is doing fine at the perform ance level, but not much has happened in the counting house so far. At Tingley Coliseum here last night, for example. Brian Oldfield set a world indoor record for the shotput, 70 feet 9 inches; Lee Evans ran the fastest indoor 440yard dash, 49 seconds, accomplished by an obviously paid athlete, and Kip Keino did 4:03.7 in the mile, which was regarded as a real achievement because the altitude is 5,100 feet here.

title: White House Grounds Will Be Open to Public
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will open the White House grounds April 14 and 15 for a garden tour.

title: Tito Pressing Drive to Strengthen Party and Reform Economy
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 7  President Tito, who half a century ago undertook a career as Marxist revolutionary among his fellow workers in Croatia, once again has turned to factory workers to rally support for revolutionary transformation  this time inside the Communist party he heads.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe telegram from the Commander in Chief was nothing less than exultant. Please relay to your troops my personal appreciation and my hopes that the winning cornbination you have forged will hang together for further successes.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: 1. JONATHAN LIVINGSTON SEAGULL. Bach. Well, there's this philosophical seagull, see, and heoh forget it.

title: FRANCE
description: PARIS  The picturebook Frenchman used to wear a beret, sport a mustache and love women and wine. The contemporary Frenchman, mostly hatless and often cleanshaven, also loves his car, which most often is a gray Peugeot Model 204, according to the statistics.

title: JANKUNIS SNAPS 2 MEET RECORDS
description: Billy Jankunis, who hadn't trained in two weeks,. set two meet records yesterday in the scholastic Brandeis Relays at Downing Stadium In Randalls Island.

title: Smaller Radar Clocks Cars
description: TRENTONA handheld, portable radar unit, capable of tracking vehicles to a range of one mile, has speeders in eight communities in central add northern Newsrsey warily peeking over their shoulders.

title: The bare
description: Comfort and the utter simplicity achieved by paring away extraneous elements are Joseph Whited's guidelines for designing interiors. His own apartment on a high floor of an older midtown building shows that they can lead to an easy, understated elegance. Rather than starting out with a master plan in mind and acquiring furnishings to fit it, he pared down and discarded. The present look evolved during several years of living in the apartment and discovering gradually the furniture and arrangement that resulted in a feeling of comfort both when he was alone as well as when he entertained. The color scheme is predominantly monochromatic  honey  toned wool rugs and upholstery with darker browns and a dash of black for accent. Plants and fur pillows subdue the severity of the apartment's modern lines.

title: The FellowTravellers
description: During the period roughly from the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917 to the Hungarian uprising of 1956, those who sympathized to a greater or lesser degree with the policies of the Soviet Union but never joined the Communist party were often carelessly lumped together under the label fellowtraveler. It was a large umbrella indeed, capable of covering committed individualists like Andre Gide and nearMarxists like Bertolt Brecht, such lifelong friends of Eastern Communism as Edgar Snow and such occasional allies as Sidney and Beatrice Webb  in fact the whole gamut from JeanPaul Sartre to Danny Kaye. In postwar America the term came to mean something sinister, but for the most part the fellowtravelers were nowhere near being fifth columnists. They were sympathizers, and therein lies the rub, for in the context of the hewhoisnotwithmeisagainstme mentality that off and on characterized the mental set on both sides of the Iron Curtain, they couldn't fit in well anywhere for long.

title: LIBYA HALTS AID TO CHAD REBELS
description: FORTLAMY, Chad (April (AP)Libya has cut off arms supplies to rebels in this landlocked nation in the heart of Africa, apparently as a reward for Chad's, rupture of diplomatic ties with Israel last November.

title: Webb Head U.S. Team For 11Day Tour of Europe
description: CINCINNATI, Aprit 7 (AP)) Rick Colella, a University of Washington senior who was the high point winner in the national Amateur Athletic Union meet, will head a 27member United States swimming squad for a European tour later this month.

title: HOUSING DECISION IRKS HAMTRAMCK
description: HAMTRAMCK, Mich., April 7Mayor Raymond Wojtowicz has announced plans to appeal a decision by a United States District Court in Detroit ordering Hamtramck to construct 530 new housing units for the residentsmost of them black and elderly  who have been displaced by urban and industrial development in the city since 1962.

title: Kay L. Zendler Becomes Bride Of S. B. Osborn
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 7Miss Kay Lorraine tendler, daughter of William Trayice Zendler of Sydney, Australia, and the late Mrs. Zendler, was married here this morning to Steele Bartley Osborn, son of Mrnd Mrs. Edward Bartley Osborn of Bronxville, Palm Beach, and Tryall, Jamaica, W. I.

title: Moving away from the coldwar era
description: We are living through a fascinating period of transition in the making of foreign policy. After 25 years of a relatively frozen situation, old moorings are coming loose, new options are opening up and statesmanship is being given new creative opportunities. Transitions, of course, always cause dilemmas and these are thoughtfully mirrored in the hundredorso pages of A World Elsewhere, by James Chace, who is currently managing editor of Foreign Affairs quarterly.

title: Police in Bermuda Study Month's 2d Double Killing
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 7 (AP)  Local policemen and Scotland Yard detectives were investigating today the second double murder in four weeks in this British island colony.

title: State's Safety Council Is Honored
description: NEWARKThe New Jersey State Safety Council has received an award for establishing the best defense driving program in the country. The announcement was made last month at the annual meeting of the council's board of trustees.

title: Blood
description: WASHINGTONIt is a temptation to think of bones as nothing more than the body's structural supportsthe girders on which the whole living edifice hangs.

title: NAVY TRACKMEN BEAT MANHATTAN
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md. April 7Mike keogh and Tony Colon of Manhatten scored an impress sive middledistante double, sweeping the mile and two mile, in a dual meet with Navy today. Navy won the meet though, 120 points to 33.

title: Television
description: IAM not alone. Someone is out there, every day, taking care of things. I may be here, in this house, with these children and this particular husband, all of us here in this life together, around the table eating Meals and interrupting each other. But between 7 and 9:30 every weekday morning, no matter what, I can turn on the television and she is there. Barbara Walters. I have read the profiles; that woman gets up at 5 o'clock in the morning, and look at her: Alert? On top of her subject?

title: Study Seeks to Determine Best Treatment for Breast Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, April. 7 About 900 patients have been enrolled so far in longterm studies to determine the best kind of treatment for breast cancer. The studies are sponsored by the National Cancer Institute.

title: Unseeded Kerry Harris In Final With Mrs. Court
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 7 Top  seeded Mrs. Margaret Court, the current ruler of women's tennis, and unseeded Kerry Harris, who some people are touting as a possible successor, will meet tomorrow afternoon in an allAustralian final of the $50,000 MaxPax tournament.

title: Movies
description: BLACK used to be Hattie McDaniel with a feather duster and Stepin Fetchit polishing the rump of a racehorse and Bill Bojangles Robinson in spic and span livery tapping up and down the mastah's staircase with little colonel Shirley. Gay used to be Franklin Pangbarn as a prissy florist and Eric Blore as a primping butler and Erik Rhodes as a flouncy dress designer whom Ginger Rogers spurned for Fred Astaire in The Gay Divorcee.

title: What's left to eat? Plenty
description: Trying everything from Zen macrobiotic diets to the Atkins Diet Revolution, caught between $2billion worth of advertising for highly processed foods and soft drinks and claims of miracle cures and rejuvenation through megavitamin therapy and organic foods, exposed daily to categorical statements by authorities of unknown qualifications, the American public is feeling more and more confused.

title: The wonderful world of tax shelters
description: The Federal incometax schedule runs from 14 per cent on the first $1,000 of taxable income to 70 per cent on taxable income over $200,000. Under this schedule the effective rate of tax on individualstheir total tax as a percentage of their total income  should be 45 per cent for incomes of $100,000; 64 per cent for incomes of $500,000; and 67 per cent for incomes of $1million. The actual average effective rate of tax for individuals with incomes of over $100,000 is in the range of 29 to 33 per cent.

title: RAIN POSTPONES PLAY IN MASTERS
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7A steady rain forced postponement of the third round of the Masters golf tournament today, possibly jeopardizing Jack Nicklaus's chance of winning the event for the fifth time.

title: News of the Rialto
description: TALK about nostalgia! Remember the Andrews Sisters Patti, Maxene and LaVernewho made themselves part of the sound of the forties? Remember their inimitable recordings, which included Bei Mir Bist du Schoen, Don't Sit Under the Apple Tree and Pistol Packin Mama? Well, Patti and Maxene are with us still and, come fall, they hope to be cavorting in our town in a musical called Victory Canteen.

title: Immigration
description: The words of a Beatles songget back to where you once belongedtook on new, ironic overtones, last week for John Lennon, the 32yearold former Beatle who has been battling to remain in the United States.

title: AvantGctrde Accidemician
description: THE Bruce Nauman show at the Whitney Musewn is remarkable in several respects, none of them having to do with significant artistic achievemeat. Of course, we are long past expecting our museums to apply any stringent artistic standards to the general run of shows that appear under their auspices. But the Nauman exhibition marks a certain nadir even for the Whitney, where for some years the only discernible standard among its younger curators has been a solemn determinationas vulgar as Is comicto keep abreast of whatever it is that makes a claim to avantgarde status at any given moment. The Nauman show is indeed a perfect example of estabhshmentarian taste Operating under the banner of vanguard esthetics.

title: SURGEONS TAUGHT LATEST ADVANCES
description: More than 5,000 doctors met here last week at a conference devoted to bringing the practicing surgeon up to date on treatments for common medical conditions.

title: Letters: Where Theie's Smoke
description: In the Dec. 31 Travel Notes article about a stricter regulation against smoking in airplanes (Caution, Smoke ing Is Hazardous to Passengers Comfort, by Jonathan B. Segal), excerpts from a letter by Larry Goodman of Phoenix, Ariz., to the Civil Aeronautics Board, included this passage: I consider it an infringement of my personal freedom and a detriment to my health to be a captive audience 40,000 feet up in the blue sky with someone puffing and blowing smoke around me.

title: Warm Springs, Ga.: A Famous Dateline Declines in Disuse
description: WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 12 [1945]President Franklin D. Roosevelt, his strength sapped away as CommanderinChief in Ariterica's greatest war, died this afternoon. Associated Press

title: Kidnapped American Freed
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 7 (UPI) Anthony R. daCruz, an American executive held by kidnappers since Monday was released today, the Kodak Argentina Corporation announced. Mr. daCruz, 43yearsold, a Portugueseporn United States citizen, had been kidnapped by eight armed men as he drove toward the Kodak plant. While the announcement did not disclose the ransom paid, one report, which Kodak Argentina declined to confirm, was that it was $1.5million.

description: MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, N. J., April 7Sixtyfive policemen from a number of communities disrupted a fundraising rally last night at which a man accused of killing a patiolman in the 1967 Plainfield racial riots was to have spoken.

description: LONDON, April 7 (AP)The unbeaten Montana allstars basketball team scored the 10th victory on its British tour today by defeating a United States Air Force team, 13659.

description: ITHACA, N. Y.  He who visits New York State's Finpa Lake region to take part an the opening day of the trout season may be overwhelmed by the thousands of anglers in quest of rainbow trout that have ascended the tributory streams to spawn.

title: Grocery Offering Philippine Foods
description: EAST ORANGE  All it takes is a small dish of pancit or a heaping one of mango ice cream to make a homesick Filipino feel like he's never left home. And, once he hears about the Philhouse, a grocery at 17 Prospect Street, he is likely to become a lifetime customer.

title: Indian Talks Delayed
description: Negotiations to implement an agreement ending the siege of Wounded Knee, S. D., were postponed in Washington yesterday as a dispute developed between Indian leaders and Justice Department officials. Page 34.

description: NEW BRUNSWICKMiddlesex County, sheriff's officers will start training this week with black steel stun guns that will replace the standard .38caliber revolvers used in the courthouse.

description: ASTORIA, Ore., April 7Oregon may breed salmon to swim north instead of south when they leave the mouth of the Columbia River here unless a fishing dispute with California can be worked out.

description: A Transit Authority bus operated by a driver with 17 years experience struck six parked cars late yesterday afternoon as the driver was about to begin his eastbound run on West 86th Street.

title: POINT OF VIEW

Cyert, president of CarnegieMellon University, and Mrs. Cyert have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucinda Carol Cyert, to Eugene Quirn Steffes 3d, son of Brig. Gen. E. Q. Steffes Jr., U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Steffes of Offutt Air Force Base, Omaha. A July wedding is planned.

Evans Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Charlottesville, were married this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Dudley A. Boogher.

description: A 32yearold minister with firm theories about community building has become a guiding force in the development of new housing in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

description: Every now and then, a railroad man for 26 years and a onetime trolley motorman, walks from his home to Rockaway Parkway and Avenue J in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn and pays his respects to the old trolleys of Brooklyn. His name: Nick Morrone.

title: Education Campaign Is Aimed At Veterans
description: Brooklyn College is planning a major drive to inform veterans of the war in Vietnam in the borough that they are eligible for many of the services provided by the college even if they have not completed high school or were not discharged honorably. The college is seeking to reach 43,000 veterans.

title: People Will Always Be Kind
description: The chances are that it has already been said, and by Wilfrid Sheed himself. Whatever words you have found for his work he already has rejected, before moving on to words yet more apt. He turns your condescensions back on you before they have a chance to apply. He surrounds them with an irony that reveals what you left out. The condescensions of his essay The Minor Novelist are surrounded by the irony of his having written six minor novels himself: At his best moments, he thinks of himself as the last Of the oldifashioned craftsmen, turning out water clocks or filigreed sleeve garters.

title: GOLDEN ERA WINS AT NEW CANAAN
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 7Golden Era, an aged chestnut gelding, won the junior working hunter championship at the New Canaan Mounted Troop Horse Show today for his new owner and rider, 14yearold Laurie Fulton of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Highway Funds Spur New Fight
description: WASHINGTONAt a time when the Nixon Administration is committed to holding down government spending and taxes, and when pro; grams to aid the Cities are being jettisoned like excess baggage on a sinking ship, there is a stash of money in the Federal bankroll that is not being fully spent.

title: Brandt Bans X Movies In 6Week Clinton Test
description: CLINTON  The Brandt Theater chain has agreed to a sixweek experiment during which it will show only generalaudience movies at the only movie house in this town of 5,000.

title: Colson Reported Passing A Lie Test on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Charles W. Colson, former apedal counsel to President Nixon, has, voluntarily taken a private liedetector test in New York to buttress his sworn testimony, that he had nothing to do with the Watergate raid last summer.

title: Legislature Tackles A TaxBill Package
description: TRENTON  A package ofbills that would dramatically change New Jersey's system of handling tax appeals is slowly making its way through the Legislature.

title: Rome Is Restricting Autos To Protect Aurelius Statue
description: ROME, April 7 (AP)  The Government is going to ban automobiles from the Piazza del Campidoglio to protect the 1,800  year  old statue of Emperor Marcus Aurelius.

title: GIANTS BEAT REDS IN II INNINGS, 75
description: CINCINNATI, April. 7 (AP)Bobby Bonds's tworun double in the 11th inning enabled the San Francisco Giants to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 75, in a rainplagued game today. Bonds had homered in the seventh.

title: Fordham Lightweight Eight Triumphs Over Kings Point
description: Fordham's crew scored its first victory of the season as the lightweight varsity eight finished seven seconds ahead of Kings Point yesterday on the 2,000 meter Harlem Rive course. The Rams were topped in 5 minutes, 59.7 seconds Fordham rode at 34 strokes per minute and was in the lead from the start.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times is to be congratulated for its penetrating efforts to promote an informed public and open discourse on such crucial constitutional issues as the relationship between the Presidency and Congress [news articles March 4, 5 and 6]. As the late Prof. Harold Laski and other observers have reiterated, the authority of the Constitution rests principally on the constant scrutiny of a concerned citizenry.

title: Secretariat Equals Mark At Aqueduct, Pays $2.20
description: Secretariat took a positive step in the direction of retaining the championship that he won last year, at Aqueduct yesterday. The Meadow Stable star, syndicated at a price of $6,080,000, won the onemile Gotham with a smashing recordbreaking performance.

title: CHINATOWN FIRES SPUR RENT STRIKE
description: Ten weeks ago, the usually passive and uncomplaining residents of a dilapidated Chinatown building, who for years accepted defective electrical wiring, faulty plumbing, falling plaster and boiler breakdowns, declared a rent strike. They did so after fire swept through the sixstory structure, causing severe damage.

title: Tom Benton of Mazura Comes Back to Joplin Grown Up
description: AYONE who thinks regionalism in American art died on December 7,1941, along with isolationism in American politics, just hasn't been to the right region lately. They certainly weren't in Joplin, Mo., the weekend of March 23 when the city celebrated its centennial with the dedication of a new mural by a native son, Thomas Hart Benton. Mr. Benton be only sixteen years younger than the town itself, come his eightyfourth birthday next Sunday.

title: More thoughts out of China
description: In viewing China, Americans have an extraordinary capacity to shape their picture of the country to fit their own mood and preconceptions of the moment. Only a short while ago the predominant images of China in the United States were almost wholly negative. China was viewed, alternately, as an aggressive colossus about to overrun Asia, or as a crippled giant on the verge of internal chaos and collapse. Today, the pendulum is clearly swinging far in the opposite direction. In a mood of euphoric admiration of all things Chinese, many Americans now seem to see it as a country with few if any warts, surging ahead at breakneck pace toward a model new China at home and superpower status abroad.

title: A Fertile Land Of Varied People
description: THE LAND  Sikkim is 2,745 square miles in area, situated in the Himalayas between Nepal and Bhutan, with Tibet to the north and India to the south. It is a fertile land, with wide varieties of climate and wildlife, and is known to the Sikkimese as DenjoinThe Valley of Rice.

title: Keeping the President, in Line
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.War is the forcinghouse of executive power, and the end of war usually brings a reaction against the Presidency. Radical Republicans after the Civil War sought to cripple the President's authority over his Cabinet members and even his military commanders. Conservative Republicans after World War I counterattacked the Wilson Presidency. Isolationist Republicans after World War II pushed the Bricker Amendment in order to roll back the President's authority in foreign policymaking.

title: La Prevoyante Returns To the Winner's Circle
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 7 (AP)La Prevoyante, the 2yearold filly of the year last season, returned to the winner's circle with ease today after, having suffered the first defeat of her career earlier this year.

title: C. M. Pincus to Wed Miss Penny Sussman

title: A Car Population Explosion Abroad
description: OMEJulius Caesar ordered in 45 B.C. that no cart or chariotexcept those carrying the vestal virginscould enter the city Rome between sunrise and sunset. Now, another Roman administration is planning to ban the chariots again, at least from the Eternal City's historic nucleus, in an attempt to prevent its strangulation and destruction.

description: You tell yourself you are going to bicycle across the country, from New Hampshire to California, oneeighth the circumference of the planet, and you hear your answers:

title: Karel Reisz Gambles on Las Vegas
description: KAREL REISZ, considered one of Britain's brightest directorial talents because of his smashing success several seasons ago with Saturday Night and Sunday Morning and Morgan!, has been depressingly absent from the film scene since 1969, the year of his butchered but beautiful The Loves of Isadora. But Reisz will soon be back where he belongs  sort of Although he won't he churning his cameras along the Thames, he will be shooting a movie in Las Vegas. Reisz, who has shied away from Hollywood for a long time, apparently received an offer he couldn't refuse from Paramount. So, starting in June, he will direct The Gambler, drama based on an original screenplay by James Toback about an English literature teacher at our own City College who is bitten by the gambling bug and lights out for Las Vegas.

title: Numismatics
description: At, uncirculated, olivetoned specimen of the 1787 George Clinton cent, said to be the finest of the five known specimens, sold for $34,000 at the auction conducted by Stack's last weekend in conjunction with the 17th annual Metropolitan New York Numismatic Convention. The bidding opened with an $18,000 mail offer, but then floor bidders immediately took over and, in $1,000 jumps, carried the piece to the knockdown price in little more than one minute. The winning bidder is reported to have said he was prepared to go substantially higher and considered the piece a bargain at $34,000.

description: New York 3, Philadelphia 2. San Diego 4, Los Angeles 3 (n.)

description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 7 (UPI)Finland has decided to give diplomatic recognition to North Korea as well as South Korea, the Foreign Ministry said today.

description: FREEHOLD, N.J., April 7 (AP) Our Prize captured the $8,000 Woodbury mile pace by a nose at Freehold Raceway today and paid $4.80, $3 and $2.20 for $2 across the board.

description: AUBURN, Ala., April 7 Auburn University may soon be calling on its loyal Florida alumni with an unusual request: Help your alma mater by taking in a homeless dog.

description: Serve em up! was the cry yesterday as the outdoor tennis season officially began with the opening of 500odd municipal courts throughout the five boroughs.

description: Msgr. John A. McDermott, pastor emeritus of Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church, Morninpide Drive and 114th Street, died Friday in the Pope Plus VI residence for priests in Riverdale, the Bronx lie was 76 years old. Monsignor McDermott was pastor of Notre Dame Church from 1965 until his retirement last year.

title: We Are Utterly Unable to Let Henry Alone by WALTER KERR
description: PIRANDELLO'S Emperor Henry IV, as it is being called in its current, flamboyantly caparisoned and spikily acted revival at the Barrymore, is such an awkward, erratic, fascinating play that we tend to throw up our hands and call it a masterpiece, hoping to be rid of it and its problems that way Masterpiece becomes a word we hide behind, relieving ourselves of the obligation of trying to explain why it never seems to function as well on the stage as, say, Six Characters in Search of an Author or even Right You Are If You Think You Are.

title: What's New in the 1973 Imports
description: Volkswagen, the perennial best seller, hai iiputation for sticking to one body style, making slight alterations each year only when they are functionally necessary. The company prides itself on the basic Beetle shape. But this year, that conformity has been compromised.

title: FENCING TITLE WON BY CORNELL WOMEN
description: TRENTON, April 7Cornell successfully defended its National Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association championship today by rolling up 106 victories, six more than secondplace William Paterson College.

title: Miss Geller Fiancee Of Jeffrey Posner
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Geller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lydia Susan Geller, to Jeffrey Posner, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Posner of Floral Park, L.I. The wedding is planned for next March.

title: A New Test In Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON  In the spring of 1970 President Nixon provoked what he later was to describe as an unprecedented barrage of criticism by sending American troops into Cambodia. The stated purpose was to clear out North Vietnamese sanctuaries in that presumably neutral country and eliminate a military threat on South Vietnam's western flank.

title: Congress Renews Drive For Safer School Buses
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Of the 20 million children who board school buses each year, about 35 are killed in bus accidents. An estimated 40,000 other children suffer disabling injuries.

title: the traveler's world
description: MIAMI  Residents of Miami and Miami Beach  and visitors, too  take much pride in the string of shining white cruise liners tied up in the new Port of Miami on Dodge Island, a short turn off Biscayne Boulevard. And justifiable pride it is, because Miami in five years has Come the busiest cruise port in the Vidted States, outrunning her neighbor and earlier starter, Port Everglades, just up the coast at Fort Lauderdale, and eying New York City's crumbling waterfront and faltering shipping far behind.

description: College and School Results

title: ISRAELIS QUESTION CUTBACK 111 HOMES
description: TEL AVIV, April 7A Government decision to cut back home construction this year has raised eyebrows in a society in which housing shortages have been a major source of social tensions.

title: Linda Sandfort Wed to A. J. G. Sparrow
description: BETHLEHEM, Conn., April 7Miss Linda N. Sandfort, daughter of Mrs. Nelson Sandfort of New York and Southbury, and the late Richard Leland Sandfort, was married this afternoon to Anthony John Guy Sparrow, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Sparrow of Horsham, England.

title: Wholesale Trouble The Truly Dreary News
description: WASHINGTON  It isn't only meat, or even just food. The truly dreary news on the inflation front last week was in a figure watched closely by economists but not widely familiar to consumersthe wholesale price index of industrial commodities. This index went up 1.2 per cent in Marchthe largest monthly increase since the Korean War inflation of 1951. What is worse, the indexwhich includes such diverse commodities as copper, machine tools, shirts and automobiles rose for the first quarter of this year at an annual rate, of 10.3 per cent, a larger increase than in any quarter during the long Vietnam war inflation, which had seemed to cool off in late 1971 and 1972.

title: Massachusetts Auto Penalty
description: BOSTON, April 7 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent has signed legislation allowin; the Registry of Motor Vehicles to suspend licenses of drivers who fail to pay auto excise taxes. Previously, the registrar had the authority to revoke or suspend auto registrations, but not licenses.

title: Women's Golf for Denver
description: DENVER, April 7 (UPI)The second annual National Jewish Hospital Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament will be held at the Green Gables country Club in Denver Aug. 2426, tournament officials said today. All proceeds from the threeday affair go to the children's treatment facilities at the hospital.

title: QUEEN'S HUSTLER TAKES COAST RACE
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 7Lightly regarded Queen's Hustler defeated Big Spruce by a head and thwarted the bid of Cougar II to enter the thoroughbrd millionaires club today in the $125,000 San Juan Capistrano invitation handicap at invitation handicap at Santa Anita Park.

title: NoFault Gaining In States
description: WASHINGTON  The movement for nofault automobile insurance has started to take on bandwagon aspects with four state legislatures climbing aboard in the early months of 1973 and others poised to follow.

title: APPOINTIVE PLAN ON JUDGES SCORED
description: State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein declared yesterday that the judiciary would lose its independence if members of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, were appointed by the Governor rather than elected by the people.

title: Kerr on The Karl Marx Play
description: ALL of the other characters in Rochelle Owens's The Karl Marx Play, now trying its dubious wings at the American Place Theater, keep hounding poor Karl. Why don't you writes Das Kapital? they want to know, displaying remarkable familiarity with the title though nary a word seems to have been put to paper. Or You'll never write Das Kapital', they mourn, shaking their heads and sometimes kicking one another. On the evidence of the very freeform evening, With incidental songs by Galt MacDermot that range from American showboatbanjo to outdoor Viennese, I'd say Plat there were five or six very clear reasons why Marx is not getting on with his work:

title: Taps, Bugs AplentyFor What?
description: In his continuing study of the costs and benefits of electronic surveillance, Herman Schwartz of the State University of New York at Buffalo has produced a new accounting that is at once encouraging and unsettling.

title: Elise Silverman Becomes Bride Of R. J. Kaschak
description: Miss Elise Sharon Silverman, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Benjamin Silverman of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last night to Robert J. Kaschak. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kaschek of Binghamton, N. Y.
