description: Yankee Box Score

title: DEEPSEA DUMPING RAISES QUESTIONS
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., April 7 (AP)  Oceanographers say that garbage dumped in the deep ocean will probably degrade so slowly that one day large quantities could float up undecayed and contaminate seas and beaches.

title: Music
description: LAST week Pierre Cochereau sat at the organ in Philharmonic Hall and gave a demonStation of the lost art of improvisation. Themes were drawn from a hat, and from those themes he created an organ symphony and whatever else his pleasure happened to dictate. Fugues, sonata developments, all rolled exquisitely fibm Cochereau's nimble mind and fingers.

title: Plans Are Canceled for Closing Catholic School for Girls on S.I.
description: St. JosephbytheSea, a Roman Catholic high school for girls in the Huguenot section of Staten Island, got a new lease on life last week when plans to close it next year were canceled.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: April 4Rangers 6, Bost. 2. April 5Rangers 4, Boston 2. April 7Boston 4, Rangers 2. April 8At Madison Square Garden, 8:35 P.M. April 10At Boston, 7:35 P.M. April 12At Madison Square Garden, 8:05 P.M. April 14 or 15At Boston. Time to be announced.

title: Official at Wellesley College Shifting to U. of Puget Sound
description: TACOMA, Wash., April 7R. Franklin Thompson, president of the University of Puget Sound for 31 years, will be replaced in June by Philip Phibbs, executive vice president of WelMiley College, the university has announced.

title: Camera World
description: In a joint release issued some weeks ago, Canon U.S.A. and the Bell & Howell Consumer Products, Group announced that under the terms of a new agreement reached between the two corporations all Canon brand photographic products previously distributed in the United States and Canada by Bell & Howell will now be distributed directly by Canon. This new arrangement will start on July 1, with Canon planning to continue existing arrangements with all camera dealers who have been handling. Canon products distributed by Bell & Howell.

title: A Town in Missouri, Citing Strings, Gives Back Federal Gift
description: STOUTSVILLE, Mo., April 7 It was only a $222 revenuesharing check that the city fathers of this northeast Missouri town sent back, but for community of about 35 persons that is quite a lot. It is as though the city of New York sent about $50  million back with a request for the Federal Government to keep its nose out of the city's business.

title: Valente and Valenti Team For a Program of Handel
description: Valente and Valenti are not ballroom dancers but two distinguished musicians who joined forces for a delightful mostly Handel program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night.

title: R. F. O'Brien Weds Clare Lynch
description: Miss Clare Lynch and Richard Francis O'Brien were married yesterday afternoon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer by the Rev. Patrick Walsh A reception was given at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Kenneth Riegel Went to the Zoo
description: THE title role in Hans Werner Henze's The Young Lord, the New York City Opera's newest production, is taken by Kenneth Riegel, one of the company's finest tenors. In the role he is required play the part of Adam, a circus ape, who is dressed, up and passed off as Lord Barrat, the nephew of one Sir Edgar. At the end of the opera he reverts to his original self in the excitement of a large ball. So far Riegel has found the opera a rather hazardous experience, and here is how he describes it:

title: Westchester's Links To Open Wednesday
description: Westchester's five public golf courses will reopen Wednesday. The courses are Saxon Woods in Scarsdale, Maple Moor in White Plains, Dunwoodie and Sprain Lake in Yonkers, and Mohansic in Yorktown. Heights.

title: SEALS CAMPAIGN GAINS IN OMNI
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 7When Bobby Seale announce last May that he would seel election as Mayor of Oakland his campaign was looked on more as a reflection of the change in the Black Panthe party than as the beginning of a serious political venture.

title: New Jersey
description: New Jersey

title: Harris Thrives on Hard Knocks
description: The nose has been brokenhow many times? Oh, quite a few, replied Ron Harris. I really don't remember. The knee he thought was finished. Now, winning the Stanley Cup is a possibility. For the first time in my life I'm on a team with a chance to go all the way.

title: Margaret Sleeper Plans Bridal
description: ANNANDALE  ON  HUDSON, April 7Dr. and Mrs. William A. Sleeper of AnnandaleonHudson and Camden, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Allen Sleeper, to Jonathan David Tankel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Tankel of Fair Lawn, N. J. Mr. Sleeper is a member of the music faculty of Bard College here, and Mrs. Sleeper is a member of the English faculty of Dutchess Community College.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets Matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers In reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, thore cond end third, the third end fourth the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Because they were regarded as the poor relations of the lordly New York Giants and because they had very little identity of their own, the New York Yankees were ideal house guests during their early years of sharing the Polo Grounds with a ball club that not only dominated New York, but virtually owned it. And the man who dominated the Giants as well as All baseball was the managerial genius, John McGraw.

title: Art: A Touch of Theology
description: JERSEY CITYThe wayout world of abstract art and the stern discipline of Jesuit theology may seem like strange companions; however, in the work of the Rev. Oscar Magnan, they are reconciled.

title: Home Sales on Rise On L. I. South Fork
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.Summer rentals on Long Island's South Fork are slightly below normal, a survey of real estate brokers disclosed last week, but there appears to be a boom in housing and building plot sales in this town, East Hampton and the villages of Sag Harbor and Bridgehampton.

title: MEATISLONTLY IN AUSTRALIA TOO
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 7 (Reuters)  Australian meat prices continue to soar but attempts by housewives organizations to stage buying boycotta have for the most part been unsuccessful.

title: RIGHTS STRATEGY VOTED BY WOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  The National Women's Political Caucus voted today to adopt what it called an elective strategy to obtain ratification of the proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution.

title: The Making of a NonSuperstar
description: RUDOLF Firkusny has the kind of career from which legends are not made. Ever since he came here from his native Czechoslovakia 35 years ago, the pianist has gradually and modestly laid the solid foundation for an international reputation that places him among the world's most respected and genuine keyboard artists. Credit him with guts as well as perseverance. The 61yearold musician has never taken the easy way out.

title: Nuptials for Mrs. Hirsch, W. H. Friedman
description: ALBANY, April 7 Mrs. Mercedes Hirsh and William H. Friedman were married here this evening at the home of the bride by Rabbi Daniel Wolk of Temple EmanuEl of Westchester.

title: 2 FOREIGN JURISTS REBUFFED BY GREECE,
description: ATHENS, April 7The Government rejected today as, un lacceptable interference an attempt by a United States and a British jurist to investigate the arrest of six young Athens lawyers by the military police five weeks ago.

title: The World
description: MOSCOW  What, again? That was the reaction of most Russians last week to the announcement of yet another economic reform  one that would consolidate the Soviet Union's 50.000 industrial plants into a system of large Government corporations, each combining a number of related factories. The people have been through so many reorganizations of Soviet industry that they tend to be skeptical of one more plan to correct the chronic problem of inefficiency and poor product quality.

title: Volunteer Aide 50 Years.
description: Mrs. Rachel Everson, who will be honored for 50 years of work for voluntary organizations in Brooklyn at a dinner this Thursday, paints a vivid picture of her early days of community work. There were gangs then, as now, and as now, weapons seemed to be easy to get, she reminisced. I remember we had to ask some of the boys at ColonySouth Brooklyn Settlement houses to deposit their guns on the table before we'd allow them to enter.

title: Imports Slowed By Devaluation
description: DETROIT  Moving into mid  February, the spunky little foreign, cars were back on the high load again, almost certainly:headed for an eighth consecutive year of record sales.

title: DIDIANSOCCUPYING APITAIA OF SIKKIM
description: NEW DELHI, April 7Indian troops have reportedly taken control of Gangtok, the capital of Sikkim, at the request of the ruler of the tiny Himalayan protectorate.

title: MRS. JAMES W. TURGEON
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 7Mrs. Patricia Ann Turgeon, wife of James William Turgeon, an executive with the National Geographic Magazine, died today at the Princeton Medical Center. Her age was 46. Mrs. Turgeon was a graduate of Marymount College in Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: If You Go.
description: to the Pliny Freeman Farm, you can explore the entire Old Sturbridge Village with its stores, artisan shops, mills, residences, schools, taverns and churches where the yoemen would meet, trade, study, drink, quarrel and pray. Then you can follow any of the village's main dirt roads to the farm, which should first be seen from the fields if it is to be fully appreciated. Walk straight down to a small wooden bridge over the millrace that creeps through the fields and stand near the center of the farm. Woods of ash, maple, hickory, Oak, hemlock and pine form a circle of green around farm, a stately reminder that clearing the land is a task for generations.

title: Thompson Has Surgery
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 7 (AP) David Thompson, an allAmerican basketball player at North Carolina State, was operated on yesterday to remove damaged cartilage in his right knee. Thompson had knee trouble throughout the post season, but still led the second ranked Wolfpack to a 270 wonlost record.

title: Mine Safety Chief, Reprimanded for Trip in a Company Plane, Is Reported Involved in Other Violations
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Government's top coalmine safety official has been severely reprimanded for one of several free trips he took in the corporate aircraft of companies holding major contracts with his agency, the Bureau of Mines.

title: Auto Boom: Hottest Ever
description: DETROIT  Edward J. Meier, a Ford dealer in Memphis, Tenn., feels good this spring.

title: Michele Marie Sheridan Bride Of Kevin Quinn, Lawyer Here
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., April  Miss Michele Marie Sheridan, whose father is retired general manager of the Pfizer CorporationAustralasia, was married here this morning to Kevin A. Quinn, whose father is president of the New York Bank for Savings. The Rev. James N. Loughran performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Marymount Academy Chapel.

title: Tax Refund Shift Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI)  Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, has introduced legislation that would force the Internal Revenue Service to pay a 6 per cent penalty if it fails to issue a refund within 30 days to a taxpayer who files a valid claim by March 1. Under existing law, the service has 45 days from the April 15 filing deadline to issue a refund without drawing an interest penalty.

title: Baby Giant Panda Lures Crowds to Peking's Zoo
description: PEKING, April 7 (Reuters) People have been flocking to the Peking Zoo to catch a glimpse of a baby giant panda recently donated by a hunter in Szechwan Province.

title: 2 HELD IN KIDNAPPING OF COED IN ILLINOIS
description: WEST BURLINGTON, Iowa, April 7 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investibation has armted two men in the kidnapping of a Western Illinois University coed, who was held for a $20,000 ransom.

title: Music: Stern and Group
description: One of the nicer musical developments in recent years has been an increase in the number of major solo instrumentalists willing perhaps eagerto play chamber music in public concerts.

title: Condominium Life Can Present Unexpected Challenges
description: Recently I have been reading a lot about condominiums and the prediction that they are the wave the future for suburbia. Only five years ago, before we bought into a new, small condominium, I could not have defined the term. A friend's guessthat a condominium was a birthcontrol device used in ancient Romewas as accurate as my own knowledge.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE subtleties of censorship have never been devastating to me personally until I viewed John Steinbeck's The Red Pony on NBC recently. At least The Bell System Family Theater said it was presenting John Steinbeck. What I expected to see was something resembling the story of Jody Tiflin's maturation; the semisweet losses and gains, the painful first steps into adulthood which a young boy experiences in the process of growing up. Instead, I viewed 90 minutes of a Henry Fonda Western.

title: The Guillotine Lives
description: PARISThere is a man who lives in Auteuil who earned 1.2 million old francs one evening. Mr. Obrecht pulled a string twice: 600,000 old francs for each head that fell into the basket.

title: Religion
description: MEMPHIS  For more than a decade, negotiations have been under way to merge eight Protestant denominations into a single, 22millionmember church. Three years ago a merger plan was sent to the churches involved for reaction, Last week the word from the grassroots was in, and the message was clear: Take the plan back to the drawing board.

title: C.I.A. Witness for Ellsberg Asserts Agency Has Apparently Ousted Him
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Samuel A. Adams, the Central Intelligence Agency analyst who testified about military deceit at the Pentagon papers trial, said in an interview today that he has apparently been discharged. The agency denied it it.

title: An Urban Car Is on Display
description: Attempting to combine practical design and safety with economy and attractive lines, engineering students at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn have come up with what they call an urban carnow on display at the International Auto Show.

title: Turnpike Records Low Mishap Rate
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Turnpike compiled the lowest accident rate of any toll road in the nation during 1972, according to statistics released by the International Bridge, Tunnel and Turnpike Association.

title: POSITIONS HARDEN IN KOREAN TALKS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 7  The dialogue between North and South Korea, intended to reunify this peninsula, has settled down after nine months into political trench warfare. The two sides are no longer sniping or maneuvering against each other. Instead, each has hardened his position and is pounding away at the other.

title: Dorothy Toby Wed to A. B. Coxe
description: SUMMIT, N.J., April 7Miss Dorothy Carroll Toby was married here this afternoon to Alexander Brown Coxe of New York. The Rev. Dr. David K. Barnwell performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Paris Report on Iraqi Denied
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7 (Reuters)The American University of Beirut today denied reports from Paris that Dr. Basil ElKubaisi, an Iraqi shot to death in Paris yesterday, was a professor at the university. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine said in a statement here yesterday that Dr. Kubaisi was one of its leading members and had been on a mission.

title: Foreign Flair To Car Show
description: THE 17th International Automobile Show opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum with a heavy foreign accent. Imported cars dominate the show more than ever before. Of the four major United States auto makers, only the American Motors Corporationthe smallestis displaying its line of 1973 models.

title: Joan Baez Fights U. S. Tax
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 7 (AP)Joan Baez will refuse to pay part of her Federal income taxes again this year to protest military spending even though American troops have left Vietnam, the singer's business manager, Roy Kepler, said this week.

title: The Decline Of Civility
description: WASHINGTON, April 7There is a kind of spring madness in Washington these days. The President and his men seem to be threatening all kinds of dreadful things they have no intention of doing, and their political opponents are promising all sorts of sensational retaliations they have no power to carry out.

title: SOVIET UNION
description: MOSCOW  Like all Soviet car owners, Eduard Iosifovich Pesov fills aer up himself when he drives to get gas at his favorite service station on Lenin Prospect, a major thoroughfare in southwestern Moscow.

title: WILD LIBERALS SCORED BY JESUIT
description: Roman Catholics who despair of the future of their church have been urged to take heart by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, who will mark his 80th birthday on Good Friday, April 20. An elder statesman in the Society of Jesus, Father Gannon was president of Fordham Univerisity from 1936 to 1949.

title: Michigan Panel Bars Rate Rise For Public Utility as Inflationary
description: LANSING, Mich., April 7A Michigan utility concern's petition for a $142million electric and gas rate rise has been dismissed by state regulatory officials on grounds that it violates Nixon Administration antiinflation policies.

title: Have License, Will Travel
description: Planning to travel overseas this year? If so, like many Americans, you will probably be tempted to rent a sporty foreign car for a spin in the country. But before you do that,. there are a few things you should remember about driving in, another country.

title: The P.O.W.s Story,
description: I have been beaten, I have been shackled, I have been mistreated, I have been placed in solitary confinement.

title: POST TEAM WINS RELAY CARNIVAL
description: GREENVALE, L. I., April 7C. W. Post won seven events and dominated the first C. W. Post College Relay Carnival. The meet, which attracted colleges and two track clubs, was the first major event of the outdoor season in the metropolitan area.

title: Amusement Park Adjacent to Civil War Battlefields Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Marriott Corporation has won final approval for the construction of an amusement park in Virginia adjacent to the site of two of the Civil War's most celebrated battles. The project had been rejected in Maryland last year.

title: Feuerbach Puts. Shot 702 For Year's Outdoor Besi
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 7 (AP)Al Feuerbach of San Jose, Calif., put the shot 70 feet 2 inches today at the Sacramento State Encina High School Relays for the best out door mark in the world this year.

title: Art Mailbag.
description: TO THE EDITOR: IN response to Hilton Kramer's review on March 25 of our Alfred H. Maurer exhibition titled The Lost Years Re. discovered, we are presenting the following facts.

title: L.I.R.R. Strike's Impact Put at Half That Expected
description: The loss of riders on the Long Island Rail Road following the 50day strike that ended Jan. 18 was apparently less than half of what railroad officials had said publicly that they expected.

title: NICK STUART, 69, 30'S NIOVIE STAB
description: BILOXI, Miss., April 7 (UPI) Nick Stuart, who starred in a series of collegiate movies in the nineteenthirties and later became a bandleader, died of cancer today s at the Biloxi Howard Memorial Hospital. He was 69 yens old.

title: Mazda's Rotary Engine Draws Crowds
description: DETROITRichard Connell 3d, assistant manager of Packer Mazda, recalled that all hell broke loose when the dealership first opened here last Dec. 1.

title: Knicks Out to Take the 4th
description: With a little bit of perspective restored by. Baltimore's 9789 victory over the Knicks Friday night, the teams will resume their firstround National Basketball Association playoff series today at Madison Square Garden at 2 o'clock, with the Knicks still in command.

title: Big Vinnie was an honorable man
description: Vincent (The Fat Man) Teresa's taperecorded book of revelations is two books, one good, one bad. One, morbidly enthralling for its matteroffact descriptions and acceptance of the worst kinds of corruption and violence; the other, an accumulation of balderdash. Would that they could be separated.

title: PRESIDENT PLANS NEW IMPORT FEES ON GAS AND 011
description: WASHINGTON, April 7President Nixon is expected to announce the imposition of new fees on imports of gasoline and oil, according to Administration sources.

title: Royals Crush Angels, 12.5; Rojas Drives in 4 Runs
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 7 (AP) Cookie Rojas doubled twice and drove in four runs as the Kansas City Royals got 13 hits and routed the California Angels, 125, tonight.

title: Beirut School Halts Classes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7 (AP)Classes at the American University of Beirut were suspended indefinitely yesterday after threedays of clashes between students and policemen, over the suspension of 200 pubs lic school teachers. The school last closed in June, 1971, when students protested a planned increase in tuition fees.

title: A food critic's postscript By Raymond A. Sokolov
description: These foods will kill you. At least, that is what leading nutritionists, including Prof. Jean Mayer (see Page 72) and most doctors, say. They say so because mountains of research findings suggest that people who indulge themselves with creambutterducketc. and all the other delectable highcholesterol foods gradually convert their arteries from freeflowing flexible tubes into rigid, fatclogged bottlenecks. The bottlenecks are conducive to heart attacks, which are conducive to deathand an end to the creambutterducketc. banquet.

title: BILL HANDS WINS DEBUT AS A TWIN
description: OAKLAND; Calif., April 7 (AP)Larry Hisle hit a three run homer for the Minnesota Twins to beat the Oakland A's, 53, giving Bill Hands a victory in his American League pitching debut today.

title: Gillian Rider Bride of Howard Perkins
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., April 7  Miss Gillian Elizabeth Rider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Burr Rider Jr. of Boston and Brewster, and Howard Stone Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Howard Perkins of Spring Hill, Md., and North Haven, Me., were married here this evening in a candlelight service by the Rev. George L. Blackman at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour.

title: Yale Lightweight Oarsmen Beat Kent and Coast Guard
description: DERBY, Conn., April 7Yale's lightweight crew took command midway through the race today and won its season's opener from Kent School and the Coast Guard Academy.

title: Trendy Auto at Art Museum
description: WASHINGTONThe journey from an Italian chicken farm to the Museum of Modern Art's permanent collection is not an ordinary trip for the Cisitalia 202 GT. But then the Cisitalia is no ordinary automobile.

title: City Council Committees To Hold Public Hearings
description: Following are City Council committee hearings this week open to the public. They will be held in the Council committee room.

title: KENNEDYS READY A LIBRARY MODEL
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7Plans for the John F. Kennedy Library, already six years behind schedule, finally appear to be moving toward frui tion.

title: RUTGERS 3 CREWS DEFEAT PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 7Rutgers three heavyweight crews swept the Logg Cup regatta from Princeton today on Lake Carnegie.

title: Gardens
description: AN IMAGE of wildflowers in the garden seems usually of delicate nestlings of woods and marsh that often fail to adapt to cultivated conditions. Yet many of those common wildflowers of fields and roadsides that we still enjoy were once the source of grandmother's perennials. Many have been hybridized, with improved flower size and compact growth, until now they are better garden plants than exotic perennials which are more difficult to grow.

title: No Early End Seen for Dutch Political Deadlock
description: BRUSSELS, April 7The Netherlands has not had a Government for 130 days and, with the failure this week of a Socialist leader to form a coal, tion, there is no sign that the crisis will end soon.

title: Frank Robinson Is Injured
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 7 (AP)  Frank Robinson, who celebrated his debut with the California Angels last night by homering on the first pitch thrown to him, missed tonight's game against Kum City with a pulled ligament in his left leg.

title: Nuclear Unsafety
description: The United States now seems to be working its way through an overly rigid commitment made some two decades ago to, nuclear energy as a source of electric power. If alternatives for the short terms are limited, the Federal Government should lose no time in broadening the options for the nineteeneighties and beyond.

title: Eggsibitors Show Their Art
description: PHILLIPSBURGMrs. Angelo Verdiramo of Hampton is among the more than 100 exhibitors from almost 20 states and Canada who will display intricately decorated eggs at the annual Eggsibit here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Marione Hajkowski notes in a letter published March 18 that savings on fire insurance can offset the cost of sprinkler installations. This is true only in certain types of buildings in New York City.

title: Is Foreign Language At School
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. English is a foreign language taught at Paul D. Schreiber High School in this suburban community  as much as French, German, Spanish and Latin.

title: Eliot Elisoion, PhotoJournalist, Writer and Painter, Dies at 61
description: Eliot Elisofon, the photo grapher, painter and writer died yesterday of a cerebra hethorrhage rn University Hosgoital. He was 61 years old anc lived, at 145 East 27th Street.

title: Theater Benefits
description: April 9National Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress. Tickets $18.75 from Lily Mars, 15 East 84th Street.

title: J. W. Moscow to Wed Gale Gwiazdowski
description: NORWICH, Conn., April 7  Miss Gale Gwiazdowski, who is in her final year at the Boston University School of Law, plans to be married in September to John Warren Moscow, an assistant district attorney for New York County.

title: 18thCentury Black Poet Once Lived In Suffolk
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.  A Colonial mansion near here that was recently acquired by the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities is known for more than its architectureit was once the home of this country's first published black poet.

title: AL UNSER VICTOR IN 200MILE RACE
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., April 7 (UPI)Al Unser, the Indianapolis 500 winner in two of the last three years, defeated Gary Bettenhausen by twotenths of a second today to win the 200mile United States Automobile Club race for Indianapolis type cars at Texas World Speedway.

title: Most Rev. Dr. John C. McQuaid, ExDublin Archbishop, 78, Dies
description: DUBLIN, April 7 The Most Rev. Dr. John Charles McQuaid, former Archbishop of Dublin, died in a hospital today. His age was 78.

title: InSchool Vote Drive Here Drew 28,738 Twice as Many as in 70
description: This year's inschool voter registration drive, conducted for nine days last month to encourage voter participation in the May 1 community school board (elections, was significantly more successful than a similar drive conducted for four weeks in 1970.

title: GHENT TAPE IS STAR OF COMPUTER ARTS
description: The Friday evening event in the Computer Arts Festival at the Kitchen (240 Mercer Street) boasted several highlights and no lowlights.

title: Paperbacks
description: END ZONE, by Don DeLillo. (Pocket, $1.25.) A football player interprets the game as a metaphor for nuclear war: DeLillo's vision of our lives is compounded of nightmare and disgust, his writing energetic, shifty, fun.

title: New York A.C. 8Oared Crew Scores
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 7The New York Athletic Club elite eightoared crew coasted to a 4length victory over Manhattan College today on the Orchard Beach Lagoon. Perfect conditions prevailed with only a slight cross wind as Johnny Killen, a 13yearold coxswain urged his much older teammates into a halflength lead in the first 300 meters.

title: Joys Fella, $5.60, Victor In Third Stakes of Year.
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April (UPI)  Edward P. Shammy's Joys Fella captured his third stakes race of the year today. The 5yearold gelding scored halflength victory in the $25,000 added Benjamin Franklin Handicap at Garden State.

title: Smallpox Shots Urged Before trip to Britain
description: Diagnosis of three cases of smallpox in London has prompted authorities here to advise people going to Britain to get smallpox vaccinations.

title: Lisa K. Beaudouin Wed to Alfred Bauer
description: Miss Lisa, King Beaudouin, daughter of John Tyrell Beaudouin of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mrs. Patricia Curtin Beaudouin, was married here yesterday afternoon to Alfred Young Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Charles Bauer Jr. of Baldwin Harbor, L. I. The Rev. Dennis Wagner performed the ceremony at Christ Church Methodist.

title: Places
description: James Morris admits that this is an oldfashioned genre the travel essay that is also a charming mouthful of literature  and perhaps Places A British traveler on an oldfashioned trip, which only an Englishman could write, is one of the very last examples we shall meet of a once popular and even moderately lucrative nearart form. In the thirties, Aldous Huxley, Evelyn Waugh, Gra

title: Earl Nemser Fiance of Randy Lehrer
description: Mrnd Mrs. Morton Lehrer of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Randy L. Lehrer, to Earl H. Nemser., son of Drnd Mrs. Harold Nemser of New York and Long Beach, L. I.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Dog Show Calendar

title: Vietmine Takes Gold Rush On Coast by 1 Lengths
description: ALBANY, Calif., April 7 (AP) Vietmine was an upset winner in today's $40,000 Gold Rush Stakes at Golden Gate Fields. The favorite, Out of the East, finished a wellbeaten fifth.

title: New York
description: ALBANYThe issue of disparities between rich and poor school districts has evoked much concern in New York State, but has brought little corrective action.

title: If You Go.
description: on a crosscountry bicycle trip, plan your route from west to east if at all possible. That way you won't buck the prevailing summer winds, which blow from the southwest diagonally across the country.

title: Miami Mayor and 2 Judges Among 6 Indicted for Bribe Plots
description: MIAMI, April 7  Mayor David Kennedy, two Dade County judges and three other Miamians were indicted last night in an inquiry into alleged corruption.

title: HOUSING SCARCE IN BRAZIL'S BOOM
description: CAMPINAS, BnazilThis old coffee capital, like most of the cities in Brazil's eastern seaboard area, has become a new pole of attraction for industry and migrant labor and is faced with acute housing problems.

title: New ovel
description: If truth is anything like Anton Myrer's fiction, it's time to head for the hills with a supply of survival rations.

title: C.A.B. Chief Says S.S.T.'s Will Be Put Into Service
description: LONDON, April 7  Secor Browne, chairman of the United States Civil Aeronautics Board, has predicted here that supersonic aircraft will ultimately take over the longhaul interhational routes.

title: Black P.O.W. Is an Echo of 1966
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 2 The students examined Norman McDaniel as if they had unearthed an intriguing fossil. They were taking part in a race relations seminar at North Carolina A. & T., and Maj. Norman McDaniel, United States Air Force, was a member of a nearly extinct sociological species: American Negro, circa 1966.

title: UNAUTHORIZED AID IS LAID TO PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The Defense Department has given away to other countries large amounts of surplus military equipment to make up for cuts by Congress in foreign military aid appropriations, according to a General Aecounting Office study.

title: Grow Your Own Protein
description: WE have a solution to the high cost of meatwe grow our own protein  not on the hoof, but on the plant, soybeans. There is hardly a person who is not familiar with soy products in one form or another: soy flour, dried soybeans, small boxes of delicious toasted morsels the list goes qn and on.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: RECENTLY I saw the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center's new production of The Merchant of Venice. I went with many misgivings, believing that the play's antiSemitic impact upon our audiences is built into its very structure. I recognize that Ellis Rabb, the director, made an earnest, even desperate, attempt to mitigate this antiSemitic impact. He failed. As I was leaving the theater, I passed a cluster of schoolchildren grouped around their teacher. One girl said, Antonio sure wasn't afraid of losing his chips. The teacher commented, That's right. That's the Christian way of doing business, not the Jewish way.

title: Food critic's postscript (cont.)

This piquant chicken dish is a good example. Aside from the use of polyunsaturated oil, there is little to distinguish it from a normal recipe. People who want to keep their arteries soft through diet should cook this waydisrupting standard recipes as little as possibleand not try to pretend they can concoct a lowcholesterol duplicate of the deadlier dishes of haute cuisine.

They are the kind of people who will pay off an obligation at a dollar or two a week. He insisted that there were no rich people in Lyndhurst, a town of 23,000 people, and that the residents were satisfied with what they had. The result is that most of the houses are old, and the three major business districts show signs of age. Still, Lyndhurst Plaza, in the middle of town, is a major shopping mall, having the most modern stores, a huge parking area and the latest in styles. It was opened about two years ago.

title: Why should liberals bleed when the President cuts?

Senator Edward Kennedy described the budget as a ruthless reduction of this Government's commitment to its social obligations. A retreat from social responsibility, said Senator Edmund Muskie. An abandonment of our efforts to help those least able to help themselves our children, our aged, our sick, said Senator Harold Hughes. And economist Robert Lekachman, writing in these pages on Feb. 18, spoke of the wholesale slaughter of New Deal and Great Society legislation threatened in the President's fiscalyear 1974 budget and called it a reversion to StoneAge social policy.

They complied.

title: Friends Or Foes?
description: MANY types of wildlife add interest and benefit our natural surroundings. But when they Move close to home especially where large numbers of people are hoosed, they become nuisances and can in some instances cause a great deal of damage. One of the most frequently asked, question by homeowners who are plagued by the presence of an unwanted animal, is how do I get rid of it?There are many solutions. Two of the disposal methods that have been used in days past are shooting or poisoning. Both of these methods still work, however, they are not very satisfactory in the confines of our present day communities where unforseeable outcomes may result in most communities, it is unlawful to shoot anything and wisely so as you may hit more than the pest that you wish to get out of your hair. Poisoning, on the other hand, is more controlled than shooting, but it has its drawbacks under our present close living conditions. The number of animals that roam about under such conditions are not all bad. Think of the number of cats and dogs that live within your own neighborhood. What are the alternatives? To select the most, feasible method, consider some of the animals that often visit the home property and explore some of their habits. By knowing something about the animal and its habits, one can focus on these and often devise an effective method to discourage its presence.Moles:.At this time of year, one of the little pests that may have visited you during the past few months without too much notice may have been the mole which is first noticed in the spring often while looking over the condition of the lawn. Ridges and valleys throughout the lawn indicate this little fellow is or was present. Moles are insect  eating mammals and are highly specialized for living beneath the soil so you are not likely to see them above ground. They live almost continually in a. highly organized Systent of tunnels. Moles prodtice only a single litter of young in late April or early May When: their tunnels are made just under the surface, you can: see the ridges clearly. This up rooting of the grass or other plants in the area is what causes plant damage. The mole itself does not feed on plant materials. The mole's damage is caused by tunneling in search of insects and worms, within the soil environment. Since they live underground, moles are difficult to control. Special traps have been designed to enable one to trap them within their tunnels. They are available at most hardware stores. If you choose traps, you must determine where the active tunnels are, as many are only temporary. To find active tunnels, walk across the ridges to push them down. Then keep an eye on them to see if they are repaired. If they are, the tunnels are active and a trap should be placed there. Another method to eliminate moles is to control the bisects that formulate their food supply. Grubs are one of their favorites. These are easily controlled by the use of insecticides such as chlordane or milky spore disease which is specific for Japanese beetle grubs. When the food source is no longer available, the moles will venture elsewhere.

title: Majority Leader: Democrats Fear Mansfield, at 70, Has Lost Zest Needed for Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Mike Mansfield has always been a gentle man. For a dozen years, longer than anyone before him, he has held the title of Senate majority leader, but considered himself a Democratic coordinator. He gave the Senate its head yet nudged it into the forefront of efforts to guarantee civil rights, diminish poverty and halt American involvement in Indochina. Now the Senate has embarked on a crusade to restore its own authority by restricting the President's powers to make war and control spending. But Mr. Mansfield, who turned 70 last month and is expected to retire in 1976, has appeared to some of his colleagues to have lost his zest for gentle persuasion.

description: PARIS'A living woman, a real woman, who dared to be natural. Thus the poet Francis Jtunmes described the young Sidonie Gabrielle Colette, who was born 100 years ago last Jan. 28 and died in 1954. Although the Bibliotheque Nationale will honor her with an exhibition following hard on the heels of a show devoted to Copernicus, it is doubtful if presentday feminists would recognize France's most considerable woman novelist as a pioneer of their movement.

title: Floodway Opened to Ease A Threat to New Orleans
description: A spillway 25 miles from New Orleans was opened yesterday in an attempt to divert floodwaters from the Mississippi River, which is building toward its highest New Orleans crest in 23 years after almost incessant rains the last two weeks.

title: STEWART TAKES FORMULA I RACE
description: SILVERSTONE, England, April 8 (UPI) Jackie Stewart of Scotland drove a TyrellFord through high winds and snow storms today to victory in the International Trophy Formula One auto race.

title: Martti Talvela, Finnish Bass, Dazzles Hunter Audience But Leaves It Too Soon
description: The late Bette Richart once wrote in a poem Dazzle me like July but, oh, stay a little longer. The line came to mind at the end of Martti Talvela's recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall on Saturday night.

title: Percentage of Blacks Employed By Newark Up in Last 2 Years
description: NEWARK, April 8 (UPI)The percentage of blacks employed by New Jersey's largest city has increased in all departments except sanitation over the last two years, according to figures released over the weekend by the Newark Human Rights Commission.

title: In Baseball as in Golf, a Miss Does Not Bring a Smile
description: While Cesar Cedeno was on his way to a .320 batting average for Houston last season, Hank Aaron, the Atlanta Braves slugger, said, The last player to come into the league with such ability was me.

title: Berra's Pain in the Side Not Caused by 20 Mets
description: The reason Yogi Berra was laughing just a little cautiously La the locker room at Shea Stadium following yesterday's rainout against Philadelphia wasn't because the Mets manager was unhappy with his team, which had a 20 wonlost record for the first time in its history. It was because of a twinge in his side.

title: M'CORD REPORTED LINKING PAYOFFS TO A G.O.P. LAWYER
description: WASHINGTON, April 8James W. McCord Jr. has told a Federal grand jury that he believes that Kenneth W. Parkinson, an attorney for the Committee for the ReeleCtion of the President, channeled cash payments to the Watergate defendants in return for silence after their arrest inside Democratic headquarters last June 17, sources close to the case said today.

title: First Horsemeat Shop To Open in Connecticut
description: WESTBROOK, Conn., April 8 (UPI)Connecticut's first retail outlet for horsemeat for human consumption was scheduled to open Tuesday.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MOSCOW, April 8 (AP)Alexander Martynyuk, a forward, scored a record total of eight goals tonight as the unbeaten Soviet Union won Its sixth game in the world ice hockey championships with an 182 rout of West Germany. The victory kept the Russians in command of the sixteam tournament. Sweden is second with a 41 wonlost record.

title: Protean and Prodigious, the Greatest Single Force in 70 Years of Art
description: There was Picasso the neoclassicist; Picasso the cubist; Picasso the surrealist; Picasso the modernist; Picasso the ceramist; Picasso the lithographer; Picasso the sculptor; Picasso the superb draftsman; Picasso the effervescent and exuberant; Picasso the saturnine and surly; Picasso the faithful and faithless lover; Picasso the cunning financial man; Picasso the publicity seeker; Picasso the smoldering Spaniard; Picasso the joker and performer of charades; Picasso the generous; Picasso the Scrooge; even Picasso the playwright.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Three tankers and two cargo ships from a convoy of 18 vessels reached Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, yesterday with the first fuel that the city has received in two weeks. The tankers brought enough fuel to last for six days. Government officials had said that nine tankers were needed to ease the capital's critical fuel shortage, which began last week when Communist troops cut all the roads to the capital and blocked traffic on the Mekong River. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Environmental Movement Registers Gains in 3 Years
description: Three years ago millions of Americans interrupted their usual pursuits to observe Earth Day, an interlude of contemplation of the nation's deteriorating environment and of resolve to rehabilitate and protect it.

title: Brezhnev Trip Plans Stir East Germans
description: BERLIN, April 8The visit that Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, plans to make to Bonn next month for talks with Chancellor Willy Brandt has caused remarkable repercussions in East Germany, the Soviet Union's close ally.

title: Strip Mme Hearings Resume
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI)  Two House subcommittees will open a second round of hearings tomorrow on the need for Federal legislation to control strip mining. The joint hearings were organized when Representatives Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, and Patsy T. Mink, Democrat of Hawaii, decided the issue belonged before House Interior subcommittees that they head. Mr. Udall's subcommittee deals with environmental matters and Mrs. Mink's handles mining.

title: Gibson's Bout for Charity Leaves. Some Memories
description: NEWARK, April 8 (UPI)Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today he felt only a little sore after going three rounds for charity with a former professional boxer.

title: PanAmerican Week Set
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 8 (AP)  President Nixon has proclaimed April 814 as PanAmerican Week and hailed the Organization of American States for building a climate of friendship and understanding. In his proclamation yesterday, the President said an intangible force forms the basis of solidarity among the. Americas and added that the O.A.S. is the focal point of this force, a place where cooperation rather than confrontation strengthens the common ties shared by the nations of the hemisphere.

description: Although rain and unseason ably cold temperaturels com bined yesterday to cut a plan ned 20mile March of Dime: Walkathon to two mile: in Manhattan, a hearty grout of 6,000 participated in the fundraising effort to fight bird defects.

title: 2 Marine Pilots Are Rescued

title: BALI FLOURISHING AS TOURISM RISES
description: DENPASAR, Indonesia  As tourism here in Bali inexorably expands, the commercialization of this green island's unique culture grows apace. However, those familiar with Bali aver, it is still alive, vital and flourishing, basically uncorrupted by money and new influences.

title: That Model Is Now a Casting Director

title: Canape Bidding Style Brings Success at Spring Nationals
description: A style of bidding that has always been popular in France and to a lesser extent in Italy is known as canape. This has no connection with refreshments, but simply requires its practitioners to bid a short suit first and keep a longer one in reserve.

title: 12 in Coast Motorcycle Gang Accused of Attacking ExG.I.
description: MONTEBELLO, Calif., April 8 (UPI)  More than a dozen motorcycle gang members tracked down and taunted an ailing Vietnam veteran early today, then hauled the 22yearold former Army Sergeant from his car and stabbed him four times in the chest, the police reported.

title: Curtis Mayfield's Soul Singing Displays His Fluency in Argot
description: Curtis Mayfield, with a 15yearsinging background has moved completely into the area of radical soul singing if Saturdav's program at Philharmonic Hall is any guideline. Mayfield recently had his biggest success with the music for the film, Superfly, a leader in the black action films. His soundtrack album sold around two million copies (although the music was unaccountaly ignored in this year's Oscar nominations) and as a result of this success, Mayfield concentrates on this side of his writing and performing.

description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.Morris Epstein has become an expert in international monetary affairs by sheer necessity.

The three crewman of the copter, all Americans, also died.

title: A Bag for a Burglar
description: ROCK FALLS, III., April (AP)Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hubbard, managers of the Eagles Club, were closing up early today when a masked burglar shoved aside their 13yearold daughter and made off with one of two paper sacks Mr. Hubbard was carrying. The bandit escaped with two dozen Been peppers and a tossed salad. Mr. Hubbard was left with the other bag, which contained the evening's cash receipts.

title: TV Review
description: Children of Trouble, a onehour documentary shown last night on the National Broadcasting Company network, fired off a scathing inquiry on problem youngsters who are channeled through courts and correction facilities in New Jersey. title: Announcer Dies in Crash

The same 18car Missouri Pacific freight train was involved in both crashes. Sheriff Fred Tesch, who investigated both accidents, said the announcer, Deldon M. Hamann, 23 years old, was leaving the station when lie was struck by the train on the station's property. Minutes earlier, Julia P. Smith, of Bellevue, died in the other crash.

title: Zeffirelli's Film Study of St. Francis:The Cast
description: Franco Zeffirelli's "Brother Sun, Sister Moon" is the sort of movie that tries to make poverty look chic, and almost goes broke in the attempt.It's the splendiferously costumed, fancily photographed (through rain, smoke, mist or muslin, whenever possible), multimillion-dollar, near-musical life of Giovanni Francesco Bernardone (1181-1226), the cloth merchant's son who later became St. Francis of Assisi. The title is taken from Francis's "Canticle of Creatures," and it could be worse, since Francis had a way of referring to everything as his "brothers" or "sisters," including his illnesses. These he called his "sisters" and on their part he once begged the pardon of his "brother ass the body."Like Roberto Rossellini, who sought the essence of St. Francis more in fable than in fact, Zeffirelli makes no special claims to historical accuracy. However, unlike Rossellini, whose "Flowers of St. Francis" is a film of sweet purpose and simplicity, Zeffirelli has made a big, absurd doodad, a movie that confuses simplicity with simple-mindedness and that makes saintliness look like an extreme form of Asian flu.When Francis comes down with it, he gets feverish, hallucinates, goes off into a long coma and then wakes up as a Good Person. We know this because he spends a lot of time weeping for the underprivileged, giving away his daddy's yard goods and hanging out with birds, bees and flowers.The screenplay, written by Zeffirelli with three other people who should be nameless but aren't (see listing), opens with Francis's return from the war with Perugia and his vow to follow the life and teachings of Christ covers the years that finally culminate with the recognition of what was to become the Franciscan order by Pope Innocent III.In a film that isn't exactly devoid of unintentionally funny moments, this last sequence is a standout, when the sack-clothed Francis and his little band of barefoot followers confront Innocent III in a St. Peter's throne room so photographed as to look like a set from a "Ziegfeld Follies." Francis's philosophy consists entirely of assorted cribs from the Gospel according to St. Matthew, which Francis hurls around the throne room as if they were thunderbolts instead of familiar quotations. The Pope is so impressed he falls on his knees in front of Francis, at which point we suddenly recognize Innocent III as old Alec Guinness, wearing his famous Fagan beard but not the controversial nose.Guinness and Valentina Cortese (who plays Francis's mother) are the only familiar actors in the film. Graham Faulkner (Francis), Judi Bowker (Clare) and the men who play Francis's followers are all young English actors making their film debuts. They are noteworthy only in that they share a prettiness that is barely distinguishable from the landscape's.Although Zeffirelli has a fondness for posing Francis in attitudes suggested by Christ on the cross, he downplays the visions to, literally, one blinkof the eyes of a statue. Zeffirelli makes Francis seem such a bland sort of fellow that we spend most of the time looking at the scenery, the auroral photographic effects and the costumes, which were also the chief attractions of the director's hugely popular "Romeo and Juliet."The film is scored to a point that makes your teeth hurt with awful songs ("Birds are singing sweet and low/ From the trees that gently grow . . .") by Donovan, sung by him on the soundtrack in a role I assume to be God's.

title: Mrs. Court Wins Final in 38 Minutes
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 8 Playing at what amounted to $316 a minute, Mrs. Margaret Court collected her biggest purse as a professional tennis player today, and no championship match ever came easier.

description: Despite a strong starting pitching performance by George Medich and a gutty, gametying slide by Thurman Munson, the Boston Red Sox edged the Yankees, 43, when Orlando Cepeda, the designated hitter, socked a home run off Lyle in the ninth inning.

title: Foodland Cuts Meat Prices
description: PITTSBURGH, April 8 (AP)Price reductions from 10 to 30 cents per pound on all cuts of meat were announced today by Foodland markets.

title: Miss Louise Dembeck Wed to Giora Neeman
description: Miss Louise E. Dembeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin W. Dembeck of Spring Valley, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Giora Neeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Itzak Neeman of Kibbutz Beit Asheta, Israel. New York Civil Court Judge Beatrice Shainswit performed the ceremony at the AmericaIsrael Foundation.

title: ALFRED E. FISCHER, PEDIATRICIAN DIE
description: Dr. Alfred E. Fischer, long a leading pediatrician here, died Saturday at his home, 1112 Park Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 73.

title: Picasso Symbol of a Conquest in Art
description: Whatever else he was, Pablo Picasso was the most potent single rorce In the art of the 2fith century. Matisse and Kandinsky might rival him as second leaders in the most violent revolution since the Renaissance. But neither of their revolutions was quite as drastic, as far reaching, as varied in manner of assault and foray against tradition as Picasso's. And yet as soon as the word tradition is mentioned, Picasso must be thought of as a colleague of the masters of the past as well as the artist who seemed most to reject them. It has always been typical of Picasso that he could not be captured within a single net. He was this, he was that, he was the otherat one moment a poet, at the next an inspired buffoon; tender and romantic to the point of sentimentality, intellectual to the point of frigidity; now a cynic, now a compassionate man; ebullient in one painting, despairing tin another; exquisitely refined, and deliberately

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The head of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club has given his personal endorsement to offshore atomic power plants, such as those called for in a $1billion program by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the state's largest electric utility.

title: On Slaving Over a Hot Cassette Player
description: Hi! This is Jim Beard, the voice on the CookAlong With James Beard cassette declares.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: GEORGE R. ESTERLY
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J. April 8 George R. Esterly, who retired in 1965 from the Rutgers University Graduate School of Business Administration in Newark, died today in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 71 years old and lived at 62 Nottingham Road.

title: 5 SHIPS OF CONVOY WITII FUEL REACH CAMBODIA CAPITAL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 8Three tankers and two cargo ships from an embattled convoy of 18 vessels reached this besieged capital late today with the first fuel that the city has received in two weeks.

title: Meat Boycott's Impact On Prices Here Is Slight
description: The meat boycott failed to crack the general level of prices last week either in the New York City or Hartford areas, the two places in the country where market analysts survey current retail food prices weekly. But there was evidence that consumers were making their voices heard.

title: Blumenthal Pictures Himself As Apostle of Compromise
description: If there is one thing that the polls and the polls agree on, it is that Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal of Manhattan is the least wellknown of the four B's who are expected to make up the field in the Democratic mayoral primary on June 4.

title: Television
description: 0:30 (2)Sunrise Semester (4)Consumerism (5)Read Your Way Up (7)Listen and Learn

title: Shelley Katz Is Bride
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 8Miss Shelley Katz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Katz of the Bronx, was married this afternoon to Lawrence D. Lutzker, son of Isidor H. Lutzker of Scarsdale and the late Mrs. Lutzker. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony in the Temple Israel Center.

title: CrossPull in Belgrade
description: A strange contradiction has developed in United StatesYugoslav relations, with some disturbing new trends Belgrade threatening to undermine the structure mutual confidence built up between the two countries since Stalin excommunicated Tito's Yugoslavia in 1948.

title: STEPUP IS SOUGHT INWORLDBANK AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The world's industrial nations, with the United States still holding back, are close to agreeing to nearly double their contributions to the World Bank for aid to the least developed countries.

title: Dutch Beat U.S. Five
description: BREMERHAVEN, West Germany, April 8 (UPI)The Dutch national basketball team scored a 10591 victory over a United States team today.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: Mexico Learns to Live With Blackouts
description: MEXICO CITY, April 8Three times last week Mexico City had power failures.

title: Search for Trustee For Equity Pressed
description: LOS ANGELES, April 8Federal Judge Harry Pregerson continued his search today for a trustee for the troubled Equity Funding Corporation of America, which has filed under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: In the Small Print, an Official Secrets Act
description: FROSTBURG, Md.We are tangled in angry and important disputes about Presidential and Congressional power, about spending and taxation, about social needs and governmental indifference, about the whole structure of our Federal system and about the integrity of our political process.

title: DR. CLYMONT M'ARTHUR
description: NEWARK, April 8Dr. Clymont MacArthur, chief of staff of United Hospitals here until 1968, died yesterday in the Hunterdon Medical Center, Flemington. He was 78 years old and lived in Califon, N. J.

title: Sheepshead Fish Free As Rain Slashes Sales
description: Bad weather kept customers away from the piers of Sheepshead Bay yesterday and forced fishermen to give away 900 pounds of flounder, but this did not detract from their happiness over the huge sales they enjoyed during the week of the meat boycott.

title: Charles Goldberg Weds Robin Straus
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., April 8Miss Robin D. Straus was married here this afternoon to Charles Goldberg of New York. Rabbis Ely E. Pilchik and Barry H. Greene performed the ceremony at the Straus home.

title: Bridal Held Here For Miss Schuster
description: St. Stephen of Hungary Roman Catholic Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Zsuzanna Schuster to Karoly Okolicsanyi of New York. He is the son of Dr. Karoly Okolicsanyi, a radiologist, of Budapest, and the late Mrs. Okolicsanyi, who was a pediatrician under the name Dr. Llona Arvayl.

title: Rain Delays Completion Of Kearny Curb Painting
description: KEARNY, (UPI)Light rain held up plans by the Army Reserve to finish painting the curbs yellow today, but only a small portion of the 2,400 feet of corner curbs remained to be marked for noparking zones.

title: Warning to the States
description: The ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court that the state's system of school financing violates the rights of children in taxpoor districts constitutes a crucial step in the battle against educational inequalities. The opinion by Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub assumes special importance because it was preceded by a Texas case which the United States Supreme Court held that there were no grounds for imposition of Federal standards on what the Constitution intended to be a state responsibility.

title: Walt Disney Productions Reports Higher Earnings
description: Walt Disney Productions reported higher earnings for its fiscal second quarter and half year ended March 31. The company cleared $10.4million, equal to 36 cents a share, for the quarter on revenues of $86.5million. In the quarter ended April 2, 1972, net income was $9million, or 31 cents a share, on revenues of $75.4million.

title: Some New Views on an Old Subject At a Conference on Sex Stereotyping
description: A slendtr, blueeyed woman who strongly resembled Julie Andrews entered a classroom at Fordham University's Manhattan campus the other day and began writing what she called sexual stereotypes on the blackboard:

title: Camden Mayoral Hopeful Runs a Flamboyant Race
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 8This blighted city on the Delaware River, the back door to Philadelphia, has received an infusion of flamboyance and imagination that has left residents blinking.

title: Dandelions on Lawns? Try Some on the Menu
description: VINELAND, April 8 (UPI) Farmers in this Cumberland County community will finish harvesting their dandelion crops this month, which to some is an important source of income.

title: What Now for Guernica'?
description: The death of Picasso reopens the question of the ultimate destination of his great painting Guernica, which has been in the Museum of Modern Art since 1939.

title: Horse Show Results.
description: AT NEW HOPE, PA. AT POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.

title: Death of a Giant
description: One of the world's great artists and one of the seminal minds of the modern epoch, Pablo Picasso leaves behind him an achievement of enduring glory.

title: Orange County Gives Scroll fo First Citizen
description: EL TORO MARINE AIR STATION, Calif., April 8 (AP) President Nixon flew back to Washington today, carrying a Himalayan goatskin scroll proclaiming him to be Orange County's First Citizen of the Century.

title: News Summary and Index
description: News Summary and Index MONDAY, APRIL 9, 1973

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Abortion II: Making the Revolution, by Lawrence Lader (Beacon Press, Boston, $7.95). A report of the recent campaign in the movement.

title: Books of The Times
description: ABSOLUTELY NOTHING TO GET ALARMED ABOUT. By Charles Wright. 215 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $6.95.

title: Miss Friedman Bride Of Steven Wolinsky
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., April 8Miss Naomi Chienna Friedman, daughter of Rabbi Morris Friedman, spiritual leader of Temple Hillel, and Mrs. Friedman of North, Woodmere, was married here at noon today to Steven Bart Wolinsky. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Wolinsky of Malverne. The bride's father performed the ceremony in his temple.

title: Innis Says CORE Is Pushing to Build Black Links With Africa
description: Roy Innis, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, says his 31yearold organization is broadening the scope of its program to include the development of links with African nation$  starting with Uganda.

title: Lefkowitz Plans Study Of Equity's Offerings
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that his office had begun a broad investigation into the activities of the Equity Funding Corporation's realestate syndication offerings to New York investors between 1970 and 1973.

title: Blumenthal Pictures Himself As Apostle of Compromise
description: If there is one thing that the polls and the polls agree on, it is that Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal of Manhattan is the least wellknown of the four B's who are expected to make up the field in the Democratic mayoral primary on June 4.

title: Oosterhuis Leads Masters by 3 at 211 as Nicklaus Fades
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 Peter Oosterhuis of England, a 6foot5inch professional, provided a strong foreign threat in the Masters golf tourney today. He gained a threestroke lead with a total of 211 for 54 holes with a 68. Play resumed today after rain had forced postponement of the third round yesterday.

title: DAVID P. ALTERBAUM
description: David P. Alterbaum, a lawyer with an office at 116 John Street, died Saturday of a heart ailment in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old and lived at 900 Avenue H, Brooklyn.

title: Killy Gains Pro Ski Title With a Victory in Slalom
description: ASPEN, Colo., April 8 (AP)JeanClaude Killy, the former Olympic star, captured the world professional ski championship today by winning the slalom event of the Lange Cup.

title: FIRE AT UMBERTO'S; POLICE CALL IT ARSON.
description: A fire that the police said had been set swept through the basement and washrooms of Umberto's Clam House last night, following a bomb threat that was reported on Saturday, the first anniversary of the, murder at the restaurant of Joseph Gallo, the mobster.

title: PROXMIRE CRITICIZES INTELLIGENCE COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, says covert American intelligence operations have brought embarrassment abroad and confusion at home and should be cut to the bone.

title: U.S. HEARS SOVIET HAS SOMALI BASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Soviet Union recently built a longrange communications facility in the Somali Republic, on the east coast of Africa, through which naval headquarters in Moscow can directly control the movements of its warships throughout the Indian Ocean area according to American military analysts.

title: Sabres Down Canadiens, Trail by 31
description: BUFFALO, April 8 (AP)Gil Perreault scored two, goals tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Montreal Canadiens, 51, for their first victory in, the National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoffs. The Canadiens lead the firstround, fourofsevengame set, 31.

title: Creativity And the Public
description: A next to last word about the Sticks and Bones postponement on television may be in order because it affords a chance to see how governmental postures, communications structures and even philosophical considerations can determine what reaches the American people across almost the entire spectrum of the performing arts and of other acts of creativityfrom TV and films to periodicals and books.

title: ITCORD REPORTED LINKING PAYOFFS TO A G.O.P. LAWYER
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 James W. McCord Jr. has told Federal grand jury that he believes that Kenneth W. Parkinson, an attorney for the Committee for the Reelection of the President, channeled cash payments to the Watergate defendants in return for silence after their arrest inside Democratic headquarters last June 17, sources close to the case said today.

title: Conrad MSS. Go on Display at Library
description: Manuscripts of two of Joseph Conrad's later novels, with extensive changes made in his own handwriting, are going on display at the New York Public Library today through Saturday.

title: Mayor's LameDuck Problems, Cont'd.
description: How does a man maintain a low profile and yet strive to seem 10 feet tall?

title: Markets Must Post The Ceiling Prices On Meats Today
description: In supermarkets, butcher shops and grocery stores across the country, shoppers will have an opportunity to police meat prices on their own, starting today, with the help of posters listing the legal ceiling prices for beef, pork, lamb, veal and mutton.

title: MAGNOLIA GOLF WON BY NEVIL WITH 268
description: MAGNOLIA GOLF WON BY NEVIL WITH 268

title: SHOP TALK
description: There have been mud baths for the body and mud packs for the face. Now it's mud treatments for the hair. Not the mud you might dig up in Central Park or your backyard, explains Bruno Demetrio, a mustachioed 29yearold hairdresser with skyblue eyes who owns Le Salon at 16 West 57th

title: Text of Statement by Lindsay
description: Early in this past week, Governor Rockefeller made the latest in a series of illinformed and destructive statements about conditions in our city. Specifically, he said that under the current administration, the city is experiencing rampant crime, deterioration of city services and loss of jobs.

title: CERTIFICATE SERVICE TO ADD 5 FACILITIES
description: Central Certificate Service, Inc., said yesterday it planned to add five regional depository facilities in cooperation with various banks.

title: Israel Bars OccupiedLand Purchases
description: JERUSALEM, April 8Israel decided today not to permit individual Israelis or Israeli concerns to buy land in the Arab territories occupied since the 1967 war.

title: Interne Weds Rosine Rossignelly
description: Miss Rosine Rossignelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Rossignelly of Vesenaz, Switzerland, was married yesterday in Geneva to Dr. Robert B. Nussenblatt of Long Island City, Queens.

title: Militant Indians Are Reported Rejecting Agreement Made by 4 of Their Leaders
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., April 8The insurgent Indians occupy ing Wounded Knee were reported today to have rejected an informal agreement, reached last night by four of their leadtrs and Government officials, That would have ended the occupation of the village tomorrow or Tuesday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: 1 Search widely

title: New Delhi Takes Over Control Of Sikkim on Request of Ruler
description: GANGTOK, Sikkim, April 8 (Reuters)The Indian Government today took over the administration of the troubled Himalayan monarchy of Sikkim, which has been shaken by agitation for political reform during the last week.

title: Seven Die in Polish Crash
description: WARSAW, April 8 (UPI)A train hit a bus at a crossing south of Warsaw today, killing seven bus passengers and injuring five seriously, the Polish press agency P.A.P. said. A preliminary investigation showed that a railway guard had failed to lower barriers at the crossing near the town of Warka, 34 miles south of Warsaw, the agency reported.

title: LINDSAY CHARGES GOVERNORHARRIES CITY GOVERNMENT
description: Mayor Lindsay accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of politically motivated harassment of the city government and of callous indifference to sound management in the way the Governor runs the state.

title: PEACE PLAN GIVEN BY METAL UNION
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The sheet metal workers union announced today a new stabilization plan for the construction industry that would give union members a guaranteed income and other benefits in return for a pledge against featherbedding, slowdowns and other disruptive work practices.

title: Federal Inquiry Into Cahill Started in a Familiar Way
description: TRENTON, April 9State Police Detective James Challen der walked a familiar path last month when he provided Unitec States Attorney Herbert J Stern with information that launched an investigation intc the handling of campaign funds luring Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign.

title: Grand Jury Inquiry in Building Collapse Begun
description: The Queens District Attorney's office started a grand jury investigation yesterday to determine if criminally negligent homicide was involved in the collapse of a building parapet in Corona, Queens, on Saturday night that killed three persons.

title: Thieu Visits Pope, Who Bids Him Free Political. Prisoners
description: ROME, April 9 (AP)While policemen and leftist demonstrators battled near St. Peter's Square, Pope Paul VI met President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam here today and urged hint to release political prisoners.

title: Traffic Deaths Drop
description: CHICAGO, April 9 (AP)Traffic deaths dropped 2 per cent in January and February from the twomonth totals in 1972, the National Safety Council reported today. In those months 7,560 persons were killed, 160 fewer than in the corresponding months last year.

title: MORE AID URGED FOR FOREIGN ARTS
description: John Richardson Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Education and Cultural Affairs, urged a committee of businessmen in volved in the arts yesterday to broaden their support to the arts and artists of foreign countries as a path to international understanding.

title: The Paris Shows in a Word Sweaters
description: Sweaters. Sweaters. Sweaters.

title: Gillette Agrees to Invest In a Yugoslav Enterprise
description: The Gillette Company of Boston said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to acquire minority interest in a Yugoslav company that will make razor blades and metal tape measures. It will be Gillette's first manufacturing venture in Eastern Europe.

title: $15Million Health Program Set For Speeding Emergency Care
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the National Academy of Sciences announced today a $15million program to help improve emergency medical care throughout the United States.

title: Prices of Hog and Cattle Futures Climb Sharply
description: A slight drop in meat futures prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange at the end of last week was of short duration as live hogs and live beef cattle prices climbed sharply yesterday, with some months rising the daily permissible limit. For beef cattle, this is a cent a pound and for hogs, 1 cents. Pork bellies also showed gains.

title: Procaccino Decides to Drop Out Of the Race for City Controller
description: Mario A. Prococcino withdrew yesterday as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for City Controller, saying he did not have enough money to run a citywide campaign.

title: Metropolitan
description: In the first major change of the city's secretive realestate tax assessment system since it came under fire by the State Commission of Investigation seven weeks ago, tax commissioners have been directed to state in writing for public scrutiny their reasons for granting certain reductions in assessment valuation.

title: 12 Million Automobiles Were Recalled By Their Manufacturers Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Manufacturers recalled more motor vehicles for correction of safety defects in 1972 than in any other year, the Department of Transportation reported today.

title: William F. Chapman, 53, Counsel to Mutual Banks
description: William F. Chapman, assistant general counsel of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, died Saturday in Long Island College Hospita after a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 25 Remsen Street in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 9President Nixon will send his trade message and legislation to Congress tomorrow, the White House announced today. While the broad outlines of the legislation have already been indicated in the President's international economic report to Congress, it understood to include numerous points of detail not previously disclosed.

title: A Quiet Debate Over Atomic Arms
description: A quiet but intense debate is developing in the Pentagon over which service will dominate America's nuclear arsenal and win the major share of appropriations. Reduced funds for research and development, procurement and construction in a period of modernization, qualified sources say, have sharpened arguments over the future of what is known as the Triad Concept. Under this concept, the nation's total nuclear force is divided into three parts. The Air Force, with its ICBM's and manned bombers, controls two of the three and thus has a major role in nuclear strategic planning. The Navy, with its ballistic missile submarines, controls the remaining one.

title: On National Book Awards Eve, 500 Meet on Turning a New Leaf
description: More than 500 publishers, authors and other citizens of the book world convened at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue last night to discuss and decry the weaknesses of the publishing trade.

title: Weekend Fights
description: Buenos Aires  Miguel Angel Castellini, Argentina, outpointed Thurman Holiday, Youngstown, Ohio, 10 rounds, junior middleweights.

title: CITY LIFTS CURTAIN ON REALTY RULING
description: In the first major change of the city's secretive realestate tax assessment system since it came under fire by the State Commission of Investigation seven weeks ago, the tax commissioners have been directed to state in writing for public scrutiny their reasons for granting certain reductions in property assessment valuation.

title: Tennis Near Peace Pact For Women
description: Peace is at hand in the women's tennis feud, Walter E. Elcock, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, said yesterday.

title: Judges Release Patient in Psychosurgery Case
description: DETROIT, April 9Mr. L., a rakntal patient confined for 18 years for killing and raping a nurse, was given his freedom by the Wayne County Circuit Court here today, but he begins his new life with pos$ibility of being charged with murder.

title: VIETCONG BLAMED IN COPTER ATTACK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 10Canada's highestranking military official here has rejected Vietcong assertions that two helicopters carrying representatives of the international peacekeeping commission were shot down Saturday because they had strayed off their prescribed course.

title: ISRAELIS ATTACK GUERRILLA SITES IN A BEIRUT RAID
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, April 10  Israeli commandos attacked Arab guerrilla bases early today in Beirut and Saida, on the Lebanese coast. The raids, carried out in darkness, followed a Palestinian corn, mando attack yesterday in Nicosia, Cyprus, in which an Israeli El Al aircraft was attacked at the airport and a bomb exploded in the home of the Israeli Ambassador.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH IN SIKKIM STREETS
description: GANGTOK, Sikkim, April 9(Reuters)Thousands of demonstrators marched through the streets today demanding the removal of the ruler of this Himalayan kingdom.

title: Space Antenna Will Open
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) A 210foot space tracking antenna capable of probing the outer reaches of the solar system will be opened in Australia on Friday by Prime Minister Gough Whitlam at the Tidbinbilla deep space communications complex near Canberra.

title: Sins of the Fathers
description: LONDONUntil recently investigators had studied individuals seen as mentally ill but not their social contexts. The focus had been upon the patients, not the behavior towards them of other people; it still is in certain circles. As a result, the concept of mental illness has been built upon only some of, not all, the data I think are needed to understand experiences of people considered mentally ill.

title: Majors Get Snowballed
description: More than eight inches of snow in the Midwest has played havoc with today's major league baseball schedule. Four games, including the Mets at St. Louis, were postponed. The others were Boston at Milwaukee, Oakland at Chicago and Baltimore at Detroit. All four were rescheduled for tomorrow.

title: 5 New York Wines Ruled Legal for Sale in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 9 (AP)  Wine produced by five New York wine companies are legal in Ohio, state Liquor Department officials said today.

title: Surcharge for Copper Is Raised by Cerro Corp.
description: The Cerro Corporation's copper products division announced yesterday that it was raising the surcharge on copper industrial and redraw tube 1 to 4 cents a pound, effective immer diately.

title: Radio
description: Talks, Sports, Events News Broadcasts

title: ANTHONY DE BALASY
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Anthony De Balasy, a former Hungarian diplomat and official of the World Bank, died Friday at his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: VEGETABLE SUPPLY ESTIMATED LOWER
