description: WASHINGTON, April 10Senator George McGovern, the 1972 Democratic Presidential candidate, told a group of Democrats who gathered today to start work on a national charter for the party that the party reforms of which he had been a principal architect did not fail but can be improved.

title: Specialists Caution Legislators. Against Isolating the Drug Problem
description: ALBANY, April 11State legislators were cautioned by a seminar of drug specialists today against isolating the drug problem as a demon that, could be treated apart from the broad range of society's problems.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: W.H.A. Playoffs

title: Sihanouk Bars a Truce With Lon Nol
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Prince Norodom Sihanouk has declared in a speech in Hanoi that the insurgent groups in Cambodia would under no circumstances accept a ceasefire with the Government of President Lon Nol.

title: Cost of Abortions, Vasectomies And Pills Ruled Tax Deductible
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service ruled today for the first time that expenses for abortions, vasectomies and birth control pills are tax deductible, including those for 1972.

title: Chicago to Play Rangers
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (AP)Firstperiod goals by Jim Pappin and Stan Mikita sent the Chicago Black Hawks wheeling to a 61 victory tonight, eliminating the St. Louis Blues from the Stanley Cup playoffs in the National Hockey League.

title: Bridge:
description: Most experts nowadays employ the negative double, one of Alvin Roth's many brainchildren, but they differ considerably in the scope they give to it. Roth himself plays it all the way: A double of an overcall at any level simply suggests some highcard strength, and the opener uses his discretion. The higher the level, of course, the more likely he is to try for a penalty.

title: Warriors Subdue Bucks, Take 32 Lead in Series
description: MADISON, Wis., April 10 (UPI)Rick Barry sank a key layup with 1:14 left to play and then scored on two free throws after the final horn to give the Golden State Warriors a 100.97 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight. The triumph gave the Warriors a 32 margin in their National Basketball Association playoff.

title: Books of The Times
description: In Wilfrid Sheed's earlier novels, I always had the feeling that he had saddled himself with protagonists who cramped his style, who weren't complex enough to give the author a chance to work up a sweat. Sheed the wellknown literary critic seemed at least a generation older and infinitely wiser+than. Sheed the novelist, and I used to wonder how he could fail to see this and why he didn't do something about it. I', guess he did see it, because he wrote Max Jamison, a novel about a drama critic who can't mesh gears, with, people because he sees and thinks too much. Unfortunately, this simply shifted the problem now the protagonist was so complet that Mr. Sheed couldn't find any situations or emotions that would suithim. Max was a character who needed footnotes to explain him. As Wolcott Gibbs said of Maurice Evans's Hamlet, he was peevish with thought.

title: Editor Returning to Head The Times Travel Section
description: William H. Honan will return next month to a senior editorship in the Sunday Department of The New York Times, it was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the Sunday editor.
The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: SOYBEAN PRICES RISE THEN DROP
description: Blizzards, which dumped from 12 to 15 inches of snow in some parts of the Midwest, plus floods along the Mississippi, continued to influence prices of farmcommodities futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: People in Sports: Searcy Eligible for N.B.A. Draft
description: Ed Searcy, a 6foot7inch junior at St. John's, was one of 11 players granted eligibility yesterday under the hardship rule for the National Basketball Association college draft next Monday. Searcy had a 13.2 scoring average and averaged 13.1 rebounds in 21 games. The 11 underclassmen will be eligible along with the regular graduating seniors.

title: Midwest Freeze Begins After Peak Snowstorm
description: Bitter cold followed a record April snowstorm into the Midwest yesterday, hampering the work of clearing main traffic routes clogged by drifts as high as 10 feet.

title: WindDriven Water, as Predicted, Batters. Homes on Lake Erie
description: DETROIT, April 10  Alex Steve sat on the second floor of his house on the Michigan lakefront of Lake Erie last night and watched the waters engulf his first floor as he mixed anc sipped martinis.

title: Girl Goes to Bat Against Ban in Sports
description: PISCATAWAY, April 10 (AP)A Piscataway High School student who struck out in her attempts to make the varsity baseball team has started a Federal court suit to change New Jersey's scholastic sports rules on ground that they discriminate against women.

title: URGENCY STRESSED
description: WASHINGTON, April 10President Nixon sent Congress today a comprehensive trade bill that would give him sweeping new authority both to raise and lower United States tariffs and other trade barriers as prelude to forthcoming international negotiations.

title: Radio
description: Talks, Sports, Events News Broadcasts

title: Mitchell, Maryland Legislator, lndicated for U.S. Tax Evasion
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Clarence M. Mitchell 3d, a Maryland State Senator and member of one of the South's most prominent black families, was indicted today on four Federal counts of income tax evasion.

title: Spaniards Hail Picasso As True Son and Genius
description: MADRID, April 10Although Pablo Picasso lived most of his life in France and refused to return to his native Spain as long as the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco was in power, he is being hailed here as one of the greatest of Spanish paintersalbeit with world dimensions.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: And Perhaps The Story of Ruth Dayan, by Ruth Dayan and Helga Dudman (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6,95).

title: Another Strong Man
description: MANILAThroughout nonCommunist Asia there has been a tendency in recent years to strengthen the executive power at the expense of the legislative and judiciary. One can see this trend in South Vietnam, South Korea, Thailand, Cambodia, Indonesia, Pakistan and most recently the Republic of the Philippines, where martial law was declared and Congress abolished last September.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Elects
description: Raymond S. Fries was elected yesterday as a corporate vice president of Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc. He will report directly to Robert J. Buckley, president, and will be given varied executive assignments throughout the company. Mr. Fries was formerly president of the Eugene Dietzgen Company, maker of drafting, engineering and surveying equipment.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The boxing team of Poland will open a twoweek tour of the United States tonight by opposing the New Jersey Golden Gloves champions at the Elizabeth Armory.

title: Camp Operator Admits ModelCities Bribery
description: The operator of an Ulster County camp pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring in $10,000 bribe for two officials of the federally financed Model Cities program in Harlem.

title: 100 Die in Swiss Crash
description: More than 100 Britons, mostly women and children, were killed yesterday when a charter plane crashed in Switzerland in a storm. Sixtythree women on the plane were from one town. Page 93.

title: Vote on Sex Curb Reversed
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 10 (UPI)The Pennsylvania House reversed itself yesterday and defeated a proposal to make premarital and extramarital sex illegal. The vote was 101 to 81.

title: ExStudent Upstate Gets 4 Years in Draft Board Fire
description: SYRACUSE, April 10 (AP)A former Cortland State College student has received a fouryear Federal prison term for helping to set the Cortland draft board office afire in September, 1970 in an antiwar protest.

title: Laos Official Says A Coalition Cabinet Is Due in a Month
description: VIENTIANE, Laos April 10 (Reuters)  Formation of a provisional coalition cabinet in Laos will be announced within a month, Interior Minister Pheng Phongsavan said here today.

title: A State Trooper in Funds Investigation Is the Target of a Departmental Inquiry
description: TRENTON, April 10  The state police detective, James Challender, who touched off Federal investigation last month when he gave information to United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern, is now the target of a departmental investigation.

title: BOYCOTT OF MEAT IS SPOTTY IN CITY
description: It was supposed to be meatless Tuesday, but many stores in the metropolitan area reported meat sales near normal yesterday.

title: Ted Gross Admits He Accepted Bribes
description: Ted Gross, the former Commissioner of the City Youth Services Agency, admitted in State Supreme Court yesterday that he had accepted bribes during his 16 months in office.

title: MRS. JAMES WAKELIN JR.
description: GEORGETOWN, Md., April 10  Mrs. Margaret Smith Wakelin, whose husband, Dr. James H. Wakelin Jr. was Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Research and Development from 1959 to 1964, died here Sunday. She was 62 years old.

title: KENNETH G. AGNEW
description: Kenheth G. Agnew, who retired in 1961 as president of Agnew Associates, Long Island City, Queens, died Monday in St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived at Port Jefferson Station.

title: TROUBLE IS HINTED ON SALYUT FLIGHT
description: It has been more than week since the Soviet Union launched its Salyut 2 space station, and American observers are now wondering why astronauts have not been sent out to occupy it  wondering if some serious trouble has developed.

title: Jamaican Dance Troupe Defies Label
description: We ripple more, said Rex Nettleford, artistic director of the Jamaica National Dance Theater Company. The 11yearold West Indian troupe made its local debut last night, starting a run, through Sunday, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and there is no doubt that this is a special kind of dance company.

title: Kleindienst Sees Wider Executive Shield
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, appeared to widen the Administration's definition of executive privilege today to cover 2.5 million employes a the executive branch of the Government.

title: First Quarter's Climb of 10% to 15% Is Posted
description: Two of the nation's electronicelectrical giants  the General Electric Company and the RCA Corporationreported yesterday sharply higher firstquarter results.

title: Marlboro Players Convey Message In a Fine Concert
description: Nine musicians assembled under the Music from Marlboro banner at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night and played Mendelssohn, Mozart and Faur. For those who get the Marlboro message, that statement should be enough. Quality ruled, as usual.

title: Hartack Posts Riding Triple, His 2d of Pimlico Meeting
description: BALTIMORE, April 10 (UPI) Bill Hartack posted his second riding triple of the Pimlico meeting today.

title: Old Docks on Hudson Burn As Mud Blocks Firemen
description: A Coast Guard utility boat and apparatus of the North Bergen Fire Department, along with residents and motorists on Manhattan's upper West Side, watched a fire last night as it burned through a jumble of derelict barges and docks on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, al Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:
Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Queens College psychologist, his wife and his son routed wouldbe robbers who sought to force their way into the family's home in East Norwich, L. L, yesterday. Two men were arrested, and two others were being sought.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Summary Forecast Extended Forecast Temperature Data Yesterday's Records Precipitation Data Sun and Moon U.S. and Canada Abroad

title: PROFITS LIFT HEX AND 0TC STOCKS
description: Buoyed mostly by favorable firstquarter earning reports, prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market advanced yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Corporate Profit Reports Spur Rally on Big Board
description: The nation's corporations continued yesterday to deluge Wall Street with a flow of strong firstquarter earnings reports and the stock market responded with another upsurge on rising turnover.

title: American Party Figure Declares for Governor
description: NEWARK, April 10 (UPI)A. Howard Freund, a George Wallace supporter who ran unsuccessfully last year for the United States Senate, declared his candidacy today for Governor on the American party ticket.

title: CLEANUP ORDERED AT WILLOWBROOK
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday directed the state to remedy the inhumane and shocking conditions at the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded.

title: House Unit Votes Job Bill That Nixon Vowed to Veto
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)  The House Education and Labor Committee approved today a $4.5billion twoyear extension of a public jobs bill that President Nixon has vowed to veto if it is passed by Congress.

title: F.P.C. HEAD URGES END TO GAS CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, said today that he favored ending Federal price controls for new supplies of natural gas on the interstate market.

title: Trooper in Funds Inquiry Is Target of Investigation
description: TRENTON, April 10  The state police detective, James Challender, who touched off a Federal investigation last month when he gave information to United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern, is now the target of a departmental investigation.

title: Hood Ornaments Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Representative Bertram L. Podell, Democrat of Brooklyn, asked the Transportation Department today to ban protrud ing automobile hood ornaments for safety reasons.

title: U.S. Expects Soviet to Buy Grain This Year, but Less
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Soviet Union is expected to buy sizable quantities of grain again this year, though not as much as in 1972, Department of Agriculture officials said today. The Soniet purchases in world markets are expected to reach, about 14 million tons, or approximately half of last year's purchases of 28 million tons. The United States sold 18 million tons of that grain.

title: Television
description: Television

title: Trade Plan and Soviet
description: President Nixon asked Congress yesterday to permit him to grant trade concessions to the Soviet Union without linking them to the lifting of Moscow's restrictions on free emigration of Jews and other Soviet citizens. Details on Page 7.

title: To Get to Italy, They Had to Travel Only as Far as 59th Street
description: Italian home furnishings, designers have been the innovators in recent years, so it wasn't really much of a surprise last night to find Is an Italian theme to Bloomingdale's new model rooms.

title: Tax Checkoff Repeal Sought
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Nine Republican Senators, led by Peter M. Dominick of Colorado, introduced a bill today to repeal the tax checkoff plan for financing Presidential election campaigns.

title: Gardening Takes Root on Roofs and in Yards
description: Stewart R. Mott, the political big spender and Park Avenue penthouse gardener, says he particularly likes growing kohlrabi, rubyred lettuce and the Chinese pea pods called snow peas.

title: Pentagon Aide Will Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)President Nixon announced today that he would promote a Pentagon spokesman, Jerry W. Friedheim, to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs. Mr. Friedheim, 38 years old, has been a deputy, assistant secretary since 1970.

title: Chile to Issue Big Banknote
description: SANTIAGO, April 10 (UPI)The Chilean Government said today it will soon issue a banknote in the largest denomination ever as result of this nation's skyrocketing inflation rate. Government officials said a 1,000escudo note, worth about $9.00 at the tourist rate of exchange, would be placed in circulation later this month. The biggest bill now in circulation is a 500escudo note.

title: Advertising: Agency Created
description: Howard Cohen, the copy writer, and Bob Pasqualina, the art director, who created the muchtalkedabout Alka Seltzer campaign of a year ago, have now created an advertising agency.

title: Afternoon Special to Lead A.B.C. Children's Fare
description: The George Peabody Awardwinning Afternoon Special programs for children on the American Broadcasting Company will be seen 12 times next season, it was announced yesterday.

title: GENERAL FAVORS INTELLIGENCE CUT
description: WASHINGTON, April 10A top military intelligence of ficer, writing in an unofficial Army journal, has called for reducing duplicative analyses by civilian, intelligence agen des of threats facing the United States.

title: Navy Tanker Runs Aground
description: SAN DIEGO, April 10 (AP)The 25.000ton Navy fleet tanker Guadalupe went aground today off Harbor Island in San Diego Bay. No damage or injuries were reported.

title: A DIVERSE PROGRAM OF COMPUTER ARTS
description: The Computer Arts Festival at the Kitchen, 240 Mercer Street, offered something of a media blitz Monday night. Perhaps the most unusual item was Charles Dodge's Speech Songs, in which simple phrases were synthesized and then particular variables (pitch, intensity, attack, etc.) varied to strikingly expressive effect.

title: British Football
description: Semifinal, First Leg

title: New Zealand Bars Visit By S. Africa Rugby Team
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, April 10  This country's most intense and prolonged controversy of recent times culminated today when Prime Minister Norman E. Kirk directed the Rugby Union to call off a proposed visit here by an allwhite South African team.

title: Funding Bills Signed
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Bills providing a oneyear extension of funding authority for the cleanair and solid wastedisposal laws were signed today by President Nixon. These set spending ceilings at $475million for clean air and $238.5million for solid waste disposal for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1974. Those figures are the currentyear levels.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: 18 FOOD PLACES FAIL 2D HEALTH CHECKUP
description: The Health Department has cited 18 more food establishments here for failing their second healthcode inspection. If violations persist at a third and final inspection, closing; orders could result for the of fenders.

title: CARLTON OF NILS BEATS EXPOS, 75
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP)Loose Montreal fielding and a tworun homer by Willie Montanez helped Steve. Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies to a homeopening 75 victory over the Expos tonight.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SAINTS HAUNT Two Saints does not take its name from any particular deeds of virtue but from its address, St. Marks Place (GR 79650), just east of Third Avenue, where it does duty as a restaurant and after 9, as a night spot, with eats and/or drink, Two Saints is the descendant of a saloon that used to be run by Salvatore Termiti at Cooper Square.

title: State Pact Gives 136,000 $156Million in Pay Rises
description: ALBANY, April 10  Agreement on a new contract covering about 136,000 state employes and calling for wage increases of $156million over two years of a threeyear contract was announced today by negotiators for the Civil Service Employes Association and for the state.

title: U. S. Expects Soviet to Buy Grain This Year, but Less
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Soviet Union is expected to buy sizable quantities of grain again this year, though not as much at in 1972, Department of Agticulture officials said today. The Soviet purchases in world markets are expected to reach about 14 million tons, or approximately half of last year's purchases of 28 million tons. The United States sold 18 million tons of that grain.

title: Hart Renamed to Liquor Unit
description: ALBANY, April 10, (UPI)John C. Hart, a New York City lawyer, has been reappointed to the State Liquor Authority for a term expiing April 12, 1978, the Governor's office announced today. The post pays $32,575. Mr. Hart also is a lecturer on admiralty law at the State University's Maritime College.

title: Check on City Refund Urged on Taxpayers
description: New Yorkers who did not file city income tax returns because they earned $8,000 or less last year may be missing out on getting refunds, according to the City Finance Administrator, Richard Lewisohn.

title: Red Smith
description: The 51st baseball season in Yankee Stadium was launched Monday on a flood of literature that left the interesting impression that the team that opened the big playpen on April 18, 1923, was composed of two men named Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig. This was not exactly the case, as witnesses of next Sunday's game with the Red Sox will discover. That afternoon has been chosen for the park's golden anniversary celebration, presumably because it is three days short of the anniversary, and each customer will receive a copy of the sou@Sports venir programme sold on the original opening day. Between gaudy orange covers @of bearing photographs of Col. Jacob Ruppert The Times@ and Col. Tillinghast L'Hommedieu Huston, the owners, appears an oldfashioned nineman batting order, not the 10man lineup we are familiar with today. All the names, not just two, stir memories. Leading off and playing center field was Whitey Witt, who had been involved in a disturbing incident the previous September. Racing the Browns for the 1922 pennant, the Yankees had taken a halfgame lead into St. Louis. In the first game of the series, which New York won, 21, a pop bottle hurled from the bleachers bounced off Witt's skull as he chased a fly ball. Whitey was knocked senseless and carried off with blood pouring from twoinch cut.

title: Upturn Is Cited by International Paper Co.
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest papermaking organization, had record firstquarter net earnings of $29.7million, equal to 67 cents a share, Paul A. Gorman, chairman and president, reported to some 500 stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

title: Uniformed Fire Officers Elect Staten Island Deputy
description: Deputy Chief David M. McCormack of Staten Island has been elected president of the 2,600member Uniformed Fire. Officers Association.

title: Joe Notter, Only Rider to Win Kentucky Derby on Filly, Dies
description: BRENTWOOD, L. I, April 10 Joe Notter, the jockey who rode the only filly ever to win the Kentucky DerbyHarry Payne Whitney's Regret in 1915 died today in Pilgrim State Hosiptal. He was 82 years old.

title: Excerpts From President Nixon's Trade Message
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress proposing trade reform legislation:

title: Teleprompter Advances Public Access
description: While public access on cable television juggles nervously with publicity generated by charges of obscene programming, its basic concept continues to be advanced by the Teleprompter Corporation. In the first week of May, it has been learned, the company's Manhattan CATV operation, which covers the northern half of Manhattan, will open its access studios in Harlem to free live origination. In effect, any individual or group will be able to reserve up to a half hour of live transmission any evening Monday through Friday between the hours of 7:30 and 11. Reservations, accepted on the usual access basis of firstcome, firstserved, can be made up to a halfhour before appearance time. Direct feedback from viewers can be arranged through studio telephone.

title: Quarter Results Climb
description: John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporadon, reported yesterday that income for the first quarter this year totaled $20.8million, or 75 cents a share, compared to $13.3million, or 48 cents a share, for the yearearlier period.

title: Farm Homes Will Get Disaster Loans
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The Small Business Administration extended its disaster assistance program today to cover damage to the homes of farmers and other rural residents in disaster areas.

title: F.H.A.V.A. Rates Drop For Home Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (Reuters)  Effective interest rates on Federal Housing AdministrationVeterans Administration home mortgage loans in the first week of March were the lowest this year, the Department of Housing and Urban Development reported today.

title: Three Slain Were Prominent Commandos
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 10If the Palestinian guerrilla movement had a foreign minister, Mohammed Yussef Najjar, who was killed early today by Israeli commandos, would have been a likely candidate.

title: A HOLDUP SUSPECT WAS BIAGGINIVER
description: A policeman arrested last week on charges of trying to steal $80,000 worth of cocaine was Representative Mario Biaggi's chauffeur in the mayoral campaign.

title: Traffic Is Tied Up As Xerox Pickets Check Nonstrikers
description: ROCHESTER, April 10 (AP) Traffic jams built up for the second day in a row today at struck Xerox Corporation plants in suburban Webster and Henrietta as cars carrying nonstriking employes threaded through picket lines.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Abolish Fixed Broker Rates in a Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Senate securities subcommittee approved legislation today that would abolish fixed brokerage rates by April, 1974, and requiring brokerage affiliates of institutional investors to conduct a 100 per cent public business to qualify for membership on national stock exchanges.

title: Dynamics Delays Meeting
description: The annual meeting of the Dynamics Corporation of America has been postponed from May 4 until Sept. 14, Andrew Lozyniak, president and chief executive officer, announced yesterday. The company has operated under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since last Aug. 2.

title: Policing Therapists
description: The state's first effort to police the wide variety practitioners in the mental health professions has become embroiled in professional controversy, The dispute over the issue, however, does not bring into question the urgent need for effective safeguards.

title: LEVERETT M. NORMAN
description: Leverett M. Norman, an assistant professor in the library department at City College, where he was a specialist in charge of the institution's collection of Federal government publications, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 95 Christopher Street.

title: Soviet Criticizes Voznesensky Poems
description: MOSCOW, April 10Andrei Voznesensky, the internationally known Soviet poet, has come under official attack for a new cycle of verse containing criticism of censorship, falsity, shallowness and conformity in current Soviet literary life, along with the suggestion that the Revolution has not lived up to its ideals.

title: New Zealand Bars Visit By S. Africa Rugby Team
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, April 10 This country's most intense and prolonged controversy of recent times culminated today when Prime Minister Norman E. Kirk directed the Rugby Unioti to call off a proposed visit here by an allwhite South African team.

title: Weather Closes Track
description: CLEVELAND, April 10 (AP) Thistledown race track canceled its 10race card today because of possible danger to jockeys and horses through poor track conditions caused by the weather.

title: Three NatureStudy Areas Proposed for Long Island
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 10 A proposal to develop three tracts of wetlands in Lido Beach, Seaford and Baldwin to serve as marine naturestudy areas was announced yesterday by Presiding Supervisor Francis T. Purcell of Hempstead Town.

title: Rich Oil Deposits Are Indicated Off L.I.
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Sedimentary deposits with an oilbearing potential that may be as rich as those off the coasts of Louisiana, Texas and California have been found 30 to 50 miles off Long Island and New Jersey, the United States Geological Survey and Nixon Administration officials disclosed today.

title: People and Business
description: Richard R. Shinn, 55, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, has been named chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Gilbert W. Fitzhugh, 63, who will retire from the top post at the nation's second largest life insurer which has assets of $31billion. The Prudential Insurance Company of America is the largest.

title: VisionInspired Indians Offer Plan to End Wounded Knee Siege
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., April 10 The Government was studying today a set of counterproposalsone of them reportedly inspired by a vision that appeared to a Sioux religious leaderfor putting the Wounded Knee peace agreement into effect.

title: The Gasoline Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Greenbelt Consumer Services, Inc., a cooperative, operates 10 filling stations in the Washington area under the BP emblem. It pumps more than eight million gallons of gasoline a year, and it charges 2 or 3 cents less than, the going price. A few days ago the BP Oil Corporation told the cooperative that it would stop delivering gasoline to the cutrate stations when the present contract expires July 9. The company blamed the gasoline shortage, which has already begun to pinch insome parts of the United States and is expected to get worse this summer.

title: Hawaii Teachers Bargain,
description: HONOLULU, April 10 (UPI)The striking Hawaii Teachers Association and the state. Department of Education resulted bargaining today as the statewide teachers strike entered its seventh day. A number of schools remain closed. About 10 per cent of the teachers have been working and the same proportion of students are reporting to classes.

title: Theater: Soldier Opens
description: There is nothing much wrong with Nick Bellitto's new play, The Soldier, which opened last night at the Provincetown Playhouse. But then again, there is nothing much right with it. It is sincere and even serious but unoriginal.

title: MAYOR OF BOSTON SHIFTS ON SCHOOLS
description: BOSTON, April 10  Eight years after he gave strong backing to passage of the landmark Racial Imbalance Law of Massachusetts, Mayor Kevin H. White of Boston declared today that tle law was not working and that it overemphasized the need for racial balance in the, schools.

title: $2.30 WAGE BASE BY 76 PROPOSED

title: Australia Investigating Pro Boxing as Sport Is Condemned by a Medical Group

title: North Says Korean Talks Will Stall if U.S. Remains

title: Rich Oil Deposits Are Indicated Off L.I.
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Sedimentary deposits with an oilbearing potential that may be as rich as those off the coasts of Louisiana, Texas and California have been found 30 to 50 miles off Long Island and New Jersey, the United States Geological Survey and Nixon Administration officials disclosed today.

title: Houk Not Hitting Ceiling Over the Poor Early Start by Bombers
description: Ralph Houk always has said people forget spring training records once the season begins and this year the Yankees are proving him right. But he didn't mean it exactly the way it has been happening.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

title: From Rural Cambodia, War Looks Different
description: TRAM KHNAR, Cambodia, April 10A single Communist mortar shell crashed into a village 100 yards away, sending soldiers and their families running for ditches. Three persons were killed by a rocket last night, and everyone was nervous.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 10 (AP)  Terrorists bombed a Roman Catholic church early today for the third time in three and a half years, and guerrillas wounded a British soldier in an ambush.

title: Pentagon to Use P.O.W.Data To Settle Status of Missing
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Following the recent return of the last of 588 American prisoners of war from Southeast Asia, the Department of Defense has begun to try to determine the status of 1,328 men still listed as missing in action in the Indochina war.

title: 500 More Asians to Enter
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The United States will admit 500 additional Asians who were forced to leave Uganda last fall, informed officials reported today. Last year after President Idi Amin of Uganda ordered all Asians to leave his country, the United States admitted 1,500.

title: ALLENDE SCOFFS AT FUNDS FOR I.T.T.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 10 (AP)President Salvador Allende Gossens said today that cniie would not compensate the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for its expropriated Chilean assets. Dr. Allende also contended that the Central Intelligence Agency had worked with I.T.T. to try to block his election in 1970.

title: Nebraska's Governor Signs Bill to Shield News Sources
description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 10 (UPI)  Gov. J. J. Exon signed toda legi slation to protect newsmen from being forced into disclosing the sources of news.

title: U.S. BEGINS AIRLIFT TO PROVIDE FUEL FOR PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 10The United. States began airlifting fuel into this besieged capital today.

title: 3 Top Guerrillas Slain
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 10Premier Saeb Salam submitted his resignation today following a predawn raid by Israeli commandos in which three prominent Ralestinian guerrilla leaders here were killed.

title: Weeden & Co. Posted Loss In March and First Quarter
description: Weeden & Co, announced yesterday a net loss of $1,128,000 for the month of March, compared to a profit of $445,000, or 25 cents a share, in the same 1972 month.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Films Operas Concerts Dance

title: CITY WILL EXPAND CULTURE PROJECTS
description: A twoweek Puerto Rican fesitival of music and dance, with the cellist Pablo Casals as a participant is a highlight of an ambitious new program worked out between the City of New York and the Carnegie Hall Corporation.

title: Speculum Musicae Offers a Premiere
description: Speculum Musicae, which has been making a name for itself in the short period of its existence, kept up itsgood work on Monday evening in Carnegie Recital Hall. This group is dedicated to 20thcentury music, but with a difference. Where many other groups confine themselves to the avantgarde in general, or (often) to the products of a specific school of composition, Speculum Musicae surveys the entire field.

title: Screen: New Directors:4 Foreign Works at. the Modern Art Have Political or Social Themes
description: Surely by accident, and not by programing design, each of the last four films in the New-Directors/New-Films series at the Museum of Modern Art deals with a decision made for some kind of political or social commitment. The causes range from fascism (Juraj Herz's "The Cremator") to anarchy (Claude Faraldo's "Themroc"), but the movies share a tendency to replace dramatic development with thematic or historical demonstration. For this they pay a high price.The Czechoslovak "The Cremator" was made in 1968, and so is not a new film. But, like its director, it is new to us. The central character, a Mr. Kopfrkingl, is the director of a fancy crematorium, happy in his work, who finds that almost without his wishing it the spirit of his times (the very late nineteen-thirties) is propelling him toward the peak of his career: directorship of a super crematorium with massive ovens and all the necessary bodies to burn in them.Kopfrkingl's story, how he feels rising within him the power of his one drop of German blood, how he finally solves the problem of his beloved half-Jewish wife and quarter-Jewish children, is treated with a blend of intelligent theatrical irony and inflated film technique that is so typicaland so typically the limitationof East-European cinema. But Kopfrkingl himself, played by Rudolf Hrusinky, with the face of a gently demonic Charles Laughton and the manner of a malevolent Herbert Marshall, is a creation of considerable interest.I suspect that almost everything outside the film is more interesting than what actually gets into Paul Leduc's "John Reed: Insurgent Mexico." It is an account of a famous journalist's involvement with the revolutionary forces of Pancho Villa under Gen. Tomas Urbina that began as a magazine assignment and became a process of personal radicalization.Leduc obviously means to keep his film low keyat which, alas, he more than succeeds. But he seems also to claim for it a quality of authenticitypartly by way of soft sepia-tone photography, like the reproductions in old photo-journalismthat it never earns. The pseudo-documentary style of "John Reed" isn't a style at all, but rather an affectation hopefully overlaid upon a flaccid, didactic, fairly conventional treatment of political biography.Shinsuke Ogawa's "The Peasants of the Second Fortress" really is documentary, 2 hours of it, dealing with a 1971 struggle by farmers to stop the construction of a Tokyo airport on their land. The movie has a characteristic look, the look of the wet gray spring during which it was filmed, and it is sometimes very beautiful. More often it is dull.Ogawa's uncanny selectivity in photographing the actual combat between peasants and riot police (like a medieval battle staged by Kurosawa at his best) contrasts with his seemingly total indulgence of every random conference among the peasants, to produce a movie that appears always at odds with itself.Because it uses big stars, and because it is the most ambitiously imaginative, I suppose place of honor should go to Claude Faraldo's "Themroc," though I do not much like it as a movie. Themroc, a Parisian laborer, gets bounced from his job one day. He goes home, seals off his room in his mother's apartment, breaks open the outer wall, and begins living like a happy caveman, making ardent love with his kid sister and feeding himself on roast policeman, captured during nighttime raids in the city streets.There is much more to the movie than this, but not enough to hide the earnest propagandizing behind its fantasywhich, for all its daring, might have come from a Stanley Kramer slightly high on pot. But the real pleasure comes from the performances. In "Themroc" some speak a nonsense language, while everyone else merely makes noises or acts in mimeand it is fun to watch Michel Piccoli, so often the fastidious hero of boulevard romances, cope with a role in which he can only grunt and groan, and to see Batrice Romand, the extra-articulate teen-ager of "Claire's Knee," as the kid sister, a part that enforces total silence. In fact they both do very well.One further film, "Kodou," by the Senegalese director Ababacar Samb, arrived in an unsubtitled print. Because I do not understand its language, I do not think it proper to review it at this time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The White House has been laboring, without result so far, to produce legal memorandum justifying President Nixon's continuing war in Cambodia.

title: Bacteria Grown to Eat Ship's Oil Sludge
description: TEL AVIV, April 10Americanborn microbiologists experimenting aboard an Israeli supertanker off Elath grew baceria that ate more than half the sludge, tar and oil in ballast water during a fourday sailing, it was reported here yesterday.

title: State Pact Gives 136 000 $156Million in Pay Rises
description: ALBANY, April 10  Agreement on a new contract covering about 136,000 state employes and calling for wage increases of $156million, over two years of a threeyear contract was announced today by negotiators for the Civil Service Employes Association and for the state.

title: Top Black in H.E.W. Quits To Be Policy Aid to Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Philip J. Rutledge, the highest ranking black in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today that he was resigning effective May 5.

title: IRVING ZELINKA
description: Irving Zelinka, a principal in the coat and suit firm of ZelinkaMatlick, Inc., of 512 Seventh Avenue, died Sunday after a brief illness at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Zelinka, who lived at 8058 222d Street, Hollis Hills, Queens, was 51 years old.

title: Blue Shield Drops Its Chief After State Criticizes Him
description: Blue Shield of Greater New York has declined to renew the contract of its president, Dr. Leonard J. Raider, following a report by the State Insurance Department that criticized him for having allowed $15million in reserve funds to be dissipated by toolow premiums for city employes.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN ANSWER TO PREVIOU PUZZLE

title: Inquiry Into Cahill Funds Centers on T ax Violations
description: TRENTON, April 10Authoritative sources reported here tonight that the state and Federal investigations of the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 Republican election campaign had narrowed down to Federal charges that heavy contributors wrote off their done: tions as business expenses in violation of incometax laws.

Muskie, Democrat of Maine, today ordered an investigation into what he called the Administration's propaganda campaign against Congress over spending. Senator Muskie asked the Controller General, Elmer B. Staats, whether the alleged campaign, if undertaken at Government expense, violated any law, specifically antilobbying statutes.

Myers's The Children of Pride and Isaiah Trunk's Judenrat.

description: BONN, April 10 (UPI)Thousands of youths protesting a visit by the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, today battled the police and stormed city hall in Bonn's most violent leftwing demonstration in five years.

The post pays $32,575. Mr. Hart also is a lecturer on admiralty law at the State University's Maritime College.

title: Floor Under Wages
description: No group has been harder hit by the steady climb the price of food, rent and other elements in the family budget than the workers at the bottom of the wage ladder. In the five years since the last increase in the Federal minimum wage, the cost of living has gone up by onequarter. The resulting pinch on the living standards of the working poor makes imperative Congressional action this year to break the deadlock that blocked higher minimum standard last year.

description: JERUSALEM, April 10 Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, the Israeli Chief of Staff, said today that his forces spectacular commando raid in Beirut this morning was staged in response to the intensification of terrorist acts in Europe and other places in the last months.

The endofterm crunch, when opinions pour forth in profusion within a span of a few weeks, is a familiar feature of the process.

title: Carrier, City Afloat, Suffers City Stress

The men are too busy arming, launchand landing aircraft, and the only concerns are for time and safety. Nothing else seems to matter. They have learned to ignore the wind, the cold and the thunderous noise. They have learned to ignore the long hours, and while they are busy lugging bombs and pushing planes, they have learned to ignore color too.

description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)Ten years after the first loss of a United States nuclear submarine, the Navy still lacks a modern, worldwide system for rescuing sailors trapped undersea.

title: RUTH RODNEY KING, A MAGAZINE WRITER
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Ruth Rodney King Manley, who wrote short stories and poems in several leading national magazines, died last Tuesday in Doctors Hospital here after a heart attack, her family announced today. She was 66 years old.

title: Tax Evader Sentenced
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10 (UPI) Allen V. Dowling, 60 years old, former president of the Chicago National Life Insurance Company, was sentenced yesterday for failing to file Federal income tax returns in 1966, when he made more than $77,000. He was given a oneyear suspended sentence and placed on two years probation.

title: Screen:'Class of '44,' a Sequel to 'Summer of '42'
description: "The little bird has scratched at the window," says the girl who looks like Ann Rutherford in cap and gown, "for nature has told him it's time to go." It's June, and Hermie, Oscy and Benjie, the three friends of Robert Mulligan's "Summer of '42," are graduating from their Brooklyn high school to face not the terrors of a world at war but those of a sequel gone suddenly, hopelessly flat.The only things worth attention in "Class of '44" are the period detailsthe cars, the billboards, the haircuts, the songs, the suits and dresses and shoes, all soberly researched and reconstructed as if they were artifacts for Colonial Williamsburg. But because nothing much happens with these props, "Class of '44" seems less like a movie than 95 minutes of animated wallpaper.The new film takes Hermie (Gary Grimes) and Oscy (Jerry Houser) to college (Benjie joins the Marines), where Hermie falls in love while Oscy provides the comic relief by, among other things, installing the town whore in his fraternity house for one busy night. The boys have intimations of mortality, and there are jokes about making out, but "Class of '44" has about as much relation to what growing up was like then (and may still be now) as did the Henry Aldrich radio series of that period.The screenplay is by Herman Raucher, who also wrote "Summer of '42." Those were the good old days," I assume we're supposed to say, but the good old days in "Class of '44" seem incredibly unimportant and Hermie and Oscy essential clods, fellows who've most likely grown up to be legendary bores on their respective Thursday night bowling teams.Paul Bogart directed the film, which opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A fire that destroyed most of the restaurant and convention facilities of the Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge in Atlantic City caused damage that will probably amount to the many millions, according to Maxwell Goldberg, one of the owners.

title: Whitmore Gains Freedom at Request of Gold, Who Discloses New Evidence'

description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said yesterday that he would announce today whether he would run this year for his old job in City Hall.

title: ASSEMBLY TO VOTE ON LAY ANALYSTS
description: The Assembly is expected to vote today on a bill that would strictly define the practice of psychological counseling and limit mentalhealth work to persons practicing under statelicensed supervisors.

title: More Presidential Power

For he is asking the House and Senate to grant him vast new powers to raise, lower or, eliminate tariff duties precisely when the Congress is more alarmed than ever before about its loss of power to the Chief Execu, tive.

Searcy had a 13.2 scoring average and averaged 13.1 rebounds in 21 games. The 11 underclassmen will be eligible along with the regular graduating seniors.
