title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the peaceful uses of outer space, legal subcommittee10:30 A.M.

title: Hartford Will Add 50 Auxiliary Police To Combat Crime
description: HARTFORD, April 10The Hartford City Council, stirred by some recent and highly publicized crimes, voted 7 to 2 last night to create a 50man auxiliary police force of volunteers who would provide added protection in the city.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)A House Banking subcommittee approved today a bill to make formal the 10 per cent devaluation of the dollar in terms of gold.

title: A l Unser: Winning Maneuver In Texas 200 No Dirty Trick
description: Did Al Unser win the Texas 200 by a dirty trick? Was his tactic unsporting? Were the fans justified in booing him?

title: California Set for Sunday Racing
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 10  Hollywood Park announced today that it would conduct horse racing on Sundays throughout its 15week meeting opening tomorrow.

title: ACQUISITION IS MADE BY BEATRICE FOODS
description: The Southwestern Investment Company, a diversified financial services and insurance company, announced yesterday it had signed an agreement under which it would became a wholly owned subsidiary of the Beatrice Foods Company.

title: Explanation in Tel Aviv
description: JERUSALEM, April 10 Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, the Israeli Chief of Staff, said today that his forces spectacular commando raid in Beirut this morning was staged in response to the intsification of terrorist acts in Europe and other places in the last months.

title: Nixon to Name Labor Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) President Nixon announced his intention today to nominate Bernard E. DeLury to be Assistant Secretary of Labor for employment standards. Mr. DeLury, now Deputy Industrial Commissioner for the New York State Labor Department, would succeed Richard J. Grunewald, Who left the Labor Department in January.

title: Teller on Her First Day Pays Out to a Gunman
description: A gunman entered a branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank in the Bronx yesterday and thrust a threatening note and a bag to a young woman teller on the job for the first day.

title: Working Mothers Protest in Capital On Day Care Cuts
description: WASHINGPTON, April 10 (UPI) Preschool children romped through offices on Capitol Hill and in other parts of the country today in a working mothers protest against proposed cuts in Federal day care funds.

title: Body of Picasso Is Transferred To Chapel of Medieval Castle
description: VAUVENARGUES, France, April 10Pablo Picasso's body was moved across his beloved southern France today from the villa where he died at Mougins north of Cannes to the chapel of the 16thcentury castle dominating this village in the sere, almost forbidding hill country north of Marseilles.

title: TRUSTEE IS NAMED AT EQUITY FUNDING
description: Robert M. Loeffler, a senior vice president of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the biggest mutual fund company in the nation, was named late yesterday as trustee for the scandalridden Equity Funding Corporation of America, a financial services conglomerate, now in reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: PHARMACISTS SUE TO BAR SALE GUIDE
description: NEW HAVEN, April 10 (AP) A lawsuit in Superior Court seeks to block further distribution of a buying guide that rates about 50 locale drug, stores as being good, average, poor or erratic in terms of their prices.

title: Westinghouse Opens Talks
description: PITTSBURGH, April 10 (UPI) The Westinghouse. Electric Corporation opened wage contract negotiations today with the International Union of Electrical Workers, which represents about 32,000 workers at 40 plants across the country.

title: Kennedy Youth Fined $30
description: PLYMOUTH, N.H., April 10 (AP)Robert F. Kennedy Jr., son of the late Senator, has pleaded guilty by mail to driving 30 miles above a 35mileanhour limit and has been fined $30 by District Court Judge Leonard Sawyer. The youth, of Hyannis Port, Mass., was earlier held in default when he failed to appear at a court hearing March 16.

title: Major League Baseba
description: TODAY'S PROB ABLE PITCHERS

title: Places to Take the Children
description: Exhibitions

title: EMANUELSHAPIRO,71, OF METRO SERVICES
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 10  Emanuel Shapiro, president of Metro Associated Services, Inc., at 80 Madison Avenue, New York, died of a heart attack last night while on the way to his home here. He was 71 years old and lived at 40 Cushman Road.

title: Strike Against Terror
description: Israeli commandos have struck a stunningly effective blow in the war against terror that was proclaimed by Premier Golda Meir after last fall's Munich massacre. Yesterday's swift, pinpointed attack against three, key Palestinian guerrilla leaders in their homes in downtown Beirut and against other guerrilla targets inside Lebanon rivals in daring and brillianceand in potential import Israeli victories in three conventional wars against the Arabs.

title: Counselor to Nixon Terms Watergate a Blow to Party
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Anne Armstrong, Counselor to President Nixon, said today that the Watergate affair was hurting the Republican party across the nation.

title: WILLIAM REIBER
description: PARIS, April 11 (AP)William Reiber, director of marketing for the ChryslerSimca automobile company, died today at the American Hospital. He was 52 years old.

title: Dance: At Paper Mill
description: Some very well known names in American ballet were not doing their usual thing Tuesday night, and we have the New Jersey Ballet Company to thank for this opportunity to see these dancers performing outside their repertory at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: PRESS SHIELD BILL DIES IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD, April 11A proposed shield law designed to protect newsmen in Connecticut from having to disclose confidential sources died in committee this morning, the victim of an unresolved disagreement over the extent to which sources should be protected.

title: Marine Instructor Convicted
description: SAN DIEGO, April 11 (AP)A drill instructor at the Marine Corps recruit depot was convicted of assault and hazing and returned to duty after being fined $600, a spokesman said today. The instructor was identified as Sgt: John F. Morland, 23 years old, of St. Louis.

title: Truce Copter Reportedly Was on Course
Business Panel Presents Health Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The Committee for Economic Development, a businessoriented research and education group, proposed today a broad plan for American health care, including universal coverage by some form of health insurance.

title: Nixon Nominates Virginian
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  President Nixon announced today that he would nominate John O. Marsh Jr., a former Democratic Representative from Strasburg, Va., to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for Legislative Affairs. Mr. Marsh, who served in the House for eight years until 1971, would succeed Gardiner L. Tucker.

title: Crucifixion Mural to Fall With School
description: A striking mural depicting the Crucifixion has attracted much attention as wreckers demolish the centuryold Holy Cross Academy on West 42d Street.

title: CARLETON L. MARSH
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 11 Carleton L. Marsh, a lawyer and civic leader, died yesterday in the Stamford Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived on Gilliam Lane in Riverside.

title: Chiropractor Charged
description: ATLANTA, April 11 (UPI)L. J. Goodwin, who said he had a lapsed license from the Missouri College of Chiropractic, has been charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a woman he injected with silicone to enlarge her bust.

title: LOWLAND FLOODED INVICKSBURG, MISS.
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., April 11 (UPI)  The Mississippi River, at its highest level in 30 years, rolled past this historic river town today, sweeping away tenant shacks and driving plantation owners to higher ground.

title: Year's Grace
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, did what he had to do in giving the automobile industry an additional year to achieve the antipollution standards laid down by law. Rather than risk widespread economic disruption, especially on the employment front, by insisting that all the standards be met for 1975 models, he chose to postpone their full impact to 1976. The statute clearly empowered him make that decision.

title: Scientists Correct Course Of JupiterBound Pioneer
description: PASADENA, Calif., April 11 (AP)The course of the Jupiterbound Pioneer 11 spacecraft was altered by a rocket burn today as the 570pound payload hurtled through space at 84,000 miles an hour.

title: Hennigan Gets Final Out at St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, April 11  The New York Mets defeated the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 54, for their third straight victory of the season and the Cardinals fourth straight loss.

title: Records: Songs by Ellie Greenwich
description: Ellie Greenwich's album Let It Be Written, Let It Be Sung (Verve Records V 65091, $5.98) comes loaded with a grandiose title and grandiose statistics. Miss Greenwich is a songwriter and producer with a lengthy track record. When Bette Midler today sings Leader of the Pack, she is recreating the song and mood that Miss Greenwich, together with Jeff Barry and Phil Spector, worked out in 1964, the days when it was possible to build a Sistine Chapel of an arrangement based solely on the phrases Do Ron Ron or Do Wah Diddy.

title: For Children, Some Good Came Out of That Tragedy
description: After 10yearold Luis Ortiz was murdered and sexually mutilated on West 106th Street last month; a wave of terror swept the West Side. Parents escorted their children everywhere to protect them from the West Side child killer; some youngsters were confined to their homes; others carried weapons as they walked to and from school.

title: BIG OUTLAY IS SEEN BY UPSTATE UTILITY
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., April 11Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., expects to spend about $62million on construction this year, Charles H. Tenney, 2d, chairman, told about 200 stockholders at today's annual meeting here.

title: WAGNER DECLINES TORUN FOR MAYOR ON ANY TICKET
description: Robert F. Wagner declined yesterday to run for Mayor, declaring that he did not have the overriding desire needed for the pOst and expressing concern that he might hurt the election prospects of his son, Robert Jr., who is a candidate for councilman at large in Manhattan.

title: Lebanese Break Up AntiU.S. Protest
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 11Lebanese policemen fired rifles and teargas grenades today to disperse a thousand student demonstrators who marched on the United States Embassy and cultural center in protest against Israel's attack on Palestinian guerrillas here.

title: Wooden Receives Trophy
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11 (UPI)The University of California, Los Angeles, basketball coach, John Wooden, received the United Press InternatiOnal Board of Coaches national championship basketball trophy in ceremonies in his office today. Wooden's Bruins have won seven straight National Collegiate titles and nine of the last 10. U.C.L.A. has won 75 games in a row, an N.C.A.A. record.

title: Theater Classes Make Loft Bronxville's Other School
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 11  Susan Ingalls, about to be graduated from Sarah Lawrence College here and in need of a job, decided to try making money by doing what she liked best  teaching children about the theater.

title: Miss Osterlund on Big A Victor
description: Irene Osterlund, a blonde 24yearold Swede, came to the attention of the 17,159 fans at Aqueduct yesterday by steerMg John M. Olin's Opiniontion to victory in a sevenfurlong race. Competing against some of the meeting's leading riders in the field of eight, Miss Osterlund made a big early lead stand up as she guided Opinionation to a onelength triumph.

title: Boycott Leaders Plan a Protest; Urge 2 Meatless Days a Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Boycott leaders from across the Country, with none of their anger spent by a meatless week, crowded into a Congressional conference room today to organize a National Consumers Congress for a continuing fight against high prices.

title: BOYCOTT OF ISRAEL LAID TO JAPANESE
description: Three leading Japanese manufacturers of automobiles and electronics equipmentToyota, Niss0 and Hitachiwere accused yesterday of refusing to do business with Israel because of the Arab economic boycott.

title: A Mothers' Holiday, Then Grief in British Villages
description: AXBRIDGE, England, April 11Six small boys were swinging on the iron schoolyard fence in this bereaved Somerset village.

title: Master CapitalBudget Process, Mayor Urges Community Panels
description: Mayor Lindsay urged 300 members of the city's community boards last night to master the exquisitely complex process of one of government's most arcane institutions the capital budgetbefore they could hope to wield more power in city affairs.

title: El Diario Reaches Settlement, Ending Strike by Craft Unions
description: El DiarioLa Prensa, the Spanishlanguage daily, reached a settlement last night with four striking craft unions that have blocked the newspaper's publication since April 5.

title: College, School Results
description: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)

title: Burroughs Net Rises
description: Two of the nation's major computer manufacturers, the International Business Machines. Corporation and the Burroughs Corporation, announced yesterday increases in earnings for the first quarter of 1973.

title: Commons Defeats Effort to Restore the Death Penalty
description: LONDON, April 11 The House of Commons turned back an effort today to restore the death penalty after a new campaign by the hanging lobby that stirred British emotions over rising crimes of violence.

title: MRS. IRVING FRIED
description: Mrs. Ruth Fried of 80 Brighton 11th Street in Brooklyn died at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday. She was 67 years old.

title: SHOP TALK
description: There's been a fad for ivory jewelry . . . for tortoise shell . . . for jade . . . for wooden bangles . . . for anything silver. Now, Claire Hall, the jewelry buyer for Henri Bendel who has been in on the ground floor of virtually every trend, has spotted a new one: motherofpearl.

title: C.B.S. Fall Lineup For Children Adds. 4 Cartoon Series
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System will add four animated cartoon series to its Saturday children's schedule next season. Two of the cartoons will be based on My Favorite Martian and I Dream of Jeannie, comedy shows that ran successfully in prime evening time.

title: Flower Paintings Offer Beauty, With Surprises
description: The flowers that bloom in the spring have long been a favorite subject of some of our greatest painters. As a general rule, however, we tend to see these flower pintings in the company of works depicting larger and more dramatic subjects. Rarely is so minor a theme given an extensive exhibition.

title: $110Million Deal Is Set Beatrice Foods Makes Bid for Samsonite
description: The McCrory Corporation and the Lerner Stores Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle for the merger of Lerner into McCrory. The transaction is valued at about $110million. McCrory already owns about 60 per cent of Lerner.

title: 184Truck Convoy, First in 3 Weeks, Gets to Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia. April 11  A large convoy of supply trucks arrived here this afternoon, the first to make its way from the sea past Communist positions in three weeks, but a senior figure in the Government took issue with reports that Phnom, Penh had been under siege.

title: F.P.C. PLAN POINTS TO GAS PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The Federal Power Commission, in a step apparently designed to raise natural gas prices, began today a streamlined proceeding to establish a uniform national ceiling price for gas from new wells in all parts of the United States.

title: Utility Files for Expansion
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company anounced yesterday that it had filed an application with the Atomic Energy Commission for permission to build two additional nuclear power units at its Surry County, Va., power station.

title: Complexity in the Bunraku's Stagecraft
description: At Bunraku, the National Puppet Theater of Japan, in residence through Sunday at the City Center 55th Street Theater, one is compelled to focus on the lifelike puppets, but for full appreciation one should also be aware of the other aspects of this complex, highly synchronized art.

title: FOOD SANITATION CALLED IMPROVED State Health Aide Credits New Plan on Violations
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, April 11A tightening of inspection, increasingly cooperative purveyors and public disclosure of unsanitary restaurant and food handling conditions significantly improved food handling sani tation in the last, six months, a consumer expert said today.

title: Grain and the Soviet Professional Traders in Commodities Rely on Four Key Factors in Dealings
description: Professional commodities traders, the people who buy and sell tomorrow's meals and manufactures, have traditionally depended on four key factors to guide them in their daytoday dealings.

title: Tass Confirms Change in Salyut Orbit
description: MOSCOW, April 11The Soviet Union confirmed today that it had raised the orbit of its spade workshop Salyut 2 to a height not normally accessible to manned flights.

title: HOUSE UNIT KILLS PRICE ROLLBACK
Assembly Bars Voter Veto Of Public Housing in State
description: ALBANY, April 11 A combination of Democrats and Nassau County Republicans today narrowly defeated an Assembly bill to permit voters within a county t odetermine if publichousing projects should be built.

title: Lansky Trial Rescheduled
description: MIAMI, April 11 (AP)The Federal income tax evasion trial of Meyer Lansky, alleged crime figure, who is recuperating from open heart surgery, has been rescheduled for July 9.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Cleveland at New York (2 P.M.)Tidrow (01) vs. Kline (01).

title: Judge Ousts Newsmen Bat Lets Public Stay
description: PLYMOUTH, Ind., April 11 (UPI)Saying newsmen were not the public, Marshall County Circuit Court Judge Tom Huff today ordered about 15 newsmen and cameramen from his court but let other spectators remain.

title: New Jersey Sports Rutgers Beats Drums
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 11Professional teams from New York and Philadelphia frequently invade New Jersey in their off seasons for promotional efforts with fans various communities in what have been described as Caravans.

title: Bankers Trust Lifts Profit
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, parent of the country's seventh largest bank, reported yesterday that its operating earnings, before securities transaction, increased 19.8 per cent in the first quarter.

title: Three Fined for Delay in Setting Rents
description: A Criminal Court judge, the former administrator of the Housing and Development Administration and a current deputy administrator of the agency were found guilty of contempt and fined yesterday for their delay in setting maximum base rents for more than a million apartments.

title: City Council to Vote on Memorial Day Store Closings
description: A controversial bill that would require retail drygoods stores to close on Memorial Day is expected to be voted out of a City Council conunittee next week over the strong objections of the Lindsay administration and merchants associations representing the major department stores in the city.

title: Bostonian Indicted in Death Of Girl From Paramus, N.J.
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP) A man being held on murder charges in the deaths of two Bostonarea women was indicted today for murder in connectio with the slaying of a third woman.

title: Soviet Sticks and Stones for David Rabe
description: MOSCOW, April 11David Rabe, the American playwright, was accused today of having written a letter attacking a Soviet version of his play Sticks and Bones because he lacked the courage to stand up to pressures from the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: Brig. Gen. James Kincaid Dies; Headed American Hotels Corp.
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., April 11 Brig. Gen. James Leslie Kincaid, U.S.A., retired, former president of the American Hotels Corporation, died yesterday at his home on Captiva Island near here. He was 88 years old.

title: Lakers Assure Fans The Alarm Was False
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11  A major crisis was passed by the Los Angeles Lakers last night in defense of their National Basketball Association championship and the sigh of relief shook the smoggy atmosphere all the way from the Forum in Inglewood to Wilt Chamberlain's famous mansion in Bel Air.

title: Counselor to Nixon Terms Watergate a Blow to Party
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Anne Armstrong, Counselor to President Nixon, said today that the Watergate affair was hurting the Republican party across the nation.

title: BANK BOARD EASES SAVINGS UNIT RULES
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (Reuters)The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today it had relaxed rules affecting nationwide lending and participating practices of federally insured savings and loan associations.

title: Secrist Alleges That Phantom Accounts Were Used to Mislead Auditors
description: ATLANTA, April 11Ronald H. Secrist, the 37yearold insurance executive who first exposed the multimilliondollar scandal that has rocked his former employer, the Equity Funding Corporation of America, alleged yesterday that some Equity officers and employes signed large numbers of internal company audit forms designed to confirm the existence of phantom funding accounts.

title: Mayor Gets Annual Report From Board of Correction
description: Mayor Lindsay received the third annual report of his Board of Correction yesterday from William J. vanden Heuvel, who has resigned as its chairman. He refused to comment on widespread reports that Dean Robert McKay of the New York University Law School would be appointed as Mr. vanden Heuvel's successor.

title: Arabs and Israelis Battle in Europe, Too
description: ROME, April 11The recent spectacular actions by Arab and Israeli commandos have been accompanied by a chain, of deadly but obscure duels among secret networks all over Europe and elsewhere, intelligence specialists here say.

title: Lacey Denies Trenton Aim
description: NEWARK, April 11 (AP)Federal Judge Fredrick B. Lacey denied reports today that he was interested in challenging Governor Cahill for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, Instead he said, he intends to return to private practice with a. New York City law firm no later than June 30.

title: NIXON CRITICIZED OVER BOMBINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Two legal scholars and a former Attorney General argued before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that President Nixon had no constitutional authority to continue bombing in Combodia.

title: HEARINGS ARE URGED ON OPTION PROPOSAL
LakersBulls to Be Televised
description: The American Broadcasting Company said last night that it would televise tomorrow night's National Basketball Association WesternDivision playoff game at Chicago between the Bulls and Los Angeles Lakers. The game will begin at 8:30 P.M., New York time A.B.C. is Channel 7 in New York.

title: United Transportation Union Approves Railroad Accord
description: CLEVELAND, April 11 (UPI) General and local chairmen of the 195,000member United Transportation Union have approved the proposed railroad industry agreement, which would raise the salaries of railroad men by 4 per cent next January.

title: Anger and Confusion Pervade School BoardPetition Hearing
description: Flaring tempers and some confusion marked a hearing before the Board of Elections yesterday on objections to the nominating petitions filed by some community schoolboard candidates.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M.

title: People in Sports: Agee Unhappy on Bench
description: While Cleon Jones is off to a good start with the Mets, Tommie Agee, his buddy, is unhappy sitting on theHouston bench. The 30yearold Agee, traded by the Mets to the Astros in the offseason and beaten out for the regular leftfield spot, said, I'm not angry at any of the players or Leo Durocher, but feel I can still play if I'm given the chance. I just happen to be witli a club which has a set outfield. I will do anything I can to help the team. I feel I can still play with anybody and do most things anybody can. I can steal 3540 bases, I can run, hit and throw.

title: Initiative in Congress
description: The realization is growing among influential members of Congress that, if it is to hold its own institutionally in the battle with the White House over the budget, it has to modernize its procedures. The failure of the House this week to override President Nixon's veto of the rural sewer and water program and the Senate failure last, week to override his veto of the vocational rehabilitation bill underscore the urgency of Congressional action. It is plain that Congress has to have effective machinery of its own for establishing spending priorities and making them stick or else the President will make the decision by use of his veto power. Fortunately the Joint Study Committee on Budget Control has now reached tentative agreement on legislation that would move far in the direction of effective reform.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES 2 BUDGET CHANGES
description: ALBANY, April 11In an unusual action that focused on the question of who has control over the state budget, Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had vetoed two changes made by the Legislature in his newly approved budget for 197374.

title: RUBEN TELLS OF SHIFT IN VIEWS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11 Dr. Daniel Ellsberg testified today at the Pentagon papers trial that his feelings about the Vietnam war had been changed by such experiences as standing amid burning huts or watching schools built with American supplies turn to dust and blow away on the wind.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY GETS PAPERS OF INVENTOR
description: Mrs. Chester F. Carlson, widow of the inventor of xerography, presented yesterday the bulk of the scientist's papers and notebooks on his experiments to the New York Library's division of Manuscripts and Archives. Included among the more than 9,000 items are letters revealing the inventor's extensive philanthropic interests and correspondence reflecting his interest in parapsychology and the religions of the Far East.

title: Yarborough's Time Fastest
description: DARLINGTON, S. C., April 11 (UPI)Cale Yarborough turned in the fastest speed today during the first day of practice runs for Sunday's Rebel 500 stock car race. Yarborough toured the 1mile oval in 152.7 miles an hour. David Pearson was the closest challenger at 151.9 m.p.h.

title: Black Caucus Seeks TV Time
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The 15member Congressional Black Caucus has taken to court a twoyear battle to try to force the teevision networks to give the caucus free prime time to answer President Nixon. The caucus asked the United States District Court here, in a suit filed this week, to reverse a ruling by the Federal Communications Commission on Feb. 6 that the networks did not have to supply the time.

title: JAMES STOLCZ
description: TRUMBULL, Conn., April 11  James Stolcz, owner and president of WNLK and WDRNFM radio stations in Norwalk and WBUX in Doylestown, Pa., died Tuesday at his home here.

title: Mohawk and Goodyear Plan Fiber Glass Radial Tires
description: The development of a radial tire, using all fiber glass was announced early yesterday by the Mohawk Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio. The new tire will retail at prices slightly below those of steelbelted radial tires, the company said.

title: West Germany Closes the File On Bormann, Calling Him Dead
description: BERLIN, April 11Martin Bormann, Hitler's aide, was officially declared dead today on the basis of identification of a skeleton uncovered during construction work in West Berlin last December.

title: Turco Keeps Newark Post
description: NEWARK, April 11 (UPI) The Newark City Council has decided to let Louis M. Turco, indicted recently by a Federal grand jury, remain as Council President. Five Councilmen and Mr. Turco issued a statement yesterday following a special session. The statement said Mr. Turco has not abused his position as President of the Council despite the indictment.

title: TV: N.B.C.'s Version of Gallico's Small Miracle
description: On the National Broadcasting Company network last night, Paul Gallico's The Small Miracle was transformed into a large dud. If any miracle was involved, it was that the production managed to make 90 minutes seem like three or four long hours.

title: Sound of Reaction
Business Lauds, Assails Trade Plan
description: The Admistration's new trade bill drew sharp criticism as well as strong endorsement from business leaders yesterday.

title: F.P.C. PLAN POINTS TO GAS PRICE RISE
Advertising: Recall of Ingenue
description: In its last issue under its old publisher, Ingenue, a magazine, for teenaged girls, departed from a 14year tradition and ran an explicit article on sexual conduct.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Billy Cunningham, the league's most valuable player, was upstaged by Artis Gilmore of the Kentucky Colonels yesterday in balloting for the American Basketball. Association allstar team. The 7foot2inch Gilmore, the A.B.A. rebound leader, was named on 55 of 58 selections and totaled 111 points in voting by sports writers and broadcasters.

title: PENNSY DIRECTORS GET COMPENSATION
description: Five of 22 former directors of the Penn Central Company who have agreed to settle 18 lawsuits brought against them by stockholders of the bankrupt railroad are being compensated for their expenses in the proposed settlement by concerns they represented on the Penn Central's board.

title: N.H.Z. Playoffs
National Stock Exchange Accepts Associate Members
description: John D. Girard, president of the National Stock Exchange, said, yesterday the exchange has established associate memberships for the first time.

title: INTERSTATE CLOSING 19 TOPPS OUTLETS
description: Interstate Stores, Inc., New Yorkbased operator of, discount and conventional department stores will close 19 unprofitable Topps stores after Easter, Sol. W. Cantor, chairman, said yesterday. The company had also closed 19 White Front stores in the fiscal year ended Jan. 28.

title: Some Thoughts on the Other Side of This Life
description: HAYWARD, Calif.A halfcentury after Freud, it remains, from the viewpoint of the intellectual and academic mainstream, a dangerous proposition that there is morevaluably moreto the human personality than immediate consciousness tells us there is. Two centuries after the Romantic poets began probing the transrational regions of the mind for the insights and images on which psychotuialysis was later reared, it remains an unforgiveable betrayal of Reason to suggest that what these artists and their successors have had to teach us about life, nature and society should be treated as any form of knowledge, rather than as a merely esthetic entertainment.

title: Troopers in Jersey Support Detective In Inquiry on Funds
City Sells $285Million in Bonds At Interest Rate of Just Over 5%
description: The city sold $285,360,000 in serial bonds yesterday at a net average interest rate of slightly more than 5 per centa percentage low enough to gladden the Controller's office, which saw it as a vote of confidence in the city's finances.

title: A Vote for Dirty Water
description: Because the sewage systems of Connecticut's cities are obsolete, a state official pointed out the other day, takes only ten minutes of heavy rain for raw human waste to overflow into nearby streams and into Long Island Sound. Connecticut's problem arises from the old practice of running wastes and storm water through the same sewage lines to the nearest body of water. It can be corrected at a cost of $500 million by building new pipes parallel to the old ones, thus segregating the wastes from the storm water and carrying them to sewage treatment plants already in existence.

title: FINAL PLEAS MADE ON GAMBLING VOTE
description: TRENTON, April 11Advocates of legalized ,gambling in New Jersey made a final effort today to have their proposals Offered to the public in a statewide referendum in the November elections.

title: Nixon Acts on Pensions
description: President Nixon asked Congress yesterday to establish Federal standards for improving private pension systems for 35 million workers. Details are on Page 34.

title: Israeli Team in Yugoslavia Goes for Security Reasons
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, April 11 (AP)The Israeli table tennis team withdrew from the world table tennis championships today after, having been advised by Yugoslav officials that security would be served by their departure.

title: Chanfreau Beats Cox
Congress Urged to Act on Indian Issue
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  An Administration spokesman told Congress today that confrontations such as that in Wounded Knee between Indians and the Government would be minimized if Congress would pass a legislative package based on the principle of selfdetermination that was proposed by the President more than two years ago.

title: MORE FOOD OUTLETS FAIL 2D INSPECTION
description: Fourteen more food establishments in New York City have been cited by the Health Department for failing a second healthcode inspection. If the violations have not been corrected before a third and final inspection later this month, the establishments may be ordered closed.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
Government's Pollution Fighter
description: WASHINGTON. April 11 Despite intense pressures in making his decision on auto pollution standards, William Doyle Ruckelshaus found time for a fantasy:

title: Roundup: Blue and A's Trounce White Sox, 122
description: Vida Blue, the toast of the baseball world in 1971, when he won 24 games, but a comparative nonentity last season when he won, only six, pitched the world champion Oakland A's to their first victory of the 1973 campaign yesterday.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 4 Top U.S. Auto Makers Upset by E.P.A. Action
description: DETROIT, April 11The four major United States auto makers reacted here today with dismay at the decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to relax the 1975 autoemission standards of the Clean Air Act.

title: Princess of Sikkim Accuses Indian Agents in Disorders

title: Unconventional Engine Uses 2 Fuel Mixtures

title: Advance Fizzles in the Credit Markets
description: The bond market's latest advance petered out yesterday after just about a week, apparently because of growing doubts that economic controls will be tightened after all, despite increasing inflation.

title: P.O.W.'s Report a Colonel Listed as Missing Is Dead
description: Lieut. Col. Richard S. Schott, of Rockville, Md., who had been listed as missing in action in Vietnam for a year, has been declared dead by the Defense Department on the basis of information from American prisoners freed by the Vietcong.

title: EAST COAST WARY ON OFFSHORE
description: Officials of New York, New Jersey and other East Coast states said yesterday they would intensify their efforts to prevent what they believe could be disastrous consequences, of offshore petroleum drilling.

title: Notes on People
description: At a White House dinner in his honor, Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore toasted President Nixon with champagne and said he had discovered that the American news media were not sympathetic to the Nixon Administration. With celebrities such as Glenn Ford, Edgar Bergen and Bob Feller in attendance at the dinner, the Prime Minister said, In the last few days in this country I have discovered that any statement, any argument, however dispassionate  which can be faintly, directly or indirectly construed as in support of, or in sympathy with, any of the hopes, policies or aspirations of this administration finds very scant space in the mass media. Then Mr. Lee praised the President for the cultured detachment of mind which enables you to pursue what is right in the long run, never mind what it is in the short run, whether it wins rapturous applause or otherwise.

title: Mrs. Georgina MacKinnon, Keeper of Drambuie Secret
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, April 11 (Reuters)  Mrs. Georgina MacKinnon, who held the secret recipe for Drambuie, the Scotch whisky liqueur, died at her home near here today. She was 89 years old.

title: 2 Drifters on a Photogenic Landscape:The Cast
description: Max and Lion (full name: Francis Lionel) are classic drifters. Cut loose from their lower-middle-class backgrounds, for various, probably neurotic reasons, they float across the face of America with all of the resolution of a couple of cheerful mongrels checking out the bushes, trees and lampposts on any new street that happens to cross their field of limited vision.They never quite get where they're going, which, I suspect, seems more poetic and tragic to the makers of a movie like "Scarecrow" than it does to the Maxes and Lions of real life. It's the moving around, not the getting anywhere, that counts.For most of "Scarecrow"for as long as the movie doesn't intrude on their essential aimlessness  Max (Gene Hackman) and Lion (Al Pacino) are two marvelously realized characters.Max, a big, near-sighted clown with a bad temper, has just finished an extended stay in San Quentin for assault. He's always a bit cold, which is why he wears a half-dozen layers of long johns, shirts and sweaters. He wants to open a carwash in Pittsburghnot because he knows Pittsburgh but because that is where his savings account happens to be.Max is not without a kind of sloppy sex appeal. When he enters a cocktail lounge, a female barfly named Darlene issues an invitation by screaming: "Shut the door, you big dope! You're letting all the smoke out!"Max neither loves nor trusts anyone until he meets Lion, an ex-seaman hitching his way from California to Detroit to see the wife he deserted six years before and a 5-year-old child who may be either a boy or a girl. He doesn't knowwhich is why the present he carries is a lamp. A lamp, he figures, is a suitable way to avoid the issue.The friendship of Max and Lion, as they lurch across the United States, with time out for a visit with Max's sister Coley (Dorothy Tristan) in Denver (as well as for a month's stay on a Denver Honor Farm), is genuinely moving and funny. It all goes decisively wrong when Jerry Schatzberg, the director, and Garry Michael White, who wrote the screenplay, decide to saddle the pair with a poetic vision that suddenly makes everything needlessly phony.This doesn't come as a complete surprise. There have been hints earlier in the picture that Schatzberg and White want to impose their own sensibilities on Max and Lion. The hints are in the title (Max and Lion and all of the other drifters are life's scarecrows) and in the spectacularly beautiful landscapes, photographed, by Vilmos Zsigmond, through which Max and Lionel move, unaware (though we aren't) that they are in the world as it might be seen by Peter Hurd. No amount of time and no expenses have been spared to obtain the right light.The hints are also there in the supporting performances, which aren't bad, just too busy. There is a definite limit on the number of nose-wipings on sleeves, speeches said with mouths full and elegant burps that any movie can contain before it begins to turn back on itself, like parody. Which is too bad because both Hackman and Pacino are fine and so many of the early, character-setting scenes are so accurate.I assume that Schatzberg and White wanted somehow to ennoble Max and Lionel, but they sentimentalize them in ways rigidly avoided by both John Huston's "Fat City" and Barbara Loden's "Wanda," two other films about a similar kind of sad, almost national witlessness. "Scarecrow" opened yesterday at the Cinema I.

title: C.A.B. Is Overruled by Nixon'Foreign Policy Reasons Are Cited

title: TV : The Haunted West
description: By now, it's hard to imagine the National Geographic Society turning out a dull television hour. Its third special of the season; The Haunted West, to be shown tonight at 8 over the Columbia Broadcasting System, is warmly diverting. Briskly and atmospherically, the documentary scans what is left of the American frontier for remnants of the live customs and folkways of the area centered on the area between Utah and California. These pockets are leathery holdouts against oblivion or progress.

title: Jews Whose Tradition Includes Stuffed Grape Leaves at the Seder

Seders, no matter where they take place, are more or less the same, with matzoh replacing leavened bread as a reminder of the hasty departure from Egypt, when there was no time to allow bread to rise.

title: Film: 'Book of Numbers':St. Jacques Focuses on Southern Town The Cast
description: For reasons I can only guess at, "Book of Numbers" seems a lovely title for a movie. And neither the title, nor its quality, is wasted on Raymond St. Jacques's film about the adventures of two benevolent entrepreneurs who bring the numbers game to the grateful black population of El Dorado, Ark., sometime in the nineteen-thirties.Before their story is over, the younger man finds a sense of purpose and a marvelous girl, the older finds the means to an act of heroism he had never imagined, and El Dorado finds a whole new interest in such simple pleasures as learning the number of the hymn the pastor wants them to sing in church on Sunday.This is a lot to expect from the numbers game, and "Book of Numbers" doesn't expect it with too much seriousness. The film has all the standard accouterments of crime melodrama, including real danger and real death. But its spirit comes mainly from its musicbackground music, blues and spirituals, dance tunesrather than from the requirements of melodramatic plotting. That may be why it moves with such efficiency and agility (there is almost nothing wasted in its mere 80 minutes of running time), why it spends no energy on examining profundities where none exist, why the faults of some parts never really threaten the success of the whole.I don't mean to make "Book of Numbers" sound like a perfect movie, which it surely isn't. But it does seem an uncommonly well-balanced movie, intelligently directed, very cleverly edited (by Irv Rosenblum), with an air of real enjoyment in what it is about.The characters are all stereotypes of greater or lesser intricacy  which is what they ought to be. The situations are fairly predictable, though no less exciting for all that. And life itself, as the movie sees it, is just enough show-biz so that cardboard characters can run through it as it were on railroad tracksand still maintain the illusion of exceptional grace and freedom.The cast, headed by Mr. St. Jacques (the numbers chief), Philip Thomas (his protg), and Freda Payne (the girl) is expert and very attractive. Sometimes they seem to be having more fun with their material than the screenplay strictly allowsan agreeable kind of excess. In a supporting role, Hope Clarke plays a knowing charmer with the wonderful name of Pigmeat Goins and she is so outrageously good that if I had to see the movie again, she would be reason enough."Book of Numbers" opened yesterday at the DeMille Theater.
