title: CRUSADERS GAIN SWEEP OF SERIES
GOING OUT Guide
description: TRIPLE PLAY The Pierpont Morgan Library, 33 East 36th Street (6850008) is an Instant, beautiful journey to yesteryear, when the rich lived in mansions and arts and letters were their hobby and their bricabrac. This elegant house, once a Morgan home, shelters one of the greatest collections of the written word, and it is open, free, to the public. There are three striking exhibitions now on view, through May 2. One, occupying an entire room, is The Classics Revived, which construes the word classics in its classic sense, the great Greek and Latin works. Here are papyrus fragments from the first to sixth centuries, precious shreds of an Aristophanes comedy, of the Iliad, of the fables of Babrius. The exhibition also contains ancient manuscripts and early books, thus tracing the classics from earliest writing to first printings, and it is a handsome show. In the main lobby, welllighted panels show The Life of St. Edmund, one of the most important Romanesque manuscripts in the collection. Finally toward the rear of the house is a spread of recent acquisitions, that is, of old things recently come by. It is an assortment of letters,scripts, prints, drawings and music manuscripts. The names involved are such as George Washington, Lord Cornwallis (his official amnesty proclamation to the American rebels), Charles Dickens, Herman Hesse, Niccolo Machiavelli, Edgar Allan Poe.

title: Armco Forms Foreign Unit
description: The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday formation Df a whollyowned foreign trading subsidiary, Armco International, Inc. The chief aim of the company will be to develop trade opportunities between it and the Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries.

title: STANFORD U. RAISES $101MILLION IN YEAR
description: After just one year of trying, Stanford University has raised more than onethird of its $300million fund drive goal.

title: COLONELS DEFEAT COUGARS, 113103
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 11 (AP)Wendell Ladner led a late surge as the Kentucky Colonels outscored the Carolina Cougars, 248, in the last 6 minutes 20 seconds for a 113103 victory tonight.

title: Bruins Thud Hits Waltham
description: WALTHAM, Mass., April 11 (UPI)A sign of the time: For several months Waltham schoolboys have been using an outdoor basketball court as a street hockey ring. But the Boston Bruins were eliminated from the Stanley Cup playoffs last night. And today, for the first time this year, the schoolboys were playing basketball on the court.

title: Grand Jury Says Laxity Led to Tombs Escape
description: A Manhattan grand jury reported yesterday that the escape last fall by seven from the Manhattan House of Detention never would have occurred if the guards had inspected the prison bars every night as they were supposed to.

title: Bennett Recaptures Lead In Texas Relays Decathlon
Javits, Not Rose, Initiated the Fusion Drive
description: The quest for a fusion candidate for Mayor was initiated by Senator Jacob K. Javits, not, as has been believed, by Alex Rose, the Liberal party leader, or by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Javits, Not Rose, Initiated the Fusion Drive
description: The quest for a fusion candidate for Mayor was initiated by Senator Jacob K. Javits, not, as has been believed, by Alex Rose, the Liberal party leader, or by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Sears Tower Fire Kills 4 Working in Elevator Shaft
description: CHICAGO, April 11 (AP)A flash fire swept today through the Sears Tower, destined to be the world's tallest building, killing four elevator mechanics as flames raced down an elevator shaft between th 42d and 33d floors of the skyscraper.

title: Picasso, Superstitious of Death, Left No Will, His Lawyer Says
description: MOUGINS, France, April 11 (UPI)Because of his superstition about death, Pablo Picasso did not make out a will his lawyer and friend Armand Antebi said today.

title: A Policeman Is Exonerated In Fatal Shooting of Youth
description: A grand jury in Queen yesterday exonerated a policeman who fatally shot a 17yearold boy he was attempting to arrest last month.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in EasternStandard Time

title: Personal Finance: Perils Lie in Pooling of Debts
description: Recently Joseph Smith began to think his bills were too much for him to handleBank Americard $1,063, Chemical Bank $868, First National City Bank $853, and Macy's $163. The total was almost $3,000.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 10 (AP)  Duane Bobick, Olympic heavyweight boxer, made his professional debut tonight, flooring Tommy Burns of Canada four times and stopping him at 2 minutes 59 seconds of the first round.

title: Mr. Nixon's Power Grab
description: On the same day that President Nixon made the reasonable and necessary proposal that he be given executive power to raise or reduce tariffs, his Attorney General made the unreasonable and absurd claim that all 2.5million Federal employes could be directed by the President not to testify before Congress. There could hardly be a better illustration of how the need for strong executive government, which no one can dispute, can be perverted into an open grab for imperial powers

title: 184 TRUCKS REACH CAMBODIA CAPITAL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 11  A large convoy of supply trucks arrived here this afternoon, the fir* to make its way from the sea past Communist positions in three weeks, but a senior figure in the Government took issue with reports that Phnom Penh had been under siege.

title: College, School Results BASEBALL
JOHN FENTON, 66, A TIMES REPORTER
description: LAWRENCE, Mass., April 11 John H. Fenton, who served as Boston correspondent of The New York Times from 1947 until he retired in 1970, died this evening, apparently of a heart attack, at the Lawrence General Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Winthrop, a Boston suburb.

title: New Haven's Cosmopolitan To Enter Service Monday
description: The first of the longawaited and much delayed Cosmopolitan commuter cars for the New Haven branch of the Penn Central are expected to go into service Monday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: What Not to Wear For Haute Cuisine
description: At La Cede Basque, Henriette Spatter puts her foot down. Pants are pants, she says, and how can you say, You, madame, are chic to one woman wearing them and You, madame, are not chic to another, even if her pants are jeans?

title: Test for Speaker Albert
description: The Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives is about to meet a severe test. Last year the House was prevented by a technicality from even having the opportunity to vote on an amendment to the highway bill which would have allowed cities to divert Highway Trust funds to the needs of local mass transit. There is a strong possibility that the same sort of maneuver will be tried this year. But it will not succeed if Speaker. Carl Albert and his top lieutenants do not want it to succeed.

title: ExYanks Golf Pupils
description: Jerry Volpe, golf pro at Crystal Lago in Pompano Beach, Fla., has had as golf pupils three former Yankee starsMickey Mantle, Whitey Ford and Ralph Terry.

title: FERDINAND JELKE 3D
description: SARASOTA, Fla., April 11 Ferdinand Jelke 3d, a retired New York lawyer who had lived here since 1952, died yesterday at his home. He was 77 years old.

title: Watergate Grand Jury Hears Two Former White House Aides and Segretti
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Two former White House aides and a man they are said to have hired for a campaign of espionage and sabotage against the Democrats last year appeared before the Watergate grand jury today.

title: Inquiry Into Bases Asked
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, called today for a Congressional investigation of Defense Department decisions to shut down numerous military bases. He introduced legislation to set up a Senate commission. The action followed reports that among the bases to be closed or curtailed are the. Boston Navy Yard; Westover Air Force Base, Mass., and the Navy facilities at Newport, R. I.

title: Letters to the Editor Of Prisoners, Torture and the Antiwar Movement
description: To the Editor: Our fervent hope and prayer is that all the antiwar zealots, like George McGovern, Jane Fonda, Ramsey Clark and Dr. Benjamin Spock, have the courage and the conscience to listen carefully to the poignant stories being told by our returning P.O.W.'s about their incredibly cruel and brutal torture by their fiendish Communist captors.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
College Baseball
Cemetery Union Calls a Strike At Cypress Hills This Morning
Grain Futures Prices Register a Mixed Trend
description: Reports from Washington caused varied reactions in commodities markets yesterday. Some of the announcements sent prices down for a while but others caused them to rise. On the Chicago Board of Trade, prices of grains and soybeans were off considerably early in the day because of an estimate by the Department of Agriculture that the Soviet Union probably would import less grain this year that last.

title: Westinghouse Lags
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation achieved record firstquarter sales but net income fell below the 1972 peak, Donald C. Burnham, chairman. reported yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Although some members of the Maryland Department of Natural Resources admit that the state's decision to ban the use of lead shot for waterfowling by the opening of the 1974 hunting season has not endeared them to all sportsmen, it is clear that a similar nationwide restriction is not far away.

title: EINAR B. PAUST, 65, OF STANDARD OIL
description: Einar B. Paust, who retired last May 1 as general counsel of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), which on Nov. 1 became the Exxon Corporation, died on Tuesday in Southern Pines, N. C. He was 65 years old and lived in Englewood, N. J.

title: The Spalding Guide First Baseman
description: A decade or so ago, large Bob Allison played first base for the Minnesota Twins with a lumbering effectiveness. Not being a fancy Dan as a fielder, he was in the lineup only because he could team up with Harmon Killebrew to supply the Twins with a twin home run threat. The Minnesotans were at the Yankee Stadium on this particular day and I was standing behind the batting cage when Allison sneaked up behind me and wrapped his arm around my throat. I was being muggedgently. Then he hissed into my ear, acting out his private joke to the end. How can you write such fairy tales? he asked, releasing his grip and not looking at all menacing. If anything, he looked puzzled as he added, You're just trying to make all first basemen looked bad, including me. You tell about George Sisler making plays at first base that were impossible. I refuse to believe that anyone could be that good. But Sisler was that good. In fact, he even was better.

title: May 22 Is Maritime Day
description: WASHINGTON, April 11(AP) President Nixon today proclaimed May 22 as National Maritime Day.

title: ELLSBERG TELLS OF SHIFT IN VIEWS
CANADIENS OUST SABRES IN SERIES
description: BUFFALO, April 12 (UPI) Murray Wilson scored one goal and assisted on another during a fourgoal firstperiod outburst tonight and led the Montreal Canadiens to a 42 victory over the Buffalo Sabres. The victory advanced the Canadians to the semifinals of the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ADDITIONAL BOOK ADVERTISING ON FACING PAGE

title: Nixon Given Peace Prize
description: BOSTON, April 12 (Ap) The Republican Middlesex Club of Massachusetts gave its first Lincoln Peace Prize last night to President Nixon, citing him for his vision of a generation of peace.

title: Major League Box Scores
Wood, Field and Stream
description: Bony fish, however sweet to the taste, are discouraging table fare, but there are ways of surmounting the problem.

title: BONN PARTY SPURNS ANTIU.S. POSITIONS
description: HANOVER, April 12With strong persuasion from Chancellor Willy Brandt, his Social Democratic party tonight rejected a number of resolutions critical of the United States or opposed to American policy

title: Bond Prices Show Limited Changes Despite Mills Talk
Crime Wave on City Buses Reported by Borough Chief Abrams
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx called yesterday for 700 more Transit Authority policemen to combat What he called a reign of terror on the city's buses.

title: Gloom Shrouds Equity Headquarters
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 Tomorrow will be Kitty Lucerno's last day of employment at the Equity Funding Corporation of America at 1900 Avenue of the Stars in Century City here.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
MeatandPotatoes CommissionerDesignate
description: Practically every Sunday at the Cawleys' in Floral Park, Queens, there is pot roast on the table. He's a meatandpotatoes man. What can I tell you? He's not a gourmet, said Jane Cawley talking yesterday in City Hall's Blue Room about her husband, Donald F. Cawley, chief of patrol, who wa s named the city's 30th Police Commissioner. Chief Cawley's 22year career from patrolman to Commissioner is in a sense as prosaic as his Sunday dinner. He is ambitious, he studied incessantly, he worked hard. But in a department whose strength now is 29,700 men and women, it takes more than brains and energy to emerge from the mass of blue.

title: Miss Goolagong Advances With Victory in Miami Beach
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 12 (AP) Evonne Goolagong of Australia advanced to the semifinals today of the $20,000 Miami Beach tennis tournament with a 64, 62 victory over Isabel Fernandez of Colombia.

title: Mackell Reflects SmallTown Aura of Queens
A $930Million Highway Bill is Adopted by the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The Senate passed today a twoyear $930million Federal highway safety authorization bill, which was more than the White House wanted but far less than had been authorized in recent years.

title: Voter Rule Eased in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., April 12 (AP)  The residency requirement for voter registration in elections in Maine has been reduced to nine days by a state Supreme Court ruling. Maine's highest tribunal disapproved today a proposed constitutional amendment that would have set the residency requirement for voters at 30 days. Up to now Maine citizens thad to reside in the state for six months and in a community for 90 days before registering.

title: Poor Adoptive Parents Will Get Aid
description: TRENTON, April 12Governor Cahill signed legislation today that will provide up to $960 a year in direct aid to poor families for each foster child they adopt.

title: Mrs. King, Mrs. Court Win At Indoor Championship
description: QUINCY, Mass., April 12 Mrs. Billie Jean King and Mrs. Margaret Court moved toward a confrontation with victories today at the Virginia Slims national indoor championships in Quincy, Mass.

title: HAIG GIVES NIXON INDOCHINA REPORT; CRISIS DISCOUNTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 Gen. Alexander M. Haig, Jr., just back from a special mission to Southeast Asia, reported to President Nixon this afternoon on the military situation in Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam.

title: Cinematheque Planned Under the Queensboro
RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER HAWKS, 41, WITH LATE SURGE
description: CHICAGO, April 12After a tiebreaking goal by Vic Hadfield early in the third period, the New York Rangers most important contributor in a 41 victory, over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight in the opener of their Stanley Cup semifinal series, was a skatesharpener, Jim Young, the assistant trainer.

title: Australia Protests to China On Tests in the Atmosphere
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 12 Australia has protested to Peking against China's nuclear tests in the atmosphere, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Five New Jersey peace activists, all in their 20's, were released yesterday on $7,500 bond each in York, Pa., for a May 7 hearing on charges of conspiracy and malicious mischief to railroads.

title: Cost of Centralization Is a FactorMellon Registers Rise
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, the fifth big New York City banking concern to report its firstquarter results, was the first to show a decline in earnings.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DENTON, Tex., April 12 (UPI)Carl Babcock, the 34yearold North Texas State University track coach, died in the wreckage of his automobile early this morning on a highway four miles north of here.

title: H.E.W TO SOFTEN SOCIAL CARE CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is prepared to make concessions to critics of proposed new rules controlling Federal funding of such social services as day care for children and aid to the elderly and mentally disturbed.

title: King Jazz Goes Home To Canal St.
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 12  Two of the world's greatest clarinetists, Benny Goodman and Pete Fountain, began the fourth annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival that opened Tuesday with music that will rival the hot Creole foods to be served during the week.

title: AGNEW RELAXES ATTACK ON MEDIA
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Vice President Agnew, the Nixon Administration's most outspoken critic of the news media, said today that media fears of threats to their freedom were fictional.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to hold a special meeting within two weeks to discuss the competency of the top management of the agency, which operates the city's 19 municipal hospitals.

title: IMPASSE RETURNS AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., April 12  The situation at Wounded Knee reached a new impasse today, one week after a general peace agreement to end the siege and occupation was signed, and there was no solution in sight.

title: RULING ON WELFARE IN STAMFORD UPHELD
description: The United States Court of Appeals has upheld a Connecticut Federal judge's rulings th Stamford may not require one year of residence for welfare recipients.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press.

title: GRAIN PRICES UP; SOYBEANS CHB
description: Grain futures prices, which closed mixed Wednesday, rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, joining an advance in soybeans and soybean meal futures. The last two rose the daily limit of 15 cents a bushel for soybeans and $5 a ton for soybean meal in the nearby contracts.

title: A Bus Crime Wave Reported by Abrams
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx called yesterday for 700 more Transit Authority policemen to combat what he called a reign of terror on the city's buses.

title: $4.60 TRAFFIC COP SCORES BY A HEAD
description: Traffic Cop held off a spirited bid by Whitey II at the close to take the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday by a head.

title: JUDGE WON'T SEAL M'CORD TESTIMONY
description: WASHINGTON, April 12A Federal judge rejected today a request by Senate investigators to keep secret further pretrial testimony by James W. McCord Jr., one of those convicted in the Watergate conspiracy.

title: Mr. Wagner Says No
description: In his twelve years as Mayor, Robert F. Wagner was never a ball of fire, when it came to decisions. But even by his own standard of not making up his mind until the last possible moment, Mr. Wagner outdid Hamlet in soulsearching on whether to seek a new lease on City Hall November. Now the answer is out: No.

title: STARS TOP PACERS IN OPENER, 124107
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 12 (AP)The Utah Stars with Willie Wise and Zelmo Beaty leading the way, pushed open a tight game in the fourth quarter tonight to defeat the Indiana Pacers, 124107, in the first game of their American Basketball Association Western Ddvision title playoff series.

title: Bridge: Calls for Divergent Aptitudes Making Impossible Contracts
description: A reputation for making impossible contracts is a mixed blessing: it implies remarkable skill in card play, but a tendency to overoptimism in the bidding. Those who rarely reach such contracts do not have sufficient opportunities for memorable successes.

title: Turkey's Crisis Eases
description: With the election of a respected Senator, Fahrl Koruturk, as President by the Grand National Assembly, Turkey seems to have surmounted one of its worst crises since the founding of the republic. At a time of tension and instability in the eastern Mediterranean, their allies share with the Turks a great sense of relief at the breaking of a dangerous monthlong deadlock between political leaders and the armed forces.

title: Television
Metropolitan Briefs
description: A chase that began after a woman was mugged on a Brooklyn street ended with the death of one suspect and the capture of two others after an exchange of gunfire. The police said they had stepped up patrols in the area Sheepshead Bayfollowing a rash of muggings. . . In Prospect Park, Patrolman Joseph Cianfrone commandeered a bicycle to pursue and capture a suspect who fled on foot from an allegedly stolen car. The policeman suffered a fractured hand in the course of the capture of the suspect, identified as Brian Hammerstein, 16 years old, of 411 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn,. . . . A nineyear sentence and a $30,000 fine were meted out in Federal court to a reputed underworld figure, John (Johnny Dio) Dioguardi, as a result of his conviction in January in a mail fraud case.

title: State Seeking Right To Pay Obligations To Private Schools
description: TRENTON, April 12, (UPI) The State of New Jersey said today it was seeking permission in Federal Court to fulfill its obligations under a $19.5million program of aid to private and parochial schools that was declared unconstitutional.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES CREDITBIAS BAN
description: TRENTON, April 12Citing evidence that women are better credit risks than men, the Assembly passed without dissent today a bill prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex or marital status in extending credit or granting bank loans

title: S.E.C. CHIEF MEETS GOVERNORS OF AMEX
description: G. Bradford Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, met with governors of the American Stock Exchange yesterday at a getacquainted luncheon at the Amex.

title: A.E.C. APPROVES L.I. ATOM PLANT
description: SHOREHAM, L. I., April 12  The Atomic Energy Commission gave its approval today for the Long Island Lighting Company to begin construction of its 820megawatt nuclear power, plant here, five year after the utility filed its application.

title: Earlier Prosecutors Accused
description: Thomas J. Mackell of Queens is the first District Attorney ever indicted in New York City, according to legal historians. But he is hardly the first prosecutor in the five boroughs to get in trouble with the law.

title: Screen
Expo Opener Today Put Off
description: MONTREAL, April 12 (UPI) The Montreal Expos today postponed for one day their home opener against the Pittsburgh Pirates because of bad weather and field conditions. The club said the game scheduled for tomorrow would be played Saturday.

title: Chief Attorney of Ellsberg Ill; Trial Postponed Until Monday
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's testimony in the Pentagon papers trial was suspended today because of the illness of his chief attorney, Leonard B. Boudin, and will not begin again until Monday morning.

title: 2d Meat Boycott Set For First Week in May
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 (AP)A second weeklong meat boycott to protest still outrageous prices has been scheduled for April 30May 6, June Donavan, chairman of Fight Inflation Together, announced today.

title: Let'
description: WASHINGTONIf you listen to all the arguments and threats between the White House and the Congress these days, you might think this town was hellbent for a constitutional crash, but that's not exactly the way it is.

title: Retail Sales Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week, were an estimated $883million, up 17 per cent from the yearearlier $755million. Total retail store sales were about $9.25billion, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $8.11billion.

title: Free Courses for P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)  George Washington University has offered free courses to any prisoner of war returning from Vietnam who wants to study for a degree in the offcampus program sponsored by the College of General Studies.

title: News Shield Law Barred
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 (UPI)The City Council voted 12 to 0 yesterday not to support proposed state and Federal shield laws for newsmen, saying it was none of the city's business.

title: Proposed Tender Ruling Is Withdrawn by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 127The Securities and Exchange Commission withdrew today a proposed rule that would have prevented a payment of solicitation fees in stock tender and exchange offers to affiliated brokers of institutional investors tending the shares.

title: Saigon and Vietcong Aides Meet and Disagree in Paris
description: PARIS, April 12 (AP)Ministers of the Saigon Government and the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government met today for the sixth time to try to agree on an agenda for their political talks. But again they failed to make any progress.

title: Chile and Peru Carrying Out Wide and Radically Different Land Reforms
description: HUANCAYO, Peru, April 9  The two most extensive agrarian reforms in the modern history of South America are taking place in Chile and Peru with radically different approaches and results.

title: REYNOLDS TO REVIVE ALUMINUM POTLINE
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it had taken initial steps to reactivate a potline at its Listerhill, Ala., aluminum reduction plant.

title: G.O.P. Aide Heard In Inquiry in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 12  William B. Colsey 3d, reputedly a key figure under investigation by the state and the Federal Government in the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign testified before a state grand jury here today.

title: DNRETURNED G.I.'S ARE FEARED DEAD
3 Nations Evacuate Dependents From Missions in Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 12The British, Australian. and Japanese Embassies here evacuated the wives and children of their diplomats today, partly for security reasons but mainly because of discomforts caused by a serious shortage of electricity in the city.

title: MONEY MARKETS SHOW FIRM TREND Most Interest Rates Drop, but Other Reserve Figures Indicate Tighter Credit
description: Money  market conditions, which were steadily firm in March, continued that way in early April, Federal Reserve statistics released yesterday indicated.

title: Pollution Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The way of the middleoftheroader, even as that of the transgressor, is often hard. Ask William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, who is trying to walk the straight and narrow between the demands of the auto industry on one side and the environmentalists on the other. Yesterday he gave the auto industry an extra year, until 1976, to meet the 1975 emission standards for carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons, and set national interim standards that, he said, could be met without the catalytic converter on which the United States companies have settled to control these pollutants. This is what the industry had asked him to do.

title: HAIG GIVES NIXON INDOCHINA REPORT; CRISIS DISCOUNTED
Bill Scores G.I. Numbers
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)  Two Representatives introduced legislation today to outlaw military discharge numbers that they said placed homosexuals and alcoholics, for example, in the same category. Edward I. Koch, Democrat of Manhattan, and Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said that the effect of the numbers on discharge documents was to prejudice employers against certain veterans seeking jobs.

title: Market Place: Some Back Role Of the Specialist
description: Many a small investor believes that he ordinarily gets taken to the cleaners when he buys or sells a listed stock.

title: Cambodia: Tunnel at the End of the Light
description: WASHINGTONAs the last U.S. soldier left Vietnam, most Americans believed and hoped that the event signaled the end of our military involvement in the longest, costliest and most divisive war in our history.

title: Cut in U.S. Aid May Force Upstate Schools Early Close
description: HIGHLAND FALLS, N. Y., April 12 (AP)  A $300,000 cutback in Federal aid has prompted the Highland Falls Board of Education to consider closing schools two months early next school year, the board president, Ronald Cornwall, said yesterday.

title: Heavily Guarded QE2 Prepares to Sail to Israel
description: LONDON, April 11The liner Queen Elizabeth 2 will be a virtual citadel when she makes a fiveday cruise to Israel next week, a spokesman for the Cunard Line said today.

title: Roundup: Jenkins, Cold Fail to Cool Off Pirates
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates paid attention to neither the freezing weather In Three Rivers Stadium last night nor the talented pitching of Chicago's Ferguson Jenkins.

title: AL HIRSHBERG DIES; EXSPORTSWRITER, 63
description: SARASOTA, Fla., April 12 Al Hirshberg, a former Boston sportswriter and an author, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Sarasota Memorial Hospital yesterday. He was 63 years old and lived on Longboat Key.

title: LIBERALS DECIDE ON BLUMENTHAL FOR MAYOR'S RACE
description: Liberal party leaders selected Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal last night to replace Robert F. Wagner as their candidate for Mayor.

title: H. Chandlee Turner Jr., Leader Of Construction Firm, Is Dead
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 12  H. Chandlee Turner Jr., chairman of the executive committee of the Turner Construction Company, died today in Greenwich Hospital from the effects of a stroke he suffered April 3. He was 70 years old and lived here.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES PRICE ROLLBACKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The House Democratic leadership reversed itself today and pushed through the Rules Committee legislation that would roll back prices, rents and some interest rates.

title: Opera: L'Incoronazione di Poppea
description: Monteverdi was a genius who could express almost anything in music, and in his 330yearold masterpiece, L'Incoronazione di Poppea, he chose to express lustnot only the kind now euphemistically called love or sex, but the lust for position and power. There are other aspects to the score, too, but good old lust is what the Opera Society of Washington's production had on its mind.

title: NIXON ASKS RULES ON JOBLESS PAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  President Nixon asked Congress today to set Federal standards for unemployment compensation and to extend coverage to 635,000 farm workers.

title: Married at 10, Deserted at 15, She Lives in Delhi Street
description: NEW DELHI, April 12  She sits on a shady corner of Connaught Place, carefully folding the betel leaves each morning and selling them to the laborers, shopkeepers and taxi drivers who surge around the center of the city.

title: Red Smith
description: The first game I ever pitched in organized, ball,' said Joseph T. Cascarella, was in Pittsfield, Mas., in the Eastern League, Billy Whitman, the manager, had seen me work on the sandlots in Philadelphia and condeived the peculiar notion that I had a future. It was opening day, around April 18 or 20. There was a parade through town with the players in uniform in open cars, and Admiral Byrd had it better in the Antarctic. Throwing into the wind, I had a curve that broke off likewell, Bob Feller or Tommy Bridges or Whitey Ford should have had a curve like it. I went 10 innings with snow falling the last three or four innings, and beat Albany by something like 43. During the next week I was gracious enough to let two or three people say hello to me. That was in 1927 and it was neither the first nor the last time that baseball was played in weather fit only for Malamutes and seals. Rainouts, freezeouts and now and then a snowfall, managers worrying because the pitchers can't work in rotation, batters complaining that their timing is offthis is how it is at the start of the season.

title: 2 INTRUDERS BURN BROOKLYN WOMAN
description: A 42yearold woman was critically burned early yesterday by two youths who forced their way into her apartment in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: Time to Speak Out
MAJOR PURGE VICTIM REAPPEARS IN PEKING
description: PEKING, April 12 (Agence FrancePresse)  The former secretary general of the Chinese Communist party, Teng Hsiaoping, purged in the Cultural Revolution after being heavily criticized, has been rehabilitated and named a Deputy Premier.

title: NIXON MOVE URGED ON A MY LAI ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, April 12A civilian lawyer who aided in the Army's investigation of the My Lai 4 massacre said today that the pending retirement of Lieut. Gen. William R. Peers, who headed the inquiry, was simply incredible. He termed it a move adding to the impression that the Army was not really serious about punishing those responsible.

title: Senate Backs Memorial To Vietnam Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)The Senate approved by voice vote today a resolution to authorize a memorial in Washington to Vietnam war veterans.

title: Kennedy Says Tax Laws Give Welfare to Rich
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the present tax laws bestowed a Government welfare payment averaging $720,448 a year on each of the nation's 3,000 families with incomes of more than $1million.

title: To Kids, a Yo Yo Is Part of Life; For Tom McCoy, It's a Living
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va.  When Tom McCoy confesses what he does for a living, people sometimes look at him a little suspiciously, as if he is somehow violating the unwritten law that defines honest work.

title: FARMERS REJECT BLAME ON PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Farmers put on a display of beef and an array of speakers here today in a counterattack against boycotters and backers of a bill in Congress to roll back prices.

title: Amex Prices Mixed in Slow Trading
description: After four consecutive sessions of advances, prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished mixed yesterday in slover trading.

title: CITY POSTPONES PARK FUND DEAL
description: The Board of Estimate deferred action at the last moment yesterday on an unusual proposal that would grant builders extra bulk rights in return for cash contributions to a special fund for the improvement of parks and other public areas.

title: Midair Collision Kills.16
description: Sixteen men were killed yesterday when a space agency flying laboratory and a Navy antisubmarine patrol plane collided in midair in California. Page 78.

title: AN OPERA IN TURIN STAGED BY CALLAS
description: TURIN, ItalyThirtyseven years after the fire that destroyed it, on Feb. 8, 1936, Turin's Teatro Regio reopened this week. The importance of the occasion was marked by the presence of the President of Italy, Giovanni Leone, with his wife, Vittoria, in the central, box of the elegant red and white oval auditorium, and by some minor demonstrations, in the square before the theater, by students protesting the elegance of the evening.

title: The Pop Life
description: Threequarters of the Beatles, defunct since 1970, were out in Los Angeles recently, and the question many people in the recording industry asked was: Will the four of them soon be playing and singing together again?

title: Occidental Hits Peruvian Oil
description: LIMA, Peru, April 12 (UPI) The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today it has struck oil on the second well it has drilled in jungle terrain under contract with PetroPeru. Production of the well in the Peruvian northeast was estimated. at 3,931 barrels a day. Drilling ranged from 11,000 to 13,000 feet. PetroPeru has also struck oil in the area in its drillings and is planning construction of a 625mile pipeline to carry the oil to the coast of Piura, crossing the Andes into northern Peru.

title: College Baseball
Equity Financing
The Basis for Pacific Bases
description: MANILAThe United States and the Philippines are now approaching the final phase of renegotiating an American base agreement here designed to assure U.S. support of mobile forces in the western Pacific after withdrawal from Indochina and Okinawa's reversion to Japan. A joint working group from both nations has completed about 90 per cent of a proposed draft.

title: LIBERALS DECIDE ON BLUMENTHAL FOR MAYOR'S RACE
AUTHOR DENIES BEING CAPTIVE OF VIETCONG
description: Frances FitzGerald, in accepting a National Book Award last night, said reports that she had been a prisoner of the Vietcong were greatly exaggerated.

title: American Can and Time Also AdvanceU.A.L. Earnings Decline
description: Firstquarter earnings reports yesterday were led by PPG Industries, Inc., with a 28 per cent rise in profits; the American Can Company, whose net was up 91.5 percent; Time Inc., whose profit rose 25 per cent, and CPC International, Inc., whose earnings were up 9.9 per cent. The earnings all set records.

title: A Basic Computer Patent At Sperry Rand Annulled
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 12 (AP)  A Federal judge has ruled that a basic computer patent held by the Sperry Rand Corporation is invalid and that Honeywell, Inc., need not pay royalties for it, a spokesman for Sperry confirmed today.

title: NIXON ASKS RULES ON JOBLESS PAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  President Nixon asked Congress today to set Federal standards for unemployment compensation and to extend coverage to 635,000 farm workers.

title: Cawley, Chief of Patrol, Named to Murphy Post
description: Donald F. Cawley, chief of patrol, was named Police Commissioner yesterday to succeed Patrick V. Murphy, and he immediately vowed to wage war on street crime, continue the efforts to elevate the professionalism of the department and root out any cancers of corruption that exist.

title: College, School Results
Exhibitor of Deep Throat Is Fined $100,000
description: The principal exhibitor here of the film Deep Throat was fined $100,000 by Criminal Court Judge Joel T. Tyler on charges of promoting obscenity.

title: Truce Team Says Downed Copters Were Off Course
description: HUE, South Vietnam, April 12  The two trucesupervision helicopters that were downed by the Vietcong near the Laos border last week had strayed more than 15 miles from their prearranged course, a team of investigators who returned from the crash site reported today. The investigators represented the International Commission of Control and Supervision.

title: Cawley, Chief of Patrol, Named to Murphy Post
description: Donald F. Cawley, chief of patrol, was named Police Commissioner yesterday to succeed Patrick V. Murphy, and he immediately vowed to wage war on street crime, continue the efforts to elevate the professionalism of the department and root out any cancers of corruption that exist.

title: Midair Collision Kills 16
description: Sixteen men were killed yesterday when a space agency flying laboratory and a Navy antisubmarine patrol plane collided in midair in California. Page 78.

title: How Tofa, a Child From Bangladesh, Found a Home in Oregon
description: LAKE OSWEGO, Ore.I had some ambiguous feelings about adopting Bangladesh child, David McCormick said, because it would make us the toast of the bleeding heart liberal circuit.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
U.S. Beef Production Is Up
description: CHICAGO, April 12  American farmers and ranchers produced 22.3 billion pounds of beef in 1972, an increase of 430 million pounds over 1971.

title: Nixon Names Former Aide To Fill a Nuclear Position
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 President Nixon nominated William E. Kriegsman of Bethesda, Md., today as a commissioner on the Atomic Eenrgy Commission, replacing James R. Schlesinger, who is now director of Central Intelligence.

title: Guggenheim Fellowships Underwrite 339 Projects
JAY E. CRANE DIES; OIL EXECUTIVE, 81
description: ORANGE, N. J., April 12 Jay E. Crane, a former director of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), died last evening at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Hurls Yankees 2d Consecutive TwoHitter
description: Steve Kline made it two shutouts in a row for the New York Yankee pitching staff yesterday by hurling it twohitter and defeating the Cleveland Indians, 50, before a paying crowd of 4,532, and 6,800 youngsters from the New Jersey Safety Patrol who got in free.

title: Chicago Tribune Names Stanton Cook as Publisher
description: CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) Stanton R. Cook, president of The Chicago Tribune, has been appointed publisher and elected chief executive officer of the company it was announced today.

title: Mills Urges Return to Phase 1 Controls
description: Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, urged yesterday a return to Phase 1 economic controls freeze and said he believed President Nixon would take such a step despite his abhorance of controls.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs EAST DIVISION
Exchange Cites Dirks for Equity Role
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday brought disciplinary charges of fraud against Raymond L. Dirks, the security analyst who gave his clients advance warning of the financial problems of the scandalridden Equity Funding Corporation of America.

title: A. &
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company said yesterday it was omitting its quarterly dividend for a second straight quarter. The last time it paid a dividend was two quarters ago, when the dividend was 20 cents a share.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 13, 1973

title: Oil Pipeline Study Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)Several Senators cosponsored a bill today calling for a study to find the best route for a pipeline to carry oil from Alaska to the lower 48 states. The bill would authorize a study by the National Science Foundation to compare alternate routes.

title: Retarded Youth Displays Its Fortitude
description: When George Foreman stuck out a friendly hand, the slackness around Otis Taylor's jaw disappeared in a grin of elation.

title: City Council Votes $75 for Uniforms To Auxiliary Police
ITALIAN LEADER WINS VOTES OF CONFIDENCE
description: ROME, April 12  Premier Giulio Andreotti demanded and won four votes of confidence in Parliament today as he fought for the survival of his 10monthold centrist Government.

title: Captured Papers Linked To Arab Arrests in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, April 12  Israeli security forces reported arresting a number of suspected Arab guerrillas in Israel and the occupied territories last night and today on the basis of documents described as having been seized Tuesday during the Israeli commando raid in Beirut.

title: Soviet and Occidental Oil In MultibillionDollar Deal
Swaziland's King Assumes Full Control
description: MBABANE, Swaziland, April 12  Swaziland's 73yearold King, Sobhuza II, announced today he had scrapped the Constitution and assumed personal power in this landlocked country in southern Africa.

title: SLAIN GUERRILLAS BURIED IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 Three Palestinian guerrilla leaders and the wife of one, all slain by Israeli commandos in a raid here Tuesday, were buried today in the Martyrs Cemetery, to which they were borne by the largest funeral procession in Beirut in three years.

title: A Pupil Busing Ban Called Step Back
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 Supporters of pupil busing charged today that a constitutional amendment to prohibit busing would result in resegregation Of the schools.

title: HOSPITAL MANAGERS FACING CITY INQUIRY
description: The board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to review the competency of the top management of the $800million quasiautonomous agency that runs the city's 19 municipal hospitals.

title: Residents Protest Felling of Trees to Gain Sewers
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 12A group of residents on Shippan Point, a sedate residential section here jutting into Long Island Sound, are protesting to City Hall over treecutting program ordered to make way for a sewer project.

title: ANDRE BING, OFFICER OF TRIBUNE IN PARIS
description: PARIS, April 12  Andre Bing, former general manager of The International Herald Tribune and a hero of the French resistance during World War II, died today in a hospital here. He was 62 years old and lived in La Varenne.

title: Acute Food Shortage Found Around Globe
description: ROME, April 12Experts of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today that a series of bad harvests in many parts of the worldcaused mainly by severe droughtsand other unfavorable factors had resulted in acute food shortages.

title: A Mixed Community Planned for Lake Candlewood
description: HARTFORD, April 12A nonprofit communitydevelopment organization proposed today to join with private business in building a $50million community of 8,000 people on the exclusive western shore of Lake Candlewood.

title: BigStore Retailing Here In Downturn for March
description: Bigstore retailing in March ran into its tightest month in more than a year following a strong February performance. But most of the sales declines may have been caused by this year's later Easter, which comes three weeks after it did in 1972.

title: Midair Collision Near Coast Base Kills 16
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif., April 12 (UPI)A space agency research jet and a Navy antisubmarine patrol plane collided in the air today and plunged in flames onto a golf course, killing 16 men.

title: British Troops Kill A Gunman in Ulster And Capture Three
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 12 (UPI)British soldiers killed an Irish Republican Army gunman and captured three others in a running battle in Belfast's Lower Falls area tonight, the British Army said.

title: DR. DONALD W. BRADEEN
description: CINCINNATI, April 12Dr. Donald W. Bradeen, an authority on Greek history and head of the department of classics at the University of Cincinnati, died of a heart attack at his home here last night. His age was 54.

title: Cards Lose, 21, In a Duel of Bean Balls
description: By JOSEPH DURSO

title: Bennett Captures Decathlon In Texas With 7,855 Points
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 12 (AP) Jeff Bennett won the United States Track and Field Federation decathlon today, amassing 7,855 points in the twoday event at the 46th Texas Relays. Bennett, who placed fourth in the Olympics, was most impressive with a pole vault of 16 feet.

title: Meatless Entrees In Weekend Meals
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Executive PrivilegeDevious Doctrine
description: WASHINGTON  The Fitzgerald case demonstrates the extreme evil that executive privilege can be in hiding relevant facts from the public in an Air Force conspiracy to destroy truthful witness.

title: BONNPRAGUE TALK ON TIES IS REOPENED
description: BONN, April 12 (AP)Talks between Czechoslovakia and West Germany designed to arrange for the opening of diplomatic relations between the two countries resumed today, with both governments indicating optimism after a 10month deadlock.

title: Senate Nutrition Panel to Focus On Perils of Being Overweight
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  After devoting tour years to the problems of the nation's hungry and malnourished, the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs turned its attention today to the estimated 30 per cent of the population who are overweight.

title: Negotiators Continue Talks At 3 Major Dailies in City
description: Negotiators for the city's major daily newspapers met again yesterday with the bargaining committee of Typographical Union No. S. Talks also continued between the papers and the Newspaper Guild.

title: TOKYO TAKES STEP TOWARD HANOI TIE
description: TOKYO, April 12The Japanese Government dispatched the Foreign Ministry's senior specialist on North Vietnam to Hanoi today in a major step toward establishing diplomatic relations between Tokyo and Hanoi.

title: MASSACHUSETTS MAN INDICTED IN SLAYING
description: BOSTON, April 12A Suffolk County grand jury indicted a Dorchester man yesterday for the murder of Ellen Reich of Hackensack, N. J., whose body was found in an abandoned tenement last November.

title: ...as Knicks Minutemen Dust Off Their Weapons
description: Should the Boston Celtics end their National Basketball Association Eastern Conference play off semifinal tonight in Atlanta, the final round of the fourofsevengame series with the Knicks would begin Sunday afternoon at the Boston Garden.

title: NEW JUDGE URGED IN CASE ON FRAUD
France, as Picasso Wished, Will Get His Collection of Other Artists Work
Navy Reported Planning $50Billion Building and Conversion Program Covering 271 Ships in Next 10 Years
description: The Navy plans a construction and conversion program covering 271 ships that will cost $50billion in the next 10 years, according to data collected by defense experts.

title: Jersey State College Uses TV to Cut Campus Crime
description: JERSEY CITY, April 12A new, $16,000 video system is helping to cut down crime at Jersey City State College, the first of New Jersey's eight state colleges to install such a system.

title: College, School Results
Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. (Television  Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Historian Tells Senators, Meeting on Executive Privilege, You Are the Superior Power
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Senators examining President Nixon's use of executive privilege were told today that they needed no new laws and no further hearings, only the gumption to assert their superior power under the Constitution.

title: Architecturally, A Promise in Use of Found Space
description: The Cinematheque will not be just for cinema buffsit will be for architecture buffs, who are often cinema buffs as well. And yet, at a time when cultural centers frequently emphasize marble and concrete over cultural contents, it will not be a building at all. It will be in found space under the Queensboro Bridge. Architecturally, this is a lot more exciting than it sounds. The space is a dramatic series of cathedrallike vaults and arched openings of landmark quality below the bridge structure at First Avenue between 59th and 60th Streets.

title: Brandt Clears the Air
description: By masterly leadership at Hanover, West German Chancellor Willy Brandt has routed the noisy leftist minority in the Social Democratic party and rededicated his Government to a policy of pragmatic reform at home and a foreign policy anchored in the Atlantic Alliance. As always, Mr. Brandt's manner was conciliatory; but his message was clear for the Young Socialist factions demanding massive nationalization of industry and West Germany's detachment from the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Victory Possible Tomorrow
description: BOSTON, April 12Coach Cotton Fitzsimmons of the Atlanta Hawks, a Southern gentleman to the core, complimented his hosts lavishly today before going home to plot their destruction.

title: SLAIN GUERRILLAS BURIED IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 Three Palestinian guerrilla leaders and the wife of one, all slain by Israeli commandos in a raid here Tuesday, were buried today in the Martyrs Cemetery, to which they were borne by the largest funeral procession in Beirut in three years.

title: Aaron Shoots 77, Quits
description: PENSACOLA, Fla. April 12 (AP)  Homero Blancas scored a fourunderpar 67 today for the firstround lead in the $150000 Monsanto open golf tournament and the new. Masters champion, Tommy Aaron, withdrew after a 77.

title: Health Agencies Plan No Aborted Fetus Research
description: BETHESDA, Md., April 12  More than 100 opponents of abortion attended a meeting at the National Institutes of Health here today to ask questions about the institutes policy on the use of aborted human fetuses for medical research.

title: EXXON PLANS TO CUT MIDWEST STATIONS
description: HOUSTON, April 12 (AP) The Exxon Corporation announced today that it planned to eliminate about a third of the service stations the Houstonbased company operates in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Wisconsin. The announcement said about 150 stations in the Midwest district where the company has less than 2 per cent of the market will be disposed of on a selective basis. A spokesman said continued operation of the stations was not economic.

title: D. W. CHAPMAN JR., VASSAR PROFESSOR
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., April 12  Dr. Dwight W. Chapman Jr., professor of psychology at Vassar College and chairman of the school's psychology department from 1952 to 1968, died here yesterday. His age was 67.

title: 105 Jews, Refused Exit Visas By Soviet, Appeal to Congress
description: MOSCOW, April 12  More than 100 Soviet Jews who have been refused exit visas to Israel appealed to the United States Congress in an open letter today not to be misled by an apparent lifting of high emigration taxes.

title: GEORGE Z. MASON
description: George Z. Mason, a former director of Camp Greylock for boys in Beckett, Mass., and an organizer and director of mutual funds, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Lenox Hill Hospital on Monday. He was 84 years old and lived at 315 East 58th Street.

title: STOCK PRICES SLIP IN BRISK TRADING
Books of The Times
description: Arthur K Bremer, the man who shot and crippled Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, is an odd example of what Hannah Arendt described as the banality of evil. Except for that single act, Bremer would seem to be only banal. In the diary that he kept while he was planning first to assassinate President Nixon and then Governor Wallace, we find little more than pathetic delusions of grandeur. Shooting a famous man was the only way he could think of to make a name for himself.

title: Going Out Guide
description: E PLURIBUS DUO Jascha Silberstein and Eve Queler are usually faces in the opera crowd, outstanding faces but still visages that show up en masse. He is principal cellist at the Metropolitan Opera and she conducts (Opera Orchestra of New York and, formerly, assistant baton wielder for the New York City Opera). But tonight at 8, the two will play hooky from their group living and perform, just the two of them, at Town Hall, 113West 43d Street (582.4536). He will stick to cello, Valle she will take to piano, because it would be pointless to shake a baton while ho solos. The program will be mostly nonoperatic, with such composers as Boccherini, Popper, Dvorak, Chopin. Three works, however, will be a bit tradelike, that is, Met opera origins. Admission; $5.

title: Arthur Freed, Screen Producer Who Won 2 Oscars, Dead at 78
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 12 (AP) Arthur Freed, the film producer who won Academy Awards for the musicals An American in Paris (1951), and Gigi (1958), died today of a heart attack. He was 78 years old and had retired several years ago.

title: Robert McFadden Of The Times Wins Press Club Award
description: Robert D. McFadden, a rewrite man for The New York Times, was named yesterday as the winner of the annual Byline Award of the New York Press Club for the best example of spot news writing on deadline.

title: G.O.P. AIDE HEARD IN JERSEY INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, April 12  William B. Colsey 3d, reputedly a key figure under investigation by the state and the Federal Government in financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign, testified before a state grand jury here today.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
TV: WNET Starting a Film Series
description: With public television running noticeably short of original material, it should be noted that a new eightpart series is beginning this week on the dollartight network. It's called The Humanities Film Forum, and it is produced by station KCET in Los Angeles. It is also made possible by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities, which is the most significant fact about the project.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: A Change of Hearts: Plays, Films and Other Dramatic Works, 19511971, by Kenneth Koch (Random House, $6.95).

title: Fabric Sculpture With Something to Say
Jersey P.O.W. Promoted
description: PHOENIXVJLLE, Pa., April 12 (UPI)Army Maj. Floyd J. Thompson, of New Milford, N. J., the longestheld military prisoner of war in United States history, was promoted today to lieutenant colonel in a ceremony at Valley Forge General Hospital.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)Henry Kearns, chairman of the United States ExportImport Bank, today forecast that the United States would realize a surplus in its trade balance around July or August. He said at a news conference following completion of a 12nation, sixandahalfweek tour that we can solve our balanceoftrade problems and ultimately our balanceofpayments problems if we use the tools that are at hand. bank now has a ceiling of $20billion.

title: BBA Gets Down to Basics of Rock and Stays There
description: Rock music suffers much from people's adding parts on to the basic structure and giving it a neat name tagpsychedelic rock, acid rock, etc. Therefore it is a pleasure to report a concert where a group has gone back to basics.

title: NIXON AIDES OFF FOR ENERGY TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Three of President Nixon's senior energy advisers, including Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz, flew to the Bahamas today for an offtherecord conference at an exclusive club with 80 top executives from oil, natural gas; mining and electric power companies.

title: Governor Modifies Plan On Stiffer Drug Penalties
description: ALBANY, April 12Governor Rockefeller today proposed a significantly modified version of his stringent proposals for dealing with traffickers in dangerous drugs. The new version includes mandatory minimum prison sentences, a limited form of plea bargaining and a system of mandatory life sentences that would permit parole but require lifetime supervision of the parolee.

title: Chavez Warns of Boycott If Grape Pacts Are Shifted
Commodity Price Index Up 0.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 152.2 from 151.6 last week.

title: A Standby of Restrained French Dining
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon formally announced the nomination of William H. Sullivan, the State Department's top Southeast Asia expert, as Ambassador to the Philippines. The White House also said that Robert J. McCloskey, for many years the chief press spokesman at the State Department, had been nominated as Ambassador to Cyprus. The nominations, which went to the Senate for confirmation, had been expected for some time. The present Ambassador to Cyprus, David H. Popper, is returning to Washington as Assistant Secretary of State for international organization affairs. Henry A. Byroade, the Ambassador to the Philippines, is retiring.

title: COSMOS 533 MARKS SOVIET ANNIVERSARY
description: MOSCOW, April 12The Soviet Union marked Astronautics Day today by sending up the 553d satellite in its Cosmos series, apparently an electronic monitoring craft.

Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: DECISION ON O.E.O. STIRS CONFUSION
description: There was confusion in antipoverty offices yesterday in the wake of a Federal judge's decision that stops President Nixon from going ahead with his plan to dismantle the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: Stennis Backs WarPower Limits, but Would Exclude Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, called today for the adoption of warpowers legislation that be said would prevent the President from reintroducing military forces into Vietnam without Congressional consent.

title: NETWORKS STRUCK BY WRITERS GUILD
description: The Writers Guild of America went on strike at 12:01 A. M. yesterday against television network live and videotaped entertainment programs, such as soap operas and talk shows.

title: 3 OF TERROR GROUP DIE IN YUGOSLAVIA
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 12  Yugoslavia disclosed today that three migrs captured last summery during gun battles after they had infiltrated from Austria had been tried on counterrevolutionary and other charges and put to death by firing squad.

title: INVENTORIES MAKE ANOTHER UPTURN
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Total business inventories continued to rise strongly in February, though the increase was less than the big jump in January, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Beirut Hotels Tell of 6 Israeli Guests
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 (UPI)  One of the hotel guests kept asking about the weather forecast because, he said, he wanted to go swimming. Another went to the seashore every night to fish. Another two were perfect English gentlemen.

description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens was arrested yesterday after his indictment on charges of blocking the prosecution of a $4million getrichquick scheme in which members of his staff had invested money.

title: WEAK FIRE SUPPORT ASCRIBED TO SAIGON
description: PHNOM PENH, April 12 The chief mate of a cargo vessel that got through a Communist ambush on the South Vietnamese side of the border and sailed up the Mekong River to Phnom Penh accuses the South Vietnamese armed forces of failing to provide promised protection.

description: Friday, April 13, 1973

title: France, as Picasso Wished, Will Get His Collection of Other Artists'
description: PARIS, April 12Pablo Picasso's second wife and his only legitimate son announced through Picasso's lawyer today that the artist's priceless private collection of works by other great modern painters would be given to France.

title: MeatlessDay Call Lacks the Response Of Week's Boycott
description: Despite calls by national boycott leaders for meatless Tuesdays and Thursdays, there was little indication here yesterday of the sort of intense shopper resistance to meat that characterized the widespread consumer rebellion last week.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST ORANGE, April 12Although the professional ice shows make their annual visits to New York, the performers the skating public is eager to see are the top amateurs who recently made headlines at the various international championships.

title: People and Business 3 Saudis Join Board of Aramco
description: With the Government of Saudi Arabia owning 25 per cent of the ArabianAmerican Oil Company since Jan. 1, it now has three representatives on the board of the petroleum corporation, Yesterday the three Saudis joined the 15 other directors of Aramco at its regular directors meeting.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: Advertising: Facts on Funerals
description: For the first time in its 90year history, the National Funeral Directors Association of the United States is running a national institutional advertising campaign. It is aimed at maintaining traditional practices and has, in short time, received considerable response from the public.

title: Consumer Unit Lists 7 Best Buy Menus; Total Cost $19.89
description: NEWARK, April 12The State Division of Consumer Affairs, which has been criticized in the past for having expensive tastes, shaved $2,69 off the price of its recommended dinners in Its list of seven best buy menus issued today.

title: Vicksburg Records Mississippi River At a 35Year High
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., April 12 (UPI)The Mississippi River swelled today to its highest level in 35 years, flooding miles of rich farmland and threatening many farmers with heavy crop losses.

title: Garelik Quits Mayoral Contest As Candidates File Petitions
description: In ostentatiously bulky bundies or in modest shopping bags, or briefcases candidates for public office carried their nominating petitions to the city Board of Elections yesterday.

title: People in Sports: The New Ryan Is as Fast as the Old One and a Great Deal Cooler
description: Nolan Ryan, who has an unhittable reputation when his fastball is under control, says he has learned to keep his composure under pressure and he is showing it in his first two starts for the California Angels. The former Mets' pitcher, who led the American League in strikeouts last season (329), is off to a quick start with 23 strikeouts and two complete game victories. I think I'm a lot better off than I was at this time last season, said Ryan after he defeated the Minnesota Twins, 41, Wednesday night. My mental makeup is much more advanced and I've learned to keep my composure.

title: Ponzi Game an Old One
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell is accused of covering up his office's involvement in a Ponzi scheme, one of the oldest confidence games around.

title: ASHE AND RIESSEN WIN IN CLEVELAND
description: CLEVELAND, April 12 (AP)  Topseeded Marty Riessen continued to march toward the final of the Cleveland Tennis Classic today, defeating Ross Case of Australia, 64, 75.

title: Miss Burfeindt a Shot Back
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 12 (AP)Kathy Whitworth and Jane Blalock, the favorites, got caught in water hazard confusion and Mrs. Murle Lindstrom Breer shot 68 for a onestroke firstround lead today in the $154,000 ColgateDinah Shore golf tournament.

title: Soviet and Occidental Oil In MultibillionDollar Deal
description: MOSCOW, April 12  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation signed the largest commercial agreement in the history of SovietAmerican trade todaya 20year, multibilliondollar chemicalfertilizer barter arrangement with the Soviet Government.

title: AMEX DISCIPLINES STOCK SPECIALIST
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that a disciplinary panel had found Leon F. Diodoardo, an Amex member, guilty of certain acts detrimental to the exchange.
