title: W. HAROLD ESSEX, 68, LED BROADCASTERS
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., April 12 (UPI)W. Harold Essex, president of the Triangle Broadcasting Corporation here and a past president of the National Association of Broadcasters, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: Quagmire Revisited
description: Twelve years ago President Kennedy dispatched a trusted military aide to Southeast Asia to assess a rapidly deteriorating military and political situation there. The recommendations brought back by Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor led to fateful steps into the quagmire from which this country has recently emerged, sadder but not necessarily wiser.

title: H.E.W. TO SOFTEN SOCIAL CARE CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is prepared to make concessions to critics of proposed new rules controlling Federal funding of such social services as day care for children and aid to the elderly and mentally disturbed.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: **Major Domo, 77 Kinderkamack Road, River Edge, N.J. (201) 4875045. Armenian food in the suburbs? Assuredly yes at the new Major Domo restaurant. Why? Because Arshag Tarpinian, the owner of Sayat Nova  a mecca for devotes of Armenian cuisine in Manhattan's Greenwich Village lives near River Edge and relishes a challenge.

title: Assembly Rejects Move To License Lay Analysts
description: ALBANY, April 12The Assembly today rejected an attempt to introduce state controls over a broad range of mental health counselors and therapists after opponents argued that the bill was a power grab that would have allowed psychologists with degrees to monopolize the field.

title: DEADHEAT PACER FACES LONG ODDS
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 12 If Fur Elise, who is coupled with Bootsie Barrett in tomorrow night's featured $25,000 Jones Beach pacing series final at Roosevelt Raceway, finishes in a dead heat for first place, she will earn a place in the record books that may never be matched.

title: Phnom Penh Festively Marks New Year Amid Communist BuildUp
College Baseball
Penn Central Moves To Curb Vandalism On Yonkers Trains
description: YONKERS, April 13 With Easter vacation next week, the usual start of the railroad vandalism season, a Penn Central Safety team today brought to 400 Yonkers schoolchildren the message that railroads are the world's most dangerous playgrounds.

title: Lubavitch Rabbi Honored at 71 With 71 Projects as Presents
description: An expanded allday Jewish school in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, a new Chabad House in Johannesburg, South Africa, and 69 other projects, one for each year that he has lived, are the worldwide birthday present for the Lubavitcher rabbi who had asked his followers for a gift that will forward Torahtrue Judaism.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Hospital Unions in Britain End Fight on Wage Policy
description: LONDON, April 13A major challenge to the Government's policy of holding down pay increases ended tonight after six  week dispute that had seriously affected hospital services.

title: News Source Bill Passed
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13 (UPI)The City Council reversed yesterday kits vote of Wednesday and went on record in favor of state and Federal laws protecting newsmen who refuse to identify their news sources. The 8to2 vote repealed a motion passed 12 to Wednesday, which maintained that the issue was none of the city, government's business.

title: High School Notes Students Decide to Build Too Costly Science Center Themselves
description: John Jay High School in Katonah needed a building to house its science and botany departments, but the project was ruled too expensive by the local school board. So the students decided to build the structure themselves, and at no cost to the taxpayer.

title: Yanks'
description: A 6  foot  high birthday cake and 40,000 specially wrapped Hostess cupcakes were delivered to Yankee Stadium yesterday as the Yankees prepared for tomorrow's official goldenanniversary celebration of the Stadium's opening.

title: Notes on People
description: The White House said that President Nixon intended to nominate former Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann of Nebraska as Federal Highway Administrator. Mr. Tiemann, a Republican, who was Governor from 1967 to 1971, is expected to succeed Francis C. Turner in the highway post, which pays $42,500 a year. Also announced was the President's intention to nominate Vincent R. Barabba as Census Director. Mr. Barabba's Los Angeles research company did polling for the. Nixon reelection campaign last year. The census job pays $36,000 a year.

title: People and Business
description: As Assistant Attorney General Thomas Kauper sees it, there is no reason for the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department to alter its close watch on conglomerate mergers.

title: 400 Upstate Students Protest Impending Ouster of Teacher
description: SANDY CREEK, N. Y., April 13Four hundred high school students in this rural community near Lake Ontario staged a twohour walkout this morning to protest the impending ouster of a young teacher whose unorthodox lifestyle was cited by the students as the reason for the action against her.

title: Santa Barbara Area Facing Resumption Of Drilling for Oil
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The Interior Department has quietly started clearing the Way for resumption of offshore oil drilling inside an area once proposed as an oilfree saneWary of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: MAY 7 HEARING SET ON MAGEE RETRIAL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP)A tentative retrial date was set today for Ruchell Magee, whose first trial on murder and kidnapping charges in the Marin County courthouse shootings in 1970 ended in a hung jury.

title: Riessen's Lob Brings Light to Foe's Court
description: CLEVELAND, April 13 (AP)  Ismael El Shafei of Egypt narrowly escaped injury today when a light fixture was knocked down at the Cleveland Public Auditorium during the Cleveland Classic tennis tournament.

title: Pentagon Aides Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The Senate confirmed today President Nixon's nominees for two positions as Assistant Secretary of Defense. John O. Marsh Jr., a former Republican Representative from Virginia, will become Assistant Secretary for Legislative Affairs. Jerry W. Friedheim will succeed Daniel Z. Henkin as Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs.

title: SMITH, STOCKTON REACH SEMIFINALS
Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M.

title: Ryun Wins 3:59.8 Mile, Speediest in Pro Track
Art Peters, 44, Columnist of Philadelphia Inquirer
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (UPI)Art Peters of The Philadelphia Inquirer, one of the most widely read columnists on life in this city, died Wednesday of meningitis at Valley Forge Medical Center. He was 44 years old.

title: PRICES RISE AGAIN FOR PORK BELLIES
description: Live hog and pork belly futures rose again yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The price increases in hog futures were confined largely to the nearby months but the rises in pork belly prices covered all contracts.

title: U.S. SEES DAMAGE TO PALESTINIANS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 State Department said today that irresponsible behavior and extremist tactics by Arab guerrilla leaders were likely to be damaging to the interests of the Palestinian people.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAGAFJORD (Norw. Amer.), MedCruise; sails 11;30 A.M.; from W. Houston St.

title: OILQUOTA END ASKED BY EXXON
description: The Exxon Corporation, in an aboutface, called yesterday for suspension of all quotas on imported crude oil and products.

title: 6 Killed in Plane Crash Near Greensboro, N.C.
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 14 (UPISix persons were killed tonight when a private plane crashed and exploded shortly after takeoff from the Triad regional airport

title: Flood Rips Dam, 200 Families Flee
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., April 13 (AP)The flooding waters of the Mississippi River began slowly falling here today, but a dam broke on nearby Eagle Lake and forced the evacuation of 200 homes.

title: Indictment in Queens ...
description: A district attorney under indictment for a crime can hardly command the public confidence essential to the effective performance of his functions as lawenforcer. Thomas J. Mackell has just achieved the dismal distinction of becoming the first district attorney in New York City ever indicted in connection with his duties as a prosecutor. While that fact in no way predetermines his guilt, it does make it imperative that he step down until his trial is concluded and a final verdict rendered.

title: John Woodlock, Produced, Designed Books at Norton
description: CRESTWOOD, N. Y., April 13 John P. Woodlock, production manager and designer for W. W. Norton & Co., Inc., the bookpublishing house, died in St. Vincent's Hospital in New York yesterday following a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 232 Manhattan Avenue.

title: Major League Box Scores
Rolls Royce Engines Ordered
description: BREMEN, West Germany, April 13 (UPI)The VFWFokker Aviation Company has ordered 60 M 45 H jet engines from Rolls Royce of Britain to be installed in West Germany's first postwar passenger jet airliner, a firm spokesman said today, Assembling of the 44seat VFW 614 will begin in the fall. The spokesman said VFWFokker estimated sales at between 250 and 450 planes within the next 10 to 15 years.

title: Monsanto Golf Scores THE LEADING SCORES
A $60,000 Iron Grille
description: That weirdly shaped wrought iron grille in the window of Gemini Antiques, 1269 Madison Avenue (at 91st Street) may well be the only architectural element designed by Antoni Gaudi available for sale outside of the late Art Nouveau architect's native Spain.

title: Meade F. Moore, 78, Dies Developer of Compact Car
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 13 Meade F. Moore, a former vice president of automotive research and engineering manager for the American Motors Company in Detroit, died here yesterday. He was 78 years old and formerly lived in Kenosha, Wis.

title: . . . Hope in the Police
description: In contrast to these sordid developments over so broad an area, the ceremony surrounding Mayor Lindsay's designation of a new Police Commissioner had a refreshing quality, the promise of one honest official turning over the reins of office to another. The outgoing Commissioner, Patrick V. Murphy, has made an enviable record not only for personal incorruptibility but for his aggressive campaign against the moral slackness and blatant scandal that had become ingrained in the. Police Department. The enthusiastic endorsement Mr. Murphy has given to Donald F. Cawley, chief of patrol and his personal choice for succession, comes close in itself to being an assurance that New York City will continue to have bold and honest leadership in this allimportant arm of municipal government.

title: Merck Raises Quarter Sales and Earnings to Peak
description: Merck & Co., a leading healthproducts maker, posted record first quarter earnings with an increase of 14 per cent. Sales were the highest for any quarter and 15 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago, the report from Rahway, N. J., headquarters disclosed yesterday.

title: Study for Congress Finds Fund Cuts Aren't Genuine
description: WASHINGTON, April 13A Congressional staff study of the budget reductions that President Nixon has made or proposed concludes that many of the reductions are not real reductions and that the reasons the Administration has given for many of the others are unsupported or false.

title: Desert Museum, an Oasis of Arizona Life
description: TUCSON, Ariz.As head of the ArizonaSonora Desert Museum, 14 miles west of here, Mervin W. Larson has helped to create a plantandanimal oasis in a fragile desert environment that is gradually succumbing to the incursions of man.

title: Indiana Paper to Fight Courtroom Ban on Reporters
description: SOUTH BEND, April 13  Legal briefs and depositions were being prepared today in preparation for a challenge by The South Bend Tribune of an attempt by a Plymouth judge to limit news coverage of preliminary proceedings in a murder trial.

title: Wounded Knee Indians Assail Militants
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 13 The Indians who were driven from their homes by the occupation of Wounded Knee, largely silent until now, spoke up angrily yesterday and today against the insurgent Indians who hold their village.

title: Inquiries Reported On Travel Abroad By Equity Officers
description: The overseas travel of a number of former top officers of the scandalridden Equity Funding Corporation of America is being looked into by several Government agencies, according to a source close to the investigations.

title: Commuters'
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it would raise the price of tickets for its ParkRide facility in North Bergen, N.J., from $1.25 to $2 on May 1.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: VAUVENARGUES, France, April 13 (AP)Pablo Picasso's widow today was reported planning to create a museum with the thousands of paintings, drawings and other works of art her husband had left unsold at his death last Sunday.

title: JACOB.Q. UMBERGER
description: LONG BEACH, N.J., April 13 Jacob Q. Umberger, research fellow at the du Pont Photo Products Division in Parlin, N.J., who had patented many photographic processes, died yesterday in Monmouth Medical Center. He was 54 years old and lived in Holmdel Township.

title: Endangered Species Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) President Nixon sent today to the Senate for ratification treaty establishing international controls on the trading of wild fauna and flora in danger of becoming extinct.

title: Formal BonnPrague Talks to Begin
description: BONN, April 13West Germany and Czechcislovakia agreed today to begin formal negotiations aimed at establishing diplomatic relations, ending their long quarrel over the 1938 Munich Pact, under which Hitler dismembered the Czechoslovak state.

title: NOT ALL THE D.A.'S HAVE DETECTIVES
description: The spreading investigation into the office of Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackll has put the spotlight on county detectiveslong the subject of differences among the city's District Attorneys, who disagree on the need for the detectives.

title: Story of Flood Victims: Laughs, Toil and Shame
description: BOOK, La., April 13Mrs. W. C. Monnin was minding her own business when the Red River climbed out of its banks, moved slowly but without stealth across two miles of flat farmland and occupied every room of her house up to a depth of four feet.

title: $20Million Commercial Development Is Planned Near Fordham in the Bronx
description: Revitalization of the major business district of the Bronx through a $20million plan redevelop commercially part Fordham Road was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Borough President Robert Abrams.

title: NO SPECIAL COURTS FOR SCHOOL VOTING
description: The assistant administrative judge of the Manhattan Supreme Court said yesteiday that no special courts could be set up to hear challenges and complaints that might arise from the community school board elections May 1.

title: Diversity Is Stressed
description: MOSCOW, April 13  The Singer Company of New York, eager for a slice of the developing Soviet trade, set up shop here this week in the House of Scientific and Technical Propaganda for a bit of propaganda of its own.

description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The Nixon Administration, in a complete turnabout, announced today that it would release impact aid funds that go to school districts situated near Federal installations and disaster aid funds to districts suffering loss from floods.

description: Saturday, April 14, 1973

title: TV: Jewish History Beautifully Told
description: On the eve of Passover, the American Broadcasting Company has stretched to an hour its regular 30minute religiouscultural series called Directions. The result, tomorrow afternoon at 1, is Rendezvous With Freedom, a superbly engrossing documentarp tracing the history of Jews in the United States. The program is so beautifully done  as scholarly fact merges with impassioned faiththat one viewer, who happens to be the son of a Presbyterian minister, was thrilled at a preview and planned to see it again at home.

title: People in Sports: Wings Dismiss Wilson
description: Almost but not quite able to lead the Detroit Red Wings into the National Hockey League playoffs, Coach Johnny Wilson paid the penalty yesterday. He was dismissed.

title: ACQUISITIONPLANNED BY ISC INDUSTRIES
description: ISC Industries, Inc., a diversified finance, insurance and manufacturing company, announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire 34 per cent of the stock of the Anchor Savings Association for $21.90 a share and to make a tender offer at the same price for the remaining shares.

title: Chilean Police Break Up student Protest in Capital
description: SANTIAGO, Chile April 13 (UPI)Policemen hurled teargas grenades today at striking highschool students demonstrating against drastic education reforms proposed by the leftist Government.

title: Naval Board Names Chief
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 13 (AP)Joseph S. Sinclair, a Warwick; R. I., business executive, was elected chairman of the United States Naval Academy Board of Visitors yesterday, replacing the former chairman, H. Ross Perot.

description: Three of the crews expected to be the strongest in the East this season, Brown, Coast Guard and Northeastern, will be in action today as the inter'collegiate rowing season gets under way on several fronts.

title: GOING OUT Guide Spring Holiday: From Strolling To Egg Rolling
description: BLOSSOMTIME Not only the youngsters are out, but so are the first colorful blossoms that make the holiday a real spring season. The bulk of the cherry trees will bloom in about two weeks, but several species have already come out. Magnolias are blooming. You can see delicate shades of pink on the serried crabapple ranks in Central Park's Conservatory Gardens, Fifth Avenue and 105th Street. The azaleas are creating a purple stir in the neophyte Queens Botanical Garden, 4350 Main Street. But for cherry trees, you don't have to pack up for Washington. They're out along Central Park's East Drive from the upper 60's north; at the Bronx's New York Botanical Gardens, 200th Street, east of Webster Avenue, and in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, in Prospect Park at Eastern Parkway and Flatbush Avenue.

title: Delinquency Bill Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, joined today in sponsoring a bill to establish a new, comprehensive program to combat juvenile delinquency and rehabilitate delinquents. The bill would create a centralized authority, the National Office of Juvenile Justice, which would coordinate Federal juvenile delinquency control efforts that are now fragmented and scattered.

description: A Flower From Every Meadow, at Asia House, 112 East 64th Street, turns out to be the most delightful single group of Indian paintings can remember seeing, in or out of India. All from American collections, the 82 examples date from about 1520 to 1900 and include folk paintings and company picturesadaptations of Indian style to British tastealong with the standard classical styles.

description: Nathan Ginsberg, a former assistant attorney general for New York, died Thursday at the Nassau Nursing Home in Oceanside, L. I, He was 76 years old and lived at 1020 Grand Concourse in the Bronx, where he had been a Republican district leader for many years.

title: News Summary and index
description: Fire swept the Americanowned terminal. of the TransArabian oil pipeline early today at Saida, 20 miles south of Beirut, Lebanon. Its cause was not known, but a company spokesman said, sabotage was a possibility. The fire occurred after two Lebanese newspapers quoted Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, as having threatened big vengeance for what he charged was United States collaboration with Israel in the killing of three Palestinian leaders Tuesday. [Page 1, Columns 78.]

Foley, marketing manager for the computer peripheral product line, said the $49price would apply to single terminal on a 12month rental basis or the units could be purchased for $1,790, with quantity discounts also available. All prices include maintenance.

description: OAKLAND, April 13  A golden opportunity faced the Golden State Warriors tonight when they faced the Milwaukee Bucks at the Coliseum here with a 32 lead in the fourofseven firstround National Basketball Association playoff series.

description: The Seattle SuperSonics, who lost their firstround college draft turn because of an alleged violation of the National Basketball Association bylaws, almost had it back againbecause of another violation. Federal Judge. Charles H. Tenney ruled here Thursday that N.B.A. Commissioner Walter Kennedy had usurped the authority of the N.B.A. board of governors last November when he awarded Seattle's firstround draft choice to the Philadelphia 76ers when they signed John Brisker, then on the 76ers negotiation list.

description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) The District of Columbia has asked the Inaugural Committee to pay for damages to a $20,000 carpet on which partygoers stamped out cigarettes andspilled liquor during the Presidential inaugural ball in the Pension Building that houses the city's Superior Court.

title: Dave Anderson
description: CHICAGO, April 13What kind of soup do you have? Vic Hadfield asked. Turtle soup, sir, the waiter suggested, Can you make it snappy? Hadfield said. Slowly, the waiter smiled, realizing that Hadfield had been putting him on. Hadfield's smile was much quicker. The significance of his subtle humor at lunch today was that the captain of the New York Rangers was acting like himself. One reason was that last night he had scored the winning goal in a 41 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in the opener of their Stanley Cup semifinal series. The goal represented a private drama. For the last six weeks, ever since he was struck in the face by a puck on Feb. 28, he has been living and playing in the drumming daze of a concussion. With every body check, his headaches pounded louder. His wife and children were aware of its effects. So were his coach and teammates. But spectators didn't understand what he was going through. Quickly, most of them had forgotten about his concussion. When they saw him on the ice, they assumed that he must be all right. Often he wasn't. Once, when he scored a goal on a quick slap shot, his teammate, Rod Gilbert, instinctively hugged hira in celebration.

title: ...Folly in Jersey...
description: Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. of New Jersey seems to have fallen victim to the same upsidedown thinking that has prevailed in much of official Washington lately on what to commend and what to punish in the performance of public employes.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Reno, Nev.(Irish) Pat Duncan, 190 pounds, Carson City, Nev., knocked out Eduaro Coffey, 194, Sonora, Mexico, 5 rounds.

title: Service Bonus Gains in Iowa
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 13 (UPI)On a unanimous vote, the Iowa House Appropriations Committee approved today legislation to award Vietnam veteran bonuses to 76,000 Iowans. The bill was a priority proposal of Gov. Robert D. Ray. Under the $28million proposal, veterans could receive $10 for each month of service in this country and $12.50 a month for overseas duty, with a maximum of $500 for each veteran. The $500 limitation would not apply to prisoners of war.

title: Phone Rate Rise Denied
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 13 (AP)The Vermont Public Service Board has denied a rate increase request by the New England Telephone Company, which it said was higher than any ever granted to Bell System affiliates in New England. The proposed Increase averaged 35 per cent.

description: LONDON, April 13 (AP) Opposition Laborites won power today in local elections in London and six other big centers of , England and Wales.

Turco pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of defrauding his law clients of money due them to settle personal in jury suits and of filing tax returns that were late and false. He was ordered to post a $10,000 personal recognizance bond and given time to obtain the bond.

description: Mrs. Gertrude Low Solon, wife of Stanley Solon, owner of the Meredith Galleries on East 57th Street, died Tuesday in Doctors Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 180 East 79th Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A West Harlem man was shot to death early yesterday when he entered the Queen Bee Lounge, at 2711 Eighth Avenue, and found three gunmen holding up the bar and six patrons. The polite said the victim, 27yearold Gary Lilly, of 2715 Eighth Avenue, had refused to surrender his money, so one of the gunmen shot him in the head, before all three fled in a cab.... On the West Side, the police are seeking the three daughters of Rudolph Milos, a 56yearold bartender, who was fatally stabbed in his apartment 441 West 48th Street, near 10th Avenue, last Sunday.... In the Bronx, cameras triggered by a silent alarm, the police said, recorded three gunmen and a woman wearing stocking masks robbing $4,000 from the Bankers Trust Company, at 2104 Crotona Parkway, at East 180th Street, in the East Tremont area. They fled in a red car, leaving one bank employe slightly injured.

description: WASHINGTON, April 13A Congressional staff study of the budget reductions that President Nikon has made or proposed concludes that many of the reductions are not real reductions and that the reasons the Administration has given for many of the others are unsupported or false.

title: A Berlitz Gets Right To Use His Name On Language Books
description: Charles F. Berlitz, grandson of the founder of the worldwide language schools, yesterday was awarded $376,000 and the right to use his name as author of books on foreign languages.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Reno, Nov.(Irish) Pat Duncan, 190 pounds, Carson City, Nev., knocked out Eduaro Coffey, 194, Sonora, Mexico, 5 rounds.

title: Antiques: Lore of Lace
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.Lace, once so lionized by kings and queens that it sparked feuds between nations, restrictive laws, class distinctions and brutality toward dogs, seems the epitome of delicacy in an exhibition on view here through June 1.

title: Two City Policemen Are Found Guilty Of An Extortion Plot
description: Two suspended policemen were found guilty here yesterday of plotting to extort money from the operator of a tavern where detectives had found a small amount of drugs in the men's room.

title: If Rangers Make Final, Seiling May Be Ready
description: CHICAGO, April 13Rod Selling, the New York Rangers defenseman who suffered a broken left collarbone on March 20, was listed as a possible participant in the Stanley Cup final if the New York Rangers qualified.

title: Hart Discloses Earnings
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Senitor Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, said today that his earnings from stocks and bonds during 1972 had totaled $8,299, an increase of $188 from the previous year.

title: River Grove in Capital Will Honor Johnson
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson formally approved today the planting of a grove of 500 trees in a park near the Potomac River as a memorial to the President.

title: Big File of SmallBusiness Dreams
description: A line forms at 9 A.M. every business day in Room 109 of the County Clerk's office in downtown Manhattan. Those in line are businessmen, and they mean business.

title: Mays Lets a Dentist Relieve the Pressure
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 Willie Mays, having a little trouble with his bridgework, went to see a dentist early today and underwent oral surgery. Apparently, the bridge had been pressing against his gums on the left side and there was a possibility of an infection. The bridge was trimmed down just a little to relieve the pressure, according to a club spokesman.

title: Richardson Faces a Storm Over Plan to Close Bases
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 When Elliot L. Richardson was about to become Secretary of Defense, the White House decided that his national image would be enhanced if he were to announce the closing of more than 50 military bases around the country as an economy measure.

title: 8 AMERICAN DOCTORS TO VISIT CHINA SOON.
description: CLEVELAND, April 13 (AP)  Eight American heart specialists will tour Chinas later this month at the invitation of the Chinese Medical Association, the Cleveland Clinic announced yesterday.

title: Gulf Oil Unit Signs Deal
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday that its Gulf Energy & Environmental Systems Company has signed an agreement with International Atomreaktorbau, G. m. b. H., Interatom) of Bensberg, Gernany, to market its Triga nuclear research reactor in 13 European countries. The reactor uses a special fuel that is an alloy of uranium and zirconium hydride that makes it far safer than most research reactors by reducing the fission chain reaction to a safe level.

title: Books of The Times
description: WELLINGTON. Pillar of State. By Elizabeth Longford 472 pages. Harper & Row. $10.

title: Brinegar Weighs Northeast Rail Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Secretary of Transportation Claude S. Brinegar indicated today that the Administration would consider railroad industry proposals that Amtrak the national railroad passenger corporation  take over the 459mile Northeast rail corridor from Washington through New York City, New Haven and Providence to Boston.

title: Music:.Londoners'
description: The appearances of the London Symphony Orchestra have always been one of the brightest spots in Carnegie Hall's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras. This week that fine ensemble is in town, conducted by Andre Previn, and the Thursday night program demonstrated once agam that the London Symphony is one of the world's great orchestras. It also demonstrated that Mr. Previn continues to grow in assurance and expertise.

title: HARRY ROSENTHAL OF SHOECRAFT, INC.
description: Harry Rosenthal, who retired a year ago as chairman of Shoecraft, Inc., 603 Fifth Avenue, retailers of footwear for tall women, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 165 East 66th Street.

title: Business Briefs
description: Reduced supplies of livestock, continuing margin squeezes and other conditions, have forced the closing the second largest meat packing plant of John Morrell & Co., at Ottumwa, Iowa.

title: Further Security Reported For QE2's Trip to Israel
description: LONDON, April 13 The Royal Air Force and Royal Navy were reported today to be preparing to keep watch over the liner Queen Elizabeth 2 as she sails from Britain to Israel starting Sunday.

title: CHRIS EVERT GAINS SEMIFINALS, 62, 7N5
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 13 (AP) Top seeded Chris Evert used deadly accurate placement shots to defeat Marie Neumonnova of Czechoslovakia, 62, 75, tonight in the $20,000 Miami BeachCarner Bank tennis tournament.

title: Washington Halting All Aid Projects in Uganda
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) 4The United States will halt all aid projects in Uganda by June 30, officials here reported today.

title: Girl Wins but Rejects the Right To Try Out for Baseball Team
description: PISCATAWAY, April 13No hardline feminist, 17yearold Mori Irvine thinks of herself first as a girl, then as a baseball player, and proved it today by exercising what many male chauvinists regard as highly feminine prerogative. She changed her mind.

title: DR. FINLA CRAWFORD OF SYRACUSE U. DIES
description: WELLSVILLE, N. Y., April 13 Dr. Finla G. Crawford, vice chancellor emeritus of Syracuse University and a former trustee of the State Power Authority, died today at Jones Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Andover.

title: Ellsberg Defense Considering Calling on Fulbright to Testify
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13 The defense in the Pentagon papers trial has still not decided whether to ask Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, to testify in behalf of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr.

title: Jersey Raises Standards on Meat Processing
WINE TALK
description: Many people who drank wine all winter are now planning trips to see where it came from. This could mean California's Napa Valley, New York's Finger Lakes, or for someone pressed for time, a subway ride down to Rivington Street to the venerable Schapiro's Wine Company, Ltd. The big wine trip, of course, is to France and, not surprisingly, there are some very attractive trips to the French wine country all packaged and ready to go.

title: FUNDING AGENCY DEFERS TV ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Corporation for Public Broadcasting deferred action today on the question of whether it or the Public Broadcasting Service, representing public broadcasting stations, would control public TV's interconnection network.

title: State Jury Is Said to Call For G. O. P. Finance Data
description: TRENTON, April 13  The statewide grand jury has supoenaed the records of the Republican state finance committee in its investigation of Republican fundraising activities during and after the 1969 gubernatorial campaign, according to sources close to the state investigation.

title: Chinese Boycott a Talk By South Korean in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, April 13 (UPI)  Chinese delegates boycotted a South Korean's speech, but sat and listened to criticism of China by the Soviet Union at today's session of the Economic Conference for Asia and the Far East, a United Nations unit.

title: Bridge:
description: The standard procedure for successful elimination play is to denude the opponents of all trumps, leaving at least one trump in declarer hand and the dummy. But When this is impossible, partial elimination may come into consideration. Strip the trumps from one defender, and endplay him while trump still lurks in the hand of the other defender.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: CHAMPIONSHIP PLAYOFF Syracuse 4, Roanoke Valley 1 (Syracuse won championship series, 42).

title: Sperry Reports on Payments
description: The Associated Press in dispatch from Minneapolis in The New York Times yesterday erroneously stated that payments from the International Business Machines Corporation had continued at a $1million annual rate. The Sperry Rand Corporation said here yesterday that it had received no royalty payments from any source since 1965 on its patent for a computer design known as Einac  Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer. A spokesman said that I.B.M. had made payments totaling $11.1million between 1956 and 1965, but indicated no further payment was due.

title: Soviet Six Regains World Title
description: MOSCOW, April 13  The Soviet Union tonight clinched its ninth world amateur hockey championship in 10 years with a sharply contested but decisive 42 victory over Czechoslovakia, the defending champion.

title: Makarios Formally Declared Defrocked
description: LIMASSOL, Cyprus, April 13  The three senior bishops of the Cypriote Orthodox Church announced the ouster of Archbishop Makarios from the clergy today, charging that by serving as President of Cyprus for 13 years he had broken church law against holding secular office.

title: MALTBY D. JELLIFFE
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., April 13Maltby D. Jelliffe, who retired in 1963 as an executive of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company ha New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, last evening. He was 74 years old and lived at 74 The King's Highway.

title: Dix Training Center Is Expected to Close
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The closing of the Army's basic training center at Fort Dix, N. J., where millions of men received their initiation into military life, is expected to be announced on Monday, according to the office of Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey.

title: AP Photographer Wins White House Contest
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Henry Burroughs, a photographer for The Associated Press, won the top honor last night at the 30th annual photo contest of the White House News Photographer's Association.

title: Foreign Investors Remaining Wary Of Wall St. Lure
description: PARIS, April 13  Two months after the second devaluation of the dollar in 14 months the foreign investor is still afraid of putting his money into Wall Street.

title: Boon for Business
description: MOSCOW, April 13  The Soviet Government has agreed to grant resident American businessmen multiple visas to permit freer movement from the Soviet Union to other countries, American officials disclosed today.

title: Plan to Honor Garibaldi in Sicily Stirs a Furor
description: MARSALA, Sicily  A Communist legislator's request for nearly $1million in Goxemment money to build a huge monument here to Giuseppe Garibaldi, the hero of Italian unification, has stirred a nationwide furor but leaves most of Marsala's people unruffled.

title: JEAN GUITTON
description: PARIS, April 13 (AP)Jean Guitton, who wtote a number of plays that were staged here between the two world wars, died at his home in Juan les Pins on Sunday. He was 86 years old.

title: Safety Standards for Cribs Are Proposed by F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration proposed today the first national safety standards for baby cribs and said that at least 133 children had died in crib accidents since 1970.

title: Pentagon Aide Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Jerry W. Friedheim to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs. Mr. Friedheim, a 38yearold Pentagon spokesman, has been a deputy assistant secretary since 1970.

title: Christenson, 19, Hurls 5Hitter in Debut
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 Looking very much like an old established professional, Larry Christenson made his major league debut tonight, pitching the Philadelphia Phillies to a 71 victory over the Mets before a crowd of 7,127 in Veterans Stadium.

title: Hilton Hotels in Agreement To Build Units in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 13 The Hilton Hotels Corporation ntered into an agreement with a Brazilian concern today for the construction of between 30 and 50 hotels in Brazil, it was announced here.

title: Canadians Oppose Seattle Power Plan
description: SEATTLE, April 10  Like many other cities, Seattle is facing rising demands for electricity. And like many other cities, Seattle is facing environmental opposition in trying to meet those needs. But Seattle's plan to meet its energy needs through hydroelectric power by flooding 5,200 acres of Canada is also stirring the opposition of nationalism.

title: Setback for Mr. Heath
description: The Labor party's sweep in Britain's county elections far surpassed the predictions of its leaders, but perspective and precedent warn that it is too early to count out a Conservative Government that need not face the voters until mid1975. For one thing, the turnout was extremely lightabout half that of the usual parliamentary election. And the county balloting came at a peculiarly unfavorable time for Prime Minister Heath's Tories.

title: APRIL 110 SALES OF CARS SET HIGH
description: DETROIT, April 13Newcar sales set another high in early April.

title: Bucks Eliminated, 10086
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 13 The Golden State Warriors completed their conquest of the Milwaukee Bucks tonight by pounding out a 10086 victory that left a capacity crowd of 14,000 screaming with unforeseen ecstacy.

description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 13 (AP)Joyce Kazmierski, a nonwinner on the women's pro golf tour, shot a fourunderpar 68 in high winds today for a twostroke lead after two rounds of the $154,000 ColgateDinah Shore golf tournament.

description: BUFFALO, April 13 (AP)A Federal grand jury has indicted seven persons in the Buffalo area on charges of tax evasion, including the president of a paving company.

title: Canada Charges Hanoi Sends More Troops South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 (AP) Canada's peacekeeping delegation here charged today for the first time that North Vietnam was violating the Paris peace agreement by sending fresh troops into South Vietnam. Similar allegations were made by the United States.

title: Lieut. Cox Ends Training
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., April 13 (UPI)First Lieut. Edward Finch Cox graduated with honors from the infantry officer basic course today with his wife Tricia Nixon Cox, in the audience. Lieutenant Cox, President Nixon's soninlaw, has been in training at Fort Benning for nine weeks.

description: TOKYO, April 13  The Government adopted today a sevenpoint program designed to contain spiraling prices brought about by inflationary speculation and excessive money supply in recent months.

description: The Metropolitan Museum's major summer exhibition, called simply Gold, opens to the public today after a fouryear on againoffagain history in the museum's schedule. It is well worth the wait.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, April 1A major fire swept through the Americanowned terminal of the TransArabian oil pipeline following an explosion early today.

title: The Kleindienst Doctrine
description: Attorney General Kleindienst has gone to extraordinary lengths to tell Congress that the President is in the driver's seatand to defy the legislators to challenge him. If the President so commands, Mr. Kleindienst said in answer to a question by Senator Muskie, any member of the executive branchdefined to mean all 2.5 million administrative employes of the Federal Governmentmay disregard a call to testify before Congress. This amounts to a translation of executive privilege into terms of regal authority. Brushing aside all the customary niceties, the Attorney General told the Senators, in effect, that the Administration was confident that it had the popular support to humiliate Congress in any showdown on that issue. A Senate lawyer rightly summed up the position of the Justice Department chief as a blueprint for government by the Presidency, with Congress and the judiciary relegated to outer space.

title: Irton Prince 31 Choice In U.S. Pacing Debut
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 13 Can Irton Prince, a 7yearold New Zealandbred brown gelding who is scheduled to make his American debut in tomorrow night's eighth race at Roosevelt Raceway, live up to the high rating given him by the track's race secretary and oddsmaker?

title: Boston U. Picks Paul Kemp As Head Football Coach
description: BOSTON, April 13 (AP)  Paul Kemp, a 40yearold assistant coach at the University of Pittsburgh for the last four years, was named head football coach at Boston University tonight.

title: Parties to Hold Talks:The Cast
description: Costa-Gavras's "State of Siege" is a riveting film and possibly an inflammatory one. It oversimplifies recent history, but raises so many complex and important moral questions that to attack it for oversimplification may be just a discreet form of rationalization, of looking the other way.The screenplay by Franco Solinas, who wrote "The Battle of Algiers," is based on the kidnap and murder of Dan. A. Mitrione in August, 1970, in Montevideo, Uruguay. Mr. Mitrione, an Italian-born American, the father of nine children and a former police chief in Richmond, Ind., was an official of the United States Agency for International Development assigned as an adviser to the Uruguayan police. Officially he was an expert in traffic control and communications, and in this capacity he had earlier been an adviser to the police in Brazil and the Dominican Republic.On July 31, 1970, Mr. Mitrione and the Brazilian consul in Montevideo were kidnapped by the Tupamaros, a group of Marxist-oriented, urban guerrillas who demanded the release of 150 political prisoners. The Uruguayan Government declined, and 10 days after his kidnapping, Mr. Mitrione was executed by the Tupamaros who, until then, had mostly refrained from violence in their efforts to discredit the Government and what they called its repressionist policies.Much of the world was appalled, as it was by the Black September massacre at the Tel Aviv Airport, by the killing of the Israeli athletes in Munich and by the more recent murders in Khartoum.After Mr. Mitrione's murder, information began to be published here and abroad that suggested that Mr. Mitrione's specialty was not necessarily traffic control and communication, but internal security, more specifically, antiguerrilla warfare, with close associations to those responsible for the systematic torture and liquidation of the revolutionary opposition.Among the many questions raised by "State of Siege" is one relating to the film maker's responsibility to stick to the truth of an event even when it might be inconvenient. The Solinas screenplay changes the names of the principals (I suppose releases would be hard to get from those alive) and only indirectly alludes to the Uruguayan setting (the film was actually shot in Salvador Allende's Chile). It very carefully never puts the Mitrione character (named Philip Michael Santore in the film and played by Yves Montand) at the scene of any tortures, but the inference  very loud and very clear  is that Mitrione-Santore was a major architect of those policies.Thus to the extent that Costa-Gavras and Solinas suggest that the A.I.D. man was secretly involved in the internal affairs of a foreign government, the film is a rationalization of a terrorist act. However, in its biased but elegantly cool way, it's much more than that. It's an examination of an event first, then of national policies that led to that event (including the United States' historical role as Big Daddy in Latin America through economic programs that help others to help themselves as well as our industry), and lines of responsibility.Finally, it's an examination of our capacity to be shocked, a capacity that may have begun to run out with the disclosures about the Bay of Pigs, so that now, when we read the stories about the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and Chile, we are as much inclined to laughter as we are to grief or even to surprise. We shrug and ask ourselves, in effect, what will they do next? Self-interest carried to the limit is no longer evil, or a matter for review by one's conscience, but a kind of dumbfounding rascality, a high form of scalawaggery.What makes "State of Siege" so harrowing is not that it is all true (I'm not in a position to know), but that it could be true, and all of us could be responsible. This is more important, I think, than carping over details of the film, over the fact that no effort is made to define the inflationary economic conditions in Uruguay that first prompted the press censorship and other repressive measures that, in turn prompted the revolutionary opposition.Strictly as an example of film-making, "State of Siege" is exceptionally shrewd. Although we have no doubt what the outcome of the narrative will be, Costa-Gavras and Solinas maintain our interest at what is sometimes called (in admitted desperation) a fever pitch. Through the kind of rapid cross-cutting made familiar in both "Z" and "The Confession," they manage to make straight exposition hugely dramatic.Will or won't the police find the kidnapped officials? Cut to the Uruguayan legislature where a report is being read concerning the existence of "an uncontrollable and autonomous organization" within the national police. Cut to the rebels' interrogation of Montand, cut to . . . cut to. . . . The movie's pace is unrelenting, and it wasn't until I saw it the second time that I recognized the essential monotony of the techniques.Most shrewd is the casting of Montand, who, because he is Montand, evokes sympathy for a character who remains at best sincerely wrongheaded, at worst a fuzzy villain. Were this American played by an American actor, the film might well be insupportably antagonizing."State of Siege," which opened yesterday at the Beekman, also raises the question about what the American Film Institute was up to when it first booked the film to open its new Washington theater at the Kennedy Center. It should have been apparent to anyone who had seen it that "State of Siege" would ruffle a lot of people in Washington, but then to cancel it, as was done last week, suggests incompetence of an order as scary as outright censorship.

title: NEW HOPE VICTOR BY NECK IN MILE
description: New Hope impressed his trainer, Preston King, most favorably at Aqueduct yesterday. New Hope, a 4yearold Kentuckybred son of Pia Star, carried the colors of Sam Lehrman to a thrilling victory in the feature race, beating the favorite Paternity of the Tartan Stable by a neck.

title: ARTHUR FRANK
description: WEST NEW YORK, N. J., April 13  Arthur Frank, a lawyer, died, apparently of a heart attack, last evening. He was 87 years old and lived at 6040 Boulevard East.

title: Richardson Faces a Storm Over Move to Close Bases
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 When Elliot L. Richardson was about to become Secretary of Defense, the White House decided that his national image would be enhanced if he were to announce the closing of more than 50 military bases around the country as an economy measure.

title: 70 Die in Bangladesh Storm With Winds of 90 M.P.H.
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 13 (Reuters)Seventy people were killed and several hundred injured as a storm with winds of 90 miles an hour swept across the Faridpur District, southwest of Dacca, last night.

title: The Indochina Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Nixon Administration officials are saying these days that they are concerned over the worsened military situation in Cambodia, angered by Hanoi's swift military buildup in South Vietnam and distressed by the reluctance of the Soviet Uninn and China to do much to uphold the 76day  old Vietnam cease  fire agreement. But when asked what they plan to do, the officials equivocate. We continue to assess the situation, Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, said again today, repeating what Henry A. Kissinger and others have been telling Congressmen, and newsmen for more than a week. We have no deadline for action, another aide said. We can wait and see.

title: Paintings Stolen in France
description: CANNES, France, April 13 (Reuters)A Picasso and some other modern paintings valued at about $200,000 have been stolen from a villa near here, the police said today. The paintings, which include works by Braque and Leger, were stolen from a house at the village of TourettessurLoup. The owner of the house was identified as Pierre Schlumberger, 60yearold oil industrialist.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
St. Louis Missing a Picasso
description: ST. LOUIS, April 13A small painting by Pablo Picasso, entitled Nude, is missing from the St. Louis Art Museum and is presumed to have been stolen, the museum's director, Charles E. Buckley, announced today. The absence of the oil painting on a wood panel was first noticed late Wednesday afternoon. A search of the building failed to locate it, and the police were notified.

title: House Panel Names Swigert
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) John L, Swigert Jr., who in Apollo 13 survived a space crisis three years ago, was named executive director of the House Science and Astronautics Committee staff today.

title: News Summary and Index
2 GROUPS ASSAIL THE MAIL SERVICE
description: Irate community groups told a Congressional subcommittee hearing yesterday that firstclass letters often took eight days to travel three and a half blocks in New York City.

title: Julie Heldman Surprises Kerry Melville in Tennis
description: QUINCY, Mass., April 13 (AP) Seventhseeded Julie Heldman of New York pulled a stunning upset in defeating secondseeded Kerry Melville of Australia, 63, 75, tonight in the quarter finals of the $25,000 Virginia Slims of Massachusetts indoor tennis tournament.

title: A Disorganized American Party Is Locked in Factional Dispute
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP) While Republicans contend with the Watergate controversy and Democrats reorganize, the American party is struggling to overcome a bitter factional dispute.

title: Hawks Out, Knicks Next
description: ATLANTA, April 13  The Boston Celtics threw a steelwebbed defense at the Atlanta Hawks midway through the final period and held them scorgless for 7 minutes, and coasted to a 121103 victory before a capacity crowd of 16,181 tonight at the Omni.

title: Plan to Hear Nixon Aides On Watergate Discussed
description: WASHINGTON, Airil 13The White House and the Senate committee investigating the Watergate case are discussing an arrangement under which Presidential aides Would testify publicly on the scandal, it was reported today.

title: Computer Mail Center Opens Next Week
description: Inside the vast babyblue building off Route 1 in Jersey City, a wilderness of conveyer belts, computer terminals and sophisticated equipment is being shaped into the Postal Service's most modern bulkmail facility.

title: Blancas Registers a 69, Leads Beard By 2 Shots
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 13 (AP)Homero Blancas put together a hardearned twounderpar 69 and stretched his lead to two strokes today in the second round of the $150,000 Monsanto open golf tournament.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two women in their sixties were killed and five other persons including two firemen, suffered minor injuries a fire in Newark yesterday. Julia Pattillo, 69 years old, was found dead under the bed in her secondfloor room about 2:58 A.M. Later the body of Eva Alexander, 62, was found in her thirdfloor bedroom.

title: GRAY WITHDRAWS HIS MAYORAL BID
description: Assemblyman Jesse Gray of Manhattan withdrew yesterday from the race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, narrowing the field to four contenders.

title: BARNINGS RAISED BY FIRST CHICAGO
description: The First Chicago GorporaLion, parent company of the First National Bank of Chicago, reported yesterday that firstquarter earnings, before security transactions, rose to $19,729,00Q, to $1.01 a share, from $17,831,000, or 93 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Art: Unusual StillLifes
description: Occasionally, one comes across works of art so perfectly contrived that one's response is a kind of numbing awe. The large exhibition of stilllife paintings by Jane Wilson now on view at the Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue, is an experience of that type.

title: One Dead in Upstate Blast
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., April 13 (AP)One person was killed and another injured today when an explosion and fire destroyed the Jones Baking Company in this Chautauqua County community. The dead man was identified as Roger Gustofson. Investigators said a bulldozer clearing a site next to the bakery may have cut a natural gas line, causing the explosion.

title: Speculation Rises as Peking Rehabilitates a Victim of Pure
description: PEKING, April 13  Wang Haijung, an Assistant Foreign Minister, approached correspondents at a state banquet in honor of Prince Norodom Sihanouk Thursday night and aliened them to the fact that a news story was Staring them in the face.

title: Kidnapper's in Argentina Free British Businessman
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 13 (AP) Francis Brimicombe, a British businessman kidnapped last Sunday, was released by his captors tonight after an undisclosed ransom was paid, a relative of the executive said.

description: LONDON, April 13 (AP)  Policemen and security men raided 111 Irish homes across Britain today in a crackdown against suspected Irish Republican Army guerrillas.

description: Joseph C. Swidler, chairman, of the State Public Service Commission, said here yesterday that stricter government controls were going to be necessary to restrict the use of energy because voluntary efforts like the Consolidated Edison Company's SaveaWatt programwere not doing the job.

title: Notes on People
description: The White House said that President Nixon intended to nominate former Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann of Nebraska as Federal Highway Administrator. Mr. Tiemann, a Republican, who was Governor from 1967 to 1971, is expected to succeed Francis C. Turner in the highway post, which pays $42,500 a year. Also announced was the President's intention to nominate Vincent R. Barabba as Census Director. Mr. Barabba's Los Angeles research company did polling for the Nixon reelection campaign last year. The census job pays $36,000 a year.

title: Television
FIRE NEAR BEIRUT HITS OIL FACILITY OF U.S. COMPANY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, April 14A major fire swept the Americanowned terminal of the TransArabian oil pipeline early today. The origin of the fire near Saida, 20 miles south of here, was not determined, but a company spokesman said that sabotage was a possibility.

title: Nixon Nominates Banker
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (Reuters)John M. Porges of New York City has been nominated by President Nixon to be United States executive director of the InterAmerican Development Bank for a threeyear term, replacing Henry J. Constanzo, who resigned Dec. 31. Mr. Porges has been vice president in charge of Latin America with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company since 1962.

title: PRESIDENT CLEARS SCHOOL AID FUNDS IN A POLICY SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Nixon Administration, in a complete turnabout, announced today that it would release impact aid funds that go to school districts situated near Federal installations and disaster aid funds to school districts suffering loss from floods.

title: GOING OUT Guide
Inaugural Damage Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) The District of Columbia has asked the Inaugural Committee to pay for damages to a $20,000 carpet on which partygoers stamped out cigarettes and spilled liquor during the Presidential inaugural ball in the Pension Building that houses the city's Superior Court.

title: Topless Radio Shows Draw Fine From F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)  The Federal Communications Commission voted 6 to 1 today to fine the owner of an Illinois radio station $2,000 for broadcasting two topless radio shows dealing with oral sex.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: Edited by WILL WENG

title: Plan to Hear Nixon Aides On Watergate Discussed
PHARMACY BILL SIGNED BY MAYOR
New Avery Aspects: Paintings on Paper
description: Few experiences in art are more gratifying than the discovery of new pleasures in the work of an artist one already admires. In the case of the American painter Milton Avery, who died in 1964 at the age of 71, a large body of work had enjoyed a prominent place on the art scene for many decades, and yet new aspects of his accomplis'iment continue to be revealedand admired. His achievement seems even larger now than it did a decade ago.

title: Dudley Senanayake Dies at 57; Was Prime Minister of Ceylon
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 12Dudley Senanayake, three times Prime Minister and son of a former Prime Minister, died tonight of a heart ailment. He was 57 years old.

title: Miss Wright Has Nuptials
description: Miss Janice Diane Wright, a specialist in flight service procedures with American Airlines, was married here yesterday afternoon to Peter

title: Cleveland Press Prices Up
description: CLEVELAND, April 13 (UPI) The Cleveland Press, in its first price rise since 1959, announced today that its editions sold at newsstands and in vending machines would go from 10 cents to 15 cents a copy, effective Monday. The move followed by a week a similar price rise by The, Cleveland Plain Dealer.

title: CHARLES COURBOIN, CHURCH ORGANIST
description: Charles Courboin, organist and music director of St. Patrick's Cathedral from 1943 to 1970, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old. A native of Antwerp, Belgium, Mr. Courboin studied at the Brussels Conservatory and played at the Antwerp Cathedral before coming to the United States in 1904. During the nineteentwenties he was organist of the Wanamaker department stores in New York and Philadelphia and focused considerable attention upon them through by presenting musical programs offering American and European artists including Leopold Stokowski and Marcel Dupr.

title: Miss Wright Has Nuptials
description: Miss Janice Diane Wright, a specialist in flight service procedures with American Airlines, was married here yesterday afternoon to Peter Louis Truebner, an, assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Marriage: Everybody's View Had a Champion on the Panel
description: Marriage, one of the most Attacked institutions of the last decade, was variously dissected, defended and denounced at an East Side church the other night by 10 people whose views might well represent the entire spectrum on the subject.

title: HEAD OF PRESSMEN ASKS MEDIATION AID
description: William J. Kennedy, president of Pressman's Union 2, said yesterday that he had requested state and Federal mediation assistance after his union ran into an impasse in negotiations with the city's three major dailies.

title: Buzzing the Screech Out of Student Violins
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 A New York instructor in stringed instruments has invented a series of devices to enable students to teach themselves to play violin, banjo or guitar. A signal sounds when something is done wrong. Burton Kaplan, who is on the music faculties of New York University and other institutions, has been granted patents on five pieces of instruction equipment, called Practice Partners. They warn when the instrument, the bow or the player's hand is in improper position.

title: PreMature
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Salmon Betrothed to F.D. Wells
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 14Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Salmon 3d of Garden City and Lake Placid, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Dunning Salmon, to Frederic Donald Wells, son of Mrs. Marshall B. Taft of Devon, Pa., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Donald K. Wells. A September wedding in Lake Placid is planned.

title: Miss Barr Betrothed
description: Mrs. C. Frederick Westin of Bay Head, N. J., and Henry B. Barr of North Plainfield, N. J., have announced that their daughter, Miss Carolyn Armstrong Barr, and Reed Wasson Hoyt will marry May 5. The future bridegroom, who graduated from the University of Arizona, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael P. E. Hoyt of Bethesda, Md. His fiance is an alumna of the Kent Place School in Summit and Sweet Briar College.

title: Phnom Penh Is Reported Facing About 40 Communist Battalions
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 14 (Reuters) Military sources say that about 40 Communist battalions of 300 men each are concentrated around the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh.

title: Trucker Opens Family Play Center
description: NORTH BERGENA new venture in employe relations was celebrated here yesterday with the formal dedication of the APA Transport Corporation's family recreation center at 220 East 85th Street.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 01973, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Thieu, Back Home, Says New Peace Era Is Starting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 14  President Nguyen Van Thieu returned to Saigon from a twoweek world tour tonight and told a huge throng at Tan Son Nhut Airport that his trip marked the end of a difficult period and the beginning of a new era of peaceful reconstruction for South Vietnam.

title: 440 AND MILE RELAYS SPARK COAST MEET
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (UPI) The University of Southern California and the San Diego Track Club recorded the fastest 440yard and onemile relay times in the world this year and Steve Smith suffered his first defeat in the pole vault in 16 meets today at the Trojan invitation event.

title: Integration
description: BOSTON  In 1965, Massachusetts became the first  it is still the onlystate to pass a racial imbalance law forbidding schools with more than 50 per cent nonwhite enrollment.

title: Dance
description: THERE is a momentary lull in the dance sceneas I write, we are awaiting visits from the. Jamaica National Dance Theater, the National Ballet of Canada) the New York City Ballet, the Martha Graham Dance Company, the Stuttgart Ballet and then, sailing into the Summer, American Ballet Theater and the Bolshol Ballet. Yet, just for a few, days things are fairly quiet, so let me raise a couple of issues.

title: The World
description: For nearly threequarters of a century, Pablo Picasso dominated the world of art. From the days of his early youth as a classicist, through his years as cubist and surrealist, his achievements as painter, sculptor, lithographer and ceramist were immense and unique. Although 91 years of age, in recent weeks he had been preparing for yet another exhibition of his work. He seemed eternal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The following is a selection of letters representative of those received in response to an article published two weeks ago describing homeowners complaints in a New Jersey development called Contempra at Monmouth Heights. The development, in Freehold Township, was built by Levitt and Sons, Inc.

title: Dance: A New Phoebe Neville Work
description: Exquisite finish, unhurried presentation and an air of mystery characterize the work of Phoebe Neville. She presented a concert of her dances, including the new Passage in Silence, Tuesday evening at the Cubiculo.

title: Elmwood Park Makes a Name for Itself
description: ELMWOOD PARKThis is one town that cannot he found on any map published before Jan. 1, simply because it was East Paterson until then. The name was changed at that time (after having been approved in a referendum last November) because enough residents in this community of 25,000 people felt they did not want to be identified with Paterson, which is just across the Passaic River. In addition, many people here felt that, since they were at the western end of Bergen County, there was no reason why their borough should be identified with the scat of Passaic County.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In Victor Navasky's piece on the Hollywood Ten (To name or not to name, March 25) John Howard Lawson is quoted as saying it's beyond him where I got the idea that revolutionaries (actually, I said radicals) are candid. This means that The Communist Manifesto is beyond him, for it reads: The Communists disdain to conceal their views and aims. They openly declare that their ends can be attained by the forcible overthrow of all existing social conditions. I quoted this the first time around, on the page of my Thirty Years of Treason that Lawson is talking about. On that same page I also mention conditions under which secrecy is legitimate. I still don't think it was on the level to profess allegiance to Jeffersonian democracy when one's real allegiance was to a Stalinist Communist party. Blacklist is a euphemism indeed for the list of Stalin's victims.

title: Handling of Millions of Complaints and Inquiries From Customers Proves a Challenge for Con Edison
description: On the wall of the Manhattan office where Consolidated Edison handles telephoned complaints, a sign admonishes service representatives to treat every customer as though his problem were your own.

title: New Jersey
John Lionberger Davis, Art Collector, Dies at 94
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 14  John Lionberger Davis, art collector and philanthropist, died yesterday at the Medical Center at Princeton. He was 94 years old and lived here at 41 Independence Drive.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The women's hat industry is climbing out of the depths of a 15year recession and business this year is expected to be the best since the midnineteensixties.

title: Movies
description: JANE FONDA might get a lot farther with President Nixon if she tuned in to the Late Late Show now and then. A few old Jean Arthur films could teach her a thing or two about handling politicians. As admirable as Jane's social consciousness may be, I cannot shake the feeling that a razzledazzle smile from the screenJean might accomplish more.

title: Valerie Boltz Is Betrothed
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., April 14Mr. and Mrs. William Emmet Boltz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Valerie Ann Boltz, to Stephen Bradford Austin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl B. Austin Jr, of Auburn, Me. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Medicine
description: WASHINGTON  Every human heartbeat starts with a little jolt of natural electricity that spreads throughout the heart muscle, making the pumping chambers contract rhythmically and in proper sequence to send a spurt of blood throughout the body.

title: Tall Czechs Band Together
description: PRAGUE (UPI)Membership of the Tall Men's Club in Prague, whose tallest member measures 6 feet 11 inchs, has reached 200. The city also has a club for tall women. Both clubs help members to overcome difficulties connected with their size.

title: Black Swim Club Aims at Olympics
description: If a black swimmer should ever make it to the Olympics, he or she may well owe it all to a BedfordStuyvesant swim club and the youthful dreams of two men from the Brooklyn ghetto.

title: Carole A. Weiss Bride in Bedford
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., April 14 Miss Carole Ann Weiss and Russell Kenneth Kramp were married this afternoon. The Rev. Thomas A. Hughart performed the ceremony in the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

title: World of Luce
description: Books:

title: Dr. H. McLeod Riggins Is Dead
description: MERCER ISLAND, Wash., April 14Dr. H. McLeod Riggins, who had been a leading New York chest physician, researcher and teacher of medicine, retiring seven months ago, died Thursday in Seattle. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Design in Steel Award Winners Named
description: The American Iron and Steel Institute has announced the 28 winners of the sixth biennial Design in Steel Awards. More than 1,000 entries were submitted.

title: The Fall Of America
description: The fall of America is not Ginsberg's real subject in this new book, in spite of his title. He has two subjects: the state of America and the state of his life, the first now almost eclipsing, on the pages, the second. Balked by the roadblock of middle age, Ginsberg marks time around it, baffled, like other poets, by the era when poetry thins out, everything is already known, and everything has stopped happening.

title: Canarsie School Vote Hotly Contested
description: A total of 341 candidates will be vying for 108 seats on Brooklyn's 12 community school boards in the elections that will be held May 1the second such elections since the start of citywide school decentralization in 1970.

title: New Legal Aid Chief Promises To Press for Series of Reforms
description: The Legal Aid Society of New York yesterday selected a new president, and he promised to press for a series of reforms that would promote speedy trials and better representation for indigent criminal defendants, and improved legal services for families with civil grievances and juveniles brought into Family Court.

title: 61 Go to the Orient For Garden Tour
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR  If the weather is good this afternoon, 84  year  old Karl Mann will probably go looking for a golf course, where, he says, My age is my only handicap.

title: Navy, U.S.C. Tied for First In Kennedy Sailing Regatta
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 14Navy and the University of Southern California finished the first day of the ninth John F. Kennedy intercollegiate sailing regatta tied for first place with 10 points each today. The University of Michigan followed with 11 points and Ohio State was next with 12 in the field of 11.

title: An Opening To the East
description: WASHINGTON  Although the emphasis of President Nixon's message to Congress last week was on commerce with this country's traditional trading partners, the President also asked for authority to enter into trade agreements with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries. His message thus set into legislative motion a process that, if accepted, would mark the end of an era in United States foreign economic policy.

title: Delinda Dent Is Betrothed
description: EL PASO, Tex., April 14Mr. and Mrs. Bill Dent have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Delinda Sue Dent, to John David Lybrand. He is the son of Fred Lybrand, chairman of the board and president of the Bank of Commerce in New York, and Mrs. Lybrand of Stamford, Conn. The future bride's father is with Furr Foods as director of general merchandising.

title: Yankee Records
Laotian Premier Pledges To Pursue Peace Accord
description: VIENTIANE Laos, April 14 (UPI)The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, accused the proCommunist Pathet Lao today of undermining that ceasefire, but promised that negotiations would continue.

title: Daniel C. Churchill to Marry Miss Lavinia Cargill Gordon
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., April 14Mr. and Mrs. Prince H. Gordon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lavinia Cargill Gordon, to Daniel Creighton Churchill, son of Creighton Churchill of Portland, Me., and New York and Mrs. James Farley of Cornish, N. H.

title: State Expert Urges Vaccinating Horses
description: HACKENSACKNew Jersey horse owners are advised to have their horses vaccinated against eastern and western encephalitis before June 1. The recommendation comes from Dr. C. Kenneth Jewell, director of the State Department of Agriculture.

title: Cuban Refugee Aid Urged
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 14 (UPI)The Florida House of Representatives has passed a bill urging Congress to speed up the entry into the United States of 30,000 Cuban refugees who fled to Spain in hopes of continuing on to the United States.

title: Conviction For Gross
description: In those days when a shirtsleeved Mayor Lindsay was walking the summer streets of New York's slumskeeping the city cool was the way his admirers described itthe same watchful young men were always nearby, a right arm raised to signal the path to follow through the milling crowds.

title: State Is Fighting New Drug
description: TRENTONA new, potentially dangerous drug that was not included in Governor Cahill's drugabuse reforms, which were enacted three years ago, has appeared in high schools and on college campuses throughout the state.

title: Presidential Powers
description: WASHINGTONCongress failed a second time last week to overturn a spending veto and it looked, as Republican Representative John B. Anderson observed, as though President Nixon was really in the catbird seat in the struggle over spending. But the White House victory on Tuesday may actually have helped to set the stage for the Senate and House of Representatives to regain their constitutional power of the purse by forcing Congress to shop seriously for a new pocketbook.

title: The Short, Sometimes Happy Life of Custer, Idaho
description: CLISTER, Idaho  The empty city is all gray, whites and blacks, and muted browns. A magpie, its iridescent color hidden under folded wings, sits in the lacework of branches of a bare quaking aspen. The house beyond the tree, the McKenzie residence according to a map, is sagging at the rear under a heavy head of snow, its brick chimneys broken and short poles bracing the lee side as it heels before the slow swell of the earth. West, toward the neighboring town of Bonanza two miles away, ski tracks disappear into a thick gray mist of cottonwoods and aspen, the western limit of the ghost town of Custer.

title: PERRY WINS, 82, IN TIGER DEBUT
description: DETROIT, April 14 (AP)Jim Perry, making his Detroit pitching debut, hurled a sevenhitter and the Tigers designated hitter, Gates Brown, hit a threerun double in the fifth inning today to pace an 82 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Most Big Cities May Fail On 75 Clean Air Deadline
description: Most of the nation's big cities, including New York, appear unlikely to be able to meet prescribed Federal standards for clean air by the deadline of May 31, 1975.

title: Stepping Stone to China
description: NEW DELHILenin once said the road to Paris lay through Peking, and there is clear evidence that President Nixon reckoned the political road to better relations with Moscow also lay through the Chinese capital. Improved SinoAmerican relationships obviously provided the United States with a new diplomatic option the Kremlin couldn't ignore.

title: ARMY TRACKMEN TAKE 3WAY MEET
description: WEST POINT, N Y., April 14  Army opened its outdoor track season on an auspicious note today by capturing first places in 14 of 18 events to sweep a triangular meet from Yale and Columbia. The Cadets finished with 126 points to 42 for Yale and 24 for Columbia.

title: Liberal Party Formally Endorses Blumenthal for Mayoral Race
description: Leaders of the Liberal party formally substituted Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal for Robert F. Wagner as their candidate for Mayor yesterday, but their actions will be challenged in the courts as illegal and invalid.

title: NORTHEASTERN, NAVY CREWS WIN
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 14 The Northeastern and Navy varsity crews were the winners here today in two regattas rowed on Princeton's Lake Carnegie under ideal conditions.

title: Don't Write, Walk
description: The first in a nationwide series of Congressional hearings has added a thick new layer of horror stories to those that have been piling up for months about the condition of the United States mailsa condition charitably described by one Congressman as a national disgrace.

title: Home Improvement
description: THIS is the time of year when most homeowners come out of hibernation and start tackling outdoor repair and painting projects. Since many of these jobs call for the use of a ladder of some kind, and since a high percentage of home accidents involve falls off ladders, it is important that the home handyman or woman be familiar with the safety rules recommended for the handling of all ladders.

title: 2 Setbacks Of a Sort
description: President Nixon suffered two apparent defeats last week in his power struggle with Congress. But how significant the consequences will be remains to be seen.

title: BEAME OPPOSES TESTGRADE RULE
description: One item in Mayor Lindsay's Civil Service reform package headed for a showdown in Albany last week when City Controller Abraham D. Beanie asked the State Civil Service Commission to overturn anew rule adopted by its city counterpart earlier this month.

title: A. E. Randall to We Cathy Robinowitz
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., April 14The engagement of Miss Cathy L. Robinowitz to Andrew Edward Randall has been announced by Mrs. Seymour R. Robinowitz, mother of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Randall of Stamford, Conn., and Mill Harbor, St. Croix, Virgin Islands.

title: M.I.T.'s Lightweight Eight Tops Yale, Stays Unbeaten
