The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Martin Dempsey of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Dempsey. A reception was given at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn.

title: PETERMARRIOTT, LED N.B.C. INTERNATIONAL
description: LONDON, April 14  Peter A. C. Marriott, managing director of N.B.C. International, a subsidiary of the National Broadcasting Company for Europe, Africa and the Middle East, died here today after a short illness. His age was 51.

title: Pastor Doubles as a Barber
description: HACKENSACKOutwardly, the Christian Faith Barbershop is a small, nondescript establishment, lying placidly between other small dispensaries and boarding houses on Warren Street.

title: Book Prize Winners Loved Their Subjects
description: Two works that had been many years in the making were named last week as winners of National Book Awards. Arthur M. Wilson won the arts and letters prize for Diderot and James T. Flexner the biography prize for George Washington: Anguish and Farewell (17931799).

title: Lindsay Outraged
description: In American constitutional theory, municipal corporations are traditionally regarded as creatures of the state governments. There is no inherent right of local selfgovernment, and their existence and powers, as well as the designation and powers of their officials, are subject to state control.

title: Maisie Markham dreamed her life like a lucky Emma Bovary
description: The writing of this wispy little novel is by Angus Wilson on holiday from his big family chronicles. The drawings and their captions, which complement rather than illustrate text, are by the biographer and historian Philippe Jullian, whose line is as wiry and nervous as Ronald Searle's and as fastidiously careless as Cocteau's.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: The haves and the havenots
description: There is no doubt that luck is a significant factor in bridge, although not one that can be measured scientifically. And this applies to the duplicate game, in which the luck introduced by the deal is eliminated.

title: Falling in Love With Love
description: lOVE, the Hungarian film directed by Karoly Makk, is very specialprecise and moving and finegrainedand unless you make a point of getting to it within the next several days, you may well miss one of the best films of the year to date. In a season in which excellence has been as rare as snow, it's difficult to understand why Love should be leading such a gypsy life. It's now at the Art Theater in Greenwich Village, where it moved from the Beekman, where it played briefly following its initial oneweek engagement at the First Avenue Screening Room, where it opened five months after its local premiere at last year's New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. It still hasn't taken New York by storm, and perhaps It shouldn't. I'm almost inclined to feel protective towards it, as if a lot of people crowding in on it would in some way be an act of rudeness. Which is to deal in a kind of sentimentality that the film consistently avoids. It's also to mistake the respect Love shows for its characters for cinematic weakness.

title: Dodgers Set Back Braves, 21, in 9th
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (AP) Joe Ferguson singled in Willie Crawford from second base with two out in the ninth tonight, giving the Los Angeles Dodgers and Claude Osteen a 21 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Miss Kathleen Morrone Is Bride of William J. Cherko in Riverdale
description: Miss Kathleen Morrone, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. G. Charles Morrone of Yonkers, was married yesterday afternoon to William John Cherko, son of Mrs. William Cherko, also of Yonkers, and the late Mr. Cherko,

title: Major League Baseball
Public Colleges Say Nixon Budget Imperils Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)The nation's major public colleges and universities said today that the changes proposed for higher education in President Nixon's budget would cause staggering losses of revenue for educational institutions.

title: COUGARS CONQUER COLONELS, 125105
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 14 (AP)The Carolina Cougars, getting 27 points from the American Basketball Association's most valuable player, Billy Cunningham, evened the ABA East Division championship playoffs with a 125105 victory over the Kentucky Colonels today.

title: If You Go
description: to the Museum of the American China Trade, take Exit 22 from the Southeast Expressway (State Route 3) south of Boston. The museum is at 215 Adams Street, Milton, Mass. 02186 (telephone: 6176961815) and it is open from 2 to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday, except holidays, the year round. It is supported by donations and by memberships, which cost from $10 to $1,000 (flag officer) a year. For contribution of $25 or more you become a member of the Keechong Society, named for the Chinese title of Russell and Company, and membership gets you into an annual banquet featuring a speakers program on various aspects of the American China trade.

title: Sea Gull Scavengers Clutter Air Lanes at St. Petersburg
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 12  The air lanes around St. PetersburgClearwater International Airport are becoming increasingly crowded  with sea gulls.

title: Uneasy Host
description: BEIRUTThe Israeli raid on Beirut last week impaled Lebanon on a dilemma: What to do about the Palestinian guerrillas who use Lebanon as a base?

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Geoffrey H. Moore, who used to head the Bureau of Labor Statistics, has written an article about the employment and unemployment figures for a rather obscure Government publication called The Statistical Reporter.

title: Virginia Jean Callan Is Affianced
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 14  Dr. and Mrs. George Milholland Wheatley of Old Brookville have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wheatley's daughter, Miss Virginia Jean Callan, to John Hanley Baxter. He is the son of Mrs. Raymond Stanley Baxter Jr. of Manhasset and Mr. Baxter Jr. of Washington.

title: Key to the Mint Captures Excelsior by Two Lengths
description: Key to the Mint, the ruler of the 3yearold division in 1972, made a successful season's debut at Aqueduct yesterday. The Rokeby Stable's colt competed in the 1mile Excelsior Handicap against four rivals, and he scampered to a twolength triumph over the Bohemia Stable's King's Bishop.

title: Chicago Gang Figure Found Slain in Garage at His Home
description: CHICAGO, April 14 (UPI)Sam DeStefano, a reputed crime syndicate leader who was awaiting trial for murder, was found shot to death today in the garage of his West Side home, the police said.

title: Lost Art World Of Tibet on View
description: NEWARKTo step inside the Newark Museum these days is to be drawn back into the mystical, mountainous and medieval Asiastic theocracy that was early 20thcentury Tibet.

title: Peter Michael Farrell Marries Miss Prudence Hartzler Wear
description: UNION CITY, N.J., April 14Miss Prudence Hartzler Wear, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Wear, was married here this morning to Peter Michael Farrell, son of Eugene G. Farrell and the late Mrs. Margaret F. Reidy Farrell.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two drivers of gypsy cabs attempted to rescue a damsel in distress yesterday morning. The damsel turned out to be a female impersonator, and the cab drivers suffered superficial gunshot wounds for their trouble.

title: Three Men With Disparate Views of City Hall Vie in Race for CouncilmanatLarge Post
description: Three young men who have already spent a lot of time at City Hall are trying to get back there for the next four years by way of the Democratic nomination for Councilman at Large from Manhattan.

title: Pete Herman Is Dead at 77
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 14 (AP)Pete Gulotta, who, as Pete Herman was twice the world bantamweight boxing champion, died last night in a hospital here. He was 77 years old.

title: Lord Vancouver Wins Pan American on Turf
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 14 Walter Blum leaves Florida for Kentucky this weekend, where he will ride the unbeaten Mr. Prospector at Keeneland on Tuesday and, it is hoped, in the Kentucky Derby on May 5.

title: Bede Fischbach Is Bride of S. J. Levinson
description: HARRISON, N.Y., April 14 The marriage of Miss Bede Fischbach, daughter of Jerome Fischbach of Harrison and Mrs. Wilfred. R. Kahn of Hollywood, Fla., and Harrison, to Steven J. Levinson took place at Mrs. Kahn's home here this evening. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Levinson of Brooklyn, New York.

title: Marked for life
description: On Jan. 18, 1970, Paul Cowan was arrested in Brooklyn for possession of marijuana. Two months later the charge was dismissed. In September, 1970, Cowan moved to Boston. He applied for a license to drive a cab. On Feb. 15, 1971, a hack license was issued, but a week later, on Feb. 22, he was ordered to report to the Boston Police Department's Bureau of General Services and informed that his license was being revoked. The reason: a routine check with the Federal Bureau of Investigation had disclosed that an open charge of possession of narcotics was pending against Cowan in New York. He protested that the charge had been dismissed. No good. On March 12, 1971, Paul Cowan received formal notice that his license had been revoked because he was not a suitable person to be so licensed. Cowan's story is unusual in only one respect. He found out why he lost his job. Most people who are denied jobs because of arrest records are never told the reasons.

title: Special Dishes For Passover
description: Anyone attempting Passover cooking for the first time had best put beaters in order, have an unlined copper bowl for beating whites and practice separating eggs. No holiday, not even Easter, relies on eggs as much as Passover. At Easter, they are mainly symbolic and decorative. During Passover, when all leavens are proscribed, eggs perform the essential chemistry in the preparation of traditional foods, as well as being one of the ceremonial morsels.

title: 25YearOld Swedish PainKilling Drug Is Now Used in Treating Heart Patients
description: STOCKHOLM, April 14Twentyfive years ago Swedish chemists marketed a new drug that since has been injected into tens of millions of people to deaden rapidly the pain of dental extractions and numb the skin before minor surgery.

title: Guggenheim Museum to Review Plan to Alter Building's Facade
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum may abandon its plan to alter the facade of its building, on Fifth Avenue between 88th and 89th Streets, to create a new lobby and a restaurant.

title: Green Light for the Railroads
description: TRENTONBillsigning ceremonies authorizing emergency state subsidy payments to New Jersey's bankrupt railroads have become almost routine occasions in the Governor's office. Although there have been dozens of them during the last two administrations, they have been marked by recurring railroad commuter crises.

title: If YOu Go
description: to Custer, or to any other snowbound ghost town, know what you're doing. Use crosscountry skis or snowshoes, know your waxes and be sure you understand the mechanics of avalanches; there are several tricky slide areas near Custer.

title: Computer Will Do A Town's Assessing
description: SUFFERN, N. Y.The State Board of Equalization and Assessment and the Town of Ramapo are embarked on a pilot program designed to pro. duce the nation's most equitable and uptodate propertytax assessment system.

title: BRITTLE WINS ON 4 AT SOUTHERN PINES
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., April 14 (AP)Clay Brittle rode three winners and another horse that finished in a dead heat for first at the Stoneybrook Races today.

title: Canada's Senate, Often With Few Tasks to Keep It Occupied, Hears Demands to Reform or Perish
description: OTTAWA, April 14  In Canada nearly everyone pokes fun at the Senate, including some of the Senators.

title: A Boycott of Chanel No. 5 Urged by Humane Groups
description: The Society for Animal Rights, Inc., called last week for a nationwide boycott of Chanel No. 5 perfume on the ground that the civet cat musk oil used as one ingredient is obtained from animals allegedly treated cruelly.

title: Dr. Wesley Megaw, 82, Pastor Of West End Church, Is Dead
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 14The Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, who became pastor emeritus of the West End Presbyterian Church of New York in 1967, died today here, where he had recently made his home. His age was 82.

title: Epileptic in a Landmark Case
description: TRENTONJohn Langenbach of Plainfield has been an epileptic all his life. Until last August, there was little he could do about the discrimination he faced while finding employment, serving in the military or enjoying his hobby of parachute jumping.

title: Bill to Permit Acupuncture Sent to Nevada Governor
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., April 14The Nevada Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would make Nevada the first state to sanction the use of acupuncture on patients on a fullscale basis.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT NIXON sought authority to cut, raise or cancel tariffs. He urged Congress not to tamper with tax rules permitting corporations to withhold income taxes on their foreign subsidiaries.  Gold closed in London at $90 an uunce at the weekend, down from $90.75 the week before.

title: Envoys in Cairo Expect Arab AntiU.S. Sabotage
description: CAIRO, April 14 Moderate Arab diplomats from many countries are convinced that the Arab world is being swept by a ground swell of hatred for the United States that could lead to a rash of uncontrollable sabotage operations such as this morning's attack on the American oil terminal in southern Lebanon.

title: Two Bouts for Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 14 (AP)  Esteban de Jesus, fourthranked lightweight, and Victor Ortiz, fifth ranked junior welter, will head separate boxing cards here in the next two weeks. De Jesus meets Johnny Gant of Washington Monday and Ortiz takes on Saul Mamby of Neweyork April 23.

title: Hispanic Catholics Seeking Diocesan Recognition of Culture
description: PATERSON  Spanishspeaking Catholics in the Paterson Diocesetheir number ranges from an estimated 50,000 to 120,000, depending on whom one asksare organizing to obtain diocesan recognition of our own linguistic, cultural and religious needs and differences.

title: Pop
description: AFTER checking around, one would almost have to say that 1972 was the year of the greening of the multimilliondollar recording industrythe Al Greening, that is. This intense, soulstirring 26yearold brother with the singing ?? that he calls velvet funk, gathered up endoftheyear awards by the handful. Billboard, for instance, not only designated him Top Singles Male Artist, but selected his monster single, Let's Stay Together (over two million sold), as Top Soul Song. Of course, all the awardgivers did was to verify what Al's fans already knewas witnessed by his record of five consecutive gold singles and two gold albumsthat Al Green is a mindblowing superstar who has sho nuff his stuff together.

title: Hot stuff
description: The Hunam Restaurant created a sensation last year when it introduced the cuisine of China's Hunan Province to New York. Here are two dishes from the Hunam's repertory. Hacked chicken is a fiery cold appetizer that will make an impression at any cocktail hour, and it is easy to make. Beef with water cress is more of a challenge to the cook but less spicy. It provides an excellent opportunity to find out how good water cress tastes cooked.

title: TIMELESS MOMENT TAKES PRINCESS
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 14 (AP)Rokeby Stable's Timeless Moment got through on the inside under a welljudged ride today by Carlos Barrera to win the $26,300 Princess Stakes by 3 lengths over Jim Duncan at Garden State Park. A halflength back was Actuality.

title: RESIDENTS IRKED AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., April 14Spokesmen for the permanent residents of Wounded Knee said today that they would give the Government three weeks to end the occupation of the village by insurgent Indians before taking action themselves. Militants have been holding the hamlet for 46 days.

title: Auto Group Selects Granatelli Man of Year
description: Andy Granatelli, a car owner whose entries have won the Indianapolis 500 and the Daytona 500, was honored last night as auto racing's Man of the Year by the Auto Racing Fraternity of New York. The occasion was the fraternity's annual achievement awards dinner at the SheratonNew Yorker Hotel. The fraternity is a philanthropic organization that helps members of the racing community who are in neednot only disabled drivers, but also stewards, corner workers, mechanics and others.

title: Family Fight, Texas Style
description: DALLASA threeyearold interfamily fight over the oil resources of the Dallas billionaire, H. L. Hunt, is moving into another chapter in Federal court here next month.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Sports Week
description: BASEBALL

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IN her review of Last Tango in Paris, Grace Glueck has done what I fear doingallowed honest commitment to the women's movement to blot out other subtleties, other meanings. She sees the film only as a male sex fantasy exposing women's real sexual stetus. She finds director Bernardo Bertolucci's main theme to be See what happens [death] when you strip yourself bare for a woman?

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Bowery Savings Bank has purchased from Joseph E. Levine, the motionpicture producer, the entire eastern blockfront on Third Avenue between 60th and 61st Streets.

title: Flyers Win Opener From Canadiens, 54
description: MONTREAL, April 14Rick MacLeish rifled a hard shot past the Montreal goalie, Ken Dryden, with less than three minutes gone in suddendeath overtime tonight to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 54 upset victory over the Canadiens.

title: A Return to Morality
description: How can any American contribute to building an adequate defense in the face of an everexpanding inflation, resulting from forty years of governmental extravagance on voteluring bureaucracies?

title: Janet Blaylock Wed
description: KINDERHOOK, N. Y., April 14 Miss Janet Lynn Blaylock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Blaylock of North Chatham, was married here this afternoon to Henry Alexander Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Phillips of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Edward Fiebke performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: 3 AREA COLLEGES FACING CENSURE
description: Three metropolitanarea in stitutions are among the 11 colleges and universities that ?? to be considered for censure by the American Association ?? University Professors at the ?? ganization's annual meeting be ginning April 26 in St. Louis.

title: Paris Fight Date Changed
description: PARIS, April 14 (AP)A 10round middleweight fight between Max Cohen of France and Tony Mundine of Australia was postponed today from May 3 to May 14 because Cohen has the flu, the promoter reported.

title: Johansson and Hsi Reach World Table Tennis Final
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, April 14 (AP)Kjell Johansson of Sweden and Hsi EnTing of China each defeated Yugoslavs tonight and moved into the men's final of the world table tennis championships.

title: Chief Gardener in Brooklyn
description: Long after the Brooklyn Botanic Garden has been closed for the night the lights are still burning in some of the offices and labs of the 63year old institution at 1000 Washington Avenue.

title: Offshoots of an OffCenter Cartwheel
description: PART 2 of Phase 1 of the Government's Great Silver Sale closes April 30. When Part 1 closed, last Jan. 31, roughly one million Carson City silver dollars dated 1882, 83 and 84 remained unsold from the General Services Administration's original stockpile of 1.7 million CCmintmarked cartwheels bearing those dates. So far, no reports have been received as to whether Part 2 is turning out to be a greater success  or, as some would phrase it, a lesser failure  than Part I was. But Part 1 is already assured a place in numismatic annals that has nothing to do with sales figures

title: Margaret Fleder to Wed
description: HARRISON, N. Y., April 14 Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Fleder have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ellen Fleder, to Robert Alan Feinman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Feinman of White Plains. An August wedding is planned. Miss Fleder is a senior at the University of Arizona. Her fianc, who attended Arizona, is a news commentator with radio station KOPO in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Photography
description: THE French have a phrase for it; haute vulgarisation  which means translating difficult and original discoveries into more easily understandable terms, but all on a very high levels It differs from popularization in the highness of the level aimed for and achieved. Haute vulgarisation is useful and necessary work in science and philosophy. It is not at all easy to do, and the results are often admirable. But in art there is often a point, too quickly reached, where haute vulgarisation lapses into chic.

title: E. R. Detchon 3d to Wed Miss Susan McGlothlin
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Miss Susan Louis McGlothlin, a founder and managing director of Fte Accomplie Inc., a coordinator of business entertainment in New York, will he married in June to Elliott R. Detchon 3d, an investment officer with Brown Brothers Harriman in New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Detchon Jr. of New York.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TAKES DAVIS CUP DOUBLES
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 14 (AP)South Africa won the Davis Cup tennis doubles today and trailed Argentina, 21, in their series.

title: Police Believe Killer Used Garrote on Canarsie Woman
description: A 32yearold Canarsie housewife found dead outside the door of her secondfloor apartment at 1459 East 89th Street late Friday afternoon had been garrotted some 12 hours earlier, police believe.

title: Fire Warden Urges CleanUp of Debris
description: TRENTONNow is the time for property owners in forested areas to remove debris and flammable materials to help guard against an outbreak of fires.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Judy Klemesrud, no mean wordsmith herself, complains in this space (under the heading One Reader Writes) that authors should not be allowed to review the work of other authors. She leaves dancing in the haunted air implications of  incest?  The fix is in?  The bookreview editor passing out freebies to his pals? As editor of Book World (before we folded) I'd like to enter a rebuttal.

title: Samuel I. Newhouse Jr. Weds Mrs. Victoria de Ramel Here
description: The marriage of Mrs. Victoria Benedict de Ramel to Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., publishing director of Vogue, took place here Friday evening. Civil Court Judge Alvin F. Klein performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Hansen.

title: The Lone Ranger Lives!
description: IT'S like the echo of an echo: Return with us now to those thrilling days of yesteryear . And you go willingly, eagerly, buckling on the heavy gunbelt studded with silver bullets, threading your way through your own yesterdays to yesteryear. Thundering hoofbeats, quickening, pulsebeats, the Masked Rider of the Plains, Silvercup Breadit's almost too much, nostalgia fansthe Lone Ranger rides again! I swear it on my old StrombergCarlson.

title: PROFITS ON STOCKS REPAID BY VATICAN
description: VENTURA, California., April 14 (AP)  An investment adviser representing the Vatican has paid a $308,000 settlement to Vetco Offshore Industries, Inc., here as compensation for shortterm trading profits in Vetco stock, the company said.

title: Belgrade Professors Stall Party Attack on Colleagues
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14Professors at Belgrade University's department of philosophy, which is under growing criticism as a center of opposition to Communist party control, thwarted a showdown meeting yesterday by declining to appear.

title: The Ordeal of Rebecca Harding
description: With this book, Life in the Iron Mills (Feminist Press; paper, $1.95), in my hand, I feel I am standing in a corridor of echoes. Why should that be? Partly, I think, because of Tillie Olsen, who wrote the biographical interpretation attached to, and nearly half again as long as, the book. A careful, caring, almost heroic work of rediscovery and rehabilitation. (Tillie Olsen once had fellowship to work on her writing at the Radcliffe Institute for Women, where now I, and others, are struggling to do the same. When she was there, she wrote a wrenching account, called Silences, about what makes artists fall mute and how this works on women most of all. Silences also have their echoes.)

title: Historical Society Finds a Way to Preserve the Old
description: WILTON, Conn.To rescue some of the more interesting old buildings here from wreckers and developers, the Wilton Historical Society has been moving the buildings when necessary, fixing them up and leasing them to commercial and residential tenants.

title: The farm business
description: JEFFERSON, Iowa. On the prairies, seasons of adversity have always produced a variety of rough humor, and this spring, with the deepest, thickest mud in memory, is no exception. Farmers who use this central Iowa town as their processing and banking center tell the one about finding their neighbor all alone in his sodden feed lot and up to his armpits in mud.

title: the traveler's world
description: HOLY WEEK is usually a time of unholy frustration for thousands of wouldbe travelers to Bermuda as well as for the Bermuda Department of Tourism and Trade Development, the Bermuda hoteliers and the four scheduled airlines that fly from the United States to the island resort. In terms of frustration the Easter holiday is usually worse than the Christ mas, Thanksgiving, Washington's birthday, Labor Day and July Fourth holidays. The problem is how to match potential Bermuda visitors months in advance to airplane seats and then, with passage insured, to hotel rooms. The solution is not easy, although this Easter's Bermuda crunch may be eased slightly as the result of a recent conference.

title: To the Greeks second place was unforgivable
description: The Greeks had no word for sport. Thus H. A. Harris falsestarts in his survey of the games people never played. He begins by defining the English term, which, from its earliest usage, has connoted frivolity and triviality. But the Greek for competition is agonia, which even in classical times also meant mental anguish. It was the opposite of sport.

title: Portrait of a man and the satellites he attracted
description: We know, from the example quoted in Graham Greene's autobiography, that Peter Quennell could write, at the age of 17, letters so graceful in their witty penetration as to evoke the pages of Laurence Sterne; and the succession of Quennell's booksamong them portraits of Byron, Ruskin and the young Alexander Pope  have themselves chronicled his development into the most cultivated, stylish and knowledgeable of contemporary English literary historians. Mr. Quennell is coeditor of History Today, a publication distinguished equally for its scholarship and its prose; and his own essays, some of them collected in the volume The Singular Preference, are models of perception, compression and a style that resembles Hogarth's classic line of beauty in being always elegant and never precious.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column.

title: 14 Hits Blasted Off Peterson F. Alou Homers
description: The Boston Red Sox, who have played only the Yankees so far this season, defeated them again yesterday, 31, for their fourth victory in four games.

title: Investigator for Nadjari Is Charged With Assault
description: A charge of felonious assault was lodged at the Bay Ridge police station in Brooklyn yesterday against George H. Baccash, a 25yearold investigator for Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: Elective Attract Students In Queens
description: A visitor to Grover Cleveland High School these days might encounter a medium conducting a seance or an instructor teaching a class in his specialty, horror literature.

title: Boycott
description: WASHINGTON  They came in force, and they came in angerbut not in defeat. For the housewives who gathered here last week after leading a sevenday boycott against meat knew that though they had failed to beat down prices they had constructed a new consumer power, and one to be reckoned with.

title: Television This Week
Library Acquires the Newark News Files
description: NEWARKThe entire morgue of The Newark Evening News, a collection that includes microfilms and millions of newspaper clipping and photographs chronicling life in New Jersey for nearly 100 years, has been acquired by the Newark Public Library.

title: Bill Offered To Save Wetlands In Queens
description: State Assemblyman John G. Lopresto of Queens has submitted a proposed amendment to the Environmental Conservation Law designed to insure the ecological wellbeing of such areas in Queens as Powells Cove, Fort Totten, Little Neck Bay, Alley Park and Udall's Cove.

title: Seder Tomorrow to Mark Beginning of Passover
description: The question Why is this night different from all other nights? will be asked by the youngest child in Jewish households shortly after sundown tomorrow as the weeklong celebration of Passover begins.

title: Marilyn King Plans Nuptials
description: GREENSBURG, Pa., April 14Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. King have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Anne King, to Douglas Bryan Bellaire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bellaire of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Headliners
description: Donald F. Cawley leaned over the microphone and told the news conference last week: It will be difficult to follow in the shoes of a man I consider to be the finest administrator of police in the entire nation. That man is Patrick V. Murphy, 52, who announced that he would retire as New York City's Police Commissioner to head the Police. Foundation in Washington, effective, May 7. Mr. Murphy had signaled last month that he would not serve after Mayor Lindsay, who appointed him, ended his term this year. It was no surprise that the Mayor picked Mr. Cawley, the chief of patrol, as the new Commissioner. The Mayor was high on Mr. Murphy and Mr. Murphy was high on Mr. Cawleywho, at age 43, will be the youngest head of the department since the city expanded to its present boundaries in 1898.

title: The Portrait of Queens Artist
description: The Queens County Art and Cultural Center in Flushing Meadow Park is in part a dream, in part a realityor perhaps it is a dream that has acquired a little corner in reality.

title: NEW RIZZO FIGHT: PHILADELPHIA AID
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14A proposal by business interests to make private contributions to specific programs of this financially hardpressed city has stirred a new tempest around Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, who backs the plan.

title: Son to the Massauas Jr.
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. George J. Massaua Jr., of Bayside, Queens, on April 7 at the Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L. I. The child has been named Steven Scott. Mrs. Massaua is the former Miss Jean McCormick of Mineola, L. I. Her husband is manager of press relations for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporations.

title: Merrill Matthews Wed to Colleague
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., April 14Miss Merrill Jeanne Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Basil W. Matthews of Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of Old Greenwich, and William Beveridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Beveridge of Yonkers, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Merton Libby performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: Keystone Prospering in Clifton
description: CLIFTON  The Keystone Camera Division of Berkey Photo, Inc., a company that has had a remarkable growth rate since 1967, will add 80,000, square feet to its plant here by the end of the month, and by October it expects to add 600 employes to the 1,400 already on its Clifton payroll.

title: Miss Alexandra Mills Is Bride of T.J. Devine
description: HOBE SOUND, Fla., April 14Miss Alexandra Mills, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Wynne Mills of Locust Valley, L. I., and Hobe Sound, was married here this afternoon to Thomas J. Devine, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Adrian G. Devine of Rochester. The ceremony was performed by Dean N.R.H. Moor in Christ Memorial Episcopal Chapel.

title: 3 Track Stars to Speak At Luncheon Tomorrow
description: Three of the metropolitan area's outstanding track and field athletes will speak tomorrow when the Track Writers Association resumes weekly luncheon meetings at Mamma Leone's.

title: Hail to Postal Service People
description: United States Postal Service is patting itself on the back. The Postal Service is patting itself on the back with tentennew stamps picturing the men and women who do the things the Postal Service does. On the gummed backsides of the stamps are texts with statistics  and statistics and statisticsabout the doings of the men and women who do what the Postal Service does.

title: SHIFT ON EMISSION MAY COST DRIVERS
description: The year's delay granted auto makers in complying with rigorous emission rules appears to have increased chances that cars driven into the city's business districts will have to be equipped with a $175 device to help meet overall cleanair standards.

title: After Two Weeks, Feelings Are Bitter on Both Sides in Hawaii's First Teachers Strike
description: HONOLULU, April 14Three years ago Hawaii passed a law that permits public employes to organize labor unions and call strikes if bargaining fails to settle disputes over wages, hours and working conditions. have provided teachers with preparation time, a free period of 40 to 50 minutes during the day to prepare class work for the remaining periods.

title: Pan American Chart
50 Years of Stadium Memories
description: April 18, 1923, was a cool and somewhat cloudy Wednesday in New York. At the Strand theater, Dorothy Gish was appearing in the film The Silent Shawl. On the Rivoli screen, Pola Negri in Bella Donna, and at the Rialto, Gloria Swanson in Prodigal Daughters. At Keith's Palace, the S. S. Leviathan Orchestra, which would soon furnish music on the world's largest ship. On the front pages: reparations payments and Prohibition.

title: A Rival Sinks as N.Y.A.C. Wins
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 14Within hailing distance of Execution Light, a rocky shoal feared by sailing captains as long ago as Colonial days, one of four shells competing in the Hughes Cup regatta went down this morning. The boat, a Donoratico sectional eight, manned by members of the Penn Athletic Club of Philadelphia, sank almost 10 minutes after the start of the annual 4mile race across Long Island Sound.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: EAST DIVISION

title: New Panasonic Headquarters
description: This 250,000squarefoot office building and a 500,000squarefoot warehouse and distribution plant will be the new headquarters of the Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, which imports Panasonic electronic products. The complex will be on a 50acre site in the Free Zone Center, an office, industrial and residential development being built on Route 3 in Secaucus, N.J. The buildings were designed by Raymond, Rado, Caddy and Bonington of New York. The brokers in the $50million lease transaction between Matsushita and Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc., the center's developer, were Harry Macklowe and Steve Ifshin of Wolfe & Macklowe, also of New York. Matsushita expects to complete its move by 1975. It will give up 150,000 square feet of office space in the Pan Am Building and 300,000 square feet of warehouse space at several sites in Queens.

title: Robin Smith Married
description: Miss Robin Yvonne Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Smith of Rapid City, S.D., was married last evening to Sgt. Howard May, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving May of Howard Beach, Queens. Rabbi Fredric S. Dworkin performed the ceremony at the Avenue R. Temple in Brooklyn. The bridegroom, a Vietnam veteran, is stationed at Ellsworth Air Force Base, S.D.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Barbara Wilson Married
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 14 Miss Barbara Jean Wilson and Earl Geoffrey Littlehale were married here this afternoon in St. Alban's Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Morett. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Homer O. Wilson of Washington, Ind. Her husband is the son of Robert F. Littlehale of Columbus and Mrs. Barbara Bragg Littlehale of New York.

title: Mr. Fischer, be seated
description: If you have ever had to kill time in an air terminal, chances are that you sat in an Eames molded plastic chair. That leathercushioned armchair in which Bobby Fischer swiveled and tilted before the television cameras at Reykjavik while Boris Spassky brooded motionless was an Eames chair designed in 1960 for the old TimeLife lobby. (Spassky eventually got one, too. The Herman Miller Corp., which has produced Eames furniture since 1946, airfreighted a duplicate chair to him in Iceland as a gift.) And the lounge chair with ottoman in soft black leather on a rosewood frame that is the hallmark of contemporary intellectual litism is an Eames design.

title: Rare Eagle In Zoo Here Seeks Mate
description: The Bronx Zoo is playing marriage broker with its monkeyeating eagle these days, but It is not making any bets on results.

title: Religious Fetes
description: Today marks the opening of a week of religious observances for Christians, Jews and Moslems.

title: Johncock, Foyt Pace Qualifiers For Trentonian Split 300 Today
description: TRENTON, April 14Gordon Johncock, who promises to be one of the hottest shoes in the 1973 championship trial of the United States Auto Club, won the pole position today for tomorrow's running of the Trentonian Split 300.

title: A Vest Pocket Flower Border
description: EVERY gardener needs a vestpocket flower border. In fact, for reasons of space, cost, or labor, some gardeners must restrict themselves to a small area to the exclusion of all others. But even the fortunate gardener who is able to have a large family vegetable plot and a sweeping English perennial border usually has space near the outdoor sitting area.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: When the Congo was the Belgian Congo, Dr. Michael Kenney was sent there by the Belgian Government to study tropical diseases. He took his young wife along, and what she studied was the natives. She learned Bangala, the language of the region, and with great tact introduced herself into the lives of Molali, the palmwine merchant; his two charming children; Mafuta, the chief with a roving eye; two nasty witch doctors; and an entire village (mboka) of intricate characters. Mrs. Kenney recalls her adventures in this other time and place with charm and feeling; possibly she has made an amateur's contribution to anthropology by writing this memoir.

title: Blancas Posts 66 for 202 and Increases Lead to 4 Shots
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 14 (UPI)Homero Blancas posted his third straight round in the 60's, a fiveunderpar 66, to raise his lead in the $150,000 Monsanto open golf tournament to four strokes today.

title: Circus Aerialist Dies in Fall
description: STOCKHOLM, April 14 (AP) A West German circus artist, 32yearold Rosita Winter, fell to her death from a 164foothigh swing last night before her husband and hundreds of shocked spectators.

title: Radio
NIGHT'S EVE WINS AT SUFFERN SHOW
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., April 14Night's Eve, a 12yearold bay mare owned and ridden by 14yearold Kitty Ford of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club at Darien, Conn., won the regular working hunter championship today at the Catamount Hunt's horse show.

title: Recoding
description: No composer has ever been able to hide behind his music. I had a teacher who even claimed he could give piercingly accurate character analyses of his students simply after a year of correcting their harmony exercises. One hardly needs to be a professor of harmony to psych out Antonin Dvorakfrom all accounts he appears to have been as totally direct, genuine and lovable a personality as his music seems to indicate.

title: Garden
description: FERTILIZER TRENDS Feeding plants these days is much more complicated than it once was. There are ever so many products on the market and ever so many kinds of products. Gardeners should do some homework before they go shopping.

title: Criminals At Large
description: One of the more gripping, bitter books about the cold war is THE MUSHROOM CAVE by Robert Rosenblum (Doubleday, $4.95). It is an espionage novel. It also is a merciless comment on presentday morality. When it comes to the power play, Their side is no different from Our side. Dr. Johnson was once asked which of two preachers he preferred. Sir, rumbled the Doctor, there is no determining the point of precedency between a louse and a flea. That is Rosenblum's attitude about the K.G.B.and the C.I.A.

title: Newspaper Official Quits
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 14 (AP)Charles A. Wahlheim, executive vice president for operations of HarteHanks Newspapers, Inc., resigned this week, the company announced. The reason for the resignation, termed amicable, was put as policy differences between Mr. Wahlheim and several other members of the board of directors.

title: AngelsRangers Rained Out
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 14 (AP)The American League baseball game tonight between the California Angels and Texas Rangers was rained out and rescheduled as the second half of a doubleheader tomorrow.

title: M'KAY APPOINTMENT IS EXPECTED TODAY
description: Mayor Lindsay is expected to announce formally today the appointment of Dean Robert B. McKay of the New York University School of Law as chairman of the City's Board of Correction. He will succeed William J. vanden Heuvel, who resigned to challenge the incumbent Manhattan District Attorney, Frank S. Hogan, in the June Democratic primary.

title: At The Wall in Warsaw,
description: WARSAW. Several weeks ago, Jack P. Eisner, a New York businessman specializing in foreign trade, arrived here to confer with Polish officials on exportimport matters. Visits of this kind are increasing with the improved political climate between Poland and the United States. As Mr. Eisner ate breakfast in the restaurant of the Europeski Hotel, he saw others like him who had also come to talk business.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS A WELFARE BILI
description: ALBANY, April 14Governor Rockefeller submitted legislation today to have the state gradually take over the administration of welfare and Medicaid programs that are now run locally.

title: Mounted Protesters Fail to Discourage Horsemeat Shoppers
description: WESTBROOK, Conn., April 14Equestrian lovers picketed Carlson's House of Choice Meats here today to protest the emergence of horsemeat as a dinner table delight, but there was no indication they nagged customers consciences.

title: 5Show Dog Circuit Opens Wednesday
description: The fiveshow Cherry Blossom circuit opens on Wednesday, with the Warrenton Kennel Club event on the 4H Junior Fairgrounds, on Route 55, between The Plains and Marshall, Va., and it ends a week from tomorrow, with the Harford County fixture on the grounds of the Harford Community College on Route 22 in Bel Air, Md.

title: Power Wrns Relay As Centrowitz Runs 4:12.8 Anchor Mile
description: Matt Centrowitz ran 4 minutes 12.8 seconds for his anchor mile leg to lead Power Memorial to victory in the distance medley relay in the New York Diocese Catholic High Schools Athletic Association relay carnival yesterday at the Mount St. Michael field in the Bronx. The Panthers were timed in 10:29.5.

title: Naval Board Elects Head
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 14 (AP)  Joseph S. Sinclair, a Warwick, R. I., business executive, has been elected chairman of the United States Naval Academy Board of Visitors. He replaces H. Ross Perot.

title: Janet Williams Is Bride
description: NORTH SYRACUSE, April 14 The Luther Memorial Lutheran Church was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Janet Marion Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Williams to John Tweedy Garnjost, son of Stanley L. Garnjost of Woodbridge, Va., and Mrs. Dorothy T. Garnjost of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Eric C. Pearson, who also read a prayer written for the couple by the Rev. Ralph E. Peterson, pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York.

title: Nancy Linzer Fiancee Of Louis J. Freedman
description: Miss Nancy Linzer and Louis Jay Freedman will he married next month in Cedarhurst, L. I.

title: Jersey City Egyptians Keep Customs
description: JERSEY CITY  Since 1965, several thousand Egyptians have settled here, leaving many traditions of their leisurely homeland behindbut keeping a few alive.

title: DELIVERERS AT NEWS HALT WORK 2 HOURS
description: A twohour walkout by 175 newspaper deliverers at The Daily News halted distribution of 200,000 papers last night in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island.

title: INMATES PRAISE PRENATAL CLINIC
description: A prenatal clinic that has been operating at Rikers Island for nearly five months now has drawn praise from hundreds of inmates who say they now receive immediate medical attention during pregnancy.

title: Donna L. Bascom Will Be Married
description: SYOSSET, L. I., April 14 Miss Donna Lynn Bascom, who expects to graduate in June from Dartmouth College as a member of the first class to include women, plans to be married in September to Geoffrey Posselt Clear, who was graduated cum laude from Dartmouth last year.

title: '74 WHEAT LIMITS SET FOR FARMERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)The Agriculture Department formally proclaimed 1974 wheat marketing controls today, but officials hope the program will never be activated.

title: An Excess of Apartments
description: CORAM, L. I.  Suffolk County builders and apartment managers, who were basking in the euphoria of a clamor for apartments throughout Suffolk County two years ago, have come upon hard times and, unlike their counterparts in neighboring Nassau County, are facing one of the gravest crises in their history.

title: In Cold Print: What Is an Editor Worth?
description: It was nice to hear that the Roger Klein Award for Editing went this year to Jim Landis, a young Morrow editor who told Publishers Weekly An editor is really a parasite  he makes more money than many of his writers. The award, which carries a $1,000 cash prize with it, goes to a tradebook editor under 40 who has shown special talent in discovering and/or getting the best work out of his authors.

title: Bridal for Christy Carpenter And H. A. Levin Is Set in June
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Carpenter of Washington and Austin, Tex., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christy Carpenter, to Harvey Alan Levin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Mark Levin of Sewickley, Pa.

title: SHIELDS AND CLARKE ARE SAILING LEADERS
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 14 Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. of the home club sailed Pumpkin into a 12point Interclub Class lead today with a low score of 28 points or eight races in the opening of the annual spring regatta of frostbite dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

title: Anne Coleman And Newsman Are Wed Here
description: Miss Anne Norton Coleman was married here yesterday afternoon to Polk Laffoon 4th, a feature writer for The Cincinnati Post and TimesStar. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony in the Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church.

title: A secret addiction, snatched from household duties
description: The tradition of women as poets has not been easily accessible. This rich, necessarily incomplete anthology is the first of its kind, to my knowledge, reaching back to the anonymous AngloSaxon and continuing through to the present. I wish that more of us were here: both those who succeeded in doing their work, and those who remain unrealized. I am grateful for what is here, as all women concerned with our imaginative past must be grateful; but I'm appalled at what I know has been lost to us.

title: OMAN USES WATER TO COMBAT REBELS
description: SALALA, Oman, April 14 (Reuters)  Government forces fighting leftist guerrillas in the forgotten war of Oman have established a new front in the form of a waterdrilling rig deep in rebelheld territory.

title: New and Recommended
description: A BOOK OF CHANGE, by Frederick Morgan. (Scribner's, $7.95.) Poems written to master the emotions, as all good poetry does and that are public, transparent and eloquent.

title: Rabbit Roundup
description: So who needs the Easter Bunny? How about most of the children (Christian or not) in the Western world, where the legendary rabbit has been bringing and hiding the eggs for centuries? And just as Santa Claus has had various names and roles, there are different kinds of Easter Bunniesor so Wiltrud Roser amusingly informs us in EVERYTHING ABOUT EASTER RABBITS (Thomas Y. Crowell, $3.95). There is the Genuine Original Easter Rabbit, who looks like an ordinary rabbit, but lays eggs and then hides them in high grasses and under bushes near the homes of all children everywhere. Or the Hardworking Easter Rabbit who since he can't lay eggs, buys or begs them from the hens, so that he and his family can dye and decorate them in brilliant colors and deliver them to good children on Easter. Then there's the WorldTraveling Easter Bunny, who buys candy eggs, jelly beans and chocolate bunnies at the Easter Rabbit department store. Being a mod fellow, he makes his deliveries by motorbike, ship and helicopter. The author has illustrated her pleasantly facetious explanation with drawings that, while not with Easter, are zesty and cheerful, lively and humorous.

title: Arthur Daley
description: From a purely chronological standpoint it will be three days early, but that will seem of little consequence today when the Yankees toss a gigantic birthday party to mark the opening of the Yankee Stadium 50 years ago this week. It will signify the start of a golden anniversary year that the planners would love to see end with the flourish of a World Series. Once upon a time that almost would have been taken for granted. But not any more.

title: Child to the Finkelsteins
description: A daughter was born April 6 to Mr. and Mrs. Allen Finkelstein of Holliswood, Queens, at the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset. Mrs. Finkelstein is the former Miss Judith Stutman.

title: Toby Kleiner to Wed
description: NORTH WOODMERE, L. I., April 14Miss Toby Kleiner and Lloyd Scott Bashkin, students at Syracuse University, plan to marry in December. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kleiner have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr, and Mrs. Jules Bashkin of Fairfield, Conn.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 14 (Reuters)at least 12 people died in an earthquake that shook this Central American republic today, the Government reported.

title: Lawyer Elected to Head BlindnessPrevention Group
description: Thomas R. Moore, a partner in the law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, was elected president of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness at a meeting last week of the society's board of directors at the Roosevelt Hotel.

title: Ecology Study Due In Route 287 Fight
description: WAYNEA 12year battle over the proposed route of Interstate Highway 287 through Passaic and Bergen Counties may reach a climax this month if the Federal Highway Administration is on schedule in issuing its final review of the environmental impact of the sixlane road.

title: MISS KAZMIERSKI LEADS BY 4 SHOTS
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 14 (UPI) Joyce Kazmierski braved gusty desert winds today to shoot a oneunderpar 71 and increase her lead to four strokes after three rounds of the $135,000 ColgateDinah Shore golf tournament. The 27yearold pro from Detroit had a 54hole total of 211.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Along with a deep draught of cold maple sap, a pan of fresh alewife roe fried in butter or the arrival of the first terns along the Eastern Seaboard, there is nothing more symbolic of spring than the male woodcock's mating flight and song.

title: PUZZLES
Stoopers Cash In at OTB Parlors
description: It was only 2 P.M., but Slim had already found $27 worth of refundable tickets discarded by careless or confused OTB patrons.

title: RAY W. HERRICK, 82, WAS FORD ASSOCIATE
description: TECUMSEH, Mich., April 14 (UPI)Ray Wesley Herrick, an industrialigt and onetime associate of Henry Ford, died today at the Tecumseh Memorial Hospital, which his contributions helped build. He was 82 years old.

title: New & Novel
description: Will Henry conducts his excursions into Americana from the inside looking out. Whether it is a horsesoldier's lot on San Juan Hill or the end game of the horseback Indian, his recreations of old adventures carry a rare essence of immediacy. In The Bear Paw Horses, Henry's empathetic flair is applied to the disgraceful last chapters in the betrayal of the Sioux (who have been in the news again these days) and the flight of the Nez Perc.

title: RUFUS E. M'GAREN, ALA GUARDIA AIDE
description: Rufus E. McGahen, Deputy Mayor from 1939 to 1945 in Fiorello H. La Guardia's Administration, died Friday at Samaritan Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 89 years old and lived in the St. George Hotel.

title: Hitchhiking Bandit Gets Big Haul at British Field
description: LONDON, April 14 (UPI)A bandit hitched a ride on a truck traveling without armed protection at London Airport yesterday and took $1.2million in diamonds and platinum from the vehicle.

title: KEELBOAT IS VICTOR IN MARYLAND HUNT
description: MONKTON, Md., April 14 (AP)Turney McKnight guided his 6yearold gelding, Keelboat, to victory over six rivals today in the 63d running of the My Ladys Manor pointtopoint race.

title: Italy Approves Funding Of Work to Aid Venice
description: ROME, April 14  Parliament has adopted a hardfought bill appropriating $300million for floodcontrol installations and other work to prevent damage to Venice.

title: Union Alters Moving Plan
description: CLEVELAND, April 14 (UPI)  The United Transportation Union, which has had its headquarters in this area since 1885, has decided to stay in this area rather than to move to Hot Springs, Ark. But the union will move from the city proper to suburban Lakewood.

title: State Cool to Coastal Drilling
description: TRENTONThe state's Department of Environmental Protection said last week that it was against in principle the prospect of large oil companies drilling for petroleum off the Jersey coast.

title: The World Still Desires A Streetcar
description: Twentyfive years after its Broadway premiere, Tennessee Williams's A Streetcar Named Desire remains one of the most highly regarded works in the American theater. This season it has been honored with several revivals; it will next be staged by the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center on April 26, with Rosemary Harris as Blanche DuBois. Here a critic analyzes the play's meaning and appeal. His article is adapted from his book, Tennessee Williams, to be published late this year by Frederick Ungar.

title: Flood Waters Rise 5 Feet In Mississippi Community
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., April 14 (AP)Flood waters rose more than five feet in the Eagle Lake community near here today and engineers predicted they would crest about two or three feet above most of the homes in the area.

title: POLISH BOXING TEAM DEFEATS U.S. AGAIN
description: WEST PATERSON, N. J., April 14 (APThe Polish Olympic boxing team continued its winning ways this afternoon by defeating a less experienced American team, 40, at the Scotsman Theater Banquet Manor.

title: The Intricacy of Lace
description: GARDEN CITY  Ruth P. Hellmann peered intently through her magnifying glass, inspecting every inch of that riot of leaves, flowers and ribbons pattern in a gossamerfine lace inside the display case.

title: PHILIP ILLSON
description: Philip Ilison, a retired clothing manufacturer, died yesterday in the Jewish Memorial Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in the Inwood section of Manhattan.

title: Legislator Sees DayCare Crisis If New Federal Rules Are Kept
description: ALBANY, April 14  An influential state senator from Brooklyn warned today that unless Congress and the Legislature reevaluated their stand on daycare programs, about onethird of the children currently receiving services would be declared ineligible next year.

title: Princeton Lures Saxophonist for Gig Seminar
description: PRINCETONBecause the chairman of Princeton University's sociology department made an impulsive telephone call to California four years ago, Benny Carter, one of the most versatile and innovative figures in jazz until he settled in Hollywood in the, midforties, will spend two days here this week.

title: New Esalen Center Spurs a Sports Revolution
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 On a walk through a small town in Virginia a year ago, George Leonard passed the high school field where 35 boys and girls were sitting on a grassy bank. In front was an athletic young man in teeshirt, gym pants and shoes, a clipboard in one fist and a serious look on his face. He was standing next to a single chinning bar.

title: 2 CITIES ON COAST TO VOTE TUESDAY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14Berkeley and Oakland will hold Tuesday municipal elections that are viewed as critical.

title: Defectors Study at Rabbinical College
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP From early morning until late in the evening, 30 Jewish college graduates, among them some who had been into drugs or beliefs ?? the Orient or the New Left, are learning about themselves, their people and their faith.

title: G.M. AND FORD TOLD TO CUT PARTS PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)The Cost of Living Council said today that it had ordered General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company dealers to make nearly $9.6million in price cuts on automobile parts because of violations of the Government's economic stabilization program.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Harry S. Johnson's article on floating exchange rates [Learning to Love Floating Rates, March 18] was a superb example of the quality of economic thought emanating from the ivory towers of academia. The theories are all so beautiful, I hesitate to spoil the fun by mentioning that inconsequential stumbling block called reality.

title: State Pact With Employes Called Blow To Proposal for Uniform Pension Plan
description: ALBANY, April 14A controversial proposal by a state agency for the adoption of a uniform pension plan for the state's one million public employees has received another legislative setback with the announcement that the state has agreed upon a new contract covering 136,000 state employes.

title: WalltoWall Italian Sweets
description: ORANGEThere's a transplanted pasticceria, or Italian dessert shop, on Central Avenue. It is called Coquelle's and it is compact, cozy and an exact copy of its Italian counterpart, right down to the tables for two and the gleaming silver espresso machine over the ice cream counter.

title: ST. LOUIS PUSHES PLANS FOR CENTER
description: ST. LOUIS, April 14  St. Louis will open one of the nation's largest convention centers Jan. 1, 1976, if city officials can hold construction to the tight timetable they have laid out.

title: ROBERTS EXCELS IN TEXAS RELAYS
description: AUSTIN, TEX. April 14 (UPI)Dave Roberts, who finished behind two Olympians in the open polevault event last night, cleared 17 feet 1 inch in the rain today to win the universitydivision pole vault on the closing day of the Texas relays.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A previously unknown organization, the Lebanese Revolutionary Guard, said that had set fire to an Americanowned oil terminal in Saida, in southern Lebanon, yesterday. In a statement phrased in Marxist terms, the group said that it had struck a blow against American support for Israel. Meanwhile, Israel denied that she had made the attack, as was charged by Palestinian revolutionary groups in Beirut, and the Palestinians, in turn, said that they were not responsible for it. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Long Island's Salesman of Culture
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. LWhen he is in a mystical mood, Robert Bernstein sees himself as a conjurer. When he is more pragmatic, he sees himself as a salesmanselling culture.

title: Student Weds Sansi Girard
description: SANTA FE, N. M., April 14 Miss Sansi Needham Girard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Girard, was married here this afternoon to John Samuel Agnew, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Agnew of Los Alamos.

title: PRESS AWARD SPURS HUNT FOR NEWSMEN
description: The Overseas Press Club is to present its rarest award, the President's Award, to the United States Committee of the International Committees to Free Journalists in Southeast Asia to spur the search for 20 newsmen missing in Cambodia and Vietnam.

title: COURTS ARE FOUND UNABLE TO DETER CRIME IN THE CITY
description: The Criminal Justice Coordinating Council criticized the State Supreme Court and the juvenile justice system yesterday as the two big obstacles to the city's war on crimea war, it said, in which the justice system as a whole was gaining increased capability.

title: Suffolk Pulls Out Of a Pact It Sought
description: WASHINGTONThe United States Geological Survey was asked last week by the Suffolk Department of Environmental Control to drill a series of test borings within several hundred yards of the coast of Long Island next summer to determine where fresh water off Long Island ends and the salt water of the ocean begins.

title: Suicide Barrier Approved
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 (UPI)A total of $67,500 was approved yesterday by the Golden Gate Bridge District Board of Directors for design and engineering studies for a proposed suicide barrier on the bridge, from which nearly 500 persons have leaped to their deaths.

title: MARLUE PRIDE, 12, 4TH AT WESTBURY
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 14 (AP)Marlu Pride, who returned to the races last week after a layoff of 14 months, failed again in his comeback campaign tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, finishing fourth in the field of six as the 12 favorite in a $17,500 trot handicap.

title: Hal's Follies
description: NOSTALGIA can be sugar and spice and everything nice at the Broadway box office, as it has been with No, No, Nanette! and Irene. Or it can be tough and cynical and something less than commercial dynamite, as was the case with last season's awardwinning but sadly shortlived musical Follies.

title: Mitchell Expects Nixon Aides to Talk To Watergate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today after conferring with President Nixon that he expected White House aides to testify before the special Senate committee investigating the Watergate bugging case.

title: Christenberry Rites Set
description: A funeral service for Robert K. Christenberry, former Postmaster of the City of New York, will be held at 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Memphis Funeral Home. A memorial service here, originally set for Thursday, has been put off to Monday, April 23, at 11 A.M. at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Child to the Silversmiths
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Norman Silversmith of New York on March 27 in the Klingenstein Pavilion of Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Silversmith is the former Miss Garin Gedin of Stockholm.

title: Down on the farm in Indiana
description: Knowing Curt Harnack as he is now in his middle forties handsome, urbane, cosmopolitanone finds it hard to believe that he was born and spent his early childhood on an Indiana farm. Moreover, he found his years on the farm rich and gratifying, as this book of charming recollections demonstrates. Although he is describing a kind of life that has almost vanished, his tone is not elegiac but alive with remembered happiness.

title: The only thing to do is wipe 'em all out
description: RAPID CITY, S.D. Early last June, shortly before Hurricane Agnes inundated much of the East Coast and usurped the nation's interest in natural disasters, prodigious rains and thunderstorms in the moody Black Hills of southwestern South Dakota sent a massive flood out of the mountains and through the middle of Rapid City, the second largest town in the state and, by an eagle's route, less than 65 miles from the geographical heart of the country. Rapid Creek, known commonly as the crick, had flooded before, frequently in fact, but never so unexpectedly or with such sickening devastation or relentless democracy.

title: Cyclists Rev Up Kindly Image
description: NORTH BERGENA number of residents here were terrified on hearing rumors of the pending arrival of the Skyway Riders Motorcycle Club in their neighborhood.

title: Not Since the Early Days of Rise Stevens?
description: YVONNE MINTON is a lady with a composure that immediately characterizes a woman who is confident that the goods she's got are the genuine items. The Australian mezzo is 34, 5 feet 8 inches tall, auburnhaired and has dazzling blue eyes. She is, as the saying goes, built, and is not afraid to showcase her assets in an offwhite, formfitting sweater and slacks ensemble. For a touch of color coordination she wears a red and white painted scarf and a pair of trendy red platform shoes. The effect is striking and she knows

title: Spring in the Air
description: There are certain times that declare themselves, without calendar or almanac, in the city as well as in the most rural countryside, and April is one of them. Perhaps it is even more pronounced in the city because cities are not really seasonal places. But April simply cannot be walled out.

title: Jerry Saslow Marries Miss Linda Sperling
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., April 14 Miss Linda Ellen Sperling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sperling of Lido Beach, was married here this evening to Jerry Saslow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Saslow of Long Beach. Rabbi Bernard Kligfeld performed the ceremony at the Middle Bay Country Club.

title: Richardson Aide on Trip
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth Rush left for Hong Kong today as part of what was called a familiarization trip to South Asia. He was accompanied by Joseph J. Sisco, Assistant Secretary for Near East and South Asian Affairs. Mr. Rush will visit the countries in South Asia, such as India and Pakistan, in preparation for a meeting with American ambassadors in the area to be held later this month in Teheran.

title: Chess: Smyslov's Furious Atonement Leaves Uhlmann Repentant
description: The 10th Capablanca Memorial Tournament, held this year in Cienfuegos, Cuba, to honor the man who first brought the world chess title to the Western Hemisphere, gave another former world champion, Vasily Smyslov, the opportunity to make up for some recent sins.

title: Miss Williams Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Miss Mary Beth Williams and Thomas More Barritt who teach in New Haven, were married here this afternoon in the Kay Spiritual Life Center of the American University, The ceremony and the nuptial mass were concelebrated by the Rev. Charles J. Murphy of Bluepoint, L. I., and the Rev. Paul F. Liston, the university's Catholic chaplain.

title: Expos Beat Pirates, 64, on 5Run 8th
description: MONTREAL, April 14 (AP)Tim Foli tied the game with a toorun homer and Ron Fairly followed with another homer as the Montreal Expos struck for five runs in the eighth inning today to pull out a 64 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A previously unknown organization, the Lebanese Revolutionary Guard, said that it had set fire to an Americanowned oil terminal in Saida, in southern Lebanon, yesterday. In a statement phrased in Marxist terms, the group said that it had struck a blow against American support for Israel. Meanwhile, Israel denied that she had made the attack, as was charged by Palestinian revolutionary groups in Beirut, and the Palestinians, in turn, said that they were not responsible for it. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: ExtraCensory Reception
description: In a nation mad with permissiveness in which modesty and purity are no longer cherished virtues, it is nice to know that for at least 30 or 60 seconds at a stretch one can find a semblance of normalcy: in the TV commercial.

title: NORWEGIAN WINS REINSMAN TITLE
description: The European harness driving champion, Ulf Thoresen of Norway, took top honors yesterday, winning two of five races in the world driving championships held in Vienna. Joe Marsh Jr., the United States champion, placed second in the standing, with Herve Filion of Canada fifth.

title: Black Heroes Honored By 70,000 in Newark
description: NEWARK, April 15 (UPI) A crowd of 70,000, waving balloons and cheering, lined Broad Street under sunny skies and temperatures in the 60's today for the AttucksKing memorial parade.

title: Miss Goolagong Bows in 3 Sets to Floridian
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 15 (AP)Chris Evert fought bach to defeat Evonne Goolagong 36, 63, 62, in the final of the $20,000 Miahli BeachCame Bank tennis tournament today It was the second time she had beaten the Australian in two weeks.

title: Glass Flies as Fight By Cuban Factions Rends Rally Here
description: ProCastro and antiCastro students clashed yesterday at Queens College at a meeting addressed by the Cuban representative to the United Nations, the police reported.

title: Congress Fights for Regional Health Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Regional medical programs all over the country are winding up their affairs, on orders from the Nixon Administration, in spite of the fact that the Senate has passed a bill to keep them alive and the House is considering an almost identical measure.

title: FULBRIGHT CHIDES SENATE ON ISRAEL
Picasso's Children Plan to Sue Widow For Part of Estate
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., April 15A son, and daughter born to Pablo Picasso and his former mistress Frangoise Gilot during their 11 years together are preparing to challenge the artist's widow in the French courts for a share of his multimilliondollar estate.

title: Congress Is Resisting the Nixon Administration's Orders for Elimination of Regional Medical Programs
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Regional medical programs all over the country are winding up their affairs, on orders from the Nixon Administration, in spite of the fact that the Senate has passed a bill to keep them alive ,and the House is considering an almost identica measure.

title: Some Hems Will Be Lower, But It's Not Worth the Worry
description: They're calling the longer hemlines, the ones that stop anywhere from below the knees to above the ankles, the young lengths in Paris. The hems that stop at the knees or just above are called the mature look.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP. SHIFTS MANAGEMENT
description: The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the $8.8billion First National Bank of Chicago, has realigned top management, Gaylord Freeman, chairman, announced over the weekend.

title: High. Civilian Toll Is Seen In Bombing of Cambodia
New Bid to Mrs. Gandhi
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 15 President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto today renewed his invitation to the Indian Prime Minister, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, to visit Pakistan to solve the outstanding problems between the two countries through negotiations, to pave the way for peace in the South Asian subcontinent. Pakistani officials said there had been no response to Mr. Bhutto's invitation of Feb. 2.

title: SLUM BLIGHT TIED TO HIGH TAX RATES
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 High property tax rates in the slums  higher than in better neighborhoods in many casesare discouraging rehabilitation that would otherwise be a profitable investment, according to a study by independent experts. The study was made public totoday by Senators Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, and Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois.

title: State Oil Monopoly Brings Luxury Town to Indonesia
description: PANGKALAN BRANDAN, Indonesia  A de luxe headquarters is being created for Pertamina, Indonesia's state oil monopoly, in this little coastal center 60 miles north of Medan. Incorporating spacious administrative buildings, workshops, warehouses and a new town for several thousand Pertamina employes and their families, the headquarters reflects the growing importance of oil, which provides 60 per cent of Indinesia's export earnings and almost 50 per cent of Indonesia's budget.

title: 40,945 at Hollywood Park For First Sunday Racing
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 15 (AP)Gold Bag, carrying Lafit Pincay Jr. to his fourth victory of the day, went to the front in the final strides to win the $27,350 Coronado Stakes today as Hollywood Park initiated Sunday thoroughbred racing before a crowd of 40,945, who wagered $3,774,180.

title: National League
description: Monday, April 16, 1973

title: Advertising: Purina for D.D.B.
description: There were contented purrs coming from Doyle Dane Bernbach Friday when the staff received a memo from on high that the agency had been assigned the Purina Cat Chow business by RalstonPurina. The memo said the business billed over $6million, which makes it sound like D.D.B. got all of the Purina cat food brands.

title: Suicide Now No.2 Cause Of Deaths Among Young
Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: ROSEWALL WINS 2D EVENT IN ROW
description: CLEVELAND, April 15 (UPI)  Ken Rosewall, the socalled old man on the World Championship Tennis Group B tour, vanquished Roger Taylor of Britain, 63, 64, in the final of the $50,000 Cleveland tennis tournament today. It was the Australian's second tournament triumph in two weeks. The match lasted 1 hour 3 minutes, and Rosewall's backhand passing shots were the big factors. Rosewall is the only player in Group B to take two tournaments.

title: Leaders in Country Music See Chance to Win the City
Japanese Concerns Raise Direct Overseas Investing
description: TOKYO, April 15The Normura Research Institute has estimated that Japan's direct foreign investment rose $2.5billion in the fiscal year ended March 31, three times as much as in the preceding year.

title: Defense Sours in Opener of East Final
description: BOSTON, April 15  The Boston Celtics held service today by winning the first of their fourofsevengame Eastern Conference playoff series with the New York Knicks, and they did it with the basketball equivalent of a tennis ace. The score was 134108, and it was the worst defeat suffered by the Knicks in 88 games this season.ferent than before the series began.

title: Fire Damages Bronx School; Firemen Call It Suspicious
description: A fire of suspicious origin heavily damaged Public School 29 in the Melrose section of the Bronx early today. Firemen brought it under control about 40 minutes after it was discovered at 12:55 A. M. The blaze was declared of suspicious origin because firemen had found two separate fires on the second floor of the three32010 story brick building at Courtlandt Avenue and 156th Street one inside a classroom and another in the hallway. The second floor was badly burned and the first was damaged by water.

title: Repression in Rhodesia
description: The sentencing of a wellknown white Rhodesian journalist to two years at hard labor has provoked fresh outcry, especially in Britain, against the white minority Government in Salisbury. Even Tory members of Parliament who have previously defended Prime Minister Ian Smith were infuriated by the harsh punishment decreed for Peter Niesewand after six weeks in solitary confinement and a secret trial on an unknown charge.

title: Governor to Name New Prisons Chief
description: ALBANY, April 15 Governor Rockefeller is expected to name Peter Preiser, the state's director of probation, as Commissioner of State Correctional Services, succeeding Russell G. Oswald.

title: JETS TRIUMPH BY 85, TAKE SAINTS PLAYOFF
Rhodesia Gets 3 Airliners In Spite of U.N.'s Sanctions
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 15 (ReutersjRhodesia has obtained three Boeing 707 airliners despite United Nations sanctions, and no one will say where the jets came from.

title: CableTV Programing Curb Is Expected
description: WASHINGTON, April 15A special committee of the Nixon Administration that has been working for nearly two years on a longrange Government policy for cable television is expected to recommend soon that cablesystem operators be prohibited eventually from producing their own programs.

title: An Essential Saving
description: Now that Congress is going ahead with a large new Senate Office Building, there is less reason than ever to mutilate the Capitol. While this does not solve the problem of masterplanning Congressional space, it does take off some of the pressure and obviate the need for immediate violence to the Capitol's West Front. Approval of this beleaguered and misguided plan extend the West Front, which is to raise its weary head again this week, would now be an act of purely gratuitous destruction.

title: Arlene Walker Percival, Actress, Casting Director
description: Mrs. Arlene Walker Percival, casting director for the Young & Rubicam advertising agency and a former actress under her maiden name, died yesterday at her home, 140 West End Avenue. Her age was 54.

title: American League
description: Monday, April 16, 1973

title: News Summary and Index
description: South Vietnamese troops have pushed across the Cambodian border for the first time since a Vietnam ceasefire went into effect two and a half months ago, according to reports from the field. Fighting was reported yesterday at two points along the border and hundreds of refugees, were said to have fled from Cambodia into South Vietnam. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Fire Sweeps Top Floors of 3 Village Tenemerits
description: A stubborn fire swept swiftly through the top floors of three tenements on Jones Street in Greenwich Village just before dawn yesterday, forcing 75 residents to flee and killing a dog.

title: BLUMENTHAL GETS MORE SUPPORTERS
description: The Blumenthal  for  Mayor campaign inherited yesterday the East Side branch of Representative Edward I. Koch's abandoned mayoral effort

title: IRISH SOCCER
description: Waterford 2, Cork Hiberians 0. Limerick 1, Finn Harps 2.

title: Robert A. Ross, ExHead Of College of Obstetrics
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., April 15 (AP)Dr. Robert A Ross, a former president of the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology, died at his home here today, apparently after a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

title: ITALIAN PREMIER DUE IN U.S. TODAY
