description: ROME, April 15Premier Giulio Andreotti, who is due to arrive in Washington tomorrow for talks with President Nixon, says that Italy and the United States are linked by a friendship of peoples that no event can jeopardize.

title: National Ballet Revives Water Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 More and more modern dance appears to be penetrating the repertories of classic ballet companies, both here and abroad. The novelty given by the National Ballet of Washington at the Kennedy Center yesterday afternoon was the revival of Doris Humphrey's practically legendary Water Study.

title: SAIGON'S TROOPS ARE SAID TO CROSS CAMBODIA BORDER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 16South Vietnamese troops have pushed across the Cambodian border for the first time since a Vietnam ceasefire went into effect two and a half months ago, according to reports from the field.

title: World Tennis Body, Issues Ultimatum To Women Players
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, April 15 (AP)  The International Lawn Tennis Federation threatened today to suspend Mrs. Billie Jean , King and other women tennis players competing as an independent group if they do not return to the fold by the end of April.

title: Anita Koppelson Is Bride
description: EASTCHESTER, N. Y., April 15  Miss Anita Elaine Koppelson and Jamie Ligator, both of Yonkers, were married here this afternoon by Rabbi Joseph Speiser at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney H. Eiges, uncle and aunt of the bride. Mrs. Ligator, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis N. Koppelson of. New York, is an alumna of the State University College at Cortland. Her husband, a dataprocessing consultant, is a graduate of New York University. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Ligator of Holtsville, L. I.

title: Hospital Releases Three With Nuclear Pacemakers
description: NEWARK, April 15 (UPI)Three of the 15 patients who received the first Americandeveloped nuclear  powered heart pacemakers last week were released from Beth Israel Hospital today.

title: McKay Outlines His Goals As Correction Board Head
description: Robert B. McKay said yesterday that his main goal during a probable nine months in office as chairman of the city's Board of Correction would be to depopulate the city's jails as much as possible and to try to make them less degrading, less dehumanizing and less brutal than in the past.

title: YANKEES TRIUMPH OVER RED SOX, 62
description: They hung the championship banners from the roof, they (placed wreaths n the monuments, they sang happy birthday, they cut the golden anniversary cake and filled Yankee Stadium with nostalgia of Yankees of the past.

title: Laver Is Beaten Decisively at Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, April 15 (UPI)  In only 80 minutes Stan Smith defeated Rod Laver, 62, 64, 61, to win the 850,000 World Championship Tennis Group A tournament today. The tall American earned the $10,000 first prize, but perhaps more satisfying for him, he now holds a 32 edge over the Australian in their matches this year.

title: Solyom Is Piano Soloist With National
description: Janos Solyom, who made his United States debut last Tuesday in Washington and appeared in New York for the first time yesterday afternoon with the National Symphony at Philharmonic Hall, is clearly Antal Dorati's kind of pianist. Like the conductor, who is also music director of the Stockholm Philharmonic, Mr. Solyom was born in Budapest and has strong ties to Sweden, having lived in Stockholm since his emigration in 1956.

title: RIO PUBLISHER HELD FOR DEFYING CENSOR
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 15 (AP)Brazilian federal police today arrested a publisher who defied censorship orders.

title: Capitol Tourists, Eager to Observe Congress in Action, Hear Long Debate on Bill With Little Future
City Seeks $78.7Million To Finish Housing Projects
description: A $78.7million Federal grant which would provide not for expansion of New York City's neighborhood development program, but for its winding down, was requested by city officials yesterday.

title: Peronists Consolidate Gains In a Second Round of Voting
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 15 (Reuters)Peronists today consolidated their gains made in the March 11 general election by electing senators and governors in 12 of Argentina's 15 provinces, according to official returns that are almost completed.

title: 3 Chinese Aides Leave To Open Office in U.S.
description: PEKING, April 15 (Reuters) Han Hsu left Peking today with two top aides on the first stage of a journey to Washington where he will open the Chinese liaison office in the United States.

title: Libyan Copilot Says Captain Heard Israeli Warning Fire
description: JERUSALEM, April 15 (AP) The Libyan copilot of an airliner downed by Israeli jets Feb. 21 in the Sinai Peninsula said today that the plane's captain heard the warning shots fired by the interceptors and planned to land, but at the last moment he changed his mind and tried to escape back to Egypt.

title: Strollers Enjoy the Sun At Start of Holy Week
description: Holy Week, the last seven lays, in Lent that commemorate the final events in the life of Christ before His Resurrection, began yesterday in Roman Catholic and Protestant churches with the traditional prayers, meditations and music of Palm Sunday.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
FREDERICK J. BALMER
description: Frederick J. Balmer, president of the Balmer Cadillac Corporation, car dealers at 8904 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, and a founder and vice president of the Dealers Leasing Corporation, died Saturday in New York Hospital, after an operation. He was 77 years old and lived at 8901 Shore Road, Brooklyn, and in Spring Lake, N.J., and Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: Blancas, With 75 for 277, Beats Beard by Shot in $150,000 Golf
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 15 (AP)Homero Blancas blew fourstroke lead, then rallied and limped home the winner with a 75 today in the final round of the $150,000 Monsanto open golf tournament.

title: Silurians List Winners Of 72 Journalism Awards
description: The Society of the Silurians, an organization of veteran New York newspaper men and women, announced yesterday the winners of its awards for outstanding journalism during 1971

title: McDonald Victor in Bradham
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 15 (AP)John MacDonald of Hong Kong, driving a Brabham BT40, won the Malaysian Grand Prix auto races today for the third time in four years.

title: Tews at Princeton Prepare for Seders
Events Today
description: LE MEDECIN MALGRE LUI (The Doctor In Spite of Himself) a play by Mollere, performed In French. At the American Place Theater, 7:30, through Saturday.

title: Chicago Saves 54 Triumph in Wild 3d Period
VISIT TO COPTER SITE BY SURVIVORS ASKED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 15 (Canadian Press) Michel Gauvin, head of the Canadian delegation to the International Commission of Control and Supervision, says it is essential that survivors of a crash of a commission helicopter be allowed to return to the area to verify the crash site.

title: Foyt and Andretti Both Regain Winning Ways in Trenton Races
description: TRENTON, Apri115Two old pros, A. J. Foyt and Mario Andretti, who have suffered painfuI slumps these last few years, finally came through today in a pair of United States Auto Club championship races.

title: Gallup Poll Shows A 6 Per Cent Drop In Nixon Popularity
description: President Nixon's popularity shows a further decline in the latest survey, with 59 per cent expressing approval of the way he is handling his job, the Gallup Poll says today.

title: Sports Today
description: Rodrigo Valdes vs. Kim Booker, 10round middleweight bout, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street; first preliminary, 8:30 P.M.

title: Canyon Closed to Campers
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 115 (UPI)  The police closed Tahquitz Canyon yesterday to prevent camping by large numbers of young people who have invaded the desert resort during recent Easter vacations. The police evicted nearly 30 persons camped in the canyon, but said there were nowhere near the crowds of recent years.

title: Healing of Fracture In Animals Speeded By Static Electricity
description: Scientists at Columbia University yesterday reported encouraging results in tests on animals of the use of static electricity to speed the healing of fractured bones.

title: Mastery Over World Oil Supply Shifts to Producing Countries
Turkish Cypriote Calls for Intervention
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus. April 15The leader of this island's Turkish minority urged today that Greece and Turkey jointly take over the internal security of Cyprus to prevent a surge of violence in this tiny republic.

title: Mrs. Simon Is Married
description: In the East End Temple here yesterday morning, Mrs. Florence Rosenzweig Simon was married to L. Regis Peloquin, both of New York. Rabbi William Kloner performed the ceremony.

title: GREGG, IN PORSCHE, IS TRANSAM VICTOR
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., April 15 (AP)Peter Gregg of Jacksonville, Fla., leading for the last 265 miles, drove his Porsche Carrera to victory today in a TransAm 500 event at Road Atlanta. The 315mile event opened the Sports Car Club of America's 1973 TransAm 500 series.)

title: Canada's Arctic Search for Oil and Gas Stirs Opposition
description: INUVIK, Northwest Territories, April 3This bleak outpost, suddenly a boom town, has become the focus of a multimilliondollar search for gas and oil, which is bringing to the frozen wilderness changes as harsh as its Arctic winds.

title: Stage: Carmines's Faggot Oratorio
description: One wonders why the individual members of Al Carmines's harmonious choirlike company are not spirited away from the Judson Poets Theater by Broadway and record companies. The same thing goes for Mr. Carmines himself. Not only is he a composer, lyricist, librettist, director, conductor and oneman orchestra (at the piano) and overflowing with creativity in all those areasbut he also has a rich, robust voice perfectly suited to his songs.

title: ARAB IS CONVICTED IN ISRAEL AS A SPY
description: TEL AVIV, April 15 (AP) A military court in the occupied Golan heights of Syria convicted an Arab Druze today of leading a proSyrian spy ring, the state radio reported. Sentencing of the Druze, Sheik Abu Jabal, was postponed, the radio said. He was one of 11 defendants in what is described as a 59member spy network. All the suspects were Druzes, members of a sect that is an offshoot of Islam.

title: Knicks, Rangers Lose
description: The Knicks and Rangers lost secondround playoff games yesterday. The Knicks dropped the opening game, 134108, to the Celtics in Boston. The Rangers fell, 54, to the Black Hawks in Chicago, with the series now even at one each. Details, Page 53.

title: Roundup: Perry Blanks Tigers
description: Last November's sixplayer trade between the Yankees and Cleveland paid off yesterday for the Indians.

title: Executive Obligation
description: The issue of executive privilege dominates the political debate, but little attention is paid to executive obligation or accountability. We cannot savor the fullness of the President's duties, wrote the late Prof. Clinton Rossiter in 1956, unless we recall that he is held primarily accountable for the ethics, loyalty, effie ciency, frugality and responsiveness to the public's wishes of the two and onethird million Americans in the national administration. These are the same people whom Attorney General Richard Kleindienst last week took under the protective umbrella of executive privilege.

title: MEAT PRICES CUT LITTLE BY PROTEST
description: Meat prices reacted last week to the consumer boycott of the week before, in both the New York and Hartford areas, but the reaction was insignificant. It left Agriculture Department market analysts of New York and Connecticut wondering what it would take to lower the prices.

title: Miss Nina Rosenberg Wed to Eric Hertz
description: MERRICK, L. I., April 15 Miss Nina Rosenberg was married here this afternoon to Eric Hertz. Rabbi Sanford Saperstein performed the ceremony in the Reform Jewish Congregation of Merrick Temple.

title: Madeleine N. Mandel Wed to K. L. Haralick
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., April 14 Miss Madeleine Nancy Mandel, who teaches music in the Valley Stream, L.I., schools, and Kenneth Lane Haralick, director of bands at Plainedge High School on Long Island, were married here this afternoon at the Old Oakes Country Club by Rabbi Irving Koslowe of the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck.

title: The Brothers Nixon: Close but Not Equal
Motor Vehicle Travel
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 (UPI)Motor vehicles in the United States traveled an estimated 1.25 billion miles in 1972, reports the National Automobile Club, with passenger cars covering 79 per cent of the total, trucks 19 per cent and buses and motorcycles the rest.

title: The Boston Marathon: Finn, 26, Man to Watch
description: BOSTON, April 15  A prison guard from Finland, factory president from Japan, a famous novelist from everywhere, a nobody from Nowheresville

title: New Books
description: Dorothy Thompson: A Legend in Her Time by Marion K. Sanders (Houghton Mifflin, $10).

title: SPANIARDS SEEING TANGO IN FRANCE
description: MADRIDAwoman here has spent about $50 in car fare to see Last Tango in Paris.

title: Leila Joseph Bride of Paul Elkin
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 15  Miss Leila Muriel Joseph, daughter of Dr. and Mrs., Edward D. Joseph, was married here this afternoon to Paul M. Elkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Elkin of Larchmont. Cantor William Wolff. performed the ceremony at the Joseph home.

title: Miss Wright Wins Coast Golf by Two Strokes
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 15 (AP)Mickey Wright sank a tricky 25foot downhill putt for a birdie on the last hole today, breaking a threeyear victory drought with a twostroke triumph in the $154,000 ColgateDinah Shore Winner's Circle golf tournament.

title: Soviet Hockey Victory Empty Without Canada
description: MOSCOW, April 15  The Canadians did not take part in the 1973 World Hockey Championship but they were a ghostly presence nonethelesss, and some Russian fans walked away saying it would never be the real thing unless the Canadians werehere in the flesh.

title: HOLY WEEK OPENS IN A SUNNY CITY
Deaths
Ronan Is One of Two Cited By Citizens Budget Group
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan civic watchdog group, will award its Medal for High Civic Service to Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and George Champion, head of the Economic Development Council of New York.

title: ISRAEL HOLDS ARABS IN BOMBINGS IN 1972
description: TEL AVIV, April 15 (AP)Israeli security forces have detained several Arabs in Israel and the occupied Arab territories, charging them with responsibility for a series of bomb attacks last year, the military command reported today.

title: In Sikkim, Only the First Phase of the Crisis Seems to Be Over
description: NEW DELHI, April 15The Year of the Water Ox has begun badly, said the lama looking sadly toward the distant hill where Sikkim's royal palade is situated. Peace of the land is broken. The King is troubled. I can only pray that peace may return soon for the King and his country.

title: N.Y.U. Choir King David Marks Century of Singing
description: The New York University Choral Arts Society celebrated a century of group singing at the school with a concert on Sunday afternoon at Town Hall. (The New York University Glee Club was operating in 1873.) The major effort was Honegger's King David, conducted by E. Jon de Revere in a conscientiously genteel oratorio style that did not achieve much intensity or dramatic power.

title: Bay State Gambling Raids
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., April 15 (AP)The state police said today that 25 persons were scheduled for court appearances Tuesday in connection with gambling raids on 21 locations in 10 eastern Massachusetts communities.

title: Knicks Box Score
GOING OUT Guide
description: AGAINST ORDERS In 1922 Ralph Vaughan Williams wrote The Shepherds of the Delectable Mountains, a oneact sacred opera, part of a series of works based on The Pilgrim's Progress. This segment has been rarely performed, partly because the composer wanted it to be staged and not done in a church.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Department of Real Estate disclosed yesterday that it would spend $83,655 to demolish 25 obsolete public toilets in city parks.

title: No PATH Negotiations Set; Transport of N.J. Adds Buses
description: No new talks were scheduled between the railway carmen and Port Authority TransHudson (PATH) as the strike that was affecting 70,000 commuters entered its third week today.

title: Legal Aid's President Sheldon Oliensis
description: The Legal Aid Society has often attracted the services of young, radical, longhaired lawyers with a militant approach to the cause of justice for the poor. Sheldon Oliensis, the society's new president, hardly fits the archetypal mold. He is 51 years old, studiously lowkeyed, has been a partner in a Park Avenue law firm for many years and has hair so short that its brownturning to gray color is hard to discern.

title: U. S. Plans World Group of OilImporting Nations
description: WASHINGTON, April 15State Department officials, in consultation with other foreign ministeries, have been drafting plans for an international organization of oilimporting countries.

title: Troy Is Seeking to Change Biaggi's Campaign Organization by Hiring More Professional Personnel
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., who is also the Queens Democratic leader and the new manager for Representative Mario Biaggi's mayoralty campaign, strode into Biaggi headquarters oneevening last week and startled some 40 mostly middleaged men working on Biaggi petitions by demanding: How many of you guys are carrying guns? Easily a dozen of the Biaggi workers raised their hands, Mr. Troy recalled, noting that many of them are present or retired policemen.

title: Proxmire Seeks to Limit U.S. Funds for the Arts
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)Senator William Proxmire says he will move to cut Federal spending for the National Arts and Humanities, contending that funding for it is increasing at an unprecedented and unconscionable rate.

title: Cook Industries Profit Up
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 15 (AP)  Cook Industries, Inc., a concern involved last August in the multimillion dollar grain sale to the Soviet Union, announced this weekend an almost fivefold jump in profits for the first nine months of fiscal 1973. Net aftertax earnings were $11.55  million, or $3.80 a share, up from $2.41million, or 78 cents a share, during the first nine months of fiscal 1972.

title: Runaway Economy
description: The Administration's strange reversion to donothingism on the inflation front is forcing Congress into actions that will complicate the intricate task of managing economic controls.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: AT LARCH MONT Y. C.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
U.S. AIDES BARRED AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: The Community Relations Service is a conciliation and mediation arm of the Justice Department. Although it has no enforcement powers, one of its major functions at Wounded Knee has been to help prevent violations of a ceasefire that went into effect last March 26.

title: TEAMSTERS GAIN CALIFORNIA FARMS
description: INDIO, Calif., April 15 (AP) The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced today it had won contracts from growers previously signed with the United Farm Workers Union led by Cesar Chavez.

title: U.S. Commits $7.5Million To State Housing Programs
description: S. William Green, the regional administrator of the Housing and Urban Development Department, disclosed yesterday that the Federal Government had committed $7.5million to state interestsubsidy programs the first specific housing funds allocated since the Federal freeze on Jan. 5.

title: U. S. Assigns Saigon Role To a Woman
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 15First the Americans concentrated on Vietnamization. Then they turned to civilianization. Now they are trying a little feminization.

title: Moratorium on Housing Subsidy Spells Hardship for Thousands
description: DETROIT, April 15James Nicolson and his wife Katie stood on the porch of their twostory frame house surrounded by a neat lawn and cyclone fence and looked across to a row of houses wrecked by vandals and fires.

title: E.P.A. Chief Doubts Shift By Congress on Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)  The head of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that Congress would be less inclined to relax auto emission standards now that the auto makers have a oneyear extension of the stiff 1975 requirements.

title: 5 Killed in Colorado Crash
description: WALSENBURG, Colo., April 15 (UPI)Five young men believed returning from a dance in La Junta, Colo., were killed today when their car struck the rear of a twoandahalfton truck. The victims were identified as Alan J. Lopez, 27 years old, of Thornton, Colo., the driver of the car; Barney R. Ferri Jr., 18, also of Thornton; John E. McNabb, 21, and his brother, James A. McNabb, 19, and Robert L. Hudson Jr., 19, all of Gardner, Colo.

title: Picasso's Children Plan to Sue Widow For Part of Estate
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., April 15A son and daughter born to Pablo Picasso and his former mistress Francoise Gilot during their 11 years together are preparing to challenge the artist's widow in the French courts for a share of his multimilliondollar estate.

title: Libyan Announces A New Program; Threatens to Quit
British Rugby
description: By Reuters

title: Costa Rica Quake Toll at 16
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 15 (Reuters) The official death toll in the earthquake here rose to 16 today and rescue workers said they believed it might eventually reach 50. Four more bodies were recovered overnight from the ruins of homes in Tilarn, near the border with Nicaragua. Tilarn, with a population of about 30,000, is the major town of Guanacaste Province, the area worst hit by the quake yesterday morning.

title: College, School Results
TV: McCartney and His Group on A.B.C. Tonight
description: James Paul McCartney, an 8 to 9 o'clock special on the American Broadcasting Company network this evening, gets off to a smashing start and comes to an effectively lowkeyed end. It's the middle that presents problems. No one element is disastrous, but the whole lacks cohesion. The result is a series of disconnected routines strung together with commercials for Chevrolet cars.

title: 3:56.8 WINS MILE FOR PREFONTAINE
description: EUGENE, Ore., April 15 (UPI)  Steve Prefontaine doubled up in the mile and threemile yesterday to help his Oregon Ducks in a fourway meet and ran what may be the best times in the world in both events this year.

title: Freshman in Albany: An Exhilarating Process
description: ALBANY, April 15The Rubicon in the path of all serious politicians whether to stop renting dinner jackets for the chicken banquet circuitwas crossed last month by a freshman Assemblyman, Edward H. Lehner, when he bought his first formal outfit for $130 and took his mother to the Governor's annual legislative ball.

title: Lawrance Thompson, 67, Dies; Frost Biographer Won Pulitzer
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 15 Lawrence R. Thompson, Pulitzer Prizewinning biographer of the poet Robert Frost, died today in Princeton Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 611 Lake Drive.

title: Taxpayers Spend Refunds on Basics
description: Ben R. Womer, a steel worker who lives in Dundalk, Md., earned $11,000 last year and has just received a tax refund of $190. We gave it to Sears, Roebuck, he said toward .a new clothes washer and dryer.

title: LEONARD E. RUISI OF FAMILY COURT
description: Judge Leonard E. Ruisi of the Family Court died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 24520 Grand Central Parkway, Bellerose, Queens. He was 69 years old.

title: State Audit Turns Up Ineligible Welfare Clients
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that a center in the reorganization of the Department of Social Services was paying ineligible clients, had misused manpower and had been laggard in its investigations of reports of child abuse and neglect.

title: 11,474 Stream in to See White House Gardens
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)For the first time the gates to the White House gardens were opened to the public this weekend, and 11,474 persons streamed In on the special spring tour.

title: China Buys Japan Trucks
description: TOKYO, April 15 (UPI)A Japanese usedcar concern said today that it had signed a contract to deliver 3,000 used truck to China. Shoei Jidosha Kogyo of Tokyo said it would receive $6million for the trucks, which range in weight from three and a half tons sewn tons.

title: NEWARK BOYS CHOIR PERFORMS WITH ELAN
description: The Newark Boys Chorus is full of the noblest purpose, both sociologically and artistically. Ideally, it could become our leading ensemble of its type. But its performance Saturday night at Tully Hall suggested that from a strictly musical standpoint, work still needs to be done.

title: Japanese Concern Bays Palace Hotel on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 (UPI)The famed Palace Hotel, where President Harding died and Enrico Caruso survived the 1906 earthquake, is being sold to a Japanese conglomerate.

title: New Jersey Briefs
BOND MEN BRACE FOR HECTIC WEEK
description: Highly volatile elements could combine to produce bondmarket explosions this week.

title: Aoki Wins Tokyo Golf
description: TOKYO, April 15 (AP)Isao Aoki of Japan shot a threeunderpar 70 today for a 36hole total of 143 and won the $7,700 first prize in the $27,000 Caldbeck golf tournament. Hsieh YungHo of Taiwan, closed with a 74 over the 7,070yard, par73 DaiAtsugi Country Club course and finished second at 146.

title: Knicks, Rangers Lose
description: The Knicks and Rangers lost secondround playoff games yesterday. The Knicks dropped the opening game, 134108, to the Celtics in Boston. The Rangers fell, 54, to the Black Hawks in Chicago, with the series now even at one each. Details, Page 53.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The quilts in the collection at Nonesuch Ltd., 1023 Lexington Avenue, date from 1820 to 1930 and are mostly in perfect condition. Many in fact have never been used and are as crisp and fresh as the day they were made.

title: 3 Carnegie Grants Awarded For Faculty Union Projects
description: The Carnegie Corporation announced yesterday that it had awarded three grants totaling $377,733 to support projects for spreading information about faculty unionization and collective bargaining in American colleges and universities, United Press International reported.

title: Bridge: A Toronto Player Is Ranked Among 6 Best Contestants
description: If a group of top experts were asked to name the best six players in North America in ranked order, there would be considerable disagreement about the top spot. But it is a safe bet that every list would include quiet, tenacious Sam Kehela of Toronto, who has been an outstanding performer since he settled in Canada as a very young man nearly two decades ago.

title: Atlantic Dialogue
description: President Nixon has now underscored the importance of his designation of 1973 as the Year of Europe by confirming his plans to visit several European countries this fall. His trip will include return calls on at least four leaders of European governments allied with the United States who will have been White House guests earlier in the year.

title: SHIP'S COMPANY IS SHOW VICTOR
FEW IN PACE FIND SCHOOLS DO WELL
description: The Public Education Association has released a citywide survey indicating that only one out of five candidates in the May 1 school boards elections feel that the schools in their districts are performing as well as can be expected.

title: Dibiasi and Miss Lock Win Hall of Fame Diving Finals
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 15 (AP)Klaus Dibiasi of Italy, an Olympic gold medalist, took the 10meter platform title today and 18yearold Christine Lock of Fort Worth, Tex., won the threemeter springboard event in the swimming Hall of Fame diving championships.

title: E.E.C. Farm Policy Debated
description: PARIS, April 15The debate over who should buy what food products from whom promises to get hotter.

title: BIG BOMBING TOLL IN CAMBODIA SEEN
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 15Knowledgeable Western diplomats here say that they believe that the heavy United States bombing campaign in Cambodia is being carried out on the basis of inadequate intelligence data and often with imprecise control, causing high civilian casualties.

title: Sports Today
description: Rodrigo Valdes vs. Kim Booker, 10round middleweight bout, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street; first preliminary, 8:30 P.M.

title: An Exercise Class for Men Also Includes Dance Movements
description: During the last segment of the men's class at the Dance N Shape studio, the class goes through a routine similar to the opening number of West Side Story, when the Jets gang leaps and twirls all over a playground. The three men attempting the ballet gymnastics the other evening didn't exactly look bike the teenage gang. But although older and paunchier, they certainly tried.

title: COURT BROADENS VIEW ON SEX BIAS
description: State and city laws prohibit ing discrimination because of race, religion, national origin and sex apply equally to New Yorkers and nonNew Yorkers, the Appellate Division ruled last week.

title: 3 Foreign Jurists Quit Greece; Officials Refused to See Them
description: ATHENS, April 15 American and Canadian jurists who came to Athens more than week ago to seek information about the arrest and detention of six young lawyers left here today saying, to a statement, We regret that the Greek Government has rejected an opportunity extended in good faith to state its position.

title: New Jersey Sports Ice Rink Opening Due
description: PARAMUS, N. J., April 15The Bergen Mall Ice Arena, a longawaited and muchneeded facility in this area, is expected to be open by Sunday.

title: Charles Cash, $6, Scores
description: BOSTON, April 15 (AP) Charles Cash, ridden by Paul Capaldo, won the $8,000 Dancer's Image Purse by a nose from Rabbit Run today at Suffolk Downs. Charles Cash ran the six furlongs in 1:12 35 and paid $6.

title: Robeson, at 75, Is Feted in Absentia
description: Only Paul Robeson's famous bassbaritone voice was present (on tape) yesterday at Carnegie Hall. Its owner, in impaired health, had stayed at home in Philadelphia. But despite his absence, a crowd nearly filled the hall, assembled for a cultural celebration of the black actorsinger's 75th birthday.

title: W. H.A.Playoffs
Miss Levenson Bride of Heywood H. Adler
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 15Miss Lisbeth Lynn Levenson, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Levine, was married here this noon to Heywood Henry Adler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Adler of White Plains. Rabbis Morris Kertzer and H. Leonard Poller performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Temple. They were assisted by Cantor Edward Graham.

title: BUSINESS GROUP BULLISH ON ASIA
description: HONG KONG, April 15A group of more than 50 American financial and business executives just finishing a twoweek tour of Southeast Asia have expressed optimism on the potential for investment in the region.

Highland's Whip of Penmaen; 3, Mrs. Cheever Porter's Irish setter, Ch. Glenarian Hallelulia, C.D.; 4, Bonnie L. Proctor's and Helga Tustin's English cocker spaniel, Ch. Kenobo Capricorn.

title: A Transit Fare Rise to 60 Cents During 74 Is Foreseen by Kheel
description: A warning that the city's I subway and bus fares may have to rise to 60 cents next year was voiced last night by Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator and transportation expert.

title: 14th City WalkingTour Season Opens
British Rugby
description: By Reuters

title: ENERGY USE CUT ON ECOLOGY DAY
description: BURLINGTON, Wis., April 15 After a day playing in the snow in the aftermath of the worst storm of the winter, the children of Mr. and, Mrs. Ralph Heck could have been expected to settle down to watch television.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
Man Charged in Tots Killing
description: WORCESTER, England, April 15 (AP)The police charged a man today with murdering a 4yearold boy and his two baby sisters whose knifehacked bodies were found impaled on spiked iron railings near their home.

title: MELVIN L. GONICK
description: ALBANY, April 15 (AP) Melvin L. Gonick of suburban Latham, a public relations consultant and magazine editor, died yesterday at the age of 45.

title: Bulls Shut Budapest Airport
description: BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 15 (UPI)  Two bulls broke loose as they were being loaded from a cargo plane at Budapest's airport early today, forcing officials to close the field to all traffic. The bulls roamed over the runways and the rest of the airfield for two and a half hours until dawn, when the police were able to corral them.

title: Nabisco Names Officer
description: Nabisco, Inc., has announced the appointment of Malcolm B. Bacon to the new post of vice presidentmanufacturing and distribution of its special products division. Mr. Bacon has been with Nabisco since 1931.

title: Mondale Says the Minimum Tax Still Lets Some Pay Nothing, Others an Average of 4%
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Under the minimum tax added to the law in 1969 to insure that all wealthy persons paid some Federal income tax, 24,000 of them are paying at a rate averaging 4.13 per cent, or about what a $6,000ayear worker pays.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 16, 1973

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SPRINGTIME COMES TO PRINCETON: University students pausing to view magnolia trees in blossom on the campus, where 60degree temperatures yesterday were enough to make students forget books and being indoors.

title: School Tax Credit Plans
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) Oral arguments are to be presented to the Supreme Court tomorrow aimed at salvaging Pennsylvania's plan to reimburse parents of students in nonpublic schools. The high court also will hear arguments on the constitutionality of a similar taxcredit plan in New York State. A ruling in both cases is expected later this spring.

title: Jersey Moratorium on Cable TV Ends
Diana Ettenberg Wed
description: Miss Diana Ettenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Ettenberg of Ferndale, N. Y., was married at noon yesterday to Lorin Mimless. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Mimless of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Norman H. Strickman performed the ceremony at the Marine Park Jewish Center in Brooklyn. The couple are students at Brooklyn College.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Central Westchester Humane Society today said it would have to kill 50 dogs, both purebred and mongrel, unless they were adopted by Easter. The Greenburgh Town Board gave the humane society until next Sunday to place the dogs because neighbors near the kennel had complained about their loud barking, a Society spokesman said. Interested persons should call the humane society in Elmsford, N.Y. at (914) LY 27334.

title: A.B.A. Shifts Date of Draft
description: The American Basketball Association has changed its undergraduate draft from tomorrow to Friday, an A.B.A. spokesman announced last night.

title: Minus, Amid His Jazz Quintet, Plays Mainly Inspirational Role
description: The room at 2 St. Mark's Place, which was known until 1968 as the Five Spot, was a basic stomping ground for Charles Mingus, the eminent jazz bassist, until it abandoned its jazz policy in 1967. Recently reopened as the Two Saints, it has now retrieved Mr. Mingus.

title: The New Relations: II
description: MOSCOWIn the economic outlook of the Soviet Union there is one fundamental factor that gets relatively little attenion in the West. That is the demographic trend: a drastic reductiOn in prospective new recruits for the labor force.

title: Curran Urges Beefing Up Of City Narcotics Courts
description: Despite a finding by his panel that special city narcotics courts were failing, Paul J. Curran, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, said yesterday that the federally financed courts should continue and that their efforts should be beefed up.

title: College Baseball

description: WASHINGTON, April 15President Nixon said today that he planned to make a grand tour of Europethe first foreign trip of his second termthis fall.

title: Coop Conversion
description: Cooperative housing is a good thing for the city, because older buildings are generally better maintained as coops than as rentals. But too often since the end of World War II, conversion to cooperative status has been forced upon unwilling rental tenants because a minority35 per centhave favored it. For the majority the alternative has been buy or get out.

title: Alan King's Younger Son Held On Drug Possession Charges
description: Andrew King, the 18yearold younger son of the comedian Alan King, was arraigned yesterday morning in Nassau County on charges of felonious possession of marijuana and hashish.

title: Chinese Win Singles Titles In World Table Tennis Event
description: SARAJEVO, YugoSlavia, April 15 (AP)  Communist China swept the singles titles today at the world table tennis championships. Hsi Enting took the men's crown with a 2118, 1321, 1321, 2119, 2118 victory over Kjell Johansson of Sweden, and Hu Yulan won the women's title with a 2117, 2111, 2114 triumph over Czechoslovakia's Alicia Grofova.

title: SHIRAGIAN, 73, DIES; AN ARMENIAN HERO
description: LEONIA, N. J., April 15Arshavir Shiragian, a retired dealer in Oriental rugs, who, as a young man, killed three prominent Turks in reprisal for the massacre of Armenians in World War I, died Thursday ill Englewood Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 530 Grandview Terrace.

title: PEARSON CAPTURES 3D CAR RACE IN ROW
description: DARLINGTON, S. C., April 15  David Pearson won his third 500mile stock car race in a row today, weaving his redandwhite Mercury through maze of broken cars to capture the 17th Rebel 500 at Darlington International Raceway.

title: Books of The Times DeLillo Runs Out of Bounds
description: Oh, dear! There really are so very many little things to like and laugh at in Don DeLillo's third and latest novel, Great Jones Street. Browsing through it once more, I can see all the Jelly beans fairly leaping off the pages; so if you'll be patient a moment, I'll try to convince you (and myself) that this novel is alive and worthy successor to the author's talented first book, Americana, and his altogether glorious End Zone. Consider, for instance, the pipesmoking man who shows up at the party for retired rock superstar Bucky Wunderlick and announces, I'm Morehouse Professor of Latent History at the Osmond Institute. . . . This professorship deals with events that almost took place, events that definitely took place but remained unseen and unremarked upon, like the action of bacteria or the rising and falling of mountain ranges, and events that probably took place but were definitely not chronicled. . . . One of the major thrusts of latent history is to avoid a narrow purview. . . It's axiomatic that people in the Middle Ages went to bed early. We're studying this to learn what effect it had on the Hundred Years War dragging on for as long as it did.

title: Turkey's New Chief Picks Cabinet From Two Parties
description: ANKARA, April 15 (Reuters) Turkey's Premierdesignate, Naim Talu, tonight named a Cabinet of 24 ministers drawn from two political parties. The new Government is to lead Turkey toward the general elections scheduled for October 14. Mr. Talu has taken 13 ministers from the conservative Justice party and six from the Republican People's party and has named three independents and two technicians.

title: Anniversaries
description: ABRAMSLoret. My dearest, darling sweetheart. This Is our sixth. Fortyfour ad. ditIonal happy and healthy years to go. Your toying husband and family.

title: MINNA GOMBELL, 81, OF STAGE AND FILMS
description: SANTA MONICA Calif., April 15 (AP)Minna Gombell, an actress who appeared in more than 100 movies and starred in several Broadway plays, died here yesterday. She was 81 years old.

title: COURT RULING DUE ON HIRING POLICE
description: JERSEY CITY, April 15A challenge by this city to the constitutionality of a New Jersey law that bans residency requirements for local policemen and firemen is nearing a ruling in the State Superior Court.

title: Ft. Lee Rent Strike Enters 3d Week
description: FT. LEE, April 15Tenants of the highrise Colony apartment building in Fort Lee, where the rents range from $400 to $2,100 a month, are going into the third week of a rent strike.

title: Happy Birthday

Motley, the fiveborough Cole Porter. title: Frad's Mushrooms Back
description: CINCINNATI, April 15 (AP) Fred's Mushrooms, removed from grocery store shelves more than a month ago, will be back on the market tomorrow, the company announced yesterday. A recall was ordered in March when Food and Drug Administration officials indicated botulism had been detected.

title: Suicide Now No. 2 Cause Of Deaths Among Young
description: It was a pleasant Saturday morning and Marie Bettoni, a 17yearold graduate of a Brooklyn high school, had dutifully accompanied her mother and father to a church wedding. Her parents went on to the reception; she returned home.

description: The body of an unidentified man, about 30 years of age, was found shortly after 7 o'clock last night on the Penn Central Railroad tracks at West 157th Street

description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15  There was a telephone call in the locker room for Harry Parker after the New York Mets righthander won his first major league game as a starter, 21, from Philadelphia today, but it wasn't from President Nixon.

title: Decision Near on Bugging Inquiry Rules
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The White House is nearing a decision on the terms under which staff members would be permitted to participate in the Senate investigation of the Watergate episode, Administration sources said today.

description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 15 (AP)The University of Michigan won the John F. Kennedy intercollegiate sailing regatta in the final two races at the Naval Academy today. Navy finished second and Kings Point was third.

With a threeweek break before resuming its prizemoney tour May 12 and 13 in Toronto and Philadelphia, the International Track Association has achieved several milestones in its opening series of eight meets. description: MONTERREY, Mexico, April 15 (AP)Rafael Herrera got off the poor in the eighth round last night and became the World Boxing Council's bantamweight champion by stopping a fellow Mexican, Rodolfo Mai:tinez, in the 12th round of a scheduled 15rounder. The title had been vacant.

description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia  When Saudi Arabia petroleum officials want answers to complex problems, they turn to the computer center at the Petroleum College here.

description: JOHNSON CITY, Tex., April 15 (UPI)The boyhood home of President Johnson, maintained as a national historic site, will be reopened this summer after extensive refurbishing.

title: BELFAST HOUSEWIFE KILLED AT HER DOOR
description: BELVAST, Northern Ireland, April 15 (AP) A Protestant housewife who answered midnight knock at her Belfast door, died in a fusillade of bullets through the door. The police identified her as Margaret Miller, shot in the chest, and said her slayers escaped by car.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your recent editorial entitled Truth on Tax Reform cites a list of shopworn reforms often advocated by witnesses before Congressional committees. You admit that each of these proposals is open to argument, which implies uncertainty as to the soundness, or shall we say truthfulness, of the various reform plans offered to improve the Federal tax system.

description: WASHINGTON; April 16 (UPI) Josef Grossman, an information officer for the United States Information Agency in Accra, Ghana, died Friday apparently of a heart attack, while visiting friends in Bethesda, Md. He was 49 years old.

title: U.S. Distance Runners Succeed
description: Last September, Frank Shorter became the first American in 64 years to win an Olympic gold medal in the marathon. Yesterday, Jon Anderson ended four years of foreign rule with a convincing victory in the Boston Marathon.

title: A Growing Shortage of Gasoline in U.S. Threatens Vacationers and Independent Service Station Operators
description: Glen Hatcher, who has kept his Atlanta area gasoline stations open around the clock for nearly 20 years, went out last week to buy some locks for the doors.

title: Five Priests Withhold Taxes
description: PITTSBURGH, April 16 (AP) Five Roman Catholic priests said today that they were withholding 20 per cent of the money due on their Federal income tax returns to protest the continuing United States war effort in Southeast Asia. We will refuse to pay that 20 per cent of our taxes which goes to a war we judge to be totally immoral, said the Rev. John O'Malley, a spokesman for the group.

title: COURT BACKS F.P.C. ON GAS PRICE RAISE
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 16 (AP) Prices for onethird of America's natural gas can be increased by the Federal Power Commission to stimulate further exploration, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled here today.

title: U.M.W. Chief Assails Policies on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The head of the United Mine Workers, whose members dig most of the nation's coal, assailed the Nixon Administration today for what he called its deference to the instincts for profit of private industry in shaping national energy policy.

title: $3Million Is Sought to Insure Future of the Jersey Symphony
description: NEWARK, April 16A drive to raise $3million over a threeyear period for the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra was announced today.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Tempo Quickens in L.I.R.R. Negotiations
description: The tempo of negotiations in the Long Island Rail Road contract dispute quickened yesterday as the end of a 90day coolingoff period approached.

title: NIXON'S RAIL PLAN FAULTED BY I.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 A top aide of the Interstate Commerce Commission told Congress today that the Ninon Administration's plan for resolving the Northeastern railroad crisis was little more than a naive hope.

title: G.I. Search Unit Ready
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 16 (UPI)United States military spokesmen said today that a special American unit assigned to search for more than 1,300 American servicemen missing in Indochina would begin its task as soon as diplomatic permission was received from the countries involved. The spokesman said that organization of the Joint Casualty Resolution Center was 70 per cent completed and that more than 100 of 150 soldiers, assigned to the unit had arrived.

title: Tough Ecology Bill to Protect Coast Sails Through Assembly
description: TRENTON, April 16A tough environmental measure that would give the state the power to ban heavy industry from much of New Jersey's remaining undeveloped coastline was approved overwhelmingly in the Assembly today.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Monday, April 16. 40th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: ONION SHORTAGE STIRS CONSUMERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  For onion fanciers who have been viewing with alarm for some time the sharp escalation in onion prices, matters have now reached a crisis. There are none to be had, even for a great deal of ready money.

title: Pan Am Pays $30,000
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that Pan American World Airways had paid $30,000 in a compromise over civil penalties for illegal ticket discounting on CaliforniaHawaii flights in December, 1971, and January, 1972.

title: G.O.P. Caucus in Trenton Kills Move for Gambling Referendum
description: TRENTON, April 16The drive to put a legalized gambling referendum before the voters in November died in Senate Republican caucus here today without a public fight.

title: Chicago Orders 545 Buses
description: CHICAGO, April 16 (UPI)The Chicago Transit Authority said today it would place the largest single order for buses ever placed in the transit industry when it signs contracts tomorrow for 545 vehicles at a cost of $22.7million. Low bidder for the contract was the Truck and Coach division of the General Motors Corporation at $41,656 a bus.

title: U.S.VSAS ORDERED FOR MEXICAN HELP
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that seasonal workers from Mexico, estimated by the United Farm Workers Union to total between 100,000 and 400,000, must obtain visas before entering the United States.

title: COORS SUBDUE COUGARS, 10894 Kentucky Gains 21 Edge in Playoffs as Issel Excels
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 16 (AP)Led by Dan Issel's 34 points, the Kentucky Colonels defeated the Carolina Cougars, 10894, tonight to take a 21 edge in their American Basketball Association Eastern Division playoffs.

title: The Missing Newsmen
description: WASHINGTONAmong the 1,300 Americans still missing in Indochina, there are five who were not there to shoot anyone, drop bombs or napalm on anyone or help in any other way to carry on the U.S. military intervention.

title: No Lonely Runners in Boston
description: BOSTON, April 16Playing it cool while one leader after another wilted in 77degree heat, Jon Anderson moved up strongly in the late stages today and became the first American since 1968 to win the Boston Marathon. An applauding, sympathetic crowd of perhaps one million saw him do it.

title: News Summary and Index
description: American bombers, for only the second time since the ceasefire in Laos, struck North Vietnamese positions in that country yesterday, Pentagon officials said. Several dozen B52 bombers and F111 fighterbombers hit in and around the Laotian town of Tha Vieng on the southern edge of the Plaine des Jarres, after the town had reportedly been overrun by tanks and troops from North Vietnam. Word of the renewed bombing came amid reports that the Soviet Union had provided advanced SA3 antiaircraft missiles to North Vietnam for the first time, which could render any American decision to resume bombing in Laos more costly than ever before. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: Candidates for the Council
description: Following are the candidate lists as written by the clerks at the Board of Elections (D stands for Democrat, R for Republican, C for Conservative and L for Liberal and incumbents are marked with a *):

title: Prisons Counselor Peter Preiser
description: ALBANY, April 16It would be nice if I could say I was sitting in my office here and the telephone rang and I heard a voice say, Hi, I'm Nelson Rockefeller,  remarked Peter Preiser.

title: JOHN E. FOLEY
description: BUFFALO, April 16 (AP) John E. Foley, director of the Internal Revenue Service in the Buffalo district, died last night in Buffalo General Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: HOUSE RULES OUT PRICE ROLLBACK BY 258147 VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  The House rejected today legislation sponsored by the Democratic leadership that would have placed ceilings on prices, rents and interest rates.

title: Interest Committee Limits Profit Margins for Banks
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends imposed for the first time today a profitmargin limitation on the nation's banks while announcing guidelines for a new dual prime interest rate for loans to business

title: Goss Takes 10Rounder
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP)Sam Goss of Trenton won a unanimous 10round decision twight from Jorge Ramos of San Jose, Calif.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A woman was shot with her own .22 caliber pistol yesterday as she allegedly tried to hold up a Lexington Avenue clothes store. The police said the woman, Lenora Brown of 19101 122d Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, had made several purchases in Mangol's, 736 Lexington Avenue near 58th Street, and had then pulled a pistol at the cash register. The pistol went off in a struggle with the owner, Eugene Gladstone. The woman, shot in the stomach, was taken to Bellevue Hospital in serious condition. While she was being examined, seven decks of heroin dropped from her boots, the police said.

title: Stewardesses Delay Strike, Talks With Eastern Go On
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)Stewardesses and Stewards of Eastern Airlines agreed tonight to postpone a strike deadline until 6 P.M. tomorrow while negotiations continued for a new contract, a national mediator announced.

title: British Rugby
description: British Rugby

title: 2 INDIAN LEADERS DENY U.S. CHARGES
description: PIERRE, S.D., April 16 (UPI) Two leaders of the American Indian Movement pleaded not guilty today to Federal indictments, including charges that they wounded a United States marshal and an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, in the 48dayold occupation of Wounded Knee.

title: CURB ON SPENDING GAINS IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A joint Senate and House study committee gave unanimous ap proval today to a plan for a drastic revision of the Congressional budget process.

title: Israel Holds Arab Editors On a Censorship Charge
description: JERUSALEM, April 16Two Palestinian editors of an last Jerusalem Arabic weekly were arrested by the Israeli police today on charges of evading censorship and inciting revolution among the residents of the West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Forrest Allen, ExReporter For Cleveland Press, Dies
description: CLEVELAND, April 16Forrest Allen, a retired investigative reporter for The Cleveland Press and other ScrippsHoward newspapers, died yesterday in Melbourne while on a roundtheworld tour with his wife, Elizabeth. He was 70 years old and lived in Boulder, Colo.

title: Television
City to Shut Shelter And Jail for Girls Within the Year
description: Callagy Hall, New York City's oftcriticized shelter for adolescent girls, and Manida, the city's turnofthecentury girls jail, will be closed within the year, Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday.

title: Home of a New Zealander In Washington Hit by Bullet
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (Reuters)A bullet shattered window early today at the home of a New Zealand diplomat. The shot was apparently fired by terrorists who believed that the building was still occupied by the Jordanian Ambassador.

title: Rangers Stemkowski Turns on Steam at Playoff Time
description: The clubs that have played some of the more memorable Stanley Cup gamesthe Rangers and Chicago Black Hawks bring their semifinal playoff series to Madison Square Garden tonight for Game 3 of this fourofsevengame affair. The series is tied, 11.

title: Controversial Italian Book Ordered Seized as Obscene
description: LODI, Italy, April 16 (Reuters)A controversial book titled Sex in the Confessional, based on secret tape recordings of 632 false confessions to Roman Catholic priests, has been ordered seized throughout Italy on grounds of obscenity.

title: Splinter Analysts Will Admit The Press to Closed Meetings
description: More than a score of Wall Street's small organizations of security analysts known as splinter groups  often criticized for their closed meetings have decided to permit press attendance.

description: LOS ANGELES, April 16On the 71st day of his trial, Daniel Ellsberg told the jury today, for the first time, that he had disclosed the Pentagon papers to give Congress the confidence to act to end the war.

description: LOS ANGELES, April 16 (AP) The C.B.S. Evening News was nominated today for three Emtny, awards in the news and documentary categories for its coverage of the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama last May 15.

description: Kentucky vs. Carolina

title: Search for Slayer Yields Only Fear
description: For more than five weeks now, a massive manhunt has been conducted by the police throughout the Upper West Sidein fact, throughout the worldfor the man responsible for the brutal murder and sexual mutilation of 10yearold Luis Ortiz, whose body was found in a tenement basement on West 106th Street.

title: Former Transit Policeman Gets 15 Years in Slaying
description: A 28yearold former Transit Authority patrolman was sentenced to 15 years in prison yesterday on a manslaughter conviction stemming from a gun slaying in Greenwich Village in August, 1968.

title: MEDIU IS THREAT TO KEKICH STATUS
description: When George Medich passed up the second half of his third year of medical school to go to spring training with the Yankees last month, he wanted to find out whether or not he could win a major league job. He won the job, and in the next week he'll find out just how good that job is.

title: George K. Myers, 61, Dies; Executive of Boy Scouts
description: George K. Myers, director of finance and relationships for the Boy Scouts of America national office in North Brunswick, N.J., and Manhattan Scout Executive from 1948 to 1954, died Thursday of a heart attack in Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Matawan and Mendham, N. J.

title: Marathon Victor's Dad Not Quite Speechless
description: SALEM, Ore., April 16 (UPI) Mayor Les Anderson of Eugene, Ore., lost his political cool today when he heard his son, Jon, won the Boston Marathon.

title: Philadelphia Boy, Slain
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP)  Twelveyearold Jones Bedford, walking home from church yesterday, was fatally shot as he tried to warn his brother of an approaching gang. The killer reportedly, fled in an auto.

title: Chavez's Followers Picket Grape Fields In Teamster Dispute
description: INDIO, Calif., April 16 (AP) Several hundred MexicanAmerican followers of Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farm Workers, picketed several grape ranches in the lower Coachella Valley today after their union lost field work contracts to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Teacher Who Opposed Flag Pledge Wins Court Fight
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Supreme Court let stand today a decision barring public school officials from discharging a teacher who refuses to recite the Pledge of Allegiance to the flag with pupils in her homeroom.

title: Not the SST Again?
description: A littlenoticed item in President Nixon's proposed budget suggests that the supersonic transport plane still has a champion or two in the White House. The sum of $5.8 million is included to cover further studies of the plane's possible effect on the stratosphere. The persistence of the SST's promoters within the Government is remarkable on at least three counts. Financially, it seems farfetched for the Administration to find even this modest sum to spare when it is paring all other programs to the boneparticularly when the foreignmade Concorde is losing potential customers.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: U.S. and Europe: Ties Are Damaged but Not Irreparably
description: BRUSSELS, April 14The echoes of President Nixon's pronouncement that this is the year of Europe are ringing here, but with a hollow and sometimes sardonic tone. No one contends that EuropeanAmerican relations are as good as they should or could be. Assessments vary, but the range is only from frankly, the cilmate is not good to this is a time of transition; things are not so bad as they appear. Talks with many influential people of different nationalities produced a clear consensusthat this is a time of change on both sides of the Atlantic, that nothing irreparable has happened to the relations on which the Western world's safety and prosperity have been based for more than a generation; that serious irritants have developed and that it willtake conscious and skillful effort to avert real danger.

title: Mrs. Meir Says That Fulbright Has Never Shown Friendship
description: TEL AVIV, April 16 (Reuters) Premier Golda Meir said in an interview published here today that Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chairman of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee, had never said a good word about Israel.

title: Muskie Defends Rules Curbing Car Emissions
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 Senator Edmund S. Muskie opened a counterattack today against the auto industry's effort to win a reduction in the auto emission standards set by the 1970 clean air act.

Tostao, 26, years old, has undergone surgery on the, left eye twice in the last two months and he said his playing career would depend on how it healed in the next four months.

Flanigan, a top Presidential adviser, predicted yesterday that the Administration's trade bill would be enacted by the House of Representatives by September in time for the start of forthcoming world trade negotiations. As for Senate approval, his expectation is that it will come by the end of the year.

description: HARRISON, N. Y., April 16 Sam Snead, hailed as the greatest player in the history of golf, waited until the ovation given him today at the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association ceremony ceased, and said, I'm surprised and happy.

title: SAIGON REPORTS BORDER FIGHTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 17A South Vietnamese military official said yesterday that Government troops might have crossed the border into Cambodia Sunday as newsmen on the scene reported.

title: People in Sports: Yanks Get Hart to Fill dh Role

Hart, a 31yearold third baseman and outfielder who has been prone to injury since coming up the Giants in 1964, will be used mainly as a designated hitter.

title: No Gains Without Pains
description: LOS ANGELESHere in Southern dalifornia there is no way to escape the socalled environmental issues and their human costs. Air pollution is something you see and breatheand cause when you take to the freeways. The energy crisis is in plain view out in the Santa Barbara Channel. Offshore oil drilling is an issue in the city election, as it may become in New York tion, politics with the discovery of oil deposits off Long Island.

title: Dublin Frees I.R.A. Chief
description: DUBLIN, April 16  Sean MacStiofain, the onetime chief of staff of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, was released from the Curragh Military Prison this moring and told newsmen at the gates, I remain an unrepentant republican separatist.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Witco Chemical Corporation has completed its plan to purchase 200,000 shares of its common stock in the open market and through block purchases. The shares will be used for convertible securities and stock option programs. The stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 20 up .

title: Elizabeth Flood, 67 Debutante, Wed to John Fell Stevenson

Stevenson, United States Representative to the United Nations, and the late Mrs. Borden Stevenson. The ceremony in the Woodside Village Church, Congregational, was performed by the Rev. Patrick McConnell.

title: Screen:'How Tasty Was My Little Frenchman'
description: Anybody confronting a film with a title like "How Tasty Was My Little Frenchman" has a right to know what it is about. Well, it happens to be about eating a Frenchmanthough that's not all. And even that isn't quite the simple gastronomic thrill the average moviegoer may have come to expect from his celluloid cannibalism.In the coastal wilds of 16th-century Brazil, a French soldier (Arduino Colasanti) escapes his officersonly to be captured first by the Portuguese and then by a tribe of man-eating Indians. Mistaking him for one of their mortal enemies, the Portuguese, the Indians decide to kill him for his crimes and then to eat him for his powers. But first he is given a long period of relative privilege, enjoying a young Indian wife (Ana Maria Magalhaes) and counseling the tribal chief (Ital Natur). This period is the central concern of the film.But it is not the only concern. "How Tasty Was My Little Frenchman" means to be a meditation on the past and perhaps the future of Brazilironic, often comicand it mixes fictional drama with allusions to economic, social and religious history. In portraying its Indians, it exercises great care (there is an elaborate Indian village, which looks for all the world like a superb, animated textbook reconstruction), and if they sometimes suggest too much the noble savage, they at least represent an attempt at verisimilitude.The verisimilitude, of course, is something of a joke. The Indians are middle-class white Brazilians (ordinary men and exceptionally beautiful young women) stripped down and reddened up for the occasion. "How Tasty Was My Little Frenchman" is the first absolutely non-exploitative (not nonerotic) movie I have seen to require almost total nudity from its cast, both sexes. Everyone is very convincing, but not always so convincing as to dissociate daily life in a 16th-century Indian village from just having an awfully good time.But in the last analysis the film isn't all that funny, and it doesn't really mean to be. A very uneven work, its best passages are among its most seriousespecially one sequence near the end, when the Indian wife describes for her captive husband the ritual that is to be his death. Half-dancing, sometimes smiling, sometimes almost crying, she re-creates on a barren placea huge rock by the seashoreall the elements and emotions of a complex and fateful drama. It is a lovely performance, and, in its respect for space and movement, it seems very close to the spirit of classic cinema."How Tasty Was My Little Frenchman," which was directed by Nelson Pereira dos Santos, opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema.

description: HONOLULU, April 16 (UPI)  Striking teachers and the Hawaii Department of Education announced today that they had agreed to settle their threeweek dispute by arbitration.

description: Esthetically shaped and tasteful gymnastics in wittily appealing vignettes is the most obvious quality of the Pilobolus Dance Theater. This small company of four men presented seven works Sunday afternoon at The Space.
