description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Administration told a Congressional subcommittee today that the daily bombing raids over Cambodia had permitted the survival of the Lon Nol Government but had failed so far to persuade the Communistbacked insurgents to start negotiations for a ceasefire.

title: Jonson's Bartholomew Fair in Capital
description: BARTHOLOMEW FAIR, a play by Ben Jonson. Directed by Robert Mandel; setting by William G. Mickley Jr.; costumes by Pullallen Weiss; lighting by Jack Carr; composer, Robert Dennis; choreographer, Virginia Freeman; music director, Cash Clay; production stage manager, Steven Ristow. presented by the Foiger Theater Group; producer, Richmond Crinkly, associate producer, Louis W. Scheeder. At the Folger Theater In Washington.

title: Energy at Issue
description: Battered by conflicting scenarios of doomsday, threatened with cutoffs of electricity at any moment, warned of the possibility of localized gasoline rationing this summer, the American consumer has ample reason to demand Federal Government leadership in charting a way out of this country's energy crisis.

title: Chess:
description: There have always been gamblers of the chessboard, hunch players who prefer to operate beyond the limits of foreseeable logic. When the genial Frank Marshall, United States champion from 1909 to 1936, got off a brilliant knight sacrifice in a game with H. Wolf, Nuremberg, 1906, he scribbled the symbol for questionable (!?) next to his move on his scoresheet,

title: Francks of Molloy Tosses Javelin 207.3 in Relays
description: Steve Francks of Archbishop Molloy posted the second best javelin throw in New York State history yesterday on the first day of the Brooklyn Diocese Catholic High School relay carnival at St. John's University in Queens. The meet will be completed next Monday.

title: Chrysler's Earnings Soar As Many Companies Gain
description: DETROIT, April 16 (UPI) The Chrysler Corporation today reported record sales and earnings for the first quarter of 1973, but it said the profit would have been higher if the company could have raised prices further to balance costs.

title: Scott Panel Urges Halting Work on New Hospitals
description: An immediate halt to all new hospital construction here, both public and private, was recommended yesterday by a state commission that has spent year and a half examining the inner workings of the Lindsay administration.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BALTIMORE, Apra 16 (UPI)Marian Bender, a flashy filly who has been nominated for the May 19 running of the $150,000added J'reakness Stakes, chalked up her seventh straight victory in eight career starts today. She defeated five other Marylandbred 3yearold fillies Pimlico. Pete's Lass was second, Softly was third.

title: GOINT OUT Guide
description: ISLANDERS A play about West Indians living outside of West Indies, performed by West Indians living in New York and written by Edgar White, a West Indian living away from home (he's studying architecture at Yale), will be shown at 8 today through Saturday at the Billie Holiday Theater, 1368 Fulton Street, between Brooklyn and New York Avenues in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyesvant section (63609189). Lament for Rastafari is a comedydrama, a ritual concerned about the islanders who emigrate and often behave like tourists when they go home. The cast, speaking in island idioms, particularly those of Jamaica, was assembled by the Cornbread Players and is directed by Albert Le Vau, The Billie Holiday Theater is a 218seater, a new house completely built from scratch In what was once a milkbottling plant. It opened about a year ago and has been busy ever since.

title: MRS. BASIL MANLY
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Mrs. Marie Bradley Manly, widow of Basil Manly, economist, author and former chairman of the Federal Power Commission, died yesterday at her home here. She was 91 years old.

title: Truce Unit to Ask Vietcong To Permit Crash Site Visit
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 17A fournation truce investigating team unanimously has agreed to ask the Vietcong to let survivors of the crash of a peacekeeping helicopter visit the wreckage to determine whether it was moved, Canadian sources said today.

title: Rockefeller Masquerade
description: Governor Rockefeller's modified drug program is in some respects worse than the one he originally unveiled some weeks ago. While he has dropped hashish from the list of dangerous drugs for which lifeterm penalties might be imposedcertainly a welcome changeMr. Rockefeller at the same time proposes to expand the application of mandatory criminal sentences. This is a discredited idea, which judges, prosecutors, penal officials and parole authorities almost uniformly oppose.

title: QUARTER'S LOSSES SHRINK AT POE
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad reported yesterday a firstquarter net losson a fully accrued basisof $55.2million. This represented a decrease of 15.2 per cent from the $65.2million net loss reported for the comparable period of 1972.

title: HOMER BY HORTON BEATS RED SOX, 97
description: BOSTON, April 16 (AP)Willie Horton wrecked Boston strategy by smashing a threerun homer today, powering the Detroit Tigers to a 97 victory over the Red Sox before a Patriot's Day crowd of 29,006.

title: Cleveland Nuptials
description: CLEVELAND, April 16 Miss Patricia Angly, an editorial assistant with Cleveland, a magazine, was married here this morning to Peter G. Dearing, a law student at Case Western Reserve University. The civil ceremony was performed in the Municipal Court.

title: F.D.A. Orders Containers That Children Cannot Open
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration ordered today that prescription drugs for oral dosage be packaged in containers most children cannot open.

title: City to Shut Shelter and Jail for Girls
description: Callagy Hall, New York City'softcriticized shelter for adolescent girls, and Manida, the city's turnofthecentury girls jail, will be closed within the year, Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday.

title: Search for Slayer Yields Only Fear
description: For more than five weeks now, a massive manhunt has been conducted by the police throughout the Upper West Sidein fact, throughout the worldfor the man responsible for the bnital murder and sexual mutilation of 10yearold Luis Ortiz, whose body was found in a tenement basement on West 106th Street.

title: QE 2 Changes Route
description: LONDON, April 16 (AP)The British luxury liner Queen Elizabeth 2, wary of possible Palestinian guerrilla attacks while carrying hundreds of Jews to Israel in a Passover cruise, changed her route tonight to Stay far from the North African coast.

title: Big Board Members Merge
description: Coggeshall & Hicks, Inc., and Laidlaw & Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that they had completed their previously announced plan to merge to form Laid lawCoggeshall, Inc. The Canadian affiliate of Laidlaw is not involved in the transaction. The newly formed company will be active in investment banking and will act as brokers and dealers in stocks, bonds and mutualfund shares.

title: Advertising: Buyers vs. Sellers
description: The buyers are saying the prices are too high and the sellers are saying they're too low. So what else is new? said Mike Weinblatt, vice president for sales of the National Broadcasting Company television network.

title: Letters to the Editor
Mrs. Mitchell Calls White House Denial A GodBlessed Lie
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) Mrs. Martha Mitchell said today that a White House denial that her husband, former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, conferred with President Nixon at the White House Saturday was a Godblessed lie.

title: Trapped Commuters on Hand to Greet New Train Arriving at Grand Central
description: The New Haven Division of the Penn Central unveiled the first of a modern fleet of commuter cars yesterday in a special run from Stamford, Conn., to Grand Central Terminal. The train was new but, to New Haven veterans, its performance was familiar: it was 12 minutes late.

title: Licensed Masseurs Sue City to Exempt Them in New Law
description: Statelicensed masseurs and masseuses, up in arms over a city law scheduled to go into effect tomorrow, a law actually aimed at massage parlors, have filed suit in State Supreme Court to prevent the law's being applied to them.

title: FASHION TALK
description: When Ralph Lauren presented his Polo collection for men, he was wearing a pinstriped black suit, a white shirt and a black tie. How long has it been since designers dressed that way?

title: SAIGON REPORTS BORDER FIGHTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 17A South Vietnamese military official said yesterday that Government troops might have crossed the border into Cambodia Sunday as newsmen on the scene reported;

title: Evelyn Waugh Diary: A Life Revisited
description: LONDON, April 16They drank themselves silly. They went to brothels in Paris. They loved orgies. Some established homosexual relationships. And they all moved in smart and clever circles where people say such things as, My dear, if I caught a cold from you, I should cherish it.

title: Energy Crisis: Shortages Amid Plenty
description: The following is the second in a series of articles on the world fuel and energy situation.

title: Broiler Chicken Association Sued by U.S. as PriceFixen
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)The Justice Department today accused the National Broiler Association of fixing prices.

title: Radio
TRIAL BEGINS IN CASE OF TELEX VS. I.B.M.
description: TULSA, Okla., April 16A $1billion Federal District Court trial between the Tulsabased Telex Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation began today with Telex lawyers asking the court to make the computeraccessories market competitive again.

title: Phelps Dodge Plans Smelter
description: The Phelps Dodge Copper Corporation, a subsidiary of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, announced yesterday in Santa Fe, New Mexico, that it planned to build a $100millionplus copper smelter in New Mexico, 17 miles southwest of the tiny cattleloading station of Hachita. It will be designed to handle all ore from the company's openpit at Tyrone, about 75 miles north.

title: Bridge:
description: The final stages of the Grand National Championship in Westchester and New Jersey were completed during the weekend. The winners were David Mason and Ron Rubin of Maplewood, N. J.; Louis Levy of Fort Lee, N. J., and Neil Silverman of East Orange, N. J. They will compete with the Greater New York Bridge Association winners, to be decided next weekend, and the New England champions, to determine the zonal champions.

title: Playoff Survivors vs. Each Other
Amerigo Lassie Wins at Big A
description: Amerigo Lassie of the Live Oak Plantation won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, and the first thing the assistant trainer, Pat Kelly, said to the filly's rider in the winner's circle was, I'm sure glad she runs with her neck out.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Tagging is one of the most effective ways to learn something of the growth rate, numbers and migratory habits of fish.

title: Argentina Ousts South Africa In Davis Cup. Play in Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 16 (AP) GuillermoVilas defeated South Africa's Deon Joubere, 62, 61, 61 today to enable Argentina to clinch the Davis Cup South American Zone semifinal series.

title: Slower Growth Was Voted For Monetary Aggregates
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted at its Jan. 16 meeting to seek bank reserve and money market conditions that would support slower growth in the monetary aggregates than occurred in the second half of last year.

title: U.S. BOMBS TOWN IN LAOS, CHARGING A TRUCE BREACH BY THE NORTH VIETNAMESE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  American bombers, for only the second time since the ceasefire in Laos, today struck North Vietnamese positions in that country, Pentagon officials said.

title: Picasso Buried in a Private Rite In Park of Vauvenargues Castle
description: PARIS, April 16  Pablo Picasso was buried this afternoon in the park of his 16thcentury castle at Vauvenargues, near AixenProvence.

title: HOUSE RULES OUT PRICE ROLLBACK BY 258447 VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The House rejected today legislation sponsored by the Democratic leadership that would have placed ceilings on prices, rents and interest rates.

title: Study Links Tooth Decay To Presweetened Cereals
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) A special Senate committee today made public a 1967 Food and Drug Administration report showing that a very high rate of cavities occurs among children who eat presweetened cereals.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: April 12Rangers 4, Chi. 1.

title: Pfizer Earnings and Sales Break Records in Quarter
The Opera
TV  Child Monitor for Mothers Is Installed in Bronxdale Houses
description: An experimental electronic security system, which enables mothers in their apartments to monitor their children playing outside by means of closedcircuit television inside their own apartments, has been installed in a Bronx housing project on a $157,000 grant from the Mayor's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council.

title: SABOTAGE EFFORT IN LEBANON FAILS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 16 (AP)Unknown saboteurs tried to blow up the ArabianAmerican Oil Company's pipeline today, Government sources in southern Lebanon reported.

title: Energy Crisis: Shortages Amid Plenty
description: The following is the second in a series of articles on the world fuel and energy situation.

title: Oswald Resigns as Head of State's Jails
description: ALBANY, April 16Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had accepted with deep regret the longreported resignation of his Commissioner of Correction, Russell G. Oswald, effective May 1.

title: Stiff Disclosure Bill On Campaign Funds Passed in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 16 The State Assembly gave final legislative approval by an overwhelming margin today to a tough campaign disclosure bill that provides criminal penalties for state or local candidates who willfully violate its terms.

title: METALS FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: President Nixon's announcement that he planned to cut the nation's stockpiled materials by some $6billion worth of commodities out of a total of $6.7billion sent metals full tures tumbling on the commodities markets yesterday.b This move could result in lower prices at wholesale and possibly in reduced prices at retail for articles made from such materials.

title: Trot Drivers Asked to Take LieDetector Tests
description: In the wake of the suspension of superfecta betting at New York race tracks and OTB shops, George M. Levy, president of Roosevelt Raceway, has asked that all drivers at his track take a liedetector test.

title: A Suburban Street Where Integration Is a Friendly Tradition
description: RYE, N.Y.  Grapal Street looks like a perfectly ordinary suburban street. Curving in a now sharp, now gentle Sshape for the length of about one long city block, it is lined with small neat houses and immaculate little lawns, treeshaded, flowerbright and filled with the homey sound of children playing.

title: Deaths
Concert Music by Vivian Fine Performed at Finch
description: A complete program of anybody's music can be too much, even if the anybody is a Bach or a Beethoven who has been unlucky enough to attract a mediocre performer's undivided attention. But a concert of Vivian Fine's compositions at Finch College Concert Hall on Sunday night proved all too short, for two good reasons: She writes elegant and inventive works, and Jan DeGaetani thinks highly enough of them to pour her remarkable talent unstintingly into them.

title: 2 Contracts Are Let For Sports Complex
description: NEWARK, April 16 (AP) Contracts totaling $7.8million for the race track and football stadium at the Hackensack Meadowlands sports complex were announced today at a meeting of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: 2 of 33 New Council Districts Held to Violate Contiguity
description: Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of the Bronx, land the five Republican county leaders won a partial victory yesterday in a suit to have the newly established Councilmanic districts declared in violation of the State and Federal Constitutions.

title: CLEAN AIR COSTLY, STATES TELL U. S.
description: New York and New Jersey are telling the Federal Government it will be too costly for them to meet cleanair standards by 1975.

title: A Picasso Worth $207,500 Is Stolen From Paris Home
description: PARIS, April 16 (Reuters)A Picasso painting valued at $207,500 was stolen from a private collection here today. It was the second robbery in the last few days of a canvas by the late painter.

title: REDS USE HOMERS TO DOWN PADRES
description: SAN DIEGO, April 16 (AP) Tony Perez, Dave Concepcion) and Johnny Bench hit home runs tonight to lead the Cincinnati Reds to a 76 victory over the Padres.

title: Munich: Reinhardt and Echoes of Past
description: MUNICH, West Germany In September, Germany and Austria will note the centenary of the birth of the first largerthanlife stage director: Max Reinhardt, Letters of his and scientific publications on him have appeared recently, and just now in Salzburg, where Reinhardt lived in the glory and pageantry of Schloss Leopoldskron, a book has come out on Reinhardt's staging of Molieretaking in two anniversaries at one stroke. But the most moving testimonial is the slim volume by the movie director Gottfried Reinhardt on his father, Der Liebhaber (The Lover). The best part in it is the detailed description of Reinhardt's staging of Die Fledermaus, which opened with a pantomime scene: An elegant man wearing a cape, smoking a cigarette in the garden of a wine restaurant, is planning a sinful evening. The scene expressed the theatrical essence of the whole show and integrated the music with the action as it had never been done before.

title: Appeals Court Bars U.S. Plea for Delay OnIntegration Move
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia denied today the Government's request to halt courtordered desegregation proceedings against school districts in 17 states.

title: AETNA LIFE WILL BUY 100% OF AIMS GROUP
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced plans yesterday to enter the field of total personal financial counseling by the proposed purchase of the AIMS Group, Inc.

title: VACANT U.S. POST A SOVIET CONCERN
description: MOSCOW, April 16Many Soviet conversation with visiting Americans these days opens with a discreet private question: What can you tell us about who our ambassador will be?

title: $5.25Million More Voted For Nassau Medical Unit
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 16 The Board of Supervisors today authorized an additional $5.525million to complete the Dynamic Care Building at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow.

title: Skylab Space Station Is Moved to Pad
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 16 (AP)  The Skylab space station was moved to its launching pad today to be prepared for launching on May 14.

title: India Drought Perils Millions
description: LONDON, April 16An official of Christian Aid, a charity organization said today that more than 20 million people were imperiled in India's worst drought since 1800.

title: THUNDERSTORMS ADD TO MISSISSIPPI WOE
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., April 16 (UPI)  Heavy thunderstorms dumped more water today on already flooded sections of Mississippi and caused new flash flooding in other parts of the state.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New York's Environmental Protection Administrator, Herbert Elish, called upon the Port Authority yesterday to reverse its announced intention to nearly double the price of tickets at the authority's Park and Ride facility in North Bergen.

title: Study Finds Colleges Now in a Fragile Stability on Finances
description: The country's colleges and universities, faced with a deepening financial crisis two years ago, have achieved a fragile stability in the tugofwar between rapidly rising costs and more slowly growing incomes, according to a new report by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education.

title: Nixon Asks Death Penalty For Murderers and Spies
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) The Administration asked Congress today to restore the death penalty under specific circumstances.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Methadone maintenance, which in the last decade has blossomed from a tentative experiment into a major therapy for heroin addiction, has not achieved unanimous acceptance in the United States. Indeed, in the eyes of some physicians involved in addiction treatment, the methadone debate, which is profoundly political, could curtail or at least inhibit the expansion of maintenance programs that now reach some 94,000 addicts around the country.

title: ExOfficers of Krueger Are Suing Lear Siegler
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 16 (AP) Fifteen former officers of the Krueger Manufacturing Company have filed suit against the Lear Siegler Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., alleging fraud and deception in the California company's purchase of Kreuger three years ago.

title: Wilson Says Wings Clipped His Wings
description: DETROIT, April 16 (AP) Johnny Wilson, dismissed last Friday as coach of the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League, fired repeated volleys of criticism at the team's front office during a news conference today.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Knicks vs. Boston

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW ORLEANSAcquired Preston Riley, wide receiver, from San Francisco for future draft choice.

title: 42,812 Jobs to Be Lost
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Defense Department informed members of Congress today of plans to close or change the size of 274 military bases as part of an economy move estimated eventually to save $400million annually.

title: Aura of Billie Holiday Is Captured at the Jazz Museum
description: What is still tangible of the sound and the sight and the aura of Billie Holiday has been brought together in an exhibition at the New York Jazz Museum, 125 West 55th Street. The exhibition, Billie Holiday Remembered, is made up of pictures, records, films, mementos and spoken recollections of the singer, who died in 1959 and would have celebrated her 58th birthday on April 7. It will continue every day, from noon until 7 P.M., through June.

title: Shipping/Mails
Stronger Job Insurance
description: President Nixon has made three useful suggestions for improving the Federalstate unemployment insurance system. Congress ought not only to approve all three but also to add at least two more reforms in the interest of making the system stronger still.

title: Four N.B.A. Playoff Survivors Analyzed
description: The number of possible champions of the National Basketball Association for 1973 is down to four, and each team has ample reason to consider its own chances excellent.

title: BRAZILIAN STUDENTS ASSAIL GOVERNMENT
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 16 (AP)  Student leaders from five major universities circulated a secretly printed note today accusing the militaryrun Government of responding to legitimate student activities with slander, threats, arrests and even death.

title: Japan Registered Record Deficit In March Balance of Payments
description: TOKYO, April 16The Finance Ministry reported today that Japan had registered a record monthly deficit of $1.1billion in the nation's balance of international payments in March.

title: The Reading Question
description: The dispatch by the Board of Regents of a 25man task force to reverse the massive reading failure in the city's schools might lead the innocent observer to believe there could be a quick, spectacular solution to this most difficult problem. To kindle hopes of a panacea would be as irresponsible as to dismiss out of hand the contributions that a group of outside experts might make. The prerequisite is a task force with no political ax to grind.

title: The Can'tDo Guys
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 4 Those of us who were brought up with absolute faith in the absolute superiority of American mechanical skills cannot help feeling embarrassed about Detroit's performance in this matter of exhaust pollution standards.

title: Federal Judge George Rosling Of Eastern District Dies at 72
description: Federal Judge George Rosling, who had served on the bench for the Eastern District of New York since 1961, died yesterday in the Downstate Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 1600 East 26th Street in Brooklyn.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MORRISTOWN, April 16Don't be surprised if the funminded Morris Bar softball team of the New Jersey Industrial League opens its season by serving an order show cause to the seven other clubs in the Class A division.

title: Jews Begin Passover By Partaking in Seder
description: Jews began the weeklong observance of Passover at sundown yesterday, marking the liberation of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian bondage.

title: Briefs on The Arts
description: Advanced plans for a new Broadway version of the longrunning mystery thriller, Sleuth, with one or two women in the hitherto allmale cast, wait chiefly upon the possible acceptance of the lead by Joan Crawford.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: DOWN

title: Balance From the Bottom Up
description: WASHINGTONBelieve me, President Nixon, prices just aren't going to stop rising without some firm, nononsense action from you. And may I respectfully suggest that you act quickly and start a Phase 4 right at the heart of the matterprices of food at the farm level.

title: Miss Dillon Bride Of Peter Greenfield
description: In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Barbara Joy Dillon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reed Aldridge Dillon of Indianapolis, became the bride of Peter Roe Greenfield. He is the son of Mrs. Henry Kirkham Parsons of Princeton, N. J., and the late Dr. Nathaniel L. Greenfield, a Princeton pediatrician.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Bronx policemen were suspended for refusing complete cooperation with a Police Department inquiry into charges that a man was thrown to his death by two policemen from a Bronx roof last September. The two suspended men, William Byrne and Gerard McCann, face departmental charges. The case involves Jorge Gallardo, an electrician, who died in a plunge from the roof after he had been chased there by policemen who were trying to quell a street disturbance. Mr. Gallardo was heard to have cried don't throw me.

title: For the College Student Who Fails at Hot Plate Cooking
description: STONY BROOK, L. I. What happens when students in a college dormitory are suddenly forced to cook for themselves?

title: NYQUIST SHIELDS PARENTS NAMES
description: ALBANY, April 16  State education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist refused today to order the New York City Board of Education to furnish lists of names and addresses of parents of students in the city schools to candidates in the forthcoming elections for community school board members.

title: 3 BIG BANKS POST PROFIT INCREASES
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Continental Illinois Corporation, holding companies that own three of the country's largest banks, reported higher firstquarter earnings yesterday.

title: Judges'
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) The Supreme Court upheld today a Massachusetts constitutional amendment requiring judges to retire at age 70.

title: College and School Results
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: German Steel Mill Ordered
description: ESSEN, West Germany, April 16 (UPI)The Brazilian Usiminas concern has ordered a steel mill worth $22.9million from Ferrostahl, A.G., a spokesman for the West German company said today. Ferrostahl is a subsidiary of the Gutehoffnungshuette industrial giant. the new mill will increase Usiminas's annual crudesteel capacity to 2.4 from its present 1.4 million tons, the spokesman said

title: Interest Committee Limits Profit Margins for Banks
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends imposed for the first time today a profitmargin limitation on the nation's banks while announcing guidelines for a new dual prime interest rate for loans to business

title: Prices of Stocks Decline In a Slow Trading Session
description: The stock market plodded through another dull session yesterday in slow trading.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Jack Sharkey left the Yankee Stadium that night and he didn't even know it. He had just been knocked out by Jack Dempsey and he wasn't aware of that either. He stood on the sidewalk outside and kept looking upwards at the clouds that were blotting out the stars. He shook his head and turned to his manager, Johnny Buckley.

title: ODDITIES NOTED IN COUNCIL RACES
description: There is a sevencandidate race in a City Council district in Brooklyn that includes Martin Markowitz and Morris Markowitz  something that occurred with malice aforethought, Martin Markowitz charged yesterday. Morris Markowitz denied it.

title: Bond Prices Reflect a Mixed Pattern
HYMAN J. FLIEGEL, 74 LAWYER. AND ZIONIST
description: HYMAN J. FLIEGEL, 74, LAWYER. AND ZIONISTHyman J. Fliegel, a retired lawyer, died yesterday in Miami Beach. He was 74 years old and lived at 141 East 21st Street, Brooklyn.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 18, 1973

title: Supreme Court Limits the Right of Criminals to Protest Bias in the Grand Jury System After Convictions
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Supreme Court imposed limits today on the right of criminals to protest after their trials that the grand juries that indicted them had been chosen by a racially discriminatory system.

title: Equity Financing
description: Hatteras Income Securities, a bond fund advised by the North Carolina National Bank, made of a public offering yesterday of 2.75 million shares of capital stock through a sixmanager syndicate of underwriting firms headed by Salomon Brothers. The stock was priced at $20 a share.

title: Mr. Nixon Turns Around
description: President Nixon's complete aboutface on the Watergate affairfrom a stance of belligerent resistance to the promise of full White House cooperation with both a Federal grand jury and the select Senate committeeis as welcome as it is belated.

title: Lucas Is Seen as Key to the Knicks Chances
description: The most essential victory so far this season will be the goal of the New York Knicks tonight when they square off against the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden at 9, an unusually late starting time caused by the need to dismantle the circus after a matinee performance.

title: DEMOCRATS PLAN NIXON BUDGET CUT
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Key Democrats on the Senate Appropriations Committee disclosed today that they intended to slash at least $1.6billion from the $268.7billion that President Nixon has proposed to spend in the next budget year.

title: BANKERS MAY AID RAILROADS IN EAST
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Secretary of Transportation, Claude S. Brinegar, told Congress today that he had strong indications from the financial community that private] funding would be available to help restructure troubled railroads in the Northeast.

title: School Vending Machines Assailed for Junk Food
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  School lunch officials warned the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs today that vending machines that dispense junk food threatened to undermine the national school lunch program.

title: House Panel Disagrees on Shield Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Seven members of a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee tried in vain today to reach a consensus on a news men's privilege bill.

title: Graham Winslow, Who Headed Council for Public Schools, Dies
description: SOUTH DUXBURY, Mass., April 17Graham T. Winslow, who was chairman of the Council for Public School and its Massachusetts council from their formation in 1950 to his resignation last June, died yesterday in Jordan Hospital, Plymouth. He was 80 years old.

title: Text of Nixon's Statement
description: I have two announcements to make. Because of their technical nature, I shall read both of the announcements to the members of the press corps.

title: 6 May Go in the Wood, But It's a 2Horse Race
description: He's fast and fit, said Lucien Laurin, trainer of Secretariat. I'm not conceding anything, said Frank (Pancho) Martin, trainer of Sham.

title: FLORIDIAN INDICTED ON PEONAGE CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The leader of a migrant camp in Homestead, Fla., was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Miami today on charges of holding 13 workers in peonage and involuntary servitude, the Justice Department said.

title: Judge Lets Telex Use I.B.M. Figures In Monopoly Case
description: TULSA, Okla., April 17 (UPI) A Federal judge today allowed the Telex Corporation to submit evidence from the International Business Machines Corporation's files in its $1.2billion antitrust suit against the giant computer concern.

title: 50 Catologue Outlets Set
description: ST. LOUIS, April 17 (UPI) The Consumers Distributing Company, a joint venture of the May Department Stores Company of St. Louis and the Consumers Distributing Company of Toronto, announced today plans to open 50 catalogue showroom stores in the New York and San Francisco areas this year. The company hopes ultimately to have 150 catalogue showroom stores.

title: MRS. PETER TISHMAN IS KILLED IN PLUNGE
description: Ellen Tishman, wife of the realty operator Peter Tishman, jumped or fell to her dath yesterday morning from the thirdfloor window of the couple's nineroom apartment at 1120 Park Avenue, the police said.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: EAST DIVISION

title: Heinsohn Coach of Year in N. B. A.
description: Tom Heinsohn of the Boston Celtics was named yesterday as the National Basketball Association coach of the year for the 197273 season.

title: Ruckelshaus Seeks to Ease an Emission Standard
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 William D. Ruckeishaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that the 1976 auto emission standard for nitrogen oxides was unnecessarily stringent and that he would propose its relaxation after further study.

title: IMMUNITY BARRED
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 President Nixon announced today that major developments had come to light in the Watergate case as a result of a new investigation that he himself had conducted.

title: Records: Bernstein Conducts Carmen
description: The new Deutsche Grammophon recording of Bizet's Carmen (2709043, three disks, $20.94), which should be in the shops momentarily, is of significance on several counts. Using essentially the same forces as the Metropolitan Opera's opening production last fall, it stands as a document for those who were there of what was reportedly a gripping musicaltheatrical experience, and as a memento of what might have eventually taken place at the Met, had Goeran Gentele lived to effectuate his reforms.

title: CheckingInterest Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Senate Banking Committee today approved a bill to authorize the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to regulate checkwriting on interestpaying accounts at savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks if the affected states do not do so.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
3 PICASSO CHILDREN SUING FOR LEGALITY
description: PARIS, April 17Pablo Picasso's three illegitimate children, Claude RuizPicasso, his sister Paloma, and Maya Widmaier, have filed suit to be declared his legal offspring, their lawyer Gaston Bouthoul, said in Antibes yesterday. If the court grants such recognition, it would enable them to take the next step of seeking part of Picasso's vast inheritance. The painter's direct heirs are his widow, Jacqueline Roque Picasso, and his only legitimate child, Paulo.

title: New Traffic Chief Sworn In
description: Mayor Lindsay today swore in Benjamin Ward as the city's Traffic Commissioner in ceremonies at City Hall. Mr. Ward, former deputy police commissioner for community affairs, replaces Theodore Karagheuzoff in the post.

title: Fannie Mae Posts Increase In Income for First Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (Reuters)  The Federal National Mortgage Association said today that income from its mortgage portfolio rose to $45million in the first quarter from $27.9million a year earlier.

title: Major League Box Scores
Peter and the Wolf Given With Dancers From Boston Ballet
description: After having survived a halfdozen productions of Peter and the Wolf, one realizes that the music and the narrator are paramount, with cute costuming following behind. The Robert F. Kennedy Theater for Children production broke no new ground, but provided a pleasant hour of the key ingredients on Monday afternoon at the Beacon Theater.

title: Derby Nominee Is Sold
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 17 (UPI)  Kentucky Derby nominee Hearts of Lettuce, owned by Tom Gentry of Lexington and William R. Eagan, was sold today for an undisclosed price. The purchaser was identified as Peter Tattersall, a Louisiana horseman.

title: G. O. P. OPPOSES CONTROLS ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Legislation extending President Nixon's authority to regulate wages and prices ran into unexpected difficulty in Congress today, raising considerable doubt whether a bill could be enacted by the April 30 deadline.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 17 (AP)The National Collegiate Athletic Association pressured at least one athlete to withdraw from the United StatesSoviet Union track meet, a United States district court was told today.

title: Monsanto Reports Record Results
description: The Monsanto Company, the nation's third largest chemical producer, achieved the highest sales and earnings of any quarter in its history in this year's first three months, according to the results reported yesterday.

title: U.S. BOMBS IN LAOS FOR 2D DAY IN ROW
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 United States B52 bombers struck at what were identified as North Vietnamese forces in Laos today for the second consecutive day in response to what Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson this morning called a flagrant violation of the Laotian ceasefire by Hanoi.

title: A KEY SAIGON PAPER ENDS PUBLICATION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17Tin Song, the small daily newspaper that has often reflected the thinking of President Nguyen Van Thieu's Government, ceased publication today.

title: Rangers Beaten by Hawks, 21
description: The Chicago Black Hawks wondrous little Stan Mikita, perhaps the finest small center in recent hockey history, was in the right place when it mattered last night and his finalperiod goal lifted the visitors to a 21 victory over the Rangers.

title: Energy Crisis: In Quest of New Sources
Girl, 3, Leaves Hospital With Mother's Kidney
description: BOSTON, April 17 (AP) Threeyearold Barbara Regan left a hospital today with a kidney received from her mother in a transplant operation March 27.

title: I Parents Warned on Chicks
description: Health Commissioner Joseph A. Cimino warned parents against buying baby chicks or ducklings for their children during the Easter holidays because of infections they can transmit to humans.

title: Suit by Pants Maker Says Zipper Lost Grip
description: A Maryland pants manufacturing concern filed suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday against a Queens zipper manufacturer from which it purchased 60,000 yards of allegedly faulty zippers.

title: A CHEMICALS CURB IN INDUSTRY NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Department of Labor is about to issue regulations limiting workers' exposure to more than a dozen industrial chemicals suspected of causing cancer.

title: Research on Live Fetuses Is Banned
NARROWING OF LOSS REPORTED BY T.W.A.
description: Trans World Airlines reported yesterday a consolidated net loss for the first quarter this year of $14.8million. A $22.9million net loss had been reported for the same period of last year.

title: Prices of Bonds Stage a Broad Decline
description: Bond prices staged a broad decline yesterday, apparently reflecting disappointment over efforts to tighten economic controls and in the higher prime rate posted late in the day by three major banks.

title: 11 Policemen Are Among 23 Indicted in a Numbers Plot
description: WASHINGTON, Apr. 17 (UPI) A Federal grand jury today indicted 23 persons, including 11 policemen and two former officers, in an alleged conspiracy to operate a numbers racket with police protection.

title: College and School Results
OUR NATIVE RULED KEENELAND VICTOR
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. April 17 (AP)  The Flamingo Stakes winner, Our Native, was declared the winner of the Calumet Purse at Keeneland today after being beaten by a neck by another Kentucky Derby nominee, Starkers, in a 1116mile prep for America's most famous horse race.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: MITCHELL'S WIFE REPEATS SUPPORT
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell continued to maintain last night that her husband was innocent of any wrongdoing in the Watergate case.

title: Mets'
EGURBIDA DISPLAYS GUITAR SPONT ANEITY
description: Although only 28 years old, Leonardo Egrbida has been head of the guitar department of the Puerto Rico Conservatory of Music since 1968. If he teaches as well as he played Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, Puerto Rico is the place for aspiring young guitarists.

title: DRAFTS TO START WITH HAZY NOTE
Striking Groundskeepers Picket Pirates Stadium
description: PITTSBURGH, April 17 (AP) The 26 groundskeepers at Three Rivers Stadium went on strike today to back their demands for higher wages, a union spokesman said. The groundskeepers, members of Teamsters Local 250, set up picket lines following a oneday extension of a wage reopener clause in their current contract.

title: Prices on Amex and OTC Dip For the Third Session in a Row
In Publishing, It's Feast and Famine
description: Some call them superbooks: the veteran writer's new novel with the unpromising title, Beulah Land, that sells to a paperback publisher for $800,000, and the prosy cookbook that sells to a paperback house for $1.5million  40 years after it first came out.

title: Lindsay Notes Progress In Times Square Cleanup
description: Using the slogan Broadway will live, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the oneshot crackdowns on pornography and prostitution in the Times Square area would be followed at once by an accelerated and sustained offensive that would concentrate as much on property owners as on pimps.

title: Mets Downed, 10, By Cubs Jenkins
description: Not even Torn Seaver could survive the docile swinging of his teammates yesterday as the Chicago Cubs defeated the New York Mets, 10, on a twohitter by Ferguson Jenkins and a home run by Rick Monday.

title: Warning to the Colonels
description: Greece's military dictatorship has received a stern rebuke and an admonition to return the country to democratic rule from an unexpected but significant source. Four retired generals who have held highest positions the Greek armed forces have warned Premier Papadopoulos that his regime is no longer permissible, and called on him to create immediately the conditions for a return to free democratic institutions.

title: Pennsy's Proposal To Repay 49 Banks Rejected by Judge
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (UPI)A Federal judge, citing objections from the Government, today rejected Penn Central Railroad petitions proposing a settlement of $287million on a $300million loan from a group of banks.

title: Street Fighting Woman
description: The F.B.I. told us that violent crimes in the nation rose again last year and that forcible rape took the biggest jump of all, a whopping 11 per cent. It is not exactly unrelated that at the age of 38 I have solemnly embarked on a dedicated program of selfdefense instruction.

title: Two Airy Teaching Museums Are Built at Smith and Cornell
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.An airy, sunlightbathed new art center and museum that is expected to meet the art needs of Smith College for the next 50 years was formally opened to the public Saturday.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 17Always a popular sport in New Jersey, golf will have a special place in women's activities this year. Both the girls junior championship of the United States Golf Association and the women's amateur championship are slated to be held on state courses in August.

title: Parley Set in Puerto Rico
description: MAYAGUEZ, P. R., April 17 (UPI)The University of Puerto Rico's Mayaguez campus, which houses its Agriculture School, will be host April 2427 for the spring meeting of the deans of agriculture schools of the Southern United States.

title: Militant at Wounded Knee Is Shot as Fighting Erupts
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., April 17 An occupier of Wounded Knee was shot in the head and critically wounded today as a fierce battle erupted between Government forces and insurgent Indians holding the village, shattering a threeweekold ceasefire.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN HIS OWN IMAGE. The Supreme Court in Richard Nixon's America. By James F. Simon. 310 Pages. David McKay. $7.95.The President has already been so successful in dealing with the Supreme Court on his terms, writes James F. Simon, almost anything he does in his second four years in office will almost seem anticlimactical. If Nixon has additional opportunities to appoint members to the Court in the next four years, he undoubtedly will keep his formula of the first term. His appointees will again boast conservative positionstough on law and order issues, deferential to the other branches of government in policymaking areas and generally modest in their aspirations for the Court.

title: Manila Calls Off Amnesty; Full Drive on Rebels Set
description: JOLO, the Philippines, April 17 (AP)The Government has abandoned its offer of amnesty for Moslem rebels in the southern Philippines, and a military drive is planned to wipe out the secessionist movement, the armed forces chief of staff, Gen. Romeo C. Espino, said today.

title: CAPITAL APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 President Nixon's announcement today that White House aides would be allowed to testify before the Senate committee investigating the Watergate affair was greeted with general approval on Capitol Hill.

title: Unwanted General
description: In 1969, when the nation was still in a state of shock over the wanton killing of women and children by American soldiers in Mylai, a major note of hope was the appointment of Lieut. Gen. William R. Peers to head an inquiry into the tragic affair. General Peers carried out a vigorous and unsparing investigation, and in 1970 established that a tragedy of major proportions had indeed occurred in the illfated Vietnamese hamlet.

title: HARRY M.JONES, 82, AN EARLY AVIATOR
description: OLD ORCHARD BEACH,Me. April 17 (AP)  Harry M. Jones, who made, in 1913, the first air parcel post flight from Boston to New York in 52 days  died Sunday in Tulsa, Okla., where he had been living since his retirement as an inspector for the Civil Aeronautics Administration. He was 82 years old.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, April 18, 1973

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Using the slogan Broadway will live, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the oneshot crackdowns on pornography and prostitution in the Times Square area would be followed at once by an accelerated and sustained offensive.

title: Toys  Whittled And Witty
Lefkowitz Studies Reports Of Shortage in Gasoline
description: The office of the State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, disclosed yesterday that it had started investigating whether a gasoline shortage existed in the state and if major companies were using alleged shortages as a tool to force small, independent retailers out of business.

title: Jersey City Voters Face Rerun of the 71 Election
description: JERSEY CITY, April 17In three weeks, voters here will decide one of the most important city elections in 60 years, with a number of political ghosts looking over their shoulders.

title: News Summary and Index
The Random Killer
description: The use of poisoned meat to kill coyotes and other predatory animals is a haphazard and ecologically destructive way of protecting livestock. It is unimaginably cruel since animals which ingest 1080, one of the most popular predator control poisons, can take two three days to die. It is also ineffective as the steady rise In the number of lambs lost each year would indicate.

title: NoFault Divorce Backed
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., April 17 (UPI)The Nevada Senate has approved, 13 to 7, a bill providing for nofault divorce.

title: The Carnegie Hero Medal Is Awarded Posthumously
description: CLARK, April 17 (AP)A Carnegie Hero Fund Commission medal has been awarded posthumously to William B. Harrison of Clark, who died after saving a 15yearold boy from drowning and attempting to save another youth.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal judge in Newark ordered a temporary halt yesterday to the seizing of movies shown by two of New Jersey's most conspicuous sexfilm theaters. I'm no great protector of obscenity, but I have a great reverence for the First Amendment, said United States District Court Judge Leonard I. Garth.

title: G.O.P. Unit Is Said To Offer Settlement Of Watergate Suits
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) An offer has been made by the Committee for the Reelection of the President to settle a series of civil suits brought by the Democratic National Committee as a result of the Watergate bugging and breakin; the Democratic National Chairman, Robert S. Strauss, said tonight.

title: LON NOL REPORTS CABINET RESIGNS
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 17President Lon Nol announced the resignation of his Cabinet today.

title: Nixon Names Quesada
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) Elwood R. Quesada, former head of the Federal Aviation Agency and now a Washington realtor, was named by Presi dent Nixon today to be chairman of the board of directors of the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation. The corporation was created by Congress last year to prepare plans for the improvement of the ceremonial avenue between the Capitol and the White House.

title: L.I. Plans Suit to Bar Leasing Of Offshore Oil Rights by U.S.
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., April 17 The Nassau and Suffolk County Executives agreed today to prepare a joint lawsuit seeking to enjoin the Federal Government from taking any steps toward leasing petroleum rights along the outer Continental Shelf anywhere near the Long Island coast.

title: U.S. AID EMBARGO STRAINS PERU TIES
description: LIMA, Peru, April 17More than four years ago, the United States embarked on a policy of withholding public loans and grants for development in Peru. The American action was the result of the Peruvian military Government's decision to expropriate the vast hodings here of the International Petroleum Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, now part of Exxon.

title: Volvo's U.S. Sales Up 38%
description: STOCKHOLM, April 17 (AP) Volvo, the Swedish automobile company, registered a record sales increase of 38 per cent during the first quarter of 1973 in the United States compared with the corresponding period in 1972. During the first quarter 13,822 Volvo cars were sold in the United States.

title: ExClerk of Cook County Sentenced in Bribery Case
description: CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) Edward J. Barrett, a longtime Democratic politician, was sentenced today in United States District Court here to three years in prison and was fined $15,000 for accepting bribes and kickbacks.

title: A CHEMICALS CURB IN INDUSTRY NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The Department of Labor is about to issue regulations limiting workers exposure to more than a dozen industrial chemicals suspected of causing cancer.

title: Jan Ciechanowski Dead at 85; Wartime Polish Envoy to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador to the United States from 1941 to 1945, died yesterday at his home. He was 85 years old.

title: Latinization of the Miami Area Is Showing No Signs of Abating
description: MIAMI, April 17  The Latinization of this metropolitan area of 1.3 million does not show any signs of abating even though the sevenyearold Cuban airlift ended earlier this month.

title: Jankunis Paces New Dorp To Meet Record in Relays
description: Bill Jankunis of New Dorp Sigh School high jumped feet 9 inches for the second time this season yesterday in the Richmond Relays at the Port Richmond Field.

title: Music: Improvisations
description: The idea of group improvisation is a seductive one for some musicians, but for: this listener the interest often seems to be inversely proportional: to the number of performers involved. Earlier this season, the pianist Frederic Rzewski and the percussionist Gregory Reeve put on a remarkable duo performance that showed how workable improvisation on that level, can be.

title: Two Decades of Rumors Come True Finally for St. Albans Naval Hospital: Its Closing Is Ordered
description: Mrs. Eloise Jones recalls that 23 years ago, when she asked to be transferred from her job at an Army base in Brooklyn to St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens, she was told she was being foolish. The hospital was about to close, she was informed.

title: Television
Business Briefs
description: HOUSTON, June 17 (AP)The Exxon Corporation announced today it had increased its dealer tankwagon prices for motor gasolines by seventenths of one per cent to 1.4 cents a gallon in 10 states. Retail service stations began passing the increases on to consumers.

title: Subpoenas Are Served To 15 Harness Drivers
description: WESTBURY, LI., April 17 Subpoenas were served at Roosevelt Raceway tonight to 15 harness racing drivers in an investigation by the Nassau County District Attorney's office into certain questionable races at Roosevelt:

title: Abel Leaving Blues to Be Kansas City General Manager
description: KANSAS CITY, April 17 (AP) Sid Abel, a hockey Hall of Famer as a player who later gained extensive experience as a club executive, was named general manager today of the Kansas City team that will begin play in the National Hockey League in 1974.

title: MAJ. JOHN BYWATERS
description: LONDON, April 17 (UPI)Maj. John Bywaters, secretary of the British Professional Golfers Association, died today of a heart attack. He was 56 years old. Major Bywaters directed organization of the 1965 and 1969 Ryder Cup matches against the United States. He had been working on arrangements for this year's matches at Muirfield, Scotland, in September.

title: People in Sports: Prognosis on Oliva Is Favorable, According to Twins Trainer
description: Tony Oliva will be an outfielder again, not merely a designated hitter, according to Dick Martin, the Minnesota Twins' trainer. Al Worthington, the Twins' pitching coach, was quoted as having said, I don't believe Oliva will be able to play any more. I don't think his legs will hold up or be that good. But yesterday Martin's rebuttal was, In my opinion, Tony will be able to play. He's improving and running better. It's just that it's a slow thing. His knee is strong structurally and he's got good muscle tone. I doubt, though, that it'll be 100 per cent again.

title: Joan of Arc in a Sari
W.H.A. Playoffs EAST DIVISION
description: Cleveland vs. New England

title: FATAL CRASH LAID TO PILOTS ERROR
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 17 An investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board said today that a plane crash that took six lives yesterday resulted from excessive stress placed upon the aircraft by its pilot.

title: New French ATests Opposed
description: PARIS, April 17 (UPI) Pacifists streamed into the Elysee Palace today and presented petitions urging President Pompidou to cancel French nuclear tests.

title: Military Idea of Equality: Some Women Wonder If It's a Forward March
description: WASHINGTON  It's still a man's army, complained Specialist2 Elizabeth Gomez, just like it's a man's world.

title: FLOOD SURVIVORS SUE MINE CONCERN
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Apri 17More than 600 survivors and victims of West Virginia's worst flood disasterthe inundation last year of the narrow, densely populated valley of Buffalo Creek by a 50foot wall of sludge and water that broke through a defective coal company damsued the Pittston Company today for $64million.

title: Red Smith
description: When the late Christopher Chenery was just getting started in racing, he paid $750 for a yearling daughter of Col. E. R. Bradley's 1926 Kentucky Derby winner, Bubbling Over. She was named Hildene, and in the next two years she managed to earn back all but $600 of her purchase price. One day Norman Tallman, who was campaigning Chenery's stock in New England, watched her finish far back in a maiden race, and the next morning he offered her to Phil Bieber for $300, to be paid out of her winnings, if any. Bieber had a filly that had started in the same race and run slowly, but considerably faster than Hildene. Norman, Bieber said, that noaccount mare of mine is pounds better than your horse, and she ain't worth the money you're asking, even on the cuff. A day or two later Tallman reported that he couldn't find anybody willing to invest oat in Hildene, and Chenery instructed him to put her on the next van to the farm at Doswell, Va.

title: MRS. F. C. SAHLOFF
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., April 17Mrs. Wilhelmina Luedtke Selloff, the widow of Frederick C. Sahloff, a manufacturer of electrical fixtures, died in her sleep today at her home. She was 89 years old.

title: EMANUEL BALABAN OF JUILLIARD STAFF
description: Emanuel Balaban, former orchestra conductor and a member of the faculty of the Juilliard School of Music, died yesterday of cancer at St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 235 West 76th Street.

title: USAC Promoters Need Gimmick to Keep Fans
description: What do fans want, racing or vaudeville? Or can you have it both ways?

title: Engineers Open Spillway in Attempt to Save an Imperiled Mississippi Dam
description: MORGANZA, La., April 17 At 6 A.M. today, minutes before a new downpour of rain began to fall on this already sodden countryside, an engineer pulled a lever and opened the first steel gate of the Morganza spillway to lower the water level at an imperiled dam on the Mississippi River.

title: INDIANS AND BLACKS SEIZED IN CAROLINA
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 17 (UPI)About 20 Tuscarora Indians and black supporters who had camped out since Saturday on the steps of the State Indian Commission were arrested today.

title: Spending for Pandas Stirs Jealousy at Zoo
description: WASHINGTON, April 17(AP)The National Zoo isspending $550,000 this fiscal year on its two newly acquired Chinese pandasand $4million for the zoo's 1,800 other inhabitants.

title: U.S. Bids Newark Oust 3 Job Officials
description: Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan announced yesterday that he had asked Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark to agree to the removal of three top officials in Newark's Public Employment Program and to the return of more than $1million of Federal job funds. That the Labor Department said had been misused.

title: Ellsberg Tells Jury Of Secrecy Pledge
Penalty Clause Cited
description: NEWARK, April 17 (UP1)A lawyer for a West Long Branch company building the control versial $6.4million Kawaida Towers highrise apartment to day requested an indefinite sus pension of work on the project pending the outcome of suits filed by white opponents of the building in state and Federal courts.

title: Canadiens Top Flyers, 43, In Overtime, Tie Series

description: Mayor Lindsay issued new regulations yesterday aimed at increasing the number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and members of other minority groups employed on construction in the city.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: BEAMS ANGERED BY A BOND RATING
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame charged again yesterday that credit rating agencies were acting arbitrarily in evaluating taxexempt bonds.

title: Mr. Nixon and Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, April 17President Nixon has finally spoken out on the Watergate charges, and this political city, which has waited for him so long, is jumping with excitement and jumping to conclusions. But maybe it should wait a little longer.

title: Tracking Ship Ready
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 17 (UPI)The U.S.S. Vanguard, space tracking ship, arrived here today in preparation for establishing a Southern Hemisphere communications link with the Skylab launching May l4.

title: ROCKEFELLER ACTS TO OUST NIACKELL FROM QUEENS POST
description: Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had begun proceedings to remove District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens from office.

title: Sinatra at White House Gets a Standing Ovation
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Frank Sinatrathe chairman the board of the music businessearned that title all over again tonight at the White House at a state dinner for Premier Giulio Andreotti of Italy.

title: Federal Panel Urges Reforms To Diminish Malpractice Suits
description: WASHINGTON, April 17A Governmentappointed commis sion recommended today wide spread reforms to diminish the impact of medical malpractice suits on health care.

title: Bases Cutback Defended by Richardson
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson defended today a nationwide reduction of military bases as a necessary and timely economy measure in the wake of the Vietnam war.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
$3Million Harkness Theater To Stage Dances YearRound
description: If it's just a lot of baloney and no technique, it doesn't belong here, said Mrs. RebekHarkness in an impromptu definition of the policy that will govern the new Harkness Theater. The Harkness, which will open in October, is the first theater in the city devoted exclusively to dance.

title: Brennan Hires Guards For Labor Department
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)Labor Secretary Peter J. Brennan, who carries a gun for selfprotection, has hired five special guards at a cost of $60,000 a year to protect his office, department officials said today.

title: Prices of Stocks Decline In Moderate Trading Day
Mike Quarry Heads Card At Felt Forum on Monday
description: Mike Quarry of Los Angeles, the third ranked lightheavyweight contender, headlines the boxing card at the Garden's Felt Forum on Monday when he meets Hal Carroll of Syracuse in a scheduled 10rounder.

title: Mrs. William V. Mason Jr., Van Cortlandt Descendant
description: Mrs. Isabel Mathews Mason, the last descendant of the Van Cortlandt family of New York to occupy the 283yearold Van Cortlandt Manor House at CrotononHudson, N. Y., died Sunday at the Booth Memorial Medical Center in Flushing, Queens. She was 93 years old.

title: Back to Controls
description: The decision of the House of Representatives to give President Nixon another blank check on the conduct of economic stabilization only intensifies the President's responsibility to take action to arrest the upsurge in prices.

title: DIRKS TOLD S.E.C. OF BROKER TALKS
description: Raymond L. Dirks has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had a total of six lengthy telephone conversations and meetings with officials of a subsidiary of the Boston Company shortly before that firm's subsidiaries began selling off more than $15million in Equity Funding stock.

title: An Army Come Home
description: WASHINGTON  The sign outside headquarters, Military Assistance Command Vietnam, read: Will the last man out please turn off the lights?

title: SILVER FUTURES CONTINUE TO FALL
description: Silver and platinum futures prices yesterday continued their downward trek started the day before with the President's announcement that he planned to reduce the Government's stockpiles of strategic materials. Copper futures, however, which had also dropped Monday, rebounded yesterday.

title: 3MONTH NET OFF AT MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith, Inc., the nation's largest brokerage house, yesterday announced a drop of more than 50 per cent in its firstquarter earnings to $10,824,000 from the yearearlier $23,250,000. Earnings per share dropped to 34 cents from 72 cents.

title: Advertising: Needham Meeting
Scientists Report Isolating Chemical Linked to Memory
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 17 (AP)  Scientists at the Baylor College of Medicine say they have captured animals memories in a test tube.

title: OUR NATIVE RULED KEENELAND VICTOR
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. April 17 (AP)  The Flamingo Stakes winner, Our Native, was declared the winner of the Calumet Purse at Keeneland today after being beaten by a neck by another Kentucky Derby nominee, Starkers, in a 1 116mile prep for America's most famous horse race.

title: Biaggi Said to Have Taken 5th Amendment on Assets
description: Although he has repeatedly denied it, Representative Mario Biaggi, a leading candidate for Mayor, refused to answer at least 30 questions when he appeared before a Federal grand jury more than a year ago, according to authoritative sources.

title: OneDay Strike in Japan
description: TOKYO, April 17 (UPI)Rail service was crippled, mail deliveries were slowed and patients in public hospitals were left unattended today when 3.5 million Japanese workers staged a oneday strike to demand better pension systems.

title: U. S. BIDS GIBSON OUST 3 JOB AIDES
description: Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan announced yesterday that he had asked Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark to agree to the removal of three top officials in Newark's Public Employment Program and to the return of more than $1million of Federal job funds that the Labor Department said had been misused.

title: 3 WRITERS BITTER AT YEVTUSHENKO
description: MOSCOW, April 17The poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko was accused today of betraying old literary friends, impairing their chances for publication and trying to gain political safety for himself by publicly attacking offbeat writers.

title: GOODRICH SHOWS 51%RISE IN PROFIT
City Rule to Widen Minority Hiring in Construction
description: Mayor Lindsay issued new regulations yesterday aimed at increasing the number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and members of other minority groups employed on construction in the city.

title: Guards to Be Hired to Protect VestPocket Housing Projects
description: The city's Housing Authority yesterday announced that it would hire both armed and unarmed private guards for its 25 vestpocket housing projects and developments for the elderly.

title: SHEER MOVE IS 41 IN SIRE STAKES TROT
description: WESTBURY, L.I., April 17Tomorrow will be Women's Night at Roosevelt Raceway and one of the better trotters in the $14,075 New York Sire Stakes fourth race onemile feature will be Sheer Move, a mare.

title: 184 School Districts Told by U.S. to End Alleged Segregation
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)Declaring that it had no alternative but to obey the order of a Federal Judge, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare sent letters to 184 elementary and high school districts in 16 states today in an effort to end alleged school segregation.

title: Show of Nazi Photos Marks Warsaw Ghetto Rising
description: There are several hundred photographs in the new display at the headquarters of the Jewish Labor Committee here, but Vladka Meed, the committee's assistant director who assembled the exhibit to mark the 30th anniversary of the uprising of the Warshaw ghetto, has omitted the credits. Most of the pictures were taken by German soldiers.

title: HOUSING STARTS FOR MARCH FELL
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Housing starts in March showed their first significant decline in more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Baraka Threat Ignored
description: TRENTON, April 17If the Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor are to take Imamu Amiri Baraka at his word, none can expect any black votes in the June gubernatorial primary election.

title: Sports Today
description: Ages vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M.

title: HENRY S. REEDER
description: Henry S. Reeder, a senior partner in the law firm of Whitman & Ransom, 522 Fifth Avenue, died at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center on Monday after a brief illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street and in Quogue, L.I.

title: Militant at Wounded Knee Is Shot as Fighting Erupts
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., April 17A member of the Indian force occupying Wounded Knee was shot in the head and critically wounded today as a fierce battle erupted between Government forces and insurgent Indians holding the village, shattering a threeweek old ceasefire.

title: U.S. and Britain Ask Urgent U.N. Steps on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., 17  Both the United States and Britain warned the Security Council today that the situation in the Middle East was taking on new and uglier dimensions and both urged the Council to take steps on an urgent basis to break the ArabIsraeli deadlock.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A National Transportation Safety Board investigator said yesterday that the plane crash that killed six persons in Brick Township, N. J., resulted from excessive stress placed on the aircraft by its pilot.

title: I Never Thought I'd Last Four Years, He Says at Exit
description: TORONTO, April 17 (AP) The Toronto Maple Leafs, who finished a dismal sixth in the National Hockey League's East Division this season, failing to make the playoffs, announced today the resignation of Coach John McLellan.

title: Stage: Le Jenne Theatre
description: There is a treat in store for lovers of Molire, at the American Place Theater, where Le Jeune Thatre National from Paris is celebrating the tercentenary of the poet's death with a production of Le Medecin Malgre Lui.

title: Lebanon Army Says It Learned Of the Israeli Raid Afterward
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17 (UPI)The Lebanese Army said in a statement published by Beirut newspapers today that it was not informed of last week's Israeli raid on Beirut in which three Palestinian guerrilla leaders were killed until it was over.

title: Ellsberg Tells Jury Of Secrecy Pledge
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17Dr. Daniel Ellsberg said today under crossexamination at the Pentagon papers trial that he had signed a pledge that he would not copy the documents.

title: Corning Unit Seeks Electrical Concern And a Glassmaker
description: The Corning International Corporation, a subsidiary of the Corning Glass Works, announced yesterday that it and Thomas Tilling, Ltd., of London were at an advanced stage of negotiations whereby Tilling'g 60 per cent interest in the glassmaking concern of James A. Jobling & Co., Ltd., of Sunderland, England, and Tilling's 8 per cent interest in Electrosil, Ltd., would be acquired by Corning.

title: Roundup: Twins Use PH For DH to Down Angels
description: A pinchhitter for the designated hitter? That's like bringing coals to Newcastle.

title: Newsprint Price Raised
description: MONTREAL, April 17ConsolidatedBathurst Newsprint, Ltd., and its United States subsidiary, Consolidated Newsprint, Inc., today raised the price of newsprint to the United States by $5 to $175 a ton f.o.b. New York effective July 1. Two other leading North American newsprint producers have made similar increases recently.

title: Victor E. Aldridge, 79, Dies; ExMajor League Pitcher
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 17 (AP)  Victor F. Aldridge, a former major league baseball pitcher, died today at St. Anthony Hospital here. He was 79 years old.

title: State to Study Cemetery Strike; Board Opening Hearings Today
description: Louis L. Levine, the State Industrial Commissioner, appointed a threeman board of inquiry yesterday to investigate and make recommendations for settlement of the contract dispute involving 47 cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

title: GENEVA ARMS TALKS RECESS UNTIL MAY 4
description: GENEVA, April 17  The United States and the Soviet Union today recessed until May 4 the second phase of their talks on limiting strategic nuclear weapons.

title: Narcotics Official Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) President Nixon accepted the resignation today of Paul L. Perito, deputy director the Special Action Office for Drug Abuse Prevention.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS A CLEANAIR PLAN
description: As he was required to do by court order, Governor Rockefeller sent the Federal Government yesterday a plan for meeting cleanair standards in New York City by 1975, but he said he did not intend to implement one of the key tactics because it would be too expensive and not technologically feasible.

title: Monday's Fights
description: New YorkRodrigo Valdes, 160 pounds, Colombia, knocked out Kim Booker, 157, Oakland, Calif., 5 rounds.

title: WILLIAM T. SMITH JR.
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 17  William T. Smith Jr., vice president and senior marketing officer of the American National Bank and Trust Company of New Jersey, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. He was 60 years old and lived in Madison.

title: Eastern Stewards End Walkout After a TwoHour Shutdown
description: Negotiators for Eastern Airlines and its striking flight attendants reached agreement on a tentative contract early today, two hours after the airline had shut down its entire system as a result of a strike that lasted for seven hours.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: People and Business
description: Gerald W. Eskow, 49, resigned yesterday as executive vice president of Yale Express System, Inc. the trucking company founded by his father, Benjamin, and ended a decade of rocky experiences with the Kearny N. J., company.

title: Feliciano Gets Four Winners, Gains in Pimlico Rider Race
description: BALTIMORE, April 17 (UPI) Ben Feliciano, taking advantage of an injury to the leading jockey, Vincent Bracciale Jr., improved his position as the runner  up in the riding competition at Pimlico with four winners today. He now has 31 victories.

title: Broadcasters Urged to Resist Bullying for License Security
description: Elton H. Rule, president of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., yesterday urged broadcasters not to allow any Presidential Administration to bully them into putting on bland news and entertainment programs in exchange for license security.

title: Japan Imports More Cars
description: TOKYO, April 17 (AP)Sales of imported motor vehicles in Japan totaled 3,257 units in March, 74.9 per cent more than in March, 1972, statistics compiled by the Toyota Motor Sales Company showed. In the first quarter of 1973, sales of imported vehicles rose 62.6 per cent from a year earlier to 7,759 units.

title: Western Sources Voice Strong Doubts That Saigon's Army Is Planning a Major Drive Into Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April I8Informed Western sources expressed strong doubt yesterday that the South Vietnamese army was planning a major thrust into Cambodia

title: TV: The Shenyang's Acrobatic Skills
description: After tonight, the sight of acrobats on the television screen may no longer automatically prompt thoughts of the old Ed Sullivan show on Sunday evenings. That distinction should, if excellence is any gauge, shift to the People's Republic of China. The vagaries of show business and international relations are awesome.

title: Oil Import Quotas Due to Fall, Despite Energy Lobby
First National City Corporation Expands 3Month Earnings 25%
description: The First National City Corporation reported yesterday that its consolidated operating earnings in the first quarter jumped 25 per cent in a broadly based increase resulting about equally from operations overseas and in the United States.

title: Princeton Likes Perverto Slate
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 17Promising their electorate nothing more than mindless perversion, four Princeton University students were given solid chances today for victory tomorrow in several races in the election for Undergraduate Assembly officers.

title: India and Bangladesh Offer Plan For End of Deadlock on Prisoners
description: NEW DELHI, April 17India and Bangladesh, seeking a breakthrough in the political deadlock on the subcontinent, announced a joint initiative today that seeks the return of most Pakistani prisoners of war.

title: Notes on People
description: Associate Justice William O. Douglas celebrated his 34th anniversary as a member of the United States Supreme Court. In the history of the Court only three men have served longer than Mr. Douglas: Chief Justice John Marshall, 34 years, 9 months and 15 days; Stephen J. Field, 34 years, 6 months and 11 days, and Hugo L. Black, 34 years and 29 days.

title: LAKER RALLY TOPS WARRIORS, 10199
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17 (UPI) Jerry West hit a 15foot jump shot from the side with eight seconds to play tonight to give the Los Angeles Lakers a 10199 victory over the Golden State Warriors in the first game of the National Basketball Association Western Conference final playoffs.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1973, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Tuesday, April 17. 41st day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: Man Wins SexBias Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (Reuters)Dale Smith, a telephone operator, said he was being discriminated against because the telephone company gave women operators who worked night shifts taxi fares to get them home safely. Mr. Smith sued the Pacific Telephone Company, and he won $7,500 damages yesterday.

title: Marcona Agrees to Build Saudi Arabian Steel Mill
description: The Marcona Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Petromin, a Saudi Arabian corporation, for development of a steelmill project in that country. Marcona would head a group that would include another San Franciscobased company, the Gilmore Steel Corporation which operates an integrated steel plant in Portland, Ore., and the MidlandRoss Corporation of Cleveland.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The annual controversy over the decline in reading scores for the New York City schools is really not all that mystifying. It is, as a matter of fact, the outcome of demographic changes.

title: Many Flee Apartment Fire
description: A flash fire yesterday afternoon in a sixthfloor apartment of a 12story building at 135 Central Park West, at 73d Street, sent billowing smoke through the upper floors and firemen evacuated many residents. No one was injured and the fire, brought under control in a half hour, was confined to the apartment.

title: Republic Steel Net Advances 118.1%
description: Companies in all fields climbed aboard the profit bandwagon that American industry has been happily riding so far this year.
