Earnings in the first quarter ran as high as 118.1 per cent for the Republic Steel Corporation and 60.7 per cent for Champion International, the forest products company, that were among the flood of reports announced yesterday.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: BARRYMORE AND MORE Theater 80 Saint Marks, which takes its name from its address, at a onetime Off Broadway theater, 80 St. Marks Place (2547400), specializes in film musicals of all ages. Occasionally it lapses into straight prose, as it does from today through Saturday, when the stress is on the Barrymore family, that most beautifully  voiced brothersandsister group in moviedom. Not that the Barrymores were team performers; they were far too individualistic for that. But one of the current double bills, Rasputin and the Empress, made in 1932, is the only film made that starred the entire trio at one swoop. Richard Boleslaysky directed.

title: QUAKE FORECAST VIEWED AS NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) Three earth scientists have concluded after extensive study that earthquake prediction, an old and elusive goal of seismologists and astrologers alike, appears to be on the verge of practical reality.

title: Vanden Heuvel Challenge Brings Alumni Rallying to Hogan's Side
description: To hear one friend of Frank S. Hogan tell it, the widespread membership of the unofficial Hogan Alumni Association woke up one recent morning and said simultaneously: This guy vanden Heuvel could beat Mr. Hogan.

title: RELOCATION HELP IS RAISED BY CITY
description: Increased benefits for residential or commercial tenants relocated for public improvements or urbanrenewal projects were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Orioles Top Yanks, 42, on TwoRun Homer Off Lyle
description: BALTIMORE, April 17Unawed by unbeaten Dave McNally's previous performances this season when the stylish Oriole southpaw pitched 18 2/3 scoreless innings in winning both starts, the Yankees staged an early uprising tonight.

title: Data on Maturity Of Bonds Is Shown By Salomon Study
description: Only 18.6 per cent of the presently outstandinng $140billion of corporate bonds comes due between now and the end of 1981, an ambitious yearlong study conducted by Salomon Brothers showed yesterday upon its distribution to the press.

title: Despite Gaps, Sanctions Hurt Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 17  The three American jet airliners that Rhodesia has recently thanaged to purchase are only the latest proof that international economic sanctions against this breakaway British colony cannot block the flow of goods for which Rhodesia can pay.

title: ROCKEFELLER ACTS TO OUST MACKELL FROM QUEENS POST
description: Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had begun proceedings to remove District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens from office.

title: Religious Holidays Aid Ridgefield Unity
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., April 17Nicholas Kovarko, a Congregationalist, said that this week's celebration of the death and Resurrection of Jesus was a season of rejuvenation. Carla Schair, a Reform Jew, called the telling of the story of the Exodus a time when you sense who you are.

title: Things for Children to Do in the City
description: PECK'S BAD BOY AT THE CIRCUS (1938) at Films for Children Program, with short films and serials, at 2 P.M. Saturday at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. $1. JU 22424.

title: Chavez Charges Growers Conspire With Teamsters
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers Union, charged today that growers in California were engaged in conspiracy with teamsters officials, involving large illegal cash payments, to crush his union.

title: Abel Leaving Blues to Be Kansas City General Manager
description: KANSAS CITY, April 17 (AP) Sid Abel, a hockey Hall of Famer as a player who later gained extensive experience as a club executive, was named general manager today of the Kansas City team that will begin play in the National Hockey League in 1974.

title: CAPITAL APPROVAL
Istvan Kertesz, 43, Conductor, Drowns Swimming off Israel
Chrysler to Study Dividend Policy, Meeting Is Told
description: The chairman of the Chrysler Corporation told the automobile company's annual meeting yesterday that I'm absolutely certam the board will be able to look at Chrysler's dividend policy some time in the futures

title: G.T.E. Lists Peak Earnings Level
Falling Tree Kills 3 Scouts
description: DALLAS, April 17 (UP1)High winds blew a tree onto a tent and killed three 13yearold boy scouts on a camping trip in the Davy Crockett National Forest in Fast Texas, Scout leaders said yesterday. The victims were identified as Steve Wester, Cris Phillips and Scott Stephens, all of Dallas.

title: Florida Rejects Ratification, Of Equal Rights Amendment
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 17 (AP)Florida rejected ratification of the proposed equal rights amendment today when the state House of Representatives killed the amendment on a 64to54 vote.

title: Chavez Charges Growers Conspire With Teamsters
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers Union, charged today that growers in California were engaged in a conspiracy with teamsters officials, involving large illegal cash payments, to crush his union.

title: Watergate: Inept Burglary With Wider Ramifications
Drug Sales Prompt Closing Of East Village Juice Bar
description: Because of the drug selling and other unlawful activity that was taking place on the premises, State Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine yesterday ordered the temporary closing of the Sanctum Sanctorium, a socalled juice bar.

title: Postcard Registration
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) Opponents of a bill providing for registration of voters in Federal elections by postcard filed a petition today to cut off Senate debate. Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama, said he and 20 other Senators who signed the closure petition hoped the vote on it would convince the bill's supporters to give up.

title: Tax Refunds Running $3Billion Over'72 Rate
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)Federal income tax refunds are running $3billion ahead of last year's pace, and the increase may reach $8billion by the time all returns are processed.

title: Project to Extend Capitol Is Approved By 6 Votes in House
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Backers of a plan to extend the west front of the Capitol won a crucial round today as the House narrowly rejected a move to cut the project off without a penny.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: SEMIFINAL ROUND

title: Highs and Lows
A Bid for Rationality
Biaggi Said to Have Taken 5th Amendment on Assets
description: Although he has repeatedly denied it, Representative Mario Biaggi, a leading candidate for Mayor, refused to answer at least 30 questions when he appeared before a Federal grand jury more than a year ago, according to authoritative sources.

title: Fulbright Praised by Press In Egypt as Voice of Truth
description: CAIRO, April 17 (AP)  Egypt's press today hailed Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chairman of the United States Senate's Foreign Relations Committee, as a courageous voice of truth on the Middle East.

title: Three Major Banks Raise Their Rates On Loans to Corporations to 6%
description: Three Major banks, getting the goahead from Washington Monday, moved quickly yesterday to raise the interest rate they charge on loans to large corporate borrowers to 6 per cent from 6 per cent. The increase takes effect today.

title: LON NOL REPORTS CABINET RESIGNS
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, April 18  President Lon Nol announced the resignation of the Government headed by Premier Hang Thun Hak last night. [The United States bombing of Laos went into its second day, with B52's striking at what were identified as North Vietnamese forces in response to what Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson termed a flagrant violation of the Laotian ceasefire. Page 14.]

title: CURTIS SAID TO QUIT AS PUBLIC TV CHIEF
description: ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP)  Thomas, B. Curtis of Missouri has resigned as chairman of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting in dispute over control of public TV, the St. Louis PostDispatch said today.

title: Libyan Chief Pessimistic on Arab Cause
description: CAIRO, April 17The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, in three public statements in the last four days, has given a bitterly pessimistic assessment of the state of the Arab cause against Israel.

title: WIDOW WINS A BID FOR HUSBAND SEAT
description: CHICAGO, April 17 (AP)  Mrs. Cardiss Collins won the Democratic primary race in the Seventh Congressional District today. The victory almost assures that she will succeed her late husband in the House seat.

title: Princeton Likes Perverto Slate
ALBION H. ADAMS
description: RACINE, Wis., April 17  Albion H. Adams, retired executive secretary of the Oratorio Society of New York, died Friday at the Lincoln Lutheran Home. He was 89 years old.

title: John Hope, Chief Geologist At Phelps Dodge, Is Dead
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., April 17John Hope, chief exploration geologist of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, producers of copper, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown. He was 56 years old and had lived here.

title: 6 May Go in the Wood, But It's a 2Horse Race
Previous Statements by the President
description: WASHINGTON, April 17. Following, excerpted from news conference transscripts, are previous statements by President Nixon on the Watergate case  including statements denying any involvement by White House staff members that Ronald L. Ziegler, the President's press secretary, said today were now inoperative:

title: Scenario of a Drug Raid in the Making
description: The arrest of 65 reputed bigtime drug dealers in a series of heavily armed and dramatic raids over last weekend had its roots in a chance encounter on a Greenwich Village street four years ago, according to high police officials.

title: Text of Nixon's Statement
description: WASHINGTON, April 17Following is the text of President Nixon's announcement today concerning the Watergate investigation:

title: ULSTERMAN SLAIN BY BRITISH FORCE 2 Others WoundedArmy's Version of Clash Disputed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 17One man was shot dead and two others wounded by British troops in the Roman Catholic Ardoyne District here today.

title: Bay State Justice Named
description: BOSTON, April 18 (AP) Gov. Francis W. Sargent nominated Senator Mario Umana today to be an associate justice of the Boston Municipal Court. Mr. Umana is now majority leader in the Massachusetts Senate.

title: Music: Two Premieres
Law and the President
description: LONDON, April 18In the course of a recent trip to the Soviet Union I heard about a Russian, denied an exit visa though he was ready to pay the tax, who tried to find out the legal basis for the decision. He asked the men of the Interior Ministry whether there was anything in the Soviet Constitution restricting the right to emigrate. No. Could they show him any law that did so? No. What then? We have our internal regulations.

title: The Scott Commission: Who, What and When
description: The state study commission for NeW York City was created by the Legislature in June, 1971, to Investigate and hold public hearings on present management, structure, organization and the fiscal and governance practices of the City of New York and its agencies thereof.

title: National Council of Churches Joins Plea to Reverse Ruling Ending Tax Exemption for Hargis Ministry
description: The Rev. Billy James Hargis, the antiCommunist crusader, had been joined by one of his most frequent targets of criticism, the National Council of Churches, in appealing a Federal appeals court decision that stripped him of his tax exemption.

title: BOARD SEEKS A PACT IN CEMETERY STRIKE
description: The new board of inquiry set up to investigate the Brooklyn cemetery dispute met informally for three hours yesterday with representatives of management and labor but deferred a public hearing to see whether a settlement could be negotiated.

title: 13.9% Earnings Increase Is Reported for 100 Banks
description: The first 100 banks to report firstquarter earnings showed an overall increase In profits of 13.9 per cent, M. A. Schapiro & Co., Inc., a securities firm specializing in bank stocks, reported yesterday. Of the 100 banks, 89 reported higher earnings and 11 disclosed lower profits. Their return on equity capital equaled 13.6 per cent.

title: Public TV Plans Coverage Of Hearings on Watergate
description: Public television plans to provide complete gaveltogavel coverage of forthcoming Senate hearings into the Watergate bugging allegation, it was announced here yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
Even the Knicks Shocked By the OneSided Contest
description: The Knicks really rubbed it into the Celtics last night. Got even for what happened up in Boston on Sunday.

title: MORE BANKS RAISE THEIR PRIME RATES
description: More than a dozen large commercial banks yesterday raised the interest rate they charge on loans to big corporate borrowers. The rate, lifted to 6 per cent from 6 per cent, goes in to effect today.

title: City Tax Office Feels the Crush As Returns Pour In at Deadline
description: Tons of city incometax returns, filed to meet the April 17. deadline, poured into a huge blocksquare office on the second floor of 770 Broadway yesterday.

title: U.S. APPEAL DOUBTED IN O.E.O. FUND CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Nixon Administration has decided not to appeal a court ruling that halted dismantling of the Office of Economic Opportunity, in the current fiscal year, The Washington Post said tonight.

title: Chess : A WellEntrenched Outpost Can File Down the Opponent
description: An open file is mainly exploited by massing the vertical attacking pieces, rooks and queen, to penetrate the enemy position. However, such a direct method will not succeed if the opponent can oppose his own heavy pieces to level the game by exchanges. In that case, an additional devicethe establishment of an outpost in the fileis needed to choke off resistance.

title: Major Crime in State Was Off a Bit in 1972
description: TRENTON, April 18 (UPI)  The state police said that although crimes reported in New Jersey dipped slightly in 1972. Reports of forcible rape rose 18.3 per cent and murder. 14.5 per cent.

title: Black Group Urged to Consider Filing Suit in Kawaida Dispute
description: NEWARK, April 18  An informal inquiry team recommended today that consideration be given to filing civil rights suits against the Police Department, the City Council and construction trade unions that have refused to cross neighborhood picket lines to work on the Kawaida Towers housing project.

title: MEANY CRITICIZES TEAMSTERS DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., accused the Teamsters today of a vicious and disgraceful campaign to wipe out the United Farm Workers Union and pledged an allout battle by his federation to help this small, struggling union.

title: 2 Give Up After Holding 42 Hostages in a Harlem Bank
description: One of the F.B.I.'s 10 mostwanted men was killed yesterday and his two alleged accomplices were captured after the attempted holdup of a Harlem bank in which 32 customers and 10 employes were held hostage for nearly two hours.

title: Chinese Mission Arrives in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 A 10man delegation from China arrived today to prepare for the opening here next month of Peking's liaison office, the Chinese Communists first official mission to this country.

title: Albany Bill to Make Coop Conversions More Difficult Is Bogged Down
description: ALBANY, April 18Legislation that would make it more difficult to convert rental apartment buildings to cooperaties or condominiums appears to be dead for the current session of the Legalature.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Wants to Testify Publicly Before Ervin Committee
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)Mrs. John N. Mitchell, who has been called to make pretrial statement in connection with the Watergate case, said today that she would rather testify publicly.

title: ExHead of Jersey Draft Board Says Files Should Be Destroyed
description: CAMDEN, April 18A former commanding officer of the Selective Service Center for the State of New Jersey testified today in the draftraid trial of the Camden 28 that he, too, might consider participating in a draft raid.

title: HORSES &
description: Horses & Equipment 8995

title: Desert Bondship
WHALERS DEFEAT CRUSADERS, 3 TO 2 Sheehy Gets SecOnd Goal of Game in Last 25 Seconds
Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 1 P.M. (RadioWHN, 1 P.M.)

title: Excerpts From Nixon Message
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Following are excerpts from the President's energy message sent to Congress today:

title: Top Energy Expert
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 From Capitol Hill to New York board rooms and the palaces of Persian Gulf sheiks, James E. Akins is regarded as one of this country's foremost experts on energy issues and Middle Eastern geopolitics. Some say that this tall, darkhaired, urbane 46yearold Foreign Service officer has a wider, more proficient grasp of the politics, technology and economics of energy issues  particularly oilthan anyone in Washington.

title: Poor Lands Do Little on Protein Deficiency
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18The musical sensation in Zambia these days is a catchy lyric sung in Nyanja dialect:

title: SOVIET DENIES PLAN FOR MANNED FLIGHT
description: MOSCOW, April 18 (UPI) The Soviet Union has no plans to launch a manned space vehicle to link up with the orbiting station Salyut 2, space sources said today. The Salyut station was launched April 3, but the Soviet authorities did not disclose details of its mission.

title: J.P. LEVISI EXHEAD OF OWENSILLINOIS
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 18J. Preston Leyis, former president and retired, chairman of OwenIllinols, Inc., died yesterday in Toledo Hospital. He was 71yearsold.

title: Current Stars: Books on Indian, Italian and Inexpensive Food
description: Cookbooks proliferate like mink. Unfortunately, however, the fur industry maintains a higher standard of production than the publishing industry. This spring's offering of recipes between two covers could almost be seen as a famine compared to last fall's feast.

title: Personal Finance
description: Now that spring is hereand with it the racing season winners should beware. So should participants in state lotteries. The Internal Revenue Service may be watching.

title: Curtis Resignation From C.P.B. Draws Mixed Reaction
description: The resignation of Thomas B. Curtis as chairman and a member of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, confirmed by the White House yesterday, has been taken as both an embarrassment and a triumph for the Nixon Administration.

title: 38,000 Governments Asked For Data on Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The Office of Revenue Sharing asked 38,000 local and state governments today to tell how they are spending their revenuesharing funds.

title: Motion Picture Group Gets Patent for Ratings
description: The Motion Picture Association announced here that it has obtained patents for the film ratings G, PG and R from the United States Patent Office. The registration of the symbols makes illegal their use by anyone other than the association. Only the industry's X rating (no one under the age of 17 admitted) may be selfapplied to a film.

title: City's Firemen Give Panel Some Insight On Charter Needs
description: The state commission assigned to revise the New York City Charter literally answered the fire bell yesterday as it undertook the first in a series of field trips to watch city departments in operation.

title: People in Sports:Allen on Money
description: Money. The only thing I like about money is that it brings a grin to Mom's face. It makes her smile, said Dick Allen, the super star, who found only misery in Philadelphia and Los Angeles of the National League, but fame and fortune in Chicago with the White Sox.

title: Black Woman Backed by Daley Sweeps Primary in House Race
description: CHICAGO, April 18  Mayor Richard J. Daley's Cook County Democratic organization demonstrated last night that it could still get out enough voters in a special primary election, even in a predominantly black district, to sweep a candidate to victory.

title: Notes on People Shultz and Butz Give Views on Food Prices
description: Two Nixon Administration cabinet members, George P. Shultz Secretary of the Treasury, Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, gave separate, and not necessarily similar views of the rising costs of food Mr. Shultz said that weather plays a role in food supply and that every morning, the first thing I do ... is turn to the weather report to see how they're doing out there in the Midwest . . . the weather has been foul and the wage and price system can't cure that problem.

title: BIAGGI TESTIMONY SOUGHT BY TROY
description: The manager of Representative Mario Biaggi's mayoral campaign urged him yesterday to request the release of his testimony before a Federal grand jury and thus support Mr. Biaggi's assertion that he had not invoked the Fifth Amendment.

title: Roundup: A's Win on Tenace's Homer
description: Gene Tenace, the most valuable player in Oakland's World Series triumph over Cincinnati last year when he hit four home runs, struck again last night in Kansas City's Royals Stadium.

title: ROADBLOCK IS RUN BY INDIAN WOMEN
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 18 Fourteen Indian women and children ran a Government roadblock into Wounded Knee late today, refusing to obey orders from marshals and Bureau of Indian Affairs officers to stop. Marshals arrested 20 other Indians who were watching.

title: MEKONG BARGES GET PAST AMBUSH
description: HONG NGU, South Vietnam, April 18 (Reuters)A convoy of empty supply barges sailed through a Communist ambush attempt on the Mekong River while returning from Cambodia today, but heavier fighting is expected before the river banks are cleared.

title: Common Market Meeting On Farm Prices at Impasse
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 18 (Reuters)  Common Market agricultural ministers early today gave up their attempt to fix farm price increases for 197374 after a marathon session that broke up here in disagreement, informed sources said.

title: NIXON, ANDREOTTI END 2 DAYS OF TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)  President Nixon and Premier Giulio Andreotti of Italy completed two days of talks today on EastWest relations and ways to overcome problems between Western Europe and the United States.

title: 2 ExMackell Aides Indicted Over Taxes In GetRich Scheme
description: Two former members of the staff of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens were indicted yesterday on charges of having failed to report on their Federal tax returns income of about $352,000 they made from an illegal getrichquick scheme.

title: Seale Puts Oakland Race Into Runoff
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 18 Bobby Seale, the Black Panther leader, showed surprising strength at the polls yesterday and qualified for a runoff election in his bid to become Mayor of Oakland.

title: Father Ramirez Removed As Diocese Hispanic Aide
description: The Rev. Cesar. Ramirez, chaplain for the Spanishspeaking youth movement in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, has been removed after he and a group of other dissident priests charged the archdiocese with ignoring they needs of its Hispanic parishioners.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Woman Is Fishing Champion
description: LITTLE CANADA, Minn. (AP)Outfishing an estimated 3,400 anglers, 18yearold LuAnne Campanaro won the 27th World's Original Ice Fishing Contest on White Bear Lake. She landed a 7pound northern

title: PrisonerRelease Offer Is Welcomed in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 18 The official Pakistani news agency, the Associated Press of Pakistan, reported last night that observers in Rawalpindi had welcomed the proposal by India and Bangladesh for the return of Pakistani prisoners.

title: President Urges Senators Not to Link Soviet Trade and Exit Tax
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 President Nixon, arguing that he was making progress in getting the Soviet Union to relax its controversial exit tax for emigrants, sought to prevail upon a group of Senators today not to impose restrictions on future Soviet trade.

title: Western Union Seeks Rise
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 18 (UPI)The Western Union Corporation has asked the Federal Communications Commission to approve an increase to $2 for the public mailgram rate for 100 words and an increase in the charge for additional words from 1 cents to 3 cents a word.

title: Cahill Names Two Justices And Supreme Court Chief
Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Drug Makers Told To Prove Safety Of Feed Additives
LIVINGSTON WELCH,. PSYCHOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Livingston Welch; chairman of the psychology department at Hunter College from 1952 to 1968, died Tuesday in the New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 432 East 58th Street.

title: Jackson Hole 78 Ski Site
description: JACKSON, Wyo., April 18 (UPI)The Jackson Hole ski area was officially selected to1day as the United States choice for the 1978 Alpine world ski championships. Aspen, Colo., was host to the event in 1950 the last time it was held in the United States.

title: HomeIce Edge Melts in N.H.L. Playoffs
OKLAHOMA AGREES TO FORFEIT GAMES
description: The University of Oklahoma forfeited eight of last season's 11 football victories, including a 14.0 Sugar Bowl triumph over Penn State, after it was disclosed yesterday that the highschool academic transcript of Kerry Jackson, a freshman quarterback, had been altered. The games forfeited were those in which Jackson played.

title: Max Nomad Dies at 92; An AntiCzarist Author
description: Max Nomad, an antiCzarist author, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 92 years old and lived at 664 West 161st Street.

title: Xerox Reaches Agreement With Amalgamated Union
description: ROCHESTER, April 18 (Reuters)The Xerox Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union, which represents 4,800 production workers who have been on strike since April 6.

title: OHIO PANEL BLOCKS RIGHTS AMENDMENT
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 18 A committee of the Ohio Legislature voted today to block passage of the equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: For Joseph Papp, Fund  Raising Is an Art Surpassed Only by His Stage Skills
CITY AIDE ALTERS POLLUTION STAND
description: The city's Commissioner of Air Resources, Fred C. Hart, has reversed his earlier stand about New York City's ability and need to meet cleanair standards by 1975. He said yesterday that he agreed with Governor Rockefeller that the city needed more time to clean up.

title: COMPROMISE BILL WILL AID ELDERLY
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  After months of being at loggerheads over spending issues, Congress and the White House reached agreement today on major legislation that President Nixon had earlier threatened to veto.

title: RALLY AWAKENS LISTLESS MARKET
description: A sudden rally near the close of trading snapped the stock market out of the doldrums yesterday and enabled the leading price indicators to rack up their first gains in five sessions.

title: Laos Says U.S. Raids Will Echo Attacks By Enemy on Ground
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 18 (Reuters)A Government official said today that United States planes would continue bombing Communist forces if Pathet Lao and North Vietnamese troops continued their offensive in northeastern Laos.

title: N.B.A. Lets Sonics Keep FirstRound Draft Choice
description: The National Basketball Association owners, after nine hours of wrestling with the John BriskerPhiladelphia 76ersSeattle Supersonics triangle, came up with an intricate solution last night.

title: METS LOSE AGAIN TO CUBS HERE, 10
description: Like Tom Seaver the day before, Jon Matlack allowed the Chicago Cubs only one run yesterday at Shea Stadium. But like Seaver, he saw the run defeat the New York Mets, 10, as the Mets springtime slumber at home plate continued.

title: Class on Bank Hostages Proves Useful in Holdup
description: Patrolman Phillip Marion spent the first part of yesterday morning with 15 other policemen attending a training course on how to handle situations involving hostages. The subject of yesterday's class was bank robberies.

title: Southern Illinois Star Leaps 71 in Decathlon
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 18 (AP)  Bill Hancock of Southern Illinois, competing in the decathlon for only the second time, high jumped 7 feet 1 inch today in the Kansas relays decathlon. It is the best high jump mark ever recorded in a declathon.

title: HomeIce Edge Melts in N. H. L. Playoffs
description: While everyone has been talking about the homeice advantage in Stanley Cup playoffs, no one has been doing anything about it.

title: H.U.D. AND LINDSAY IN HOUSING DISPUTE
description: S. William Green, regional administrator of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, charged city officials yesterday with seriously misleading the public about Federal housing subsidies. He was immediately accused by IVInyor Lindsay of pettifogging.

title: State Accuses Dr. Jacobson of Giving Himself Amphetamines for Nonmedical Purposes
Issue and Debate
description: Long before President Nixon's energy message yesterday, energy had become a pressing political issue of national and international scope, a matter of concern and debate of crisis magnitude.

title: Jets Bell Wins Dismissal Of Charge of Harassment
description: A formal apology by Eddie Bell of the New York Jets to a city policeman who had charged him with harassment led to an adjournment of the charge by a Criminal Court judge yesterday.

title: Taking a Lesson From the Ukrainians
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Jane Goodman Pollak carried 27 raw eggs to the Passover seder her motherinlaw held this week. The eggs were not a contribution to the menu; they were ornately decorated place cards that Mrs. Pollak's class made at Westhill High School here.

title: Feliciano Rides 3 Winners
description: BALTIMORE, April 18Ben Feliciano rode three more winners at Pimlico today for a total of seven in two days to challenge Vincent Bracciale Jr. for jockey honors at the Baltimore track. The three winners lifted his total to 34, five fewer than Bracciale's total. Bracciale has been out of action with an ankle injury since last Friday.

title: Architects, in Show, Face Energy Crisis
description: Architecture is the second largest user of energy in the United States; it is surpassed only by transportation. Of all the energy this country consumes, it wastes 50 per cent. The beautiful New York skyline at night, with its romantically sparkling, brilliantly lighted, unused offices, is an example of profligate energy waste. This, and more, is in the exhibition called The Architect and the Energy Crisis, sponsored the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. A traveling show of photographic enlargements designed by Arnold Saks and underwritten by corporate, foundation and Government funds, it can be seen at the OwensCorning Fiberglas Exhibition Center at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street through April 28.

title: Criminal Justice
description: More than 2,000 years ago Cato the Elder, one of the Chief statesmen of the Roman Republic, told the judges: Those who do not prevent crimes when they might, encourage them. Today, we who are associated with the criminal justice system in the United States believe we are doing everything we can to prevent crime. The last thing we would believe is that we are encouraging it. Certainly Cato's admonition could not be aimed at us.

title: T.W.U. Local Breaks Off Brooklyn Union Gas Talks
description: Local 101 of the Transport Workers Union announced yesterday that it had broken off contract negotiations with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and was alerting, two million customers to a possible strike at midnight April 30.

title: Plane Signal Fires Missile
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 18 (UPI)A Minuteman 2 missile was launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base last night by signal from a control center in an aircraft flying overhead. Members of a missile combat crew in an EC135 activated the missile, which sped down Vandenberg's Western Test Range into the Pacific Ocean, the Air Force said.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES REGISTERS DEFICIT
description: American Airlines, Inc., yesterday reported a $29million loss for the first quarter. The carrier said it had been adversely affected by a work slowdown and sickout on the part of its pilots before a new contract was agreed to on April 2.

title: L.I.R.R. Accord Won
description: The Long Island Rail Road and 12 nonoperating unions reached a tentative agreement last night, thus averting a possible resumption of the strike against the line tomorrow night. Page 85.

title: STOPPAGES CLOSE HALF OF RENAULT
description: PARIS, April 18The Renault auto works were half paralyzed today by intensified work stoppages reflecting continued social tensions five weeks after the Gaullist election victory and nearly five years after the studentworker revolt of May and June, 1968.

title: OKLAHOMA AGREES TO FORFEIT GAMES
description: The University of Oklahoma forfeited eight of last season's 11 football victories, including a 14.0 Sugar Bowl triumph over Penn State, after it was disclosed yesterday that the highschool academic transcript of Kerry Jackson, a freshman quarterback, had been altered. The games forfeited were those in which Jackson played.

title: U.N. COUNCIL SEEKS RESOLUTION ON RAID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18The members of the Security Council, consulting behind closed doors, tried today to formulate a resolution on the Lebanese complaint that resulted from last week's Israeli commando raid in Beirut and its suburbs.

title: Tornado Injures 14 and Causes Wide Damage in Alabama Town
description: ELBA, Ala., April 18 (AP)  A tornado touched down near here late today, injuring at least 14 persons, the authorities said.

title: G. T. E. Aims to Hold Gains
description: MADISON, Wis., April 18 Top management of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation indicated here today that the company expects to maintain the recordbreaking pace it established in the first quarter.

title: Bay State Millionaire Fails To Appear on Tax Charges
description: BOSTON, April 18 (UPI) A warrant was issued today for the arrest of Edward Krock, a multimillionaire and former officer of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, in New York City, after he failed to appear in Federal District Court here to be arraigned on charges of violating the Federal income tax law.

title: Screen: Genteel Nelson Affair Opens
Corporate Rite of Spring: Ma Bell Meeting
description: CHICAGO, April 18In the springtime, the great corporate ritual is the annual meeting.

title: Rangers LineUp
Key Figures in Watergate Are Silent or Unavailable
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Like most of the central figures in the Watergate case, the White House counsel, John W. Dean 3d, was not to be found today.

title: Poker Night Is Victor, Numbered Account 2d
description: Sometimes that sure thing will let you down. It happened yesterday when Ogden Phipps's Numbered Account, the heavy favorite at 3 to 10, was beaten by Poker Night in the $25,000 added Bed o' Roses Handicap for fillies and, mares at Aqueduct.

title: Incomes Up in March to a Peak
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Consumer incomes in the United States crossed the $1,000billion mark in March, the Government reported today. It was the first time that this key economic indictor had gone above a trillion dollars on an annual basis.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: INTRAMURAL As if the towering World Trade Center, Church anal Dey Streets, were not a sight in itself, it is adding tarestries as a further attraction. Starting today, 50 tapestries by 27 artists among them Alexander Calder, Le Corbusier, Man Ray, Ossip Zadkinewill bedeck the walls of the lobby mezzanine of the northern tower, No. 1. This is the first time that the spacious, 75foothigh area is being used for an art exhibition.

title: PRICES OF BONDS CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Bond prices continued to erode yesterday, pushing interest rates higher, as the market adjusted to what seemed waning hopes of immediate action to tighten economic controls. Trading remained relatively light. Taxexempt issues rose 5 to 10 basis points in yield, most corporates slipped  in price and longerterm Treasury issues also eased. In the money market, 89day certificates of deposit moved up solidly to the 7.30 per cent level and the rate on Federal funds climbed as high as 9 per cent as the bank statement week came to a close.

title: StokesUdell Team Split Up
description: Carl Stokes, former Cleveland Mayor turned television newsman, will lose his coanchorman on WNBCTV here. He will remain as an anchorman on the National Broadcasting Cornpany's local 6 P.M. news show, and Paul Udell, his partner, will become an N.B.C. correspondent and may be assigned to Vietnam. The StokesUdell team has been on the air for nearly a year and has run a consistent third to the shows on WCBSTV and WABCTV.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The interior of St. Patrick's Cathedral formally came out from under 90 years of grime, dust and lampblack yesterday. The transformation was wrought by $800,000 worth of restoration that included vacuuming two inches of dust from nooks and crannies in the ceiling, painting, washing down the stained glass windows, and patching flaking pillars. Worshipers for the first time may now get a good look at the hats of four cardinals suspended from the ceiling 112 feet high.

title: Ideal Queens School District Is Torn By Dissent as Board Election Nears
description: Utopia Parkway borders and runs through a section of Queens School District 26 and in some ways the street is aptly named. The neighborhoods it cuts through appear idyllically tranquil. The houses are neat, the lawns appropriately groomed, and the side streets meander in pleasing, leisurely curves.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: And Now, Make Room for the Berenson Sisters
description: Sisters, sisters, there were never such devoted sisters, or so the song goes. But in their case, it isn't just a song, insist Marisa and Berry Berenson, the current Big Two sisters in the frenetic New York societyfashionshow business crowd. It's true.

title: Levy, Antiwar Army Physician, Wins a Reversal of Conviction
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit declared today that two key provisions of the Uniform Code of Military Justice that led to the courtmartial conviction of an antiwar Army physician, Capt. Howard B. Levy, six years ago were so vague as to be unconstitutional.

title: I T. T. INVOLVED IN MERGER DEALS
description: The International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation was involved yesterday in two important merger developments.

title: Key Opposition Men Seen Joining Lon No1 Cabinet
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Thursday, April 19Cambodia's chief of state, President Lon Nol, and two leading nonCommunist opposition figures appeared to be moving rapidly today toward collective leadership of this wartorn country.

title: Cathedral's Glory Restored for Easter
description: The interior of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday formally came out from under 90 years of grime, dust and lampblack.

title: SOVIET IS MENDING TIES WITH BRITAIN
description: MOSCOW, April 18Premier Aleksel N. Kosygin ended an 18monthold freeze on SovietBritish relations today by warmly receiving Peter Walker, the British Trade Minister, and sending a message of good wishes through him to Prime Minister Heath.

title: College, School Results BASEBALL Colleges
Ellsberg Completes His Testimony on Pentagon Papers, Charging That They Depicted American War Crime
description: LOS ANGELES, April 18  Daniel Ellsberg completed his testimony in the Pentagon papers trial today, telling the jury that the documents contained 1,000 pages depicting American war crimes and illegal actions  not by the troops in Vietnam, but by high Government officials.

title: Tax Refunds to Late Filers May Take Up to 7 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The Internal Revenue Service says that latefiling taxpayers will have to wait at least six to seven weeks before any refund checks duo them are mailed.

title: Advertising: New Yorker on TV
description: The purpose of the campaign is not to win new readers (newspaper ads will be used for that), only more advertisers and the 16 commercials by Lord, Geller, Federico, Peterson are all testimonials from people in the business.

title: Pacific Nations Protest Slated French ATests
description: APIA, Western Samoa, April 17Heads of governments of seven South Pacific nations meeting in this picturesque tropical capital drew up a stiff protest today against tests of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere, especially those by France over South Pacific waters,

title: Sharp Shooting Ties Series at Garden, 11
description: As badly as the Boston Celtics whipped the New York Knicks in Boston last Sunday, so did the Knicks thoroughly Crush the Celtics at Madison Square Garden last night, by a 12996 score.

title: Flyer Story Untrue, Coffee Admits
description: TRENTON, April 18 (UPI) Moments after he said at a news conference that he had ordered his staff not to pass false campaign rumors, Richard J. Coffee, the Democratic gubernatorial hopeful, admitted that the material on the front page of one of his circulars was untrue.

title: State Study: Conclusions and Reaction
description: Despite numerous difficulties and alarming trends, New York City remains the vibrant financial, business, cultural, communications and entertainment capital of the country and perhaps even the world. In addition to a resident population of nearly 8 million and the millions who come to work here each day, nearly 16 million people visited New. York in 1970; 7 of the 10 largest United States corporations maintain their headquarters here; six of the nation's eight largest banks are in New York New York's economy is changing; but a period of transition is not novel to this city's history and is not cause for despair.

title: Outspoken G. M. Executive Quits
Chrysler Discerns a Chance To Produce Turbine Engine
description: DETROIT, April 18 (Reuters) The Chrysler Corporation said today that if Congress accepted suggestions that it relax nitrogen oxide pollution standards for cars, the prospects for the gas turbine engine would increase.

title: W.H.A. Playoff S
description: EAST DIVISION

title: Stifling Public TV
description: The resignation of Thomas B. Curtis as chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting constitutes a signal that public affairs programing may be close to extinction in noncommercial television. Mr. Curtis, a former Republican Congressman from Missouri, was named to the C.P.B. board last year by President Nixon. From the start the Administration, with Clay T. Whitehead, director of the Office of Telecommunications Policy, as spearhead, put growing pressure on him to eliminate any transmission of public affairs programs via the Public Broadcasting Service network. Mr. Curtis met this pressure by laboring patiently to put together a workable, moderate compromise.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Big Triple at Westbury Pays Record $5,360.20
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 18 A record $5,360.20 big triple payoff was registered tonight at Roosevelt Raceway when the 1091 combination in the feature race was posted on the board. The previous high was $4,900 on Sept. 11, 1971.

title: Art From The Confident Years
BISHOP STUART DIES; LED GEORGIA DIOCESE
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., April 18 The Right Rev. Dr. Albert Rhett Stuart, who retired last year as Episcopal Bishop of Georgia, died in a hospital here today. He was 67 years old and lived at 611 East Bay Street.

title: ERVIN NOTES ROLE
description: DAVIDSON, N. C., April 18 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. declared here today that the Senate committee investigating the Watergate conspiracy would be the final judge on whether White House aide could refuse to answer any of the committee's questions.

title: ERVIN NOTES ROLE
TEXAS GUNMAN KILLS WOMAN AND 2 GIRLS
description: HOUSTON, April 18 (UPI) A man firing a rifle out a car window as he drove today through an uppermiddleclass residential neighborhood shot and killed an 86yearold woman and two girls. He also wounded two other children.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, April 18The secretary general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic party proposed today that toplevel meeting of the leaders of Japan, the United States, Britain, France and West Germany be called resolve the continuing monetary issue. Tomisaburo Hashimoto, who Is a close associate of Premier Kakuei Tanaka, said to newsmen that he thought President Nixon should call the meeting because he is the leader of the world's most economically powerful nation.

title: College Baseball
Set Problems Cancel Preview of Women
description: Last night's scheduled opening preview of The Women, a play by Clare Booth Luce, was canceled without warning yesterday. It was reported that there had been difficulties with the sets.

title: U.S. Sees Deal on a Parley to Cut Forces
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Administration officials said today that a break seemed near in the lengthy impasse that has prolonged preliminary talks between nations of the Soviet bloc and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on ways to reduce their military forces in Central Europe.

title: MAINE POTATOES CLIMB THE LIMIT
description: Maine potato futures rose the limit of 35 cents a hundred pounds yesterday on the New York Meteantile Exchange on volume of 1,395 lots of 50,000 pounds each. Other contracts rose 9 to 22 cents. There were 1,095 unfilled bids at the end of the day.

title: State Study: Conclusions and Reaction
description: Following are the texts of the Scott Commission's con, elisions on the operation of city government and the reply from Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton:

title: PASARELL BEATEN IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 18 (UPI)Charlie Pasarell, surprise conqueror of topseeded Stan Smith, was eliminated from the $50,000 South African tennis tournament today by Ove Bengtson of Sweden.

title: U.S. Steel Told to Clean Air
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 18 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency put United States Steel at Gary on 30 days notice today to clean up the air or face possible criminal and civil action. United States Steel officials said that they would not comment on the notice until after discussing it with lawyers.

title: McCrane Appearance Promised In Inquiry Into Cahill Campaign
description: NEWARK, April 18Former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. was pictured today as a fugitive from a Federal grand jury that wanted to question him about his fundraising activities for Governor Cahill's 1969 gubernatorial campaign.

title: N.H.L. Repudiates Talks With W.H.A. Concerning Merger
description: Under pressure from its Players Association and a multimilliondollar antitrust suit, the National Hockey League yesterday repudiated the secret merger talks held recently between some N.H.L. and World Hockey Association owners.

title: An Illegal Council
description: The City Council of New York City is an ineffective body that too rarely lives up to its responsibilities. Long a sanctuary for partisan faithful who received the councilmanic nod from county leaders as a reward for their service, the local legislative body of the nation's largest city has remained seriously unrepresentative. It contains no Puerto Ricans and only two blacks among its membership although the city's population is now about 15 per cent of Puerto Rican descent and 25 per cent black.

title: Willie Smith, jazz Pianist, Dies at 79
description: Willie (The Lion) Smith, the jazz pianist and composer, died last night at the New York University Hospital after a brief illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 634 St. Nicholas Avenue.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
description: Supplementary OTC

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SUIT BY SANDMAN
description: NEWARK, April 18  Federal Judge James A. Coolahan dismissed today a suit in which Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., a candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, challenged the constitutionality of the state's primary election laws.

title: POLISH AIDE'S VISIT IS PUT OFF BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The United States has told Poland to postpone a visit here by Deputy Premier Jan Mitrega because

title: FOODLAW VIOLATORS ARE NAMED BY CITY
description: Fourteen more foodprocessing establishments in New York City have been named by the Health Services Administration for serious violation of the city's Health Code.

title: National Emergency
description: The United States has been in a state of national emergency since 1933. This is not a flippant statement, but a matter of law discoveredto the astonishment of members of Congress as well as many in the executive and judiciary branchesby a special Senate committee investigating the powers of the Presidency.

title: A FRAGILE PROGRAM IS SUNG BY JOY KIM
description: As befitting her light, rather fragile soprano, Joy Kim offered a correspondingly light, rather fragile program of art songs in Tully Hall Tuesday night. The Mozart, Schubert and Wolf groups accented the coyly mischievous or delicately melancholy sides of these composers, and the closing selection of French, American, Korean and Spanish folk songs had a similar flavor.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
Television
description: Afternoon

title: Vatican Sees Christian Ideas in Maoism
description: ROME, April 18The Vatican made a public overture today for a dialogue with Peking on the basis of Roman Catholic recognition that the thoughts of Chairman Mao Tsetung also reflected Christian values.

title: Saigon Reports 120 Attacks, But Says None Are Major
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 18 (Reuters)Fighting in South Vietnam remained at a relatively low level today, with the military command here reporting a rise in Communist violations of the ceasefire from yesterday, but no significant attacks.

title: Equity Financing
description: Burlington Northern, Inc., the country's longest railroad system, asked, shareholders yesterday to authorize at the company's annual meeting May 10 a new class of preferred stock and to increase the authorized number of common shares to 25 million from 17.5 million. In its proxy statement dated April 4, the road disclosed that It had discussed with investment bankers selling up to $60million of nopar preferred.

title: Black Social Workers Open Conference in City
description: The National Association of Black Social Workers opened its fifth annual conference here yesterday with the continued aim of strengthening black families, but with a stronger emphasis on building economic and political institutions in the black community.

title: Philadelphia Traffic Study
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (UPI)  Philadelphians may some day be reporting for work at staggered hours in the downtown area. The Urban Mass Transportation Administration granted the city $50,000 yesterday to study the feasibility of the plan.

title: Proxy Fight Is Halted At Hamilton International
description: The proxy fight involving the Hamilton International Corporation, dissident shareholders, the company and a key group of investors in the company has been halted, as all parties have agreed on a settlement. Hamilton International is a diversified insurance and real estate corporation.

title: Hentz &
description: Hayden, Stone Inc., a large brokerage and investmentbank ing firm, said yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire H. Hentz & Co., Inc.

title: 2 Give Up After Holding 42 Hostages in a Harlem Bank
description: One of the F.B.I.'s 10 mostwanted men was killed yesterday and his two alleged accomplices were captured after the attempted holdup of a Harlem bank in which 32 customers and 10 employes were held hostage for nearly two hours.

title: Cambodia Terms Foes Vietnamese Communists
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 18The Information Minister directed foreign newsmen today to refer to enemy troops in future dispatches not merely as Communist forces but as Vietnamese Communists.

title: Stage: Rabe's The Orphan Arrives
description: With The Orphan, which opened last night at the Anspacher Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater complex, David Rabe brings his Vietnam trilogy to completion. The three plays, The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel, Sticks and Bones and The Orphan all produced by Joseph Papp and directed by Jeff Bleckner  have very much in common.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Thursday, April 19, 1973

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS POLICY TO AVERT AN ENERGY CRISIS
Nixon Counteroffensive
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  President Nixon's striking statement about the Watergate case yesterday was in keeping with his reliance on bold action in the face of crisis. By taking the counteroffensive, his associates in the White House believe, he hopes to show that he sinned not but was sinned against, to portray himself as the prosecutor and not the protector of those to be prosecuted. He moved from a posture of dogged denial not to the middle ground of waiting and seeing but to an aggressive search for miscreants.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Like virtually all social interventions which have discriminated against youth in the work place throughout our history, the Nixon Administration's proposed dual minimum wage (or youth minimum) is disguised as a social welfare measure. According to freshman economics, young people are unemployed in greater proportions to their elders because they are less productive. Thus, if wages are allowed to descend to compensate for the difference in productivity, there will be More jobs for teenagers. So much for the textbooks.

title: Shoemaker Has 4 Winners In 7 Rides at Hollywood
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 18 (AP)Bill Shoemaker, enjoying his finest day since recovering from a broken hand, rode four winnersincluding three in a rowat Hollywood Park today.

title: Yanks 5Run 9th Beats Orioles, 74
description: BALTIMORE, April 18Jim Ray Hart made his debut an American Leaguer a convincing one tonight by starting a fiverun rally in the ninth inning that gave the Yankees a 74 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games
description: SECOND GAME

title: DR. SOL N. KEEN
description: Dr. Sol N. Keen, professor emeritus of pediatrics at they New York University School of !Medicine, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 11212 72d Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: British Football Results
Syndicates Cashed In on Superfectas, Inquiry Hints
description: Betting syndicates that could beat the superfecta without help from dishonest drivers apparently are the real targets of harness racing's latest investigation.

title: Chemical Makers Gain
UTILITY IS OPPOSING SEAT FOR CONSUMER
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 18  An attempt by the Northern States Power Company to prevent a consumer spokesman from being elected to the utility's board was debated for four and a half hours today in Minneapolis Federal Court.

title: Justices Allow Habeas Corpus For Defendants Not Imprisoned
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Habeas corpus, a legal process traditionally used by unconstitutionally imprisoned criminals to win their freedom, can be invoked by lawbreakers who have never been to prison, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Amex and Counter Shares Decline in Slow Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter finished slightly lower yesterday in slow trading.

title: Ervin Committee Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Following is the text of guidelines issued today by the Senate Watergate committee dealing with witnesses who appear before the panel:

title: Voice of the Migrants?
description: Consumers all over the country are being asked once again to take sides in the running battle between Cesar Chavez and the mammoth International Brotherhood of Teamsters over union representation for California farm workers. The A.F.L.C.I.O. has put its resources behind the Chavez union in this unequal war, but now a troublesome new dimension has been added by a Chavez charge that farm owners have been making illegal payments to Teamster officials to help smash their beleaguered rival.

title: PHYLLIS BARTLETT, EDUCATOR IS DEAD
description: Dr. Phyllis Bartlett, who retired in 1967 as professor of English literature at Queens College and was a member of the doctoral examining committee of the City University Graduate Center, died Tuesday at her home at 230 East 50th Street. She was 68 years old.

title: Curran Appointed by Nixon as Successor to Seymour as U.S. Attorney Here
description: Paul J. Curran was named by President Nixon yesterday to succeed Whitney North Seymour Jr. as United States Attorney here.

title: Comeback
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The President did it his way. He did not stand in front of the cameras, bruised and embittered, apologizing about Watergate, saying he was misled by his subordinates or otherwise pushing an alibi. He neither submitted to crossexamination nor requested television time for a long explanation.

title: TV: C.B.S. Turns Waltons Into Easter Story
description: On a special twohour Easter Story edition of The Waltons this evening, Olivia, the mother, becomes a victim of polio, and her family's belief in God's love and mercy is put to the test. While attempting to prepare the older children for coping with their future, Olivia struggles toward possible rehabilitation with some new and unorthodox treatments developed by a Sister Kenny in Australia.

title: City Booklet Gives Tips For Older Consumers
description: The Department of Consumer Affairs has issued new booklet, Do's and Dont's for Senior Consumers, giving tips on how to save money shopping.

title: Stefan Rundt, Trade Expert Who Published Weekly, Dies,
description: Stefan J. Rundt, a consultant on international trade and finance and publisher of Rundt's Weekly Intelligence Briefs, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 62 years old and lived at 130 East 63d Street.

title: Nixon Counteroffensive
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 President Nixon's striking statement about the Watergate case yesterday was in keeping with his reliance on bold action in the face of crisis. By taking the counteroffensive, his associates in the White House believe, he hopes to show that he sinned not but was sinned against, to portray himself as the prosecutor and not the protector of those to be prosecuted. He moved from a posNews ture of dogged denial not to the middle ground of waiting and seeing but to an aggressive search for miscreants. If in the past he had behaved as if he thought the problem would blow away, now he seems ready to deal both with the problem and with the politics of the problem.

title: CHARGES LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Attorney General Richard G. Kleiridienst has disqualified himself from further involvement in. the Watergate investigation, sources close to the case said today, amid persistent reports that three or more of his present and former colleagues in the Nixon Administration would be indicted.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The State Department charged yesterday that the film State of Siege besmirched the life of Dan Mitrione, an American police adviser who was slain in Uruguay by guerrillas in 1970. The film describes in documentary fashion the story of an American adviser in a LatinAmerican country who participated in police torture and brutality and is slain by rebels. It was reputed to be based roughly on Mr. Mitrione's life.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: LondonJohnny Clark. 116 pounds, Britain, outoointed Franco Zurlo, 118, Italy, 15 rounds. Clark won vacant European bantamweight title. Bunny Sterling, Jamaica, outpointed Mark Rowe, London, 15. Sterling retained British middleweight title.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
Specialties Are Special For Shepherd Breeder
description: Many breeders take as much pride in winning a specialty as an allbreed show. This school goes even a step further. It insists the specialty is more of a test and a victory helps to prove a breeding program is on the right, trail.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: WHATS A NICE COUNTRY LIKE YOU DOING IN A STATE LIKE THIS? a revue, directed and choreographed by Miriam Fond; music by Cary Hoffman; lyrics be Ira Gasman; musical direction by Arnold Gross. Upstage at Jimmys, 33 West 42d Street, 7.

title: CHARGES LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst has disqualified himself from further involvement in the Watergate investigation, sources close to the case said today, amid persistent reports that three or more of his present and former colleagues in the Nixon Administration would be indicted.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 23yearold nurse at Trenton State Prison has received plaudits from inmates for rushing to the aid of a prisoner who suffered an epileptic seizure in a cell block last week.

title: Bridge: Homogenized Teams Used In a Competition in Europe
description: One of the paradoxes of tournament bridge is that a team is not really a teamit consist of two pairs, or three pairs. This can be avoided by a requirement that partnerships should rotate, so that each player must play with each of his teammates in turn.

title: L.I.R.R. Reaches Tentative Pact With 12 Unions, Averting Strike
description: The Long Island Rail Road and 12 nonoperating unions reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday and averted the possible resumption of a strike that could have come one minute after midnight tomorrow.

title: BIAGGI TESTIMONY SOUGHT BY TROY
description: The manager of Representative Mario Biaggi's mayoral campaign urged him yesterday to request the release of his testimony before a Federal grand jury and thus support Mr. Biaggi's assertion that he had not invoked the Fifth Amendment.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD STRICT STATE LAW ON OIL POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Supreme Court ruled today that states may make shippers liable for the damage that offshore oil spills cause private citizens as long as the states laws do not conflict with Federal antipollution measures.

title: Cougar Assembly to Shift
description: DETROIT, April 17 (UPI) Production of the Mercury Cougar will be transferred to the Ford Motor Company assembly plant in the Atlanta suburb of Hapeville for the 1974 model year, the LincolnMercury division announced today. Hapeville will be the only plant producing the Cougar when 1974model production begins Aug. 6.

title: Con Ed Is Expected to Get Go Ahead on Atomic Plant
description: The Consolidated Edison Company is expected to receive authority today from the Atomic Energy Commission to start operating its $200million Indian Point No. 2 nuclear power plant on a limited capacity.

title: Corruption in Government Is Theme of Talks by 3 Gubernatorial Candidates
description: NEWARK, April 18 (UPI) Three Democratic gubernatorial candidates face each other in a joint appearance today to discuss the November election, which one of them said would be a referendum on the policies of the Nixon Administration.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD STRICT STATE LAW ON OIL POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Supreme Court ruled today that states may make shippers liable for the damage that offshore oil spills cause private citizens as long as the states laws do not conflict with Federal antipollution measures.

title: But Brokers Decline
description: The spate of poor earnings reports continued, to flow from leading Wall Street investment houses yesterday. E. F. Hutton & Co., reported that its profits in the first quarter ended March 31 came to $1.5million, or 32 cents a share, down from $4.5million, or $1.09, in the like 1972 quarter.

title: COMPROMISE BILL WILL AID ELDERLY
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  After months of being at loggerheads over spending issues, Congress and the White House reached agreement today on major legislation that President Nixon had earlier threatened to veto.

title: Baruch Tennis Victor
description: Baruch College defeated Brooklyn Poly, 63, in a Metropolitan Collegiate tennis conferenece match played yesterday at the Fleet Court in the Bronx.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fickle Nature
description: CRONTON  ON  HUDSON, N.Y.One of the marks of a skilled angler is remaining at home sipping bourbon when conditions are wrong for pursuing his sport.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
Farm Editors Elect Chief
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) Keith L. Wilkey, farm editor of the Quincy (Ill.) HeraldWhig, has been chosen 1973 president of t he Newspaper Farm Editors of America, a national organization of writers on agriculture and allied affaiirs for daily papers.

title: ISRAELI MAJORITY WOULD KEEP AREAS
description: JERUSALEM, April 18A majority of Israelis oppose returning any part of the occupied Golan heights, the West Bank of the Jordan River or the Gaza Stripeven in exchange for a peace agreement ivith the Arabsaccording to a public opinion poll newly published here.

title: Mets Records
Food Riots in Indian City
description: NEW DELHI, April 18Food riots broke out today in Nagpur, 500 miles south of here. According to the Press Trust of India news agency, mobs in the central India city looted shops selling grain, clothing, wine and groceries.

title: That Summer of 1870
description: This year, New Yorkers again will be treated to the city's annual ridTimesSquareofundesirables summer festival. If history is any guide, this cleanup will elimiriate only the most visible, allurements of vicethe streetwalker for a few months at best. New York's vice will continue to thrive hereas it has for the last 150 years.

title: Jury Finds Two Assemblymen Acted Obscenely
description: ALBANY, April 18An Albany County grand jury said today that two Assemblymen acted in a boisterous and obscene manner during the administration of free heart tests by a 20yearold female technician at the Albany Medical Center last Feb. 27.

title: 2 ExMackell Aides Indicted Over Taxes In GetRich Scheme
description: Two former members of the staff of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens were indicted yesterday on charges of having failed to report on their Federal tax returns income of about $352,000 they made from an illegal getrichquick scheme.

title: Public TV Will Cover Watergate Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)The Public Broadcasting Service said today that it would provide live television coverage of the Senate hearings on the Watergate case.

title: Chilean Leads Advance In Easter Bowl Tennis
description: Form held up in the first round of the Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis championships last night. The boys 18 and 16 divisions went into action, with the girls scheduled to start play today at Tennis 59, York Avenue and 59th Street.
