description: The Long Island Rail Road and 12 nonoperating unions reached a tentative agreement last night, thus averting a possible resumption of the strike against the line tomorrow night. Page 85.

title: ACE HUDKINS, BOXED IN MANY DIVISIONS
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 18 (UPI) Ace Hudkins, a boxer who began as a lightweight in the nineteentwenties and ended in the heavyweight division in 1931, died today. He was 67 Years did and had been under treatment for Parkinson's disease,

title: Levy, Antiwar Army Physician, Wins a Reversal of Conviction
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit declared today that two key provisions of the Uniform Code of Military Justice that led to the courtmartial conviction of an antiwar Army physican, Capt. Howard B. Levy, six years ago were so vague as to be unconstitutional.

title: COUGARS DEFEAT COLONELS, 10291
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 18 (AP) The Carolina Cougars, breezing along on a 32point performance by Billy Cunningham, overwhelmed the Kentucky Colonels, 10291, tonight and tied the American Basketball Association Eastern Division final playoff series, 22.

title: C.I.A. Trained Tibetans in Colorado, New Book Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The Central Intelligence Agency set up a secret base in the Colorado Rockies to train Tibetan guerrillas in mountain warfare in the late nineteenfifties, when there was an uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet, a new book discloses.

title: People and Business
description: Richard C. Gerstenberg, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, supplanted Henry Ford 2d as the top paid corporate executive last year by a noseor more precisely, $396. According to the G.M. proxy statement for its upcoming annual meeting next month, Mr. Gerstenberg, who took office on Jan. 1, 1972, received $874,963 in salary and bonuses, which is 6 per cent more than the $825,000 his predecessor, James M. Roche, earned in 1971.

title: Dr. Cornelius Trowbridge, 74, Of Planned Parenthood, Is Dead
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 18 The Rev. Dr. Cornelius P. Trowbridge, a retired Episcopal clergyman and a former president and chairman of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, died here yesterday. He was 74 years old and lived at 3213 Fordham Road here.

title: Aide Says Administration Is Eager for Pipeline Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)  Acting Interior Secretary John C. Whitaker told Congress today that the Administration was willing to accept almost any bill that would clear the way for immediate construction of the transAlaska oil pipeline.

title: New Jersey Sports Young and Running
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., April 18George Miller, a 31yearold mathematics teacher at Park Junior High here, has added a new dimension to New Jersey track and field in the last 18 months.

title: Scott Study Calls on the City to Retrench
description: New York City must be reorganized structurally and functionally must cut costs sharply and must withdraw entirely from some programs because it no longer has the resources to meet its demands, the Scott Commission recommended yesterday in its report.

title: Inco Up by 92.5%
description: Sharply higher firstquarter earnings continued to be reported yesterday in the flurry of financial statements from companies all across the country in all kinds of businesses.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
SOVIET DISSIDENT SAID TO CONFESS
description: MOSCOW, April 18 The secret police campaign against the Chronicle of Current Events, the main underground dissident journal here, has reportedly drawn a confession of involvement from Irina Yakir, a member of a prominent dissident family.

title: Arthur Daley
description: When Leo Durocher became manager of the Giants in 1948, said Whitey Lockman yesterday, he scared me to death. But I was only 22 years old then and the only other manager I had had during my brief time as a big leaguer was Mel Ott, a wonderful man. Leo is different and I stayed scared of him for the rest of the season. But then I got used to him and he didn't frighten me any more.

title: IRISH LEAGUE
description: Ballymena Untied 4, Glentoran 1.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Urges Busing For 57,563 Memphis Pupils
description: MEMPHIS, April 18 (UPI) The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People proposed plans in Federal court today to bus 57,563 Memphis public school children next fall. The move came one day after a school was closed by racial violence over busing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Ten Hackensack High School students were treated for cuts, scrapes, bruises and similar injuries at Morrisania Hospital after a bus carrying them home from the Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., collided with another bus yesterday in their convoy on the Cross Bronx Expressway near Weeks Avenue. The driver, James Thomas, after being cut from the bus with a torch, was taken to Morrisania Hospital where he was reported good condition after treatment for a cut head and other minor injuries.

title: UTILITIES REPORT HIGHER EARNINGS
description: Commonwealth Edison and American Electric Gain

title: Winner's 'Scorpio,' Spy Melodrama, Bows:The Cast
description: Just possibly there may be something in Michael Winner's "Scorpio" that you have never seen at the movies before. But then I think it fair to ask where have you been hiding yourself for the last 10 years, as spy melodramas have come and gone, and double agents have multiplied, selling their secrets but saving their soulsfor whatever tragic, trendy, ironic fate awaits them at the end of the sordid alley-way that the rest of us call life.Set in Vienna, Paris suburban Georgetown and other fleshpots of the world, "Scorpio" pits C.I.A. agent Cross (Burt Lancaster) against his boss McLeod (John Colicos), while between them stands Laurier (Alain Delon), hired assassin, the Scorpio of the title, hired by McLeod to kill Crosswho happens to be the closest thing he ever had to a best friend, and who also taught him everything he knows about the hired-assassination business.What Cross wants to do is go off and relax with his wife Sarah (Joanne Linville), and what Laurier wants to do is go off and relax with his girl Susan (Gayle Hunnicuttin this movie all the men have only last names and the women have only first names). But there remains the problem of the contract on Cross's life, and why it is there. The situation sounds like elemental anguish, except that in "Scorpio" nobody stops long enough to feel anguishand so it all becomes merely elemental, or elementary, if your critical facilities are so disposed.The dialogue consists mainly of aphorisms. Actually, the aphorisms come only from Cross and from Zharkov (Paul Scofield), Cross's Russian counterpart and a pal from the old days when we could all be anti-Fascists together. Everybody else gets told what to think. But the aphoristic style, combined with Winner's unwavering visual instinct for crushingly obvious detail, helps to push "Scorpio" out of low dullness into vertiginous absurdity. This is almost enough to save the movie from suffocating in its own clich's.There are people who take Winner seriously ("The Jokers," "Chato's Land," "The Mechanic," etc.), but I doubt if anyone could take "Scorpio" seriously, and that is the best I can say about it. Sitting in the theater, begrudging every minute and yet slightly hoping it would not end, I am caught in the moviegoer's age-old agony, between heart felt derision and guilty delight."Scorpio" opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.

title: WOMEN'S LEADER SCORES M'GOVERN
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Frances T. Farenthold, head of the National Women's Political Caucus, criticized Senator George McGovern today for proposing a retreat from the standards that were used in 1972 to pick delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: NEW ULSTER PLAN IS IN DIFFICULTY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 18Britain's attempt to shift political power to moderates in Ulster's Protestant and Roman Catholic communitiesa policy embodied in the white paper published a month agois running into some difficulty.

title: A. T. &
description: CHICAGO, April 18  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told its stockholders today that profits for the three months ended March 31 rose to $660.89million, or $1.19 a share, from the yearearlier $542.62million, or 99 cents a share.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALL HEAVEN IN A RAGE. By Maureen Duffy. 207 pages. Knopf. $5.95 Somebodyperhaps it was Emersonsaid that a poet is someone who, having nothing to do, finds something to do. I don't know how poets feel about that characterization, but I think it could often be applied to novelists. There is a type of novel that seems to be terribly random, that reads as if it had been written simplybecause the author could not endure another moment of having nothing to do and had fastened on the first subject that came to mind. Even very good writers have been seized this way. Such novels are at the other end of the scaleif there is a scale from those that sound as if the author was possessed, as if his whole life had ineluctably led him to the point wherehe had to write this and nothing else.

title: DEFICIT WIDENS IN BRITISH TRADE
description: LONDON, April 18  After fairly optimistic economic news in recent weeks, the British Government found itself in gloom today over the prospect of serious balanceofpayments problems.

title: SCOTT STUDY ASKS CITY TO RETRENCH
description: New York City must be reorganized structurally and functionally, must cut costs sharply and must withdraw entirely from some programs because it no longer has the resources to meet its demands, the Scott Commission recommended yesterday in its final report.

title: M'CRANE IS CALLED IN JERSEY INQUIRY
Heart Surgery at Issue in 5 Hospitals
description: Blue Cross of New York has announced that it will discontinue payment for openheart surgery at five hospitals in Brooklyn and Nassau County whose programs have not been approved by the State Department of Health.

title: Fire Destroys Woolen Mill
description: SOMERSWORTH, N. H., April 18 (AP)A general alarm fire that raged out of control for hours destroyed the former Baxter woolen mill last night. The fire department estimated damage at close to $1million.

title: Putting Rumors to Rest
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, a frontrunning candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, has repeatedly asserted that he answered every question put to him in a recent grand jury investigation of immigration matters. The grand jury's term has ended with no indictments, but reports have persisted that, while under interrogation before the panel, Mr. Biaggi invoked the Fifth Amendment protection against selfincrimination to refuse answers to as many as thirty questions about his personal finances.

title: NATIONAL CONFERENCE
description: NEW ORLEANSSigned Deriand Moore, defensive end and No, 1 draft choice from the University of Oklahoma.

title: Mets'
China Demands U.S. End Rote in Laos and Cambodia
description: TOKYO, April 20 (AP)China demanded today an end to United States military intervention in Cambodia and Laos.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The good news yesterday was that employment in New York City rose by 11,000 jobs during February. The bad news was that employment in the rest of the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area declined by 4,000 jobs in February. Summing up, the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics said that basically, empoyment in the area was relatively stable, totaling 6,487,000. Compared with the situation last February, employment was up 59,000, most of it outside the city.

title: Mitchell Retains Prosecutor's Friend
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The man whom former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has retained as counsel, William G. Hundley, has 22 years of experience in criminal law, the first 15 as a hardnosed Justice Department prosecutor and the last seven as an effective Washington defense lawyer.

title: Chinese Team Floors Rivals With Kindness
description: PARIS, April 19A team of jolly Chinese giants amazed a Paris basketball crowd last night by playing Florence Nightingale to their flustered opponents.

title: Yankee Records
HORSES &
Joan G. Aller Bride Of Charles Smith
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 19In the Niles Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon Miss Joan Gale Aller, a financial analyst with Management Planning, Inc., was married to Charles Richard Smith, an independent insurance broker. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frederic E. Fox.

title: 135 More Picketers Held In Coast Vineyard Dispute
description: COACHELLA, Calif., April 19 (UPI)  Federico Chavez, 22year old nephew of the United Farm Workers Union leader, Cesar Chavez, was among 135 persons arrested today in connection with further alleged illegal picketing at the Coachella Valley's largest grape vineyard.

title: Orthodoxy Rules at Princeton U. As Perverto Ticket Is Defeated
description: PRINCETON, April 19Orthodoxy has triumphed at Princeton University, but by narrow margin. Andrew Strenio won election last night as president of the Undergraduate Assembly by capturing 1,364 votes to 1,259 cast for Richard Goodman, the standard bearer of a slate that campaigned on a platform calling for mindless perversion.

title: Woman Charges Dismissal Was Based on Sex Bias
description: TRENTON, April 19 (AP)A woman factory worker has charged that she was dismissed as a clerk for having used profane language that is commonly used by men.

title: Meany Recalls Top Aide Serving on Brennan Staff
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) George Meany has recalled top A.F.L.C.I.O. official serving on Labor Secretary Peter J. Brennan's staff. It was the latest move in Mr. Meany's feud with his former associate.

title: Belfast Boy Slain As Gunmen Attack A Soldiers Patrol
Postal Contract Talks Open
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)The United States Postal Service opened contract negotiations today with unions representing postal workers. The unions asked for substantial wage increases and improvements in fringe benefits and management said that it must hold the line on costs to head off a new postal rate increase.

title: Good Friday
description: For today, Good Friday, the following is a list of services that are or are not affected: Stock ExchangesClosed. ParkingAlternate sideofthestreet rules suspended. Public and Parochial Schools Closed..

title: Disorder Prevents Vote on Dog Run in Village
description: Angry residents of Greenwich Village disrupted a meeting of their community board last night, forcing it to adjourn before voting on the issue of the eveningwhether to retain a dog run on a local vacant lot or replace it with a basketball court.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE FURTHER
description: Soybean and soybeanmeal futures in the near months rose sharply again yesterday, with soybean meal advancing the limit of $5 a ton and soybean futures up 11 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean oil futures prices increased 20 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: JAZZ POP UPS However it turns out, it promises to be differentthe jazz show coming up at 8 tonight in Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 32d Street, (5644400). At the top of the bill is Eumir Deodato, a Brazilian pianist who composes and arrangeshis interpretation of Richard Strauss's music, used in Stanley Kubrick's space film, is called Also Sprach Zarathustra (2001) and is doing quite well.

title: EDWIN C. WOOD
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., April 19 Edwin C. Wood, an organizer Ind a former manager of the Wood Regan Instrument Company of Nutley, N.J., died yesterday. He was 83 years old and lived in Whiting.

title: Nixon Tells Jewish Group Soviet Exit Tax Is Ended
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Nixon, citing messages from the Kremlin, assured a group of Jewish leaders today that in his opinion the Soviet Union had suspended a controversial education tax on Jews wishing to leave and would not reimpose it.

title: GOTTFRIED BEATS LUTZ, 61, 57, 76
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 19 (Reuters) Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., added a thirdseeded player to his list of victims in the $50,000 South African tennis tounrament today by beating Bob Lutz, 61, 57, 76, in the quarterfinals.

title: KNICKS, CELTICS RESUME PLAYOFF
Canadian ,Satellite Blastoff Delayed by Missing Tape
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 19 (UPI)A missing piece of tape for a dust cover forced at least a 24hour postponement tonight in the launching of Canada's second national communications satellite.

title: Spurned Women Attack
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 19 (UPI)Three women with knives attacked two young men yesterday and stabbed one of them. Jerry Harrad, 26 years old, who was hospitalized told the police that the women had assaulted the men because he had turned down their offer for a date.

title: 6 Players Tied for Lead In Tallahassee Open Golf
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 19 (UPI)Six players tied for the firstround lead in the Tallahassee open golf championship today with fourunderpar 68's.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)The railroad industry said today that it planned to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a 5 per cent freightrate increase. The 402 lines said in a petition to be filed tomorrow that no increase in net operating income was expected to result from the proposal because the expected revenue yield is far short of the increased costs already experienced.

title: Bombing for Peace?
description: United States bombers rain death on Cambodia, South Vietnamese troops sally across the Cambodian border, American bombers strike intermittently in Laos it has all the aspect of the rerun of a bad movie.

title: Death Penalty Is Voted in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, April 19The Connecticut Senate voted narrowly today to restore they death penalty for six types of crime, including the sale of hard drugs by a nonaddicted person to another who dies because of them.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fifth cadet at the United States Military Academy at West Point has been found guilty of violating the honor code in an investigation of cheating being carried out by the cadet honor committee. Four cadets found guilty earlier this week and faced with the choice of voluntary resignation from the academy or resort to a hearing by a board of officers have chosen the latter course, an academy spokesman said.

title: PACERS CONQUER STARS BY 104102
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 19 (AP)The Indiana Pacers survived a 34point effort by Utah's Willie Wise and defeated the Stars, 104102, tonight in the fifth game of their American Basketball Association West Division playoff final.

title: WABCTV WINS PRIZE FOR PUBLIC SERVICE
description: Station WABCTV here and The St. Louis GlobeDemocrat were named top winners of the 1972 Roy W. Howard Public Service Awards yesterday.

title: Nixon's EnergyPolicy Outlook
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The energypolicy message that President Nixon sent to Congress yesterday was essentially a plan for producing more fuel and power to satisfy America's evergrowing appetite. Only in a secondary way, and in very cautious terms, did Mr. Nixon suggest curbing that appetite and modifying the everyday habits and the comfort norms of the American people. This tilt in favor of dealing with supply rather than demand, and the President's related implication that energy might be more important than environment, explain why reaction to the message has been more enthusiastic in the energy industries than among the environmentand consumerminded.

title: DR. HANS KEISEN, LEGA SCHOLAR 91
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 19 Dr. Hans Kelsen, a legal scholar and an authority on international law and jurisprudence, died today of cardiac arrest. He was 91 years old.

title: One of 3 Suspects Pleads Guilty In Stennis Robbery and Shooting
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)  John S. Marshall pleaded guilty today in the Jan. 30 robberyshooting of Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, the Justice Department said.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $902,000,000, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $794,000,000. Total retail store sales were about $9,469,000,000, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $8,333,000,000.

title: Red Smith Duffy Daugherty 's PearShaped Tones
F. Edward Biertuempfel Dead; Mayor of Union, N.J., Since 39
description: UNION, N.J., April 19  F. Edward Biertuempfel, who was Mayor here since 1939, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 78 years old and had been in poor health for several years.

title: Watergate at a Glance
description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has confirmed for the first time, in conversations with friends, that he discussed bugging the Democratic opposition with other Nixon Administration aides. But he has said that told them not to go through with it.

title: U.S., IN WARNING, ANNOUNCES HALT IN MINESWEEPING
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The United States announced today the suspension of all mineclearing operations along the coast of North Vietnam and the recall of the chief American official in the Paris negotiations on possible reconstruction aid to the North.

title: H.R.A. GUARDS SEEK GUNS IN A PROTEST
description: About 130 uniformed welfare guards walked off the job and picketed the offices of the Human Resources Administration yesterday; demanding the right to carry guns, after a guard was shot outside a juvenile home in Brooklyn.

title: Political Connections Paved Way for Business Deals
description: TRENTON, April 19William B. Cosley 3d and Bruce A. Mahon are two men who know the value of political connections in expediting business deals.

title: Children's Day at Prison: Mothers Could Be Mothers Again
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., April 19Normally when child comes to see his mother at the state prison for women here, they have to sit in a stuffy visiting room, separated from each other by a wide table. When the time comes to say goodby, they are limited to a short embrace.

title: Ellsberg in the Dock
description: LOS ANGELESThere is no Perry Mason atmosphere in the trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony Russo for releasing the Pentagon Papers. Federal Judge Matthew Byrne runs strict court room, and neither the defense nor the prosecution attorneys are much given to dramatics. A technique of the prosecutor, David R. Nissen, seems to be to extract from witnesses one minute detail after another in a dogged search for inconsistencies or inaccuracies. The basic facts of the case, however, are largely agreed upon, which removes the major opportunities for suspense and surprise.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: DUMONT, April 19A proposal for a Bergen County Athletic Commission to monitor league alignments and act as a coordinating agency for minor sports, officiating, and other interscholastic activities is finding broadbased support among school and athletic administrators throughout the county.

title: FASHION TALK

And the key to the season is sweaters, just as it was in the Paris readytowear collections a few weeks ago. Not just sweaters, of course. But coats that look like sweaters, suits that look like them and dresses that are as supple and comfortable as any old pullover.

title: MIKLOS LASZLO, 69, PLAYWRIGHT, IS DEAD

description: Governor Rockefeller, citing, disastrous and costly effects of several recent strikes here, suggested yesterday that voluntary arbitration was a better way to resolve deadlocks in negotiations.

title: Alcoa Sets Record Results in Most Areas
description: PITTSBURGH, April 19By most measures, the Aluminum Company of America achieved a record first quarter, John D. Harper, chairman and chief executive officer, told 335 stockholders at the annual meeting here today. Only earnings, which topped the comparable 1972 period, failed to reach a new high.

title: ARGENTINA ACCUSES AN I.T.T. SUBSIDIARY
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 19 (UPI)The Minister of Public Works and Services, Pedro Gordillo, has called for the annulment of Government contracts with the Argentine subsidiaries of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the West German company Siemens.

title: U.S. Output Soars Again, But Inflation Rate Doubles
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The nation's output continued to rise at the abnormal rate of about 8 per cent in the first quarter of this year and the rate of inflation doubled from from that of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Fire Routs 50 in Miami
description: MIAMI, April 19 (UPI)A fire badly damaged one of the downtown area's older residence hotels today, forcing more that 50 persons to flee. There were no serious injuries. Fire Chief Dan Heyder said the top two floors of the fourstory San Carlos Hotel were burned out. The adjacent PanAmerican hotel suffered little damage.

title: 'High Plains Drifter' Opens on Screen
description: Callie Travers (Mariana Hill) is indignant. Having so successfully caught the eye of The Stranger (Clint Eastwood) that he has carried her into the livery stable and had his way with her (with her cooperation), she complains to the sheriff: "Isn't forcible rape in broad daylight still a misdemeanor in this town?"It is not, and has not been for some time, not since the good citizens of the little frontier community of Lago banded together to murder their former sheriff, an honorable man who had wanted to reveal that the town's mining company was on Government land."High Plains Drifter," with Eastwood as director as well as star, is part ghost story, part revenge Western, more than a little silly, and often quite entertaining in a way that may make you wonder if you have lost your good sense. The violence of the film (including a couple of murders by bull-whipping) is continual and explicit. It exalts and delights in a kind of pitiless Old Testament wrath.However, it is also apparent that neither Ernest Tidyman, who wrote the screenplay, nor Eastwood are taking themselves too seriously. Eastwood's characterization of The Stranger, who settles God's score with Lago, is a high parody of the soft-featured, brutal Man With No Name he played in those bitter Sergio Leone Westerns. Tidyman's dialogue is funny, and the physical settingsome weatherbeaten shacks on the edge of a body of water that looks like a dead seais startlingly beautiful.Eastman, who earlier directed "Play Misty for Me," has also surrounded himself with a group of good supporting actors, including Verna Bloom, Mitchell Ryan and a 65-year-old midget named Billy Curtis.

title: Fun of 'Love and Pain' Yields to Ethic
description: "Love and Pain and the Whole Damn Thing," directed by Alan J. Pakula and written by Alvin Sargent, is most of the time such a funny and eccentric romantic comedy that you have to excuse the attack of Anglo-Saxon ethic that finally overwhelms it.Despite almost everything written by Colette, despite the experience of even Benjamin Franklin, popular American and English fiction writers persist in spreading the gloomy word that the conjoining of an older woman and a younger man is a near-mortal sin, usually punishable by death. It may not be so in life (Mary Pickford and Buddy Rogers made a go of it), but the audiences for which Hollywood thinks it is making its films (if not the film makers themselves) are afraid to believe otherwise.This is what's wrong with "Love and Pain," which is about the thoroughly revivifying love affair of an English spinster in her late 30's, Lila Fisher, who's supposed to be plain, although she is played by the spectacularly engaging Maggie Smith, and a troubled, asthmatic American college boy, Walter Elbertson (Timothy Bottoms). The setting is Spain, which, in summer, becomes a giant, open-air museum and parkland to be overrun with organized tours by bus and bicycle.Their meeting is not auspicious. Walter, taking the seat next to Lila on a bus, inadvertently squirts her with his breath-freshener and then allows her to sit on his Mounds barbut they both seem to be neurotic messes at the start.Lila is running away from Bournemouth, where she lives with two elderly aunts and lodgers who must be propped up in their baths and who misplace their teeth in the piano. Walter's background is also forbidding. His father has won a Pulitzer Prize for a book called "The Identity of Man," and his sister can build her own cellos.Lila and Walter are clearly made for each other, and the film is charming so long as it focuses on the details of their growing love and need for each other. Miss Smith, who was so fine in "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie" and somehow completely out of step with "Travels With My Aunt," is again magnificent (and magnificently funny), whether locked in a ladies room and crying out a dainty, plaintive "por favor" (read from a phrase book), or putting off an ardent Spaniard, who tries to seduce her with bird-calls. "I'm not too familiar with birds," she says with a mixture of hautiness and desperation. "I have a fish."Mr. Bottoms, the hero of "The Last Picture Show," is equally funny and believable, full of wonder at the intensity of purpose (and intensity of clichs) that Lila awakens in him. It is something of a breakthrough for him when he finds himself saying, quite seriously: "We have to smile in the rain and be cheerful losers.""Love and Pain" was photographed in front of, around and through somewhat more scenery than is absolutely necessary, and it eventually goes to soap suds, but that happens late. In the meantime, you can enjoy two of the most intelligently comic performances of the year so far.

title: PRESSMEN SETTLE NONMONEY ISSUES
description: William J. Kennedy, president of Pressmen's Union No. 2, said yesterday that noneconomic issues had been resalved in contract negotiations with The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 19 (Reuters)The Tanzanian government appealed today to Tarranians not to throw stones at drivers in the East African safari motor rally, which started today in Nairobi, Kenya. The government also asked citizens not to mislead the Myers about the Safari route.

title: Victim of Police Beating Here, Paralyzed, Awarded $3Million
description: A printer who became a quadraplegic after a Transit Authority patrolman struck him with a nightstick and an emergencyroom physician mistreated his injury has been awarded $3million in damages by a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn.

DEAN IS REBUKED
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The White House abandoned today all show of support for the embattled Presidential counsel, John W. Dean 3d, who has been accused of complicity in the Watergate case.

title: Chairman for U.S. Home
description: Charles Rutenberg, president of the U.S. Home Corporation, has been named to the additional post of chairman. Last week, Robert Winnerman sold his entire holdings of 394,000 common shares of the company and resigned as chairman. In addition, Stuart S. Golding was named to the new post of executive vice presidentoperations. Mr. Golding has been senior vice president of the investment properties group.

title: Mrs. Elias Sunstein, 85, Led School in Pittsburgh
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., April 19 Mrs. Gertrude Kingsbacher Sunstein, for many years an educator and civic worker, died at St. Mary's Hospital today. She was 85 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: Cambodia Bombing Is Jointly Planned
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 19United States air support for the Cambodian war effort against the Communists apparently continues each day without renewed GovernmenttoGovernment requests but with the continuous cooperation of American and Cambodian military planners.

title: Canadians Top Flyers, 21
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 19 Efficiently but without any effervescence, the Montreal Canadiens recorded a 21 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight for a 21 advantage in their Stanley Cup semifinal playoff. The fourth game of the fourofsevengame National Hockey League series will be staged here Sunday afternoon before a national TV audience.

title: Crash Kills Five in Family
description: KINGMAN, Ariz., April 19 (AP)A widow and her four young children were killed today when their small foreign car plunged into a dry river bed west of here, the Arizona Highway Patrol said. The victims were Edith Wright Wiltbank, 32 years old of Thatcher, Ariz., and David, 9, and his three sisters, Thelma Marie, 8; Larea, 7, and Tawni Ruth, 6.

Meskill of Connecticut said today. He said Watergate has titillated the readers, but there are more important things to do.

description: CAIRO, April 19 (UPI)Nine schoolchildren died and several were injured yesterday when a mud brick house collapsed, the newspaper Al Ahram said today.

description: The sands of Jones Beach and nearly two miles of the best recreational beaches in the New York region are in imminent danger of destruction, the head of the Army Corps of Engineers for the New York region said yesterday, necessitating a program that it is hoped will rebuild the areas this summer.

description: Donald S. Rugoff, a coproducer of the film State of Siege, categorically denied yesterday a State Department statement that the film showed any official of the Agency for International Development participating in police torture and brutality.

description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has confirmed for the first time, in conversations with friends, that he discussed bugging the Democratic opposition with other Nixon Administration aides. But he has said that told them not to go through with it.

title: Man Seized as Vagrant With $9,000 in Pockets
description: An 83yearold man with the appearance of a vagrant was picked up on a park bench in Greenwich Village last night for publip drunkenness and disorderly conduct, the police reported. What turned out to be unusual in this case was that the man, taken to the station house, was found to carry $9,665 in his pockets.

title: Gap Between Fund Sales And Redemptions Closes
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (Reuters)Redemptions of mutual fund shares topped sales by only $12million in March, compared with $203.8million in February, the Investment Company Institute, the national association of the industry, said today.

title: Markets Closed Today
description: An United States and Canadian securities and commodities exchanges will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. Banks will be closed in some cities but will be open in New York, Boston, Dallas and Detroit. The postal service will make regular deliveries. Most businesses will be operating as usual.

title: ISRAEL M. BIDERMAN, JEWISH LEADER, 60
description: Israel M. Biderman, director of the youth and education department of the Jewish National Fund of America, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Coney Island Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 200 Brighton 15th Street, Brooklyn.

People and Business

The senior member of the board with a term expiring in 1978, Mr. Robertson will leave at the age of 65 after 46 years of Government service.

title: Narcotics Suspect Wounded By Patrolman in Village
description: A plainclothesman shot and seriously wounded a narcotics suspect in Greenwich Village last night when the suspect threatened the patrolman with a gun, the police reported.

title: Mass Transit Aid Barred As House Votes Roads Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The House approved today, a $20billion highway construction bill but refused to allow urban areas to use money from the Highway Trust Fund to build mass transit systems.

title: Taking Up Arms
description: WASHINGTONNow that the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks have resumed in Geneva, early indications are that the Nixon Administration may be taking the wrong steps at a time when a strong centralized effort to deal with arms control problems is needed.

title: 2 G.O.P. Fund Raisers for Cahill Indicted on Charges of Bribery
description: TRENTON, April 19Two prominent Republican leaders with close ties to the Cahill administration were indicted today on bribery charges involving an alleged conspiracy to have $6million in state funds controlled by former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. illegally deposited in a local bank.

title: After the Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Even after the courts and the Senate have passed judgment in the Watergate case, we will still not know what happened here unless we understand the mood and assumptions of the Administration in which these bizarre events occurred.

title: Whitehead Influence on C.P.B. Is Decried
description: Ralph B. Rogers, the Texas industrialist who led stations in a struggle for their autonomy visavis the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, suggested last night that improper political influence had been exerted on the C.P.B. board by Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy.

title: Citibank's Reinstituted Loan Rate of 6% Matches Others.

description: Federal officials and the State of New Hampshire have taken the first step toward what is designed to be the nation's first major experiment involving children in private and parochial schools in the voucher system of education.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Strangling the Cities
description: The refusal by the House of Representatives to allow a mere 10 per cent of the $7 billion available annually in Highway Trust funds to be spent on urban mass transit is a heavy blow to urban survival. The combined power of the highway lobby of truckers and construction interests and of the antiurban rural forces succeeded denying some relief to cities poisoned by exhaust fumes and immobilized by collapsing transportation systems.

title: Schedule of Candidates Nights
Growers Suffer 4 Wet Seasons
Raymond F. Waters Dead; A Picture Editor at News
description: METUCHEN, N.J., April 19 illaymond F. Waters, assistant picture assignment editor of the Daily News in New York, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 21 Maryknoll Road, He was 60 years old.

title: Mets Win, 31, Then Bow, 70; Yanks Top Orioles on 6 in 2d
description: The Mets finally did some hitting yesterday  nothing to write home about, but enough to defeat the Chicago. Cubs, 31, in the opening game of a doubleheader at Shea Stadium.

title: Colbert's 66 Leads Champions
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 19Jim Colbert, who says his concept of golf differs from other professionals, scored a sixunderpar 66 to lead the $200,000 Tournament of Champions by one stroke today.

title: U.S. SEEKS TALKS BY MIDEAST FOES
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today in his annual foreign policy report that the United States would press in coming months to persuade the Israelis and Arab states to begin a genuine negotiating process.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States announced yesterday that it had suspended mineclearing operations along the North Vietnamese coast, a move Administration officials said was aimed at halting what they said were North Vietnamese violations of the ceasefire agreement. Similarly, it was announced that the United States had recalled its chief negotiator from the Paris discussions on possible postwar American reconstruction aid to North Vietnam. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Soviet Pepsi Generation Is Toasted in Champagne
description: MOSCOW, April 19  PepsiCola was officially signed on today as the first American consumer product for sale in the Soviet Union. But how much Pepsi Ivan Ivanov gets will depend on how much Soviet vodka John Jones consumes.

title: Warsaw Ghetto
description: It was thirty years ago yesterday that the German troops in Warsaw launched their attack against the city's ghetto. The plan was for a threeday operation which would end with all the Warsaw Jews dead or on their way to extermination camps. But the Jews surprised their Nazi murderers by refusing to go quietly to their destruction. They fought back with the desperation of people deprived of everything but their humanity. The Germans finally prevailed, and the Warsaw ghetto and its people were no more. But before they died, the doomed fighters of thirty years ago had written an epic of heroism that will live through the centuries as inspiration for all who fight against tyranny and genocide.

title: The New Sly Album: Music Feels Good
description: Pounding the floor with his golden cowboy boots, bobbing his head and hands upand down, Sylvester Sly Stewart sat in an East Side recording studio late last week listening to the tapes he and his group, Sly and the Family Stone, had just finished in Los Angeles for their new Fresh album.

title: Business as Usual For Hero of Siege
Notes on People Chou Greets Mexico's Leader
description: As he arrived in Peking, President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico received a handshake from Premier Chou Enlai a welcome from thousands of dancing schoolgirls and became the first head of a. Latin American state to visit China since the Communists took power there in 1948. Mr. Echeverria was scheduled for several talks with the Premier, and perhaps one with Chairman Mao Tsetung. In an interview with Mexican journalists, Premier Chou said that Chairman Mao, who is 79 years old, is in good health. He has a lot of work and dedicates himself to reading.

title: G.O,P, BID SPURNED ON SETTLING SUITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Common Cause and the Democratic National Committee said today they would not settle their civil suits against the Republicans, holding them instead as a weapon for investigating the Republican party's finances and the Watergate breakin.

title: G.O.P. BID SPURNED ON SETTLING SUITS
Bridge:
description: If asked to name the most widely distributed bridge book of all time, most guesses would center on the works of Ely Culbertson and Charles Goren. The right answer, apparently, is a 36page booklet, The Biggest Little Bridge Book in the World. Well over a million of these are in circulation, largely because of a free distribution by a cigarette company.

title: A Key I.L.A. Leader Is Shot in Hoboken In RubOut Effort
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., April 19 William Murphy, a 58yearold International vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association and a powerful New Jersey waterfront figwas in critical condition today after being shot in what a police official called a rubout attempt.

title: Notes on People
description: As he arrived in Peking, President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico received a handshake from Premier Chou.Enlai, a welcome from thousands of dancing schoolgirls and became the first head of a Latin American state to visit China since the Communists took power there in 1948. Mr. Echeverria was scheduled for several talks with the Premier, and perhaps one with Chairman Mao Tsetung. In an interview with Mexican Journalists, Premier Chou said that Chairman Mao, who is 79 years old, is in good health. He has a lot of work and dedicates himself to reading.

title: Mrs. Johnson's Party Delays Irene Curtain
description: The curtain was 15 minutes late last night for the musical Irene, but the audience, which had been growing restless, responded with a standing ovation for the late guest, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, the President's widow.

title: Relevance of the O.A.S.
description: The Organization of American States has concluded its General Assembly in Washington with far less fireworks than had been expected. As usual, a number of the foreign ministers were bitterly critical of the United States role in the hemisphere, both in and outside the O.A.S.; but only Chile even suggested revamping the Organization to exclude this country. Some came to Washington determined to force a showdown on the readmission of Cuba, but they settled instead for a simple declaration that the O.A.S. accepts a plurality of ideologies among its members.

title: ROCKEFELLER AIDES MAP MACKELL CASE
description: Governor Rockefeller's staff was reported yesterday to have begun preparation of charges that will be given to District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens in connection with the Governor's previously announced decision to initiate removal proceedings against Mr. Mackell.

title: College Baseball
There's More Room To Enjoy the Food
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: MANY LEAVE HOMES IN LOUISIANA FLOOD
description: MORGAN City, La., April 19 (UPI)  The Atchafalaya River swept, into the Gulf of Mexico at Morgan City today, several feet higher than downtown streets and held back only by a concrete wall topped with a plywood and mud barricade.

title: Roundup: Tigers Sweep Red Sox Series
description: Things may change later on this baseball season, but for the nonce the Detroit Tigers own the Boston Red Sox. Yesterday in Fenway Park the Tigers crushed Boston, 117, on a 16hit barrage and swept the fourgame series.

title: LAKERS SET BACK WARRIORS, 10493
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19 (AP) Jerry West on offense and Wilt Chamberlain on defense paced a Los Angeles fourthquarter surge tonight that fashioned a 10493 victory over the Golden State Warriors and 120 lead in their Western Division playoff of the National Basketball Association.

title: Texans Plan Big Party for Biggest Airport (It's Not)
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex.  There were strained feelings in Fort Worth when the telephone company chose Dallas's area code, 214, instead of Fort Worth's 817 for a 17,500acre expanse of prairie midway between the cities.

title: Royal and Regal Captures Keeneland Stake by a Nose

title: Tito and Brandt Announce WarReparations Accord
