title: POVERTY AGENCY SCANS PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Officials of the Office of Economic Opportunity have begun a detailed review of all programs funded by the agency after an unannounced decision not to appeal a court ruling last week that declared illegal previous efforts to dismantle the operation.

title: Watergate Breakup
description: The walls of secrecy surrounding the Watergate scandal are now tumbling down. After wearisome months of defending themselves by ridicule, denial, disparagement and diversionary tactics, Administration officials led by President Nixon himself are at last admitting that this was no caper and that serious illegal acts have been committed.

title: Screen: 'Soylent Green'
description: New Yorkers certainly have problems these daysgraffiti, income tax, the Yankees  but nothing like the horrors due in 2022 as depicted in "Soylent Green," which arrived at local theaters yesterday. To begin with, the Gotham of 2022 teems with 40-million citizens; overpopulation and its concomitant horrors aside, the erosion of the environment is such that there's little to eat other than "Soylent Green" which, we're told, is synthesized from plankton. Unfortunately, the script, direction and the principals involved in this struggle for survival often are as synthetic as "Soylent Green."There is, of course, every reason to view the next century with some fear. But "Soylent Green" projects essentially simple, muscular melodrama a good deal more effectively than it does the potential of man's seemingly witless destruction of the earth's resources.Charlton Heston, as a harried detective investigating the murder of Joseph Cotten, a bigwig in the dictatorial Soylent Company (whom we see only fleetingly), is aided by the late Edward G. Robinson in his last role as an aged, wise, suspicious researcher, who remembers the good old days of steaks and the like. And, finally exposed by a bewildering succession of hungry citizens, overcrowded streets, fancy pads and the resident, luscious lasses (called "furniture" here) of the rich few, is the awful truth about the secret ingredient of "Soylent Green."We won't reveal that ingredient but it must be noted that Richard Fleischer's direction stresses action, not nuances of meaning or characterization. Mr. Robinson is pitiably natural as the realistic, sensitive oldster facing the futility of living in dying surroundings. But Mr. Heston is simply a rough cop chasing standard bad guys.Their 21st-century New York occasionally is frightening but it is rarely convincingly real.

title: Mass Transit Aid Barred As House Votes Roads Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The House approved today $20billion highway construction bill but refused to allow urban areas to use money from the Highway Trust Fund to build mass transit systems.

title: IRISH FOOTBALL
description: By Reuters IRISH LEAGUE Ards 1, LInfield 1. Glenavon 4, Larne 1.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Song Quest
description: Recently, this column glibly implied that it was a relatively simple matter to locate courting male woodcock.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
Case for Judicial Reform
description: A muchneeded campaign to persuade the State Legislature to reform the manner in which judges are selected and to provide effective means for their discipline and removal has now been launched by a committee of prominent citizens. In announcing its goals, Orville H. Schell Jr., president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, stresses the need to improve the quality of judges by a doublebarreled strategy  one he calls appointment of the best and weeding out the rest.

title: MTN LEADS, IN EMMY CHOICES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19 (AP)The Waltons, a lowkeyed series about a family in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia during the Depression, took top honors in the nominations for the 25th Television Academy Awards today.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
Notes of a City Boy
description: Oh youngest of the giant brood Of cities far renowned, In glory's race thou hast outrun Thy rivals at a bound. Thou art a mighty queen, New York, And how wilt thou be crowned? She bowed herself And spent herself And worked her will, forsooth, And set upon her island heights A citadel of truth. . . .

title: Bill on Rights of Homosexuals Due for a Vote by Council Unit
INDIAN VILLAGERS VOW TO USE ARMS
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 19Several ousted residents of Wounded Knee, angered by the Government's hesitancy to evict insurgents from the village, have threatened to take up arms themselves.

title: TV: Alcoholism Study
description: The only connection between tonight's Dick Cavett Show and Sunday's Portrait: A Man Whose Name Was John is that both are on the network of the American Broadcasting Company. Both also happen to be very much worth watching.

title: House Votes to Tie Up L.I. Bridge Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The House of Representatives voted today to bar 90 per cent Federal funding for approaches to the proposed RyeOyster Bay bridge unless the bridge project is approved by the legislatures of both New York and Connecticut.

title: MOTION ON ISRAEL FACING A U.S. VETO
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19  The British and French submitted a resolution to the Security Council today that condemned Israeli attacks against Lebanon, but did not condemn the Arab terrorist attacks that touched them off.

title: Soviet Blast Is Detected
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, April 19 (AP)The Uppsala Seismological Institute reported that a beria. A sokesman said the explosion had take place today in the Semipalatinsk area of Siberia A spokesman said the explosion was recorded at 5:53 A.M.  11:43 P.M. yesterday, New York time  and had force of 5.5 on the Richter scale.

title: To David Storey, a Play Is a Holiday
description: David Storey's five published novels and five produced playshis first novel was This Sporting Life, and his latest play, The Changing Room, is now having a successful run on Broadwayhave made him, at 39, one of England's most highly regarded young writers.

title: School Board Voting Procedures Explained
description: Five years ago, a New Yorker could scarcely utter the words community control in public without touching off an argur ment. But now community controlor decentralization, as legislators refer to itis a legitimate if still controversial part of the city's education system. And soon voters will go to the polls in the second community school board election to be held here since the state Legislature passed the decentralization law in 1969.

title: Stamford High School Youths End Record 144Hour Basketball Game
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 19  At 9:16 this morning, a 144hour ordeal of dribbling and shooting ended for 22 basketball players from Stamford Catholic High School when they broke what they believe is the world record for the longest basketball game.

title: Secret Watergate Papers Reported Hidden by Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Written plans for the Watergate plot and other secret papers were hidden from the authorities last year by an unnamed employe of President Nixon's campaign organization, it was reported in, court today.

title: F.B.I. SAID TO FIND EQUITY FORGERIES
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has uncovered massive counterfeit securities operation that is connected to the Equity Funding Corporation of America fraud case, according to informed sources close to the investigation.

title: Oil Shifting U.S. Strategic Interests to Middle East
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Military planners expect that the strategic interests of the United States and global strategy in general will pivot on the Persian Gulf late in this decade as a result of competition for the area's oil.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The police in Atlantic City say they have smashed mailorder prostitution ring in which conventioneers were invited to join a swingers club. Five women accused being members of the ring were arrested at a hotel, and the alleged ringleader was arrested in his car shortly after dropping off the women at the hotel. He was identified as. Louis Giannini, 54 years old.

title: CONTROL IS CLAIMED OF GENERAL BATTERY
description: Northwest Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that its tender offer for General Battery Corporation common stock at $34 a share had been successful with tenders in excess of 1.6 million shares having been received to date.

title: Mrs. Johnson Hails Rayburn
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson returned to Washington yesterday to pay tribute to the legendary Mister Sam at an unveiling of a bronze bust of late Sam Rayburn. More than 200 persons crowded into the National Portrait Gallery rotunda to hear Mrs. Johnson recall lore about the famous House Speaker. She said she remembered his patriotism most "There was no doubt in his mind that the United States was the strongest country God ever made.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. (TelevisionChannel 11, 8:30 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 8:30 P.M.)

title: A Fare Increase on the. L.I.R.R. Is Considered a Certainty in '74
description: A fare increase next year for Long Island Rail Road riders seemed virtually certain yesterday in the wake of Wednesday's tentative agreement between the railroad and its 12 nonoperating unions.

title: MRS. LEE GOODWIN GETS HOUSING JOB
An Old Trot Story
description: If past performances are any indication, the questioning of top harnessracing drivers begun yesterday by William Cahn, Nassau County District Attorney, will produce little more than gossip.

title: Both Big Board and Amex Post Monthly Drops in Short Interest
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest as of April 13 declined by 432,095 shares from a month earlier to reach 18,106,354 shares. In midMarch, the total stood at 18,538,449 shares.

title: Neighbor, 17, Held as Killer in Stormy French Case
description: PARIS, April 19A 17yearold inmate of a reformatory was formally charged today with the murder of Brigitte Dewvre, the 15yearold whose slaying a year ago provoked the hottest justice controversy since World War II.

title: Jersey Tells Blue Shield To Cut Rates for Many
2 Found Slain 8 Miles Apart; Police Find a Connection
description: EDISON, April 19 (AP)The bodies of stabbing victims were found here and in Plainfield eight miles away. The police said the slayings were related.

title: Nashville Meets the Bronx
description: Yet another country music concert, the commercial Nashville kind, and yet another cable from Mayor Lindsay read from the stage at Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday. It seems nobody can sit down at a pedal steel guitar these days without getting congratulations from Gracie Mansion.

title: Kerner Sentenced to Three Years and $50,000 Fine
description: CHICAGO, April 19Former Gov. Otto Kerner was sentenced today to serve three years in Federal prison and pay a fine of $50,000.

title: Briton Terms Common Market Victim of Fraud
description: LONDON, April 19  A British Government official told the House of Commons today that the Common Market had fallen victim to acts of fraud, perhaps involving millions of dollars.

title: CEMETERY WORKERS STRIKE SECOND SITE
description: Cemetery workers extended their strike for higher pay and improved benefits yesterday to a second cemetery.

title: PIN OAK COLT WINS DASH AT AQUEDUCT
description: Tree of Knowledge performed to the satisfaction of his trainer, Sid Watters Jr., in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The Pin Oak Stable's colt, flashing steady speed, took the 6furlong sprint by 1lengths from Edgar Zantker's Sell, who had threequarters of a length over Dawn Flight.

title: Grant, Meyer and Fleming Advance in Easter Bowl
description: Ricky Meyer, Mike Grant and Peter Fleming, top metropolitan players, won secondround matches in the 18's division at the Tennis 59 courts.

title: BIAGGI CONNECTS BEANIE TO INQUIRY
description: Representative Mario Biaggi's press secretary said yesterday that a Federal grand jury had questioned Mr. Biaggi not about his personal finances but about the finances of the Beame 1965 campaign.

title: Entertainers to Pinch Kit On N.B.C.TV Baseball
description: Purists may gripe and broadcasters may groan, but entertainers will help broadcast most of the National Broadcasting Company's 13 televised Mondaynight baseball games this season.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Association of American Railroads reported today that rail freight traffic during the latest week totaled an estimated 16 billion tonmiles, 7 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 520,778 cars, 4.1 per cent above last year.

title: Football Transactions
description: BUFFALOTraded to New England Edgar Chandler, middle linebacker; Wayne Patrick, fullback; and Jeff Lyman, linebacker, for Jim Cheyunskl, middle linebacker; Mike Montler, guard; and HaIvor Hagen, defensive end.

title: There, Alone, Sits Lawrence Mitchner
description: NEW BURLINGTON, Ohio  When the Army Corps of Engineers, thinking reservoir thoughts, announced intentions of eradicating the small farm, ing village of New Burlington, Ohio, from the face of its tillable earth, Lawrence Mitchner said quietly to his neighbors that he would not move.

title: 2 Boys Shot in 2 IRT Incidents, One, 14, in an Alleged Holdup
description: Two teenagers were hospitaliied yesterday after being wounded in separate subway shooting incidents.

title: It'sFollow the Leader On Basketball Drafts
description: The American Basketball Association played follow the leader yesterday as, for the second time, it postponed its college draft following similar action by the National Basketball Association.

title: Dartmouth Trustees Named
description: HANOVER, N. H., April 19 (AP)  The trustees of Dartmouth College have elected two prominent alumni, a Boston banker and a black lawyer from New York City, to membership on the 16man board. The new trustees are Richard V. Hill of Marblehead, Mass., chairman and chief executive officer of the First National Boston Corporation and its subsidiary, the First National Bank of Boston, and R. Harcort Dodds of Brooklyn, executive assistant corporation counsel for the New York City Law Department.

title: U.S., IN WARNING, ANNOUNCES HALT IN MINESWEEPING
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The United States announced today the suspension of all mineclearing operations along the coast of North Vietnam and the recall of the chief American official in the Paris negotiations on possible reconstruction aid to the North.

title: PORFIRIO SALINAS, TEXAS ARTIST, DIES
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 19 (AP)Porfirio Salinas, a favorite artist of President Lyndon B. Johnson, died last evening of a liver ailment. He was 62 years old.

title: BRITISH RUGBY
description: By Reuters RUGBY LEAGUE York 32, Bradford Northern 9. RUGBY UNION Lydney 12, Gloucester 32.

title: DELAY EXPECTED IN SCHOOL VOTING
CROSSWORD PUZZLE
82,075 FOUND JOBS UNDER WORKFARE
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare reported today that only 82,075 people had been placed in jobs under the controversial workfare program.

title: ON STAND TODAY
description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has told friends that he was aware of proposals to bug the Democratic opposition, and that he participated in three meetings at which these proposals were discussed. But he insists that he rejected the scheme on each occasion.Mr. Mitchell's statements that he had been approached about a political bugging operation appear to run counter to the. impression that he has sought to convey in the past that the entire Watergate affair was a complete surprise and mystery to him.The former Attorney General's comments became known iyesterday as he was subpoenaed to appear in Washington today before a Federal grand jury investigating the Watergate case.

title: Screen: Cruel Fantasy
Press Institute Is Getting $2.5Million to Assist Move
description: A total of $2,565,202 in contributions and pledges has been made to the American Press Institute to underwrite the group's move from Columbia University to its own building in Reston, Va.

title: American League
description: Friday, April 20, 1973

title: Death Penalty in Nebraska
description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 19 (AP)Nebraska has reinstated the death penalty for the crimes of premeditated murder, killing in the course of rape, arson, robbery, kidnapping, hijacking and burglary. The bill approved today by the unicameral Legislature, carried an emergency clause and is to take effect the moment it is signed by Gov. J. James Exon, who has supported the measure. The law will replace one that, like those in other states, was made invalid by a United States Supreme Court ruling last year.

title: People in Sports: Honor By N.B.A. to McAdoo
description: To the surprise of virtually no one, Bob McAdoo of the Buffalo Braves was named the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year yesterday. He will receive $500 and a trophy from Walter Kennedy, the commissioner, who announced the result of the voting.

title: Hollywood Park Suspends Shoemaker for Five Days
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 19 (UPI)Bill Shoemaker was suspended for five racing days today for careless riding during the sixth race at Hollywood Park yesterday.

title: 130 H.R.A. GUARDS PICKET FOR GUNS
description: About 130 uniformed welfare guards walked off the job and picketed the offices of the Human Resources Administration yesterday, demanding the right to carry guns, after a guard was shot outside a juvenile home in Brooklyn.

title: Stocks in Solid Advance; Dow Average Is Up 4.89
description: The stock market turned in a solid advance yesterday on rising volume ahead of the Good Friday holiday in Wall Street.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on April 19 were:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Tornado Strikes College
description: BATESVILLE, Ark, April 19 (AP)A tornado struck Arkansas College today, causing extensive damage but few serious injuries. The storm skirted the western edge of the college, demolishing one building, heavily damaging the dining hall, blowing the roof off three other buildings and knocking the steeple from the chapel.

title: COOK COMMENTS ON FORECASTING
New Books
Distributor Sees 3to5Cent Increase In Gasoline Price Because of Shortage
description: HACKENSACK, April 19  A major North Jersey distributor of petroleum products predicted today that gasoline and fuel oil prices would rise 3 to 5 cents or more a gallon by this summer as a result of shortages and President Nixon's program for meeting the energy crisis.

title: Stage: Refined Marceau
Warsaw, April 19, 1943: The Ghetto Battle is On
description: WARSAW, April 19Thirty years ago a secret radio transmitting from Germanoccupied Warsaw directed an urgent plea to the world:

title: Move to Tighter Credit Conditions Shown in Banking Statistics
description: The nation's banking system is steadily moving toward tighter credit conditions, a review of firstquarter monetary statistics showed yesterday.

title: BIAGGI CONNECTS BEAME TO INQUIRY
description: Representative Mario Biaggi's press secretary said yesterday that a Federal grand jury had questioned Mr. Biaggi not about his personal finances but about the finances of the Beame 1965 campaign.

title: Acupuncture Law in Nevada
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., April 20 (AP)Gov. Mike O'Callaghan signed today a measure making Nevada the first state to allow acupuncture to be practiced without supervision by licensed United States physicians. The new law to permit such practice of the ancient Chinese healing art had been opposed by Nevada medical groups. But demonstrations of the technique on more than 400 persons here apparently convinced legislators to approve the practice.

title: Channel 13 Offers a Zippy Traviata
description: Tomorrow night at 8:30 television viewers can catch La Traviata as the third of six minioperas currently on WNET/Channel 13. Produced by Nathan Kroll, the Who's Afraid Of Opera? series stars Joan Sutherland, with Richard Bonynge conducting the London Symphony Orchestra.

title: Kurt Leopold Is Dead at 73; Bonn Negotiator With East
description: BERLIN, April 20 (UPI)Dr. Kurt Leopold, who negotiated the EastWest German interzonal trade agreement, died last evening. He was 73 years old.

title: DR. HARRY ZUCKERMAN
description: Dr. Harry Zuckerman, emeritus professor of pediatrics at the French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center, died Thursday on a visit to Ambler, Pa. He was 73 years old and lived here. His office was at 115 Central Park West.

title: Workers in Apartment Houses To Postpone Threatened Strike
Waste Is Reduced to Useful Slag
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Union Carbide Corporation will receive a patent next week for a solidwaste disposal process that it regards as an environmental breakthrough. AS tested in a pilot plant at Tarrytown, N. Y., it reduces refuse to a small quantity of useful slag and produces five times more energy in fuel gas than it uses. The inventor is John E. Anderson, a development fellow in the Tarrytown laboratories, who will be awarded Patent 3,729,298. The process will be discussed at the company's annual meeting in New York next Wednesday.

title: Nixon Says Entire Truth Is Object of Investigation
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 20President Nixon arrived here today for the Easter holidays after a morning Cabinet meeting at which he emphasized that the objective of the Watergate investigation was to discover the entire truth of the matter.

title: Aquarium Fish Hall Reopened With 8 New Habitat Exhibits
description: Visitors to the New York Aquarium at Coney Island are getting a new seacave view of exotic forms of underwater life in a newly designed Main Fish Hall, which reopened this week.

title: Football Transactions
description: DALLASSigned Bruce Walton, U.C.L.A. offensive tackle, fifthround draft choice. NEW ORLEANSSigned Derland Moore, Oklahoma defensive tackleend, firstround draft choice.

title: Key Watergate Investigator
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Twentyfive years ago Henry E. Petersen was hired as a clerk at the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Gradually he climbed his way through the bureaucracy of the Justice Department, immersing himself in the battle against organized crime and winning a reputation as a completely honest man, as tough as nails, who doesn't get. snowed easily.

title: GIRL, 7, IS MISSING DELIVERING COOKIES
description: HILLSDALE, N. J., April 20 Hundreds of policemen and volunteers searched this suburban area today for a missing sevenyearold girl who disappeared yesterday after having left her home to deliver some Girl Scout cookies.

title: JOSEPHINE SCHAIN, A PIONEER FEMINIST
description: Josephine Schain, a former lecturer on international affairs and long a leader in women's rights and peace activities, died Wednesday in the Peabody Home, 1000 Pelham Parkway South, the Bronx. She was 88 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The SoHo castiron historic district will encompass the blocks between Canal and Houston Streets and West Broadway and Crosby Street, the Landmarks Preservation Commission announced yeterday. Protective landmarks status for the district, a rundown former merchandising and manufacturing area now known for its artistresidents and distinctive architecture, is expected this summer.

title: As Prices Rise, Critics Charge Quality Drop and Exploitation
description: A long time after swapping Manhattan for the legendary $24 worth of trinkets, American Indians are making new hit as local traders thanks to a boom in the popularity of their jewelry and other handmade items.

title: LAWYER IN GREECE TELLS OF INQUIRY
description: ATHENS, April 20A leading lawyer who was interviewed by American and British jurists about allegations that lawyers were oppressed in Greece said today that he had been charged with conspiracy and told that he would be courtmartialed.

title: UNION HEAD SHUNS CEMETERY INQUIRY
description: The head of the gravediggers' union said yesterday that he had disregarded a subpoena that called for his appearance before a state board of inquiry that was investigating the dispute between his union and owners of 47 cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

title: New Jersey Sports Recruiting for 10%
description: OAKHURST, N.J., April 20George Mackay of Pascack Hills High School, the state's premier middledistance runner, recently ran a 1:52 halfmile shortly after signing a letter of intent with Rice University that completed negotiations for a fouryear athletic grantinaid scholarship.

title: TV: A Man Whose Name Was John
description: A Man Whose Name Was John, scheduled for tomorrow, Easter Sunday, at 8 P.M. on the American Broadcasting Company network, is the second in a Portrait series, with David Victor as executive producer, that stumbled off to a disastrous start with Richard Chamberlain and Faye Dunaway as the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. From that bottom, this second offering recovers nicely and even impressively.

title: Back to Hoover
description: The reaction of White House economic advisers to each huge, new jump in living costs is beginning to bear a lugubrious resemblance to Herbert Hoover's refrain in the early years of the Great Depression that prosperity is just around the cornerjust as Watergate begins to remind us of the days of Warren Harding.

title: QE2 DOCKING TODAY TOP RABBIS CRITICAL
description: ASHDOD, Israel, Saturday, April 21 (UPI)  The Queen Elizabeth 2 steamed into Israeli waters early today, her worries over possible Arab guerrilla attacks eclipsed by lastminute rabbinical criticism of her docking on the Jewish sabbath.

title: J. WILLIAM HINTON, A HEART SPECIALIST
description: Dr. J. William Hinton, a heart specialist and former director of surgery at Post Graduate Hospital, died Wednesday at his home, 1520 York Avenue. His age was 78.

title: FULLY BD FREELY
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell appeared before a Federal grand jury today and said afterward that plan; to spy on the Democrats were pressed upon him repeatedly last year.

title: Qaddafi Quoted as Saying Libya Sent Help to I.R.A.
description: PARIS, April 20 Col. IMuammar elQaddafi of Libya said in an interview published here today that his Government had financed not only Palestinian guerrillas but also the Irish Republican Army and many other rebel groups.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING Rebel 500 stock car race, at Dar. lington, S. C. (TelevisionChannel 7, 5 P.M., tape).

title: Television
Newsprint Price Raised By International Paper
description: MONTREAL, April 20 (AP) The International Paper Company announced today that it was raising the price of newsprint $5 a ton, effective July 1.

title: 2 FROGMEN SEIZED IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: Two rubbersuited frogmen swam through the murky waters of Brooklyn's Erie Basin yesterday and retrived some 28 pounds of heroin and cocaine lowered by accomplices from the deck of a Chilean freighter. But narcotics detectives, and customs agents were watching the wouldbe smugglers and arrested them and three other men minutes later in a nearby house.

title: Space Agency Cuts Jobs
description: HOUSTON, April 20 (UPI)The jobs of 45 civil service employes will be eliminated by June 1, the space agency said yesterday.

title: HELGA MASTROFF UPSET IN TENNIS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 20 (AP)  Fourthseeded Mrs. Helga Masthoff was upset, 16, 75, 75, today by Martina Navratilova of Czechoslovakia in the quarterfinals of the $20,000 St., Petersburg Masters tennis tournament.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 21, 1973

title: Ft. Deveris Pupils Barred at Schools In Rift on U.S. Aid
description: AYER, Mass., April 20 (AP) The Ayer School Committee has closed its schools to 2,300 pupils who reside at Fort Devens near here in an effort to force the Nixon Administration to release more impactaid funds to school districts near Federal installations.

title: Secretariat Favored in Wood
description: Contrary to the general expectation earlier in the week, the presence of Secretariat and Sham in the Wood Memorial has not scared off the opposition. The sparse group that had been expected has grown to a representative field of 11, who will compete in the 1 mile test for 3yearolds at Aqueduct today. The gross value will be $116,400, the victory worth $69,840.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AL FRESCO Here's a street exhibition by four sculptors in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow afternoon that and this is newsis no kind of a protest demonstration at all. The sculptors, Ted Fhagen, Richard Hand, Taal Mayon and Rennee Erlandson, don't even have a group name  they merely think that some art should be shown in the streets in the interests of more artistic freedom and also of making their work more alive. The objects are large. One, by Mr. Fhagen, is a fullscale American Rickshaw, made of found and fabricated objects. The viewer can put himself in the driver's, or coolie's, spot, and pull it, while a large wagon wheel revolves above it.

title: Doctors Report Transsexual Cure
description: A 17yearold boy who for as long as he could remember had felt and acted like a girl and who wished to be changed surgically into a female was successfully oriented to masculinity by psychiatric researchers at the University of Mississippi, according to a report in the current issue of the Archives of General Psychiatry.

title: ALFRED F. KLEINDIENST
description: WEBSTER, Mass., April 20 (AP)  Alfred F. Kleindienst, founder and former owner of radio station WORC in Worcester, died at his home yesterday. He was 70 years old.

title: 2 Frogmen Seized As Drug Smugglers
description: Two rubbersuited frogmen swam through the murky waters of Brooklyn's Erie Basin yesterday and retrieved some 28 pounds of heroin and cocaine lowered by accomplices from the deck of a Chilean freighter. But narcotics detectives and customs agents were watching the wouldbe smugglers and arrested them and three other men minutes later in a nearby house.

title: Trevino Leads on Coast by Shot at 139
description: LA COSTA, Calif., April 20 Lee Trevino admitted there were stars in his eyes tonight, Yeah, I know all about it, he said on being reminded as the 36hole leader that a victory in the Tournament of Champions here would make him the fourth golfer to win a million dollars.

title: Nuclear Device Recovered
description: PLANTATION, Fla., April 20 (UPI)The police recovered today a stolen nuclear device that could have produced a fatal dose of radiation. Police Chief Larry Sullivan said a caller phoned the police to say the nuclear density scanner, stolen Wednesday night or yesterday from a Department of Transportation trailer, could be recovered at a post office annex. The police found the yellow square box between two mailboxes outside the building.

title: GREEN'S 136 PACES TALLAHASSEE GOLF
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 20 (UPI)The Tallahassee open took on the look of a collegiate rivalry today as Hubert Green, a former Florida State star, took a onestroke lead over Bob Murphy, a former University of Florida player, with a 36hole score of 136.

title: Bridge: Grand National Title Tourney Is in the Semifinal Stage Here
description: The concluding stages of the new Grand National Championship, as far as New York is concerned, will be played this weekend at the New York Hilton. The Precision Team meets Alvin Roth's group today in one semifinal, and Harold Ogust's foursome meets a squad headed by Michael Engel in the other. The winner of the final to be played tomorrow will compete in a regional playoff and perhaps continue to the national final in Washington in July.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
Cambodia Expels Reporter
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 20 (Reuters)Miss Sylvana Foa, a reporter for United Press International, left Phnom Penh today under a Government expulsion order. The order, which originally gave her 48 hours'notice to leave, later extended the period to week. it gave no reason for the expulsion.

title: Pilot Who Tried to Kill Lon Nol Tells Story in Peking
description: PEKING, April 20 (Reuters) A Cambodian pilot who failed in an attempt to kill President Lon Nol by bombing his residence last month told a news conference today that he escaped by flying his Americanbuilt plane to China.

title: WOMAN, 22, SHOT BY ROBBER HERE
description: A 22yearold woman was shot and critically wounded by a holdup man here yesterday afternoon, two days after she arrived from South Carolina for; an Paster holiday visit.

title: FORMER U. S. AIDE REBUTS ELLSBERG
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20 The Pentagon papers trial was told today that Daniel Ellsberg talked about the need to have the papers made public months before he set out to disclose them himself.

title: LibbyOwens Fills Posts
description: The election of Edward E. Hiett and Henry G. Husted as corporate vice presidents and of Ralph Homan as corporate controller was announced yesterday by the LibbyOwensFord Company. Mr. Hiett succeeds Ross S. Cary, while Mr. Homan replaces H. B. Ryan and Mr. Husted succeeds Richard M. Weter. All three former holders of the posts have retired.

title: Navajos Seek To Spur Arts
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz. Tramping over the Navajo Indian Reservation through snow and mud, Sam Day was talking so fast about Indian artists that the words ran together.

title: Truck Tonnage Advances
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported today that intercity truck tonnage last week was 7.4 per cent above the corresponding week of 1972. Truck tonnage was 3.6 per cent below the immediately preceding week. The A.T.A. also announced that a terminal survey of 35 metropolitan areas showed increased tonnage last week from a year ago at 28 localities with the Albuquerque region unchanged.

title: U.S. RECALLS AIDE AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 20 The Justice Department today recalled its chief negotiator from Wounded Knee for consultation as Indian tribal leaders renewed threats to drive insurgents from the village by force.

title: New Start for Ulster
description: Despite continuing intermittent violence in Northern Ireland, Britain is moving rapidly to establish a strikingly different government for the province on the basis assembly elections on June 28. Some idea of the prospects for this new effort to restore political collaboration between Ulster's Protestant and Catholic communities will be provided by local government elections to be held a month earlier.

title: Knicks Win, 9891, Lead Celtics, 2 to 1
description: BOSTON, April 20That tough game everyone had been expecting in a BostonNew York series finally turned up tonight, and the Knicks won it, 9891. The victory gave the Knicks a 21 lead in the fourofsevengame series for the right to reach the finals of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Campus Notes
description: Some students in the State University of New York with their own ideas about where and how to live at college may be in for a surprise next fall, when they find out it may be harder to move out of dormitories and into their owh offcampus housing.

title: U.S. WELFARE CODE FACES TIGHTENING
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Nixon Administration proposed today strict welfare regulations, which, if adopted, would wipe out many of the liberalized procedures adopted in the nineteensixties.

title: Screen: Gunn's 'Ganja & Hess' Opens
description: As a black-oriented, contemporary horror study, "Ganja & Hess," which arrived at the Playboy yesterday, is dedicated to what is obviously meant to be a serious theme. The artistry for which it strives, however, is largely vitiated by a confusingly vague mlange of symbolism, violence and sex.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
2 British Cooperatives Planning Big Merger
description: MANCHESTER, England, April 20 (Reuters)Directors of the Scottish and English Cooperative Trading Organizations today proposed that their two societies merge to form one organization handling 700million ($17billion) a year.

title: U.S. BIDS COURT STAY ORDER ON THE O.E.O.
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)The Nixon Administration asked a Federal District Court today to stay an order blocking the dismantling of the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: BEAME DISPUTES BIAGGI'S FITNESS
Contempt for Congress
description: In an interoffice memorandum earlier this year, Howard Phillips, acting director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, set forth his intention to dismantle the agency before Congress had a chance to stop him. Congress has not yet acted on this irregular and irresponsible assertion of power, but a court has.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A generous sampler of university drama will open at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington next Monday for a 13day run. Among the offerings will be Volpone, with the University of Virginia players: Antigone, by Gallaudet College; Dames At Sea, with six students from the Fort Wayne campus of Purdue University, and Long Day's Journey Into Night, by Fordham University players.

title: Roberta Falke Wed To Edward Rogoff
description: Miss Roberta Falke, a student at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, was married here last evening to Edward Rogoff, who is campaign manager for State Senator Harrison J. Goldin, a candidate for City Controller. Civil Court Judge Arthur Blyn performed the ceremony at Hutton's, a restaurant.

title: In Beaton's Photos, Delightful Artifice
description: There are times when a small exhibition, properly selected and discreetly installed, brings us a good deal closer to an artist's work ,than a large, extravagant show designed to hold the attention of a crowd. Such is the case, anyway, with the exhibition of photographs by Sir Cecil Beaton that has now come to the uptown Sonnabend Gallery, 924 Madison Avenue at 74th Street. Although much smaller and more narrowly focused than the mammoth show mounted at the Museum of the City of New York four years ago, the exhibition at Sonnabend leaves one with a sharper impression of Beaton's essential quality.

title: Ulster Gunfire Hits Soldier and Women Trying to Aid Him
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 20 (Reuters)Three wolinen and a soldier were shot and wounded today when a British Army patrol came under fire in Belfast.

title: Maine Acts on Shield Bill
description: AUGUSTA, Me., April 20 (AP)  On a vote of 89 to 24, the House rejected today a bill to allow newsmen to protect their confidential sources. The motion to postpone indefinitely the controversial shield law measure was made after about 10 Minutes of debate. The matter now goes back to the Senate, where a modified shield bill has been approved.

title: Gambler Gets 615 Years
description: BOSTON, April 20 (UPI)Francis A. Vitello, alleged organizer of a multimillion dollar gambling ring in Boston, was sentenced yesterday to serve a 6to15year term in state prison. He was also fined $12,000 on charges of organizing and financing an illegal gaming organization and being concerned in a lottery.

title: Soviet Trade and Soviet Jews: Exit Tax Is Only Part of the Issue
description: MOSCOW, April 20On both sides of the Atlantic events have auickened and maneuvering has intensified in the last few days on the issue of whether expansion of EastWest trade should be linked with American demands for unrestricted emigration from the Soviet Union.

title: Pioneer 10 Gear Activated
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., April 20 (UPI)  Instruments that measure solar wind and sample interplanetary cosmic rays were activated today on Pioneer 10, which is now seven million miles from earth on its journey to Jupiter.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Rose to 153.3 Last Week
5 Killed as Camper Trailer Strikes Truck in Missouri
description: NEVADA, Mo., April 20 (AP) Five persons were killed and four others injured last night when a camper trailer apparently went out of control and crashed into a tractortrailer truck 15 miles south of here on U. S. 71.

title: SOVIET SAID TO SEND 40 MIG's TO SYRIANS
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The Soviet Union has shipped about 40 MIG jet fighters to Syria since January, Pentagon sources report.

title: South Vietnam Said to Halt Thai Boat Carrying Drugs
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 20 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Navy has apprehended a Thai fishing boat carrying from two to three tons of narcotics, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Arab Oil Money Seen Flowing to the U.S.
CANADA ACQUIRES RADIO SATELLITE
description: A Canadian communications (satellite was launched from Cape Kennedy, Fla., last night to serve not only Canada but also to provide the first domestic satellite communications for the United States.

title: PAKISTAN INVITES TALKS ON P.O.W.'S
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 20  The Government invited India today to send representatives to Pakistan to discuss the exchange of prisoners and internees proposed by India and Bangladesh on Tuesday.

title: Roundup: Belanger Lifts O's to Top of the Division
Art: Vincent Smith's Expressive Style
Frozen Food Batches Recalled; Tainted Mushrooms Suspected
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Food and Drug Administration ordered today the recall from restaurants, stores and institutionsmany in the New York metropolitan areaof more than 100,000 frozen food packages containing mushrooms suspected of harboring organisms that cause botulism.

title: E.E.C. TRADE PACT IRKS NORWEGIANS
description: BRUSSELS, April 20  The European Economic Community's new trade agreement with Norway is distinctly less generous than the agreements that the bloc negotiated last year with Sweden and other members of the European Free Trade Association.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A generous sampler of university drama will open at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington next Monday for a 13day run. Among the offerings will be Volpone, with the University of Virginia players: Antigone, by Gallaudet College; Dames At Sea, with six students from the Fort Wayne campus of Purdue University, and Long bay's Journey Into Night, by Fordham University players.

title: U.S. PLANES RENEW RECONNAISSANCE OF NORTH VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The United States has resumed military reconnaissance flights over North Vietnam, despite the ban on such activity in the Vietnam ceasefire agreement, officials of the State and Defense Departments said today.

title: Liens Placed on Property Of Financier in Tax Case
description: BOSTON, April 20 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service filed liens today totalling $4,551,195 on the 500acre Brookfield estate and 38room home of the Worcester millionaire financier Edward Krock.

title: FORMER U. S. AIDE REBUTS ELLEN
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20 The Pentagon papers trial was told today that Daniel Ellsberg talked about the need to have the papers made public months before he set out to disclose them himself.

title: Next Film in TV Poll Will Discuss Poverty
description: Poverty: The Great Obstacle, the fourth in a series of six hourlong television films produced by the Regional Plan Association, will be shown 24 times over 19 television stations in the area April 28, 29 and 30.

title: Trade Bloc Seeks Sure Energy Supply
description: PARIS, April 20The European Common Market, which consumes more than 10 per cent of the energy produced in the world and itself produces only 5 per cent, is in the throes of defining policies that would assure its supplies.

title: By BabySitting for Each Other, They Watch Their Budgets, Too
description: Among the victims of inflation may be the teenage babysitter who has been nudged out of the market in some areas by economyminded babysitting cooperatives. These have been started by parents anxious to save money.

title: REPORTER OF TIMES GETS PENTAGON POST
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson announced today the appointment of William Beecher, military correspondent of The New York Times, as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: RestaurantS are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: U.S. Requests Stay Of Order Barring O.E.O. Dismantling
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)The Nixon Administration asked a Federal District Court today to stay an order blocking the dismantling of the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: The Watergate Channels
description: Senator Ervin's Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities has decided to allow hearings open the public and the news media, which can serve as an educational forum for the American people. In past hearings on war, crime and corruption, television has been a source of visual information on the function Congress as a coequal branch of the Federal Government. The hearings scheduled for May 15, under judicial guidelines established by Senator Ervin's committee, could help clear the airwithout circumvention or circusesover the Watergate investigation.

title: People and Business
description: The late Senator William H. Benton has urged in his will that his family not yield to the Wall Street son of the Pied Piper and allow the Encyclopedia Britannica to become a public corporation.

title: TELEX TIES '71 DROP IN ORDERS TO I.B.M.
description: TULSA, Okla., April 20 (AP) The order rate for the Telex Corporation's peripheral equipment increased steadily last year although orders had come to a standstill after disclosure of a new leasing plan by the International Business Machines Corporation in May, 1971, a Telex official testified today.

title: Some U.S. Officials Doubt Cambodians Face Vietnam Reds
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 20  Official American sources here said today that since the Vietnam cease  fire three months ago, there has been no documented evidence that Vietnamese Communist troops are serving in combat roles in Cambodia.

title: Englewood Youths Get Group Therapy
description: ENGLEWOOD, April 20  None of the other 11 teenagers seated on the floor around him in one of the conference rooms at St. Paul's Parish House had to be told that Bob is an angry young man.

title: Broker Sending Clients To College (for a Price)
description: OAKHURST, N.J., April 20George Mackay of Pascack Hills High School, the state's premier middledistance runner, recently ran a 1:52 halfmile shortly after signing a letter of intent with Rice University that completed negotiations for a fouryear athletic grantinaid scholarship.

title: California Schools to Shift To Metric System in 1976
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 20 (UPI)  California schools will convert to the metric system starting in 1976, the state superintendent of public instruction, Wilson Riles, said yesterday.

title: Strikes and Snow Snarl Italy's Holiday Weekend
description: ROME, April 20  A mass exodus of vacationbound Italians from the big cities, the influx of Easter pilgrims and tourists from abroad, a series of crippling strikes and unseasonable snowstorms are combining to create a chaotic holiday weekend in Italy.

title: Food Costs Pace Index in Metropolitan Area Meat Gains 5.7%
description: Food prices in the metropolitan area continued their precipitous climb in March, contributing to the biggest monthly increase in the Consumer Price Index in 21 years 1 per cent seasonally adjusted.

title: SENATOR'S WIDOW SUES SECRETARY
description: ST. LOUIS, April 20  A complex legal conflict intensified today between the widow of Senator Edward V. Long of Missouri and his longtime legal secretary and companion over disposition of his estate.

title: S.E.C. Orders Data On Effects of Laws For Environment
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Securities and Exchange Commission directed registered companies today to Include in registration and reporting forms information showing any material effects of compliance with environmentalprotection laws on their expenditures, earnings and competitive position.

title: ALONZO O. BRISCOE
description: Alonzo O. Briscoe, who retired in 1962 as a mathematics teacher at Newtown High School in Elmhurst, Queens, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, near his home at 8227 165th Street, Jamaica, Queens. His age was 81.

description: Following Is a weekly listing of the net asset value of a closedend Investment fund's shares as reported by the companies through The Association of ClosedEnd Investment Companies at the close of business Friday. Also shown Is the closing market price of each fund's share, with the percentage of difference discount, or premium. Where the stock Is traded over the counter, the market Price Is the N.A.S.D. dealertodealer asked price.

title: TWO HOSPITAL AIDES ACCUSED OF THEFT
description: The administrator of the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Hospital and a plumber working at the institution were indicted yesterday on charges of stealing $2,980 in employes funds, Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola announced.

title: Nixon Says Entire Truth Is Object of Investigation
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 20President Nixon arrived here today for the Easter holidays after a morning Cabinet meeting at which he emphasized that the objective of the Watergate investigation was to discover the entire truth of the matter.

title: Francis Analyzes Loss: Hawks Had More Goals
description: Perhaps for the first time since he charged onto the Ranger scene 10 years ago, there was a plaintive quality to Coach Emile Francis yesterday as he said:

description: April 21, 1973

title: Plea to Use DDT Denied
description: SEATTLE, April 20 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency denied today a request by the Forest Service to be allowed to use the banned pesticide DDT against a Tussock moth infestation in Oregon and Washington. The agency said that the benefits of using the pesticide do not outweigh the risks.

title: 7 U. S. Students Briefly Detained In Moscow for Protest on Jews
description: MOSCOW, April 20  Seven American students were detained for several hours by the police today after demonstrating at the Moscow visa office on behalf of Soviet Jews seeking to emigrate to Israel.

title: Revue
description: WHAT'S A NICE COUNTRY LIKE YOU DOING IN A STATE LIKE THIS? A revue. Music by Cary Hoffman; lyrics by Ira Gasman; musical direction and vocal arrangements by Arnold Gross; orchestrations by Hurbert Arnold; setting by Billy Puce; costumes by Danny Morgan; design consultant, Paul Zalon; graphic design by Joe Budne; directed and choreographed by Miriam Fond; Production stage manager and lighting by Richard Delahanty. Presented by Budd Friedman. At Upstage at Jimmy's, 33 West 52d Street.

title: Dr. Henri Rolin, Belgian Jurist Who Helped Found U.N., Dies
description: BRUSSELS, April 20 (AP) Dr. Henri Rolin, international jurist, died of a heart ailment in Paris today. His age was 81.

title: Crumb's Songs, Drones and Refrains
description: George Crumb has given musicians and listeners a number of good reasons to be grateful for his existence in the years that he has been composing, and the Evenings for New Music concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night provided yet another instance to rejoice in his talent.

title: People in Sports: Bruins Legend Moving
description: Milt Schmidt, a member of the Boston Bruins organization since 1936 as a player, coach and general manager, was named yesterday as general manager of the National Hockey League's new Washington franchise. He signed a fouryear contract. The team will begin play in October, 1974 in the 17,500seat Capital Centre Arena, under construction in suburban Largo, Md.

title: Punctured Shield
description: A compelling new reason has arisen for Representative Mario Biaggi to clear up definitively the issue of fact on whether he did or did not refuse to answer questions about his personal finances in a recent grand jury investigation of immigration matters, and whether he did did not at that time invoke his constitutional right protection against selfincrimination under the Fifth Amendment.

title: Jersey Woman Dies at 102
description: DEAL, N. J., April 20Mrs. Mary Detmer Reiss, widow of Jacob L. Reiss, an industrialist and philanthropist who died in 1955, died yesterday at her home, 59 Deal Esplanade. She was 102 years old. She leaves a son, Raymond; a daughter, Mrs. Marion Tietje; 16 grandchildren, 84 greatgrandchildren and three greatgreatgrandchildren.

title: REV. GERARD ROONEY OF PASSIONIST ORDER
description: WORCESTER, Mass., April 19The Rev. Gerard Rooney, director of the department of education of the Diocese of Worcester, died today at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Democrats Depart From Watergate; Lock Door to Past
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Democrats left the scene of the crime today. We've locked the door to the past, Mrs. Mary Lou Burg, the deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said as she officially turned the key and her back on its sixthfloor headquarters in the. Watergate, now one of the most familiar addrrsses

title: Mindless Perversion Loses Out in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, NJ., April 20 Princeton students had to start seeking new diversions today following the defeat of the Perverto slate in the election to the Undergraduate Assembly.

title: Notes on People
description: Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan said he would visit the United States for talks with President Nixon in June or July. The Premier said at a news conference in the city of Nagoya, where he was campaigning for a conservative candidate in the mayoral election, that his visit to Washington would be followed by trips to the Soviet Union in August and to Britain, France and West Germany in October. Mr. Tanaka said he would use the trips to promote his policy of multipolar diplomacy.

title: Dr. Derrick T. Vail Dies; Ophthalmologist Was 74
description: CINCINNATI, April 20Dr. Derrick T. Vail, an eye specialist and former president of the American Academy of Ophthalmology, died Wednesday in London, where he had gone for a medical meeting. He was 74 years old and lived here.

title: FULLY AND FREELY
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell appeared before a Federal grand jury today and said afterward that plans to spy on the Democrats were pressed upon him repeatedly last year.

title: Crowds at Black Parley Stir Delight and Worry
description: Each day of the National Conference of Black Social Workers the overflow crowds at workshops on nation building and on black personality are a cause of both appreciation and concern for the conference sponsors.

title: Frozen Food Batches Recalled; Tainted Mushrooms Suspected
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Food and Drug Administration ordered today the recall from restaurants, stores and institutionsmany in the New York metropolitan areaof more than 100,000 frozen food packages containing mushrooms suspected of harboring organisms that cause botulism.

title: Antiques
description: By the time Sydney N. Blumberg packed up his leech jars, bear'sgrease pots, pill tiles and mortars and retired after more than 30 years of dispensing prescriptions here, pharmacies had begun to look like supermarkets.

title: Ilegal Detention Is Alleged By Philadelphia Prisoners
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (UPI)A Federal court petition filed yesterday by two city prison inmates charged that many of Philadelphia's 2,800 prisoners were being held illegally.

title: Goodyear and Union Extend Talks Beyond Pact Deadline
description: CINCINATTI, April 20 (AP) Talks between the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers have been extended past tonight's midnight contract deadline to next Tuesday.

title: BREWERS HOMER EATS YANKS, 20
description: MILWAUKEE, April 20Despite a twohit pitching performance by Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees bowed to Milwaukee, 20, tonight in a tight pitching duel in which no New York player reached third and no Brewer got on base until the sixth inning.

title: Assemblyman, 31, Challenges Abrams
description: Robert Abrams, who was only 31 years old when he was elected Bronx Borough President in 1969 and who proudly proclaimed himself the youngest Borough President in the city's history, now has a 31yearold opponent who wants his job.

title: MRS. KING IS UPSET BY WENDY OVERTON
description: JACKSONVILLE, April 20, Fla. (AP)Wendy Overton recorded what she said was the biggest victory of her career tonight, beating Mrs. Billie Jean King, 16, 76, 76, in the $25,000 Greater Jacksonville tennis tournament.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Overnight successes and just as sudden failures have long been a fact of fashion life. Amid great applause, a collection is introduced and a few seasons later the designer's and manufacturer's name have vanished from the directories of the Seventh Avenue buildings that house the city's major fashion companies.

title: Books of The Times
description: SIXTIES GOING ON SEVENTIES. By Nora Sayre. 419 pages. Arbor House. $9.95. The first section of Nora Sayre's collection of reportage and criticism is called Exercises in Upheaval and the articles fairly clatter with the din, the shouts and alarums, the confusion of voices of the demonstrations and confrontations of the at nineteensixties. Her lead for the account of the disturbances at the Democratic Convention in Chicago begins, Such blood: released from bruised and broken veins, from foreheads, scalps and mouths, from eyesockets, shattered wrists and skulls. Violence is always peering over her shoulder and in seeking to render an account of what happened and why, she is forced to acknowledge it, or even experience it. InChicago, standing in a crowd of onlookers, she is bowled over as the police suddenly charge. Luckily she is standing behind a fat man whose flesh cushions his impact; as a policeman threatens to strike her, she feebly waves her press pass. Ooops, press, he says, moving on to another head.

description: In this country, traditional wine for most Jewish families has come to mean the sweet heavy wines made almost entirely from Concord grapes, most of which are grown in. New York State.

title: Better but Not Always Happier Lives for Canada's Native People
description: RESOLUTE, Northwest Territories, April 5Peter Lazarus Paniloo, a 35yearold Eskimo who grew up in a drafty sod house covered with snow, sat in his warm modern kitchen the other day, sipping tea and playing with his infant son.

title: Votes in Congress
G. O. P. Bribe Case Traced Back to 70
description: TRENTON, April 20The indictment of two Republican fund raisers on bribery charges yesterday by a state grand jury came nearly three years after complaints were first made to lawenforcement officials, according to sources close to the case.

title: Music: Conductor's Turn
description: Stanislaw Skrowaczewski's Concerto for English Horn and Orchestra is an uptodate example of conductor's music, socalled because nowadays when conductors compose they often turn out just this sort of expertly scored but derivative work. Mr. Skrowaczewski, music director of the Minnesota Orchestra, wrote the concerto for Thomas Stacy in 1969. Mr. Stacy was at the time English horn soloist of that group, but he joined the New York Philharmonic this season, and for his solo appearance at Philharmonic Hall on Thursday night he brought out the Skrowaczewski concerto. Aldo Ceccato was the conductor.

title: FED CLEARS RISE IN DISCOUNT RATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Federal Reserve Board approved today an increase in the discount rate from 5 per cent to 5 per cent. The increase was approved initially for seven of the 12 Federal Reserve Banks, to take effect Monday. The five other banks, judging by past experience, will shortly follow.

title: Stock Markets Closed
description: All United States and Canadian securities and commodities exchanges were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday. Banks were closed in some cities but remained open in New York, Boston, Dallas and Detroit.

title: Tennessee Floods Halt Navy Classes; Other States Hurt
description: MILLINGTON, Tenn., April 20 (UPI)Flood waters forced nearly 7,000 students and technical experts from classes at thenearby Naval Air Station today and weathermen predicted more heavy rain for western Tennessee.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
IJ .N . Council AsksW aldheim f or Report on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20The Security Council agreed today to have the Secretary General submit comprehensive report on the Middle East situation.

U.S. REPORTS PLANE MISSING IN CAMBODIA
description: HONOLULU, April 20 (UPI)  An Air Force Phantom jet was reported missing in Cambodia by the United States Pacific command today.

title: STORE SALES UP; APPAREL A SPUR
description: The resurgence of apparel, especially certain key areas of women's wear, marked a strong preEaster sales period at the big New York stores.

title: Group Worships in Family Atmosphere
description: WALDEN, N. Y., April 20 Thirtyfive members of the Loyola Christian Life Community and their families reverently, but informally, marked the 14 solemn Stations of the Cross here today on a grassy hillside under a cloudless Good Friday sky.

title: Nature of Abuses
description: A long time after swapping Manhattan for the legendary $24 worth of trinkets, American Indians are making a new hit as local traders thanks to a boom in the popularity of their jewelry and other handmade items.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The last of 15 heart patients who received the first Americandeveloped nuclearpowered pacemakers left Newark's Beth Israel Medical Center yesterday. A hospital spokesman said Irene Tocci, 20 years old of Newark, Frank Franzese, 29, of Springfield, and William Singleton, 51, of Summit were in very good condition and in very high spirits.

title: New Gas and Old Gas
description: ITHACA, N. Y.President Nixon has asked Congress to free the field price of new natural gas from controls. And no wonder. Pipeline companies have been unable to buy all the gas they need at home, and are being forced to impose rationing and reach for supplies as far as Algeria, at delivered costs something like double those of domestically purchased gas. Regulation has undoubtedly contributed to the shortage; and since I helped develop the present system, perhaps I bear some responsibility myself.

title: U.S. PLANES RENEW RECONNAISSANCE OF NORTH VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The United States has resumed military reconnaissance flights over North Vietnam, despite the ban on such activity in the Vietnam ceasefire agreement, officials of the State and Defense Departments said today.

title: Level for First Quarter Rose at Double Rate of Last Year for Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Led by another big jump in food prices, the Consumer Price Index rose last month by the largest amount for a month since the Korean War inflation of 1951, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Ice Follies of 73'
description: Cued in by sprouting Long Island buds, the Ice Follies company is back a year later, swarming all over the rink of the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum. The huge arena's first tenants will perform through April 29, and more power to them. Why? Simply because they've got what it takes on ice, and they sock it over so warmly.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: ST. LOUISSigned Wayne Stephenson, goalle, to multi year contract.

title: Picketing Charges Dropped In California Grape Strike
description: COACHELLA, Calif., April 20 (UPI)  Illegal picketing charges against more than 300 supporters and members of the United Farm Workers Union were dropped today following agreement on new rules governing picketing.

title: PAY RAISE URGED FOR LEGISLATORS
description: ALBANY, April 20 (AP) A state commission will recommend a $10,000ayear salary increase for New York's 210 lawmakers, The Albany Times Union reported today. The increase would raise the lawmakers salaries to $25,P000

title: DEAN AND PAYOFFS
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 John W. Dean 3d, the White House Counsel, supervised cash payments of more than $175,000 in Republican campaign funds to the seven Watergate defendants and their lawyers after the bugging of the Democratic headquarters in June, 1972, sources close to the case reported today.

title: The Lion
description: In every art form there are those signal talents whose influence pervades all the rest, whether acknowledged or not. In jazz piano, this was true of the late James Johnson and his contemporary, Willie The Lion Smith. The Lion's eight decades touched the world of jazz Its every chord, melody and rhythm. No one could ever play the same again after once hearing The Lion, says one of his most illustrious and grateful students, Duke Ellington. Armed with his ubiquitous black derby and cigar, The Lion rode atop American music from the start in the sportin house to the serious contribution to world culture which it has now become.

title: Top Nixon Aide Sees No Need To Return to Freeze on Prices
description: Herbert Stein, the chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, asserted here yesterday that there was no need to return to a freeze on prices.

title: G.O.P. BRIBE CASE TRACED TO 1970
description: TRENTON, April 20  The indictment of two Republican fund raisers on bribery charges yesterday by a state grand jury came nearly three years after complaints were first made to lawenforcement officials, according to sources close to the case.

title: Water at St. Croix Airport Barred as Unsafe to Drink
description: Airliners flying to St. Croix in the Virgin Islands have been forbidden to take on drinking water there because of reported high bacteria counts in the well at the island's Alexander Hamilton Airport.

title: Chryssa Sculptures With Neon Tubes
description: Of the mixedmedia artists employing light as an important element in their works, the Greek  born sculptor Chryssa, has tended to be strict constructionist and something of a hedonist. Where lightartists like Dan Flavin, say, have been more concerned with illuminating space and limiting the structural features of their works to standard lighting fixtures and white light, deployed in corners and on walls, Chryssa has been noted for largescale constructions that incorporate elements of neon tubing, usually in vivid colors.

title: Revolution By Oil And Fiat
description: TEHERANShah Mohammed Riza is convinced he has managed to impose on Iran a revolution from the top, by imperial decree, and that as a result this country has left the category of developing lands and will be at a European level in a decade. The only other Asian nation to attain this status, he says, is booming Japan.

title: New Jersey TV Network Going on Air in 6 Weeks
description: TRENTON, April 20  New Jersey, the only state of the 50 without a VHF television station, will have is own fourstation UHF network in six weeks. With the expected spread of CATV franchises throughout the state, the network could well become a viable alternative to the commercial New York and Philadelphia TV outlets.

title: Transcript of Mitchell's News Conference
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Following is a transcript of the news conference held today by former Attorney General John N. Mitchell after his appearance before a Federal grand jury investigating the Watergate Case:

title: Associates Find Goldblum Is Not Too Easy to Know
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20  Stanley Goldblum is a muscular 6foot3Inch weightlifting devotee who looks as if he could be an outside linebacker for a pro football team. But over the last dozen years, Mr. Goldblum, who never completed college, has accumulated a net worth of perhaps $25million to $30million through his position as president and board chairman of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, a gogo mutual fundinsurance sales concern that was the darling of brokerage houses until the end of last year.

title: Market Place: An Analysis of PE Data
description: Apart from the bottomline profit item in earnings statements, there is probably no figure that gets so much Wall Street attention as the PE ratiohow many times the company's annual pershare earnings you have to pay to buy the stock.

title: Yankee Records
A.H.L. PLAYOFFS
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Coast Farm Strikers Picket Here
description: As it has for the last two months, the brownstone at 331 West 84th Street came to life at 4 A.M. Amparo Vasquez, who has spent most of her 62 years getting up early to pick lettuce and onions in the California fields, was the first one to rise.

title: JETS TOP AEROS, 51, IN OPENER OF SERIES
Some Golden Rules
description: In the last few years attempts have been made to heal New York City's wounded school system. The schools were wracked by the effects of the teachers' strike of 1968, the school boycotts and student riots. Districts were blundering into decentralization. Many members of the profess sional staff, the central Board of Education and community leaders were disenchanted.

title: The Oil Cartel Will Get Us If We Don't Watch Out
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have formed a cartel whose take last year was about $16 billion. A conservative estimate for 1980 is $80 billion, $30 billion from this country alone; about $360billion cumulative in nine years.

title: Navajos Seek To Spur Arts
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz. Tramping over the Navajo Indian Reservation through snow and mud, Sam Day was talking so fast about Indian artists that the words ran together.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
Food Costs Pace Index in Metropolitan Area Meat Gains 5.7%
description: Food prices in the metropolitan area continued their precipitous climb in March, contributing to the biggest monthly increase in the Consinner Price Index in 21 years 1 per cent seasonally adjusted.

title: ExAttorney General Halted by U.S. Guard
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 When former Attorney General John N. Mitchell arrived at the Federal District Court house today for his grand jury appearance, he was faced with an unfamiliar request.

title: Syndicate Agrees to Purchase Raiders for $1.5Million
description: A syndicate has agreed to buy the New York Raiders of the World Hockey Association for about $1.5million, and the man who arranged the marriage said yesterday: Money is no object. We want to fill Madison Square Garden and erase the stench of what happened last year.

title: Concert Will Mark Founding of Council
description: Under the sponsorship of the Navajo Tribal Museum, a concert to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Navajo Tribal Council will be held July 6 in front of the Window Rock on the sprawling Navajo reservation in Arizona.

title: Some City Employes to Gain By 5.5% Pay Adjustments
description: A 5.5 per cent increase in the pay rates of city employes who are not covered by collectivebargaining contracts was announced yesterday by Harry I. Bronstein, chairman of of the City Civil Service. Commission.

title: COUGARS CONQUER COLONELS, 112107
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 20 (AP)The Carolina Cougars, led by Billy Cunningham's 30 points, came from behind in the final 3 minutes tonight and posted a 112107 victory over the Kentucky Colonels. The victory gave the Cougars a 32 lead in their fourofsevengame American Basketball Association Eastern Division playoff series.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)The Treasury Department today announced that it had started investigations of whether sulphur from Canada and papermaking machinery from Sweden were being sold in the United States at less than fair value in violation of antidumping laws.

title: Roosevelt Results
Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Egg Gauges and Russian Easter Cakes
description: The freshness of the dozens of eggs that will be cooked and colored this Easter week can now be determined by a new gadget from Switzerland.

title: College, School Results
description: College, School Results BASEBALL

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Grover Scored for Failing To Vote on Own Measure
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Common Cause, the citizens lobbying group, accused Representative James R. Grover Jr., Republican of Long Island, of contributing to the defeat yesterday of his own amendment that would have allowed cities to use highway trust funds for urban mass transit.

title: Auto Production Declines
description: DETROIT, April 20 (AP) With almost all auto plants held to fourday operations this week, car production is, scheduled to be off about 54,000 units from last week.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, April 21, 1973

title: RELAYS WILL OPEN THE SEASON TODAY
description: Manhattan, the only metropolitan school ever to win national collegiate track and field title, will try to put the competitive pieces into place again today at the 19th annual QueensIona Relays.

title: The Case Of Vinous Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  News item: The price of European wine is rising so fast that people with money to invest are no longer putting it into waterfront property and pork bellies but into Chateau DucruBeaucaillou and Chambertin Clos de Beze.

title: Martin's Father Stricken
description: BALTIMORE, April 20 (UPI)  The Detroit manager, Billy Martin, missed tonight's game between the Tigers and the Baltimore Orioles after he learned that his father suffered a heart attack earlier in the day. Martin flew to Albany, Calif., to be with his ailing father. The third base coach, Joe Schultz, managed the club.

title: Essex International Net Up
description: Essex International, Inc., reported yesterday that in the first quarter of this year it had record net earnings of $10.9million, equal to 60 cents share, an increase of 20 per cent from $8.9million, or 50 cents a share, in the 1972 period,

title: BergenBrunswig Offers To Buy Preferred Shares
description: The BergenBrunswig Corporation, diversified health prodcts and service company, is inviting tenders of 65,000 shares of its Series One $1.15 cumulative convertible voting preferred stock for $15.50 a share. The offer will expire May 31.

title: NIXON AIDE SUED IN LOBBYING DRIVE
Democrats Depart From Watergate; Lock Door to Past
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Democrats left the scene of the crime today. We've locked the door to the past, Mrs. Mary Lou Burg, the deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said as she officially turned the key and her back on its sixthfloor headquarters in the Watergate, now one of the country's most familiar addresses.

title: DEAN AND PAYOFFS
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 John W. Dean 3d, the White House Counsel, supervised cash payments of more than $175,000 in Republican campaign funds to the seven Watergate defendants and their lawyers after the bugging of the Democratic headquarters in June, 1972, sources close to the case reported. today.

title: Israeli Tactics Forcing Arab Guerrillas Underground
GOVERNOR IS SCORED ON EDUCATION PLAN
description: Representative Herman Badillo condemned yesterday as a naked power grab Governor Rockefeller's proposal to give the Governor authority to appoint half of the Board of Higher Education.

title: Orders of Durable Goods Rose 2.2% During March
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)  New orders for durable goods increased $900million, or 2.2 per cent, during March in what economists said was a good, but not a tacular, increase.

title: Dave Anderson Blowing Kisses
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16Chalked on the blackboard in their locker room is: Let us take the shortest route to the puckcarrier and arrive in ill humor. During the National Hockey League's regular season, the Philadelphia Flyers obeyed Coach Fred Shero's commandment, but ignored most of the 10 that Moses distributed. Their arrivals in ill humor provoked 1,754 minutes in penalties, a league record for lawlessness. If their assaults had occurred in the streets instead of in Clarence Campbell's rinks, the faces Dave Schultz, Bob Kelly, Andre Dupont and Don Saleski would be on post office bulletin boards. Each accumulated more than 200 minutes. Schultz, a left wing with a soft brown moustache under his hard eyes, was the most notorious. He had 259 minutes and one regret. With 33 more minutes, he would have set an N.H.L. individual record.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The head of the gravediggers union, Sam Cimaglia, said he disregarded a subpoena for his appearance before a New York State board of inquiry because several of the principal management negotiators in a labor dispute would not be present at the hearing.

title: ADAMS DRUG ADDS ANOTHER DIVISION
description: Volume Merchandise, Inc., announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its drug division to the Adams Drug Company, Inc., of Pawtucket, R.I. Volume Merchandise's drug division includes the 40store Whelan Drug Store chain and Volume's 85 per cent interest in SayOn, Inc., of New York City, whose 24 stores sell health and beauty aids. Annual sales of the Whelan and SayOn stores included in the transaction exceed $30million. Most of the 64 stores are in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Cable for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Of Superfectas and Subpoenas: Racing Investigations Continue
description: While tote hoards blinked and horses continued going to the post, racing's investigative front produced the following developments yesterday:

title: Cuban Exiles Raise $3,000 For 4 Guilty in BreakIn
description: MIAMI, April 20 (UPI)A 14man committee from Miami's Cuban exile colony has raised between $3,000 and $4,000 to aid four Miami area men who pleaded guilty to breaking into the Democratic party's headquarters in the Watergate complex in Washington last June.

title: Robin Anne Bailey, a Teacher, To Be Bride of Darrell Harvey
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., April 21Miss Robin Anne Bailey and Henry Darrell Harvey plan to be married here July 7. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bailey, parents of the prospective bride, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Harvey Jr. of Stonington.

title: HaiKyung Lee, Soprano, Makes Local Recital Debut
description: HaiKyung Lee, a young soprano from Korea, made her New York debut Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall  a rather premature appearance judging from Miss Lee's present technical limitations.

title: KINDERGARTEN RULE AROUSES BAY STATE
description: BOSTON, April 21 (AP) Some 28 Massachusetts communities, contending that they are not prepared to open kindergartens by next September, have asked the state Department of Education to extend that deadline.

title: Maryland Lacrosse Victor
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., April 21 (AP)Pat O'Meally and Bob Mitchell scored four goals each today to lead secondranked Maryland to a 234 thumping of Army in college lacrosse action.

title: If...?
