description: The best possible news for sciencefiction readers is the eagerly awaited HALL OF FAME, VOL. II, edited by Ben Bova and issued in two sections, called A and B (Doubleday, $9.95 each).

title: Court to Decide CarPolicy Case
description: TRENTONA long and complex controversy, one that has had a substantial bearing on the size of automobile insurance premiums in the state, is on the verge of final resolution.

title: Great Jones Street
description: Last year, I trapped a number of nonnovelreading friends into becoming lovers of Don DeLillo's second novel, End Zone, by telling them it was a book about football. And it was, even if the narrator did use his tremendously vivid and exhilarating firstperson descriptions of the game as a metaphor for the goodhumored acceptance of a kind of deranged, Nixonian authority, and for the blankfaced, computerized brutality that makes that authority seem perfectly reasonable to a nation obsessed by power.

title: 60YearOldRail Car to Get New Lease on Life as Part of Wantagh Musuem
description: WANTAGH, L. L.The Wantagh Preservation Society's railroad to nowhere has acquired its first piece of rolling stock.

title: Legislators Set To End Session
description: TRENTONWith the final session of the State Senate scheduled for this Thursday and the last meeting of the Assembly set for the following Monday, the New Jersey Legislature is adjourning unusually early this year. The reason, of course, is to give the legislators sufficient time in which to campaign for the primary elections on June 5.

title: NEWSMAN ON FLIGHT TO INDIANS CHARGED
description: BOSTON, April 21 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of of Investigation said today that a warrant had been issued for the arrest of a Boston Globe reporter who was aboard one of three single  engine planes that dropped supplies to militant Indians at Wounded Knee, S.D., last Tuesday.

title: Miss Laura Hertzberg Is a Bride
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 21 Miss Laura Wise Hertzberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Charles Hertzberg of White Plains, and JeanMarc Poulin of Los Angeles, son of Mrs. Georges Poulin of St. Camille, Quebec, and the late Mr. Poulin, were married here this morning at the Little Church of the West in a nondenominational ceremony.

title: The Oral Roberts empire
description: TULSA. The sound stage in the university sports center was set for the taping of another primetime television special. Prerecorded orchestral music boomed from giant unseen speakers overhead. Young girls darted about under the camera lenses holding cue cards. Pianist Roger Williams, the featured guest star, waited in the wings for his slot on the program, while onstage, members of ranking college basketball team bounced around in front of a makeshift backboard.

title: Quebec Advises That Changer le Tire Isn't How It's Said in Paris
description: MONTREAL, April 21 Battling a strong English influence from both the United States and the other Canadian provinces, the government of Quebec is using posters and pamphlets to persuade people here to speak French as it is spoken in France.

title: MRS. JAMES MILLARD
description: Mrs. Mary Orr Millard, widow of James C. B. Millard, executor and trustee of the estate of the financier Jay Gould, died Friday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. She was 78 years old and lived in Ridgefield.

title: APlant Aids Schools
description: SHOREHAM, L. LWithin the next five years, the ShorehamWading River Free School District, a looseknit group of a half dozen small communities along the wooded North Shore of Long Island in Suffolk County, may soon be vying for a rather exclusive honorthat of the richest school district in New York State.

title: A New Source of Natural Gas?
description: HACKENSACK A Federally sponsored experiment to transform coal into natural synthetic gas easily and economically is under way at a modest laboratory here.

title: Piggy Banks Blamed for Shortage of Coins in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 21A shortage of the most commonly required coin in Taiwan in recent weeks has caused general inconvenience and economic hardship for venders of inexpensive goods.

title: Amazing Frick Cuts A Cool Figure on Ice
description: UNIONDALE, L. I.  Werner Groebli is a Swiss figure skater who went wrong. He lost his reputation as a youth, changed his name in shame, and has never since consented to go out on the ice looking like a swan in a tuxedo.

title: New Concession Pacts Weighed For TavernonGreen and Shea
description: The Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration has entered preliminary discussions on awarding new concession contracts for TavernontheGreen in Central Park and the parking fields at Shea Stadium in Queens.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Signs Showing Traffic Conditions on L.I.E. Expected to Reduce Road Jams
description: ALBANYCitybound motorist on the Long Island Expressway will no longer have to sit bumpertobumper in traffic jams, fuming because they do not know what the road conditions are ahead or if they should give up on the expressway and try an alternate route.

title: India & Pakistan Breaking A Deadlock
description: NEW DELHIThe cartoon on the frontpage of a New Delhi newspaper showed a harried figure, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan, gripping a key to a box labeled IndoBangle package. Mr. Bhutto was exclaiming over the phone: How can be sure that you are not trying to pressurize me by malting this damn sensible offer?

title: YANKS, BREWERS ARE WASHED OUT
description: MILWAUKEE, April 21  It may be that as standard equipment the Brewers will have to start including for their County Stadium a helicopter along with such routine baseball park items as a batting cage, a power mower, rakes and seed.

title: ANEW UNIVERSITY RISES IN BELGIUM
description: BRUSSELS, April 21  In 1968, the Frenchlanguage faculties of the University of Louvain were given 10 years to leave town because of Belgium's bitter language conflict between the Frenchspeaking Walloons and the Dutchspeaking Flemish. Instead of moving the faculties to another city, however, it was decided to build a new university city to accommodate 18,000 students.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: TodaySt. Bernard Club of Greater New York specialty, Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, 371 Jericho Turnpike, Smithtown, L. I.; 137 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Governor and Regents Are at Odds on an Inspector General
description: ALBANY, April 21Shortly before 1 P.M. last Dec. 15, Governor Rockefeller rose from a worn leather armchair in the Red Room of the Capitol and closed his annual threehour meeting with the State Board of Regents and Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Education Commissioner.

title: Wood Memorial Chart
description: 1973, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Amy Anatole Plans Bridal
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., April 21 Mr. and Mrs. David Z. Anatole have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amy Ellen Anatole, to James L. Schwab, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schwab of Brooklyn. A June wedding is planned.

title: HORACE WOODARD, FILM MAKER, DIES
description: SAN FERNANDO, Calif., April 21 (AP)Horace Lund Woodard, a producer who won two Oscars for short documentary films in the nineteenthirties, died here yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: Justice Department Bill Asking New Code for Prosecuting ClassifiedData Leaks Stirs Wide Attack
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 The Justice Department is asking Congress to approve a new system for prosecuting persons who leak classified information, a system designed to avoid the disclosure of that information during the trial.

title: Secretariat Finishes Third as Angle Light, His Entrymate, Captures the $114,900 Wood
description: Angle Light contributed smashing upset in the $114,900 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday, finishing a head in front of Sham, who had four lengths over the highly regarded Secretariat.This colt is going into the Kentucky Derby with Secretariat, because they are both trained by Lucien Laurin. As to who will win, I can't say, but they'll run onetwo.

title: New Tools Impairing Hearing of Woodsmen
description: GENEVA, April 21  The machine age has made the life of the lumberjack easier in many ways but it has also brought new hazards to his work, according to the International Labor Organization.

title: Ellsberg and Byrne
description: LOS ANGELESWhen Daniel Ellsberg took the stand in the Pentagon papers trial he sat only a few seats from Judge Matthew Byrne. To an observer, it was a striking juxtaposition of two men of great similarities but even greater differences.

title: Do Earnings Matter to Wall St.?
description: A congregation of statisticians gathered at the New York Hilton last Thursday, and their discussion turned to the twilight of Graham & Dodd. Corporate earnings, it seemed, are not the stock market force they once were.

title: Plan for Housing Project Ruffles Small Idaho Town
description: HAILEY, Idaho, April 21This small town, situated in Idaho's scenic big Wood River Valley, was shaken last week when the man who brought the London Bridge to Arizona announced plans to build a housing development that would triple the town's population.

title: S. African Tennis Official Asks Chance for Nonwhites
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 21 (UPI)South Africa will have to send promising nonwhite tennis players on overseas trips if she is to keep faith with promises made to the rest of the world, the retiring president of the South African Lawn Tennis Union said today.

title: LowCost Road Improvements Found to Aid Safety
description: HOUSTON  A 28yearold pipefitter crashed his 1970 Ford pickup truck at 70 miles an hour into a row of steel barrels in front of a fourfoot thick concrete freeway pier here recently. But he wasn't hurt: The impact of the crash was cushioned by the 42 barrels Iined up like a row of closely packed bowling pins.

title: Merian Cooper, Creator of King Kong
description: Merian C. Cooper, the Hollywood director, producer and author who created King Kong and spent three years making a film of the 50foot ape who defied airplanes from a perch atop the Empire State Building, died yesterday of cancer in Mercy Hospital, San Diego. He was 78 years old.

title: Music
description: WHAT is to be is considerably more interesting than what was at the Metropolitan Opera. The season, which ended last, night, was an interim period. It was a season that had been largely planned by Rudolf Bing, and Goeran Gentele had been scheduled to start guiding the destinies of the house. But we all remember the terrible shock of reading about Gentele's death in an automobile accident last July. Schuyler Chapin, the assistant general manager, had to step in and run the Metropolitan Opera as acting general manager.

title: SYRIANS SAID TO GET MOROCCAN TROOPS
description: PARIS, April 21 (AP)Two Soviet warships sailed the length of the Mediterranean last week carrying a large contingent of Moroccan motorized and armored troops to be deployed against Israel on the Syrian front, the newspaper Le Monde reported today.

title: Women Bowlers Seek Share of Spotlight and Money
description: From a purely male chauvinistic point of view, one of the prettiest allAmerica teams was in town last week to promote the Bowling Proprietors' Associaiton of America Women's United States open tournament.

title: Formula 2 Race Draws Fittipaldi Among Entrants
description: THRUXTON, England, April 21 (AP)  The world auto racing champion, Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, takes a break from the Grand Prix scene here Monday in a second division Formula Two race that has attracted drivers from a dozen nations.

title: USE OF ACUPUNCTURE AS ANESTHESIA RISES
description: HONG KONG, April 21A survey from Peking of recent worldwide experience with acupuncture anesthesia said that its experimental application in many countries had produced general feeling that this new science is beginning to become a treasure shared by all.

title: Five TeenAgers Hurt in Attack On Group Near Gracie Mansion
description: Five youths were injured last nightone criticallyin an apparently unprovoked attack by a group of other youths in Carl Schurz Park on the Upper East Side, a few blocks south of Gracie Mansion.

title: VENEZUELA OPENS CUBAN CONTACTS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela April 19Venezuela is developing new relations with Cuba through personal contacts, including official exchanges.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: New &Novel
description: The real question in this highly burnished Hollywood novel is What is Carla Hart? A successful film star, beautiful, rich, clever, impulsive. A romantic. And an incipient psycho. This last grows from a nearlyinvisible blight to a galloping dysfunction that brings on some of the disasters Carla has been begging for.

title: Dorothy Thompson
description: Molder of public opinion, intimate of leaders, adviser to rulers, bundle of contradictions

title: Educators Elect Editor
description: ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP)Don Carter, executive editor of the Macon (Ga.) Telegraph and News, has been elected president of the American Council of Education for Journalism.

title: Travel Notes: Visits to Cuba
description: ACCORDING to a recent Gallup Poll, 31 per cent of United States citizens would like to visit Cuba if restrictions on travel there were lifted. Such a percentage can be projected to mean that about 42 million travelers would be willing to go.

title: Queen Elizabeth Is 47
description: WINDSOR, England, April 21 (AP)Queen Elizabeth II spent her 47th birthday quietly with her family at Windsor Castle today. In London there were two royal salutes: In Hyde Park, the Royal Horse Artillery fired 41 guns, and at the Tower of London the Honorable Artillery Company fired 62 rounds.

title: Kerr on Ghosts
description: THE low ceiling and close quarters of The Roundabout's tiny but agreeable playhouse on 26th Street combine to alter Ibsen's Ghosts in two interesting ways. By reducing the rhetorical scale, they subdue the hovering melodrama and nowandthen pompousness of the piece, turning it into an intimate, quietly wise postmortem on 19thcentury morals and mores, almost increasing the horror by the hush. And in the closeness, with all figures stage center, the secondary characters who normally hide in the shadows or stand wiping their feet on hallway rugs take on new, and quite revealing, importance.

title: Rooney, Steeler Owner, Kisses the Wrong Stone
description: PITTSBURGH (AP)Art Rooney, owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers, not only missed the unusual play that led to his team's lastgasp victory over Oakland, but he missed the Super Bowl game in Los Angeles. And Rooney was on or near the scene each time.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, APRIL 22, 1973
description: The United Nations Security Council yesterday passed a resolution condemning Israel's military attacks in Lebanon. The resolution also condemned all acts of violence which endanger or take innocent human lives, a phrase understood to refer to attacks by Palestinian terrorists in general and, in particular, to the killing of three diplomatstwo Americans and a Belgianin Khartoum, the Sudan, last month. Eleven members voted in favor of the resolution. The United States, the Soviet Union, China and Guinea abstained. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Camillo's Sound Investment
description: HILLSBOROUGH  The compact, onestory house at 121 Meadowbrook Drive is, except for its color, identical to all the small homes that line this street just off Route 206.

title: NAVY CREW WINS TRIANGULAR MEET
description: DERBY, Conn., April 21Navy's crew, building its strength and experience for coming challenges in the Adams Cup and Eastern sprint championships, beat the Coast Guard Academy and Yale here today on the Housatonic River.

title: HYDROGEN GAS RING ON SATURN HINTED
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 21Two Cornell University engineers theorize that the planet Saturn is encompassed by a giant ring of hydrogen gas atoms shaped like a slightly squashed doughnut and larger than the sun.

title: WORKERS SHARE IN PERU INDUSTRY
description: LIMA, Peru, April 20Within a few years, the 122 employes of Laboratorios Roche, a pharmaceutical concern on the outskirts of Lima, will own onehalf of their company and have a powerful voice in guiding the company's affair.

title: Cynthia Barry, R. R. Bidwell Jr. Planning Bridal
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Miss Cynthia Herndon Barry plans to be married here May 19 to Robert Reddington Bidwell Jr. of Los Angeles. The wedding will take place at St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square.

title: New Brunswick, Rutgers Get Mounties
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The city's Police Department and Rutgers University are teaming up in a research project that will bring mounted patrols to this urban center.

title: Man Slain in Playground
description: A 21yearold Brooklyn man was knifed to death yesterday in a playground next to Public School 258 in the BedfordStuyvesant section. The victim, Eugene Murphy of 1407 Fulton Street, was stabbed two times in the chest shortly before 6 P.M. The police are searching for his assailant, who fled from the playground, which is on Tompkins Avenue between Halsey and Macon Streets.

title: L.I. Women's Lib Group Screening Therapists
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.  Consciousnessraising talk groups have been used in the women's movement, in contrast to therapy, with the explanation, We're lot sick, we're oppressed. For those concerned that they might be both, a therapy referral committee has been formed here to help sort it out.

title: Pop
description: WITH the arrival of A Little Night Music (Columbia KS 32265), Stephen Sondheim, who wrote the lyrics and the music, and Harold Prince, who produced and directed it, have achieved their first thoroughly satisfying realization of a concept musical, an idea which they attempted with provocative but erratic results in Company and then fumbled badly in Follies.

title: STUDY QUESTIONS MILITARY AID DATA
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) A twoyear study concludes that much of the foreignpolicy information that the Administration is required by law to give Congress, particularly on United States military aid, is too little, too late and often incomprehensible.

title: MINNESOTA ENDS AN INDIAN DISPUTE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 21Resolving a fouryearold Indianwhite dispute that has involved court action, racial conflict and economic reprisal, the Minnesota Legislature has approved a compromise on fishing and hunting rights on the Leech Lake Indian Reservation.

title: Hair Turns Silver (Screen)
description: HOW does a Broadway producer top a show that's already pulled in over $73million? He tries to make a movie of it, which is what Micheal Butler, the man who let his Hair down on Broadway in 1968, is planning to do. Butler says that the landmark rock musical by Galt MacDermot will be one of three films he will turn out for his Michael Butler Associates. Gerome Ragni and James Rado, who were responsible for the book and lyrics of the stage show, have already begun working on the screenplay and Butler hopes to put Hair before the cameras in the spring of 1974.

title: GEORGE SOLE, 65, ARCHITECT DEAD
description: George J. Sole, an architect who was perhaps best known for his ecclesiastical buildings, died Friday of a heart ailment at the Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 65 years old and lived at 347 East 52d Street.

title: Path of Future Technology Must Be Charted, Mr. Drucker
description: Stocks

title: U.S. Swimmers Capture 8 of 12 Events to Lead 17Nation Meet in London
description: LONDON, April 21 (UPI) The brothersister combination of Rick and Lynn Colella of Seattle, Wash., lifted the United States to a 5955 lead over Australia today in an international swimming meet.

title: Development Boom in Southeast Florida Megalopolis Creates a Host of Urban Ills
description: MIAMI, April 21After a halfcentury of doing everything under the sun to advertise its natural charms, summed up in the C'mon down! promotion campaign a few years back, the state of Florida is rapidly approaching the moment when it may have to tell outsiders to Go away!

title: Corn Is So Good When Homegrown ...
description: MANY experienced gardeners consider corn to be the most worthwhile vegetable to grow in the home garden. The yield is not often great, but no other homegrown vegetable tastes so much better than its supermarket counterpart.

title: Missile Work Pushed Despite Ban in Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Defense Department is spending hundreds of millions of dollars developing missile defense systems that could not be deployed under the armscontrol treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Demand by Hayes: Trade Me
description: Fourfour forties?

title: STEIN CUP TAKEN BY HARVARD CREW
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass, April 21 Harvard's heavyweight crew defeated Brown today to win the Stein Trophy for the ninth year on the Charles River. Alan Sheahy, a sophomore, stroked for the Crimson.

title: SOUTH BEND PAPER FIGHTS NEWS CURB
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 21 The South Bend Tribune and other Indiana media will go to court next week seeking to overturn a county judge's ruling that restricts news coverage in his court.

title: Military Bases Richardson Cuts Close To Home
description: WASHINGTONNearly 20 years ago, the Defense Department and Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts, then Chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, were caught up in a political tugofwar over closing the Naval Rope Walk, an antiquated shed at the Boston Navy Yard where hawsers were made for the Navy. One of the participants in that struggle was Elliot L. Richardson, then a young assistant to Senator Saltonstall. Eventually, despite all the arguments that Mr. Richardson devised for his Sena tor, the Rope Walk was closed.

title: SHROUD OF TURIN FACING INQUIRY
description: The Shroud of Turin, venerated by some as the burial cloth of Jesus, may soon undergo an examination to determine its authenticity.

title: Two Extremes
description: IF evidence of the potential diversity of nonstraight photography were still needed, there could be none better than the exhibits of William Larson and Benno Friedman at the Light Gallery, since these two represent almost antithetical attitudinal polarities within this medium.

title: Morton Witkin, 77, Dead; ExPennsylvania Legislator
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) Morton Witkin, a former Republican state representative, died yesterday of heart failure, at the Thomas Jefferson University Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Resistant Women Are Coed Schools the Wrong Approach?
description: Just a few years ago American women's colleges appeared doomed as singlesex institutions. The trend was toward breaking tradition and enrolling men as well as women. But now the trend is dying out. Some of the most prominent women's schools have tried coeducation and have found it wanting.

title: Vicki R. Griffin, William Walters Will Wed Oct. 6
description: LINCOLN, Me., April 21Mr. and Mrs. Vaughn W. Griffin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vicki Rae Griffin, to William H. Walters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Walters of Manhasset, L.I.

title: About Woman as a Sexual Being
description: RIFE with symbols, myths and metamorphoses, the stoneware sculptures of Mary Frank, on view at the Zabriskie Gallery, 29 West 57th Street, through Saturday, form a highly individual one might as well say unique sculptural oeuvre. There is no one quite like Mrs. Frank in contemporary American sculpture.

title: Darcey Kelley Fiancee Of Richard Bockman
description: Miss Darcey Brisbane Kelley, daughter of Mrs. Brisbane Philbin of New York and the late Solon C. Kelley 3d, plans to be married on June 16 to Dr. Richard Backman, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Bockman of New York and Ellenville, N.Y.

title: Child for Mrs. Slovis
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Laurence Slovis of Bergenfield, N.J., April 10 in the Presbyterian Hospital in New York. Mrs. Slovis is the former Miss Ellen Kops Wimpfheimer of New York.

title: The Wilds Are Not For Us
description: How I envy you, a friend of ours from the city wrote recently. You're doing exactly what we've always longed to do. Actually we were doing what we thought we really wanted to do too. Now we're not so sure.

title: African Art Display Shown in Brooklyn
description: The African art exhibition of the Dogon culture at the Brooklyn museum continues a tradition of African art shows that the museum initiated many years ago.

title: POLICE PRESS HUNT FOR MISSING GIRL, 7
description: The police in Hillsdale, N. J., continued their search yesterday for a 7yearold girl who disappeared Friday while delivering Girl Scout cookies near her home.

title: Effort to Curb T. V. A. on StripMined Coal Fails
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 21 Conservationist critics of the Tennessee Valley Authority have lost an attempt in court here to curtail the Federal power agency's large purchases of stripmined Appalachian coal for its steam electric plants.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Boulder Brook, Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, N. Y. Children's and junior working hunters, Intermediate jumpers, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Australia 300 for 6 Wickets In West Indies Cricket Test
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad April 21 (Reuters)  Lance Gibbs, the 38yearold West Indies offspinner, took the wickets of Doug Walters and Greg Chappell in successive overs to keep the West Indies in the fifth and final test against the Australians today.

title: Lorraine M. Power Is Affianced
description: MASSENA, N.Y., April 21 The engagement of Miss Lorraine Marian Power to Russell C. Tharp Jr., son of Mrs. Russell C. Tharp of Gettysburg, Pa., and the late Mr. Tharp, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Power Jr.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Fur skins are in short supply, labor costs are higher and world demand for fur garments is at record levels. All this spells higher prices for furs this year.

title: The Best Hobby Best Hobby A Man Can Have
description: I T'S the best hobby a man can have, said Ernst Johne, a beekeeper, at the beginning of what turned out to be a fascinating afternoon. Mr. Johne keeps his bees in New York City, on the grounds of the Riverdale Country School in the Bronx, where he and his wife, Gerda, help with maintenance of the school buildings.

title: Widow Will Not Authorize Exhuming of Senator Long
description: CLARIKSVILLE, Mo., April 21 (UPI)The widow of Senator Edward V. Long said today that she did not plan to authorize the exhumation of her husband's body to determine if he had been poisoned.

title: Louise Blagden Fiancee
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., April 21Mrs. Augustus S. Blagden Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Louise Wall Ladew Blagden, to Caleb L. Scott of West Cornwall.

title: 18 Charged After F.B.I. Raids on Crime Figures Upstate and in Pennsylvania
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted raids against alleged underworld figures in Buffalo, Rochester and Scranton, Pa., late Friday night, resulting in charges against 18 men for interference with interstate commerce, obstruction of justice, gambling and transporting stolen property.

title: Blowing the Whistle
description: Whatever the outcome of the series to be played by the visiting Soviet Olympic champion national basketball team and a group of American players, including some participants from the disputed game at Munich, there should be some unfinished business on the agenda of the United States Olympic Committee board of directors at the meeting here next Friday and Saturday.

title: RED SOX THRIVING WITH LEAN VEALE
description: The difference between Boston Red Sox pennant and Dick O'Connell's scalp may be 40 pounds of Bob Veale.

title: Joseph L. Wood 3d Marries Miss Susan Elizabeth Mapes
description: PRINCETON, N. J. April 21 The Princeton University Chapel was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Elizabeth Mapes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Mapes of Princeton, to Joseph Leonard Wood 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood of Riverside, Conn.

title: Dr. Albert H. Cantril Is Fiance Of Miss Susan Bradford Davis
description: WILTON CENTER, N. H., April 21 Mr. and Mrs. D. Bradford Davis of Wilton Center and Wolfeboro have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Bradford Davis, to Dr. Albert H. Cantril, an independent consultant in political and social research in Washington.

title: Sports Week
description: BASEBALL

title: DOBERMAN BEST AT RESTON PARK
description: RESTON, Va.; April 21A sleek black and tan Doberman pinscher, Ch. Galaxy's Corry Carina, from Glen Cove, L. I., was best of 3,022 dogs in Reston Park today at the largest outdoor event this year in the East, the 60th show of the Old Dominion Kennel Club.

title: REMESHWAR DAS BIRLA
description: BOMBAY, India, April 21 (AP)Remeshwar Das Birla, a wealthy textile manufacturer, died of a heart attack today, two weeks before his 81st birthday.

title: 10 WILL BE HONORED FOR LIFE OF SCIENCE
description: The National Academy of Sciences will award gold medals and cash prizes of up to $5,000 to 10 scientists at a dinner in Washington, D. C., tomorrow night.

title: Harvard and Radcliffe Mail Acceptances for New Class
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 21 (AP)  Harvard and Radcliffe Colleges mailed acceptances today to 2,098 of 10,742 applicants to next fall's freshman class.

title: Troubled Discount Chains
description: The discount revolution, which changed the nature, tempo and promotional beat of retailing, is running into its severest snag in more than a quartercentury.

title: News of the Rialto
description: WHAT Broadway dreams of are those memorable opening night's that make it all seem worthwhile. One of these occurred back in 1959 when A Raisin in the Sun, by black playwright Lorraine Hansberry, stirred its audience to a standing ovation at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. Subsequently, Raisin won Miss Hansberry the Critics Circle prize for the best play of the season, ran 530 performances, was turned into a film which became a New York Film Critics nominee for the best motion picture and screenplay award, and carried off the Cannes Film Festival prize. Now Raisin is about to complete the circle by returning to Broadway as musical.

title: MORE SOVIET JEWS QUITTING ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, April 21  A growing number of Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union have been emigrating from reel or leaving their transport on the way to Israel to seek new homes in North America or Western Europe.

title: Dedication Ceremonies Are Held for the First Commercial TV Station on L.I.
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I. Dedication ceremonies were held recently at the construction site of Long Island's first commercial television station, WSNLTV (Channel 67) here. The station will begin operation in the fall.

title: Pro Arte Chorale Sings Bach's St. John Passion
description: The Passion According to St. John is the closest Bach ever came to opera, in that the story of Jesus' last days is told with compact, cumulatively intense theatricality. It was, unfortunately, just this central aspect of the work that suffered in the performance offered Friday night at Philharmonic Hall by the Pro Arte Chorale, conducted by John Nelson.

title: Rutgers Alumni Seek Stronger Athletics
description: Rutgers has been without a varsity basketball coach for more than a month. The university's football coach, Frank Burns, and director of athletics, Fred Gruninger, are serving under oneyear interim agreements.

title: COURT TO GET PLEA ON G.O.P.'S RECORDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Common Cause plans to ask the Federal District Court Monday to force production of missing Republican financial records within 72 hours.

title: Patricia A. Coletti, Teacher, to Marry
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I. April 21Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Jeff J. Coletti of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Coletti, to Dennis William Livesey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley B. Livesey of Wyckoff, N.J.

title: Robert Armstrong, Actor, Dies; Played Director in King Kong
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 21 (AP)Robert Armstrong, the actor who brought King Kong back alive from his prehistoric island habitat, died yesterday at a hospital after a short illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Cashing Tickets Wasn't Enough for Secretariat's Backers
description: Moments after Secretariat's defeat in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday, Mrs. John (Penny) Tweedy turned to Lucien Laurin with a look of disbelief on her face.

title: Meanwhile, Back in the United States
description: Are there any programs in the United States similar to Canada's, programs that encourage young people to travel in their own country? A survey of the Interior, Commerce and Transportation Departments indicates that, with a few minor exceptions, the answer is no. The Department of Commerce does maintain a United States Travel Service, which spends about $9million a year to attract foreign visitors to this country, but Congress has refused to let it expand to promote travel within America by Americans.

title: Agnew Urged by Advisers To Repudiate Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Advisers of Vice President Agnew are urging him to disassociate himself from the Watergate affair in the most direct kind of way to avoid what they see as a harmful political impact reaching to the 1976 Presidential election.

title: Watergate: After All, Who's in Charge Here?
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.The words come hard for one who has supported Richard Nixon and his Administration, but they must be said: Watergate is the President's Becket and like Henry II he cannot escape the full brunt of responsibility for the actions of his subordinates.

title: David E. Spray to Wed Miss Weller
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Dr. and Mrs. George Louis Weller Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Elizabeth Weller, to David E. Spray of Middleburg, Va., and Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Spray of Chicago.

title: Skaggs, Sturm of Eagles Retire
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP)Jim Skaggs, Philadelphia Eagles' guard, and Jerry Sturm, center, retired today. Wayne Mass, guard, was placed on waivers.

title: Looking ahead to fall
description: In the circus that is readytowear week in Paris, 55,000 fashion people from all over the world came to laugh, be entertainedand spot new trends. The styles that may become next winter's trends or merely remain gags run from minis to maxis.

title: Brown Routed in Lacrosse
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 21 (AP)  Unbeaten Johns Hopkins, the nation's topranked lacrosse power, rolled to an 187 victory over Brown today in handing the Bruins their first loss before 6,000 fans.

title: MANSFIELD ADVICE ON WAR REVEALED
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, secretly advised two Presidents in the nineteensixties to restrain, rather than extend, United States involvement in the Vietnam war.

title: 3 Children Die in Freezer
description: IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, April 21 (AP)A mother found two of her children and a playmate dead of suffocation when she opened the door of an abandoned freezer this week, the authorities said. Ralph Nixon, a police officer, said that Mrs. David McCamas had gone looking for her children when they failed to return home. The three victims were identified as Preston Outcelt, 5 years old, and Todd, 6, and Michelle, 4, children of Mr. and Mrs. McCamas.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United Nations Security Council yesterday passed a resolution condemning Israel's military attacks in Lebanon. The resolution also condemned all acts of violence which endanger or take innocent human lives, a phrase understood to refer to attacks by Palestinian terrorists in general and, in particular, to the killing of three diplomatstwo Americans and a Belgianin Khartoum, the Sudan, last month. Eleven members voted in favor of the resolution. The United States, the Soviet Union, China and Guinea abstained. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Eating Dog Is Debated In Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 21Eating dog has been common enough in Taiwan, especially among Chinese of Cantonese origin, that a leading medical institute once had to appeal to the public to reduce consumption because of a serious shortage of animals for research.

title: Secretariat Runs 3d
description: Highly regarded Secretariat finished third in the $114,900 Wood at Aqueduct yesterday as Angle Light, his entrymate, won and Sham was second. The entry paid $2.60 for $2 to win. Details in Section Five.

title: Kenya Names Air Chief
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 21 (Agence FrancePresse)Col. D. M. Gichuru of Kenya has been named commander of the air force, taking over from the British Royal Air Force, which has operated the Kenyan Air Force since the nation became independent in 1963.

title: Football Giants' Front Office Adds Gleason and Walsh
description: The New York Giants have announced two appointments to the fobtball team's front office.

title: Joanne Cole Engaged To David M. Friedman
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 21The engagement of Miss Joanne Mary Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin A. Cole, to David Mark Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack G. Friedman of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

title: Music Mailbag
description: THE TIMES opened an issue of special interest to me with Harris Green's article, If You Want Them to Love the Classics. .. . No one can argue with his basic premises:

title: U.S. Grain Dealers Agree to Report Sales Volume
description: WASHINGTON, April 21. (UPI)  Private grain traders in the United States, criticized last year for secrecy in big sales to Russia, have agreed to disclose their 1973 sales volume.

title: Pittsburgh Aides Fear Shortage of Fuel
description: PITTSBURGH, April 21 Municipal and transit officials in the Pittsburgh district displayed concern this week over the possibility that they might be without adequate fuel supplies because of the energy crisis.

title: Death Penalty Connecticut Legislature Votes Yes
description: HARTFORDThe debate last Thursday was more passionate than any in the memory of the Senators. History and the Scriptures were invoked by both sides. Some Senators appeared to be still making up their minds as the clerk began the final roll call. But in the end, the measure to restore the death penalty passed in the Connecticut Senate, 19 to 17.

title: WAGE PANEL FORMED IN HEALTH INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)The Cost of Living Council announced formation yesterday of a health industry wage and salary committee for Phase 3 similar to one already appointed for the food industry.

title: Susan L. Smith, David Little 3d Plan Marriage
description: Mrs. Burnham Smith of New Canaan, Conn., and Harry Lee Smith Jr. of New York have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Lee Smith, to David Mason Little 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Little Jr. of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Bombs in Australia Damage Parliament, Cause Blackout
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sunday, April 22 (Reuters) Two bombs exploded here early today. One slightly damaged Parliament House, and the other planted in an electricity transformer, black out part of the Australian capital.

title: CostaGavras: I'm Not AntiAmerican
description: HE SITS there in an easy chair in of all places, a grand Pierre Hotel suite, barely moving during a threehour conversation. He is handsomely haggard, totally exhausted, and looks as though he hasn't slept for weeksperhaps because of the state of siege between himself and the American Film Institute. His only necktie (navy blue) has been shed somewhere, and he is wearing a rumpled navy and white checked shirt and the trousers of a new gray wool suit his wife insisted he buy for this trip to America. Deep lines crease his forehead. His blue eyes are bloodshot; his thick black hair in need of a comb. He rarely smiles. In fact, he is as serious and intense as his last three films: Z, The Confession, and now, the highly acclaimed State of Siege.

title: Bank Robbers They Ain't What They Used to Be
description: In some ways the attempted holdup of The Chase Manhattan Bank at Fifth Avenue and 135th Street last week was quite traditional and oldfashioned. There was Mace Brown, for exampleone of the F.B.I.'s 10 Most Wanted. In a timetested fashion, he was cut down by a hail of bullets from the police, shot dead on the sidewalk trying to escape. Inside the bank, Brown's two accomplices responded in the accepted manner: they herded together 32 customers, 10 bank employes, had them sit on the floor the way hostages are supposed to.

title: They Also Serve Who Wait, Hope and Sew While Offspring Slam
description: From 9 o'clock in the morning to well past midnight they were trading forehands, backhands and volleys, and it was hard to tell whether the tension was greater on the courts or on the sidelines at the Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament here.

title: Conflicts Over Energy
description: Only front the lofty heights of retrospect is it possible to view the true topography of historical transition and to know the actual depths of crisis, the realities from the mirages, the roads better taken. This limitation is nowhere better illustrated than in man's groping attempts to deal with the socalled crisis.

title: Rock Music
description: Slade, headlining the Friday show at the Academy of Music on 14th Street, is obviously a group on the way up. Grin, the group that Opened the evening, had to suffer heckling from Slade enthusiasts impatiently waiting for the British group to appear. And the members of Grin, competent enough, were unable to bear it, even when they turned up their energy in an attempt to Novocain the audience into submission.

title: 5 Miles By Canoe: A Hectic Journey
description: LYNDHURSTIt was not exactly like the film Deliverance, but it was a reasonably passable adaptation of it: A day roughing it among the waters and rushes of the Hackensack Meadowlands, with canoes and canoeists being shot at.

title: Some Design Do's and Don'ts
description: GROWING plants well is horticulture; arranging them well in the landscape is design, But landscape design is not plants alone, since modelled earth forms and construction items are usually included.

title: One Composer at A Time Lovingly
description: IT'S only love that makes it possible. The statement could have sounded banal, but it didn't. It was made by Cheryl Seltzer, who with Joel Sachs keeps the Performers' Committee for TwentiethCentury Music alive. The love, according to Miss Seltzer, was to be found in all the performers and administrative helpers who give their services for nothing or for minimal fees to put on an exceptionally valuable series of composers' restrospectives at Columbia University's McMillin Theater each season. On Thursday, for the first time, the organization will move downtown to Tully Hall for a special memorial program honoring Stefan Wolpe, who died last year.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: Judge Bans SnakeHandling By Church in Tennessee
description: NEWPORT, Tenn., April 21 (AP)A circuit court judge today ordered members of a fundamentalist church to stop handling poisonous snake at worship services but refused to issue a ban on drinking strychnine.

title: Doctors Study Drivers' Stress Under Race Conditions
description: Occasionally in a stock car race a few drivers play tag with one another at 150 miles an hour just for fun. They are equally cool under stress and even in crashes. How poised they are can be measured under racing conditions.

title: Headliners
description: Once a man of national prominence for his report on urban violence, twice Governor of Illinois, now a judge in the United States Court of Appeals, Otto Kerner was sentenced last week by another Federal judge to three years in prison and a fine of $50,000. A jury declared Kerner, 64, guilty of bribery, perjury, conspiracy, mail fraud and income tax evasion in connection with the secret purchase and sale, while he was Governor, of stock in a Chicago horseracing association. In return for the stock deal, Kerner was found to have influenced legislation and racing dates favorable to the association. Receiving the same sentence and fine was Theodore J. Isaacs, formerly Kerner's state revenue director. Both earned profits of $300,000 and paid no taxes. Protesting his innocence, as he had throughout his trial, Kerner told the judge, My real punishment has already been inflicted. [The jury's] verdict has already deeply tarnished my reputation and good name. Both Kerner and Isaacs are expected to appeal.

title: Clare Boothe Luce, she who is behind The Women
description: The Women, a comedy of haute bitchery, opened on Broadway in 1936. Nobody loved it but the people. It was an acid portrait (feline, the critics said) of a group of rich, monumentally nasty women, with minor sketches of some goodhearted prolescooks, nannies, hatcheck girlswho were distinguished largely by bad grammar. On the strength of almost no critical acclaim whatever, played 637 performances, was translated into 12 languages and was performed in 25 countries, and much of this happened before the film version came along in 1939, starring Joan Crawford, Rosalind Russell, Norma Shearer, Paulette Goddard and other angels of malice.

title: Rangers' Problem Easy To Find: In Hawks' Goal
description: Instead of playing today, which is what the Rangers and Chicago Black Hawks really want to do, the clubs will stage another workout as they prepare for Tuesday night's game which could end their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: VETERANS' OFFICE IS SET UP BY CITY
description: Mayor Lindsay announced the appointment yesterday of Maj. Carl M. A. McCarden, a West Point professor, as head of a new multiservice Office of Veteran Action to consolidate and expand the city's assistance to returned servicemen.

title: Rome: Voice of La Streisand Heard in Land of Verdi
description: ROMETurn on your transistor radio here any time, and you are most likely to hear some Italian imitator of Barbra Streisand or impressions of Elvis Presley or Joan Baezunless you are treated to a recording of the real La Streisand.

title: Phillies Triumph Over Cards, 74, by Scoring Four Runs in First Inning
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (UPI)  Bob Boone singled home two runs today to spark a fourrun first inning and the Philadelphia Phillies held on for a 7.4 victory over the St, Louis Cardinals.

title: U. S. JUDGE RULES ON 86 SEIZED IN '86
description: A Federal judge here has ruled that a city judge should expunge all the remaining records of charges made more than six years ago against 86 young men and women arrested at a leftist gathering on the Upper West Side.

title: Woman Jockey Triumphs After a Prolonged Illness
description: KEMPTON PARK, England, April 21 (AP)Linda Goodwill, who lay flat on her back for seven months with tuberculosis of the spine and was told she would never ride a horse again, won the first race of the year for women jockeys today.

title: ALL CUBAN STATIONS BAR U.S. POP MUSIC
description: HAVANA, April 21 (Reuters) All Cuban radio stations have banned records by American and British pop and folk singers in an apparent move to make young Cuban listeners develop a greater taste for Cuban music and Latin American and Spanish music. But other modern pap music and ballads are tolerated provided the lyrics are in Spanish.

title: AUSTRALIA LEADS IN DAVIS CUP, 20
description: TOKYO, April 21 (AP)Australia's Davis Cup tennis team, led by John Newcombe and Mal Anderson, took a 20 lead over. Japan today in the Eastern Zone Section B semifinals.

title: Americans for Palestine On March in Lebanon
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, April 21 (UPI)More than 100 American residents of Lebanon concluded a 25mile Easter peace march in support of the Palestinian movement today and were greeted by thousands of Arabs shouting for ArabAmerican friendship.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  To the surprise of many people here, President Nixon's lengthy and manysided message on the energy problem last week scarcely mentioned the term balance of payments and did not mention the word Arab at all.

title: Motorcycle Fatalities Up
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 21 (UPI)Auto fatalities declined slightly in California in recent years, but there was a sharp increase in fatal accidents involving bicycle and motorcycle riders. The Highway Patrol commissioner, Walter Pudinski, reported that there were 4,426 traffic victims in California last year, one fewer than in 1969. But the number of motorcycle riders killed increased from 394 to 596 during the fouryear period, and bicycle fatalities jumped from 66 to 129.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL CONDEMNS ISRAEL ON LEBANON RAIDS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21The Security Council today passed a resolution condemning Israel's military attacks in Lebanon.

title: 9 Chinese Going to Ottawa, Opening Student Exchange
description: PEKING, April 21  Nine Chinese students plan to leave Peking next week to study English at Carleton University lin Ottawa. They will be the first students sent to Canada by China under a new exchange program.

title: Stephen A. Douglas
description: There stands Abraham Lincoln, the Presidentelect, fumbling awkwardly with his hat as he is about to be inaugurated in 1861. And near him, sharing the platform but not the honor, sits his defeated rival, Stephen A. Douglas, who graciously takes the hat and holds it during the ceremony.

title: WATERGATE JURY BELIEVED SEEKING A HALDEMAN LINK
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 A Federal grand jury is investigating H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, to determine whether his office had a role in the initial Watergate bugging operation and any subsequent attempt to obstruct the inquiry into the case, sources close to the case said today.

title: Let's Hair It for Gerald Freedman!
description: WHY is it always raining on Gerald Freedman's parade? In these days of star directors, can't he have his place in the sun too? But there he was, last month, at the openingnight party for his latest effortGinastera's Beatrix Cenci at the City Operawhen a woman who should have known better marched up and asked him, Where have you been?

title: BREWERS' HOMER BEATS YANKS, 20
description: MILWAUKEE, April 20Despite a twohit pitching performica by Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees bowed to Milwaukee, 20, tonight in a tight pitching duel in which no New York player reached third and no Brewer got on base until the sixth inning.

title: Carmen: She Fascinates
description: DEUTSCHE GRAMMOPHON has a lot riding on its studio recording of the Metropolitan Opera's 1972 opening night Carmen (2709 043, three disks)  a production cost running well into six figures to be inexact (DG, like all record companies, is coyly reluctant to divulge such classified information): Recording economics being what they are in America nowadays, this Carmen is very likely the most expensively produced threedisk set ever to reach the market and represents DG's most ambitious bid yet for international prestige, a costly quest that has led the company over the past five years to tape Mozart in Prague, Handel in London, Renaissance cantigas in Spain and American orchestras in Boston San Francisco, and now New York.

title: QE2, With Lights Out, Docks Safely in Israel
description: ASHDOD, Israel, April 21 (Reuters)The Queen Elizabeth 2 arrived in Israel today after having extinguished her outside lights and blackened out her portholes on the final 100 miles of her journey as an added security precaution against possible Arab guerrilla attacks.

title: Barry Spector Fiance Of Shelley Bergman
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., April 21 Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Bergman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shelley Ruth Bergman, to Barry Stewart Spector. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Spector of Yonkers and Long Beach Island, N. J.

title: L.I. Sound Bridge The House Delivers a Harsh Blow
description: Like some kind of tenacious sea monster, the idea of building a new bridge over Long Island Sound has refused to let go, despite a series of rough legal, administrative and legislative blows.

title: Oil Flows in New Pipeline From Siberia to Europe
description: MOSCOW, April 21The Soviet Union began pumping oil today into a new 1,250mile pipeline in western Siberia that will soon help increase the flow of Soviet oil to Eastern Europe.

title: What for Tomorrow's Lamps?
description: What we are doing is shifting from the age of oil to another energy age, an oil industry spokesman said the other day. Historically speaking, transition periods are very interesting but living through them may not be so much fun.

title: Annelyse Fiaux Will Be Bride
description: Miss Annelyse Fiaux and Frederick H. S. Allen, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, plan to be married June 22 in Brueil, France.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, April 21  Four protest bombs and a 21gun salute heralded today the anniversary of the military coup that terminated constitutional rule in Greece six years ago.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX rose 0.8 per cent in March, from the February level, to 129,8 per cent of the 1967 base period.... The gross national product rose 14.3 per cent In the first quarter to an annual rate of $1,236billion. This was the sharpest rise in two years, with inflation accounting for 6 per cent of the total.

title: National Council of Churches Trims Its Unit for Social Action
description: The executive staff of the Division of Church and Society of the National Council of Churches was reduced almost by half last week and $80,000 was cut from its $500,000 budget.

title: Drew Offers Adults Summer Seminars in Sylvan Setting
description: MADISON Travel broadens the mind, they say. And so does a week or two of lively deepthink in a lovely forest right in New Jersey, says Drew University.

title: DART GUNS ARE USED AGAINST STRAY DOGS
description: The police are experimenting with tranquilizer dart guns to control the packs of wild or stray dogs that roam the streets of Brooklyn's slum areas terrorizing residents.

title: Taps Sounds for St. Albans Hospital
description: After 30 years of saving lives, St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens last week became a terminal case.

title: LEON J. MOHN Jr.
description: Leon J. Mohn Jr., a divisional sales manager of J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., textile manufacturer, died yesterday at the Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 51 years old and lived in Westport, Conn., and Hampton Bays, L. I.

title: Nixon Does Routine Work In Florida With His Family
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 21 (AP)President Nixon tended to routine business on Easter weekend with his family and signed a bill today giving members of Peking's Washington liaison office full diplomatic privileges.

title: Thomas Sperry, 75, Dead; Real Estate Operator Here
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., April 21  Thomas A. Sperry, for many years a realestate operator in New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 75 years old.

title: 5 Sign Cosmos' Pacts
description: Jorge Siega, an AllStar forward, and four other players signed contracts yesterday for the 1973 North American Soccer League season, the defending champion New York Cosmos announced. Also signed were Dieter Zajdel and Roby Young and a pair of newcomers, Karol Rotner of Israel and Tibby Vigh of Canada.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: L[ARRY] COLE: OUR CHILDREN'S KEEPERS  Kids place so little blame for their pains on the society that inflicts them; they want ... to believe that the adult world is worth growing into, ... to believe that adults ... really care. For this wish, kids are willing to stretch reality.

title: A monstrous story, retold without surprises
description: Is there a legitimate market for a professionally written, carefully checked and otherwise competent biography of someone as notorious as Adolf Hitler that exploits established sources and will not cause anyone to change his view of the subject, or anyhow not much? If so, then there is a good case for Robert Payne, for he is a manufacturer of standardized biographies of very good quality. He is also an eclectic workmanhis previous volumes have been on Lenin, Stalin, Mao, Marx, Malraux and Gandhi, among others. Combining these with Hitler shows lot of reach.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: April 26New York Region, Sports Car Club of America meeting at Dragon Seed Restaurant, 37th and Junction Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens, 8 P.M. Information; Peter Mole: phone (212)5359337, evenings, (212)2241010 day.

title: U.S. and Soviet Draft Pact To Protect Migratory Birds
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are drafting a treaty for the protection of migratory birds and also will institute several other cooperative wildlife programs, Spencer Smith, director of the Department of Interior's Fish and Wildlife Service, announced yesterday.

title: Theodore Beckman, Economist Who Taught at Ohio State, Dies
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 21 (AP)  Theodore N. Beckman, a noted economist and former Ohio State University professor, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: Concert for VoiceLovers
description: For most of Friday night's Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center program at Tully Hall, Eileen Farrell and Beverly Sills held forth. There was one little break, in the form of Mozart's Clarinet Trio (K. 498); otherwise the two great ladies were heard in solo and ensemble.

title: 2 CEPEDA HOMERS HELP RED SOX WIN
description: CLEVELAND, April 21 (UPI) The designated hitter, Orlando Cepeda, drove in four runs with a pair of homers and Rico Petrocelli and Tommy Harper also hit home runs tonight as the Boston Red Sox broke a sixgame losing streak by defeating the Cleveland Indians, 115.

title: Bushwick to Pick Its First Local School Board
description: Residents of the Bushwick section of Brooklyn are scheduled to elect their own community school board on May 1 as the result of the recent creation of a new school districtDistrict 32for that area.

title: Got $190,000? It Will Buy Cheapest Floor at No. 733
description: To adapt a celebrated saying, if you have to ask the price of a cooperative apartment, you probably can't afford one at 733 Park Avenue.

title: Art Mailbag
description: READING John Canaday's April 1 discussion of the Metropolitan Museum admissions policy, I found myself in agreement on principle, but I'd like to suggest a different form of protest, rather than his strategy of paying only a penny.

title: Lindsay Signs Bill Delaying Submitting Expense Budget
description: A bill that delays by a month the deadlines for submission of the city's annual expense budget and for holding hearings on it was signed into law yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: When the Ax Falls
description: Although the blow had been widely anticipated, when the economy ax finally fell last week on 274 military bases in thirty states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico, cries of outraged injury reverberated across the country, even from some of the most vociferous proponents of defense economy.

title: For Dunellen, Status Quo Is Just Fine
description: DUNELLENFor the 7,800 residents of this borough at the northwestern tip of Middlesex County, the biggest event in ages took place last Thursday. Twicein the morning and again in the afternoonofficials of the New Jersey State Lottery Commission held drawings to select weekly and daily winners. It was a time for celebrating in town, and a picnic atmosphere prevailed. More important, however, the lottery drawing convinced the people of Dunellen that they were participating in an activity that would attract attention to them, something most of them feel has been lacking.

title: Haight Street: Six Blocks In Search of a New Identity
description: SAN FRANCISCOOn one of the street signs near Golden Gate Park the name of the street has been has vanished. The storekeepers and families there now want stability. blocked out with white paint. In its place the word LUV has been carefully inscribed in green letters with gold borders, The word is appropriate. Luv is what hordes of people came to this street hoping to find, and Luv was the cry of the hippie movement, which was born here in the nineteensixties. If you look closely, you can still see the dark outline of the name that was covered up on the street sign. It reads HAIGHT.

title: Judi Goldberg Fiancee of Michael Gur
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., April 21Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Goldberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judi Bea Goldberg to Michael Gur, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moshe Gur of Ramat Gan, Israel.

title: The Relevance of Apples
description: TWO exhibitions may not be enough to prove a trend, but I suspect that a basic similarity between a pair of otherwise quite different ones, the Brooklyn Museum's African Art of the Dogon and the Metropolitan's Gold, is more than coincidental. It is symptomatic of a change in what serious museum people (as opposed to showmen) want to tell the public about art, and it is fortunately square on the target of what the public is ready for. To these two shows let's add a third as a kind of auxiliary supporting argument  A Flower from Every Meadow, the utterly delightful exhibition of Indian paintings at Asia House.

title: Clarence Townsley Marries Anne Reid
description: TOWSON, Md., April 21  Miss Anne Wellington Reid, daughter of Harry Fairfax Reid Jr. of Westfield, N. J., and the late Mrs. Reid, was married here this afternoon to Clarence Edward Townsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Townsley of Upperco. The Rev. Dr. Clark W. Hunt performed the ceremony in the Towson Methodist Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. John Bayley Jones.

title: 58 Million Check to UNICEF
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21A check for $8,050,000 has been presented to the United Nations Children's Fund by the United States Committee for UNICEF. The committee raised the money in doortodoor collections by 3.6 million youngsters, at Halloween from the sale of greeting cards and by private donations.

title: Pro Soccer League Opens Season May
description: The Chiefs are dead and so are the Gatos, but alive and kicking are the Apollos, the Toros and the Atoms, the newest offspring of the North American Soccer League, which kicks off its season May 5 with games in Dallas, Miami and St. Louis.

title: For Easter: An Egg Tree
description: In observance of Easter, the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences and the Bloomfield Public Library are featuring special exhibits of intricately colored Easter eggs.

title: COLUMBIA CHOOSES M'CANN AND DARCY
description: Peter McCann and Bob Darcy, two of the major reasons for Columbia's resurgent swimming fortunes, have been elected co captains for the 197374 season. They succeed Lyle Rexer, a senior from Bay City, Mich

title: Growth of Arbitration Appears To Point to Era of Labor Peace
description: WASHINGTON, April 21A quiet but profound and perhaps permanent change is taking place in labormanagement relations in this country.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONDuring March, Government reports disclosed last week, American consumers experienced the worst rate of inflation in nearly a quarter centurya major worsening of an illness that had shown distinct improvement in 1971 and 1972.

title: Service Aids Isolated
description: Isolation at home is a regular fear of the handicapped and the disabled. But the Easter Seal Society is seeking to ease the concern with its home service. Through it, the homebound are treated to fall art shows, birthday parties and beach outings annually, and to more frequent visits and social gatherings. Various publications also are provided. Help Easter Seals keep the homebound in touch. Donations for the annual campaign ending today may be made to the Easter Seal Society, 185 Madison Avenue, New York City, N. Y. 10016.

title: U.S & Israel Anatomy of An Unusual Alliance
description: The debate in the United Nations Security Council last week followed familiar pattern. The Arab delegates and their friends called for sanctions against Israel, including the cutting off of all arms deliveries, as punishment for the spectacular Israeli raid of the previous week against the Palestinian terrorist headquarters in Beirut. Other delegates, though not going that far, denounced the Israeli use of force in violation of international law and Lebanon's sovereignty. The American delegate stoutly opposed any onesided resolution. A BritishFrench motion condemning the Israeli raid was passed, 110. The United States, which had considered vetoing the resolution, abstained.

title: A CAUTION FLAG DROPPED BY FOYT
description: CHICAGO, April 21 (UPI)A. J. Foyt, who will try on May 28 to become the first driver to win the Indianapolis 500mile race a fourth time, sounded a warning this week for the field that will start the $1million spectacle.

title: DEB MARION WINS PIMLICO STAKES
description: BALTIMORE, April 21Deb Marion, the only 3yearold in the field of 11 fillies and mares, won the $33,950 Gallorette Handycap at Pimlico Race Course today for her second successive stakes victory on the turf.

title: Interpretations and Forecasts: 19221972
description: This collection begins with one of those almost obligatory paragraphs in which the author expresses his trust that the book will not be a mere melange or anthology. For once, the trust is fulfilled. Selecting 41 essays written over a span of almost 50 years, Lewis Mumford (winner of the 1972 National Medal of Literature, manages to create something like a genuine book. Of course, as is inevitable in any collection of unrevised essays, there is much here that is repetitive and outdated. But book reviews, lectures, scholarly essays, notes, prophecies  all take on a fundamental coherence: the coherence of Mumford's special vision.

title: FRENCH CHURCH ASKS ANTISEMITISM'S END
description: PARIS, April 21 (AP)The Roman Catholic Church of France has issued a document urging an end to antiSemitism and indirectly approving of the creation of the state of Israel.

title: Mailbox: Ad Didn't Change South African Racism
description: To The Editor:

title: U.S. Unit Is Fixing Its Image
description: The United States Olympic Committee has contrasting images that it must correct before it can count on a successful return to the Games at Montreal in 1976, insists the former top administrator now saddled with that important job.

title: Boston U. Picks Fletcher
description: BOSTON, April 21 (AP)Tom Fletcher, a defensive secondary coach for the New England Patriots of the National Football the last two years, was named assistant head coach today at Boston University. Paul Kemp, recently appointed head coach, said that Fletcher would serve as defensive coordinator.

title: Watergate Fails to Stir the Europeans
description: PARIS, April 21 Watergate is not a household word in Europe, at least not yet. Until reports this week that President Nixon had cleared the way for full investigations, only Americans abroad and a few journalists and politicians had been paying any attention.

title: The Merry Month of May
description: Actually, the cranberry didn't do too badly two weeks ago in this space, handicapping the National Book Awards. We guessed correctly on A. R. Ammons (poetry), Frances Fitz Gerald (contemporary affairs), James Flexner (biography), Arthur M. Wilson (arts and letters), George B. Schaller (sciences) and Robert M. Myers (half of history). We mentioned John Williams as a leading candidate for the fiction award; he shared with John Barth. We were wrong on philosophy and religion (Sydney Ahlstrom) and children (Ursula Le Guin). And we knew in advance we would botch translation (Allen Mandelbaum).

title: Primary for Governor May Split Hawaii Democrats
description: HONOLULU, April 21  A bitter and divisive primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor is in prospect here next year, and the Republicans are organizing an effort to regain the political control they lost 20 years ago.

title: Basketball Gaining Fans
description: Football and basketball showed the largest gains in attendance while horse racing and baseball suffered major losses last year, according to an annual survey on sports popularity at the box office compiled by Triangle Publications, which publishes the Daily Racing Form.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: SUBSTITUTE RIDER WINS ON FUN CITY
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 21 While his owner watched from the sidelines on crutches, Fun City moved into the lead for the intermediate jumper championship by winning the timefirst jumpoff class tonight at the Boulder Brook horse show.

title: Children Join in an OldFashioned Quilting Bee
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I.It was not really a traditional quilting bee. Usually they started out with general talk. You know  recipes, childraising, clothes. That kind of thing, Gail van der Hoof said. Then, as they rolled toward the center, they got to the juicy stuffthe gossip about the people who weren't there.

title: CENTROWITZ MILE HELPS POWER WIN
description: Matt Centrowitz of Power Memorial High School ran the kind of race he wanted yesterday and the result was a victory for his team in the distance medley relay.

title: Palestine and its people
description: This handsome foliosized volume of text and photographs about the Holy Land is by no means as presumptuous as its title, which is a borrowing of Ernest Renan's clever phrase for Palestine, a land illuminating the other four gospels. As well crafted as it is large, this book is a festival of graphic arts about the country that gave us the Old and New Testaments.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: CITY STANDBYS SING IN LAST YOUNG LORD
description: For better or worse, the standby singers for an opera production often get a chance to appear in its last performance. This was the case Friday night with the New York City Opera's new production of The Young Lord, which was given for the last time this season. David Hall had his first chance to play the acrobatic title role of the Henze work.

title: Worlds and worlds of birds in the Bronx
description: A world? More like a number of worlds, I said to myself, or hunks of habitat. Stand as long as you like staring into one of thesethe corner of a wood in New England, for example, where a bird scuttles through the underbrush not six feet away from you, and another flies up to sit on an overhanging branch and swing there. The ground looks wet, and, in fact, it is.

title: Watergate Tap Reported On Talks About Delegates
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21 (AP) Private delegate counts and details of strategy before the 1972 Democratic convention could have been overheard by the persons who carried out the Watergate bugging, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: Jane M. Kochanczyk Is Planning Marriage
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 21Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Kochanczyk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Mary Kochanczyk, to Donald Arthur Underwood, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lee C. Underwood of Canton, Ohio.

title: Letters: On Zermatt
description: To the Editor: As we learned from a visit to Zermatt, Switzerland, success has come to that town in the worst way. It has overbuilt and overpriced itself. Scores of new genii hotels have been built in the last few years, most of them offering bed and breakfast with minimum (if any) services. As a result, the town's restaurants have become overburdened. Bookings are hard to get at reasonable dinner hours, the waiters are overworked and surly.

title: Sinai Names Cancer Expert
description: Dr. James F. Holland, an expert in cancer research, has been named professor and chairman of a newly created department of neoplastic (tumorous) diseases at Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the director of the cancer center at Mount Sinai Medical Center. Dr. Hans Popper, dean of the medical school, said the new departments would go into operation on July 1.

title: Coast Guard Is Taking on New Environmental Responsibilities
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Coast Guard, which began protecting man from his environment in 1790, today makes a major effort to protect the environment from man.

title: GREEN'S 206 LEADS TALLAHASSEE GOLF
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 21 (UPI)Hubert Green, a former Florida State golfer, maintained his onestroke lead over Bob Murphy today in the third round of the $75,000 Tallahassee Open.

title: State of Grace By Joy Williams. 260 pp. New York: Paris Review EditionsDoubleday & Co. $6.95.
description: The fated heroine of this bleak but beautifullycrafted first novel may well be the final, perfected archetype of all the sad ladies: that formidably fashionable sorority which has impinged on the past decade or so of American fiction. But I'll remember Kate Jackson; I'll reread her stubbornly depressing story, picking out those cleverlyhidden but everpresent clues of grace. Kate is no simple sliceofdespair character; her sad story becomes, through the author's skill and intention, transsubstantiated into significant myth. This book is neither a selfindulgent journal of despair, nor journalism of despair. It is premeditated, articulate, artistica novel.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessaely represent consecutive appearances.

title: Joseph A. Cooke, Brother Of Cardinal, Is Dead at 55
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 21 Joseph A. Cooke, the only brother of Terence Cardinal Cooke, died at his home here this afternoon after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

title: OUTLOOK ON RAILS CALLED BRIGHTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The time is fast approaching when rail costs will be les: than those for shorthaul air and auto travel, according to an independent study spon. sored by Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corpora tion.

title: The Girls He Can't Leave Behind Him
description: BATTLING a fresh wave of dizziness, I swung my Reo coupe past the parking lot attendant who resembled Dick Foran and stopped in front of a shingle that read Dr. Ned Armstrong  Ailments Cure, Past and Present  Late Night Viewers Our Specialty.

title: Johnson Wins 100Mile Race
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla,, April 21 (AP)Amos Johnson of Durham, N.C., drove his Levi's Team Highball Gremlin to victory tonight in the $3,500 Goodrich Radial Challenge 1007mile race at Daytona Speedway. Johnson averaged 82.9 miles an hour to finish 34 seconds ahead of the Pinto of John Leonard of Arlington, Va.

title: Photography
description: ELEITZ, INC., in cooperation with Hart Camera Store of Huntington, L. L will sponsor a Leica seminar on. Friday evening and Saturday in the Community Room of Martins department store in Huntington (Big H Shopping Center). To be conducted by Walter G. Heun, Leica Technical Director, the seminar is for all 35mm photographers. It will include discussion of all types of 35mm cameras, as well as film properties, developing techniques, slide projection and other aspects of taking and making pictures.

title: Michigan Gas Field Pressure Endangers a Community of 400
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mich., April 21 (AP)Extensive drilling operations were to begin tomorrow or Monday in an effort to halt the spread of explosive natural gas geysers that have been threatening this tiny community.

title: Villanova Posts 4Mile Relay Upset
description: Villanova upset Manhattan in the fourmile relay yesterday, and John Hartnett surprised everyone, including himself, during the 19th annual QueensIona Relays.

title: Scott Panel Deliberately Failed To Specify Priorities for City
description: The Scott Commission deliberately chose, in preparing its final report, not to specify where the city should eliminate or curtail programs.

title: MEDIA EXBCUTIYI TOgEARKISSINGB
description: More than 1,200 newspar executives and broadcast dustry leaders will gather morrow at the WaldorfAsto Hotel to hear Henry A. Kissi ger, President Nixon's assista for national security affairs, the start of the fourday Ame can Newspaper Publishers A sociation's 87th annual mud here.

title: English Faces Test as Hospitals Chief
description: The leadership of Dr. Joseph T. English as president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation is expected to come under sharp attack Tuesday at a special meeting of the corporation's 15member board of directors.

title: Cambodia consulting the stars
description: PHNOM PENH. Early in 1970, in the last moments of Prince Norodom Sihanouk's rule, a road was built from his Chamcar Mon Palace to the Tonle Sap River. It was not much of a roadperhaps 100 yards longbut it was beautifully asphalted, and it would have enabled him to reach the river bank without getting dust on his shoes. Sihanouk was then taking a spa cure in France and, in the manner of a suzerain whose benevolence is appreciated by his subjects, he explained, My children want to give me a homecoming present.

title: Briton Assails Mold Concept of American Schools
description: A British authority on primary education, making her first tour of the United States, is concerned about what she regards as a tendency of American schools to view children as material waiting to be molded, rather than as distinct individuals.

title: Randi Eppridge to Marry May 26
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 21  Mr. and Mrs. Edward Eppridge have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Randall Eppridge, to Roger Frank Norum, son of Maj. E. Cornelius Norum, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Norum of Los Angeles.

title: AROUND THE
description: The New York Unit of the Herb Society of America had an afternoon of herbs recently. Two wellknown authorities kept an audience of ladies spellbound for several hours in Historical Hall, Bedford, N. Y. as the speakers revealed many of their innermost secrets about growing and knowing herbs.

title: Belief in Crude Reality
description: TEHERANIran today finds itself wedged between two of the world's tensest crisis areas. To the west lies Iraq, with which it is on very bad terms, and the festering Middle East, already riven by wars. To the east lies Pakistan, which shows signs of coming apart.

title: The Dance
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Whatever doubt one may have about the external appearance of the Kennedy Center or even about the oppressively plush interior the Opera House itself, once the lights are down, it is superlative house for ballet. The stage is expansive, the sight lines are exceptional, and the acoustics are unusually vivid.
