Dunne, Nathaniel Hyland and Patrick O'grien, the stewards who saw him foul Stop the Music and moved him back to second place after he won the Champagne Stakes last October).

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Judith Saffer Is a Bride
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. L, April 22Miss Judith Ann Saffer, daughter of Dr. Sidney H. Saffer, a physician, and Mrs. Saffer, was married here this morning to Ferdinand Bazin, son of Mrs. Ernestine Bazin of Vienna. Rabbi Herschel Levin performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: LIDDY SAID TO DEFY WHITE HOUSE PLEA TO TALK TO JURORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 22G. Gordon Liddy, the leader of the Watergate breakin, has turned down a White House request that he change his mind and begin telling all he knows about the bugging of the Democrats to the Federal grand jury, sources close to the case said today.

title: Beame Relies on Experience to Win Race
description: City government is a $10billion corporation, says Controller Abraham D. Beame. Would you pick someone with no experience to manage it?

title: Yanks Bow To Brewers Again, 4 to 3
description: MILWAUKEE, April 22 Al few hours before game time this morning, an elderly woman at the Yankees' downtown hotel kept insisting this afternoon's contest with the Brewers had been postponed because of wet grounds. She addressed her remarks, in particular, to Sparky Lyle, maintaining she had heard the report on the radio.

title: Beware of PIP
description: In Herman Melville's work of fiction, Moby Dick, there is a character named Pipa lunatic cabin boy with prophetic powers who lives in fear of cowardice.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES ??
description: NASHVILLE, April 22Meharry Medical College, the nation's only predominantly black private medical school, is speeding the production of physicians, dentists and allied personnel to provide more and better health services to poor and disadvantaged Americans.

title: The U.S. Abstention
description: The hypocrisy with which the Security Council condemned Israel's military actions in Lebanon came as no surprise in the wake of a debate dominated by antiIsraeli bias. The only unexpected feature of the vote, with eleven members favoring the resolution and four abstaining, was the fact that the United States chose to abstain rather than to condemn what was clearly an unfair judgment against Israel.

title: 6 Reported Killed In Shooting Spree By Gunman on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22 (AP)A man shot his grandmother dead, according to the authorities, wounded two other persons in an argument at his home today, then went on a shooting rampage that left five others dead and seven wounded.

title: Chief of State Consumer Unit Leads Her Troops in Battle With Scale Cheats
description: NEWARK, April 22With food prices continuing to climb, Mrs. Millicent H. Fenwick, director of the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs who has been making forays into food stores about the state, acknowledged that she had never worked so hard in her life. We've been having a very zippy time of it, she said, referring to expeditions with members of the division's Bureau of Weights and Measures to check the shortweighting of meats and poultry. Nobody knows what we've condemned. A thousand chickens all had to be undone and rewrapped because there was too much water in the paper; the consumer wasn't getting what she was paying for. She was getting paper and liquid instead of chicken.

title: Wellesley President Says School Can Do Without Men
description: BOSTON, April 22 (AP) Wellesley College, which has rejected coeducation, after a recent fouryear study, will not admit men because it has the financial resources to do without them, the college president said today.

title: WANTED I.R.A.LEADER APPEARS IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 22 (AP)An Irish Republican Army leader high on the British Army's wanted list made a surprise public appearance today in Belfast, but the British made no move to capture him for fear that innocent persons might be harmed.

title: ShortTerm Rates Expected to Rise In Credit Markets
description: More increases in shortterm interest rates lie ahead, increases encouraged by Federal money managers in their campaign to restrain a booming economy without preventing small borrowers from obtaining credit.

title: Tightening Censorship in Cambodia Is Slowing and Clouding Correspondents' Reports
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 22  Cambodian press censorship, at least tacitly encouraged by some United States officials here, has made prompt and reliable reporting from this country extremely difficult and threatens to become more restrictive.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: No passenger ship arrivals are scheduled for today or tomorrow.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE THEORY OF THE LEISURE CLASS. By Thorstein Veblen. With an Introduction by John Kenneth Galbraith. 261 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $6.95.

title: WIFE HELD IN DEATH OF EXECUTIVE ON L.I.
description: The Suffolk County police have arrested the 47yearold wife of a Huntington, L. I. business executive and charged her with the murder of her husband.

title: The Least Guilty
description: LONDONCambodia was always regarded by welltraveled Westerners as the loveliest of countries, her people gentle and beautiful, her art remarkable, her countryside untouched by war. That was three years ago.

title: MISSING GIRL, 7, FOUND MURDERED
description: HILLSDALE, N.J., April 22 The body of 7yearold Joan D'Alessandro, whose disappearance from her home here on Thursday Wllile delivering Girl Scout cookies had set off wide search, was discovered today in a wooded area beside Route 210 in Harriman State Park, Rockland County, N.Y.

title: LowCaste Punjabis Fight Back
description: CHANDIGARH, India, April 13The untouchables of Chandigarh, locked in poverty, ignorance and spiritual degradation, have startled the residents of this new city with a protest strike and demands for social reform.

title: GALLUP FINDS NIXON HAS LOST SUPPORT
description: Amid growing public concern over the Watergate affair, the Gallup Poll reports, President Nixon's popularity has fallen 14 per tentage points since the late January Vietnam peace settlement and five points alone in the first week of April.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The 22d annual Capezio Dance Award will be presented Thursday to Isadore Bennett, who has been a dance manager and publicity woman for more than 30 years. Miss Bennettt, who retired last year as press representative for the Joffrey Ballet, is one of the few winners of the $1,000 award who is not a dancer or a choreographer.

title: Communists Attack Gap in the Defenses Around Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Monday, April 23 (Reuters)Communist troops advanced yesterday into a gap in Phnom Penh's defensive perimeter nine miles south of the city center, despite intensive American bombing.

title: Advertising: Ayer's New LineUp
description: In a number of file cabinets, desk drawers and probably wallets around N.W. Ayer & Son there are yellowed clippings of a column that appeared in this space in September, 1968. In it Neal W. O'Connor, then 42 years old and already president a couple of years, gave himself five more years in the job.

title: Lon Nol and Political Opponents Reach an Accord
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Monday, April 23 (Reuters)President Lon Nol of Cambodia and his chief political opponents today reached a compromise formula for a new allparty council to oversee the running of national affairs.

title: Jersey and Pennsylvania Aides Work to End Nonresident Taxes
description: CAMDEN, April 21 (AP)New Jersey and Pennsylvania officials reportedly are working on ending taxation of nonresidents' incomes.

title: Eugene V. Mori: Jersey Entrepreneur With Connectionsand Growing Problems
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 22  Eugene V. Mori paid $10Million last week to reestablish his control of the Garden State Race Track here. The stocky, 75yearold entrepreneur will have to put up another $10million July 16, and the same amount Oct. 15 to buy out dissident stockholders.

title: Two Angry Factions Clash in White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 22Experts on the White House now discern, in the new outburst of recriminations on the Watergate affair, a clear pattern of factional strife that threatens the top command of the executive branch.

title: BROOKE CRITICAL ON NIXON'S ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 In one of the strongest public statements yet by a member of the President's own political party, Senator Edward W. Brooke said today that Mr. Nixon could not escape responsibility for the Watergate affair under any circumstances, without an explanation of why he had not known what was going on.

title: Governor Said to Consider 4 to Replace Mackell
description: Aides to Governor Rockefeller have mentioned four possible replacements if the Governor supersedes Thomas J. Mackell as Queens District Attorney, Matthew J. Troy Jr., the county's Democratic leader, said yesterday.

title: Establishment Values Rule on Campus
description: Political activism is moribund at colleges and universities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and students have taken on the superficial appearance of their selfcentered, socially indifferent, AllAmerican campus counterparts of the nineteenfifties.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1973

title: Saviano, Barbara Goldman Win Easter Bowl Net Titles
description: Nick Saviano of Los Altos Hills, Calif., and Barbara Goldman of Fort Lee, N. J., won titles in the 18yeardivision as the sixth annual Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis championships ended here yesterday.

title: SOARING COSTS DIM BONG KONG'S LURE
description: HONG KONG, April 22 Hong Kong, once a favored site for the Asian headquarters of American companies, is rapidly losing its attractiveness.

title: Shorter Wins Beach Race; Misner, the Defender, Is 2d
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 22 (AP)  Frank Shorter, the Olympic marathon winner, won the annual four  mile Easter beach run today, beating the defender, Ken Misner, by seven seconds. Shorter, a 25yearold university of Florida law student, finished in 19 minutes, 50 seconds.

title: Seven Die in El Paso Gas Explosion
description: EL PASO, April 22 (UPI)Leaking gas accumulating beneath the floor of a lowincome apartment house near the Mexican border exploded this morning, killing seven persons, five of them in two families. The onestory building was severely damaged.

title: Roundup: Hitters Double Pleasure at Wrigley Field
description: Wrigley Field was the place yesterday for the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Chicago Cubs to fatten their batting averages. The teams collected 45 hits, 23 by the Cubs, as they split a doubleheader. There were nine homers hit in the two games.

title: Easter Brings the Sun, Sermons and Strollers
description: With hymns and joyous prayer, with festive parties and sartorial preening, New Yorkers yesterday celebrated the glory of Easter.

title: Juvenile Justice Overhaul Urged for State in Study
description: PRINCETON, April 22  A sweeping overhaul of New Jersey's system of administering juvenile justice, including the rewriting of laws and a state takeover of the 21 county offices, was recommended today by the Center for Analysis of Public Issues.

title: METS ROUT EXPOS IN 2D GAME, 133 AFTER 21 DEFEAT
Lincoln Boyhood Home Uncovered in Kentucky
description: ELIZABETHTOWN, Ky., April 22 (UPI)  A 150yearold log cabin that served as a boyhood home to Abraham Lincoln was discovered during a recent project in this northcentral Kentucky city as part of a floodcontrol project.

title: Troy Quits as Biaggi Aide Pending Refutation of Lie
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Democratic leader of Queens, said yesterday he had taken a vacation as Representative Mario Biaggi's mayoral campaign manager until Mr. Biaggi answered reports that he lied in denying he invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury.

title: Collegian's 67 Sets Pace
description: STATESBORO, Ga., April 22 (AP)  Florida took the team title and Jimmy Ellis of Georgia Southern shot a fiveunderpar 67 for individual honors in the third annual Chris Schenkel golf tournament today at the Forest Heights Country Club.

title: ROSEWALL BEATS ASHE BY 63, 76
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 22 (AP)Ken Rosewall captured his third straight World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today by defeating Arthur Ashe, 63, 76, in the final.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Frazier Goes on Spree After Chaney Fouls Out
description: Walt Frazier had scored 12 points and the knicks were trailing, 7660, with 10 minutes to play against the Boston Celtics yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: BREEDING CATTLE SOLD TO HUNGARY
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (Reuters)The United States sold recently 2,640 head of breeding cattle worth $1.3million to Hungary, its largest single export sale of dairy breeding animals, the Department of Agriculture has reported.

title: HAWKS' HOLIDAY SPENT AT DRILLS
description: CHICAGO, April 22 (UPI)The Chicago Black Hawks went through another workout today in Coach Billy Reay's program designed to keep them sharp for the fifth game against the New York Rangers Tuesday night in their National Hockey League semifinal playoffs.

title: Knicks Defeat Celtics
description: The Knicks defeated the Boston Celtics, 117 to 110, in double overtime at Madison Square Garden yesterday and took a 31 lead in the four  of  sevengame Eastern playoff final in the National Basketball Association. One more Knick victory will clinch the series, which moves to Boston Wednesday night. Details on Page 45.

title: Bridge: Roth and Ogust Teams Meet In Final of Grand National
description: Thanks to a remarkable turnabout in a semifinal ??atch late Saturday night, teems led by Alvin Roth and Harold Ogust clashed in the final of the New York Grand National Championship at the New York Hilton yesterday afternoon.

title: Troy Quits as Biaggi Aide Pending Refustation of Lie
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Democratic leader of Queens, said yesterday he had taken a vacation as Representative Mario Biaggi's mayoral campaign manager until Mr. Biaggi answered reports that he lied in denying he invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury.

title: HUSSIES CAPTURE DAVIS CUP SERIES
description: TOKYO, April 22 (UPI)Australia, led by John Newcombe, gained the Davis Cup Eastern zone final today with a victory over Japan in the doubles that lifted the Aussies to an unbeatable 30 lead in the threeoffivematch series.

title: Arab Admits a Suicide Mission in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, April 22A Palestinian guerrilla said at a news conference here today that he and two companions had infiltrated from Lebanon Friday on a suicide mission to sabotage a bus station.

title: Procol Harum Fills Felt Forum For Night of Refined Decadence
description: Procol Harum, the British group, brought its air of refined decadence (mostly in the lyrics of Keith Reid, used exclusively by the group) to Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum on Saturday, and a packed house embraced this most gothic of groups working in the rock field.

title: CANADIENS DOWN FLYERS AGAIN, 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22Not even Kate Smith could help the Philadelphia Flyers today as they fell victim to the opportunism of the Montreal Canadiens, who scored a 4to1 victory as, both clubs proved that even playoff hockey could have:its dull moments.

title: YOUNG ARMY MEN RISING IN SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The Soviet Union has made major changes in its military high command in the last 18 months, motivated by a need for rejuvenation, according to military and civilian analysts.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Canadian Oil Group in China
description: HONG KONG, April 22 (Reuters) A Canadian petroleum mission led by Donald S. MacDonald, Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, arrived in Peking tonight, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported. He was greeted by China's Minister of Foreign Trade, Pai Hsiangkuo.

title: PRESS CLUB FETE WILL REAR ROGERS
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers will be the guest speaker, tonight at the Overseas Press Club's annual dinner, where 18 awards will be presented to journalists for distinguished reporting and interpretation of foreign affairs in United States media during 1972.

title: Gloom Is Heavy at Boston Navy Yard
description: BOSTON, April 22Two hours had passed since a mimeographed news extra from the commander had spread the gloomy news that the historic Boston Navy Yard, which has built and overhauled American fighting ships almost from the day the republic was born, was finally to be shut down. George Pearce, a strapping ruddyfaced man who has repaired naval guns and missile launchers for most of his adult life, was drowning his sorrows in whisky under the cardboard green clovers over at. McAvoy's Cafe just outside gate 4 of the hulking stonegray yard. Who needs naval guns? he wailed, his bloodshot hazel eyes getting bloodier by the minute. I'm pushing 50who's going to hire me?

title: Equity Funding Affair Reawakens Debate Over Insiders' Role
description: The use or misuse of inside information to profit in the stock market has always been a controversial topic in Wall Street. Lately, the controversy has escalated, due largely to the scandal surrounding the Equity Funding Corporation of America.

title: The Sound of a Car Radio, and It's Spring in the North
description: CHICAGO, April 22 Spring came to Ron Ohlsen the other day as he inched along this city's Edens Expressway in a warm afternoon's traffic jam.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 23, 1973

title: Developer of the Pill Urges One for Pets
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)A chemist who helped develop the birth control pill for women has said that he advocates the use of chemical contraceptives on dogs, cats and other household pets.

title: Local Weltare Units Told To Check Up or Lose Funds
description: ALBANY, April 22 The State Social Services Commissioner, Abe Lavine, warned local welfare departments today that they faced stiff fiscal penalties if they failed to comply with the state agency's new facetoface eligibility recertification policy for welfare recipients.

title: TV: Rex Harrison in Adventures of Don Quixote
description: The Adventures of Don Quixote, on the Columbia Broadcasting System from 9 to 11 this evening, stars Rex Harrison. A good deal of publicity has been generated by the fact that it stars Rex Harrison. Unfortunately, the production's biggest flaw is the performance of its star.

title: Jersey Airman Enjoys Easter at Home After 5 in Hanoi
description: ALLOWAY, N. J., April 22Maj. Joseph S. Abbott Jr., who spent the last five Easters in the Hanoi Hilton, decorated eggs with his wife and seven children this weekend and sat down with them today to a baked ham and a bunnycake with ears lined with pink coconut.

title: Ballet: Bujones Shows Promise as Don Quixote
description: WASHINGTON, April 22In dancing, as in many of the performing arts, the difference between the extraordinarily good and the great is both small and infinite. Small because in measurable quantity the variation is not all that large, and yet infinite because this is also a variation in immeasurable quality.

title: French Washerwoman Becomes Star
description: BARNEVILLE, France, April 11Until two months ago the only people in France who knew La Mre Denis were her neighbors and, the generations of summer and weekend visitors whose laundry she washed down at the River Tot.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 22The University of California, Los Angeles, won the recruiting battle for Richard Washington, a 7footer from Benson Tech High School here. Washington was the No. 1 schoolboy prospect in the nation. John Wooden, the U.C.L.A. coach, made a rare recruiting appearance during the season to watch Washington and said Washington could have started for the Bruins last season.

title: Australia Posts 419 for 8 In West Indies Cricket Test
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 22  (Reuters)Australia and the West Indies scored only 134 runs in the second day of the fifth cricket test today. Play was brightened only by lively seventh  wicket stand between Rod Marsh and Kerry O'Keeffe. Australia, with a 20 lead, has already won the series.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VOLUME TRADE The Federal Government has 24,000 different titles in print, and you'll find 1,500 of these in stock at the United States Government Printing Office Bookstore, 26 Federal Plaza (Room 110); that's the monstersize building that now dominates the west side of Foley Square south of Worth Street. You can pick up Let's Cook Clams, pocket guides to foreign countries, illustrated posters on the American soldier and astronauts, Better Fast Typing, The Effects of Urban Development on Direct Runoff to East Meadow Brook, Nassau County, Long Island, New York or, for $5.25, a Central Intelligence Agency publication, November, 1971, called People's Republic of China Atlas, with much written material and a number of detail maps. Prices range from 10 cents (for background notes, very detailed and excellent for kids doing reports, on all foreign countries) to $14.25 for Merchant Vessels of the United States, Including Yachts.

title: Eugene Mori: A Promoter With Increasing Problems
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 22 Eugene V. Mori paid $10million last week to reestablish his control of the Garden State Race Track here. The stocky, 75yearold entrepreneur will have to put up another $10million July 16, and the same amount Oct. 15 buy out dissident stockholders.

title: Minimal Pension Reform
description: The need for strengthening the private pension plans on which 30 million workers depend for much of their oldage protection was ably delineated in the message President Nixon sent to Congress the other day. Unfortunately, the reform program he has recommended fails to match his rhetoric.

title: ANOTHER SUEZ CANAL SAID TO BE PLANNED
description: Two foreign newspapers carried articles, yesterday that Premier Giulio Andreotti, of Italy and President Nixon discussed during their meeting last week a plan for a 42country consortium to construct another Suez. Canal, parallel to and west of the existing canal.

title: EBAN CLAIMS PROOF EGYPTIANS GOT JETS
description: JERUSALEM, April 22 (AP) Foreign Minister Abba Eban summoned the. French Ambassador to Jerusalem today and showed him proof that Frenchbuilt Mirage warplanes were delivered to Egypt from Libya, an Israeli Government statement said.

title: Kremlin Dissension
description: Is the Kremlin coalition that unseated Nikita Khrushchev nine years ago finally beginning to break up? If so, the unusual quiet that has ruled in the publicly visible portion of the Soviet political scene since 1964 may give way to a new era of dramatic political collisions, not unlike those of the decade after 1947.

title: Patriots' Maitland Retires
description: FOXBORO, Mass., April 22 (AP)  The retirement of running back, Jack Maitland, was announced, today, by the New England Patriots. The former Williams College back advised the Patriots Ile was retiring after three pro seasons to devote full time to the advertising business in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: BigCity Newspapers Stepping Up Their Coverage of News in Suburbs
description: The rush to the suburbsa movement that has swept middleclass families, corporate headquarters and burgeoning factories out of the central citieshas now caught some bigcity newspapers in its momentum.

title: Revising the Charter
description: The initial report of the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City reaches a fundamentally important conclusionthat the city's governmental structure requires greater political decentralizationbut on what appears to be the slimmest of evidence. Options and alternatives go almost wholly unexamined.

title: Major League Baseball Monday, April 23, 1973
description: National League

title: U.S. Pressing Indian Agency Change
description: WASHINGTON, April 22Despite the stalemate in negotiations with Indians at Wounded Knee, S. D., the Federal Government plans to move forward within the next few weeks with reorganization of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Lindsay paid a condolence call on Dr. William C. Marett of Columbia, S. C., who had flown here to identify the body of his 22yearold daughter, Jill, slain during an Easter visit to the city. Miss Marett, a friend of the basketball player Tom Riker, was fatally shot Friday by a man who followed her into M. Riker's apartment house less than a block from the Mayor's residence on the Upper East Side. The police said that before dying Saturday night she was able to describe her assailant as a black man in his early thirties and of medium build. They asked that information in the case be reported by calling 5959557.

title: Knicks Defeat Celtics
description: The Knicks defeated the Boston Celtics, 117 to 110, in double overtime at Madison Square Garden yesterday and took a 31 lead in the four of  sevengame Eastern playoff final in the National Basketball Association. One more Knick victory will clinch the series, which moves to Boston Wednesday night. Details on Page 45.

title: DEAN EAGLE
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 22 (UPI)  Luther Dean Eagle, sports editor of The Louisville CourierJournal, died yesterday after a heart attack in his automobile. He was 58 years old.

title: LOUIS NAPOLITANO
description: GRANGE, N. J., April 22Louis Napolitano, an assistant corporation counsel of New York City from 1952 to 1967, died today at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. He was 78 years old and lived at 82 High Street here.

title: Governor, in Court Plan, Asks to Appoint Judges
description: ALBANY, April 22Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to restructure the state system by making it entirely statefinanced and providing that seats on the Court of Appeals and an expanded Supreme Court be appointive rather than elective.

title: No Ozark Air Talks Set
description: ST. LOUIS, April 22 (UPI)A union spokesman said today that Ozark Air Lines had made no formal indication that it wished to resume negotiations with members of the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, which went on strike Thursday, closing down Ozark operations. An Ozark spokesman said, I guess discussions would begin again when they union starts to look at management's offer, which we feel is the best in the industry.

title: 35,000 Moravians Greet Easter in Carolina Cemetery
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., April 22  Overflowing old Salem Square and the path to God's Acre graveyard, about 35,000 people stood under the night sky early today for the start of Easter Day services that the Moravian Church, a preLuther denomination, has held here every year since 1772.

title: A $58 Million Mistake
description: If the ways of government were not endlessly inscrutable, it would be hard to believe that the members of the House have approved an extension of the West Front of the Capitol, after experts have begged, pleaded, reasoned, and inveighed against this illconsidered plan. What these gentlemen have endorsed by a close vote is bad architecture, bad restorations bad planning, bad policy, bad politics, and atrocious economics.

title: Indians Seized in California At Site for Governor's Home
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 22 (UPI)Six armed Indians were arrested today after occupying the 11acre site of proposed Governor's mansion, charging that construction would destroy an ancient burial ground.

title: Beyond Watergate
description: The questions of who did what and with whose approval in the Watergate affair must of course be asked in the effort to punish past wrongdoings and prevent future scandals of this nature. Inevitably, too, any proceedings involving those close to the summit of power exercise a lurid hold on the public's fascination. But to pay attention merely to the specific criminal details or to the Who's Who of the cast is to miss the real significance of this sordid chapter of American governmental history.

title: Elizabeth A. Pasquale Has Nuptials Here
description: Miss Elizabeth Angela Pasquale and Charles Cheney Dennis Jr., members of the theatrical group known as the ByrdHoffman School of Byrds, were married here last evening by the Rev. Adrian Dabasfn, who performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the ByrdHoffman Drama School.

title: PEKING PRESSING DIPLOMATIC DRIVE
description: PARIS, April 22  Mor quietly, but almost as vigorously as she withdrew from the world during the Cultural Revolution, China is returning to the international scene.

title: UKRAINIAN PARTY SHAKEN BY STRIFE
description: MOSCOW, April 22Charges of persistent nationalism were reported today to have been raised at a highlevel Communist party meeting in the Ukraine, the second most populous republic of the Soviet Union.

title: Easter Brings the Sun, Sermons and Strollers
description: With hymns and joyous prayer, with festive parties and sartorial preening, New Yorkers yesterday celebrated the glory of Easter.

title: Center for Concert Data May Expand
description: Composers in this day and age tend to be a paranoid lot, suspicious of one another and alienated from the society in which they create. So last summer, when a young man named Gregory Reeve announced that he was forming a Center for New Music designed to bring them all together, jaundiced doubt hung heavy in the air.

title: Columbia Rising Began Five Years Ago Today
description: Today marks the fifth anniversary of the first of a series of student uprisings at Columbia University. On April 23, 1968, 300 students occupied Hamilton Hall and barricaded the dean of Columbia College, Henry S. Coleman, in his office.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: LEON J. MOHN Jr.
description: Leon J. Mohn Jr., a divisional sales manager of J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., textile manufacturer, died Saturday at the Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 51 years old and lived in WestPort, Conn., and Hampton Bays, L. I.

title: Playbill, Seeking Profit, Plans New Fall Format
description: Playbill, the magazine for theatergoers, will radically alter its editorial format and advertising thrust next September, in a major effort to lift the failing 89yearold publication into the profit column.

title: Mr. Mackell Resigns
description: The resignation of Thomas J. Mackell as Queens District Attorney ends a situation that was even more destructive of respect for lawenforcement than his indictment on charges of blocking prosecution of getrichquick scheme in which several of his aides had invested.

title: PETER E. COSTER
description: JAMESBURG, N. J., April 23 Peter E. Coster, retired president of Thomas Galligan, Inc., shoring engineers of Long Island City, Queens, died today in Princeton Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived here and in Cold Spring, N. Y., and Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Rader Homers as Astros Triumph Over Padres, 2.0
description: HOUSTON, April 23 (UPI)Doug Rader hit a tworun homer and Dave Roberts and Jim York combined to pitch an eighthit shutout tonight to give the surging Houston Astros a 20 victory over the San Diego Padres. The triumph was Houston's fifth straight and kept them unbeaten at home in six games.

title: U.S. SEEKS NEW ATLANTIC CHARTER TO RESOLVE STRAINS WITH EUROPE; URGES PRINCIPAL ROLE FOR JAPAN
description: Henry A. Kissinger said yesterday that the United States planned to build a new Atlantic charter with its European allies this year to overcome the economic, military and diplomatic strains that have developed in the alliance recently.

title: ACQUISITION VOTED AT HOWARD JOHNSON
description: Stockholders of the Howard Johnson Company voted at yesterday's meeting in Boston to approve the acquisition of Tower Grill of Pennsylvania, Inc., a private corporation owned by Howard Johnson, chairman and president of the corporation, and his sister and set up to manage four Howard Johnson restaurants. It is subject to favorable tax rulings, expected within, the next few weeks, Mr. Johnson said.

title: A Plea for Partnership
description: Henry A. Kissinger, in a policy statement obviously approved by President Nixon, has sent a message to Europe that can be compared historically only to the famous Marshall Plan speech of Secretary of State George C. Marshall at Harvard almost 26 years sago.

title: Copters and Motorcycles Add a Dimension to Rustling
description: CHICAGO, April 23  It was comfortably dark the other night when a young man drove a rented panel truck up to the cattle feeding pen down the road from the Emmett McCormick farm near Waukan, Iowa.

title: Emile Despres, Economist, Dies; Professor at Stanford Was 63
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 23 Prof. Emile Despres of Stanford University, considered by fellow economists as one of the more original thinkers of his time, died today at his home in nearby Portola Valley. He was 63 years old.

title: Egyptians Are Ready to Push Ahead With MuchDelayed 200Mile Oil Pipeline
description: CAIRO, April 23Egypt now has sufficiently large commitments from potential users to push ahead with her muchdelayed project for a 200mile oil pipeline from the Gulf of Suez to the Mediterranean.

title: Mississippi Floods Isolate Thousands
description: ST. LOUIS, April 23 (UPI)The Mississippi River's third flood crest of the spring, swollen by weekend rains, kept thousands of persons from their homes and marooned thousands more today.

title: MARIAN BENDER 5TH, SHOW PAYOFFS SOAR
description: BALTIMORE, April 23 (AP)  The safe bettors took a heating at Pimlico Race Course today when heavily favored Marian Bender finished out of the money, setting up huge show payoffs in the $30,500 Politely Stakes.

title: Fighting in South Vietnam Reported at 3Month Low
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 24Fighting in South Vietnam during the last few days has declined to its lowest level since the Jan. 28 ceasefire took effect, Saigon and American officials reported yesterday.

title: READER'S DIGEST LOSES SALES PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Supreme Court dismissed today an appeal by Reader's Digest from a decision by the Washington State Supreme Court that the magazine's sweepstakes direct mail advertising campaign violated that state's ban on lotteries.

title: 108 Jobs Cut at Space Center
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., April 23 (UPI)More than 100 employes of the Marshall Space Flight Center were told today that their jobs were being terminated, effective June 1. Dr. Rocco A. Petrone, director of the center, signed dismissal notices for 108 persons, 87 of them in Huntsville and 21 at other Marshall installations, to reduce the number of Civil Service jobs at the center to 5,214 by June.

title: METS HOPE TRIP HELPS THEIR BATS
description: The New York Mets will test the western half of the National League for the first time tonight when they open a sixgame trip in the Astrodome against the Houston Astros.

title: Two Sentenced in California On Import of Mayan Artifact
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23 (AP)  A Federal judge sentenced two men today for illegally importing a 1,500pound Mayan artifact from Guatemala.

title: Many Congressmen Frustrated and Bitter Over Relations With White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Three months after watching President Nixon recite his second oath of office on the Capitol steps, Congress is still trying to find a formula for working its will on the White House.

title: The Forgotten
description: Those who are out of work in a time of prosperity suffer psychological misery as well as economic misfortune. Despite the distinct economic improvement the last year, 5 per cent of the work force is still unemployed. That statistic stands for 4.5 million persons including 300,000 Vietnam war veterans and about halfmillion persons who have been seeking work for six months or longer, the socalled hardcore unemployed.

title: District 18 School Feud Flares Up
description: A new battle between parents in Canarsie and East Flatbush over which community will have the majority voice in shaping local school policies is dominating the coming school board elections in Brooklyn's District 18, the scene of recent controversies and boycotts over school zoning practices.

title: Bolivian Cabinet Resigns To Allow for a New One
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 23 (Reuters)The Bolivian Cabinet resigned today to give President Hugo Banzer Suarez freedom to put together a new one, it was officially announced.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 23A group of white South African athletes decried today racial discrimination in their country's sports and called for equal and unimpaired opportunity for all athletes. In a statement issued at Potchefstroom in Western Transvaal where the national senior athletic championships are taking place the group, the Athletes for Athletes Committee, rejected claims that the recent mixedrace International games in South Africa offered a case for youth Africa's readmission into international sport.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Clashes Involving Jews Enmesh Father of Seven
description: Recent clashes between Jews and nonJews in the pleasant, treelined neighborhood of Borough Park, Brooklyn include that of a 49yearold Jewish lawyer who is charged with assaulting a 16yearold ItalianAmerican youth.

title: OGLALA SIOUX TOLL BY LEADER TO Ala
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., Tuesday April 24Richard Wilson, the president of the Oglala Siou?? Indian tribe, in a message telephoned to area radio and television stations late last night, urged all ablebodied Og lala Sioux to report to the resmelon headquarters here this morning with their rifles.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: British Land Co. Planning A Tender Offer for Uris
description: The Uris Buildings Corporation announced yesterday that the British Land Company, Ltd., intended to make a cash tender offer for all the outstanding common stock of Uris. As much as $153million could be involved.

title: Nixon ls Reported to Have Phoned Dean To Tell Him, You're Still My Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 President Nixon telephoned his personal reassurances to his embattled aide John W. Dean 3d yesterday, wishing him a happy Easter and telling him You're still my counsel, a source close to Mr. Dean said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 24, 1973

title: People in Sports: A New Coach Is Named for Rutgers' Quintet
description: Tom Young, who gained his coaching fame at American University, was named the Rutgers' basketball coach yesterday. The 40yearold Young had a 6137 wonlost record in his fourseason stay With the Eagles, including a 215 mark last season. That team, led by Kermit Washington, earned a berth in the National Invitation Tournarnent. Before coming to American Young posted a 13488 mark over 13 years at Catholic University. Young is expected to sign a fouryear contract today. He replaces pick Lloyd, who resigned last Feb. 12 because of outside pressures.

title: Whit Burnett, Founder of Story Magazine, Dies
description: Whit Burnett, who, as founder and editor of Story magazine, helped discover such writers as William Saroyan, Truman Capote and J. D, Salinger, died of a heart attack Sunday night while attending a dinner party in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Limited NonpublicSchools Aid Allowed in Jersey for This Term
description: TRENTON, April 23A threejudge Federal court ruled today that $2.13million in contracts for auxiliary services to parochial schools in New Jersey could be honored for the rest of the school year. The same panel earlier this month had struck down as unconstitutional the state's program of aid to the nonpublic schools.

title: P.U.C. Approves Rules for Cable TV
description: NEWARK, April 23  The State Public Utilities Commission today formally approved and sent out its muchdelayed set of ?? to regulate cable television in New Jersey's 567 municipalities.

title: Jerusalem Church Damaged
description: JERUSALEM, April 23 (AP) A teacher from a Roman Catholic school in Paris pushed over a pillar in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher today, damaging a tiled floor, the police said. It was the third act of violence this month against the church edifice over what tradition says wad Jesus' tomb.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2 Sides to Meet in PATH Strike

title: Books of The Times
description: RAVENNA. By Giuseppe Bovini. 212 pp. 139 illustrations. Abrams. $45.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Rise at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: A Plea for Partnership
description: Henry A. Kissinger, in a policy statement obviously) approved by President Nixon, has sent a message to Europe that can be compared historically only to the famous Marshall Plan speech of Secretary; of State George C. Marshall at Harvard almost 26 years sago.

title: Discrepancies Led Police To Jersey Slaying Suspect
description: HILLSDALE, N. J., April 23An accumulation of small discrepancies in accounts offered by the prime suspect in the murder of 7yearold Joan D'Alessandro last Thursday led to his arrest and, the Bergen County Presecutor's officers said today, to the solution of a crime that has severely unsettled this normally placid residential town of 12,000.

title: Thomas Matthew: A Man Under Fire
description: There is not much to show for at least $11million in government funds that Dr. Thomas W. Matthew handled in the last six years:

title: A Court Of Man, Not States
description: LOS ANGELESCan judgment on human conduct be reached, and justice established, by any power other than that of the state? Is it not true, in fact, that some of the most dramatic wrongs against humanity have been perpetrated by sovereign states, against which there is today no effective recourse short of war or revolution?

title: Cahill's Growing Woes
description: TRENTON, April 23With Governor Cahill's administration already hit by one political scandal and the threat of another, the new indictments of two top Republicans with close ties to the Governor are a break that Democrats and Mr. Cahill's enemies inside the Republican party were not counting on, The new indictments filed at the end of last week promised another embarrassing political case directly involving the funds of a state administration that had pledged to end New Jersey's national reputation as a symbol of corruption and political doubledealing.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Advertising: TV's MillionDollar Days
description: For the 30 or so network television salesmen in town these are long, hectic daysmilliondollar days.

title: BIAGGI FACES LOSS OF CONSERVATIVES
description: A. Conservative party official said yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi must vindicate himself thoroughly when he answers reports that he invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury.

title: Independent PublicTV Advocate
description: People say that I am a good advocate, Thomas Bradford Curtis observed the other day. If that is so, it is because I advocate what I believe in. Yesterday, the roundfaced, baldish, 62yearold former United States Representative was advocating a reassertion of its independence and integrity by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. On April 14, Mr. Curtis, a lifelong Republican, resigned abruptly from the corporation's board, and yesterday he accused the White House of tampering with the 15member board appointed by the President to oversee public broadcasting.

title: Classification of Pentagon Papers Called Routine
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23The man who classified the Pentagon papers top secretsensitive testified today that he did so in a routine manner without being aware of Government regulations concerning the classification of documents to protect the national defense.

title: Builders Get Space Bonus In Return for Park Funds
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday gave final approval to a proposal that would give builders a bonus in floor space in return for contributions to a city fund to be used to improve parks in the vicinity of the buildings to be constructed. The vote was 12 to 10.

title: Timothy Leary Sentenced To Up to 5 Years in Escape
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., April 23 (UPI)Timothy Leary, the drug cultist, was sentenced to six months to five years, in prison to day for his 1970 escape from the California men's colony.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN SEXBIAS CASE
description: A sex  discrimination case brought by the State Attorney General's office against the New York Telephone Company will be resolved today when the company enters into an agreement providing that all job categories shall be equally open to qualified candidates regardless of sex or marital status.

title: DIVIDEND IS RAISED BY ALLIED CHEMICAL
description: John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, announced at the annual meeting in Morris Township, N. J., yesterday, that the company had increased the quarterly dividend to 33 cents a share from 30 cents.

title: Cost of Market Basket Rose $49 in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)Sparked by a 6.8 per cent rise in the prices farmers receive, the Agriculture Department's marketbasket cost rose $49 more in March.

title: Chess:
description: The first round of a tournament often presehts a curious aspect to the spectators. The players strolling around to peer over shoulders or leaning back in their chairs to follow the, other games on the large wallmounted demonstration boards, seem to be giving more time and concentration to their activity between moves than to what's going on at their own tables.

title: RISE IN WORLD TRADE IS SEEN IN U.N. STUDY
description: GENEVA, April 23The outlook for a fast growth in the volume of world trade this year is very good, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today.

title: FUTURES PRICES UP FOR MOST GRAINS
description: Grain futures prices rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade in the wake of heavy rains over the weekend in the principal growing areas of the Midwest and South. Floods are again delaying spring plantings.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In the May issue of the Salt Water Sportsman, Hal Lyman and Frank Wollner offer the astonishing theory that sun spots and accompanying solar flares are the major factor in the success or failure of the breeding efforts of striped bass in a given year.

title: McLain to Pitch in Minors
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 23 (UPI)Denny McLain, the last pitcher to win 30 games in one season in the major leagues, signed a contract today with the Iowa Oaks of the American Association. McLain started spring training with the Atlanta Braves, but was unconditionally released before the start of the season.

title: Aides Report Nixon Seeks Quick Watergate Windup
description: MIAMI, April 23President Nixon's hopes for overcoming the damage that the Watergate scandals are inflicting on his Administration rest on a speedy disclosure of those Government officials involved and avoidance of protracted hearings by the Senate select committee investigating the case, according to high White House aides who apparently still enjoy the confidence of the President.

title: Eggs Roll at White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) Several thousand children and parents rolled Easter eggs on the White House South Lawn today amid band music and circus acts. Some of the children left with more eggs than they brought. President Nixon and his family, who went to Key Biscayne, Fla., for the holiday weekend, did not return for the annual Easter egg roll.

title: STOCKS ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market declined yesterday in listless trading.

title: Tire Plant Relaxes As Deadline Nears
description: AKRON, OhioMike runs two white sidewall machines, at a Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company's plant here and as he tells it, he has to run dike hell to make a buck.

title: Nixon's Reelection Panel Yields New Files to Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Three cartons of elusive Republican campaign spending documents turned up in Federal District Court today as lawyers for Common Cause continued to press for full disclosure of records.

title: Fire Bomb Damages School
description: READING, Mass., April 23 (AP)  One classroom was damaged in the 1yearold wing of the $17million Reading High School after a fire bomb went off this morning, the police said.

title: LAST NIGHT'S GAME
description: Houston 2, San Diego 0. Other teams not scheduled.

title: U.S. Denies Urging Ouster Of a Reporter in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The State Department today denied that a senior American diplomat in Phnom Penh had encouraged Cambodian officials to expel a correspondent for United Press International.

title: GRAND JURY CALLS 12 IN SUPERFECTA CASE
description: Twelve witnesses were called before a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday in connection with an investigation into unusual betting patterns in superfecta races at New York harness racing tracks.

title: All 70 Safe as Minesweeper, Afire, Sinks in Philippine Sea
description: HONOLULU, April 23 (UPI)The 750ton Navy minesweeper Force, torn by a raging fire that swept out of control, sank today in the Philippine Sea, a spokesman for the commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet announced.

title: Theater Manager Wounded
description: Thaxtor Young, the assistant manager of the Sutton East Theater, 205 East 5th Street, was shot in the chest last night in an attempted holdup by two gunmen in the theater lobby, the police said Mr. Young, of 512 Amsterdam Avenue, was taken to Bellevue Medical Center where his condition was described as critical. The two gunmen escaped on foot.

title: TAMPERING CITED IN PUBLICTV ROLE
description: CHICAGO, April 23Thomas B. Curtis, chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting until he resigned abruptly a week ago, said today that the White House had tampered with the independent board, in express contradiction to assurances that he had received.

title: British Rugby
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Copters and Motorcycles Add a Dimension to Rustling
description: CHICAGO, April 23  It was comfortably dark the other night when a young man drove a rented panel truck up to the cattle feeding pen down the road from the Emmett McCormick farm near Waukan, Iowa.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Publishers' Leader Asks Press to Guard People's Need to Know
description: The American Newspaper Publishers Association opened its 87th annual meeting yesterday with an urgent reminder by its chairman that freedom of the press as guaranteed by the First Amendment was in jeopardy and that newspapers throughout the country must raise their collective voice and defend the American people's need to know.

title: Chicago to Get 53FootHigh Sculpture by Calder
description: CHICAGO, April 23The Federal Government unveiled today a model of a new Alexander Calder sculpture to be erected in the plaza of a complex of government office buildings in Chicago's Loop.

title: Arthur Daley
description: We were lucky, awful lucky, said Dave DeBusschere. He sat on a table in the trainer's room, back braced against the wall. Exhaustion made that huge body sag and weariness was etched on every feature as he added, I couldn't have gone another minute.

title: Fiscal Records Are Seen By Sperry Rand Officials
description: The Sperry Rand Corpora tion had, in the fiscal year ended March 31, a record year of many changes, J. Paul Lyet, chairman, said in an interview here yesterday.

title: Stock Market Prices Slip In Light Trading Session
description: The stock market absorbed another drubbing yesterday it light trading as Wall Street re opened for business after the threeday Easter weekend.

title: ROGERS CAUTIONS ON CUT IN TROOPS
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers warned last night that the dramatic progress made in improving relations with the Soviet Union and China was not irreversible.

title: Marijuana Smokeins Set
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, April 23 (UPI)The Youth International party, which met here during the weekend, said yesterday that it was planning a series of marijuana smokeins across the country next weekend. The Yippies held what they called a test smokein at the University of Iowa here. The group of about 50 Yippies from 16 states and Canada called for the release of jailed marijuana offenders and the immediate impeachment of President Nixon.

title: COMPANY PROFITS ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Aftertax corporate profits surged in the first quarter, the First National City Bank re, ported yesterday. Earnings reported through last Thursday averaged 24 per cent higher than a year ago.

title: U.S. SWIMMER, 15, TOPS MISS GOULD
description: LONDON, April 23 (Reuters) Heather Greenwood, a 15yearold California schoolgirl who had never before won a big race, beat Shane Gould of Australia at the International swimming meeting at Crystal Palace today.

title: HEALTH CHECK LISTS 12 MORE FOOD SPOTS
description: The city Health Department has listed 12 more food processing establishments in New York City where health code violations persisted at the time of a second inspection. Unless the violations are corrected, third and final inspection scheduled for next week can result in closing orders.

title: Technical Aid Is Planned For Cities Losing Bases
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)  Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson said today that the Administration intended to provide technical assistance to the cities that will he hurt by a cutback in military bases.

title: Spring Mills Project Set
description: Spring Mills, Inc., has begun construction of a textile plant in Indonesia for the P. T. DaraIon Textile Manufacturing Corporation, in which Springs is the managing partner and largest stockholder. The project, estimated to cost $16.7million, is in West Java, 30 miles from Jakarta. It will produce lightweight men's suiting for use exclusively in Indonesia.

title: Attack in Schurz Park Stuns Its Young People
description: The young people who hang out in Carl Schurz Park spoke about nothing but a stabbing yesterday. The park is traditionally one of the most peaceful places in the city, but on Saturday night James Freehill, 16 years old, was there and he was repeatedly stabbed; several of his friends were hurt, too, three of them seriously.

title: Needed: A Special Prosecutor for Watergate
description: WASHINGTON  Justice rendered and justice perceived are the indispensable first steps in the journey of a thousand miles back from the political espionage and sabotage understatedly characterized as the Watergate affair, to a plateau of national decency and integrity. The starting point for that long journey is a thoroughly penetrating and totally objective investigation recognized as such by our citizens. Only a special prosecutor, free of Justice Department and White House influence and armed with an independent staff, can avoid the nagging suspicion of corruption uncovered and crime unpunished in the highest levels of Government.

title: State Coordinator Named
description: ALBANY, April 23  State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist announced today the appointment of Sterling S. Keyes, of Baltimore, to the new post of coordinator of the department's service to New York City, effective July 1.

title: BREZHNEV MEETS WITH 7 SENATORS
description: MOSCOW, April 23Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, took his campaign for American trade concessions directly to American Senators today land evidently made some headway.

title: Seton Hall Bids for Penn Relay Title
description: For many high school track and field athletes along the East Coast, the Penn Relays is the championship season, scene to see and experience, if only once.

title: Dr. English to Resign by Dec. 31 As Chief of City Hospital System
description: Dr. Joseph T. English, the 39yearold psychiatrist who has spent nearly three tumultuous years as chief of the city's new public hospital system, announced yesterday that he would leave the post by the end of Mayor Lindsay's term next Dec. 31.

title: Minnesota Hunting Act
description: ST. PAUL, April 23 (AP) Gov. Wendell R. Anderson signed the controversial Leech Lake Indian Reservation hunting and fishing agreement today, calling it the most sensitive bill that has reached my desk this session. Under the agreement, any non  Indian sportsmen will have to buy an additional $1 license to hunt or fish on the reservation, starting 60 days from today. The money will go to the Leech Lake Chippewa Band for economic development.

title: Litton Offers Minicomputer
description: Litton Industries, Inc., yesterday introduced a minicomputer that costs less than $27,000 and can store online more than 100,000 elements of data.

title: Discrepancies Pointed to Slaying Suspect
description: HILLSDALE, April 23  An accumulation of small discrepancies in accounts offered by the prime suspect in the murder of 7yearold Joan D'Alessandro last Thursday led to his arrest and, the Bergen County Prosecutor's officers said today, to the solution of a crime that has severely unsettled this normally placid residential town of 12,000.

title: Anger Voiced at Panmunjom
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 23 (UPI)United States and North Korean delegates to the Military Armistice Commission Exchanged angry charges, of truce violations today as a result of a border shooting in which two infiltrators into South Korea were killed last week. A third infiltrator escaped.

title: Aides Report Nixon Seeks Quick Watergate Windup
description: MIAMI, April 23President Nixon's hopes for overcoming the damage that the Watergate scandals are inflicting on his Administration rest on a speedy disclosure of those Government officials involved and avoidance of protracted hearings by the Senate select committee investigating the case, according to high White House aides who apparently still enjoy the confidence of the President.

title: China Backs Treaty To Ban Atom Tests In Latin America
description: SHANGHAI, Tuesday, April 24 (UPI)China announced today that she would soon sign treaty banning nuclear tests in Latin America.

title: The New York Times Company Increases Net 64% for Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the first quarter of 1973 had risen to $4million, or 35 cents a share. This was a gain of nearly 64 per cent over the comparable quarter last year, when net income was $2.4million, or 21 cents a share.

title: BIAGGI FACES LOSS OF CONSERVATIVES
description: A Conservative party official said yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi must vindicate himself thoroughly when he answers reports that he invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury.

title: Janet Coles Wins Medal
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 23 (UPI)  Janet Anne Coles, 18yearold from Aptos, Calif., took medalist honors in the North and South women's amateur golf tourney today with a 75.

title: GOTTFRIED TAKES FINAL BY DEFAULT
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 23 (UPI)Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won $10,000 and gained 10 points in the World Championship Tennis standing today without lifting a racquet when Jaime Fillol of Chile became ill and had to default in the final of the $50,000 South African tournament.

title: Board of Ethics Is Critical Of a City Aide's Activities
description: The city's Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that the activities of an assistant commissionera professional engineer in professional organizations were incompatible with his duties as a city official.

title: SitIn at Chilean Ministry
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 23 (UPI)  Leftwing extremists seized the national Public Works Ministry today and held it most of the day, surrendering the 12story building only after a personal appeal from President Salvador Allende Gossens. The intruders, members of the Militant Revolutionary Left movement, insisted on increased economic benefits for laborers who work on emergency repairs on a parttime basis.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1973
description: Henry A. Kissinger said yesterday that the United States planned to build a new Atlantic charter with its European allies this year to overcome the economic, military and diplomatic strains that have developed in the alliance recently. In a major policy speech at the annual meeting of The Associated Press, at the WaldorfAstoria, Mr. Kissinger spoke with unusual frankness about the problems that have arisen as the West European nationsas well as Japanhave become stronger and more independent of the United States. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Tito Says He Sees Big Social Changes Under New Charter
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 23President Tito forecast today that a new Yugoslav Constitution, the country's fourth since 1946, would bring about revolittionary changes from top to bottom in economic and social relations.

title: Hasidim Live in an Aura of Fear in Borough Park Area
description: Jewish sect in the Borough Park district of southwest Brooklyn shook her head sadly, and said: you walk in the street and someone shouts Dirty Jew. The wife of a rabbi heads the Bobover Hasidic

title: MACKELL RESIGNS IN FACE OF MOVE TO FORCE HIM OUT
description: Thomas J. Mackell resigned yesterday as Queens District Attorney, 12 days after he was indicted on charges of covering up a criminal investigation and five days after Governor Rockefeller said he had begun proceedings to remove him from office.

title: Alcan Aluminium Also Shows Quarter Rise
description: The nation's largest domestic copper producer and the world's secondlargest aluminum) (company reported yesterday gains in firstquarter operations

title: Pentagon Approves Plans for Superior Battle Tank for 1980's
description: FORT KNOX, Ky.  The Pentagon has approved plans for a battle tank of the nineteeneighties with unprecedented levels of fire power, mobility and protection.

title: George Allen, Presidents' Crony, Dies
description: PALM DESERT, Calif, April 23George Edward Allen, a Washington lawyer, businessman and pokerplaying intimate of three Presidents, died here early today at Eisenhower Medical Center of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: Yablonski Murder Suspect Denied Change of Venue
description: ERIE, Pa., April 23 (AP) Albert Pass, charged with murder in the Yablonski slayings, was denied a change of venue today. But Erie County Judge Edward Carney said he would consider delaying Mr. Pass's scheduled June 4 trial.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: West German Is Accused As Warsaw Ghetto Nazi
description: PARIS, April 23  A Germanborn Frenchwoman who investigates Nazi criminals charged today that the Nazi commissioner in charge of the Warsaw Ghetto during most of its World War II existence is living comfortably in West Germany and has never been prosecuted.

title: Canadien Victory Over Flyer Sextet Would End Series
description: MONTREAL, April 23 (UPI)The Montreal Canadiens have the Philadelphia Flyers hanging on the ropes, but the coach of the Broad Street Bullies has not given up hope.

title: WALKOUT HALTS CEMENT TRUCKS
description: Drivers of trucks that deliver wet and dry cement to construction sites in the city went on strike yesterday in a dispute over a new contract.

title: Mike Quarry Held to Draw by Carroll
description: Harold (TNT) Carroll of Syracuse, made his first New York City boxing appearance last night in the Felt Forum, and the result had to be considered a moral victory for Carroll.

title: DAMP SAUND DIES; EXLEGISLATOR5 73
Strike Ends in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, April 23 (UPI) Hawaii's public school teachers returned to their classrooms today, ending a twoweek strike while negotiations continued on a new contract. During the strike 90 per cent of the 9,000 state teachers remained away from their classrooms and over 90 per cent of Hawaii's more than 181,000 public school students stayed away from school and went instead to the beaches and recreation areas.

title: Summer Preview Washed Out
description: The city got a taste of its summer routine yesterday before a sudden shower washed away nearrecord heat.

title: Canadian Writers Debate Nationalism
description: TORONTO  The surging Canadian nationalism that today affects so much intellectual activity in this, country has inevitably drawn Canadian literature into the vortex of chauvinist controversy.

title: Cambodians Seem Nearer to Collective Leadership
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 23The Cambodian Government appeared to be moving today toward satisfying conditions stipulated by opposition leaders under which they would be willing to join President Lon Nol in collective leadership of the nation.

title: Thomas Matthew: A Man Under Fire
description: There is not much to show for at least $11million in government funds that Dr. Thomas W. Matthew handled in the last six years:

title: Imports Found to Maintain Sales Levels
description: A Queens housewife who had been buying wines by the case phoned her dealer last week to replenish her supply of an imported Burgundy. She was told that the price had increased $6 to nearly $40 a case because of dollar devaluation and higher wine prices in France.

title: Prisoners Sing Sample of Their Album
description: RAHWAY, April 23  A new musical group made its debut at the New Jersey State Prison here today before an impromptu audience of prison officials, prison reform advocates and a healthy sprinkling of guards.

title: Warriors Subdue Lakers As Russell Stars, 117109
description: OAKLAND, April 23The Golden State Warriors struck blow for self respect and extended their playoff series by fighting off the Los Angeles Lakers in the final quarter tonight and posting a 117109 victory.

title: Text of Kissinger's Speech at A.P. Meeting Here on U.S. Relations With Europe
description: Following is the text of an address delivered at the WaldorfAstoria yesterday by Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser for national security, at a luncheon of The Associated Press:

title: Cemetery Workers Walk Out Of Inquiry, Calling It OneSided
description: Cemetery workers walked out of a State Board of Inquiry hearing yesterday, protesting that they were not being treated evenhandedly.

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: Robber Sentenced In a Holdup to Pay Sex Change
description: WESTBURY, L. L, April 23John Wojtowicz, a former bank teller, was sentenced today to 20year prison term for the armed robbery of a Brooklyn banka holdup that he said he had committed to obtain money for a sexchange operation for his male wife.

title: Justices to Rule on Curbs on Pregnant Teachers
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether school systems that require female teachers to quit their jobs four or five months before they expect children are engaging in unconstitutional discrimination based on sex.

title: Israelis Go to Wailing Wall
description: JERUSALEM, April 23 (UPI) Thousands of Israelis went to the Old City today, to visit the Wailing Wall, Judaism's holiest shrine, on the last day of Passover.

title: 2 Women Hurt in Explosion Of Blasting Caps in Factory
description: PORT EWEN, N. Y., April 24 Two women were injured tonight, one critically, in the explosion of blasting caps that they were working on at the Hercules Powder Corporation plant here.

title: WILLIAM BRADLEY, DOCK UNION HEAD
description: William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association from 1953 to 1963, was found dead last night behind the wheel of his auto after it crashed into a parked car. He was 70.

title: Japan Faces Strikes
description: TOKYO, April 23 (UPI)Nine unions representing Japan's railroad, communications, postal, and Government employes rejected Premier Kakuei Tanaka's offer of a new contract today, setting the stage for a week of crippling strikes. Leaders of the unions of public corporations, which have 900,000 members, scheduled action tomorrow.

title: RAY DE VOLL, TENOR, SINGS APPEALINGLY
description: Ray DeVoll's song recital Saturday night at Tully Hall didn't attract the screaming millions in truth, the place looked almost empty. But the belcanto fans missed a bet, for Mr. DeVoll sings far more beautifully than many of their idols.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Whenever there is a major strike, particularly in transportation or in the public sector with the accompanying disruption and inconvenience for the general public, politicians and some of the aggrieved cry out that there must be a better way to resolve labor disputes.

title: Lindsay Swears in McKay
description: Robert B. McKay, dean of New York University Law School, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as the unsalaried chairman of the city's Board of Corrections. He will fill the unexpired term, until Oct. 18, 1975, of William vanden Heuvel, who resigned to seek the Democratic nomination for Manhattan district attorney.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Sooner or later, every designer of repute turns up in New York. A first visit to a store here, to supervise fittings and meet with the customers, is like a finishing school diploma. Subsequent visits are like graduate study: the designer is keeping up with trends in his field.

title: U.S. SEEKS NEW ATLANTIC CHARTER TO RESOLVE STRAINS WITH EUROPE; URGES PRINCIPAL ROLE FOR JAPAN
description: Henry A. Kissinger said yesterday that the United States planned to build a new Atlantic charter with its European allies this year to overcome the economic, military and diplomatic strains that have developed in the alliance recently.

title: SovietAmerican Trade
description: Roughly a decade ago the late Nikita Khrushchev was loudly proclaiming that the Soviet Union would soon bury the United States economically. By 1970, he predicted, his country would outproduce this nation, thus proving the superiority of socialism over capitalism.

title: Monroe Expects to Face Celtics Tomorrow Night
description: Earl Monroe is expected to play when the Knicks meet the Celtics in the fifth game of their National Basketball Association Eastern playoff final in Boston tomorrow night. The Knicks lead the series, 31, and need one victory to go on to the championship round.

title: AWARD IS PRESENTED TO TIMES REPORTER
description: William D. Smith, a reporter on the financial and business staff of The New York Times, has been named the winner of the A. T. Kearney, Inc., business reporting award for 1972.

title: West Indies Trails Australia By 226 in First Innings
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 23 (Reuters)A good innings of 73 by opening batsman Roy Fredericks today. failed to save the West Indies from slipping to a perilous position in the fifth and final cricket test against Australia.

title: House G.O.P. Panel Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) House Republican leaders said today they had named a 15Person panel on environment, to he headed up by Representative Pierre S. Du Pont 4th, Republican of Delaware.

title: Fire Hits San Juan Paper
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., April 23 (AP)Fire heavily damaged four of the six floors at the building of the newspaper El Impartial in old San Juan, the police said. No injuries were reported.

title: Refinery Construction Set
description: The Standard Oil Company of California announced yesterday a $310million refinery building program for three of its existing facilities. The construction, scheduled for completion in 1975, involves additions at El Segundo, Calif., Perth Amboy, N. J., and Pascagoula, Miss.

title: BREZHNEV MEETS WITH SENATON
description: MOSCOW, April 23Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, took his campaign for American trade concessions directly to American Senators today and evidently made some headway.

title: ALFRED DE PASS
description: Alfred De Pass, who retired in 1969 as head elevator starter for The New York Times, died Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 1077 Hall Place, the Bronx.

title: Yankees YriumphOver Brewers, 52
description: MILWAUKEE, April 23Lindy McDaniel, the Yankees' tall, seasoned righthander, continued to show that he has regained the finesse he exhibited as a relief pitcher in 1971 by turning in a superb rescue job tonight. The handsome 37yearold pitcher kept the Milwaukee Brewers scoreless (during 3 2/3 innings of relief work as New York beat Milwaukee, 52. It was the only Yankee victory in the three, game series.

title: Sexually Explicit Radio Shows W ilia Under Criticism by F.C.C.
description: The radio talk shows that deal explicitly with sex have been disappearing from the air.

title: Traffic Changes Start In Bronx to Let El Go
description: New traffic patterns will go into effect in the Bronx starting this morning in preparation for the shutdown of the Third Avenue elevated line at midnight Saturday.

title: Bridge: Ogust and Koytchou Emerge To Capture New York Title
description: One of the great pairs in the classical tradition of American bidding emerged from semiretirement and convincingly captured the New York Grand National title during the weekend. Harold Ogust and Boris Koytchou, who used to win national team titles in bunches but now have little time for competitive play, teamed with Dorothy Hayden Truscott and this writer to head an event that began in December with an entry of 40 teams.

title: Doing and Undoing
description: No rational argument can be advanced for requiring city and state taxpayers to foot the multibilliondollar bill for pension programs that give civil service workers more income in retirement than they earn while working. Even if the ultimate costs of these overfat benefits do not push communities into bankruptcyas indeed they mightso much tax revenue will have to go into sustaining them that vital public services will have to be cut and active workers laid off.

title: Angels Set Back A's, 40, On 3 Runs, in 3d Inning
description: OAKLAND, April 23 (AP)Rudy May pitched a fivehitter and Frank Robinson delivered a tworun single tonight in leading the California Angels to a 40 victory over Oakland A's. Only one Oakland runner reached third base.

title: Stage: Friel's Crystal and Fox Opens
description: Brian Friel started on Broadway with the successful Philadelphia, Here I Come, and Crystal and Fox, which opened at the McAlpin Rooftop Theater last night is the fifth play New York has seen from this Irish writer. First produced nearly five years ago in Dublin, the play has taken a little while to cross the Atlantic. There may be a good reason for this.

title: Indian Moslems' Anger Mirrored in Closing of College
description: ALIGARH, India, April 19The stone paths of the university campus are quiet now. In the darkened corridors, a handful of teachers and graduate students move slowly Loward empty classrooms to finish research and work silently on term papers.

title: GOTTFRIED TAKES FINAL BY DEFAULT
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 23 (UPI)Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won $10,000 and gained 10 points in the World Championship Tennis standing today without lifting a racquet when Jaime Fillol of Chile became ill and had to default in the final of the $50,000 South African tournament.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A letter written by George Washington on his retirement from military service, in which he expresses his philosophy of government, will be one of the historical items offered in an auction of important autographs May 8 at Sotheby Parke Bernet. The letter was written to William Livingstone, Governor of New Jersey on June 12, 1783, six years before Washington became President. It outlines four objectives for respectable national existence: An indissoluble union of the states under one federal head ...a sacred regard to public justice...the adoption of proper national defense ...a spirit of cooperation, and the suppression of local prejudice.

title: ARTHUR WEBB
description: LONDON, April 23Arthur Webb, a journalist who worked in Washington for almost 20 years, died Saturday at his home in Hove, Sussex. He was 84 years old.

title: Zaretzki's SoninLaw in Line For a Judgeship, Sources Say
description: ALBANY, April 23Governor Rockefeller is expected soon to name Albert A. Blinder, New York City lawyer and the soninlaw of the State Senate Democratic minority leader, Joseph Zaretzki, to a judgeship on the State Court of Claims, reliable sources in the Legislature said today.

title: Prisoners Sing Sample of Their Album
description: RAHWAY, N.J., April 23A new musical group made its debut at the New Jersey State Prison here today before an impromptu audience of prison officials, prison reform advocates and a healthy sprinkling of guards.

title: Half Century After Congress Curbed Filled Milk, Court Vindicates Illinois Dairyman Who Fought the Ban
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Fifty years ago the halls of Congress echoed with rhetoric over a battle that has now been resurrected through the persistence of an obscure Illinois dairyman and the discoveries of modern nutritional research.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION SHOWS A 0.2% DROP
description: Steel production for the week ended April 21 hacked down from the record of 3,002,000 tons set a week earlier, the American Iron and Stee Instiute reported yesterday. The trade association placed output for the April 21 week at 2,995,000 tons, second highest for any week, but a decline of 0.2 per cent. The index slipped to 122.8 from 123.0 a week ago.The weekly production figures are as follows:

title: SHOP TALK
description: Who better qualified to know what appeals to a child than his peers? Crayon sketches by 5 and 6yearolds have provided the inspiration for a new group of nylon scatter rugs for children's rooms now available on the seventh floor at Bloom ingdale's.

title: Army Study Finds Only 4,000 Became Addicts in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The Defense Department estimated today that of 300,000 Army enlisted men who served in Vietnam between 1970 and 1972, fewer than 4,000 are civilian drug addicts.

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW ENGLANDSigned Charles Davis, Alcorn A. and M. running back, Doug Dumler, Nebraska center; Dan Rusler, Okiahomy safety; Steve King, Tulsa linebacker; Bill Tinlin, Central Connecticut running back. Asked waivers on Chuck Cornell, receiver; Curt Brandon, linebacker, and Dan Yates, guard. Jack Maitland, running back, retired.

title: Sculpture Salutes Rescue Committee
description: A pair of towering aluminum figures by William King, the sculptor, were placed yesterday in the Hammarskjold Plaza Sculpture Garden at the corner of Second Avenue and 47th Street.
