The work is part of a sevenweek sculpture and photographic exhibition that commemorates the 40th anniversary of the International Rescue Committee.

title: U.S. ASSERTS HANOI HAS CAMBODIA ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The State Department said today that North Vietnamese forces were training and supplying antiGovernment insurgents in Cambodia and manning heavy weapons there.

title: New Ruchell Magee Trial Scheduled to Begin May 29
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (AP)Ruchell Magee will be retried on a charge of aggravated kidnapping in connection with the 1970 Marin County Courthouse shootings that killed judge and three other persons. Attorney General Evelle J. Younger of California said today.

title: U.S. JOINS VIRGINIA ON SCHOOLS PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to disapprove a farreaching school desegregation plan that would Merge Richmond's blackmajority system with two nearly allWhite suburban counties.

title: PERIL IN MICHIGAN FROM GAS WIDENS
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mich., April 23Ten more families were evacuated today from an area three miles west of here after the discovery of new eruptions of underground water and gas.

title: Equity Financing
description: Englehard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation plans to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the company's common stock. The purchases will be made from time to time either on or off the New York Stock Exchange.

title: RANGERS HOPEFUL HAWKS WON'T ICE THE PUCK TONIGHT
description: Perhaps tonight, as Coach Emile Francis hopes, his Rangers will have the visitingteam advantage when they face the Black Hawks at Chicago.

title: G. & W. Sets Offer Of 7% Debentures For Common Stock
description: Gulf Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it would make an exchange offer to holders of its own common stock and certain convertible securities.

title: Jacob Gelberman Dies at 63; Corps of Engineers Aide Here
description: Jacob Gelberman, chief of the operations division of the New York District of the Army Corps of Engineers, died yesterday at his home in West Hempstead, L.I. His age was 63.

title: ULSTER PARADERS AFFIRM LOYALTY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland April 23 (UPI)  More than 1,000 Protestant Orangemen led by blaring bagpipes and booming drums, staged an Easter Monday parade through downtown Belfast today to demonstrate their loyalty to Britain.

title: Dr. English Will Resign as Chief of City Hospitals
description: Dr. Joseph T. English, the 39yearold psychiatrist who ha spent nearly three tumultuous years as chief of the city's new public hospital system, announced yesterday that he wou leave the post by the end of Mayor Lindsay's term next Dec. 31.

title: New Jersey Sports Season's Reviews
description: NEWARK, April 23Matt Bolger, the Rutgers baseball coach, has been around a long time and knows that winning a doubleheader doesn't mean a team has reached perfection and can rest on its laurels.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The National Mediation Board yesterday arranged a meeting between officials of the Port Authority Trans Hudson commuter lines and the striking carmen's union, which has kept the line shut for 23 days.

title: N. Y. U. Engineering Completes Merger With Brooklyn Poly
description: New York University's School of Engineering and the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn were formally merged into a single institution yesterday.

title: American League
description: Tuesday, April 24, 1973

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Twentyfive Social Services Department patrolmen in New York City who stayed off their jobs to protest the shooting of one of their unarmed colleagues were suspended by the Human Resources Administration, which described their action as illegal.

title: GRIMM NAMED COACH FOR NETS
description: Kevin Loughery quit the Philadelphia 76ers as coach last night and announced that he had agreed to a longterm contract with the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association. Barney Kremenko, public relations director of the Nets, confirmed that Loughery had signed a contract and that details would be released at a news conference on Thursday.

title: People in Sports: A New Coach Is Named for Rutgers' Quintet
description: Tom Young, who gained his coaching fame at American University, was named the Rutgers' basketball coach yesterday. The 40yearold Young had a 6137 wonlost record in his fourseason stay with the Eagles, including a 215 mark last season. That team, led by Kermit Washington, earned a berth in the National Invitation Tournament. Before coming to American Young posted a 13488 mark over 13 years at Catholic University. Young is expected to sign, a fouryear contract today. He replaces Dick Lloyd, who resigned last Feb. 12 because of outside pressures.

title: Watergate: The Future
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Much of the comment about the Watergate case centers on retrospective questions: Who knew of the plan? Who approved it? Who covered it up? Definitive answers will not be available for months, until the investigations and trials have been completed, and perhaps not then. But regardless of who is indicted or who resigns, it is clear that the case will have farreaching effects on the three and threequarters years of the Nixon Presidency that remain. White House staff members and the friends of the Administration on Capitol Hill and elsewhere expect to see marked changes in the way the White House operates in such policy areas as the war with the news media and the lawandorder issue and in the political alignment in the Republican party.

title: MRS. B. L. JOHNSTON
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., April 23 Mrs. Maxine Dannenberg Johnston, a member of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association from 1955 to 1967, died today in Valley Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 209 West Glen Avenue.

title: MAX DREXLER
description: Max Drexler, a founder and former executive secretary of the Wholesale Licensed Alcoholic Beverage Salesmen's Union and former director of organizing for the Distillery, Rectifying and Wine Workers International Union, died Saturday in Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N. Y. He was 76 years old and lived at 7 South Eastway, Bronxville.

title: VANDALS DAMAGE EAST 2D ST. SCHOOL
description: Vandals invaded the offices and school of the Negro Action Group at 270 East Second Street on the Lower East Side over the weekend and damaged several classrooms and destroyed, office equipment, the police reported yesterday.

title: ExPremier of Greece, in Exile, Urges Return of King to Athens
description: LONDON, April 23Constantine Caramanlis, a former Premier of Greece and a conservative, broke a long silence today to call on the Government to resign and bring back King Constantine, who is in exile in Rome. He also criticized the United States position on the armybacked dictatorship in Greece.

title: CITY STORES CO. TO SHUT DIVISION
description: The City Stores Company, which operates both department and specialty stores, announced here yesterday plans to close its Lansburgh store division in Washington because of continued unprofitability.

title: Charles EamesCasual Giant of Design
description: Billy Wilder gave Charles Eames a present.

title: A LOSS IS REPORTED BY DYNAMICS CORP.
description: The Dynamics Corporation of America, which has been operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since last August, said yesterday its consolidated losses were about $35.4 million last year, and as result, its networth deficit was about $15.6million as of last Dec. 31.

title: Copier Concern's 22% Climb Paces Reports
description: The number of companies joining the ranks of those with higher firstquarter profits continued to swell as financial statements of a broad, national crosssection of industries poured in yesterday.

title: U.S. Court Will Ponder Mississippi Party Label
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 23 (AP)  A Federal appeals court took under consideration today the problem of which group of politicians in Mississippi hould be officially called Democrats. The struggle is between the socalled regular Democratic state party, headed by Gov. William Waller, and the civil rightsoriented loyalist group.

title: Caviar Prices Steady Despite Money Shifts
description: While prices of both imports and domestic products have been rising, the price of one choice luxury importcaviarhas yet to be raised because of currency realignments.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1973

title: Bodies of 2 Who Drowned After Plane Crash Found
description: WARWICK, N. Y., April 23 (AP)The bodies of two New York City men who drowned over the weekend when their light plane nosedived into nearby Wickham Lake in southern Orange County shortly after takeoff have been recovered.

title: Nixon ls Reported to Have Phoned Dean To Tell Him, You're Still My Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 President Nixon telephoned his personal reassurances to his embattled aide John W. Dean 3d yesterday wishing him a happy Easter and telling him You're still my counsel, a source close to Mr. Dean said today.

title: Equity Is Accused of Asking Illegal Transfers
description: A former officer of a New Jersey subsidiary of the scandalridden Equity Funding Corporation of America alleged yesterday that he had been asked repeatedly by officers of Equity to illegally transfer assets of the subsidiary to the parent company or its West Coast insurance operation.

title: Insurer Names a Director
description: James D. Finley, chairman of J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc, has been elected to the bboard of of the New York Life Insurance Company. Mr. Finley is also director of Borden, Inc., the Sperry Rand Corporation and the Manufactueres Hanover Corporation.

title: Reuss Wants Petersen Replaced By Outsider in Watergate Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Representative Henry S. Reuss said today that neither Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen nor anyone else from the Justice Department should be in charge of the Watergate investigation, suggesting that an impartial outsider be chosen instead.

title: MARIE CATHERINE BYRON
description: Marie Catherine Byron, who retired in 1953 as administrator of the Mary Harkness Convalescent Home of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center in Port Chester, N. Y., died Saturday in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 84 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

title: KISSINGER HINTS VIETNAM ACTION
description: Henry A. Kissinger sharply assailed North Vietnam yesterday for having totally violeted the Vietnam cease  fire agreement.

title: Notes on People
description: Bernadette Devlin, the firebrand member of the British Parliament who has championed the cause of Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland, was married yesterday on her 26th birthday. Miss Devlin, who gave birth to a daughter 21 months ago but has refused to name the child's father, was married in a Catholic ceremony at Rock, near Cookstown, Northern Ireland, to Michael McAlaskey. Her husband, a 24yearold schoolmaster, is believed to be a member of the Official, or Marxistoriented, wing of the Irish Republican Army. The marriage was the first for both.

title: Nixon's Doctor Denies Guilt
description: Dr. W. Kenneth Riland, a New York osteopath who, has treated President Nixon and has served as Governor Rockefellees personal physician, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to charges of income tax evasion. The 61yearold physician was accused in an indictment two weeks ago of evading $39,000 in taxes on $82,000 in patient fees that he allegedly failed to report as income for 1966 through 1970.

title: WEINBERGER SCORES CLOSING OF SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it was in very bad taste for a Massachusetts school district to lock out 2,300 Army children because of reduced Federal impactaid spending.

title: DR. JULIA M. JONES, EXPERT ON TB, DIES
description: Dr. Julia M. Jones, a leader in the fight on tuberculosis as physician in charge of the pulmonary disease section at Harlem Hospital, died yesterday in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, where she was professor of clinical medicine. She was 64 years old and lived at 156 Washington Avenue, Pleasantville, N. Y.

title: 300 in Yoga Society Score India in Capital Protest
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Three hundred members of the Ananda Marga Yoga Society held a daylong demonstration here today and one of their members was arrested while protesting the alleged mistreatment of their spiritual leader, Shrii Shrii Anandamurti, who has been in jail in India for 14 months.

title: People and Business
description: Arthur W. Woelfie has been named president of the Kraftco Corporation, succeeding William O. Beers, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Three Meet Records Broken In Brooklyn Catholic Relays
description: Three meet records were broken on the final day of the Brooklyn Diocese Catholic High Schools Relays yesterday at the St. John's University track in Jamaica, Queens. The first day of competition was on April 16.

title: NANCY WILSON SINGS AVANTGARDE SOUL
description: The Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, has an atypical soul show running through Thursday. In place of the highenergy betters and the soft harmonizers who usually appear there, the theater has booked a nightclub chanteuse who is a practitioner of what might be called soul avantgarde.

title: Caper Comes to Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The news here is that President Nixon is facing another crisis. Its name is Watergate.

title: RULING REVERSED ON SCHOOL VOTING
description: The five justices of the Appellate Division's Second Department in Brooklyn yesterday unanimously reversed lower court ruling on community school board election procedures that might have caused a postponement of the elections, now scheduled for next Tuesday.

title: NORWEGIAN DRIVER WINS HARNESS TITLE
description: TRIESTE, Italy, April 23 (UPI) Ulf Thoressen of Norway easily won trotting's fourth annual driving championship today beating John W. Smolenski of New Zealand by 25 points.

title: Laurin's Request to Split Derby Entry Is Rejected
Sexually Explicit Radio Shows W ilia Under Criticism by F.C.C.
description: The radio talk shows that deal explicitly with sex have been disappearing from the air.

title: Amerada Hess, Getty Oil and Occidental Gain
description: The Exxon Corporation yesterday reported firstquarter net income of $508million, or $2.27 a share, a record. This was up 43 per cent from the yearearlier $355million, or $1.58 a share. The giant petroleum producer's previous high was the $491million earned in last year's fourth quarter.

title: MACKELL RESIGNS IN FACE OF MOVE TO FORCE HIM OUT
description: Thomas J. Mackell resigned yesterday as Queens District Attorney, 12 days after he was indicted on charges of covering up a criminal investigation and five days after Governor Rockefeller said he had begun proceedings to remove him from office.

title: No Article
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Business Briefs
description: Consumer attitudes changed radically during the last few months, growing more and more pessimistic as food prices kept rising, George Katona and Jay Schmiedeskamp of the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research reported yesterday.

title: Army Reports Few In War in 1970'72 Are Addicts Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The Defense Department estimated today that of 300,000 Army enlisted men who served in Vietnam between 1970 and 1972, fewer than 4,000 are civilian drug addicts.

title: Duhon of Giants Retires
description: Bobby Duhon, a New York Giants running back since 1968, yesterday announced his retirement as a player. The 27yearold Duhon, held back by injuries, decided to devote full time to his investment banking career with Oppenheimer, Inc., here.

title: TV: Man Without a Country and Lie
description: It's not often that commercial television presents two major and outstanding dramas in a single week. So naturally enough, given the persistent idiocies of TV scheduling, they are being presented tonight, with the last part of one frustratingly overlapping the first part of the other.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: CONTEMPT ACTION IS AIMED AT VESCO
description: The Federal Government yesterday started criminal contempt proceedings here against Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who left the country recently during an investigation of his mutualfund activities.

title: TAMPERING CITED IN PUBLICTV ROLE
description: CHICAGO, April 23Thomas B. Curtis, chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting until he resigned abruptly a week ago, said today that the White House had tampered with the independent board, in express contradiction to assurances that he had received.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BACH'S BACK The International Bach Society used to bloom in July, with a special congress devoted to words and music about the life and works of J. S. Bach. It was founded six years ago by that leading Bach enthusiast, Rosalyn Tureck. Now the schedule has changed, and there will be more congressing each year; no more July sessions, but one in the fall and one in the spring.

title: STEIN SAYS TAX RISE IS BEING CONSIDERED
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) Herbert Stein, President Nixon's top economic adviser, said today that the Administration was studying the possibility of increasing some taxes as a way of holding down rising demand in the American economy.

title: METS HOPE TRIP HELPS THEIR BATS
description: The New York Mets will test the western half of the National League for the first time tonight when they open a sixgame trip in the Astrodome against the Houston Astros.

title: RATES ARE HIGHER IN CREDIT MARKET
description: Interest rates continued to climb yesterday in the absence of action to tighten economic controls. Trading, however, was described as light and the bond market recovered some of its losses late in the day following reports that the Administration was studying moves to cool off the business boom through higher taxes. Herbelt Stein, the President's chief conomic adviser, suggested one such measure might be a reduction in the tax credit allowed corporations on capital outlays.

title: Godley Leaves Laos Post For State Department Job
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 23 (Agence FrancePresse)  G. McMurtrie Godley, who has been United States Ambassador to Laos since July 24, 1969, left Vientiane today for the United States and a new position.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Cambodian CoverUp
description: A State Department spokesman has compounded the confusion that shrouds everything about military operations in Cambodia by insisting that North Vietnamese troops are actively supporting insurgents fighting around Phnom Penh. Only last week, an American Embassy official in the Cambodian capital asserted that there had been no documentary evidence of Vietnamese troops in combat in Cambodia since the Vietnamese ceasefire.

title: 3,000MILE RALLY IS WON BY ASIAN
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 23 (Reuters)A local Asian driver, 27yearold millionaire Shehkar Mehta, won the 21st East African safari today in the closest finish ever recorded in the 20 years of this rally.

title: EDUCATORS LAUD DRUG PROGRAMS
description: A study of 900 students who took part in special groupcounseling sessions at nine high schools, the report said, showed a 28 per cent reduction in absenteeism, a 49 per cent reduction in disciplinary referrals, a 66 per cent reduction in unsatisfactory conduct ratings, 39 per cent reduction in the number of major subjects failed and an increase of slightly over 5 points in the students' overall gradepoint average.

title: COURTS TO STRESS PUBLIC RELATION!
description: The ranking judges of New York State announced yesterday that they were getting ready to open up the inne?? workings of the courts to the public and that they intended to set up a public relations department to help them do it.

title: Lone Gunmen Rob 2 Banks And Escape With $4,500
description: A lone man said to have been wearing a goatee and a large, brimmed hat, entered the Chemical Bank branch at 957 Broadway, Brooklyn, at 9:40 A.M. yesterday. The man was unarmed, according to the police and passed a note to a woman teller demanding money. He was given $1,500 and fled.

title: 3 AUTO MAKERS SET SALES MARKS
description: DETROIT, April 24Three of the top four auto makers, the General Motors Corporation, Ithe American Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, continued to sell cars at record levels during the period of April 1120.

title: Washington Steel Agrees To Lower Next Dividend
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., April 24 (UPI)  The Washington Steel Corporation said today it would comply with a request from the Committee on Interest and Dividends by lowering its next quarterly dividend to 22 cents from 23 cents.

title: MISSISSIPPI NEARS GREATEST CREST
description: ST. LOUIS, April 24 (UPI)Swelling toward the greatest flood crest in the recorded history of the Mississippi, that river and its tributaries drove thousands more from their homes today along 1,400 miles of flooded watershed from Iowa to the Deep South.

title: Lithographers Sue a Bank Over Union Funds Interest
description: Charles L. McConnell, as president of Lithographers and PhotoEngravers' Union No. 1P, said yesterday that he had filed suit in Supreme Court against the Chemical Bank, seeking a judgment of $100,000 or the applicable interest on an account maintained by the union with the bank.

title: Jury Here Hears Mitchell; He Denies a Tie to Vesco
description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell testified before a Federal grand jury here yesterday, apparently about a $200,000 cash contribution from Robert L. Vesco to President Nixon's 1972 election campaign.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: An Hours Given to Eastern Standard Time

title: Utility Is Planning Suit
description: ST. LOUIS, April 24 (Reuters)The Union Electric Company said today it planned to sue the Westinghouse Electric Corporation over alleged failures of two generating units that Westinghouse supplied.

title: John F. Rich Is Dead at 70; A FundRaising Consultant
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24John F. Rich, who founded the fundraising consulting organization of that name here in 1946, died Saturday while visiting in Athens. He was 70 years old and lived in Haverford.

title: ...Signals to Hanoi
description: There are ominous hints of impending new United States military action in Indochina in Henry A. Kissinger's charge before The Associated Press meeting that North Vietnam has totally violated the Vietnam ceasefire agreement, an accusation that was backed up yesterday by a formal protest to signatories of the Paris peace accords.

title: Books of The Times
description: TEPHEN A. DOUGLAS. By Robert W. Johannsen. 993 pages. Illustrated. Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Havlicek Doubtful on Playing Tonight
description: The availability of John Havlicek for tonight's National Basketball Association playoff game at Boston between the Knicks and Celtics was the nagging question yesterday as the Knicks aimed to end the fourofsevengame series.

title: RIHODESIANREBELS KILL 4 IN A CLASH
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 24The Rhodesian security forces lost four men killed and five seriously wounded in operations against black nationalist guerrillas, a Government cornnumiqud said today.

title: Rate Rise Called Vital
description: Several highly profitable railroads issued earnings statements yesterday in which they complained of a costprice squeeze that the industry traces to the Interstate Commerce Commission's rejection last February of a 2 per cent emergency freight rate surcharge.

title: News Summary and index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: DATA FROM TAPS REPORTEDLY SENT TO WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Federal investigators have determined that officiali of the White House were regularly kept informed last May and June of some of the information obtained through the Hiegal wiretapping of the Democratic National Committee headquarters, sources close to the case said today.

title: Badillo Asserts City Is Giving Too Much To Certain Unions
description: Representative Herman Badillo charged yesterday that too many important public interests had been sacrificed in the city's bargaining with its employes.

title: URSULA JEANS DIES; BRITISH ACTRESS, 66
description: LONDON, April 24 (Reuters) Ursula Jeans, the British stage and screen actress, died Saturday in a nursing home near here. She was 66 years old.

title: ARMY WILL CUT 10% OF TRAINING GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The Army has ordered a 10 per cent cutback in the number of basic training companies because of the shrinkage in its strength, a spokesman said today.

title: NIXON WOULD SIGN A NEW CHARTER IN EUROPE IN FALL
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Highranking Administration officials said today that Henry A. Kissinger's call yesterday for a new Atlantic charter was meant to signal Western European leaders that President( Nixon wants to sign a major document of agreed principles when he visits their countries Iater this year.

title: LEONARD STEIN, 85, BRITISH ZIONIST, DIES
description: LONDON, April 24Leonard Stein, one of Britain's first Zionists, died here yesterday at the age of 85.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE.
description: ACROSS

title: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION
description: MONDAY'S GAMES

title: REGIME IN BOLIVIA REALIGNS CABINET
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 24 (Reuters)  President Hugo Banzer Suarez of Bolivia today installed a reshuffled cabinet in which the armed forces were given an additional seat to put them on an equal footing with the two main political parties that support his military government.

title: $1Billion Is Asked for Stewart Airport
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority made public yesterday a longawaited blueprint from consultants recommending a $1billion transformation of Stewart Airport near Newburgh into a major facility that, by 1990, would handle almost twice the traffic Kennedy International Airport handles today.

title: Woman, 30, Is Found Slain in Hotel On Quiet Street on Upper West Side
description: A 30yearold woman was found yesterday morning stabbed to death with a pair of scissors in a quiet residential hotel on the Upper West Side.

title: Saturday Review in Bankruptcy; Norman Cousins to Run It Again
description: The publishers of the four Saturday Review magazines filed bankruptcy proceedings yesterday and announced plans to merge the publications with World magazine to form a single biweekly.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: The North Western Orders Boxcars Worth $20Million
description: CHICAGO, April 24 (AP)The Chicago & North Western Railway announced today that it had ordered 1,200 boxcars costing more than $20million, equipment that it said was in critically short supply nationwide.

title: Greyhound Sets Russ Togs Acquisition
description: The Greyhound Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Russ Togs, Inc., manufacturers of women's and children's apparel. The proposal calls for the exchange of 1.25 share of Greyhound common for each of the approximately 4 million common shares of Russ Togs outstanding. Based on the closing price yesterday of the Greyhound Corporation on the New York Stock Exchange of $16, the transaction is valued at $80,365,000.

title: SANDMAN TO FILE SLATE IN BEND
description: HACKENSACK, April 24Representative Charles W Sandman Jr., in a bid for a pre ferred ballot position in the June 5 primary, intends to rut a slate of candidates for county office againit Governor Cahil and the Bergen County Republi can organization.

title: Eximbank Announces Loan
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)The United States ExportImport Bank said today it would lend $7,942,500 to help finance the sale of oil field drilling equipment to a Panamanian concern for use in Iran. The United California Bank of Los Angeles will lend an equal amount and the borrower, Global Services, Inc., of Panama, a subsidiary of Santa Fe International, will pay $1,765,000 in cash.

title: JAMES F. NUGENT
description: James F. Nugent, retired general foreman of the West Shore division of what is now the Penn Central Railroad, died yesterday at his home in Brielle, N. J. He was 80 years old.

title: Seoul Holds 9 in Spy Case
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 24The prosecution authorities announced today that a group of nine South Koreans had been arrested on charges of spying for North Korea or collaborating in espionage activities. The nine, five men and four women, were rounded up between March 12 and April 4 on the southern island of Cheju and in the port city of Pusan, according to the announcement.

title: Cosmetics: What Does HypoAllergenic Actually Mean?
description: The beauty industry, a sophisticated giant built to a great extent on the theory that a better product has just arrived or is just around the corner, has hopped on a 40yearold bandwagon. It has discovered the sales appeal of hypoallergenica term that simply means a product is less allergenic than something else.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Boy Dies From Accidental Rifle Shot

title: Bridge: Telling Fortunes With Cards Means Reading Foes' Hands
description: Cartomancy, or divination with the aid of playing cards, is a dubious art in the fortunetelling field. For the bridgeplayer it is a vital science, but also one that is littleunderstood.

title: CUSTODIAN IS HELD IN FIRE AT CHURCH
description: NEWARK (UPI)A 20year old former custodian of the 123yearold First Methodist Church here was held today in lieu of $10,000 bail and charged with setting a fire in the build, ing last Saturday that heavily damaged the landmark.

title: Tanzan Ishibashi Dies at 88; Was Former Premier of Japan
description: TOKYO, April 24 (UPI)Former Premier Tanzan Ishibashi died early today. He was 88 years old.

title: C.A.B. Bars Discount Plan Asked by American Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected today a proposal by American Airlines to offer discounts of up to 30 per cent on domestic flights of more than 1,000 miles.

title: STOCKS PLUMMET ON AMEX AND OTO; Concern Over Inflation See?? Trading Pace Picks Up
description: Stock prices dropped sharply in continued slow trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CURTAIN CALL The doctor's house call has gone the way of the trolley car, but it's nice to know they're still available for curtain calls. At 8:30 tonight, the Brooklyn Doctors' Symphony Orchestra, a 80member assortment of musically motivated G.P.'s, surgeons, anesthetists, medical students, dentists, lab technicians, druggists electrologists and nurses, will do a concert in the second floor auditorium of the Kings County Nurses Residence Hall, 451 Clarkson Street, at New York Avepue.

title: 2d Slaying in 18 Years Is a Shock to Hillsdale
description: HACKENSACK  Joseph McGowan, a 26yearold high school teacher, was indicted by a Bergen County grand jury today on a charge of murdering 7yearold Joan D'Allesandro, who had gone to his home to deliver Girl Scout cookies.

title: Union Councils Formed in Peking and Shanghai
description: HONG KONG, April 24Peking announced today that tradeunion congresses had been held and union councils formed in Peking and Shanghai, the principal Chinese cities.

title: 8 Soldiers Killed As Copters Crash At Base in Texas
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., April 24 (UPI)Two Army helicopters collided in a driving rainstorm and crashed today, killing eight soldiers flying simulated missions. The crash took place during military war games witnessed by Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson.

title: HOSPITALS BOARD SUPPORTS ENGLISH
description: Instead of being subjected to a vote of no confidence, Dr. Joseph T. English last night won a pledge from, the directors of the city's publichospital system that they will cooperate fully with him as long as he stays in office.

title: 76ers, Draft Protesters, Make Collins Top Choice
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, selecting first in the National Basketball Association's college draft, picked Doug Collins of Illinois State yesterday even as they were threatening to make the whole draft process illegal. Collins is a 6foot6inch guard who was on the United States Olympic team last year.

title: SLAYER, RICHEY TENNIS VICTORS
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, April 24 (UPI)Rod Laver of Australia went into action today and defeated Rob Maud of South Africa 63, 64, in the first round of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis. Group A tournament.

title: Health Aim For Nation Is at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, April 24In its efforts to set longrange health and medical research policies for the nation, the Nixon Administration clearly feels beleaguered, by what it regards as spendthrifts.

title: DATA FROM TAPS REPORTEDLY SENT TO WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Federal investigators have determined that officials of the White House were regularly kept informed last May and June of some of the information obtained through the illegal wiretapping of the Democratic National Committee headquarters, sources close to the case said today.

title: Oil Companies Charged
description: DENVER, April 24 (AP)United States Attorney Theodore S. Halaby, invoking a 50yearold law that was intended to protect migratory birds from poachers, charged seven Denverbased oil companies today with killing migratory birds by allowing oil sludge ponds to become covered with oil. The misdemeanor charges carry a maximum $500 fine per count.

title: DC10 Fills With Smoke
description: CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI) Seven persons suffered smoke inhalation yesterday when the cabin of a Philadelphiabound United Air Lines DC10 filled with smoke shortly after the plane took off from O'Hare International Airport.

title: Greek Magistrates Rule a Paper Guilty Of Subversive Act
description: ATHENS, April 24A Council of Magistrates ruled today that publication of an antiGovernment statement from former Premier Constantine Caramanlis constituted an act of subversion, and the police tonight were looking for two executives of the Athens newspaper that first printed it.

title: Watergate Is Remote to Muncie
description: MUNCIE, Ind., April 24The sun has been shining on Muncie for the last two days and, after a spring plagued by rain, that seems to surprise and interest folks here more than the daily revelations about the Watergate scandal emerging from the nations capital.

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary offering of 375,000 shares of Lawson Products, Inc., common at $19 per share was made by underwriters headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon and Bacon, Whipple & Co.

title: Senators Leave Soviet: One Met Jews
description: MOSCOW, April 24Seven American Senators ended fiveday visit to the Soviet Union today after one of them met secretly with prominent Moscow Jews to get their views on the controversial emigration issue.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Off at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: STOCK FRAUD CITED IN INDICTMENT OF 13
description: Individuals reputedly active in organized crime were among 13 persons indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan in an alleged conspiracy to cheat investors in stock in a concern established to lease luxury automobiles.

title: Atlanta Strikes an Integration Bargain
description: ATLANTA, April 24This predominantly black city, long a bellwether in the civil rights struggle, has adopted a controversial, minimumdesegregation school plan that some race experts think could affect the integration picture all across the United States.

title: CRATER ERUPTIONS REPORTED CURBED
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mich., April 24 (UPI)Progress was reported today in the effort to relieve underground gas pressure responsible for, more than 100 geyserlike eruptions in this craterscarred resort area.

title: Business Briefs
description: Torrential rain that has fallen in the last two weeks has forced sharp curtailments of paper manufacturing in an area covering East Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas and Mississippi. The International Paper Company said yesterday that it had ordered curtailments in six of its primary mills in the South, and had put customers on allocations.

title: Sharp Response to Hanoi Disclosed by Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The United States made public today a sharply worded reply to Hanoi's charges of ceasefire violations, accusing the North Vietnamese of direct and inexcusable breaches of the threemonthold Vietnam accord.

title: Stock Prices Plunge
description: The stock market suffered one of its worst setbacks in nearly three, years yesterday in moderate trading. The DowJones industrial average slid 14.60 points and closed at 940.77. Wall Street's malaise deepened after Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, hinted Monday afternoon that the Administration would consider a tax increase to combat inflation. Page 57.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs Growing Weird
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 24  The wild fluctuations of form that have marked the National Basketball Association playoffs were still in evidence today following a 117109 victory by the Golden State Warriors over the Los Angeles Lakers here last night.

title: Queens Man Changing Tire Shot 3 Times From a Car
description: A Queens building contractor, who was changing a flat tire near his home at 15110 84th Drive, Kew Gardens, was shot three times and critically wounded by assailants who made their escape in a green sedan.

title: NIXON NOULD SIGN A NEIN CHARTER IN EUROPE IN FALL
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Highranking Administration officials said today that Henry A. Kissinger's call yesterday for a new Atlantic charter was meant to signal Western European leaders  that President Nixon wants to sign a major document of agreed principles when he visits their countries later this year.

title: Dance: Sleeping Beauty
description: Rudolf Nureyev is back in town, this time with the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House. It may seem a little unfair to mention Mr. Nureyev before mentioning the company, but the two of them do get equal billing in all, publicity and while one expects Mr. Nureyev at the Metropolitan it seems possible that the Canadians, who were making their Manhattan debut, might not have made the trip without him.

title: STOCKS SUPPER ANOTHER SETBACK
description: The malaise oppressing Wall Street deepened yesterday and the stockmarket suffered one of its worst setbacks in nearly three years.

title: Moet Will Make California Wine
description: PARIS, April 24 (UPI)The Mat et Chandon champagne firm has bought land in California to make a sparkling wine in the United States, a spokesman said today.

title: JULIUS J. GANS DIES; EXSTATE JUSTICE, 77
description: Julius J. Gans, a retired justice of the State Supreme Court who served in the Assembly from 1936 to 1954, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 44 East 67th Street.

title: FirstQuarter Orders Up For British Shipbuilders
description: LONDON, April 24 (UPI) British shipbuilding concerns obtained orders for 64 merchant ships of 570,200 compensated tons (1,292,800 gross tons) in the first quarter of 1973, the Shipbuilders and Repairers National Association announced today. This compared with 17 ships of 81,200 compensated tons (142,600 gross tons) in the first three months of 1972.

title: CAMDIENS ON TOP, 53, OUST FLYERS
description: MONTREAL, April 24 (UPI) Henri Richard backhanded in the winning goal at 12 minutes 7 seconds of the third period as the Montreal Canadiens eliminated the Philadelphia Flyers from the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight with a 53 victory.

title: Sharp Response to Hanoi Disclosed by Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The United States made pubilic today a sharply worded reply to. Hanoi's charges of ceasefire violations, accusing the North Vietnamese of direct and inexcusable breaches of the threemonthold Vietnam accord.

title: Top Man in Uniform
description: I feel like the actor who's been practicing his trade for 20 or 25 years and suddenly he's in a big hita smash hitand everyone wonders about his overnight success, Hugo J. Masini said yesterday after Donald F. Cawley, the Police Commissionerdesignate, named him the department's top uniformed policeman. Actually, Chief Masini added; I've been in this department for 22 years16 years as superior officer. And I've worked at being a manager, I've studied, and my career wasn't quite the meteoric rise that people think.

title: Advertising: The Name Is News
description: At the end of their annual meeting yesterday the members of the 60yearold Bureau of Advertising voted to change its name to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. It's only right, since that's the only kind of advertising it's interested in.

title: Kent Leavitt Dies at 69; Led Soil Conservationists
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., April 24 Kent Leavitt, a past president of the National Association of Soil Conservation Districts, died yesterday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at Fraleigh Hill Farm, where he raised Hereford cattle.

title: Maine Kills Shield Law
description: AUGUSTA, Me., April 24 (AP)The House today closed the door at this session to any kind of shield law for Maine news reporters. Without debate, Representatives refused to join with Senators in a conference committee and adhered to their position against protection for newspeople who refused to reveal confidential sources

title: Red Smith
description: Shortly after 9 P.M. Perry Smith took a chair in a cramped cell on the fourth floor, the operating level of Madison Square Garden. On the wall facing him were 10 television monitorseight small blackandwhite sets and two larger screens in color. Most showed a Roller Derby girl in the Garden's main arena chopping another girl with karate blows, but a technician touched a switch and one color set brought in the Felt Forum ring where a preliminary bout was in progress. Talking around the stub of a cigar, Smith spoke into a headset: Are the talents anywhere near their mikes? Got their headsets on? Can you hear me, Don Dunphy?

title: Sports News Briefs
description: U.C.L.A. Vetoes China Trip

title: U.S. Said to Pick Its Peking Office
description: PEKING, April 22The new United States liaison mission in Peking is likely to be housed near a park called Altar of the Sun in the eastern part of the city.

title: Oil Strike in Ecuador
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 24, (Reuters)Cayman del Ecuador, an American oil concern, struck petroleum in the fourth well it drilled in eastern Ecuadorthe third productive wel lof its four drillingsthe Natural Resources Ministry said here today.

title: State Panel to Recommend a Pay Rise for Legislators
description: ALBANY, April 24A state Commission studying the salaries of legislators and members of the judiciary met secretly in New York City today and is expected to recommend shortly substantial increases for the state's 210 Senators and Assemblymen.

title: COTTON FUTURES ADVANCE FURTHER
description: Cotton futures prices con tinued to move up yesterday, still responding to talk of flooding in the cottongrowing areas along the Mississippi River. The National Weather Service expects the river to crest at a record high tomorrow.

title: The Crisis Ghost Goes West
description: ATHENSAn extensive survey of the PacificAsian area leads to one paramount conclusion: the storm center has moved westward. It is no longer Southeast and South Asian regions that threaten world conflict. Now we are back to square onethat Southwest Asian area known as the Middle East.

title: Texts of Notes by North Vietnam and U.S. Sent to Peace Conference Participants
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Following, as made public by the State Department today, are the texts of notes distributed to the countries that participated in the recent Paris conference on Vietnam, by North Vietnam on April 16 and by the United States over last weekend:

title: School Board Campaign In Brooklyn Sparks Battle
description: Two weeks ago, 42 candidates were vying for the nine seats on the school board in Brooklyn's District 13. Yesterday that number was down to 31 as a result of a well  financed legal battle over the validity of nominating petitions that left many of the candidates convinced that the United Federation of Teachers had allied with a local politician to eliminate some candidates in Tuesday's election.

title: Paul Miller, Gannett Head, Reelected A.P. Chairman
description: Paul Miller, chairman and chief executive of the Gannett Company, was reelected chairman of The Associated Press at its annual meeting yesterday.

title: Man, 26, Is Slain Leaving a Bank On West 102d St.
description: The 26yearold son of an Abraham & Straus vice president was shot and killed just before 1 P.M. Monday after he and a friend had left a bank at Broadway and 102d Street.

title: Congolese Forces Report the Killing Of Rebel Leader
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, April 24 (AP)  The leader of the Congolese guerrilla movement and his deputy were killed early today by security forces, according to an announcement broadcast by the Brazzaville radio.

title: MRS. RYAN LIABLE FOR EXTRADITION
description: Federal Judge Jacob Mishler ruled in Brooklyn yesterday that Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan was not an American citizen and therefore could be expatriated to West Germany to face charges that she murdered inmates of a Nazi death camp.

title: Japan Food Deal Sought
description: The General Foods Corporation and the Ajinomoto Company, Inc., Tokyo, Japan, announced yesterday that they had begun negotiations to establish a joint venture in Japan. The venture would be created by Ajinomoto's acquisition of a onehalf interest in General Foods' Japanese subsidiary, General Foods, Ltd.

title: Tracks in Jersey Granted 45 More Dates This Year
description: TRENTON, April 24 (AP)Racing fans in New Jersey will have an additional 45 days to place their bets this year under the terms of a bill signed today by Gov. William T. Cahill.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: June Hart, the 20yearold daughter of Mayor William S. Hart of East Orange, was sentenced yesterday to a fourtosixyear term on, a manslaughter conviction for fatally stabbing a girlfriend last October. The sentence was handed down by Superior Court Judge Leon Milmed despite a plea from Miss Hart's lawyer, Raymond Brown, that his client not be imprisoned. He said a prison term could destroy the fabric within her.

title: JAPAN BARS VISIT OF HIROHITO TO U.S.
description: TOKYO, April 24Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira disclosed today that his Government had rejected President Nixon's invitation to Emperor Hirohito to make a state visit to the United States.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Arab Attacks on Jewish Issue Seem to Be Worrying Vatican
description: ROME, April 24The Vatican appears worried by a series Arab, attacks on the Roman Catholic Church following declaration by France's bishops upholding the Jewish people's right to nationhood.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro Against the U.S. Dollar
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 24 (AP)Brazil devalued the cruzeiro today, setting the buying rate at 6.06 a United States dollar and the selling rate at 6.1.

title: SURGE BY ASTROS DEFEATS METS, 42
description: HOUSTON, April 24  Rapping Jon Matlack, a lefthander, for eight of their nine hits, the Houston Astros stretched their longest winning streak of the season to six games tonight, defeating the New York Mets, 42, before a crowd of 12,759 in the Astrodome.

title: Lockheed Profit Steady
Athenian Jews Act to Save Synagogues in Ancient Zone
description: ATHENS, April 24The Athens Jewish community has taken legal action to save this city's only two synagogues from demolition for archeological exploration.

title: Lon Nol Brings Opponents Into Cambodian Council
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 24The executive leadership of Cambodia became fourman council today under an agreement by which President Lon Nol will share power equally with three leading political opponents.

title: TV: Trip to The Forbidden Desert of the Danakil
description: An hourlong camera exploration of remote northeastern Ethiopia, titled The Forbidden Desert of the Danakil, makes fascinating watching tonight at 8 over the Columbia. Broadcasting System intelligently assem. bled, brimming with color and boldly scanning a rarely visited area and people, this is the kind of armchair tray el that home viewers crave and seldom get.

title: A Deputy Commissioner Picked for Banking Unit
description: TRENTON, April 24 (AP)The State Banking Commissioner, Richard F. Schaub, announced today the appointment of Philip A. Kerner as deputy commissioner of the State Department of Banking.

title: Monopolies and Prices
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) An investigation of the role that monopolistic practices are playing in the increase in food prices were announced today by the chairman of the House antitrust subcommittee, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. Democrat of New Jersey.

title: Black Hawks Sink Rangers, 41
description: CHICAGO, April 24  The year that was supposed to belong to the Rangers ended abruptly tonight before a bellowing Chicago Stadium crowd as the Black Hawks crushed another New York dream with a 41 victory.

title: Resignation at Royal Inns
description: SAN DIEGO, April 24 (AP)Earl Gagosian resigned today as chairman of Royal Inns of America, Inc., a financially troubled motor hotel chain which he founded in 1965. Harry Henke 3d, who succeeded Mr. Gagosian, 49, as president March 13, made the announcement.

title: Stock Prices Plunge
description: The stock market suffered one of its worst setbacks in nearly three years yesterday in moderate trading. The DowJones industrial average slid 14.60 points and closed at 940.77. Wall Street's malaise deepened after Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, hinted Monday afternoon that the Administration would consider a tax increase to combat inflation. Page 57.

title: 11 Held in Marijuana Raids
description: BEAUFORT, S. C., April 24 (UPI)United States Customs agents, state policemen and sheriff's deputies arrested 11 persons and confiscated two tons of marijuna in a series of raids last night and early today. Leonard W. Larson, chief customs agent in Charleston, said the marijuna was packed in burlap bags inside two camperpickup trucks and a trailer, and in a house on nearby Ladies Island.

title: U.S. Space Observers Suspect Catastrophic Failure of Salyut
description: American space experts strongly suspect that a catastrophic failure connected with the Soviet Union's Salyut 2 prevented Soviet astronauts from making an attempt to man the large, earthorbiting space station.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The behindthescenes story of how the almost legendary Carl Akeley collected animals in Africa and started a new art form in displaying the mounted specimens is told in a new exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: MRS. BOOTH VICTOR IN PINEHURST GOLF
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 24 (AP)Mrs. Jane Booth, finishing with a holeinone, opened a spectacular defense of her North and South amateur golf. championship today with an impressive 5and3 victory over Nancy Hager.

title: Hydrofoil Service Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)A cruise ship line plans to use hydrofoils to link Annapolis, Md., with Williamsburg and Norfolk, Va., t was announced today.

title: Jury Here Hears Mitchell; He Denies a Tie to Vesco
description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell testified before a Federal grand jury here yesterday, apparently about a $200,000 cash contribution from Robert L. Vesco to President Nixon's 1972 election campaign.

title: 125 Tractors From Soviet Being Returned by Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 24 (UPI)  Chile's leftist Government said today that it would return 125 Soviet tractors that it said proved unsuitable for the country's terrain.

title: NEW PLAN URGED FOR BICENTENNIAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 24A House Judiciary subcommittee will propose legislation to reorganize the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission in a way similar to an Administration proposal. However, it will seek to retain more Congressional control over the controversial commission's activities, according to informed sources.

title: Owner of an Art Gallery Found Slain in Apartment
description: Robert Dain, proprietor of Madison Avenue art gallery, was found stabbed to death last night in his apartment nearby. He had been reported missing by gallery associates when he failed to appear at a showing earlier yesterday.

title: $19MILLION LOSS SHOWN BY PAN AM
description: Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported a net loss of $19.1million in the first quarter this year, an Improvement on the $30.9million deficit reported in the first quarter of 1972.

title: Hamilton Fish Armstrong Dies at 80; Foreign Affairs Quarterly ExEditor
description: Hamilton Fish Armstrong, an authority on international politics and editor of the quarterly Foreign Affairs for 44 years until his retirement last fall, died yesterday, at the New York University Medical Center after a long illness. He was 80 years old on April 7.

title: Talks Continued On Goodyear Pact As Deadline Passes
description: CINCINNATI, Wednesday, April 25 (UPI)The United Rubber Workers Union and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company continued their contract negotiations today past a midnight strike deadline, but there were no reports on how the talks were going.

title: Nader Asks Open Meetings
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court today to force the Cost of Living Council to open meetings of its advisory committees to the public. He asserted that the council had violated the Federal Advisory Committee Act by denying the public knowledge of the advisory committees' discussions.

title: Supreme Court Limits Entrapment Defense in Upholding Conviction of Amphetamine Dealer on Coast
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Supreme Court ruled today that a criminal defendant cannot contend he has been unfairly trapped by undercover Government agents if they helped, him commit the crime but did not give him the idea in the first place.

title: Stage: Phantasmagoria
description: Vasek Simek is the director and, one assumes, the uncredited compiler of A Phantasmagoria Historia of D. Johann Fausten Magister, PhD, MD, OD, DL, Etc., which opened last night at the Truck and Warehouse Theater.

title: MRS. HERMAN R. REISSIG
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., April 24Mrs. Frances Emerson Reissig, the wife of, the Rev. Dr. Herman R. Reissig, died yesterday at her home, Deepwoods Lane. She was 67 years old.

title: A MahlerCooke Concert Given
description: There is a certain innocent esthetic pleasure, in which the sinful shiver of skepticism nonetheless plays a part, to be had from contemplating a Greek vase, say, that some expert has pieced together from fragments and restored in what he hopes was the artist's style. Hearing Mahler's Symphony No. 10, a work he sketched out completely but did not live to orchestrate, provides a similar experience. The very presence of doubt adds to the tension and the excitement.

title: BELL DEBENTURES HAVE BRISK SALE
People in Sports: Smith Shocked by Apartheid
description: Apparently shocked by what he described as apartheid at close quarters, Stan Smithi the top ranking United States tennis player, said he would think carefully before returning to South Africa. The 1972 Wimbledon champion teamed with Bob Lutz to win a Johannesburg tournament Monday on his first visit to South Africa. After touring Soweto, an area of African towns near Johannesburg, Smith said, It looked to me like a huge concentration camp. I know we have our Harlems and I've seen discrimination in the Communist countries, but the stark division of black and white here makes it appear worse.

title: Lansky Denied New Trial
description: MIAMI, April 24 (AP)United States District Judge James Lawrence King has refused to grant Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld financial manipulator, a new trial on charges of criminal contempt. Lansky, who is recovering from open heart surgery, was convicted Feb. 28 of contempt in refusing to leave Israel to appear before a Miami grand jury.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 25, 1973

title: Monopolies and Prices
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) An investigation of the role that monopolistic practices are playing in the increase in food prices were announced today by the chairman of the House antitrust subcommittee, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

title: A.H.L. PLAYOFFS
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Tombs Prisoner Stabbed By 2d Inmate in Quarrel
description: An inmate of the Manhattan House of Detention for Men who is the editor of the prison newspaper was stabbed in the chest last night by another, Tombs inmate, according to the police.

title: Gasoline Shortage Spreads
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., April 24 (AP)At least 30 gas stations in Massachusetts owned by members of an organization of independent gasoline dealers have closed because of fuel shortages and rationing. Harvey Alford of the Private Brand Gasoline Maketers of New England said 280 employes in Massachusetts have lost their jobs because of the closings.

title: ICELAND FIRES ON BRITISH TRAWLERS
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 24 (AP)  Icelandic coastguard vessels fired live shells and peppered British fishing trawlers with rifle fire in a flareup of the long dispute over fishing rights.

title: 5 Killed and 11 Wounded In a Mekong Delta Blast
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 24 (Reuters)  A bomb explosion in a crowded restaurant yesterday killed five people and wounded 11, the military command reported today.

title: 250 Camp in 76th Street for $350 Jobs
description: It was 6 P.M. Easter Sunday when Jack Dunn set up his folding chair outside the headquarters of Local 46 of the Metallic Lathers Union, at 1322 Third Avenue. By last night more than 250 men had lined up behind Mr. Dunn, turning 76th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues into a makeshift campgrounds.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Thirtyseven grants totaling more than $1.1million to municipalities, planning and environmental groups in 34 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia for City Edges projects have been announced in Washington by Nancy Hanks, :chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. City Edges is the first phase of a longrange program under the Endowment's Architecture and Environmental Arts Program, created to focus on problems of urban design and planning.

title: BIAGGI PUTS REPLY ON 5MINUTE TAPE
description: Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday taped his fiveminute television reply to reports that he invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury and then told political supporters that he had answered all the jury's questions.

title: Arnold Constable Tries GiveAway Experiment
description: Arnold Constable, Inc., a Fifth Avenue specialty store with a branch in West Orange, N. J., is conducting a twoweek experimental imitation of the current bank premium promotions by offering gifts to customers. Firstday response increased the store's average unit sale, Merwin Bayer, president, said yesterday.

title: Sunoco Cuts Back Gasoline For Dealers in 34 States
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP)Gasoline allocations to retail dealers are being cut back throughout the Sun Oil Company's 34state marketing territory, a company spokesman said today.

title: PUERTO RICO SEEKS JAPAN INVESTMENT
description: Plans to attract increased Japanese manufacturing investment to Puerto Rico were announced yesterday by the island commonwealth's Economic Development Administration.

title: Roundup: Expos Win, 72, Getting Seven Runs in 9th
description: The Montreal Expos erupted for seven runs in the ninth inning to score a 72 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in Riverfront Stadium last night. The defeat dropped the Reds two games behind San Francisco's Western Division leaders in the National League.

title: Spingarn Medal Awarded
description: Wilson C. Riles, superintendent of Public Instruction in California, was named yesterday the 58th recipient of the Springarn Medal by the National Association for the Advancenent of Colored People.

title: SABIN LINKS VIRUS TO 9 CANER TYPES
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Dr. Albert B. Sabin, whose vaccine has eliminated polio as a widespread health problem in large areas of the world, claimed proof today that a common virus is a causative factor in nine types of human cancer.

title: An Unusual Float
description: WASHINGTON, April 24A funny thing is happening with the world's experimental system of floating currency exchange rates. The only significant managing of the float through central bank intervention in daily foreign exchange tradingwhich some people still refer to by the less friendly term of dirty floating  apparently is being done by Japan, and it is being done to keep the exchange rate of the yen high rather than low.

title: Rockefeller CourtReform Plan Stirs Both Praise and Criticism
description: Governor Rockefeller's package of courtreform proposals continued to draw a mixed response yesterday, with the chief judge of the state praising it as a positive step forward and Democratic contender for the job of chief judge criticizing it as a plan to make the courts more dependent on politics than ever.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MORRISTOWN, April 24  Hunting remains legal in Morris Township, but members of this community's two gun clubs are aware they may soon have to set their sights in other directions.

title: DECLASSIFICATION OF DATA REPORTED
description: MIAMI, April 24The Government said today that substantial progress had been made in reducing the number of classified documents in its files.

title: DATA ARE SOUGHT FOR TRADE TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI) Ambassador William D. Eberle, special United States trade negotiator, today invited trade association representatives to pour in data to help the United States trade negotiators build their case.

title: Nixon Election Unit Linked to Campaign On Vietnam Mining
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Nixon reelection organization attempted last May to generate a favorable public response to the President's decision to mine Haiphong harbor in North Vietnam, The Washington Post reported tonight.

title: Urban Pollution: 38 Cities Are Told Their Efforts to Clean the Air Aren't Good Enough
description: The nation's efforts to ameliorate its air pollution have become so complex administratively that any citizen could be forgiven for being as confused on the subject as a Tibetan at a baseball game.

title: WEAN BRADLEY DOCK UNION BEAD
description: Capt. William V. Bradley, president emeritus of the International Longshoremen's Association, died Monday night near his home. in Staten Island when his auto crashed into a parked car. His age was 70. He had lost control of his car after suffering a heart attack.

title: Du Pont Dumping Curb Asked
description: HOUSTON, April 27 (UPI)The Environmental Protection Agency has been asked to prohibit du Pont industries from dumping 66,000 tons of toxic, chemical wastes into the Gulf of Mexico and off the East Coast every month. Many or all of these wastes would be expected to be extremely toxic to marine life, Jack W. Gehringer of the National Marine Fisheries Service told an E.P.A. hearing yesterday.

title: Weicker Says He Has No Data Linking Nixon to Bugging Plot
description: HARTFORD, April 24Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Connecticut Republican who has been pressing for a full disclosure of the Watergate case, said today he had no evidence that would indicate President Nixon knew about the bugging in advance or subsequently tried to cover it up.

title: Nixon Talked to Lawyer For 2 White House Aides
description: WASHINGTON, April 24President Nixon met for an hour here last Thursday with John J. Wilson, a Washington lawyer who is representing two Presidential aides, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman in connection with the Water gate scandal.

title: Byrne Quits Court to Run For Jersey Governorship
description: TRENTON, April 24  Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne, who a Mafia figure in New Jersey once said couldn't be bought, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: OIL PLAN SCORED BY EXXON'S HEAD
description: TOKYO, April 24  The head the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, opposed proposals today for the creation of a bargaining bloc of oilconsuming nations, such as the plan that the Nixon Administration is reported to be preparing.

title: Records: Opera With Music by Ezra Pound Proves Fascinating
description: Ezra Pound is, to put it mildly, not well known as a composerhe even described himsef once as an incompetent amateur in that regard. But he did have something of a musical background, he did practice music criticism and he did, in fact, compose. Fantasy Records in Berkeley, Calif., has now recorded his opera, Le Testament de Villon (12001, $4.98), and it turns out to be an altogether fascinating piece of work.

title: Europeans Welcome Plan For New Atlantic Charter
description: LONDON, April 24  The United States' proposal for a new Atlantic charter was generally welcomed today in European capitals, where officials said that it provided new vision of if not new solutions to vexing problems in the alliance.

title: Ban on Antibiotic Ilosone Urged; Eli Lilly Defends Drug's Record
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Health Research Group, a consumeroriented organization affiliated with Ralph Nader, has petitioned the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to bar from the market one brand of the antibiotic drug erythromycin.

title: CEMENT STRIKE ENDS AS PACT IS REACHED
description: A oneday strike of concretetruck drivers that had blocked most deliveries of cement and concrete to construction sites was settled early yesterday after allnight negotiations.

title: Blighted Study
description: The study commission created by Governor Rockefeller and the State Legislature two years ago to investigate the governmental organization and practices of New York City has completed its work without ever succeeding in separating itself from the allconsuming hostility between the Governor and Mayor Lindsay.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Patrolman Is Retired By Police Department
description: The Police Department yesterday announced the abolition of the words patrolman and policewoman from its official lexicon.

title: Cahill Signs Campaign Disclosure Bill
description: TRENTON, April 24Governor Cahill signed a tough campaign disclosure bill into law today even as a Federal investigation of fundraising activities for the Governor's 1969 campaign produced its first indictment.

title: Teamster Aide Arrested
description: COACHELLA, Calif., April 24 (UPI)The top organizer for the teamsters union in the vineyards of Coachella Valley was arrester! today for shoving member or me opposing United Farm Workers Union. The organizer, Al Droubie, was cited or battery and was ordered to appear in court at a later time.

title: Stockpile Sales Opposed
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 24 (AP)The Association of Natural Rubber Producing Countries has declared it will oppose increased disposals of the United States rubber stockpile.

title: Maye Is Defeated As Firemen's Union Elects President
description: After five years as president of the 11,000member Uniformed Firefighters Association, Michael J. Maye has been defeated in a bid for reelection for a twoyear, term.

title: People and Business
description: Frederick G. Uhlmann one of the country's bestknown commodities dealers and the chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, is planning to leave H. Hentz & Co., Inc., where he is a senior vice president. It was learned yesterday that he will join Drexel Burnham & Co., an investmentbanking and brokerage concern that will establish a commodities department.

title: PrimeTime Coverage On Watergate Slated
description: The public Broadcasting Service announced yesterday it would make available in prime time, its gaveltogavel coverage of the Sen ate Select Committee's Wiv tergate hearings,, which are expected to begin May 15.

title: Health Aim For Nation Is at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, April 24In its efforts to set longrange health and medical research policies for the nation, the Nixon Administration clearly feels beleaguered by what it regards as spendthrifts.

title: Pro Playoff Results and Schedules
description: EASTERN CONFERENCE FINALS

title: BACKER OP CAHILL INDICTED BY U.S.
description: NEWARK, April 24A Bergen County trading stamp and supermarket chain executive was indicted today on charges that he lied in saying that a $5,000 contribution to Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign fund was a legitimate business expense.

title: Ellsberg's Attorneys Contradicted by F.B.I. Agent
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent testified today that Morton H. Halperin, a former Defense Department official, had said that he sent the Pentagon papers to the Rand Corporation for storage acting as an official of the United States Government.

title: BONN SAYS BREZHNEV WILL ARRIVE MAY 18
description: BERLIN, April 24A West German Government spokesman announced in Bonn today that the West German visit of Leonid I. Brezhnev would take place May 18 to May 22, a week later than originally planned.

title: Byrne Quits Court to Run For Jersey Governorship
description: TRENTON, April 24  Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne, who a Mafia figure in New Jersey once said couldn't be bought, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: CONFLICT CHARD TO EXSTATE AIDE
description: TRENTON, April 24  Former Deputy Attorney General David A. Biederman, who touched off a Federal grandjury investigation that led to the indictment of former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin on extortion and conspiracy charges, heard himself charged with a conflict of interest today in a hearing before the. State Supreme Court.

title: 4 Winners Ease Turcotte's Pain
description: While his slightly tarnished big horse relaxed in Kentucky, Ron Turcotte rode four winners at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Kissinger's Europe
description: With his call for a fresh act of creation equal the effort that built the Marshall Plan and the Atlantic Alliance after World War II, Henry A. Kissinger has tried to project the outline of President Nixon's Year Europe. If the new Atlantic Charter envisioned by Mr. Kissinger in his address to The Associated Press luncheon in New York is still a hazy concept, its general form may be beginning to take shape.

title: JAPAN BARS VISIT OF HIROHITO TO U.S.
description: TOKYO, April 24Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira disclosed today that his Government had rejected President Nixon's invitation to Emperor Hirohito to make a state visit to the United States.

title: Goals at Kodak And at Polaroid
description: The Polaroid Corporation and the Eastman Kodak Company told shareholders at their annual meetings yesterday of planned new products and of efforts to advance instant photography.

title: Lawyers Worried by Nixon's Influence Over Investigation of Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The extent of President Nixon's influence over the Watergate investigation is a matter of growing concern among former members of the Justice Department and among legal scholars and lawyers associated with the case.

title: India Cites Food Shortages
description: NEW DELHI, April 24 (AP)The Government said today that food shortages in some parts of India were acute and authorities were straining to avert famine.

title: Celanese Forms 3Man Top Office
description: Culminating five years of restructing, the Celanese Corporation annonuced yesterday that It had formed a new threemember corporate office to develop growth strategies.

title: U.S. M inesweeper Crew Rescued by Scottish Ship
description: HONOLULU, April 24 (AP) A Scottish freighter today rescued all 65 crewmen of a Navy minesweeper eight hours after the woodenhulled ship burned and sank in the Philippine Sea, the Navy announced. The crew of the 750ton Force was reported in good condition aboard the Spraynes which took the sailors from lifeboats and rafts 280 miles west of Guam in the MarianaIslands, the Navy said.

title: $1Billion Is Asked for Stewart Airport
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority made public yesterday a longawaited blueprint from consultants recommending a $1billion transformation of Stewart Airport near Newburgh into a major facility that, by 1990, would handle almost twice the traffic Kennedy International Airport handles today.

title: A.H.L. PLAYOFFS
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: JETS TOPPLE AEROS FOR 3D IN ROW, 4 TO 2
description: HOUSTON, April 24 (AP) Chris Bordeleau of Winnipeg scored at 17:49 of the third period to end a Houston rally and give the Jets a 42 victory tonight in the World Hockey Association Western Division playoff.

title: Ceremony Welcomes Arrival Here of the New Cruise Liner Volendam
description: The 23,395ton Holland America cruise liner Volendam arrived here yesterday from European ports to take up station here. The 617foot steamship was accorded the traditional port welcome for new ships, complete with fireboat salute and surface and aerial escort.

title: Notes on People
description: It was within the last year, the State Department said, that Hertz refused to put Ambassador David K. E. Bruce in the driver's seat of one of its cars at Washington National Airport. The department said that Mr. Bruce, who is to head the American liaison office in Peking, had flown in from the Paris peace talks and needed a car to drive to his Virginia home. But because he had no credit cards with him, the Hertz clerk would not rent him a car. Hertz later apologized and, apparently trying harder, another carrental agency learned of the matter and sent the Ambassador a credit card.

title: Man, 26, Is Slain Leaving a Bank On West 102d St.
description: The 26yearold son of an Abraham & Straus vice president was shot and killed just before 1 P.M. Monday after he arid a friend had left a bank at Broadway and 102d Street.

title: Atlanta Strikes an Integration Bargain
description: ATLANTA, April 24This predominantly black city, long a bellwether in the civil rights struggle, has adopted a controversial, minimumdesegregation school plan that some race experts think could affect the integration picture all across the United States.

title: BRITISH PATROLS FIRED ON IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 24 (Reuters)  British troops came under fire twice in the Londonderry area today. A patrol in one of the city's Roman Catholic areas, Creggan Estate, clashed with a stonethrowing crowd and a nail bomb went off harmlessly near other soldiers.

title: TowTruck Driver Is Shot By Gunmen in Passing Car
description: A civilian towtruck driver for the Poke Department, Angel Anzisi, was wounded last night when motorists in a passing car fired at him with a revolver and a shotgun as he sat in his parked truck on 11th Avenue at 26th Street, the police reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: M'GRAWHILL ASSAYS TEXTBOOKS' OUTLOOK
description: Optimism for textbook publishing was exaggerated eight years ago just as the pessimism of investors is exaggerated today, Shelton Fisher, president of McGrawHill, Inc., said yesterday at the annual meeting here. He said today's attitude stems from a threatened reduction in Federal aid.

title: Stockholders. Get Together
description: In a flurry of annual meetings, some 145 major corporations confronted their stockholders yesterday in New York and other parts of the country. Today, 103 more annual meetings are scheduled, to be followed by 96 tomorrow and 42 on Friday.

title: District Has 22 Schools And 26,000 Students
description: School District 13 in Brooklyn covers all of Brooklyn Heights and Fort Greene, a small part of Park Slope and a large chunk of BedfordStuyvesant. There are 26.000 students in the district's four junior high and 18 elementary schools.

title: Terror Is Past, but Calcutta Is Uneasy Over Repression
description: CALCUTTA, India, April 21Two years after the Indian Government began to crack down on the Maoist guerrilla terrorists known as Naxalites, this uneasy city remains in the grip of a fierce police campaign that has Jed to charges of violent repression of dissidents.

title: ASH UNABLE TO SELL SOME LITTON STOCK
description: Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, has informed Representative Les Aspin he has not been able to sell 12,028 shares of his stock in Litton Industries, Inc., because it has been held as collateral for a bank loan made to a third party.

title: Let's Get All The Facts
description: The forgotten factor in the Watergate case is that it was only the most dramatic part of a much wider political conspiracy. Everybody seems to be concentrating now on punishing. the people who planned, financed or approved the illegal espionage against the Democrats at the Watergate, but very little attention is being paid to the people who organized the disruption and sabotage of the Democrats in the Presidential campaign.

title: U.S. Steel and Bethlehem Raise Earnings and Sales
description: The nation's two top steel producers, the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, and several major copper companies reported yesterday higher earnings, sales, production and shipments in the first three months.

title: CIVILIAN RELEASE DELAYED IN SOUTH
description: SAIGON, Wednesday, April 25 (Reuters)  The release of the first civilian prisoners of war in Vietnam was delayed today by a dispute between the Vietcong and South Vietnamese over their release sites.

title: Thornton, Former Penn Miler, Victor in His First Marathon
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 Karl Thornton, former University of Pennsylvania track captain, won the first marathan race to be staged at the Penn Relays today. It was the first time Thornton, from Binghamton, N.Y., had run a race of more than 20 miles.
