title: Texaco, Gulf and Other Oil Companies Lift Net Income
description: The oil industry delivered its own energy message yesterday: solid, acrosstheboard profits for the first quarter of 1973.

title: The Helmsman on the Right Course
description: WASHINGTON  Sir Winston Churchill once remarked: What's the use of being a famous race and nation if, at the end of the Week, You can't pay your housekeeping bill?.

title: Pathet Lao Says Vientiane And U.S. Sabotage Accord
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 24 (AP)  The Pathet Lao accused the Laotian Government today of delaying the formation of new provisional government by making unreasonable demands that do not conform to the February ceasefire accord signed by the two parties.

title: Ontario 500 Auto Race Is Saved
description: At long last there is now a concrete plan to run a 500mile race on Sept. 2 at Ontario Motor Speedway in California. A new management company headed by Anton (Tony) Hulman and Parnelli Jones has reached agreements with the United States Auto Club for a smaller purse and with the city of Ontario for a oneyear renewable contract. The arrangement preserves, at least for 1973, one of the units of USAC's triple crown of 500mile races; the others will run May 28 at Indianapolis and July 1 at Pocono International in Pennsylvania.

title: COLONELS OUST COUGARS, 10796
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 24 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels, getting 31 points from Dan Issel, never trailed as they registered a 10796 victory over the Carolina Cougars tonight for the East Division crown and a berth in the playoff finals against the Indiana Pacers for the American Basketball Association championship. The Colonels won the fourofsevengame series, 43.

title: Indians Set Up New Roadblock at Wounded Knee
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 24About 100 Oglala Sioux Indians defied the Justice Department this afternoon and set up a new roadblock on the trail to Wounded Knee.

title: NADJARI PRESSES INQUIRY IN QUEENS
description: Frederick J. Ludwig, the Acting District Attorney of Queens, was questioned at length yesterday by the state's anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: COURTS TO STRESS PUBLIC RELATIONS
description: The ranking judges of New York State announced yesterday that they were getting ready to open up the inner workings of the courts to the public and that they intended to set up a public relations department to help them do it.

title: American League
description: Wednesday, April 25, 1973 YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: They're Weaving A Story of War
description: SAIGON, South VietnamSome of South Vietnam's primitive Montagnard hill tribes, who traditionally weave into their fabrics the events around them, are now incorporating into standard designs all the accoutrements of modern warfare.

title: Political Trickery
description: So much publicity has been focused on the details of the Watergate affair that we are in danger of forgetting that the breakin itself was but a night's work in a much larger plan of infiltration and distortion. An enormous slush fund was established; a lawyer was put to work recruiting people to pose as bona fide volunteers for the Democratic campaign; finally, documents were forged purporting to contain the policies of Democratic campaigners in the effort to create bogus issues. It is hard to know just where the burglary fit into this de sign, but it is clear that it was part of a coordinated effort to know the opposition's plans and head them off.

title: MALALASEKERA, SRI LANKA ENVOY
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 24  Gunapala Piyasena Malalasekera, former representative of Sri Lanka (formerly Ceylon) to the United Nations, died last night. He was 73 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP)  The University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team announced today it had declined an invitation to visit the People's Republic of China. A U.C.L.A. spokesman said the team and coaches had been favorable to the idea during a meeting three weeks ago if the timing would not interfere with the academic calendar.

title: Paris Court Rules Reds Defamed Jews
description: PARIS, April 24A Frenchman who is general manager of the official Soviet Embassy newsletter in Paris was found guilty today of defamation, and incitement to racial hatred and violence for publishing an anti Jewish article.

title: National League
description: Wednesday, April 25, 1973

title: LEGISLATURE SET TO RESUME TODAY
description: ALBANY, April 24Fortified by a 12day EasterPassover vacation after completing 15 weeks of desultory sessions more notable for inertia than achievement, the Legislature resumes here tomorrow.

title: New Federal Policy on Secrecy Proves to Be Secret to Scientist
description: WASHINGTON, April 24What is the new Federal policy on secrecy in scientific research?

title: Garvin, Volatile Coach, Is Hired by Red Wings
description: DETROIT, April 24 (AP)Ted Garvin was hired today as coach of the National Hockey League's Detroit Red Wings and was expected to become hockey's counterpart of Billy Martin, the volatile manager of baseball's Detroit Tigers.

title: BACKER OF CAHILL INDICTED BY U.S.
description: NEWARK, April 24A Bergen County executive of a trading stamp and supermarket chain was indicted today on charges that he lied in saying that a $5,000 contribution to Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign fund was a legitimate business expense.

title: Medical Educators Here Alarmed by Proposed Slash in U.S. Funds
description: Nine medical educators from the metropolitan area met last week with editors and reporters of The New York Times and warned of a crisis in medical education and research in the years ahead if projected cuts in Federal support in these areas go through.

title: CON EDISON POSTS RISE IN EARNINGS
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first quarter of this year. Operating revenues rose to $425.1million from $369.4million in the 1972 period. Net income rose to $50million, or 71 cents a share from $45.5million, or 72 cents a share on fewer shares, in the three months ended March 31 1972.

title: Thornton, Former Penn Miler, Victor in His First Marathon
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 Karl Thornton, former University of Pennsylvania track captain, won the first marathan race to be staged at the Penn Relays today. It was the first time Thornton, from Binghamton, N.Y., had run a race of more than 20 miles.

title: Skylab Astronauts Enter Quarantine For May 15 Flight
description: HOUSTON, April 24 (AP)The Skylab 1 astronauts began today a quarantine designed to protect their health before they are launched into orbit May 15 for a 28day mission.

title: Hollywood Park Is Allowed To Extend Sunday Racing
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 (UPI)  The California Horse Racing Board today unanimously approved Sunday racing for the remainder of Hollywood Park's 15week season. The threemember board voted favorably on the track's application for Sunday racing days, saying there was nothing prohibiting it.

title: Original Cast Looks Back at Women
description: People were always dreaming up backstage feuds among us but there was nothing to itwe got along divinely, said Audrey Christie, a member of the original cast of Clare Boothe Luce's 1936 play, The Women.

title: Magnolia Magic
description: Now comes the time for the queenly magnolia whose gleaming white waxy blossoms shine with special radiance in the first rich light of the rising sun, and are hauntingly lovely in the soft glow of the waning moon.

title: TV: One Man's Campaign
description: Or the Public Broadcasting Service last night, Bill D. Moyers provided some public access television of his own, and the result was thoroughly absorbing. Expanding his weekly series to a full hour, Mr. Moyers presented a film called If Elected ..., produced, directed and photographed by Wayne Ewing, a 24yearold graduate of the University of Texas film School. The program will be repeated. on Channel 13 tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

title: Adventurous Spirit
description: Hamilton Fish Armstrong left his own valedictory in the pages of Foreign Affairs, the worldfamous quarterly he helped to found a halfcentury ago, of which he was the equally worldfamous editor for 44 years until his retirement last fall. Summing up his observations on international politics from the isolationist America of 1922 to what he warned was becoming the isolated America of 1972, Mr. Armstrong wrote in last October's issue:

title: Gasoline Truck Hijacked
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP)A hijacker drove of with 7,800 gallons of gasoline after blindfolding and handy cuffing a driver of a tank truck here early today. The police were told that the Sun Oil Company's cargo was valued at $2,800. The driver, Albert Jurich, 52 years old, said that he pulled into a station at 2:15 A.M. to make a delivery when an armed man accosted him.

title: Lon Nol Brings Opponents Into Cambodian Council
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 24The executive leadership of Cambodia became fourman council today under an agreement by which President Lon Nol will share power equally with three leading political opponents.

title: 13 White Sox Hits RoutYanks, 84
description: They held a sort of revival meeting at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, with the New York Yankees and Chicago White Sox both trying to recapture something from the past. But the Yankees found it less uplifting than the White Sox, who swatted out an 84 victory on 13 hits that included Ahree home runs.

title: Medical Educators Here Alarmed by Proposed Slash in U. S. Funds
description: Nine medical educators from the metropolitan area met last week with editors and reporters of The New York Times and warned of a crisis in medical education and research in the years ahead if projected cuts in Federal support in these areas go through.

title: Australia's Whitlam Expects Area to Act if France Tests
description: LONDON, April 25  Gough Whitelam, Australia's Labor party Prime Minister, said here today that further French atomic tests in the Pacific could disturb relations between Australia and France.

title: Chess: With Blunders Lying in Wait, Where Do Good Moves Hide?
description: The FrancoPolish grandmaster Savielly Tartakower once summed up chess strategy in his characteristically cynical humor by remarking, The mistakes are all there waiting to be made. One might well add that in most games they don't have to wait very long, either.

title: TREVINO FAVORED IN NELSON EVEN
description: DALLAS, April 25  Ma?? Spitz is no longer the pre tournament favorite suggeste George Connell, tournamen chairman of the Byron Nelso Golf Classic today as the su?? caused him to smile. Th?? course isn't a swimming po?? any longer. It's drying out ?? fine shape.

title: Natural Gas Geysers Make Michigan Town a Potential Bomb
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mich., April 25The first sign that Earl Gay's home was being threatened by an invisible, deadly force from deep within the earth was a small one.

title: MRS. RUTH H. WILSON
description: Mrs. Ruth H. Wilson, a former interior decorator and a charter member of the American Institute of Decorators, died yesterday at her home, 850 Park Avenue. She was 82 years old.

title: IRATE CAB DRIVERS TO DUMP LICENSES
description: The owners of more than 40 per cent of the nonmedallion taxis licensed by the city said yesterday that they would give up their licenses and go back to operating as gypsy cabs.

title: Winners in Lottery Get First Payment Of Lifetime Checks
description: Winners of the New York State Lottery's special $200aweekforlife drawing gathered at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday to collect their first monthly check and to toast their good fortune.

title: AGNEW CONFIRMS HIS FAITH IN NIXON ABOUT WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Vice President Agnew reiterated his faith in President Nixon today but conceded for the first time that some of the speculation on the Watergate scandal might eventually be substantiated.

title: COMPARES POINT TO PROFIT GAINS
description: Favorable profit results for the first quarter of this year were plentiful again yesterday for a variety of companies.

title: W.H.A.
description: EAST DIVISION FINALS

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: House in Hunt Country Built By President Kennedy Sold
description: MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 25 (UPI)A huntcountry home built by the late President Kennedy has been sold to a prominent Virginia businessman, W. Higgons Perry, it was learned today. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: ICKX, IN A FERRARI, IS FIRST AT MONZA
description: MONZA, Italy, April 25 (AP) Jacky Ickx of Belgium drove a Ferrari to victory in the 1,500kilometer Monza auto race today. It was the first suc cess for the Italian factory in this season's international automakers' championship.

title: ROGER COLEMAN
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 25Roger Coleman, president and founder of the Sandpiper Broadcasting Company, which operates station WWRTFM here, died Monday in Southampton Hospital.

title: Pike Blames the Public
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 25 (UPI)  Representative Otis G. Pike said today that the Watergate affair indicated that the American people have lost their capacity to he outraged. In a newsletter, the Suffolk County Congressman said he was forced to conclude that this is because most of them expect their public officials to he that bad.

title: No. 1 on 2 Pro Lists, Davis Awaits Offers
description: Money and security, scarce items in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, will determine whether Mel Davis signs a professional basketball contract or returns to St. John's University for his final collegiate season.

title: Sale Due Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Treasury, flush with cash,1 announced today that it would refinance only part of the $4.3billion of publicly held securities maturing May 15.

title: End of Universe in Black Hole Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, April 25A veteran explorer of gravitational theory told members of the National Academy of Sciences today that the collapse of the universe into a single, great black hole with the annihilation of all matter and all physical laws seemed ultimately inevitable.

title: Woman, 84, Falls to Death
description: Hattie Smith, 84 years old, who lived alone at 1919 Seventh Avenue at West 116th Street, fell to her deaht at A.M. yesterday from the bedroom window of her fourthfloor apartment.

title: G.E. Defeats Church Plans
description: DENVER, April 25  General Electric stockholders today defeated proposals sponsored by church groups that challenged the company's policies in South Africa and on production of military weapons.

title: Two U.S. Aides in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 25  Kenneth Rush, a United States Deputy Secretary of State, and Joseph Sisco, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, arrived in Islamabad today from Teheran, Iran, for a twoday official visit to Pakistan.

title: HENRY F. CARTON, RADIO DRAMATIST
description: Henry Fisk Carlton, a former president of the Radio Writers Guild, who is credited with writing the first dramas for radio broadcast, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street.

title: The Voter and Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Using the Easter recess to gauge the impact of the Watergate scandal, members of Congress from around the country report a sense of frustration and impotence on the part of increasingly concerned voters at home.

title: Saigon and Vietcong Offer Proposals for Settlement
description: PARIS, April 25The rival South Vietnamese regimes traded new plans for a political settlement here today, just two days before the end of the 90day period set by the ceasefire agreement for a solution to their dispute.

title: Helicopter Collision Victims Named by Army in Texas
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., April 25 (AP)The eight soldiers killed yesterday when two Army helicopters participating in maneuvers collided in flight were identified today.

title: ExP.O.W.'s to Be Briefed On the Latest World Affairs
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala. April 25 (UPI)The Air Force announced yesterday that 235 former prisoners of war will begin attending classes at Maxwell Air Force Base April 30 to bring them up to date on world and cultural affairs.

title: PHYSICIANS BACK THE RIGHT TO DIE
description: HARTFORD, April 25 (AP)Leaders of the Connecticut State Medical Society have recommended that people in good health be allowed to write a bill of rights for themselves in the event they contract a terminal disease.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 1,300,000 shares of A. H. Robins, Inc., at 33 per share became effective late yesterday, according to underwriters headed by Goldman Sachs; Smith Barney; Merrill Lynch; and Wheat First Securities Inc. The company's shares, trading on a when issued basis, closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 33, down .

title: Stocks Continue to Drop; Dow Tumbles by 10.23
description: Clouds of depression continued to hang heavily over Wall Street yesterday as the stock market absorbed yet another shellacking and skidded to new lows for the year.

title: MRS. JULIAN F. OLNEY
description: Mrs. Dorothy McGrayne Olney, a producermanager of stage plays and concerts for 35 years, died Monday in an auto accident in Newtown, Conn., where she had been a resident for the last six months. Her age was 73.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF ADOLF HITLER. By Robert Payne. 623 pages. Illustrated with photographs and holograph documents. Praeger. $12.95.

title: Hudson in the Spotlight
description: TRENTON, Aprils 25Hudson County has again emerged as a key to the fortunes of the Democratic party in this year's gubernatorial elections.

title: The Watergate Tragedy
description: The plea of Henry A. Kissinger that there be no orgy of recrimination in the wake of the Watergate scandal raises some disquieting questions.

title: HewlettPackard to Expand
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 25 (UPI)  The Hewlett  Packard Company said today it would start work at once on a $9million expansion of its manufacturing and warehouse complex at Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Expos Farm Out Mashore
description: MONTREAL, April 25 (Canadian Press)The Montreal Expos announced today they had reinstated Clyde Mashore, an list and optioned him to the Peninsula Whips of the International League. Mashore was placed on the disabled list March 28 after undergoing emergency surgery at Daytona Beach, Fla., for a bowel obstruction and appendicitis.

title: Loughlin Sets Track Marks
description: Bishops Loughlin High School shattered two meet records yesterday in the Mount St. Michael games in the Bronx. Loughlin won the 440yard relay in 44.3 seconds and the distance medley in 10 minutes 33.2 seconds. The medley quartet was anchored by Tim Behr, a junior who ran his mile leg in 4:24.7 to gain a 40yard triumph over Scanlon.

title: Steel Industry Cites a Big Year; Aluminum Producers Set Back
description: Steel company stockholders at scattered annual meetings yesterday generally heard continuing reports of the biggest year on record. On the other hand, the power shortage in the Pacific Northwest continued to have adverse effects on aluminum producers, while a leading machine tool company reported sizable first quarter gains.

title: MRS. JOHN S. ROST
description: Mrs. Thelma Bradshaw Rost, a member of the business staff of the Rockefeller family, died after surgery Monday afternoon at New York Hospital. She was 49 years old and lived at 47 Barry Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Lindsay Seeks to Attract Career City Employes
description: Mayor Lindsay, ignoring opposition from some Civil Service groups and unions, yesterday proposed Civil Service reforms on the management level that he said would increase efficiency and flexibility and induce young men and women of talent to make a career of city service.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Ship

title: E.P.A. Rates Small Foreign Cars Best on Mileage
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Small foreignmade automobiles get slightly better mileage than their Americanbuilt competitors but big cars regardless of origin, are about twice as gasolinehungry as small ones, according to Government tests on 1973 model engines.

title: L.I. Gasoline Dealer Is Forced To Close Because of Shortage
description: ELMONT, L. L, April 25An independent gasoline dealer on Long Island who has been forced to close down because of a national shortage of crude oil, said today that he was prepared to hold out for as long as three months while seeking a new supplier.

title: HAIG IS A WITNESS IN ELLSBERG CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., vice chief of staff of the Army and President Nixon's top military troubleshooter, testified today as a surprise Government witness in the Pentagon papers trial.

title: THERON J. DAMON
description: BELMONT, Mass., April 25Theron J. Damon, an Associated Press war correspondent in World War I and a captain in Army intelligence, died yesterday in a Weston convalescent home. He was 90 years old and a former resident of Worcester, where he was on the staff of the American Antiquarian Society.

title: KISSINGER WILL MEET THO IN PARIS TO DISCUSS WAYS TO MAKE TRUCE EFFECTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger would return to Paris in midMay for talks with Hanoi's chief negotiator, Le Due Tho, on ways to achieve strict implementation of the muchvia lated Vietnam ceasefire agreement.

title: Vesco Hearing Postponed
description: A criminal contempt hearing scheduled for today on Robert L. Vesco was postponed yesterday, apparently at the request of Mr. Vesco's lawyer, Edward Bennett Williams. Federal prosecutors initiated the contempt proceedings against Mr. Vesco on the ground that the New Jersey financier had failed to honor a subpoena to testify befor a grand jury here. The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged in a civil suit that Mr. Vesco and others looted mutual funds controlled by Investors Overseas Services, Ltd.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, April 25 (AP)  The Toronto Argonauts have filed a complaint with Commissioner Jake Gaudaur of the Canadian Football League that involves tampering charges against the Green Bay Packers.

title: GEORGE T. SENSENEY, PHYSICIST, 66, DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 George T. Senseney, an architect and physicist who was associated with the early phases of the nuclear and space programs, died Monday night at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Japanese Have No. Plans To Invite Nixon for Visit
description: TOKYO, April 25Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan made it clear today, after his Government canceled a visit by Emperor Hirohito to the United States, that Japan had no plans to invite President Nixon to come here any time soon.

title: Market Place: Greene Objects To Plan on Dorr
Haldeman's Role Viewed As Reduced by Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, April 25H. R. Haldeman, who once ran the Nixon White House with stern efficiency, appeared today to have lost much of his power as reports mounted that shakeup in the staff, including resignations, was being planned.

title: Market Place: Green Objects To Plan on Dorr
description: Apparently irritated by the way CurtissWright is running DorrOliver, Inc., David J. Greene & Co., the brokerage house, is reminding outside directors of the pollutioncontrol company of its obligations to minority shareholders.

title: Bell Named to Sports Unit
description: TRENTON, April 25 (AP)John H. Bell, controller of Bergen County, was appointed today by Governor Cahill as a member of the State Sports and Exposition Authority. Mr. Bell, a Ridgefield resident, will represent the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission on the sports authority.

title: KOOSMAN OF METS BEATS ASTROS, 52
description: HOUSTON, April 25With his father watching from the stands for the second night in a row, but his mother back at the hotel listening to the radio, Rusty Staub broke out of his slump with a bang tonight. He smashed his first two home runs of the season as the New York Mets beat the Houston Astros, 52, in the Astrodome.

title: Wettest Spring on Mississippi Spreads Flood Crises
description: ST. LOUIS, April 25The Mississippi River and its tributaries rolled over more farms, towns and suburbs in this area and elsewhere today as floodcontrol officials termed this spring the wettest in midAmerica's recorded history and warned of more trouble from north of Rock Island, Ill., to south of New Orleans.

title: Census Bureau Reports It Overlooked 5,300,000 People in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Census Bureau said today after a reanalysis that it had overlooked an estimated 5.3 million Americans in the decennial Census of 1970.

title: Army Studied Mississippi Basin on 220Acre Model
description: CLINTON, Miss., April 24For more than 25 years, the Corps of Engineers had a huge model of the Mississippi River Basin here on which it could study the river's quirks and problems, like those occurring during this year's flooding.

title: SOVIET EXPERTS SEE A NEW TOWN
description: COLUMBIA, Md., April 25Three Soviet urbanologists, on a tour of United States cities, visited this new town today as part of their study of the American urban environment.

title: NeoFascist Party in Italy Under Pressure and Torn by Dissension
description: ROME, April 25The neoFascist movement, which won nearly 9 per cent of the vote in the general election last year, is now politically isolated, under strong pressure on several fronts and torn by dissension in its ranks.

title: CARS IN RAIL CRASH HELD SUBSTANDARD
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)  The doubledeck commuter cars involved in the crash of two commuter trains in Chicago last year did not meet Federal safety design standards, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Strike Shuts Toledo Port
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 25 (UPI) The Toledo Port, one of the largest on the Great Lakes, was shut down today by a strike of 92 longshoremen who said they had been working for a year without a contract.

title: Suburbs of Phnom Penh Shelled; 19 Reported Killed and 72 Hurt
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Thursday, April 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  Communist forces bombarded the suburbs of Phnom Penh at dawn today for the first time in seven months.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: More than a score of theater, film and television notables protested the plight of Soviet Jews yesterday at a noon rally at Duffy Square, Broadway and 46th Street. All of them called on Americans to support the right of Jews and other Soviet minorities to emigrate and to live in freedom. They particularly stressed the persecution of Soviet Jewish artists and intellectuals, among them Valery Panov, a major dancer with the Kirov Ballet, who. was dismissed from the company when he sought to emigrate to Israel.

title: President Approves 50% Rise In Cheese Imports for 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) President Nixon signed an order today to increase imports of cheese by 50 per cent, or 64 million pounds, during the next three months.

title: POLICE SEEK CLUES IN STABBING DEATH
description: Homicide detectives sifted through a set of clues yesterday in the murder of Robert Dain, an East Side art dealer who was found dead Tuesday night in his handsome apartment with 12 stab wounds in his chest and back.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: People in Sports: Knicks Up to Old Habits
description: The alldefensive team of the National Basketball Association is getting to be an annual habit with the best defensive players on the league's best defensive team Dave DeBusschere and Walt Frazier of the New York Knicks. For the fifth straight time in five years the alldefensive team has existed, DeBusschere and Frazier were named to the select company in a poll of N.B.A. coaches.

title: Women on Faculties Earn Less Than Men
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)Women working full time on the faculties of the nation's universities are earning an average of $3,500 less than their male counterparts, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: If, on recent woodland walks, you have felt that crows are particularly brazen this spring, you may be right, for they are now an official game bird, protected by law.

title: Gloria Steinem Says Press Is Failing Woman Reader
description: Gloria Steinem told the American Newspaper Publishers Association here yesterday that the press was failing to report what women really wanted to read and that young women in particular were turning away from the Establishment press and looking for alternative sources of information.

title: Power Cut Off in New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI, April 25 (AP)This capital's electricity went out for nearly 24 hours on one of the year's hottest days. The temperature reached 108 degrees before power was restored this afternoon. It was not known what caused the city's five generators tol go off. Three of them were functioning normally tonight.

title: Businesses Fight Challenge to Their South African Operations
description: Midway through the season Of annual corporate meetings, shareholders of the General Electric Company voted yesterday on an issue that has been placed, in one form or another, before 18 other companies and that both sides concede is complex: investments in whiteruled South Africa.

title: Biaggi to Bid Judges Scan Assets Data; U.S. Offers Wider View of Jury Record
description: Representative Mario Biaggi promised yesterday to ask a threejudge panel to look at his secret Federal grandjury testimony and report whether or not I took the Fifth Amendment or any other privilege on my personal finances and assets.

title: N.B.A.
description: EASTERN CONFERENCE FINALS

title: TV:Those Commercials
description: Tonight at 10 C.B.S. News, in a gesture rare for commercial television, rather lustly bites the hand that feeds it. The hourlong documentary, produced, directed and written by Iry Drasnin, with Perry Wolff as executive producer, is called You and the Commercial.

title: Big Day for New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Senate is expected to pass today a legislative package, already approved by the Assembly, that is of extreme importance in the belated effort to save that state's invaluable coast. Since recreation is New Jersey's largest employer, the bills should do as much to protect its economy as its environment.

title: Common Market Backs Meat Tariff Reductions
description: BRUSSELS, April 25 (UPI)The Executive Commission of the European Common Market proposed today that tariff raductions on meat imports be prolonged for two months to combat meat shortages.

title: Work Is Varied but Quiet for State's PartTime D.A.'s
description: NEWARK, N.Y.No murders or robberies even, but for the District Attorney, it is still a very big day, starting with an earlymorning raid, with seven people, including the son of a town judge, arrested on charges of selling marijuana to an undercover agent.

title: Slander by Senator Brock Is Charged by 2 Democrats
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 25 (UPI)Two Democrats filed a $100,000 damage suit today against Senator William Brock, a Republican, charging he had slandered 1970 campaigners for the former Democratic Senator, Albert Gore.

title: News From Nowhere
description: BEAULY, Scotland  It is the far northeast of Britain, the bare hills, the forests and moors of the Highlands. A few miles away, past Inverness, Bonnie Prince Charlie in 1746 lost the battle that ended all real hopes of restoring the Stuarts to the throne, the Battle of Culloden.

title: Anderson Won't Print More Jury Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, said today that he had agreed to a request by Federal prosecutors to stop publishing excerpts from secret testimony taken by the grand jury investigating the Watergate bugging case.

title: Billboard Ads Planned In RapistSlayer Hunt
description: ROCHESTER, April 25 (AP) A Rochester civic group plans to use a billboard advertising campaign to help track down the man who raped and strangled an 11yearold girl.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchange yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Local and county governments are spending almost half of their Federal revenuesharing funds on their police forces, according to the State Community Affairs Department. The Federal Government has allocated $119million to local governments and $69million to counties. Of the total, they have already budgeted $145million, including $65million for public safety. After police expenses, the next largest share of the revenuesharing funds was $29million for capital projects, including roads and building construction.

title: CITY AIDE SUPPORTS RILL ON CHILDABUSE
description: Dr. Vincent J. Fontana, chairman of the Mayor's Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect, said yesterday that he strongly supported pending state legislation aimed at preventing what he called an epidemic of childabuse deaths and injuries.

title: Fire Death in India Stirs Debate Over Yoga Group
description: NEW DELHI, April 25A controversial yoga society that has gained some popularity in the United States was involved in a fierce dispute with the police today over the fiery sacrifice of a 32yearold leader of the group.

title: Anonymous but Good Tip Reported On Slayer of Man Trailed From Bank
description: While about 400 friends and relatives gathered yesterday morning to mourn a freelance film producer slain during West Side holdup, the Police Department received an anonymous telephone call that may, they hope, lead to the killer.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: Miami BeachJack O'Halloran, 256 pounds, San Diego, Calif., knocked out James Summerville, 236 Miami, 7 rounds.

title: Makarios Opponent Killed
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 25 (AP)A man with a submachine gun killed one opponent of President Makarios and seriously wounded another one early today as they left a night club in the east coast port of Famagusta. The police said they did not know whether the killing of Adonis Pissouris, cabaret owner, and the wounding of Yannis Demetri were the result of the guerrilla war between the forces of Gen. George Grivas and supporters of Archbishop Makarios.

title: Focus Is on Social Issues at Annual Meetings
description: In another heavy day of annual meetings, stockholders continued to press for added benefits in the form of larger cash or stock dividends, an4 showed their concern about ecology and the socioeconomic aspects of big business.

title: SMITH REGISTERS 6.3, 63 VICTORY
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, April 25 (UPI)Topseeded Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., stepped into the $50,000 World Championship Tennis Group A tournament tonight with a 6.3, 63 victory over Allan Stone of Australia. But another American, Charlie Pasarell, was beaten by Frew McMillan of South Africa, 67, 64, 76, in the second round.

title: Critics Lose in Honeywell Bid
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 25 (AP)  Critics of Honeywell, Inc., led by clergymen and church laity, peppered management at the annual meeting today but failed to push through a resolution to get the company out of some of its military business.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York Coliseum officials presented the city with a plan for a $274million expansion of the Coliseum as an alternative to the Lindsay administration's proposal for a new convention and exhibition center near the Hudson River. The Coliseum officials said the Lindsay plan would cost $750million. The new plan proposes adding 300,000 square feet of space tb the Coliseum.

title: ROYAL AND REGAL BLUE GRASS PICK
description: BLUE GRASS STAKES

title: Saigon and Vietcong Offer Proposals for Settlement
description: PARIS, April 25The Vietcong and the Saigon Government traded new plans here today for a political settlement in South Vietnam, just two days before the end of the 90day period set by the ceasefire agreement for a solution to their dispute.

title: 5 in Jewish Family in Iraq Reported Killed by Police
description: TEL AVIV, April 25 (Reuters) Five members of a Jewish family in Iraq were shot dead by Iraqi secret policemen last week, the Israeli News Agency reported today.

title: CATTLE FATTENER BANNED BY F.D.A.; BEEF PRICE TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Food and Drug Administration today banned the cattlefattening hormone DES, which is known to cause cancer in some animals. The move is certain to raise beef prices.

title: Natural Gas Supply In Deep Reservoirs Of Water Foreseen
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 25  At a time of increasing shortages of fuel and energy, a meeting of United States and United Nations earth scientists underscored today the vast potential of natural gas found in underground hot water reservoirs in the area of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: CATTLE FATTENER BANNED BY F.D.A.; BEEF PRICE TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Food and. Drug Administration today banned the cattlefattening hormone DES, which is known to cause cancer in some animals. The move is certain to raise beef prices.

title: Youth Pays Funeral Costs Of a Young Man He Killed
description: PLACERVILLE, Calif., April 25 (UPI)At his own request, Dennis R. McGuire, 18 years old, will pay $1,400 in hospital and funeral expenses incurred by the family of a 19yearold youth he accidentally shot and killed.

title: Soviet Scientist, Refused Exit Visa, Reported Drafted
description: MOSCOW, April 25 (Reuters)  A young Jewish scientist, who has been refused permission to emigrate to Israel, was ordered today to report for military service, Jewish sources said here.

title: Police Commanders Are Issued Manual on Corruption
description: The Police Department gave its commanders a manual yesterday describing 22 different kinds of police corruption found in New York City telling how to spot such problems in individual commands and offering specific methods to reduce various kinds of graft.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES UP BY DAILY LIMIT
description: A Government report showing smaller soybean and grain stocks, issued after the close of markets on Tuesday, sent futures prices of those commodities soaring yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Hope Cuts Fatigue for Campers Awaiting Lather's Work Permit
description: There was stubble on the faces, but a gleam of hope for highpaying lathers' jobs in the tired eyes of more than 250 men camped yesterday on the sidewalk on 76th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues.

title: Policeman Convicted of Perjury Gets Reversal After Year in Jail
description: ALBANY, April 25The 1970 perjury conviction of a New York City policeman, who served about a year in prison on the charges, was overturned today by the Court of Appeals on the ground that the trial judge had permitted extensive background testimony on alleged gambling protection payoffs to the police that was prejudicial to the defendant.

title: Ownie Carroll Day
description: SOUTH ORANGE, April 25It will be a long day and night for Ownie Carroll Saturday, when he is honored by Seton Hall University for the 25 years he devoted to coaching the Pirates' baseball teams.

title: Rubber Workers and Goodyear Agree on a 16% Wage Rise Over Three Years
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The United Rubber Workers and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reached agreement early today on a new contract calling for wage increases totaling about 16 per cent over three years.

title: Expos Farm Out Mashore
description: MONTREAL, April 25 (Canadian Press)The Montreal Expos announced today they had reinstated Clyde Mashore, an list and optioned him to the Peninsula Whips of the International League, Mashore was placed on the disabled list March 28 after undergoing emergency surgery at Daytona Beach, Fla., for a bowel obstruction and appendicitis.

title: SAIGON WARNS PRESS ON VISITING VIETCONG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Government warned foreign newsmen today that they faced arrest if they entered Vietcongcontrolled areas without permission from the Saigon authorities.

title: JAPAN PLANS TO EASE CURBS ON INVESTING
description: TOKYO, April 25 (Reuters)Japan announced a plan today to open most of her industries to whollyowned foreign subsidiaries starting May 1.

title: Lebanese Cabinet Picked to Aid Quest for Stability After Raids
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25 A new 17man cabinet was formed here today under Amin Hafez to guide Lebanon in the critical days following the Israeli raid two weeks ago in which three Palestinian guerrilla leaders were assassinated in their homes in this city.

title: Graham's Creativity Remains Unabated
description: My father always said, Martha, you run best on a muddy track, Martha Graham said. After a serious illness last spring and a selfconfessed personal crisis, Martha Graham appears to be running splendidly. On Tuesday, the revival of her highly acclaimed fullevening work, Clytemnestra, will open a twoweek season by the Martha Graham Dance Company at the Alvin Theater.

title: MITCHELL DOUBTS ACTIVISTS' CHARGE
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 25 (AP)Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell testified in Federal court here tonight that he knew of no efforts by the Committee for the Reelection of the President to tap telephone conversations by members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War.

title: SMITE REGISTERS 63, 63 VICTORY
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, April 25 (UPI)Topseeded Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., stepped into the $50,000 World Championship Tennis Group A tournament tonight with a 63, 63 victory over Allan Stone of Australia. But another American, Charlie Pasarell, was beaten by Frew McMillan of South Africa, 67, 64, 76, in the second round.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: EXAIDE TO SENATOR, WINS PAROLE PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Robert T. Carson, a former aide to Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii, sentenced to 18 months on a conspiracy and perjury conviction, was granted parole today by the United States Board of Parole.

title: Japanese Begin 3Day Strike; Train Service in Cities Stops
description: TOKYO, Thursday, April 26 (UPI)Transport and public service workers began a 72hour strike today in a prelude to what may become the worst labor dispute in Japanese history.

title: W.H.A.
description: EAST DIVISION FINALS

title: SHOP TALK
description: Vidal Sassoon, the master crimper, Is doing his hair thing in a new location. Salon No. 3, in the plaza of the General Motors building (Fifth Avenue and 58th Street), opened officially yesterday with a hair fashion show. It had the assistance of some of the stylists from the original salon, still carrying on at 801 Madison Avenue and from the Sassoon men's shop in Bons' it Teller.

title: Mobil Reports Oil Find
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation reported yesterday it had made two discoveries of oil and gas offshore Louisiana on Eugene Island Block 333. The lease was acquired jointly with others last December.

title: Biaggi to Bid Judges Scan Assets Data; U. S. Offers Wider View of Jury Record
description: Representative Mario Biaggi promised yesterday to ask threejudge panel to look at his secret Federal grandjury testimony and report whether or not I took the Fifth Amendment or any other privilege on my personal finances and assets.

title: DU PONT TO INCREASE CELLOPHANE PRICES
description: The E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. Inc., said yesterday that it would increase prices for most types of cellophane by three cents a pound, effective with shipments May 28.

title: Roundup: Marichal Wins 4th, Stopping Cubs, 50
description: Juan Marichal, the 34yearold San Francisco righthander, is off to a fine start in his 14th season in a Giant uniform.

title: BRITISH SOLDIER SHOT IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 25 (Reuters)A British soldier was seriously injured when he was shot by a sniper while on foot patrol today in the Turf Lodge section of Belfast, a Roman Catholic area.

title: DR. FLOYD A. HARPER
description: ATHERTON, Calif., April 25 Dr. Floyd A. Harper, an economist, former professor of marketing at Cornell University, and founder and president of the Institute for Humane Studies in nearby Menlo Park, died Saturday at his home here. He was 68 years old.

title: Brokers, in Profit Pinch, Report Increased Layoffs
description: More brokerage firms  ineluding Merrill Lynch, the nation's biggest investment concernhave laid off employes as high costs and low profits continue to plague Wall Street, it was learned yesterday.

title: 3 Public TV Aides Deny Pressure From White House
description: Allegations of improper pressure by the White House on the independent Corporation for Public Broadcasting were described as a phony issue and as outrageous and inaccurate in interviews with three members of the corporation's board.

title: Elder Statesmen Speak Out
description: WASHINGTONThe odorous assortment of malfeasances known as the Watergate scandals, committed by Republicans with the morals and methods of the lowest form of private detectives, is a nasty piece of politicalbusiness. Until and unless the full account unexpectedly carries conviction to the public that Richard M. Nixon was neither the easy dupe of the inner circle of men in whom hereposed the highest confidence, nor the President who betrayed the public trust by using the powers of the first office in the land to prevent exposure of the facts, the damage to his Presidency will be enduring.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Mother Teresa Is Given $85,000 Prize in London
description: LONDON, April 25 (Reuters)Mother Teresa traveled from the squalor of Calcutta's poorest quarters to the ornate splendor of London's Guildhall to be acclaimed today the first winner of an annual award for progress in religion.

title: ATOM POWER ORDER TOPS $200MILLION
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., announced yesterday that it had received an order from the Duke Power Company for the design and fabrication of six nuclear steam supply systems in the 1,200 megawatt class.

title: GEN. FUAD CHEHAB, LEBANESE LEADER
description: BEIRUT, April 25Fuad Chehab, the first commander of the Lebanese Army and former President of this Middle Eastern republic, died today after a heart attack at his country home near here. He was 70 years old. General Chehab is survived by his wife, who is French.

title: Barker Tried to Pin Bugging on C.I.A.
description: MIAMI, April 25  Bernard L. Barker, the convicted Watergate burglar, made a concerted effort here last summer to present his breakins at the Democratic National Committee headquarters in Washington as Central Intelligence Agency operations, Richard E. Gerstein, Dade County state attorney, said today.

title: Aljamin's Victory Stirs Dreams for Preakness
description: Lazarus S. Barrera's biggest dream has been to run a horse in the Kentucky Derby. Aljamin was his candidate for the Derby until he got hurt.

title: Conservatives Divided on Biaggi Pledge
description: Top leaders of the Conservative party were divided last night in their reaction to Representative Mario Biaggi's pledge to seek judicial scrutiny of his testimony before a grand jury.

title: Retrievers Bringing In Golden Prices
description: The value of trained retrievers is at a record high. A prospective field trial winner brings from $15,000 to $20,000. Authorities estimate it costs $1,000 a point on the way to a championship. Since it takes 10 points, it's a Costly business.

title: Fed Resignation Accepted
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)President Nixon accepted with regret today the resignation of James Lewis Robertson as a member of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Robertson, 65 years old, has been a member of the Fed's board of governors for 21 years. He was appointed by President Truman and served as vice chairman for the last seven years.

title: Rail Union Urges U.S. to Run 6 Lines
description: The Brotherhood of Railway, Airline and Steamship Clerks yesterday began a campaign for Government ownership and operation of the six bankrupt Northeastern railroads.

title: Two INA Units Elect
description: The election of chief execufive officers for two of the INA Corporation's major subsidiary companies was announced yesterday. Frank E. Raab Jr., was elected president of the Insurance Company of North America and Donald G. Heth was chosen as president of the Life Insurance Company of North America.

title: Total in Cadet Cheating Now 11; Inquiry at West Point Goes On
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 25 Eleven cadets have now been found in violation of the honor code of the United States Military Academy in what is developing as the most serious case of academic cheating here in more than 20 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Wesley Miller's April 18 letter is an attempted explanation of the intolerably low reading scores in the New York City schools. What is probably most disturbing about Professor Miller's statement is the fact that it does not come from just another des fensive and apologetic teacher or principal of a lowachieving school. This is the point of view of a professor of education who has the responsibility for training teachers to teach in our innercity schools. In this role he has the power to influence young teachers positively or negatively.

title: Haldeman's Role Viewed As Reduced by Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, April 25H. R. Haldeman, who once ran the Nixon White House with stern efficiency, appeared today to have lost much of his power as reports mounted that a shakeup in the staff, including resignations, was being planned.

title: Utility's Chairman Believes Coal Holds Key to Producing Power
description: The nation's largest investor owned producer of electricity the American Electric Power System, believes that coal should be the primary energy source for producing power.

title: Suspect in 6 Rapes Here Is Sentenced for Robbery
description: Richard Carbone, who was indicted for six cases of rape after a lookalike was jailed for 11 days and then freed, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens to up to 20 years for robbery.

title: Bicentennial Commission Gives $600,000 for Cultural Events
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The American Revolution Bicentennial Commission awarded $600,000 in grants today to finance a wide range of cultural activities planned in connection with the Nation's 200th anniversary in 1976.

title: Canadians Feel Sting of the U.S. From Little Things Like Stamps
description: MONTREAL, April 25A breathless American traveler dashed up to a counter at the Toronto airport one day not long ago holding a letter that bore an 8cent United States stamp.

title: Music: Series at 6 P.M.
description: Commuters who would like to hear a bit of music before heading home at a still early hour may find what they have been looking for in the new 6 o'clock Encore series of concerts being presented by Town Hall and Dubonnet. Dubonnet? Yes, the aperitif, which is credited on the program as being a product of the Schenley Imports Company.

title: For the World's Children
description: In the wake of any disaster, whether natural or manmade, the most heartrending consequence is the hardship suffered by helpless, innocent children. For the past 25 years, the United States Committee for the United Nations Children's Fund has devoted its efforts to the continuing support of the cause of children everywhere and to emergency response at times of extraordinary need.

title: None Hurt in Jet Mishap
description: DENVER, April 25 (UPI)A Frontier Airlines 737 jet with 48 passengers aboard slid off a runway at Stapleton International Airport today. None of the passengers was injured.

title: Lakers Win Series
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 25 With Wilt Chamberlain igniting fast breaks like a hyperactive launching pad and Gail Goodrich clicking off baskets like a runaway slot machine, the Los Angeles Lakers walloped the Golden State Warriors, 128118, tonight, and moved into the final round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Empire Phone Corp. Gets $53,356 Yearly Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, April 25 (AP)The Public Service Commission has approved a permanent rate increase of $53,356 a year for the Empire Telephone Corporation, it was announced today. The company originally asked for $71,766 and had been granted $25,000 on a temporary basis.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Siamese Twin Girls Are Born At Brooklyn St. John's Hospital
description: The birth of Siamese twin girls in Brooklyn on April 5 was confirmed yesterday by officials of the Downstate Medical Center, where doctors are waiting to determine if the infants can be separated.

title: Public Events Chief Sworn In
description: Walter P. J. Curley, an investment banker, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Lindsay at City Hall as the city's $1ayear Public Events Commissioner. Mr. Curley, 50 years old, was named to the post on April 10. He succeeds John S. (Bud) Palmer, who resigned to return to private business.

title: Knitted Outerwear Value Rose 26% From '71 Level
description: The value of knitted outerwear at the wholesale level in 1972 was estimated at $1.7billion, or 26 per cent above the level of output in 1971, Sidney Korzenik, executive director of the National Knitted Outerwear Association said yesterday.

title: Japanese Have No Plans To Invite Nixon for Visit
description: TOKYO, April 25  Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan made it clear today, after his Government canceled a visit by Emperor Hirohito to the United States, that Japan had no plans to invite President Nixon to come here any time soon.

title: Wettest Spring on Mississippi Spreads Flood Crises
description: ST. LOUIS, April 25The Mississippi River and its tributaries rolled over more farms, towns and suburbs in this area and elsewhere today as floodcontrol officials termed this spring the wettest in midAmerica's recorded history and warned of more trouble from north of Rock Island, Ill., to south of New Orleans.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Prisoners in the state's correctional institutions are entitled to a better grade of education while in jail, particularly an education that is geared to the job market, the State Correction Commissioner, Russell G. Oswald, said yesterday in urging the implementation of the recommendations of a special task force.

title: Personal Finance
description: With the cost of living on the rise, many men are worried about their financial security. Do they have enough to leave to their families?

title: Pickets Call Tango Filthy As It Starts Montclair Run
description: MONTCLAIR, April 25About 200 outraged residents and some town officials of this quiet suburban community, which cherishes its image of propriety and respectability, demonstrated noisily this evening outside the entrance of Upper Montclair's Bellevue Theater to protest the opening of Last Tango in Paris.

title: Royal Offers New Copier
description: The Royal Typewriter division of Litton Industries, Inc., announced yesterday a new compact desktop office copier, the Royal Citation, aimed at the lowcopy volume market. Priced at $795, it is said to be no larger than an office typewriter and requires no warmup period and can be for automatic production of up to 15 copies on 8by14inch paper.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 26, 1973

title: Charles C. Fenwick Dies at 92; Was International Law Expert
description: WASHINGTON April 25 Charles G. Fenwick, a political scientist whose specialty was international law, died here yesterday at home in Georgetown. He was 92 years old.

title: SOVIET TALKS GO ON, CONTROL DATA SAYS
description: The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it has had discussions regarding a broad agreement of cooperation with the Soviet Union but declined to confirm that it was close to concluding a multimillion dollar trade deal.

title: Celtics Defeat Knicks, 98 to 97
description: BOSTON, April 25The Boston Celtics, inspired by an 18point scoring effort by John Havlicek, who was not expected to play, held off the New York Knicks in the final seconds of play and stayed alive in the National Basketball Association playoff competition with a 9897 triumph tonight at Boston Garden.

title: C.B.S. Wins Top Rating For Bergman's The Lie
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System's presentation of Ingmar Bergman's The Lie dominated the ratings for its time slot Tuesday evening in New York. Beginning at 9:30 and running an unusual length of about one hour and 45 minutes, the story of a marriage and infidelity was given a Nielsen rating of 25.6 in New York, representing a 37 per cent share of the total audience watching TV at the time.

title: 12 Key Whalers Out Tonight For Crusader Playoff Game
description: BOSTON, April 25 (AP) The New England Whalers, who lqad the Cleveland Crusaders 31 in the World Hockey Asiociation playoff semifinals, will try to wrap up the fourofsevengame series tomorrow night without two key players.

title: Too Much Zeal
description: WASHINGTON, April 25One sure victim of Watergate, lying dead with none to mourn, is an institution that has served the nation well for a couple of centuries: the grand jury.

title: Nevada NoFault Law
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., April 25 (AP)Gov. Mike O'Callaghan today signed into law a no  fault auto insurance bill, The bill allows injured persons to sue once their medical expenses exceed $750. It calls for a 15 per cent cut in premiumi and a $10,000 ceiling on maximum nofault benefits.

title: Regan Sees End of Drought in Wall St.
description: Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., predicted yesterday that a turnaround in Wall Street's present period of drought will come before long. But he declined to set a specific timetable.

title: Bail Denied Inmate Accused Of Slaying Guard at Attica
description: BUFFALO, April 25 (AP)A State Supreme Court justice has denied the bail application of one of two men accused of killing a guard during the 1971 Attica prison riot.

title: SAIGON AND VIETCONG IN PACT ON CIVILIANS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25A Government military spokesman said today that Saigon and the Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Vietcong had agreed to an exchange of civilian prisoners beginning Friday.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Oh what a tangled web we weave, when first we practice to deceive! wrote Sir Walter Scott a couple centuries ago. This truism hasn't lost its validity over the years; it is so vibrantly alive that it can be accurately applied to such disparate things as Watergate and college athletics. The only bond between them is the element deception.

title: STOCKS OFF AGAIN ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Shares on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market declined for the second straight day yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Wood Again Master of Yankees
description: He is a round, moonfaced man of 31 with a bald dome, a Boston accent, a mild manner and an inoffensive front name: Wilbur. In the winter, he helps his fatherinlaw in the plumbing and heating business. In the summer, he pitches knuckleballs for the Chicago White Sox. 4

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 26, 1973

title: State Audit of Bellevue Reports Mismanagement
description: A state audit of Bellevue Hospital, made public yesterday, reports inadequate controls over drugs, medical supplies and food, as well as improper accounting for cash receipts.

title: Jersey Looks Into WorkerAid Fraud
description: TRENTON, April 25The State Investigation Commission will begin public hearings here next Tuesday to publicize evidence of alleged corruption in New Jersey's workmen's compensation system that one source said involved lawyers and physicians by the fistful.

title: Albany Senate Votes W elf are Ban for OutofStaters That High Court Vetoed
description: ALBANY, April 25Despite the fact that the United States Supreme Court last year unanimously struck down a similar New York State statute, the Senate today passed and send to the Assembly a bill barring state welfare aid to people who had not lived in the state at least one year.

title: Stage: A Not So Naughty Women Opens With a Stellar Cast
description: In 1936 when Clare Boothe Luce's play The Women was new and naughty, my predecessor, Brooks AtkinSon, wrote: This reviewer disliked it. Now it is not so new and not so naughty (it turned up last night at the 46th Street Theater, by the way), this reviewer didn't mind it. He didn't love it, but he was never bored, and certainly never shocked.

title: People and Business
description: Colin Stokes, who became president of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., last November, was named chairman and chief executive officer yesterday. And J. Paul Sticht, who joined the tobacco, food and transportation company in November as chairman of the executive committee, was appointed president and chief operating officer.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: If, on recent woodland walks, you have felt that crows are particularly brazen this spring, you may be right, for they are now an official game bird, protected by, law.

title: Occidental Reports on Well
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25 (Reuters)The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that a third test well on the Piper Field in the British North Sea had flowed high quality, lowsulphur crude oil at the rate of 16,415 barrels per day.

title: Horse Meat Store Opens to Brisk Sales
description: OAKLYN, April 25New Jersey's first horse meat market in years opened to brisk business here today.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: Miami BeachJack O'Halloran, 256 pounds, San Diego, Calif., knocked out James Summerville, 236, Miami, 7 rounds.

title: Bridge:Europeans Have Advantage Playing in Small Tourneys
description: Few players are at their best when playing in an international championship for the first time, since the conditions of play and general atmosphere are unfamiliar. In this respect the Europeans have some advantage, since new players can make their debut in various small international contests: the Camrose Trophy matches within Britain; the Scandinavian championships; and the Common Market championships.

title: Missionary Group Elects
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 25 (UPI)The Rev. Lynn Stephens, pastor of the Immanuel Baptist Church in Camden, Ark., was reelected yesterday to a oneyear term as president of the Baptist Missionary Association of America.

title: FASHION TALK
description: All those women who felt unhinged at the thought that they might not be permitted to pay $600 and up for their favorite Norells can relax. Though Norman Norell died six months ago, the house is in the capable hands of Gustave Tassell, who is carrying on the tradition.

title: Census Says It Overlooked 5,300,000
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The Census Bureau estimated today after a new analysis that it had overlooked 5,300,000 Americans in the Census of 1970.

title: Loughlin Sets Track Marks
description: Bishops Loughlin High School shattered two meet records yesterday in the Mount St. Michael games in the Bronx. Loughlin won the 440yard relay in 44.3 seconds and the distance medley in 10 minutes 33.2 seconds. The medley quartet was anchored by Tim Behr, a junior, who ran his mile leg in 4:24.7 to gain a 40yard triumph over Scanlon.

title: Advertising: Unsuccess Story
description: Saturday Review is not the first failure for the publishing team of John J. Veronis and Nicholas H. Charney. Does anyone remember Careers Today?

title: New Chief of Union Promises Firemen He'll Be Aggressive
description: Richard J. Vizzini, who was elected president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association Tuesday night in a surprise victory over Michael J. Maye, the incumbent, yesterday promised aggressive bargaining for a new contract.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Garment District Warned Of an Impending Walkout
description: Frank Brown, organization director of District 65 of the Distributive Workers, warned yesterday of the possibility of a strike next Tuesday against fabricators and converters who supply the garment industry with material.

title: G.O.P. Facing Its 2d Criminal Citation For Violation of Campaign Fund Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 25will cite the Republicans' 1972 campaign organization for the second time for criminal violations of the financial disclosure law, it was learned today. The charges involve unreported expenditures designed to demonstrate purportedly spontaneous public support for one of President Nixon's most controversial military decisions in Vietnam.

title: SCRUTINY FOUND ON EQUITY AUDITS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25Government agencies, including the Securities and Exchange Commission, are conducting an investigation of the auditing firms that reviewed the books of the scandalridden Equity Funding Corporation of Amerca, according to regulatory sources.

title: Only 10, She's Hostess and Interpreter at Parents' Restaurant
description: PLAINFIELD, N. Mei Ling Lee is the hostess at the Shanghai Restaurant here. With a smile, she shows customers to their tables and asks who recommended the patrons to this fairly new establishment, and then passes through a mental inventory of guests, trying to remember her customers.

title: HAIG IS A WITNESS IN ELLEN CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25 Gen, Alexander M. Haig Jr., vice chief of staff of the Army and President Nixon's top military troubleshooter, testified today as a surprise Government witness in the Pentagon papers trial.

title: Pakistan and Iraq Mend Ties
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 25 Pakistan and Iraq have agreed to restore diplomatic relations severed in February following discovery of Sovietmade arms in the Iraqi Embassy in Islamabad.

title: U.S. ORDERS STATES TO RETURN FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Four more states were added today to the growing list of jurisdictions ordered to repay more than $20million in federal education funds they are accused of misspending.

title: Nonsmokers Bill of Rights
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 25 (AP)The California Legislature is considering a 1973 Nonsmokers' Bill of Rights that would establish nonsmoking areas in public buildings.

title: Employment Rose In State for March; Jobless Rate at 5.1%
description: ALBANY, April 24  The State Industrial Commissioner, Louis L. Levine, has announced that 7.75 million people were employed in the state in March, an increase of 70,000 cher the February total and 25,000 more than in Mach, 1972.

title: SECURITY FOR NIXON IS TERMED ADEQUATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Security at the White House is described as adequate by the two top Secret Service officials. They said it did not seem likely that President Nixon would have to use an available tunnel to escape if, a mob attempted to storm his official residence.

title: Caramanlis Says He'd Return To Athens to Defend Publishers
description: ATHENS, April 25Former Premier Constantine Caramanlis has notified friends here that he would return to Athens to defend any newspaper publishers put on trial for printing his declaration attacking the Greek dictatorship.

title: JOHN F. HENNESSY, ENGINEER, IS DEAD
description: John F. Hennessy, chairman of the consulting engineering concern of Syska & Hennessy, of which he was a cofounder in 1928, died Tuesday at his Caribbean home in Lyford Cay, Nassau. He was 70 years old and lived also in Remsenberg, L.I.

title: SCHOLARSHIPS GO TO 89 IN CITY AREA
description: The National Merit Scholarship Corporation announced yesterday the names of 1,000 high school seniors, including 89 from the New York metropolitan area, who have won $1,000 nonrenewable college scholarships.

title: Transport Concern In Preliminary Pact For Steamship Co.
description: The General American Transportation Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the American Steamship Company for 200,000 shares of General American common stock and $45.4million in cash and notes. Based on the closing price of General American yesterday, at $39 on the New York Stock Exchange, the entire transaction is valued at $53.2million. T. M. Thompson, chairman of General American, said the purchase price could be reduced on the basis of a formula related to future earnings of American Steamship.

title: TRENTON WARDEN NAMED TO TOP POST
description: TRENTON, April 25 (AP) Governor Cahill announced today that the recently installed superintendent of the state prison here would take over the top criminalcorrection post in the state.

title: Muskie Urges. Rule by Congress Over Classification of Papers
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Senator Edmund S. Muskie, charging that the Nixon Administration's attitude toward government secrecy represented a nightmare for a democracy, called tonight for new Congressional controls over classified documents.

title: Federal Reserve Sought To Trace Watergate Bills
description: WASHINGTON, (AP)  The Federal Reserve System was asked by Government investigators to trace money carried by the wife of the Watergate conspirator, E. Howard Hunt, at the time of her death last year.

title: British Unions, Resentful, Accept Phase 2 Pay Limit
description: LONDON, April 25  The Trades Union Congress, the central organization of British labor, conceded the defeat today of its member unions resistance to limitations on pay raises under the Government's antiinflation program.

title: Better Investigative Work Called a Deterrent by Stern
description: NEWARK, April 25 (AP)United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said today that better investigative work rather than stiffer sentences may be the road to better crime prevention.

title: 14 FOOD OUTLETS FAIL TO ACTON VIOLATIONS
description: The Health Services Administration made public yesterday the names of 14 foodprocessing establishments charged with violating the city's health code.

title: Wounded Knee Shooting Victim Dies
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 25 Frank Clearwater, who was critically wounded on April 17 during a daylong rifle fight between United States marshals and Indian insurgents in the village of Wounded Knee, died before dawn today in a Rapid City hospital where he had been airlifted by the Government the day he was shot. Mr. Clearwater was the first victim of the confrontation.

title: Inadequate Answer
description: In an emotional appeal to New York City voters delivered over local television channels last night, Representative Mario Biaggi failed to respond adequately to reports that despite his public denials he repeatedly took the Fifth Amendment and refused to answer a number of questions recently put to him by a Federal grand jury.

title: UNION PACIFIC CITES 37% EARNINGS RISE
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, one of the most diversifled of the railroad holding companies, reported yesterday a 37 per cent gain in earnings on a 9 per cent increase in gross revenues and sales.

title: U.S. Files Antitrust Suit On Hayes Co. Acquisition
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today challenging the acquisition of the Hayes Company division of Genesco, Inc., by Blue Bell, Inc.

title: Notes on People
description: The Justice Department said that Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan was sworn in last week as a special deputy United States marshal, which means he may now legally carry a gun across state lines. The swearingin followed disclosures that Mr. Brennan sometimes carries a gun, a practice acquired during his years as head of the building and construction trades union in New York.

title: Ifs Haunting Rangers As Cup Dream Vanishes
description: If only we could have got the lead just once, Coach Emile Francis reflected yesterday.

title: MISS DI TULLIO FILLS SONGS WITH COLOR
description: Eileen Di Tullio is a New Yorkborn soprano who has sung here only intermittently since she made a successful debut in the nineteenfifties, but she has an enthusiastic following worthy of a prima donna. In her latest recital, in Tully Hall on Tuesday night, she made it apparent why this is so. Her light lyric voice has the kind of sheen that immediately pleases the ear. She can float a high pianissimo that is ravishing and then let the tone descend in a melting portamento. These are factors that delight the heart of anyone who likes the human voice.

title: Retrievers Bringing In Golden Prices
description: The value of trained retrievers is at a record high. A prospective field trial winner brings from $15,000 to $20,000. Authorities estimate it costs $1,000 a point on the way to a championship. Since it takes 10 points, it's a costly business.

title: CONGRESS GETS PLAN FOR DOMESTIC FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) The chairman of the National Urban Coalition asked Congress today to cut $6.1billion from the defense and revenuesharing budgets and spend the money on eight domestic programs being ended or cut back by the Administration.

title: San Diego Drafts Lamar And Expects to Sign Him
description: Dwight Lamar of Southwestern Louisiana, the leading major college scorer as a junior (36.3point average), and sixth best as a senior (28.9), will sign a longterm contract with the San Diego Conquistadors of the American Basketball Association. The 6foot2inch guard was the first player selected yesterday in the A.B.A. senior draft.

title: On Amazon Frontier in Peru, Businessmen Set Pace
description: IQUITOS, Peru, April 13 The lean young businessman sauntered into the steamy cafe on the town square, yawned and sat down to wait until the electric current flowed again and he could order his midmorning coffee.

title: European Soccer
description: EUROPEAN CUP

title: Catching Up With Anita Loos, or How Times Have Changed
description: I put birthdays out of my mind as far as I can, said Anita Loos, the author, trying to forget that today's birthday is her 80th.

title: Back to Paris
description: The decision of Washington and Hanoi to send their chief negotiators back to Paris to try to salvage the crumbling Paris peace accords marks a welcome shift from the recriminations and threats that have been filling the air in recent days.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LOOKING UP There's a large square tower, several stories high, above the 13th floor of the old office building at 346 Broadway, at Leonard Street. Although the building itself is occupied largely by city agencies, this Clocktower has been donated by the city to the Institute for Art and Urban Resources, which is using it as a center for contemporary art.

title: Seamans to Quit Post As Chief of Air Force
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Robert C. Seamans Jr., is to quit his post as Secretary of the Air Force to become president of the National Academy of Engineering next month, it was announced here yesterday.

title: Spirited Bidding Seen
description: Wall Street specialists described the Treasury's refinancing package $2.65billion of sevenyear 6s and 25year 7s as producing only minor surprises and predicted that the new issues be bid for aggressively next week.

title: Museum Plan Rebuffed
description: Community Board 8 voted last night to recommend that the city's Board of Standards and Appeals deny the zoning variance requested by the directors of the Guggenheim Museum's for alterations to the structure on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street. The museum proposes to alter the facade of its building to create a new lobby and a restaurant.

title: LARGER COLISEUM IS PROPOSED HERE
description: Officials of the New York Coliseum presented a plan yesterday for a $274million expansion of their exhibition halt as an alternative to the exhibition center, which these opponents say would cost upward of $750million.

title: George Lichtheim, a Historian And Authority on Marxism, Dies
description: LONDON, April 25George Lichtheim, social historian and an authority on Marxism, died here Sunday. He was about 60 years old.

title: INDUSTRY WIDENS PLANS TO INVEST
description: American industry has sharply expanded its plans to invest in new plant and equipment during 1973, a comprehensive survey by the McGrawHill Publications Company has concluded.

title: AGNEW CONFIRM HIS FAITH IN NIXON ABOUT WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Vice President Agnew reiterated his faith in President Nixon today but conceded for the first time that some of the speculation on the Watergate scandal might eventually be substantiated.

title: PATH Meeting Held
description: Representatives of the PATH rail system and striking workars met yesterday with an official of the National Mediation Board, but there was no inditation of progress or when another meeting would be held.

title: BOOK ASKS MOWS TO DRAW INVESTOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Ire head of the Securities and Exchange Commission warned today that the individual investor in the securities markets was fast becoming an endangered species whose extinction could cripple the nation's corporate capitalraising mechanism.

title: Dellums Endorses Seale
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, today endorsed Bobby Seale for Mayor of Oakland, Calif., because, he said, Mr. Seale reflects the hopes and dreams and aspirations of a significant number of blacks and other minorities.

title: COMPANY SUPPORTS INDICTED EXECUTIVE
description: NEWARK, April 25Charles G. Rodman, president of the Grand Union Company, said today that the company was supporting William H. Preis, Grand Union executive who has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on a charge of lying about a $5,000 contribution to Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign fund.

title: 2 College Officials Charged With Stealing U.S. Money
description: WASHINGTON April 25 (UPI) In what prosecutors believe is the first such case involving college officials, the dean of adult education at Federal City College and his assistant were charged yesterday with stealing $230,000 in Government money and tampering with grand jury witnesses.

title: U.S. BOMB TALLY GIVEN FOR MARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The United States dropped nearly 39,000 tons of bombs on Cambodia in March, according to Defense Department tabulations.

title: 5 Tenors Raise Voices to Honor Caruso
