title: Dr. Jean Stehelin Is Dead; Picasso's Physician, 70
description: CANNES, France, April 28 (AP)Dr. Jean Stehelin, who had been Picasso's physician for many years, died Wednesday. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S. Air Strikes Intense at Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 27American jet fighterbombers were screeching over the Cambodian capital all day today, pouring bombs, rockets and napalm onto Communist positons just across the Mekong River.

title: Quake Damage on Hawaii Is Estimated at $1Million
description: HILO, Hawaii, April 27 (UPI) The Mayor of Hilo estimated today damage at more than $1million from yesterday's earthquake that flattened one building, damaged more than 100 homes and left 11 persons injured.

title: Haldeman and Ehrlichman Reported Fighting Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, April 27H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, the two highranking White House assistants who have been implicated in the Watergate case, are fighting hard to retain their jobs, informed sources said today.

title: Federal Impact Bill Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)  Senator Lowell P. Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, announced today that he would introduce legislation next week requiring full disclosure of the impact of proposed Federal projects on various aspects of the community. The bill, he said, will let people know what will happen to their home towns when a Federal project moves in.

title: G.A.O. AGAIN CITES NIXON FUND UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 President Nixon's principal 1972 reelection committee was formally cited today for a fourth time for violations of the new campaign finance reform act that Mr. Nixon, in signing last year, had predicted would restore public confidence in the electoral process.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Stock Prices Slump To Low for Year
description: The stock market suffered another sharp setback yesterday in moderate trading. The DowJones industrial average toppled 15.57 points to 922.19, a new closing low for 1973. The Dow's decline of 41.01 points for the week was one of the largest losses for any week in Wall Street history.

title: MISS PALMER GAINS STROKE EDGE ON 70
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 27 (UPI)Sandra Palmer knocked in a 25foot chip shot for a birdie on the 18th hole today and took a oneshot lead after the first round of the Birmingham Classic.

title: COMPANY MEETINGS
description: Roper Corporation: Charles M. Hoover, chairman and president, told the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday that 1973 should be another record year. In 1972 the company earned a record $6.9million, or $2.83 a share.

title: Market Place:
description: It is easy to understand the individual investor's lack of enthusiasm for Wall Street.

title: AUDIT BEING MADE BY GIANT STORES
description: The Giant Stores Corporation, one of the discountretailing industry's dramaticgrowth companies that recently ran into financial problems, has discovered possible bookkeeping irregularities involving the last two fiscal years, its president, Jack H. Shapiro, announced yesterday.

title: Information Use Issue
description: The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here has ruled that a corporate director has no duty to provide adverse information to purchasers of the stock of a company of which he is a board member if he personally was not a participant in the transaction. The decision, 6 to 4, was handed down Thursday.

title: U.S. Considers a Bill That Would Cover All Futures Trading
description: The Administration is considering proposing a bill to bring all commodity futures trading and related services under some form of Federal regulation, a Government official said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: IRISH LITERARY PORTRAITS: W. B. Yeats. James Joyce. George Moore, J. M. Synge, George Bernard Shaw, Oliver St. John Gagarty, F. R. Higgins, AE (George Russell). Edited by W. R. Rodgers. 236 pages. Taplinger. $7.95.

title: FUTURES PRICES UP FOR SOYBEANS
description: Thinning stocks, continuing worldwide demand and the Food and Drug Administration's ban on the cattlefattening hormone, DES, sent futures prices of soybean and soybean meal futures up the respective limits of 15 cents a bushel and $5 a ton yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Gambling Bill Signed
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., April 27 (AP)Gov. Daniel J. Evans has signed into law a bill that allows bingo and raffles by charitable or nonprofit organizations and punchboards, pulltabs and pinball machines that do not provide payoffs.

title: WEST GERMAN SOCCER
description: M.S.V. Duisburg 1, Werder Bremen 2.

title: BIAGGI REALIGNS TV AD SCHEDULE
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, who had scheduled the most, extensive television campaign of any of the mayoral hopefuls, yesterday canceled a series of TV commercials planned for next week and instead planned to contractfor them on a daytoday basis.

title: SHOT KILLS INDIAN AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 27 Insurgents holding Wounded Knee reported this afternoon that one of their number had been killed and another wounded in a gunfight in which United States marshals used gas as well as rifles to try to subdue the militants.

title: New Zealand Will Take French ATests to Hague
description: PARIS, April 27 (Reuters)New Zealand's Deputy Premier, Hugh Watt, said today that he had failed to persuade France to end nuclear tests in the Pacific and that New Zealand would take the matter to the International Court of Justice at The Hague.

title: 2 I.D.S. MANAGERS ENJOINED BY SEC.
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that two portfolio managers for Investors Diversified Services, Inc., had been, permanently enjoined from violating Federal securities laws.

title: No Time for Worship
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Last week when the Watergate thing began getting very bad indeed for President Nixon, establishment thinkers of both parties began taking the line that we should all he cautious about leaning too hard on the President lest we end up by damaging the Presidency.

title: City Council Committee Rejects Homosexual Bill
description: The City Council's General Welfare Committee refused again yesterday to vote out a bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in housing, employment and public accommodations. The action was the third such setback for the bill in the last two years.

title: Met Will Proceed With Plans For Israeli Archeology Display
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Musewn of Art gave assurances yesterday that they would proteed with plans for a major Israeli archeological exhibition and not yield to terror or to threats of terror by backing out.

title: Imperial Regrets
description: It is unfortunate that domestic Japanese politicsa combination of opposition pressures, an oversensitive reaction by the Imperial Household Agency and excessive timidity on the part of an embattled Premierhave forced cancellation of Emperor Hirohito's planned visit to the United States this year, especially since the Emperor wanted to make the trip.

title: Screen. An AvantGarde DynAmo
description: During the last week Stephen Dwoskin's Dyn Amo has been screened at the Millenium Film Workshop, has been the subject of a Cineprobe at the Museum of Modern Art and has received its New York theatrical premiere last night, at the Film Forum. For a 16 mm feature, that means touching almost all bases at once. Given the film's subject matter, it is easy to see why.

title: Jill Johnston of The Voice Is Charged With Obscenity
description: Jill Johnston, a columnist for The Village Voice, was arrested late Thursday night outside the Guggenheim Museum at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street on charges of directing obscene language and gestures at a police offices, the police of the 23d Precinct said yesterday.

title: Fund Crisis to Force Move Of Overseas Press Club
description: The Overseas Press Club said yesterday that it had been unable to pay its rent at the TimeLife Building and would move into the Women's National Republican Club at 3 West 51st Street on May 15.

title: Bellah Withdraws Acceptance Of Post at Institute in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 27 The trustees for the Institute for Advanced Study today rejected the demand of a majority of the faculty for the early resignation of Dr. Carl Kaysen, director of the institute.

title: U.S.Cable About Diem's Fate Was in Hunt's Papers
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A document purporting to be a 10yearold State Department cable dealing with American policy toward former South Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem was in the possession of E. Howard Hunt Jr., the convicted Watergate conspirator, in the summer of 1971.

title: Books of The Times
description: The next best thing to hearing a literary Irishman talk is reading him talking: without the physical presence, we are robbed of the cadence and inflection (whoever said that all speech is prose?), the intense joviality that punctuates a neverending spiral of opinion, and what can only be described as a demonic gaze, full of hints of more to come. But the talk has other qualities that cold print cannot destroy: a constant shower of imagery, unfailing humor (never really black)and always a contagious delight in the vagaries of human personality. It is gossip with the highest of motives: to expose the individual's essence, what sets him apart from the crowd.

title: Daylight Saving Time Will Start Tomorrow
description: Daylight saving time will begin at 2 A.M. tomorrow, when clocks and watches should be set forward one hour. The system of advanced time will be in effect until a return to standard time on Oct. 28.

title: Morale of F.B.I. Sagged Before Gray Resignation
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Morale at the onceproud Federal Bureau of Investigation had dropped to an alltime low today before the resignation of the Acting Director, L. Patrick Gray 3d, after a year of confusion and controversy since the death of J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Producer of Firing Line Says Poll Finds Program Essential
description: Warren Steibel, producer of Firing Line With William F. Buckley Jr., said yesterday that the program, which may be withdrawn from public television for lack of funding, had recently been rated by more than 80 per cent of the public network's 237 station managers to be the most essential program in their schedule.

title: 2 Germans Died in Escape
description: HELMSTEDT, West Germany, April 27 (Reuters)East German border guards killed two men as they tried to escape into West Germany last weekend by driving a heavy truck through border barriers, West German customs officials said today. Earlier official West German reports said two men had been killed when the truck hit a concrete pillar.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal jury has ordered New York City to pay $500,000 damages to a New Jersey man who was hit in the head by a chunk of concrete that fell from the Manhattan Bridge onto an excursion boat in the East River. The victim was George Smith, 56 years old, of Westfield, N. J., a $20,000ayear executive in the family business, Jane Smith Gifts.

title: A.B.A. Playoff
description: TVCHANNEL 2, 2 P.M.

title: CARLOS MENDITEGUY ARGENTINE DRIVER
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 27 (UPI)Carols Alberto Menditeguy, veteran Argentine racing driver and polo player, died today. He was 58 years old.

title: Now It's Captain Bowa
description: CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) Larry Bowa, the Philadelphia Phillies' shortstop, has been named the team's captainits first in more than 20 years. Manager Danny Ozark said the 28yearold was officially appointed yesterday.

title: JUDGE DENIES BID TO CONDEMN LAND
description: PATERSON, April 27A Superior Court judge today dismissed a claim by Fred Ferber, the West Milford conservationist, to force the State of New Jersey to condemn 3,200 virgin acres in Passaic and Sussex Counties.

title: Rail Service Restored
description: Rail service has been partially restored across the Raritan River following an accident Thursday in which a 305foot barge being towed by a tugboat slammed into the drawbridge across which the tracks run. One of the two tracks across the bridge was opened yesterday, but there was no indication when full service would be restored.

title: 2 Blacks Criticize P.B.A. on Inquiry In Fatal Shooting
description: BERNARDSVILLE, April 27Two black members of a fiveman police committee investigating the fatal shooting of a young black man by a Bernardsville policeman said today that they had not been consulted in conclusions reached by the committee.

title: Baseball Transactions.
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: FERDINAND L. KETTERER
description: Ferdinand L. Ketterer, assistant treasurer and a director of the Manhattan Refrigerating Company and Union Terminal Cold Storage Company, Inc., died Thursday at his home, 164 Wildwood Avenue, Upper Montclair, N. J. His age was 80.

title: Bad Day for New Jersey
description: In a stunning disappointment the New Jersey Senate has turned its back on the growing demand of the people of the Garden State for legislative responsibility toward the environment. Three bills that were fully expected to win easy passage, as they had in the Assembly, were defeated in a spell of Republican apathy and Democratic subservience to the lobbies of organized labor and industrial interests, mostly oil. The result is what Thomas H. Kean, Republican Speaker of the Assembly and principal backer of the legislation, calls a major ecological catastrophe.

title: Artist Admits Copying And Selling Masters
description: BRAKE, Germany, April 27 (AP)A jobless artist, father of five children, said today that he had copied the painting styles of impressionist masters and affixed their signatures to the paintings for money to support his family.

title: A SUDDEN DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, April 27L. Patrick Gray 3d resigned today in the intensifying Watergate crisis and was immediately replaced as Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation by William D. Ruckelshaus.

title: DEAN IS REPORTED ASKING IMMUNITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 27John W. Dean 3d, the White House counsel, has told Federal prosecutors that he will not testify about the alleged wrongdoings of his colleagues John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman without being granted immunity from further prosecuton, sources close to the case said today.

title: MRS. HUNT'S MONEY SAID TO BE FOR MOTEL
description: CHICAGO, April 27 (UPI)An accountant related by marriage to a Watergate conspirator, E. Howart Hunt Jr., quoted Mr. Hunt today as saying the $10,000 his wife was carrying the night she was killed in an airline crash was to buy a Holiday Inn franchise.

title: Possible Mackell Successors Said to Shy From Appointment
description: At least two New York law enforcement officials, citing the uncertainties of the November election, reportedly have rejected soundings from the office of Governor Rockefeller about whether they would be interested in the appointment as Queens District Attorney.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Bridge: Opening Lead Often Brings A Quick Success or Failure
description: The opening lead is often an immediate success or an immediate failure. On some rare hands the effect can be more subtle and farreaching. Even with all four hands in view, few players looking at the diagramed deal can judge quickly which opening lead will prove the most effective.

title: A SUDDEN DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, April 27L. Patrick Gray 3d resigned today in the intensifying Watergate crisis and was immediately replaced as Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation by William D. Ruckelshaus.

title: Soviet Politburo Shuffled; Gromyko Among 4 Raised
description: MOSCOW, April 27The Soviet leadership today carried out its first major shakeup of the ruling Politburo since the ouster of Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1964. The changes confirmed the current line of relaxing tensions with the West, coupled with strong defense and firm security measures at home.

title: YankMinnesota Game Is Postponed by Rain
description: Rain washed out the Yankees' game with Minnesota last night and enabled Mike Kekich to maintain his perfect 1973 pitching record. Kekich has not won or lost and that's because he hasn't pitched. He's the only Yankee pitcher who has not taken a turn.

title: The Meaning in the Midwest
description: SALINA, Kan.Who done it?

title: Stravinsky Graduation Piece Is Played
description: As all students do, at one time or another, so Igor Stravinsky wrote what in effect was a graduation piece. He composed it under the direction of his teacher, RimskyKorsakov, and that venerable composer was sufficiently impressed to arrange for a few performances. It has had precious few since then.

title: Stage: Teatro Campesino in Brooklyn
description: El Teatro Campesino the farm workers' theater that grew out of the Delano grapepickers' strike in 1965  performs on picket lines, in fields, on streets and sometimes in theaters. Currently, the company is at the Chelsea Theater Center in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Tomorrow it finishes its indoor engagement and then tours city parks.

title: Hanoi Seems to Cast Doubt On a KissingerTho Parley
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 North Vietnam appeared to raise doubts today that its chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, would meet in Paris with Henry A. Kissinger in midMay, as announced two days ago by the White House. But a senior White House official insisted that we have a written commitment from Hanoi and a firm date for the meeting.

title: High School Notes
description: While teachers at the Walden School in Manhattan fill out their endofterm report cards, students from the eighth grade on up get together to evaluate the teachers. At the end of each trimester, the high school classes at the progressive private school call a meeting to discuss how the course went, what the teacher was like, and even to recommend whether or not the teacher should be rehired next year.

title: TRIAL WILL GO ON
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27The judge in the Pentagon papers trial released today a Justice Department memorandum saying that two convicted Watergate conspirators had broken into the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist here with the intention of stealing Dr. Ellsberg's medical records.

title: Frazier: We've Come Too Far to Quit Now
description: The Celtics moved the ball and shot well; the Celtics played fine team defense; the Celtics showed poise and determination.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: NONPROFIT For most of us not in the know, amateur films has overtones of a yawning interlude during which you watch a shaky panning of the Grand Canyon (that's it, over there, lower left) taken on vacation by Uncle Oscar. But there are amateurs and amateurs. For 40 years, the Metropolitan Motion Picture Club of New York has been the homefromhome for ardent amateur film makers, the kind who win international competition awards and so on.

title: Man Slain in a Hallway on W. 81st St.
description: An unidentified man around 25 or 30 years of age and wearing casual clothes and carrying no personal papers was found dead of a gunshot wound in the chest in a hallway of a West Side brownstone Thursday night, the fifth homicide victim in a week in the central Manhattan detective division.

title: WONIEN'S TENNIS NEARING A TRUCE
description: Officials of the United States Lawn Tennis Association and the Virginia Slims women's professional circuit reached a peace agreemen yesterday that now must be approved by the players.

title: 14 Presented at St. Nicholas Ball
description: There are some who consider debuts oldfashioned, but they are apparently still in favor with the daughters, granddaughters and nieces of members of the St. Nicholas Society of the City of New York. Witness the record number of 14 young women presented at the society's annual Ball and Paas Festival at the WaldorfAstoria last night, as against five last year.

title: Roundup: NoHitter for Busby
description: Steve Busby, a righthanded rookie pitcher for the Kansas City Royals who had lasted only one inning in his last start, pitched a nohitter last night, beating the Detroit Tigers, 30.

title: BigBoard Seat Price Is Lowest in 15 Years
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a seat for $86,000the lowest price in more than 15 yearsin the wake of slumping volume and eroding profits in the securities business.

title: Dow Index Drops 15.57 To a New Low for Year
description: The stock market toppled to new lows for the year again yesterday in light trading that concluded one of the most adverse weeks in Wall Street history.

title: POWER IS UPSET AT PENN RELAYS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27Paramus Catholic, which has been competing in track for only seven years, was the surprise winner of the schoolboy distance medley today at the Penn Relays.

title: Soviet Politburo Shuffled; Gromyko Among 4 Raised
description: MOSCOW, April 27The Soviet leadership today carried out its first major shakeup of the ruling Politburo since the ouster of Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1964. The changes confirmed the current line of relaxing tensions with the West, coupled with strong defense and firm security measures at home.

title: Appeals Court Dismisses Suit on TV News Source
description: CHATTANOOGA, April 27 (AP)The Tennessee Court of Appeals has dismissed a contempt of court case against Harry Thornton, host of a television talk show who refused to name a news source.

title: WEST GERMAN SOCCER
description: FIRST DIVISION

title: Dave Anderson
description: To a hitter, the hits are like the minutes of his life. When one is lost, it can't be recaptured.

title: Dr. English Resigns
description: The longstanding discord in the board of directors A the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has been coded, at least temporarily, by the decision of Dr. Joseph T. English to resign as president when a suitable sucssor is found.

title: Clark Asks Ouster of City School Board
description: ALBANY, April 27Kenneth B. Clark, a member of the State Board of Regents, asked the Regents and the State Education Commissioner today to remove the New York City Board of Education and appoint a receiver or trustee in its place.

title: Motorola Dropping Some Audio Items
description: Motorola, Inc., announced yesterday that its consumer products division at Franklin Park, Ill., was ending its manufacturing and marketing of consumer audio products in this country.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Minnesota at New York (2 P.M.)Blyleven (23) vs. Medich (10).

title: Japan Widens Program For Foreign Investment
description: TOKYO, April 27  The Government adopted today a program designed to open as much as 99.5 per cent of all Japanese industries and businesses to full foreign ownership of enterprises. The plan, which will permit wholly owned foreign subsidiaries for the first time, will go into effect Tuesday.

title: Celtics Down Knicks, 110100, Sending Series Into 7th Game
description: Outplayed, outhustled, outshot and, most surprising of all, outsteadied, the New York Knicks fell before the Boston Celtics, 110100, at Madison Square Garden last night and allowed the semifinal round of the National Basketball Association championship playoff to be reduced to one game, to be played at Boston tomorrow afternoon.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.2 From Week Ago Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 153.5 from 153.3 last week.

title: Notes on People
description: My friends think I'm a great celebrity, a great detective, said Frank Wills, a 25yearold security guard from North Augusta, S. C., who works in Washington. Down home, I'm big stuff, Mr. Wills went on. People I know call me up and say How's the hero? Mr. Wills said that it was just part of my job when, on the morning of June 17, 1972, he discovered that a lock had been tampered with on a door near the offices of the Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate complex. He informed the local police, who arrested the Republican operatives who had broken in. Since then, Mr. Wills said, he had changed security jobs in order to get a $5aweek raise, bringing his present weekly salary to $85. An unidentified Democratic party spokesman said: We have talked about doing something for him but we haven't been able to find him. I mean, we would at least like to say thank you.

title: Carolina Area Hurt By Youth Corps Cut
description: BEAUFORT, S. C.  The headquarters for the Neighborhood Youth Corps here occupies an old church on Carteret Street in Beaufort a literal biography of two decades of black social progress in the South and how it passed from spiritual leaders like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. into the hands of Federal administrators like Mrs. Ollie McAlister.

title: College Baseball
description: R. H. E.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Ever since Coco Chanel signed her name to a perfume back in the 1920's, just about every dress designer of note has fidgeted until he or she could also have a scent. Most French designers found a perfume and, in the last few years, Seventh Avenue has followed: Norman Norell, Adele Simpson, Geoffrey Beene.

title: Journalist's Appeal Is Heard in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 27  The Rhodesian Appeals Court heard today the appeal of Peter Niesewand, a journalist whose case has aroused an international furor and jeopardized the possibility of a settlement of Rhodesia's lengthy dispute with Britain.

title: Suicides Rise in Spring
description: HOUSTON, April 27 (AP)Spring is the peak season for suicides and depression, a Duke University psychiatrist said today. The suicidal and depressed people feel out of step with the changing seasons, Dr. William K. Zung told the American Association of Suicidology here.

title: Protection Is Given to Seed Plants
description: WASHINGTON, April 27For the first time, plant breeders have been granted protection on new varieties produced from seed.

title: A.B.A. Playoff TVCNANNEL TWO 2 P.M.
Legislator Denies Tax Guilt
description: BALTIMORE, Md., April 27 (AP)  State Senator Clarence M. Mitchell 3d pleaded not guilty in United States District Court today to four counts of failing to file income tax returns. The Baltimore Democrat was freed on his own recognizance. A trial date was not set.

title: Bowling Green Defeats Manhattan Relay Team
description: DES MOINES, April 27 (AP)  Bowling Green, anchored by Dive Wottle, the Olympic 800meter champion, bettered the fourmile relay meet record by more than seven seconds today in the 64th annual Drake Relays.

title: GOVERNOR'S BILL ON DRUG TRAFFIC VOTED BY SENATE
description: ALBANY, April 27  After nearly five hours of debate, the Senate tonight passed by a vote of 41 to 14 Governor Rockefeller's modified legislation fo dealing with traffickers in dangerous drugs.

title: Haldeman and Ehrlichman Reported Fighting Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, April 27H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, the two highranking White House assistants who have been implicated in the Watergate case, are fighting hard to retain their jobs, informed sources said today.

title: Likely SchoolVote Delay Averted by Albany Move
description: The State Court of Appeals handed down yesterday a unanimous decision that would almost certainly have postponed the school board elections here, but hours later Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Lindsay and legislative leaders in Albany announced plans that would effectively sidestep the court's ruling.

title: Soldier Is Slain in Londonderry Despite Truce
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 27A British soldier was killed by a sniper in Londonderry today despite a ceasefire called by the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Prefontaine Runs 3:55 Mile
description: EUGENE, Ore., April 27 (AP) Steve Prefontaine ran the mile in 3 minutes 55 seconds tonight in the University of Oregon's twilight track meet. It was the best mile of his career.

title: Times Advertising Post
description: Ron Moss, home furnishings advertising manager of The New York Times, has been given the additional title of manager of special advertising projects. In that capacity he will be charged with sales development and coordination of advertising supplements and freestanding inserts.

title: SAIGON REPORTERS TO COVER VIETCONG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Government announced today that it was permitting Saigon journalists to attend press briefings given by the Vietcong.

title: In Mandel's Art, Superb Control
description: Anyone with any interest at all in painting should try to get down to tie Max Hutchinson Gallery, 127 Greene Street, before John Mandel's new exhibition closes on May 16. It consists of one picture five feet square, three large drawings, one of which is a study for it, and two series of very small paintings related to it. The major painting is called Postlude to Original Sins, a title indicating an aspect of Mr. Mandel's show that puzzles me.

title: SOVIET UNION'S FIVE WINS TOUR OPENER
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 27 (AP)The Soviet Union's basketball team opened a United States tour tonight by outmuscling an eager but disorganized Utah college allstar team, 7263, in a ragged, foulfilled game.

title: TRANSPORT WORKERS END STRIKE IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, April 28 (Reuters)Workers on Japan's Governmentrun railroads called off a nationwide strike today after winning a large wage increase and Government consideration of their demand for the right to strike.

title: LONG FAMILY SETS EXHUMATION RULES
description: HANNIBAL, Mo., April 27 (AP)The family of Edward V. Long has given permission, for exhumation of the Senator's body if certain conditions are met, the family lawyer, Marion F. Wasinger, said today.

title: A Top Seoul General Gets 15 Years for Bribery
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, April 28Gen. Yoon Pil Yong, the former commander of the elite Capital Security ComInland of the South Korean Army, who had ben one of President Park Chung Hee's favorites, was sentenced today to 15 years in prison by an army courtmartial on charges of accepting bribes and other misconduct.

title: Texas Blaze Injures 49
description: GALVESTON, Tex., April 27 (AP)Worionen doused thousands of bales of cotton with water today after a major warehouse fire hi Which 49 firemen were hospitalized from burns on their eyes and smoke inhalation.

title: A Special Glass Is Used in Process
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A special glass, when stimulated with bright pulsed light from an electric lamp, creates intense laser beams that are useful tools for science and industry. The American Optical Corporation, Southbridge, Mass., received a basic patent this week for the glass, which contains neodymium, and its use in emitting waves of light. Elias Snitzer, director of basic research for the company, was granted Patent 3,729,690, formally entitled Means for Producing and Amplifying Optical Energy.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Shops Burn in Decatur, Ala.
description: DECATUR, Ala., April 27 (UPI)A halfblocklong downtown building was heavily damaged today by a fire that burned out of control for almost six hours. Officials said that a drugstore and a hardware store had been destroyed and other shops were damaged. Two firemen were hospitalized for injuries.

title: 2 Displays Honor Photographer, 90
description: The work of the American photographer Imogen Cunningham, who observed her 90th birthday on April 12, is not so familiar to the general public as the accomplishments of many younger photographers without half her claims to distinction. Is it because she has always lived and worked on the West Coast? Is it because she is a woman? Or is it, rather, because our awareness of the artistic achievements of photography is still so incomplete? No doubt, a case can be made for any or all of these propositions.

title: Small Flies Called Best For Angler
description: For much of this century the American shad has delighted East Coast lighttackle anglers. It was not always so.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Minority applicants for the 125 work permits available in the metallic lathers union registered yesterday after the police averted the threat of a confrontation between two competing groups: Disappointed applicants, some of whom had waited through wind, rain and cold for two or three days, were angry at their failure to get permits.

title: MANUA RAISES STREAK IN MEDLEY
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27 Villanova is not dead yet as an Eastern collegiate track and field power.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: STANLEY CUP FINALS Montreal vs. Chicago

title: People and Business
description: Robert E. Lauterbach, president of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, has been elected chief executive officer of the nation's ninth largest steel producer, effective June 1. He will succeed Allison R. Maxwell Jr., who continues as chairman.

title: BRITISH WELCOME U.S. CHARTER PLAN
description: LONDON, April 27The British Government tonight described Henry A. Kissinger's proposals for a new Atlantic, charter as realistic and timely but made it clear that Europe did not intend to link monetary, trade and defense issues in single negotiations.

title: Secretariat Sizzles in Louisville Workout
description: There's nothing like a sixfurlong workout on a muddy track in 1:12 2/5 to restore a trainer's faith in the horse of his dreams.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Gains
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.6 billion tonmiles, 4.1 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. The Association also announced that carloadings in the same week totaled 511,056 cars, 1.2 per cent above last year.

title: DEAN IS REPORTED ASKING IMMUNITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 John W. Dean 3d, the White House counsel, has told Federal prosecutors that he will not testify about the alleged wrongdoings of his colleagues John D. Ehclichman and H. R. Haldeman without being granted immunity from further prosecution, sources close to the case said today.

title: People in Sports: Fame for Five
description: The Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., inducted five new members yesterday, including Elmer Ripley, the 81yearold former coach at Georgetown, Yale, Columbia and Army, who said, I'm a happy old man. Ripley played with the original Celtics as did the late John Beckman, one of those inducted into the Hall of Fame. The other inductees were Dolph Schayes, a former New York University and Syracuse Nationals star; Dutch Lonborg, a college coach for 29 years and manager of the 1960 United States Olympic basketball team, and Bruce Drake, University of Oklahoma coach for 17 years. Schayes at 44 was the youngest man placed in the Hall of Fame yesterday.

title: Burglary Plan Aimed at Muskie in 1972 Laid to Hunt
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A burglary venture that it was thought might produce information on Senator Edmund S. Muskie's Presidential campaign was discussed, but never carried out, by E. Howard Hunt Jr. a former Hunt business associate has told The New York Times.

title: McCrane Takes 5th Before Grand Jury
description: NEWARK, April 27Former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. refused today to answer questions for a Federal grand jury investigating possible fraud in connection with fundraising activities in Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign.

title: FIRE WIDOWS WIN SUIT ON 12 DEATHS
description: The 11 widows and 36 children of 12 firemen killed when a floor collapsed during a fivealarm blaze here seven years ago were awarded a total of $2,150,000, settling in State supreme Court a trial that had begun on Monday. One of the widows has died since the fire.

title: No Easy Answer
description: An Oglala Sioux ousted from his home by militant Indiansand nonIndianswho have been holding the tribal village of Wounded Knee for more than eight weeks asked a Justice Department official the other day: Why has it dragged on this long?

title: Nixon Cancels a Meeting And Flies to Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) With the Watergate case swirling at an ever greater pace, President Nixon canceled a scheduled meeting with his chief economic advisers and flew off alone tonight to his mountaintop retreat at Camp David, Md.

title: Equity Financing
description: A special offering of 96,800 shares of R. H. Macy & Co. at 30 was made by Bear Stearns & Co. The company's stock closed at 29, down 1.

title: Small Flies Called Best For Angler
description: For much of this century the American shad has delighted East Coast lighttackle anglers. It was not always so.

title: 35,000 Are Delayed by Switch Trouble
description: Some 35,000 commuters on the Penn Central's Harlem, Hudson and New Haven lines were up to 67 minutes late getting to New York yesterday when the railroad developed switch trouble at the height of the morning rush.

title: CEMETERY UNION MAY WIDEN STRIKE
description: The head of the striking gravediggers' union, asserting that the managements of 4 cemeteries in the city had refused to negotiate for three weeks, warned yesterday than a citywide strike of cemeter workers was imminent Man agement representatives de tiled the union charge that the were refusing to negotiate.

title: U. S. Data on Cambodia Raids Show Shift to a Support Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A Senate subcommittee today made public previously secret Defense Department information officially confirming that the preponderance of American bombing in Cambodia shifted since last month from striking at North Vietnamese lines, of communication to supporting Cambodian Government forces.

title: GroceryStore Manager Killed in Brooklyn Holdup
description: The proprietor of a grocery store in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn was shot to death by one of two armed men who robbed his store and stole a customer's wallet last night the police said. The gunmen fled with an undetermined amount of money.

title: Blumenthal Asks Asset Reports From City's HighLevel Officials
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal of Manhattan called yesterday for yearly disclosures of income and assets by members of the Board of Estimate and the City Council and all employes of the city at or above the rank of deputy commissioner.

title: Computer Suit Filed
description: A class action suit has been filed against the University Computing Company charging violations of Federal securities laws and fraud.

title: Cleveland Suburb Is Sued By U.S. on Housing Bias
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)The Justice Department filed suit today against Parma, Ohio, accusing the city of denying housing opportunities to blacks.

title: 3 Months After the Truce, No Letup in the Charges
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 28 (Reuters) The South Vietnamese Government and the Vietcong blamed each other yesterday for 12,000 violations of the ceasefire in which more than 25,000 soldiers and civilians are reported to have been killed since Jan. 28.

title: Jewish Immigrants: They Fled Problems And Found New Ones
description: Polishborn Swietlana P. abruptly departed from her native Dzierzoniow when refused admission to a univer sity. It was never clearly stated, but she is quite sure her application was turned down because she is Jewish.

title: DICKSON, ON 135, LEADS BY STROKE
description: DALLAS, April 27  Bob Dickson's 66 brought him the 36hole lead at 135 in the $150,000 Byron Nelson golf tournament today as Lee Thevino was forced to withdraw on advice of a doctor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was greatly disturbed by the opinion and judgments expressed in your April 23 editorial The United States Abstention.

title: The Governor Endorses
description: This has been a week for endorsements that seem more knock than boost. Vice President Agnew started it with his patronizing attestation to President Nixon's integrity in the Watergate case. Now Governor Rockefeller has made his contribution with a half  hearted expression of support for State Senator John J. Marchi, Republican nominee for Mayor of New York City.

title: Kenny SoninLaw Indicted in 2d Case On Fraud in Hiring
description: JERSEY CITY, April 27 (AP) Paul L. Hardy Sr., the 59yearold soninlaw of the former Hudson County Democratic boss, John V. Kenny, was indicted today for allegedly putting the harbor master of Florida yacht club on the Hudson County payroll.

title: A.&P. Increases Volume and Slightly Reduces Loss in Three Months
Return of Clams and Even Oysters Is Also Envisioned
description: EDGEWATER, N. J., April 27  There are two unofficial indicators here this week that the Hudson River really is getting cleaner.

title: Skylab Rehearsal Goes On
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 27 (AP)A countdown rehearsal for next month's launching of the Skylab space station went on today despite a strike by 125 technicians manning a satellite tracking station at Cape Kennedy Space Center. Officials said that most union workers crossed picket lines set up last night by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

title: Alien Executives in Argentina Take Steps to Foil Kidnappers
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 27The foreign businessman stared out the large picture window in the living room of his comfortable suburban home and gestured to the young man mangling the flower bed in his garden.

title: BRAVES' HOMERS DEFEAT METS, 20
description: ATLANTA, April 27Unlike Rodney Dangerfield, the comedian who can't get no respect, Tom Seaver of the New York Mets gets plenty of that from his teammates, but he can't get no support. The latest example was his 20 defeat at the hands of the Atlanta Braves tonight in the opener of a threegame series.

title: Rush, Ending Pakistan Trip, Hopes for Talks With India
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 27 Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth Rush of the United States expressed hope today that differences between India and Pakistan could be resolved through negotiations.

title: Maine Repeals 2 Laws
description: AUGUSTA, Me., April 27 (AP) Maine has repealed two of its oldest and most obsolete laws. They permitted towns to have poor farms and to shackle and fetter insubordinate inmates of local correction houses and to deprive them of food. The statutes date back to 1821.

title: Newspaper Payroll Courier Felled and Robbed on S.I.
description: A 79yearold courier for The Staten Island Advance's payroll department was pushed to the ground yesterday morning by four men who robbed him of $40,000 in nonnegotiable checks and $5,000 in cash near the newspaper's Grassmere office.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: VIENNA, April 27 (UPI)Tom Szuba and Linda Stimpson, American swimmers, won two events each on the second day of an international swimming meet in Bucharest, the Rumanian news agency Agerpres said today.

title: The Pop Life
description: Finally ready and getting a New York showing is Journey Through the Past, the singer Neil Young's documentaryfantasy (his description) and first filmdirecting effort. In four to five weeks it will be screened here at the Festival Theater, and it will also open in Los Angeles at the same time.

title: TV: WNET Goes Behind the Scenes of Art Loan
description: Few of us ever see the backstage, anthill activity of an art museum as it uncrates, arranges and hangs a priceless painting collection. This earthy, brasstacks operation is the real novelty of On Loan From Russia41 French Masterpieces.

title: Rate of Costs for Labor Triples Despite a Climb in Productivity
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Despite another strong rise in productivity in the first quarter and unusually small wage increases negotiated by unions during the period, unit labor costs in the United States rose at more than triple the rate of last year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Nothing Fails Like Success
description: PARISThe most visionary initiative ever undertaken by U.S. foreign policy originated after World War II with the Marshall Plan, developed into massive reconstruction of West Europe and East Asia, and produced a global security network based on American pledges to fight, if necessary, to keep the peace.

title: TakeOver of Sikkim by India Is Laid To Protectorate's Move to Loosen Tie
description: NEW DELHI, April 27 Anger over Sikkim's efforts to loosen ties with India opened the way for New Delhi's swift takeover of the tiny Himalayan protectorate, according to authoritative reports reaching here.

title: Mississippi Crowds Cheer Nixon at Stennis Day Fete
description: MERIDIAN, Miss., April 27President Nixon took a respite from his Watergate troubles today and flew to an air naval station near here where he was cheered by a crowd of several thousand and encouraged by Senator John C. Stennis to tough it out.

title: SHOT KILLS INDIAN AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 27 Insurgents holding Wounded Knee reported this afternoon that one of their number had been killed and another wounded in a gunfight in which United States marshals used gas as well as rifles to try to subdue the militants.

title: CAMDEN IS ALLOWED TO DUMP IN ATLANTIC
description: The Environmental Protection Agency issued an interim permit yesterday to the City of Camden, N. J., allowing it to continue dumping its sewage in the Atlantic Ocean, but in a new area 50 miles offshore instead of the current dumping site 12 miles from the coast.

title: WINE TALK
description: There is a small winery in Palmer, Alaska, run by a Catholic priest, the Rev. Emet R. Engel. Father Engel, who is in his 70's, calls his operation Casa de San Jose and he makes only milk wine, a product fermented from powdered skim milk and cane sugar.

title: PRICES FALL AGAIN ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market dropped sharply yesterday in continued light trading.

title: Put Costs Put Pressure on Margin of Profit, Auto Giant Finds
description: DETROIT, April 27The General Motors Corporation announced today that sales and earnings were at record levels for the first quarter of 1973, but the company expressed disappointment that its profit margin was still less than in the last boom period in the midsixties.

title: Bouttier Stops Hernandez In 9th Round at Marseilles
description: MARSEILLES, France, April 27 (AP)JeanClaude Bouttier of France stopped Art Hernandez of Omaha tonight in the ninth round of a scheduled 10round middleweight fight.

title: El Al Employe in Rome Is Shot to Death by an Arab
description: ROME, April 27A local employe of El Al, the Israeli airline, was shot to death this afternoon by an Arab gunman in front of a department store.

title: L.I. Judge Dismisses 4 Tiana Indictments
description: A Suffolk County Court judge in Riverhead dismissed all the indictments yesterday against three present and former county officials and a realestate broker charged with land manipulations in connection with the county's purchase of land at Tiana Beach in Hampton Bays.

title: BIRTH CURB PILLS TIED TO STROKES
description: A collaborative study at 12 university medical centers around the country has shown that the risk of strokes faced by women who use oral contraceptives is nine times greater than for women in the same age group who do not use the pill.

title: TRIAL WILL GO ON
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27The judge in the Pentagon papers trial released today a Justice Department memorandum saying that two convicted Watergate conspirators had broken into the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist here, with the intention of stealing Dr. Ellsberg's medical records.

title: Screen: A Creepy Legend
description: As horror wholesalers, the production team of Milton Subotsky and Max J. Rosenberg do little to enhance the creepy legend or spooked stately mansion movie genre with "And Now the Screaming Starts." Their latest consignment from Britain, which landed at the Juliet 2 and Forum Theaters yesterday, may have a few shocks, but they're not enough to overcome a padded plot and the mounting feeling that the screaming is being done for the wrong reasons.Stephanie Beacham, as the pretty, full-bosomed but timorous 18th-century bride of Ian Ogilvy, the handsome lord of Fengriffen manor, tips the bloody mitt at the start when she observes that the house "filled my nights with horror." And before you can say "Long live the King!" the screen is filled with dire implications, bloody-eyed specters at the windows, a crawling, severed hand and five corpses, to send our now-pregnant heroine screaming out of her wits.It's not ungallant to note that Herbert Lom, as the late grandfather of the bridegroom, was the dissolute baronet who brought the curse down on the Fengriffens when he violated a local woodsman's bride and lopped off the hand of the frenzied bridegroom, who then puts the hex on future Fengriffens.Miss Beacham is decorative even when screaming. Ian Ogilvy, as her worried husband, Patrick Magee, as the family's kindly doctor, Geoffrey Whitehead, as the woodsman's strange grandson, and Guy Rolfe and Rosalie Crutchley, as Fengriffen retainers, are simply dour or frightened as they stretch the mystery.Peter Cushing, however, adds a singular bright note to the dark proceedings directed in somber, largely measured style by Roy Ward Baker. He has apparently beaten Dr. Freud by about a century as the genteel specialist in the "distress of the mind" called in to aid our obviously distressed heroine. As the script says a good deal of "torment is caused by the written word, not fact."

title: Small Stockholders Get Hearing at Montedison
description: MILAN, Italy, April 27Montedison S. p. A., an Italian industrial giant plagued by losses and a 90per cent drop in the price of its stock in the last five years, held its annual stockholders meeting today and gave its small shareholders a rare chance to be heard.

title: Katherine Ann Hoffman Is the Bride of Bernard Sean Gresh
description: SHARON, N.H., April 28Miss Katherine Ann Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Fiske Hoffman of this place and Wellesley, Mass., and Bernard Sean Gresh, son of Charles F. Gresh of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Marie Harrity Gresh, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Michael Russo of St. Aedan's Roman Catholic Church in Jersey City performed the ceremony.

title: Leaking? Plug the Hole
description: When your boat Springs a leak, it would help to have something more than your finger with which to plug up the hole. One recommendation is that all fiberglass boatowners carry a repair kit for the quick, temporary repairs that can get the vessel and its crew back to their home port.

title: They're Worth The Effort
description: AS Richard Armour wrote, the globe artichoke is the only vegetable, if vegetable it is, of which there is more after it has been eaten. But as troublesome as the artichoke may be to grow, prepare and eat, the delicacy has been thought well worth the effort for centuriesindeed, gardeners have been cultivating it for some 2,500 years. The artichoke has been valued as an aphrodisiac, has been enjoyed stuffed, in salads, in soups, and its dried flowers have even been used to curdle milk in making cheese.

title: Acrostic Puzzle
Dill Is Dandy for Aromatic Flavoring
description: DILL to me is a necessary herb, on a par with basil, sage or thyme. Though its uses may not be so Valuable or varied as onions, its flavorsharp and aromaticfits many foods.

title: Award for Jackie Robinson
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP)The late baseball star Jackie Robinson has been given a Man of the Year Brotherhood Award by Philadelphia's Congregation Rodelph Shalom. The award was accepted last night by Mr. Robinson's widow, Rachael, and daughter, Sharon. Mr. Robinson died last Oct. 25.

title: $1Million in Stocks Found In Chicago Burglary Raid
description: CHICAGO, April 28 (UPI)four men who operated their own grocery stores by day and burglarized by night were arrested today in an apartment hideout in which the police found $1million in negotiable stocks and other securities and $50,000 worth of mink coats, stereo sets and televisions. They raided the apartment after staking out the address for the last two months.

title: Cowbells at Sea ... and All's Not Well With the Foggy Crew of Saucy Jane
description: NewcastleonTyne, a city in the northern part of England, is the same Newcastle that people have been carrying coals to for countless generations.

title: Biaggi Asserts He Still Leads; Rejects Idea of Quitting Race
description: Representative Mario Biaggi declared yesterday that he was still ahead in the fight for the Democrat mayoral nomination and had absolutely no intention to withdraw.

title: Predictions for the Summer of '73
description: On a sunny Saturday this summer the boat count entering and exiting through the narrow channel guarding Block Island's Great Salt Pond will reach one vessel every five seconds. Extrapolating that figure through darkness and weekdays, an observer who stations himself at the Coast Guard dock adjacent to the channel will in the course of a few days see a boat show that transcends any of the commercial versions in armories, coliseums or marinas.

title: DISASTER RELIEF BILL SIGNED BY PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) President Nixon has signed multimilliondollar bill that revives a rural disaster relief program killed by the White House in December.

title: A Really Big Show in Jersey
description: On Dec. 26, 1776, the Continental Army crossed the Delaware and surprised the Hessians in Trenton. Next Sunday, at Washington Crossing State Park, five miles north of the Jersey capital, another army will be on the move. A force of fanciers, in their automobiles, will bring 3,830 dogs to compete in the 44th allbreed show and obedience trial of the Trenton Kennel Club. There will be many more thousands of devotees at the spectacle; which probably, for the second year in a row, will be America's largest. In 1972, with summerlike weather, Trenton attracted a crowd of 50,000.

title: Pammy Lobell Wins Pace At Freehold With Haughton
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., April 28Billy Haughton, the top moneywinning harness race driver, came over from New York today and showed them how to do it in the $8,000 Hammonton Pace at Freehold Raceway. Driving Pammy Lobell, a 4year old mare, the Long Island reinsman scored by half a length.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
NAVY CREW WINS 3D GOES TROPHY
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 28 Navy overtook Syracuse at the 1,500meter mark and held off the Orangemen today to win its third straight Goes Trophy on the Severn River.

title: In Spring a Boatman's Fancy Turns to Sail, Oar and Prop
description: Dedicated to the proposition that all boatlovers are created equal when Going Into Commission, it is time to reveal how the racing fraternity (and sorority) tries to overcome this burden in the pursuit of happiness (winning).

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market plunged sharply last week and recorded one of its largest weekly declines in history.

title: Marilyn, How We Loved You
description: I loved her from the first moment I saw her.

title: SON OF DENIM
description: The answer: gentle blue chambray. The question: after denim, what?

title: Grow the Flowers That Care for Themselves
description: WHEN garden maintenance becomes a severe problem, a change in the planting plan is usually the best solution. For many years, planting a ;profusion of annual flowers either in beds by themselves or among springblooming perennials has seemed the simplest way to achieve a successful summer garden.

title: Wasteful Arms Duplication Is Questioned Within NATO
description: BRUSSELS, April 28 (AP)The United States and its allies in the North Atlantic Treaty) Organization are wasting more than a billion dollars a year by competing with each other in arms manufactures and by not unifying their armed forces, a member of the alliance says.

description: ACROSS

description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Our House Providing New Hope For Youth
description: SOUTH ORANGEFour Years after its inception, Our House, a program for restoring, understanding between youth and adults, is winning a large measure of community acceptance in this area.

title: 2 LATIN COUNTRIES IN BORDER DISPUTE
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 28 Tempers are rising between South America's leading democracies; Colombia and Venezuela, over the disputed continental shelf and territorial waters in the Gulf of Venezuela area, where there are thought to be rich oil deposits.

title: UTILITIES IN WEST FEAR SHORTAGES
description: SAN DIEGO, April 28Major utilities in nine states of the Southwest warned this week of gasoline shortages within two months, gasoline prices of 75 cents to $1 gallon in the future, reliance on Arab nations for everincreasing oil imports, lagging research to develop alternate energy sources, and more than double the current prices for natural gas.

title: Kresge Foundation Gives U. of Chicago $3.5Million
description: The University of Chicago has received a $3.5million challenge grant from the Kresge Foundation toward construction of a Surgery and Brain Research Pavilion.

description: Warm weather checkmates: 1. Tableclothchecked jacket of seersuckerpuckered polyester and cotton is openpatchpocketed, centervented. By Mavest. $60 at Gimbels. Givenchy shirt. The slacks by Chaps.

title: Jacques Maritain Dies at 90
description: PARIS, April 28  Jacques Maritain, the renowned Roman Catholic philosopher, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in Toulouse at the community house of the Little Brothers of Jesus, where he had lived in retirement since 1960. He was 90 years old.

title: Stephanie Hill Engaged
description: WORTHINGTON, Ohio, April 28The engagement of Miss Stephanie L. Hill, to Earl G. Young 3d, son of Capt. Earl G. Young Jr., a New York Harbor pilot, and Mrs. Young of Warren, N. J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Hill of Worthington.

title: BOY KILLED, 2D HURT IN FALL OFF BMT CAR
description: One boy was killed and another critically injured yesterday when they fell to the subway tracks while riding on the outside end of the rear car of a BMT train as it sped from Manhattan to Brooklyn through a tunnel under the East River.

title: David Rabe Still Has Work to Do
description: IF David Rabe's The Orphan, now at the Public Theater, were a cohesive work for the theatera work that spoke its piece clearly to the audience it would be one of the most despairing plays ever written. Listen:

title: A Quarter of Peace
description: Three months after the signing of truce in Vietnam; the United States is still at war. Not only is the end not in sight, but each day brings new intimations that the Administration is ready for heightened combat in, Southeast Asia.

title: Invasion Of Sicily All in Fun
description: PALERMO, Sicily  Ever since man began sailing the Mediterranean, this island has been the target of invasion. Situated in one of the world's most historically important bodies of wateronly a 30minute ride by ferry boat from the Italian mainland this colorful island remains a focal point for the seagoing traffic of the countries surrounding it.

title: SCOUTS TAKE LEAD IN CLEANUP DRIVE
description: Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts throughout the country joined forces yesterday in a cleanup drive under the auspices of Keep America Beautiful, the national environment organization.

title: Council Member Gets a Death Threat
description: Aileen B. Ryan, a member of the City Council, said yesterday that she had been threatened with death and sexual mutilation by dozens of anonymous telephone callers because she had been absent from a committee vote Friday on a bill that would ban discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Welfare Study. Minimizes Impact of Migrant Blacks
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 28Southern blacks who have moved by the hundreds of thousands to the crowded inner cities of the North, mostly over the last two decades, are less likely to be poor or on welfare than their urbanborn counterparts, according to a new study of the 1970 Census findings.

title: In Praise of Windmills, Victims of a World They Helped Create
description: CARING for a windmill is like dealing with a very large problem child. When the child is abandoned, his moods and tantrums become more seriousuntil rehabilitation is nearly impossible. In a windmill that has lost its miller the unavoidable little breaks and spots of decay are left to feed upon themselves, and the mill deteriorates. Soon nothing remains but a shell, still picturesque but quite dead.

title: FRED FREEMAN
description: NEWARK, April 28  Fred Freeman, a trial lawyer and a member of the law firm of Freeman, Freeman & Cartier here, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. He was 63 years old and lived in Short Hills.

title: THEODORE H. MALMUD
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 28Theodore H. Malmud, under sheriff of Bronx County from 1939 until his retirement in 1969, died today at his home, Sherman Avenue. He was 69 years old.

title: REPORT ON MEN'S WEAR
description: The change is as welcome as it is inevitable and, sartorially, this might be the first sensible summer of the seventies. Clothes don't seem to be coming on quite so strong, trying so hard to startle. The mood for summer '73 is muted and relaxed. There is a reliance on classic, triedandtrue fabrics, which can no longer be dismissed as mere nostalgia. The revived popularity of madras, seersucker, cotton and chambray is due, above all, to their good looks and proven performance. Even colors have cooled it. While redwhiteandblue is still the favorite warm weather combination, white has left that everpopular trio and this summer solos most impressivelythe season's freshestlooking suits are frosty whiteand, with black, provides an elegant alliance in everything from shirts to shoes. In sportswear, softer tones have superseded yesterday's cartoon colors: even the ice cream shades are more Louis Sherry than BaskinRobbins. The sense of fun, has not fled, however. Boating gear is brightly splashed and color is creating something of a racket on the tennis courts. And the jean generation has inspired at least two nifty ideas: pennantworthy baseball jackets and the easygoing and (relatively) inexpensive unconstructed sport coat.

title: LEFKOWITZ WAITS FOR MET'S REPORT
description: The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, said last week that if a White Paper being prepared by the Metropolitan Museum of Art on its operations was unsatisfactory, he might prepare his own White Paper.

title: Soviet Emigration Curbs Said to Continue
description: MOSCOW, April 28  Item: Denis A. Pekarev, a Moscow geometry instructor, is being denied permission to emigrate to Israel on the ground that his parents will not give written permission. Mr. Pekarev is 35 years old and married.

title: Watergate Case Believed to Have Weakened Ellsberg Prosecution
description: LOS ANGELES, April 284 The public disclosure man months ago of the Waterside bugging apparently had the effect of softening somewhat the Government's courtroom effortg to convict Daniel Ellsberg Anthony J. Russo Jr., soaves close to the trial now believe.

title: Photography
description: CAN you imagine a museum of painting that devoted onethird of its exhibition space to pictures and the rest to brushes, paints, easels and canvases, with perhaps a few lifesize dummies, a la Madame Tussaud, of artists at work and art lovers looking at the results of their work? No, of course you cannot. But that, or its photographic equivalent, is exactly what you will find at the Smithsonian Institution's new Hall of Photography at the National Museum of History and Technology in Washington, D. C. And strangely enough, it works.

title: Drugs Counseling Seems to Help
description: The Board of Education's $3.6million SPARK drugprevention program for New York high schools is showing a marked degree of effectiveness in changing student behavior, according to a report made public last week by Gordon Chase, head of the Health Services Administration.

title: Embattled Director of Institute In Princeton Vows to Stay On
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 Dr. Carl Kaysen, director of the Institute for Advanced Study, who has been asked by the institute's trustees to stay on for at least five years, said today that he intended to stay and serve as long as I can usefully do so.

title: Ann Howard Is Wed To Patrick B. Impett
description: Miss Ann Howard, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. John A. Howard of Utica, N.Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Patrick Bruce Impett of San Francisco. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Vernon G. Impett of Seattle.

title: N.Y.U. NAMES SITE FOR A BENEFACTOR
description: New York University Medical Center yesterday honored the memory of one of its benefactors by naming its new center mall and entrance at 550 First Avenue at 31st Street, the Samuel D. Leidesdorf Plaza.

title: A Russian Beauty
description: History offered the gift of several lives to Vladimir Nabokov, and he made of it what we know: an odyssey of three languages, a stylish fable of emigres and aristocrats which he conjured finally into English, and at least one masterpiece, Lolita. Since then, it is generally agreed, he has become America's foremost, one might say our official, literary stylist: prodigiously active, caustic; alternating brilliant new works with older ones from the emigr past, retooled into English either by himself or, usually, by his son Dimitri. It is a unique destiny: to refit one's past lives to a new language, becoming again the author of one's youth; a conjuror's trick, to use one of Nabokov's favorite images. Through it, a writer haunted by an inaccessible past contrives to have no past. His background shimmers forward, year by year, to be reauthored as foreground.

title: Double Trouble for the Nation's Dinner Table
description: CHICAGOMother Nature and the Food and Drug Administration dealt heavy blows last week to the Nixon Administration's grand design to halt the rise in food prices.

title: What are they eating in Lisbon tonight? By Jean Hewitt
description: The Portuguese cuisine seems to be one of the culinary world's bestkept secrets. Ask the next person you meet what his or her favorite Portuguese dish is. Chances are he won't be able to come up with an answer. The three recipes on this pagethe basis of a pleasant springtime dinnershould change the situation. They were contributed by Betty Wason, the cookbook writer who has been living in Portugal for the last handful of years.

title: MOVEMENT DEFIES SIOUX ON FUNERAL
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., April 28 Leaders of the American Indian Movement said this afternoon that they would defy the Oglala Sioux Indian tribe and the Federal Government and march onto the Pine Ridge Reservation tomorrow to bury a Wounded Knee insurgent who died Wednesday from a gunshot wound.

title: U.S. GROUPS PLAN SALUTES TO ISRAEL
description: Israel's 25th anniversary as a nation will be observed with ceremonies here and around the country next Sunday, May 6, and on Monday, May 7.

title: CAMDEN IS ALLOWED TO DUMP IN ATLANTIC
description: The Environmental Protection Agency issued an interim permit Friday to the City of Camden, N. J., allowing it to continue dumping its sewage in the Atlantic Ocean, but in a new area 50 miles offshore instead of the current dumping site 12 miles from the coast.

title: HORSE SHOW TITLE GOES TO THE HUN
description: KENT, Conn., April 28 The Hun, last year's Professional Horsemen's Association highpoint champion, made his spring outdoor debut today and captured the open jumper title at the Kent School horse show.

title: Peace Corps Post Filled
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 28 (UPI)  Dr. Caroline Dinegar of New York City has taken over as director of the Peace Corps in Malaysia, which with 340 volunteers forms the largest corps contingent in any of the 59 countries the program serves.

title: The Monumental Martha
description: AS a choreographer, Martha Graham is also a brilliant archeologist. Or is it psychologist? At any rate, during her long career, she has been adept at exposing famous old scars of the Western world and making them bleed significantly.

title: Bertram Medley Jr. Weds Gail Johnson
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Miss Gail Christine Johnson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. H. Nelson Johnson of Westport, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Bertram Albert Medley, Jr., son of Mr. Medley of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Medley. Canon Jeffrey Cave performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Chapel at the Episcopal Cathedral of SS.Peter and Paul (the National Cathedral).

title: I.R.S. Orders Refunds on 1972 Cars
description: NEWARK  Thanks to the Internal Revenue Service, at least 400 people who purchased new cars in New Jersey last year will soon be receiving refunds averaging $50 each.

title: U.S. Tennis Open Stays With Grass for 1973
description: The United States Open tennis championships will be played on grass, after all.

title: Steam Engines Still Chug Through East Europe, but Supertrains Are Due Soon
description: Steam Locomotives  with their traditional sounds and aromas that haunt oldtime rail fansare still flourishing in Eastern Europe. But impressive modernization programs will phase them out in just a few more years.

title: Bettina Patterson Wed To Anthony Manheim
description: GIBSON ISLAND, Md., April 28  Miss Bettina Patterson, who is with the United Nations Development Program in New York, was married here this afternoon to Anthony A. Manheim, a vice president of Allen & Co., New York investment bankers. The Rev. Peter Fulghum and the Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the Episcopal ceremony in St. Christopher's Chapel by the Sea.

title: Phase 2 Charge Filed On 2 Florida Hotels
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 28 (AP)Two Orlando hotels have been charged by the Federal Government with overcharging customers by more than $500,000 during Phase 2 price controls.

title: Floods Among Worst In History
description: ST. LOUISThe overflowing Mississippi River and its tributaries had covered some 10million acres by last week. It is an area larger than Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island. The water had caused $200million worth of damage; forced 30,000 persons from their homes, and brought untold hardship to the farmer.

title: Harbor Patrol Expects a 50% Cut
description: Although city police officials deny that the 197man harbor patrol will be reduced 50 per cent, an authoritative source maintains the unit will be cut sharply by July in an effort to use all available policemen on the streets.

title: Los Angeles Is Imposing Drastic Curbs on Jet Noise
description: The most drastic airport noise restrictions in the nation are scheduled to take effect in Los Angeles today against a backdrop of mounting public hostility to jet noise that has all but halted the start of new jetports across the country.

title: Mo Bay Captures $30,700 Handicap at Pimlico
description: BALTIMORE, April 28 (AP)Augustin Stables' Mo Bay spoiled Bee Bee Bee's return to the races today with a wire to wire victory in the $30,700 Riggs Handicap at Pimlico. This was the first start since last July for Bee Bee Bee, the 1972 Preakness winner, who finished sixth.

title: Private Gifts to Colleges Set Record
description: A record total of $2.02billion was donated by private sources to American colleges and universities last year, according to an estimate based on a survey by the Council for Financial Aid to Education.

title: Stamler Sums Up Career
description: MORRISTOWN  Superior Court Judge Joseph H. Stamler, who has gained wide respect during his seven years on the bench, is retiring this week. For the last three and onehalf years, the judge, who has handed down decisions of both statewide and national impact, has served in the Chancery Division in Morris County.

title: WAR POSSIBLE NOW, MRS. MEIR ASSERTS
description: TEL AVIV, April 28 (AP)Premier Golda Meir today described Egypt's President, Anwar elSadat, as a leader in distress and said that Israel must be prepared for a new war that he might start.

title: Guinness Book of World Records
description: Biggest, smallest, longest, shortest, highest, heaviest, loudest, hottest  this wacky collection of superlatives came about as an argumentsettler in bars. At least, so Benjamin Guinness tells us in a brief foreword to this latest edition of the book that bears his stout name.

title: Home Improvement
description: WITHOUT need for doing any wiring anyone can now add adjustable lighting units wherever there is an pxisting wall or counter electrical outlet, or an existing screwin lighting receptacle. Two new adjustable, swiveltype lighting fixtures, each with its own opaque shade, make this possible. One consists of a short arm with a male plug at one end that will fit into a standard receptacle; the other end of the arm has a shade and socket mounted on a tension swivel that wit hold the light in any direr tion aimed. The other unit basically the same, except that instead of a male plug it has a male screwin plug to fit a standard bulb socket. Each takes a 40watt appliance bulb. The first is ideal for kitchen counters and other work surfaces, the second is useful in closets over garage and basement shelves and workbenches and in bathrooms. Plugmate (for plugging in) and Swivelier No. PH1, $8.50 each at hardware, houseware and department stores (Swivelier Co., Inc., Dept. CS, Nanuet, N.Y. 10954).

title: Media
description: Practical, warmhearted people they are, for the most part, and wellendowed with cash and college degrees. They enjoy cartoons. They worry about cruelty to animals. They wield influence in their communities, often college towns. They care about disarmament and the United Nations. They are dissatisfied with TV. And they love to read.

title: Stamps
description: ASTAMP in memoriam to Harry S. Truman will come out on May 8. The stamp is being put out at. Independence, Missouri, onetime starting point of the old Santa Fe and Oregon Trails, and a town that was a part of Harry Truman wherever he was. It, was also the place to which he returned to live a smalltown life after he left the Presidency.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When the World Hockey Association began raiding the National Hockey League for players nearly a year ago, the New York Rangers preserved their nucleus of talent by opening their treasury. Brad Park, Vic Hadfield, Jean Ratelle, Rod Gilbert, Walt Tkaczuk, Jim Neilson, Rod Selling and Ed Giacomin suddenly were men of opulence, some with salaries reported to be as high as $200,000 each. Other teams kept their pocketbooks closed to certain players, rather than let the moths escape. The players escaped instead. Gerry Cheevers, John McKenzie and Derek Sanderson defected from the Boston Bruins, the holders of the Stanley Cup, although Sanderson later returned. Bobby Hull deserted the Chicago Black Hawks and J. C. Tremblay left the Montreal Canadiens. On paper, particularly the paper used for the Internal Revenue Service's form 1040, the Rangers had the N.H.L's most impressive team.

title: LIVERPOOL TAKES CROWN IN SOCCER
Nightlife for 23,000 in Sheepshead Bay Means School
description: Remember those Tuesday nights in the early 50's when stores closed, streets emptied, and families huddled around their television sets to watch Uncle Miltie romp through an hour of zany antics? Well, in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, an evening adult school is having a similarly captivating effect.

title: Social Announcements
TERRYFIED
description: Tuned in to terry trio.

title: Rejuvenated Port of Camden Makes Waves in Philadelphia
description: CAMDENAlthough minisized in comparison, the rejuvenated Port of Camden is beginning to nudge, if not shove, the major Port of Philadelphia across the Delaware River.

title: WHIPPET IS PICKED AT STANTON SHOW
description: STANTON, Del., April 28A whippet proved to be a good mudder at the Delaware Park race course today and was named best in a field of 2,097 dogs at the Wilmington Kennet Club's 32d show.

title: Ft. Greene House Tour: Styles From 7 Decades
description: This afternoon's Fort Greene House Tour in downtown Brooklyn offers the participant a varied glimpse into the architectural fashions of the 19th century. For unlike most brownstone neighborhoods in Manhattan or Brooklyn, the Fort Greene area developed over a 70 to 80year periodroughly 1830 to 1900and it was a neighborhood of middleclass and wealthy families.

title: 40 Miles in 3:49:32
description: EWELL, England, April 28 (AP)Joe Keating, 24yearold English marathon runner, claimed a world record today after running 40 miles in 3 hours 49 minutes 32 seconds. The previous best, 3:49:49, was by Scotland's Alastair Wood in 1969.

title: Building Costs Jump
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP)Philadelphia area construction costs during the last 12 months increased 16.6 per cent, the biggest advance in the nation, a survey by the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill showed Wednesday.

title: Hilary S. Roche Is Married to John W. Geary 2d
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 28The First Presbyterian Church of Southampton was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Hilary Somers Roche, a debutante of the 1968 season, to John White Geary 2d, who is a partner of Ziebarth, Geary & Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. The Rev. John L. Felmeth performed the ceremony.

title: New OilSpill Cure Is Tested
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Two Rutgers University scientists have announced the development of a new substance to treat accidental oil spills in the ocean.

title: Television
description: THE project is ambitious. Using a series of television hours, the Regional Plan Association, a private and nonprofit planningresearch agency, is attempting to stimulate town meetings on various problems affecting the tristate area of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The results so far are considerably below expectations, at least those expectations fostered in advance publicity for the project.
