title: FEDERAL ART BE FACES FUND FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Once the target of Congressional snickers over fancy toe dancers and longhaired fiddlers, the National Endowment for the Arts has discovered that there are perils, too, in being taken seriously.

title: TransAm Still Here, But It's in Name Only
description: The old TransAm, she ain't what she used to be. The roadracing series, once limited to pony cars like Mustang, Camaro and Javelin, has been refurbished so radically that only a few aspects of the old format are recognizable. The new model, with a much greater variety of cars and a race lengthened to 310 miles, makes its debut in this part of the country next Sautrday at Lime Rock in western Connecticut. The race, designated the. Schaefer TransAm, is the second event of a sevenrace series, and it carries a purse of $35,000. It will be run over the 1.53mile course that winds through Lime Rock's amphitheater in a parklike setting.

title: Soviet Permits Return Of 18 Jewish Emigrants
description: VIENNA, April 28 (UPI)Eighteen Jews who emigrated to Israel left Austria for the Soviet Union today after having failed to adjust to life in Israel.

title: Recipes that fight high prices
description: Scene 1: My work room: With all the enthusiasm of a lethargic camel, I greet a Times messenger with yet another cookbook. But lo! I read the title and the foreword . . . and already, to vary the zoological simile, I find I'm reacting like a kitten to a fresh bunch of catnip. I read on.

title: This Capital H Stands for Ambrose
description: During an unexpected cruise on a 17foot Boston whaler last summer, I was introduced to a strange Trojanlike figure sitting in the water off New York Harbor. My interest aroused, I took a return trip on a 44foot Coast Guard lifeboat and got closer to what looks like a capital H.

title: James A. O'Neill, 55, Dies; Headed Niagara Mohawk
description: BUFFALLO, April 28 (AP)James A. O'Neill, president of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, died today. He was 55 years old.

title: Mrs. Schacht Is Wed Here
description: Mrs. Gillian Wormall Schacht of New York was married here yesterday morning to Dr. Norman D. Newell of Leonia, curator and chairman of the department of invertebrate paleontology at the American Museum of Natural History. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Orioles Turn Back A's, 2 to 1, as Palmer Outpitches Holtzman
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 28 (UPI)Bobby Grich singled and scored Baltimore's first run, then homered in the third for the winning one today as Jim Palmer outpitched Ken Holtzman to give the Orioles a 21 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: Mississippi Flooding Hits Record Levels At 2 Illinois Towns
description: The flooding Mississippi River, washing over or caving in levees as its crest moved southward, broke 129year records at a pair of waterlogged Illinois towns yesterday and far to the south a towboat crewman was missing after his craft hit a pier on the flooded river.

title: U.S. & Japan
description: TOKYOThey called it the Emperor shock here.

title: William Barksdale Ferrell Jr. To Marry Page E. Holrnyard
description: Miss Page Ellen Holmyard will be married to William Barksdale Ferrell Jr., a realestate broker of Delray, Fla. The ceremony is planned for Oct. 27 in the First Baptist Church, Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Mrs. Ransohoff Is Bride of Peter Wynn
description: Mrs. Joan Ransohoff, a consultant in urban affairs with the Fund for the City of New York, was married here yesterday to Peter Matfield Wynn, Deputy Commissioner of the Addiction Services Agency of New York City, at the home of the bridegroom. The Rev. Edwin Lane, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Brooke Ferris Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Ferris of Caracas, Venezuela, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Brooke Wallace Ferris, to Cary Langhorne Washburn Jr., son of Mr. Washburn of McLean, Va., who is an Assistant Secretary of Commerce for tourism in Washington, and the late Mrs. Margaret Harrison Washburn. The wedding is planned for December in Washington.

title: New Collegiate Caper: Sailing Concrete Canoes
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (UPI) Collegians at several eastern Pennsylvania schools have revived the obscure art of concreteboat building for tomorrow's first running of the intercollegiate concrete canoe race.

title: Ellen Pierson Bride of S. W. Marlin
description: MANHASSET, L. I., April 28Miss Ellen Margaret Pierson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Pierson of Plandome, was married today at noon to Scott William Marlin, son of Mr. and. Mrs. William Marlin of Wantaugh. The Rev. Robert Brown performed the ceremony here in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Frostbiters Introduce New Twist
description: Frostbiters at Stuyvesant Yacht Club, City Island, extended their winter racing season this year to try a new kind of competition: the sailing slalom.

title: GALVESTON COACH ASKED TO RESIGN
description: GALVESTON, Tex., April 28 (AP)Joe Woolley, head football coach at Galveston Ball High School, says he altered Ball's copy of the transcrip of an Oklahoma football player, Kerry Jackson, but he had nothing to do with changing Oklahoma's copy.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in last Sunday's New Jersey edition said incorrectly that a poll of the student body at Matawan Regional High School showed that more than half thestudents admitted to having shoplifted in neighborhood stores. The poll of 930 students was taken at two middle schools in Matawan, the Lloyd Road and Matawan Avenue Schools, by students from Matawan Regional High School.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports
description: TodayNorthern New Jersey Region, Sports Car Club of America open contest board meeting at Golden Crown Restaurant, 149 West Westfield Avenue, Roselle Park, N. J., 2 P.M.

title: State Swinging to Folk  Dance Tunes
description: HACKENSACK  International folkdancing appears to be sweeping the state. Every night of the week, at various places and various times, community groups and individuals are stepping to the tunes of foreign dances.

title: Dance
Charge of Politics Again Raised in Brownsville School Elections
description: History is repeating itself, in a sense, in the upcoming school board election in Ocean HillBrownsville's District 23.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE UNITED STATES trade deficit narrowed sharply to $53million in March from $476million in February. . . . Gold closed in London at $90.60 an ounce at the weekend against $90.75 a week betore. . . . The composite of economic indicators advanced 1.4 per cent in March 161.1 per cent of the 1967 base. . . . McGrawHill reports planned capital outlays by industry this year will total $105.3billion, up 19 per cent from actual outlays in 1972.

title: Poll Indicates Ethical Rules for Newspapers Differ
description: Should newspaper reporters be allowed to hold outside jobs in their communities, or might that pose a conflict of interest? How about unpaid volunteer work in civic or charitable organizations?

title: Exhibit Unfolds L I., Maritime History
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.From whaling in the sixteensixties to rum running in the nineteentwenties, a great deal of Long Island history has been tied to the sea.

title: Ava Goldman Is Wed
description: Miss Ava Eylse Goldman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Goldman of Howard Beach, Queens, was married last evening to Lewis Steven Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Silverman of Brooklyn. Rabbi David W. Gordon performed the ceremony in the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center in Queens. The bride is a sales representative for Little Topsy's, Inc., a New York children's wear manufacturer. Her husband is on the news staff of Reuters, the news service.

title: Elizabeth Arkin Wed To Jeppe B. Nygaard
description: Miss Elizabeth Jane Arkin, daughter of Mrs. Alvin M. Arkin of New York and the late Dr. Arkin, an orthopedic surgeon, was married here last evening to Jeppe Bech Nygaard. Sufrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN THE LAST week, with Congress in recess for its Easter vacation, Representative William S. Moorhead, a Pittsburgh Democrat, has been touring his workingclass district in a rented Winnebago van to determine what issues were troubling his constituents.

title: Tree Loss Forcing Squirrels Into Houses
description: ELIZABETHWhether they cavort in roomy attics or squeeze into the skeletal space between walls, squirrels are posing a gnawing problem for a growing number of New Jersey homeowners.

title: FOR THE BOYS OF SUMMER
description: As a fashion inspiration, sports have scored rousingly: the football jersey, ski jacket, rugby shirt and basketball shorts, to count off just a few. This summer, baseball has its inning.

title: L.I. Class Looks Into A Dispute In Brooklyn
description: BAY SHORE, L. I.Textbooks and lectures may provide the foundation for education, but when a group of seriousminded local high school students recently decided to personally investigate their current classroom topic, a dispute between homeowners and a large corporation took on new meaning.

title: White House Tourists Accused of Vandalism
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)  A young man and woman making the regular public tour of the White House were arrested today after they allegedly splashed a red liquid on a wall and furniture in the executive mansion's State Dining Room.

title: SHOP TALK
description: When their cramped West Side quarters were gutted by a fire a few months ago, Bob Berman and Jim Kronen packed up their old scientific and mechanical instruments and their American folk art and moved to a more spacious shop on the East Side.

title: Alcoholic Women in the Suburbs: There's More Room to Hide
description: Special to The New York Times WESTPORT, Conn.  It is a typical day for Barbara C.

title: Parent and Child: Society's child? Or society's victim?
description: A 15yearold had a big fight with her mother. She wanted more freedom and independence. The teenager threatened angrily to run away from home. But then she asked, with a flash of insight, You'll send the police after me, won't you?

title: SIBERIA RAIL FORCES GET VETERAN STATUS
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  The 33 surviving members of the American unit that helped build Russia's TransSiberian railroad during World War I will receive honorable discharges after a 50year fight for them.

title: AIDTOSTUDENT BILL SIGNED BY PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 CAP) President Nixon signed into law today a bill providing $872million in student aid for the coming college year even though it was not the kind of aid the President had requested.

title: Man Held With Explosives
description: SUN VALLEY, Calif., April 28 (UPI)A man described as a suspected rightwing extremist was arrested yesterday and the authorities confiscated enough explosives to blow up an entire block. The arrest of Joseph Francis Budnek Jr., 45 years old, culminated a twomonth investigation by Treasury agents. About 150 pounds of explosives were recovered.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 29, 1973

title: Doubts in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH  Black columns of smoke were rising disagreeably close to the center of Phnom Penh last week, some caused by Communist rockets and others by intense American air strikes. But on the whole, it was business  and politics  as usual in the Cambodian capital.

title: SHOP TALK
description: PINE BROOK  Rich's Hobbytowne and the Hook Mt. Junction Model Museum both had their beginnings in Greenville, N.C., 24 years ago. That is when Richard Palmer, the owner of these two establishments, was working his way through college by selling model gliders to the youngsters who came to the local airport to watch the planes.

title: Indictments? When?
description: WASHINGTONTwelve days ago, President Nixon told the nation of major developments in the Watergate scandal and said that real progress had been made in finding the truth. His remarks inevitably triggered speculation that the Watergate grand jury was ready to hand down more indictments, perhaps involving some high officials of the Administration.

title: SIKKINESE PRINCE IMPLICATES INDIA
description: The nephew of the ruler of Sikkim charged here yesterday that neocolonialist elements within the Indian Government were responsible for the recent political crisis in the Himalayan protectorate.

title: Scheckter of So. Africa Paces Riverside. Trials
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., April 28 Scheckter, the 23yearold South, African prodigy, led a field of 37 quilifiers today for tomorrow's opening of the 1973 L&M Championship for formula 5000 cars, which promises to he the most competitive series of road events on this year's motorracing calendar.

title: COLOR KICK
description: News note: the American Footwear Institute says that the colorful new shoes are being accepted by Young America. But first, here are five for the more mature American. Top, an enameled strap crosses a red and white crinkled patent leather slipon by Johnston & Murphy. $55 at Frank Bros. Top left,a moccasintoed, fiveeyelet shoe of white patent by Verde. $20 at Lynn Boot and Shoe. Bottom left, patent leather saddle shoe with a broad toe, $30. By and at Bostonian Shoes. Top right, the tasselfronted patent leather slipon by London Character is $25 at Barney's. Bottom right,red and blue bands stripe the elasticized vamp of a grained white leather slipon. $32 at Saks Fifth Avenue. 1. Leathertoed shoe with striped suede sides, $35. 2. Fake laces cross platformsoled patent leather. $35. Both by Harbor Imports at Le Mans. 3. Moccasintoed, mahogany leather. $26. By and at London Character Boutiques. 4. Olympiclook, pillow calf shoe, $32. 5. Brass rings lace up on plaintoed calf. $32. Both, by Renegades, at House of Cromwell in June. 6. Triangletrimmed, rubbersoled shoe, $18. By and at Flagg Bros. 7. Leatherwingtipped suede, by Crosby Square. $21 at Karpathy Shoes. 8. Art Deco designs on a leather shoe by and at London Character Boutiques $52. 9. Suedepatched, zigzagstitched shoe by Verde, $22 at London Character. 10. Squaretoed shoe with tritoned platform sole, $33. 11. Redpiped green leather on a high red heel, $33. Both and at Arrowsmith.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: When the Shenyang Acrobatic Troupe was televised by the American Broadcasting Company on April 18 it was a fairly remarkable example of corporate doityourself.

title: Headliners
description: The regime of Greek Premier George Papadopoulos dismisses most of its Greek critics in exile as irresponsible leftists. An exception is 66yearold Constantine Caramanlis, who for eight years was Premier of a stable and conservative Government but, who, since an election defeat in 1963, has lived in Paris Last week, as Premier Papadopoulos and his colleagues marked the sixth anniversary of the coup that brought them to power, Mr. Caramanlis broke a 3 year silence to call on the Papadopoulos Government to resign and to bring back King Constantine from exile in Rome. Mr. Caramanlis charged that the junta had disrupted the armed forces damaged the economy, oppressed the people and the press arid engaged in unprecedented brutality against protesting students. Three papers in Greece printed the statement but Athens anthorities seized the copies, saying they contained an act of subversion.

title: Art
description: ACCORDING to a report from the National Gallery in Washington issued on April 18th, those Russian paintingsor, rather, those French paintings on loan from the USSR had already attracted nearly 225,000 visitors by that date, This would be about 12,500 a day, wouldn't it, for an exhibition that opened May I. The doors close at 6 o'clock tonight and the pictures come down for shipment to New York. Not counting on lastminute supercrowds, the attendance figure should wind up at better than 362,000. For the exhibition's New York run, from May 3 to June 2, at Knoedler, 21 East 70th Street, there will be a $2 admission charge (for the benefit of the National Gallery), but everybody will be wanting to see these pictures anyway. Count me in.

title: Mentally Retarded Patient, 12, Raped
description: A 35yearold clothing clerk at the state institution for the mentally retarded at 75 Morton Street in Greenwich Villageh as been charged with raping a 12yearold girl patient at the recently opened faeility.

title: New School for Handicapped
description: PARAMUSSusan goes to a very special school, a school where her many problems can be handled in a very special way.

title: Thalidomide: the American experience
description: [The Merrell company's] plans called for marketing thalidomide before... spring [of 1961]; estimates are that if they had been successful in their hope, about 10,000 American babies would have been born with gross deformities. That Merrell was not successful is due largely to luck.James S. Turner, project director, in The Chemical Feast, The Ralph Nader Study Group Report on the Food and Drug Administration.

title: MiniBoats Turning Into a Big Deal
description: There's a revolution going onin small boats. Sometimes called fun boats or seamobiles or just simply oneman craft, they come in all sizes, shapes, colors and prices, but with one thing in common: zippiness.

title: State Presses to Finish I280
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey Department of Transportation and construction crews are racing to complete a vital 12mile stretch of I280 by June 30, two months before the latest deadline. They think they can make it, given continued normal spring weather. The road was originally scheduled for completion 10 years ago.

title: A fifth term next year, and a first term two years hence?
description: ALBANY. The Electric Company, a children's educational TV show, satirizes soap opera with a playlet in which a boy stands by a chair, or sits in it, while a solemn narrator intones: The boy is standing. Will the boy sit down? Or: The boy is sitting. Will the boy stand up? This is called Love of Chair, and last summer it seemed like inspiration to link it with Nelson Rockefeller's vacillating attitude toward running for a fifth term as Governor in 1974.

title: Arnie Is Converted
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I.  Arnie is going into commission again next month on Bedell Creek, proving that his conversion from tee to sea is no fluke.

title: U.S. Park Service to Use Computers
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The National Park Service, faced with an outdoor recreation boom, is turning to computers.

title: Design will not solve society's ills
description: The last year has not been good for public lowincome housing. The Forest Hills controversy in New York, the Kawaida Towers project in Newark, the dramatic demolition of the St. Louis PruittIgoe project, the sorties in hysterical suburban communities across the country and other incidents playing upon the raw nerves of neighborhoods have created the image in the public mind that public housing is not the solution to our slums, but rather has become the new slums. Yet government statistics tell us that publicly assisted lowincome housing is the only type of shelter that an estimated 20 million illhoused Americans can afford. In New York City alone 550,000 persons now reside in public housing, with another 550,000 to in.

title: Concert: Baltimoreans
description: Sergiu Comissiona, the 45  year  old Rumanianborn conductor, has had a busy career, but not in New York. Most of his recent activity has been in Baltimore. He took over the orchestra there in 1969, and has also done a great deal of guest conducting in the United States and abroad. On Friday evening, he, his orchestra and other assorted forces appeared in Carnegie Hall as part of the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras series.

title: Music
description: The program that concluded the Contemporary Music Series at the New York Cultural Center on Wednesday night did not sound very contemporary. It was devoted to vocal music, and besides reaching back into the early part of the 20th century for some of its material, it kept to the more conservative among today's composers. For those who have not relished watching the voice being distended and distorted in the creations of our time, this was probably dandy: It is nice to hear the voice treated as voice. But the evening did have a sense of looking backward.

title: Movies
description: HOLLYWOOD THERE are few beards in the studio executive suites in the spring of 1973 and no love beads. There was a timethe summer of 1969, to be exactwhen everyone in Hollywood wore blue jeans or buckskin. Now, although hair is still long by 1962 standards, the men of power wear gray flannel, solid color ties, navy blue jackets with anchors on the navy blue buttons.

title: Leone Wants Brooklyn on Front Burner
description: Brooklyn Borough President Sebastian Leone led a rebellion in the. Board of Estimate last week against what he considered a tradition of favoritism for Manhattan at the expense of Brooklyn.

title: The Ohio a Dream Stream for Campers
description: Late summer. A gentle southwesterly wind caressed the tent flaps, and a golden path reflected from a full moon danced across the Ohio River. As I turned to pluck a pebble from the Indiana shore and send it skipping across the water, the stillness of the evening was broken by a ghost sound belonging to another era  a steamboat whistle.

title: Accent on Herbs At Sussex Farm
description: SUSSEX  Do you want nasturtiums or sorrel for salad? Angelica to make candy? Southernwood for fragrance? Or any of 100 or so herbs, spices, dried roots and bark, beans and berries? Then perhaps the place to go is Hollow Herb Farm, which nestles on the side of Pochuck Mountain in the Kittatinny range and in the rich, fertile Wallkill River Valley below.

title: Six Elderly Widows Dead In Fire in Kansas City, Kan.
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., April 28 (AP)Six elderly widows died early today in an apartment fire that the authorities said was set. At least five other persons, including one fireman, were taken to hospitals for treatment of smoke inhalation.

title: A Correction
description: Due to a typographical error, the perpupil operating expense of the Great Neck schools was incorrectly reported last week in a chart listing the expenditures of Long Island School districts. The figure should have been $2,515, not $2,215.

title: Gallagher Gains Net Final
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 28  Buddy Gallagher of Larchmont, N.Y., the topseeded player, gained the final round of the Concord junior invitation tennis tournament today by defeating Michael Benado of East Meadow, L.I 62, 64. Gary Adelman of Roslyn, LI., seeded No. 3, eliminated Jeff Hull of Mountain Lakes, N.J., 6.1, 60.

title: A Little PR Might Help
description: The state's ranking judges plan to create an information office, they announced last week. And though there were warnings from critics against relying on cosmetics, there was no oneat least in the justice systemwho asked why a public relations office might be needed for New York's judiciary.

title: Judith Anne Baldwin Betrothed To Steven Batchelor Hubbard
description: GROSSE POINTE, Mich., April 28  Walter Douarin Baldwin, vice chairman of Uniroyal, Inc., and Mrs. Baldwin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Anne Baldwin, to Steven Batchelor Hubbard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Chandler Hubbard.

title: For Anyone Remotely Interested, Atka Is About As Remote As You Can Get
description: ATKA AlaskaThis tiny village in the Aleutian Islands is one of the most satisfactorily remote spots in the whole United States. It'sa major achievement to get here, challenge to make your way out again, and while you're visiting Atka you're almost guaranteed that no one can reach you to bother you.

title: I Will Go Barefoot All Summer For You
description: Most novels for teenagers are morality tales; one way of judging them is by the quality of their morals. The majority have useless lessons: Stay chaste, keep away from drugs, obey your parents. I Will Go Bare foot All Summer For You is distinguished not only by the quality of its writing, but by what it chooses to teach.

title: L.I. Service Stations Are Thirsty
description: In the Long Island motorist's newest nightmare it is a hot Saturday morning in July and the gas gauge points to emptyand it has been there for at least 30 miles.

title: Cornell Is Accused of Bias Against Nonblacks
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 28Cornell University has been cited by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for what amounts to discrimination against nonblack students in the operation of some university programs and facilities, sources in the Cornell administration here said today.

title: In or Out of the Water, This Boat Is a Family Affair
description: As soon as Joanne and Charles Schreiber had taken their 18foot Marshall catboat out of the water in Rowayton, Conn., last December, they spent the year getting it ready to put back in.

title: Patricia O'Leary Wed
description: MILLERSVILLE, Md., April 28Miss Patricia Anne O'Leary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles O'Leary of Crofton, was married here this afternoon to Vincent J. Fiorda Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fiorda of Darien, Conn. The Rev. John McManus performed the ceremony in Our Lady of the Fields Roman Catholic Church.

title: Mrs. Hart Is Wed to Frank Resnik
description: Mrs. Susan Jane Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mack Leblang of New York, and Frank Haskell Resnik, an aide to the assistant administrator of the General Services Administration in Washington were married here yesterday evening at the Park East Synagogue by Rabbi Arthur Schneier, assisted by Cantor Alfred Oppenheimer.

title: Jayne Easton Is Bride
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 28The marriage of Miss Jayne Hilary Easton to G. Rainer Bruns took place here this evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Easton, parents of the bride. Rabbi Jerome Rosenbloom performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. H. NeumannBruns of Dusseldorf, Germany, and the late Comdr. Heinrich Bruns of the German Navy.

title: ALEXANDER BEATS LAVER BY 63 76
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, April 28 (UPI)  Sixthseeded John Alexander of Australia qualified for next month's World Championship Tennis final in Dallas by beating his secondseeded countryman, Rod Laver, 63, 76, today in the semifinal of the $50,000 Swedish professional tennis championships.

title: VISITING STEPS UP IN THE GERMANYS
description: MARIENBORN, West Germany, April 25  Time was, a little over a year ago, when driving from West Germany to East Germany and back was a tiresome exercise and sometimes a downright risk.

title: Johns Hopkins Defeats Army Lacrosse Team, 137
description: WEST POINT, N. Y.April 28Johns Hopkins, the Topranked lacrosse team in the country, broke open a tight game in the second half with a ninegoal scoring burst to defeat Army, 137, before 3, 700 fans at Clinton Field today. The victory was the Blue Jays' eighth of the season without a loss.

title: Arthur Daley
description: With approximately three minutes left to play, the Madison Square Garden stands broke into the chant, Let's go, Knicks. But it semed to lack the passion and the hysteria that this exhortation normally has. It was much too feeble, almost as if the emotion had been drained from it by the sad realization that the Knicks were beaten and that the only place they would go would be to Boston for the seventh and deciding game of their playoff series with the Celtics this afternoon. It has been a rude and shocking comedown for the zealots who worship so devotedly at the Knick shrine. Their demigods had rewarded their fervor by taking a masterful 3 to 1 lead over the Celtics in the first four games of this postseason match. The New Yorkers needed only one more victory to gain the championship series against the Los Angeles Lakers. They reached for it in Boston on Wednesday and missed by one palpitating point. They reached for it again the night before last in the Garden before their fanatical followers and missed emphatically by a 10point margin, 110 to 100.

title: HarvardYale Race Nears the Finish Line
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 28The annual HarvardYale. crew race, the oldest intercollegiate sports event in the United States, dating to 1852, may be abandoned or modified after this year's contest at New London, Conn., on June 16.Yale, which has not won the race since 1962, is changing its academic calendar and will close out its spring semester early in May, 1974. The athletic director, Carmen Cozza, has told his Harvard counterpart, Robert Watson, that it would be impractical to hold the oarsmen at the university for a month awaiting Harvard's availability to row the fourmile race.

title: Entrapment
description: WASHINGTONIt was not until 1932 that the Supreme Court first recognized the defense of entrapment, the claim by a defendant that disguised law enforcement agents deceived him into commission of a crime of which he should therefor be judged innocent.

title: Soviet Aide Leaves Norway
description: OSLO, Norway, April 28 (AP)  Valery N. Erofeyev, an attach with the Soviet Embassy here, has left Norway, the Foreign Ministry announced today. Newspapers here reported yesterday that the police had said that Mr. Erofeyev had tried to recruit Norwegian spies.

title: Numismatics
description: THE first annual Greater New York Coin Convention opens at noon Thursday in the New York Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street. It will continue through next Sunday.

title: Forecaster For Suffolk Sacks Klein On Shore
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. LCounty Executive John V. N. Klein's call for a halt to construction along Suffolk's beachfront was endorsed last week by the county's meteorologist as the most stable defense against hurricane damage.

title: PICK COTTON
description: 1. Lively boxplaidwoven cotton jacket has flapped pockets, a center vent. By College Hall. $80. Wallachs. Excello shirt.

title: Weicker's Independence Rouses Resentment Among Republicans
description: HARTFORD, April 28He wants to show he's his own man, a Connecticut Republican said with mixed feelings of envy and resentment of Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: AGNEW REMAINS TOP G.O.P. CHOICE
description: Vice President Agnew is still the favorite of Republican voters for the Presidential nomination in 1976, the Gallup poll reported yesterday.

title: Drug Raids Terrorize 2 Familiesby Mistake
description: COLLINSVILLE, Ill., April 28  Herbert Giglotto was asleep with his wife in their townhouse apartment here the Other night. He heard crash by the front door. He stumbled from bed.

title: CARLOS MENDITEGUY, ARGENTINE DRIVER
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 27 (UPI)Carols Alberto Menditeguy, veteran Argentine racing driver and polo player, died Friday. He was 58 years old.

title: MISS PRENTICE LEADS IN BIRMINGHAM GOLF
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 28 (UPI)JoAnn Prentice, cheered on by hometown fans, took the secondround lead today in the Birmingham Classic Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament by one stroke over Mrs. Donna Caponi young, who had seven birdies.

title: CapsizeYou'll Like It
description: You may have heard many times what I've been told for years: You ought to take out the dinghy and roll it over, just for the experience. You may also feel as I did for years that, no matter how many junior programs and families like the Kennedys endorse and practice this, it sounds like a dumb thing to do.

title: WHALERS AND JETS OPEN FINAL TODAY
description: BOSTON, April 28 (AP)The Winnipeg Jets, led by Bobby Hull, and the New England Whalers open a fourofsevengame series for the first World Hockey championship tomorrow night at Boston Garden.

title: Blast on Train Carrying Bombs For Navy Injures 48 on Coast
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 28 (AP)A train loaded with Navy munitions, including 250pound bombs exploded in a Southern Pacific railway yard today, spewing flames, shrapnel and debris over a onesquaremile area and injuring at least 148 persons.

title: Retired New York Pilot Boat Goes South
description: An old harbor landmark has gone south.

title: Sally A. Helies To Be a Bride
description: ROXBURY, Conn., April 28 Mr. and Mrs. John Claude Helies of Roxbury and Point Lookout, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Ann Helies, to James Forsht Walker. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Walker of Lock Haven, Pa. A wedding in July is planned.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Gray Finds The Exit
description: WASHINGTON  I came to this town with reputation and integrity and I'm going to take it away, so help me God.

title: Benson Boy
description: Ivan Southall is best known in this country for Hills End, Ash Road and To the Wild Sky. Those are fastmoving action and suspense novels with spectacular backdrops of Australia's interior. Characters are varied, even believable, but outlined, not drawn in depth. Their function is strictly to keep the plot moving along.

title: Doorways to the Past: Tours in 2 Counties
description: The lifestyles of New Jersey's yesteryearthe ways in which people lived, worked, worshipped, had fun, fought and died in the 18th and 19th Centurieswill be on view a historic sites in Union County today and in Madison next Saturday.

title: How to Get More Mileage Out of Less Fuel
description: A boating industry environmental executive has outlined an engine maintenance program for the country's powerboat owners to follow as a way of conserving gasoline in case of a fuel shortage this summer.

title: Fiat Importer s Plans New Facility in Jersey
description: FiatRoosevelt Motors, Inc., the importer and distributor of Fiat automobiles in the United States, and Fiat Motor Company, U.S., will consolidate four facilities in Berto 150,000 square feet. The complex will accommodate 250 employes. Brodsky, Hopf & Adler of New York are the architects and engineers for the project, and Mixon & Blood of Montreal are the associate architects. I. E. C. Properties, Ltd., an affiliate of International Equity Company, Ltd., of Montreal, owns the property. gen County, N. J., into a new national headquarters complex in Montvale. The new threestory building, scheduled to be completed in July, 1974, at an estimated cost of $5.5million, will be on an 11.5acre site on the Garden States Parkway at Chestnut Ridge Road. It will contain 100,000 square feet of space, with provision for expansion to 150,000 square feet. The complex will accommodate 250 employes. Brodsky, Hopf & Adler of New York are the architects and engineers for the project, and Mixon & Blood of Montreal are the associate architects. I. E. C. Properties, Ltd., an affiliate of International Equity Company, Ltd., of Montreal, owns the property.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS UNIT FIGNTS BUS PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Congress of Racial Equality, a longtime foe of racial discrimination, has lined up with the Nixon Administration and the state of Virginia in an attempt to block Supreme Court approval of public school integration across citysuburban lines.

title: Haldeman and Ehrlichman
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The basic assumption of the American political system is that parties will fight hard for power, but that there is a limit beyond which the clash of personal and party strife cannot go without impairing the essential unity of the nation. This is the imponderable the Nixon Administration forgot.

title: $20Million Complex for Bronx Voted
description: At a hearing attended by more than 800 people, members of Community Board 6 in the Bronx gave formal approval last week to a $20million project for the redevelopment of the Fordham Road area.

title: Miss Kulakowski Married in Jersey
description: EDISON, N. J., April 28Miss Darlene Lorraine Kulakowski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Kulakowski, was married here this afternoon to Edward W. Marron Jr., son of. Mr. and Mrs. Marron of HoHoKus. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph R. Brzozowsld in Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church.

title: Grand Jury Gets U.S. Files on Vesco
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)  The State Department said today that it had turned over files to a Federal grand jury in New York that is investigating the financial activities of Robert L. Vesco a contributor to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: If you want to be unobtrusive, don't deal with a tattooed man
description: Have you ever taken a cab ride across Queens with a driver who had a story to tell? Eternally the tale unreels, fascinating in its scope and prolixity, very colloquial, very New York, parochialism combined with a gutter worldliness, autobiography mixed with fantasy elements from the Late Show, a semifamous name dropped as casually as the first atomic bomb, the narrator getting all the good lines in the various meetings, confrontations and arguments along the meandering way, and by the time you pay the eightbuck meter in Long Island City all really want to hear for the next three days Is silence. The Cabby Saga is an art form as ritualized as kabuki or a transit strike, and Mike Landress and Bruce Dobler, neither of whomare in fact cabdrivers, have finally committed the form to paper, with all its glories and all its other parts, too.

title: Points for a Compass Rose
description: Compass rose sounds like a flower, emblem of the polymath, that Leonardo da Vinci might have come up with. As it is, and by its other name  compass card  almost as suggestive, this freepivoting circular disc carrying the magnetic needles of a compass and marked with 32 points becomes for Evan S. Connell a combination of mandala and mosaic. Everything belongs and, in theory at least, could be fitted in. But the book that's to accommodate the total mess ends up epitomizing it with so jaundiced an awe that I reckon most readers couldn't stomach, even if they could have it, the complete cosmic catalogue in which man, the brainy fleck, looms narcissistically big.

title: RANGERS LOSE BY 43 TO BELL OF BREWERS
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 28 (UPI)The designated hitter, Ollie Brown, drove in three runs to spark the Milwaukee Brewers to a 43 triumph tonight over the Texas Rangers.

title: The Role of the Corporate Wife
description: Sherry Baltimore, 30 years old, is a busy corporate wife who lives in Phoenix, Ariz. She fills in when her husband's secretary is on vacation, travels with her husband on business, helps him entertain customers and talks with him about his work even when she's bored.

title: FEUERBACH PUTS SHOT 70 FT. 9 IN.
description: WALNUT, Calif., April 28 (AP)Al Feuerbach, inching closer to Randy Matson's world record, unleashed history's third longest shotput  70 feet 9 inchesin the Mount San Antonio Relays today.

title: The American Disease
description: Although few in number, the historians of narcotic control in America have been no less partisan than politicians, reformers, undercover agents, cure  peddlers, prohibitionists and civil libertarians locked in the historical fray. Since Harry Anslinger retired from the old Federal Bureau of Narcotics in 1962, the lawenforcement camp has not had a truly convinced propagandist to argue that ever  vigilant narcs have, throughout this century, prevented us from going off an even deeper drugged end than we already have. The inability to fill the Anslinger gap has left the published argumentation largely to the opposing medicolegal camp. Simply put, this school of thought contends that a halfcentury of conspiracy among bureaucraticminded narcs and reactionary lawmakers has grotesquely distorted a medical problem  drug addiction  into a criminal one, creating problems of deviance where there had been none before. Bad laws, it maintains, have created a bad situation; change the laws and you will remedy it.

title: U.S. Names Indochina Aide
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 28 (AP)Maj. Gen. James D. Hughes of the Air Force has been named chief of staff of the new command for United States Forces in Indochina, it was announced today.

title: Crimes Unreported
description: Criminologists have long known that crime statistics collected by police departments across the country and then published by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, report only a fraction of the crimes that occur on the streets and in the homes of America.

title: Philip Spinella Weds Marie Jo Foscato
description: MANHASSET, L. I., April 28Miss Marie Jo Foscato, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Foscato, was married here this morning to Philip Frank Spinella, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Spinella of Brooklyn. The Rev. Robert L. Brown performed the ceremony and celebrated a nuptial mass in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: CIVILIAN PRISONERS FREED IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28 (UPI)South Vietnam and the Vietcong exchanged 163 civilian prisoners today, the deadline stipulated in the ceasefire agreement for an exchange that is supposed to involve 1,387 prisoners.

title: Cosmos' Mexico Trip a Qualified Success
description: The New York Cosmos' expedition to Mexico unearthed more positive than negative things about the defending North American Soccer League champion. The good news is that the New Yorkers showed depth from goalie to outside left, that they can hold their own against strong competition and that one of their star players had been engaged to a Mexican girl by the name of Marta.

title: One Takes Away, the Other Piles It On
description: EXTREME avant  garde ideas proliferated like flies in the sixties. Two tendencies of thought in the background of many of these ideas were reductivism, which wanted to strip art to its essentials, and what might be called multimedia, which wanted to transcend traditional art categories by hybridizing them. Among the most dedicated proponents of these opposed philosophies were Carl Andre, sternest of the minimalists, and Robert Whitman, most eclectic of multimedia experimenters.

title: New and Recommended
description: A BOOK OF CHANGE, by Frederick Morgan. (Scribner's, $7.95.) Poems written to master the emotions, as is all good poetry, and that are public, transparent and eloquent.

title: Hawks and Canadiens Start Big Series Today
description: A classic hockey battlethe patience of the defenseoriented Chicago Black Hawks against the exuberance of the Montreal Canadiensbegins today in the first game of the Stanley Cup championships.

title: ITALIANS COMPARE THEIR WATERGATE
description: ROME, April 28The headline Long Live the United States has not been seen in the Italian press for a long time, and when it appeared this week it was in the virulently antiAmerican newspaper of the ultraleftists, II Manifesto, and it was on an editorial on the Watergate affair.

title: Linda G. Knox, A. A. Schmon 2d Plan Marriage
description: EAST AURORA, N. Y., April 28Mr. and Mrs. Northrup R. Knox have announced, the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Gilbert Knox, to Arthur A. Schmon 2d, son of Mrs. Hugh Mitchell of Niagara Falls, Ontario, and Robert M. Schmon of NiagaraontheLake, Ontario.

title: THE REVOLUTION THAT FAILED
description: We are in an era of revolution, an era in which longestablished mores have been examined and booted aside. Most of those revolts against the status quo have enjoyed some measure of success, but the men's fashion revolution died with a whimper despite the bang with which it was heralded.

title: Malaysia Seeks Fast Trains
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 28 (UPI)  Malaysia is considering the use of highspeed hovertrains to meet projected traffic needs by the end of the decade, Communications Minister Sardon Jubir has announced. He said French, U.S., Japanese and Malaysian interests would form a consortium to plan the project.

title: David Carradine,King of Kungfu
description: HOLLYWOOD. WHO, me? One has asked, David Carradine if he caw actually split bricks with his bare fists and he's smiled, incredulous. Man; I don't know Kung Fu combat, no, way! When we started the series, we asked some Kung Fu experts to help us, and they wouldn't, they're very serious about the art of Kung Fu, they thought we were just some commercial ripoff bull. All the fights in the show are faked, choreograp'hed. I'm not a fighting man, I'm a dancer!

title: Sutton of Dodgers Downs Pirates, 32
description: PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP) Los Angeles scored single runs in the third, fifth and sixth innings and Don Sutton scattered six hits as the Dodgers handed the Pittsburgh Pirates their third consecutive National League setback, 32 today.

title: U.S. Reports Strike Idleness Is Less So Far in Phase 3
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)Despite fears that a wave of strikes would follow the President's easing of wage controls, the time lost in labor disputes in the first three months of 1973 was the lowest for the quarter in seven years.

title: Miss Elizabeth Devoll Is Married
description: Miss Elizabeth Copeland Devoll and James Booth Fajardo Oliphant were married yesterday afternoon in the Anglican Rectory of Gustavia in St. Barthelemy, F.W.I. by the Rev. Derrick A. Stapleton of Antigua, B.W.I.

title: Steel Straightens Out
description: Steel mills are humming, and they're humming a happy tune.

title: METS TOP BRAVES ON 3RUN 8TH, 42
description: ATLANTA, April 28  Ed Kranepool, filling in at first base despite a pulled groin muscle, got two hits and singled in two runs in a threerun eighth inning to help the New York Mets defeat the Atlanta Braves, 42, before a crowd of 9,752 in Atlanta Stadium tonight.

title: OREGON TO VOTE ON SCHOOL TAXE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 28Watched by educators and politicians around the country Oregon's voters will decide Tuesday whether to take the state further than any othe in moving away from the loca property tax as the source money for running public schools.

title: ICE WHITE
description: As welcome as the sight of summer's first Good Humor man, the white suit returnslooking fresher than it ever did. Below, texturized polyester is selfplaided for a twobuttoned suit by Eagle. $155 at B & B Lorrys. Excello shirt.

title: Howya Gonna Keep 'em on Land After Seeing a Floating, Home?
description: What has a fireplace, sun deck, swimming pool and elevator, requires no real es state taxes and can be moved for $12 an hour?

title: Transportation
description: More than 13 years ago, the Port Authority, hunting for a location for a fourth metropolitan airport to relieve the growing air traffic congestion around New York, proposed that a new facility be laid down on a New Jersey swamp, 25 miles west of Manhattan.

title: Music in Review
description: There are pianists who leap to the stage like lions and attack the instrument as if they were afraid it would eat them unless they got the upper hand at once. Not so Ramn Coll, a young Spaniard who made his New York debut Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. He came on lamblike, diffident to the point of timidity. However, Mr. Coll proved to be a pianist of impressive ability and confidence in a program that required no less: Schubert's rarely heard Variations on a Theme of Anselm Httenbrenner, Ravel's Miroirs and 12 Preludes of Rachmaninoff from Op. 23 and Op. 32.

title: When the Boss Goes on Television
description: Business has long been accustomed to using closedcircuit television for training, sales promotions and management briefings, but now some corporations are extending the process and using it, as a means of corporate communications with employes.

title: Hospital Clinic Specializes in the Problems of Adolescents
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I.Many youths whose problems fall awkwardly between the concerns of the pediatrician and adult's specialists are bringing their most agonizing afflictionsfrom acne to venereal diseaseto the adolescent clinic here.

title: Getting Worse
description: LOS ANGELES  The Pentagon papers case had been characterized as an attempt to put the Vietnam war on trial. It had raised major constitutional issues involving freedom of the press. As a continuing claimant to national attention, it was overshadowed only by the Watergate scandal. But incredibly, on the 80th day of the trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr., the Pentagon Papers case and the Watergate case merged in Federal court here.

title: Miss jean Stoddard Married To Whitney D. Pidot, Lawyer
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., April 28In St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here this morning, Miss Jean Stoddard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond H. Stoddard, was married to Whitney Dean Pidot, son of George B. Pidot of Locust Valley, L. I., and the late Mrs. Pidot. The Rev. John J. Corcoran, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Other Byways on the Tour Circuit
description: Inveterate house  tourers who are unable to attend today's Fort Greene excursion may find some solace in the fact that two more tours are being, offered next Sunday. One, the Park Slope Civic Council House Tour, is a rainorshine expedition into eight Victorian brownstones, which begins at 1:30 P.M at St. Augustine's Church, Sixth Avenue and Park Place.

title: 95 Named to Academy of Sciences in Recognition of Achievements
Probation In Nassau. Peers Aid The Young
description: MINEOLA, L. I.Thirty young people, many of whom are on probation themselves, are working as paraprofessionals in the Nassau County Probation Department.

title: For Poets, Two Rooms of Their Own
description: Two years ago a lavishly produced magazine called Prose made its first appearance, as if to remind us that prose should be at least as well written as versePound's prescription turned back on itself now that Pound's battles for poetic excellence and abundance (the two not necessarily synonymous) have been won on the American paperback shelves of the nineteenfifties and sixties. It clear that poetry has drawn over many of the energies of American prose: those of autobiography or confession, minority selfdefinition and radical dissent. There are not only new readers and new writers of verse, but also new kinds of poets and audiences. Like all fresh appetites, this one is not exercised without confusions, false starts, bad taste and unfulfillable yearnings.

title: CHEATING SCANDAL GROWING AT POINT
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 28 For 10 days now the cheating scandal at the United States Military Academy here has continued to grow. Fifteen cadets have been found in violation of the academy's honor code, and the cadet honor committee gave no sign that its investigation was nearing an end before it recessed its hearings yesterday for the weekend.

title: It's back to the good old summertime
description: Nostalgia is sweeping the backyard this summer. The old porch and patio standbys are staging a comeback. Back again is the folding beach chair with bright striped awning canvas. Back again is the hooded wicker chair. Even the director's chair, that summertime staple, is still with us, although this year's chair has a bright steel frame.

title: AROUND THE
description: Thinking ahead to summer hiking and camping time, the government has put out a handy bulletin Be Safe From Insects in Recreation Areas. It provides help on space sprays, repellents and precautions to use to keep outdoor recreation pleasurable without ticks, gnats, fleas, chiggers and mosquitoes. The bulletin is Home and Garden #200, 10 cents, from Superintendent of Documents, U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C. 20402.

title: Illegal Subleasers Taking Bigger Risk
description: When a tenant subleases an apartment without authorization from the landlord, he does so at his own risk, and managing agents say the risks are growing greater.

title: ASIAN BANK TAKES STEP FOR REGION
description: MANILA, April 28  Governors of the Asian Development Bank agreed today to set up special development fund for the region, but United States reluctance to contribute was holding up some pledges from other countries.

title: Pregnancy Test Is Disputed
description: OAKHURST  A small, neighborhood drugstore in this Monmouth County community is offering its customers a new service: a onehour test to determine whether or not a woman is pregnant.

title: Indochina
description: WASHINGTON  North Vietnam charged the United States with brazenly and systematically rupturing the Vietnam ceasefire agreement. Washington responded by accusing Hanoi of direct and inexcusable breaches in the threemonths old accord. American reconnaissance planes again flew over North Vietnam  a nonetoosubtle warning of a possible renewal of American bombing.

title: Air Force Chief Is Honored For Advances in Programs
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The National Geographic Society today named the Air Force Secretary, Robert C. Seamans Jr., winner of its annual Gen. Thomas D. White space trophy.

title: Jacques Maritain Dies
description: Jacques Maritain, the 90yearold intellectual and teacher whose philosophy of Christian humanism helped pave the way for EcumenicalCouncil Vatican II in 1962, died yesterday in Toulouse, France. Details on Page 60.

title: VILLANOVA TAKES 2 MORE RELAYS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28Villanova shrugged off Dave. Wottle and resumed its romance with the Penn Relays today.

title: Ellsberg Says His Trial Now Seems to Be Political
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28 Daniel Ellsberg says that the newly reported link between Watergate conspirators and his trial has convinced him that the Pentagon papers prosecution was related to efforts to reelect President Nixon.

title: A kind of immunity that leads to jail
description: Salvatore (Sam) Giancana is a Chicago man who, in the opinion of some Federal law enforcement officials, used to be a leading figure in organized crime. He would not appear to have much in common with Sue Sussman, a young Oberlin graduate who volunteered a few years back to work on a committee in support of Father Philip Berrigan and his codefendants in the Harrisburg Seven case.

title: 5 Movies Involving Watersport
description: Five new boating, fishing and outdooraction movies have been added to Johnson Outboards' library of freeloan films available to schools, clubs and other interested groups.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Here's a name to remember: Ian Mowatt. This young Scot has written a first novel, JUST SHEAFFER OR STORMS IN THE TROUBLED HEIR (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $5.95) and it turns out to be witty, literate and wacky. Mowatt has an active imagination. Take his idea of having the hero sell pornographic literature to get up the money to repair a church steeple. There's something awfully nice, somehow, about that.

title: SCHOOL ELECTIONS MORE POLITICIZED
description: The United Federation of Teachers has been running one of the biggest political campaigns in its history to advance its favored candidates in this week's community school board elections.

title: Adelphi Sets Up a School of Psychology
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.Adelphi University recently became the first university in the country to establish a school of psychology with doctoral and postdoctoral degrees.

title: RESIDENTS UPHELD AT LAKE MOHEGAN
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 28A State Supreme Court justice ruled this week that the Town of Yorktown had acted illegally and in violation of its own zoning requirements in granting approval for 168 apartments to be built with septic tanks on the shores of Lake Mohegan.

title: Big Money, Dirty Tricks
description: WASHINGTONSmall wonder that Theodore H. White has postponed his deadline for writing The Making of the President 1972. For as investigators continue to lift that great flat rock called Watergate, they expose not simply the Watergate crime but a swarming campaign netherworld never fully seen before.

title: RCA Streamlines for Future
description: MOORESTOWN  The executive vice president of RCA Government and Commercial Systems, one of the largest employers in Southern New Jersey, says that a decline in business that cut its work force by 5,568 persons in the last three years has bottomed out, and that the end of the Vietnam war is having a bullish effect.

title: To Walk on Fire You Must First Master Yourself
description: SHIMEIIN, the Hermitage of Shining Purpose, is a Shingon Buddhist temple in the hills above Kyoto. It was founded in the year 650. There, where the valley narrows, a 13thcentury gate opens onto a stonepaved terrace; beyond is the Waterfall of the Flying Dragon, to each side steep banks and silent trees. The air is cool and the valley is secluded and peaceful, 75 minutes by bus and on foot from the heart of the city. Every year, about this time, Shimeiin is the scene of a long and colorful ceremony at the end of which large numbers of ordinary people walk barefoot over glowing coals.

title: HAWAII U. TO ADD 2 MAJOR SCHOOLS
description: HONOLULU, April 25  A law school and a fouryear medical school, each the first in the islands, will open at the University of Hawaii this summer with the expectation that they will lead to deep social changes.

title: Brenda H. Fox Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Brenda Humstone Fox, a junior at Wellesley College, plans to be married Aug, 6 in Vienna to Peter Johannes Gall, where the future bridegroom teaches classical guitar.

title: London Transit Authority Asks Ban on 40% of Cars
description: LONDON, April 28 (AP)London bus service is grinding to a halt because there are too many cars on the streets, and 40 per cent of the cars must be banned, the city's Transport Authority warned in its annual report this week.

title: Super Sail Sets Track Mark In $55,900 Arlington Race
description: CHICAGO, April 28 (AP)Super Sail, owned by Allie Reuben of Toledo, Ohio, took the lead near the stretch turn and won the $55,900 Governor's Cup Handicap in record time today at Arlington Park.

title: Spending in Billions
description: Boatmen spent $3.9billion on boating equipment in 1972, according to the Outboard Boating Club of America. This figure includes new and used boats, motors, accessories, safety equipment, fuel, insurance, docking, maintenance, launching, storage, repairs and club memberships.

title: Icing Industry's Drinks
description: PARISIt is just as obvious that the United. States must curb its ridiculously exaggerated reliance on fossilized fuel as that new energy sources other than petroleum and natural gas must speedily be developed.

title: KARL D. HESLEY
description: Karl D. Hesley, New York State director of the National Youth Administration from 1935 to the early nineteenforties, died Friday in Chicago, where he lived. He was 78 years old.

title: The Berlin blockade through the filter of history
description: Lexington and Concord, Sumter, the Maine, the Lusitania, Pearl Harbor. American history is filled with dramatic episodes which define the nature of wars in the popular mind, and afterward become contested issues among historians. The Berlin blockade of 1948 serves this function for the cold war. After 25 years the blockade deserves another look.

title: ARBEES BOY WINS AT GARDEN STATE
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 28 (UPI)  Otly Stable's Arbees Boy, carrying low weight of 108 pounds, rallied from fourth at the top of the stretch to score a halflength victory in today's $25,000 added Delaware Valley Handicap for 3yearolds at Garden State. The time for 1 116 miles was 1:48 on a muddy track.

title: Mets Records
description: BATTING

title: Theater Group Finds Students Are a Large, Eager Audience
description: ORANGEBarry and Fran Weissler founded the National Theater Company in the basement of Mrs. Weissler's West Orange home eight years ago, with the express purpose of performing for elementary, highschool and college students. They lost their entire $1,500 investment, even though their company played before 6,000 students during its first season.

title: Notes: Tailored For Travel
description: JUDGE not according to the appearance, saith the Bible, but some countries continue to do so anyway when deciding whether or not to let trilveiers In. One county. or another is always trying to dictate how a tourist should, or should not look. A while ago it was Greece that made the headlines by refusing bearded youths admission to the homeland of the bearded Achaeans of yore. Hippie types and sloppy dressers also reported difficulties with Spain and a number of other countries. Today it seems to be the turn of Costa Rica, in Central America, and Malawi and Uganda, in Africa, do crack down on attire and hair Styles.

title: CLOSED TV NETWORK LINKS 4 HOSPITALS
description: HANOVER, N. H., April 23 (UPI)An interstate medical communications system was dedicated on Thursday in Hanover and Claremont, N. H., and Burlington and Berlin, Vt.

title: Resort Season in Miami Called Close to Disaster
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 28 (AP)Contaminated water and a fluctuating stock market have been blamed by officials for a 10 to 15 per cent drop in Miami Beach hotel bookings and a winter season described as close to disaster.

title: LYING COLORS
description: Red, White and Blue: still summer's rousing favorites. Center, doubleknit polyester is tripleplaided for a two buttoned, centervented jacket. WorstedTex. $90 at Browning Fifth Avenue.

title: Queens SchoolBoard Candidates Listed
Scientists Explore Whether the Copernican Era of Discovery Is at an End
description: Men whose lifelong concern has been the continuing vigor of science explored last weell the possibility that the era of discovery inaugurated by Copernicus almost five centuries agc is at an end.

title: FERDINAND L. KETTERER
description: Ferdinand L. Ketterer, assistant treasurer and a director of the Manhattan Refrigerating Company and Union Terminal Cold Storage Company, Inc., died Thursday at his home, 164 Wildwood Avenue, Upper Montclair, N. J. His age was 80.

title: FRANCE TO ASSIST SMALLER HOTELS
description: PARIS, April 28 (AP)  The French Government has decided there is longterm virtue in the fleabag hotels of Paris.

title: Soviet Salute to Astronaut
description: MOSCOW, April 28 (AP)As evidence of the growing goodwill of the Soviet Union toward the United States, Russian scientists have named a newly discovered mineral Armstrongite, after the American astronaut Neil A. Armstrong, Tass reported today. The Government press agency said the mineral was found by a joint SovietMongolian expedition in the Gobi Desert, that it belonged to the zirconiumsilicate compounds and that a sample had been sent to the astronaut, the first man on the moon.

title: The Sol Hurok of the Washington press corps
description: Although I knew Drew Pearson moderately well during the last 20 years of his life, it was not until I read this entertaining biography that I understood how he came to be a distinctively American journalistic phenomenon. He was, above all, his father's son, though a wilier and tougher version.

title: PACERS VANQUISH COLONELS, 111107
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 (AP)  Freddie Lewis scored on a driving jump shot with 17 seconds left in overtime today, carrying the Indiana Pacers to a 111107 victory over the Kentucky Colonels. The disputed triumph gave Kentucky a 1.0 lead in their fourofseven series for the American Basketball Association championship.

title: EXPERTS EXPLORE WATER SHORTAGE
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 27 With the energy crisis occupying the center stage of the countrys concern, Government and industry officials, scientists and engineers gathered here for two days this week to look into another crisis they feel is building upshortages in the water supply.

title: E. T. Brondo Weds Pamela R. Stallings
description: RYE, N. Y., April 28The Rye Presbyterian Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pamela Rose Stallings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. Stallings of Rye, to Edwin Theodore Brondo. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Brondo of Bayside, Queens.

title: Trudeau, in Reversal, Favors Rise in Baby Bonus
description: OTTAWA, April 28  The baby bonus, the Government's postwar boon to prosperity and population increase, is enjoying a comeback after having been swept to the brink of extinction a year or two ago.

title: HOUSING PATROLMAN IS HELD FOR MURDER
description: A 32yearold City Housing Authority patrolman was arrested early yesterday by Brooklyn police on a murder charge after, the police say, he shot and killed an 18yearold youth during an argument.

title: Decentralization
description: The election of local school boards has long been a tradition in most areas of the country, but it, is still a new experience for residents of New York City. Thus, for weeks interest has been building for the balloting scheduled for this week.

title: Nancy Lewine Will Be Bride Of Robert Saler Blank in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. David E. Winer have made known the engagement of Mrs. Winer's daughter, Miss Nancy Lewine, to Robert Saler Blank. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Blank of Keystone Point, Fla., and Philadelphia.

title: John G. Dalton Jr. Weds Miss. McGovern.
description: Miss Maureen Anne McGovern of New York was married here last evening to John Gregory Dalton Jr. of Port Washington, L. I., where the bridegroom has his practice as a lawyer and certified public accountant, The Rev. Thomas Bergin performed the ceremony in the Friiars Chapel of St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: HAVING read Patricia Bosworth's article on Seesaw in The Times of April 8, I feel duty bound to make some reply to it.

title: GEARED TO GO
description: Air males; I. Golf jacket t siut of yellow cotton gabardine. Fly front, zip pockets, straightlegged pants. By Rafael. $135. Gimbels East. 2. White stitching outiines the four pockets of a snapfronted, flame red cotton jacket. By Barney Sampson. $60 at The Shirt Tale. 3. Elasticwaisted, ribbonepauletted safari suit of peanutcolored polyestercotton. Chromesnapped coat, $25; pants, $13. Ohrbach's. 4. The leatherbuttoned bush coat is a boneshaded blending of twilled polyestercotton. By Zero King. $55 at Lord & Taylor. 5. A bodyshaped gray wool leisure suit with pleatstriped jacket and wide, flaring pants. Made in Belgium. $185. By and at Jackie Rogers.

title: Dance: Elegant Coppelia
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The American Ballet Theater is coming up to the end of its spring season here at the Kennedy Center. The tour preceding this season has been notable for the number of chances it has offered young dancers. This afternoon, for example, Christine Sarry had her first opportunity to dance Swanilda in Coppelia.

title: Frenn Puts Up $10,000 That Says Nobody Beats Him in Hammer
description: There's a $10,000 reward for the man who proves George Frenn is not the best hammer thrower in the world.

title: SUMMER TATTOO
description: The royal prints of summer: 1. Lushlyshaded flowers blossom on a basketweave background. The polyesterandcotton shirt, left, is by Foxey World. $15 at Mr. Gray Ltd. Oval tintypes on elegant argyle squares. NikNik's splendidly patterned shirt, right, of texturized nylon, is $20 at Bloomingdale's.

title: Son for the Stamlers
description: A son was born April 15 to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Charles Stemler of New York at the New York Hospital, Mrs. Stemler is the former Miss Susan Krall of West Hartford, Conn.

title: MEET MARKS FALL AT DRAKE RELAYS
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 29 (AP)Kansas and Kansas State! relay teams broke meet records, in today's concluding session of the 64th Drake Relays.

title: Radio
description: For two years, middleaged Los Angeles disc jockey Bill Ballance scintillated an estimated 1 million listenersmostly womenwith a radio talk show, Feminine Forum, that urged callers to discuss their sexual problems over the air. About 30 stations carried the show, and Mr. Ballancewho addressed his callers as doll baby, filly and darling kidletbecame an instant celebrity in southern California.

title: Tuition Up in Providence
description: PROVIDENCE, R. L, April 28 (AP)Providence College announced yesterday a tuition increase of $100 a year bringing the total cost to $2,085.

title: Downing St. Reopens; No. 10 Still Barricaded
description: LONDON, April 28 (UPI) No. 10 Downing Street was on public view again yesterday. That is, its front door was.

title: Joanne Breckinridge Is Affianced
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., April 28 Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Breckenridge have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanne Ruth Breckinridge, to Robert Frank Zurhellen, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Owen Zurhellen Jr. of Putnam.Valley and Tel Aviv, where the elder Mr. Zurhellen is deputy ambassador to Israel.

title: SPARE PARTS
description: 1. Plumcolored jacket, polyester and wool, sports blazer buttons, open patch pockets, center vent. By Hart Schaffner & Marx. $105. Wallachs. Kaleidoscopic shirt, Treviraknitted, by Givenchy. $25 at Kolmer Marcus. The slacks: plaided polyesterand linen. Majer. $38.50. Altman's. Buxton's white glove leather belt reverses to a blue side. $8.75.

title: Contenders Heat Up Race to Oust Cahill
description: TRENTON  New Jersey's 1973 gubernatorial races break from the starting gate this week, with Republicans facing a replay of a 1969 grudge match and the Democrats trying to avoid a divisive fourway primary fight.

title: Douglas Henck Fiance Of Susan C. Sanders
description: The engagement of Miss Susan Cornwall Sanders to Douglas Curry Henck, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Seymour Henck of Atlanta, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Durward Eldon Sanders of New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Now that the U.S. combat role in Vietnam is terminated, it is time to consider reviving some of the serious casualties of that adventure. One of these is a serious commitment to the use and development of the U.N. so that it may become a responsible and effective basis for a civilized international system of law and order. American concepts of freedom and justice lose their meaning in a world which bases its international relations on the war system, as is now the regrettable fact.

title: Officer Kills a Suspect, 10; A Murder Charge Is Filed
description: A Queens policeman was charged with murder last night about 12 hours after he shot and fatally wounded a 10yearold boy while investigating the holdup of a taxi driver.

title: SCIENTISTS TO STUDY WATER AND WEATHER
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)New projects to learn more about water and weather, including cloudseeding, and variations in ocean currents, have been announced here.

title: COLOR ON COURT
description: Despite the boos of some traditionalists, color is getting a royal welcome at court. I. Classicallystriped sweater of cablestitched Orlon, $16. Cottonandpolyester shorts, $9. Both by Brentwood at Gimbels East. 2. Ribbed wool cardigan, left, chromebuttoned and ribbonstripetrimmed, $36. Navy mesh shirt. $13; polyestercotton shorts, $18. All by White Stag at Herman's. Braidtrimmed mesh shirt, right, of Dacroncotton, is $7; coordinated shorts, $7. Both by Barclay at Alexander's. 3. Equally adept on court or track, a striking set of contrastpiped knitted nylon. The jacket, $25, and elasticized pants, $17, are both zippocketed. By Head Ski and Sports at Herman's.

title: N.Y.A.C. EIGHT TAKES 5TH RACE IN A ROW
description: The New York Athletic Club won its fifth straight eightoared race of the season today on the Orchard Beach lagoon. The winners, stroked by Joe Caminiti, defeated New York State Maritime College by four and a half lengths in rough conditions to capture the Gen. John Glover Cup.

title: Sharing Of Homes Is Popular In Suburbs
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.For single, widowed or divorced people it can be expensive as well as depressing to live alone in the suburbs.

title: Tennis Club Will Honor Seewagen, LongTime Pro,
description: George L. Seewagen, longtime pro at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens, will be honored by the club next Saturday night.

title: Fosse, From Tony To Oscar to Emmy?.
description: A SPORTS writer ought to be doing this. It's a racing story, with Bob Fosse two thirds of the way to the theater's triple crown. He took Broadway's Tony (well, two Tonys) for directing and choreographing Pippin (the musical fable about a nice dopey young Prince's search for answers); he took Hollywood's Oscar for directing Cabaret (the most recent of several works based on Christopher Isherwood's Berlin Diary), and he's up for television's Emmy May 20 for directing Liza with a Z (a special which featured Liza Minnelli singing to a live audience). If he sweeps em all, he'll be the first person who ever did it in a single year.

title: When It Goes 7 Games, The Celtics Don't Lose
description: One of the most remarkable clutch records in sports is the Boston Celtics' record in seventh games of National Basketball Association playoffs. They have never lost in 10 series that went to the seventh game.

title: Elizabeth Jane Cohn Sets Nuptials
description: DEAL, N. J., April 28Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lewis Cohn 3d of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jane Cohn, to Mayo Sturdevant Stuntz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuntz of Vienna, Va.

title: the traveler's world
description: DETROITThe high point of a week in the research and technical centers and proving grounds of Chrysler, Ford and General Motors in pursuit of what's new in pollution controls, safety and engine development was the opportunity to drive two of the gasturbine automobiles Chrysler is building for the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Last autumn, the E.P.A. contracted with Chrysler for a $6.4million threeyear development program for a turbine engine that will comfortably, efficiently and economically meet E.P.A.'s air pollution standards.

title: DOUBLECHECK
description: Two to draw interest: Corded yellow outlines the three shades of tan which ginghamcheck a jacket, top, of lightweight Indian cotton madras. Flapped pockets, deep center vent. By I. Aaronson, Ltd. $75 at Altman's. Geno shirt. Black and white check out a waffleweave leisure suit, left, of doubleknit Trevira. The chestpocketed jacket tops flared slacks. By Oleg Cassini. $130 at George Leonard, Georgetown Shopping Center, Brooklyn.

title: Cheryl McGuirk Fiancee
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 28Mr. and Mrs. George J. McGuirk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cheryl Ann McGuirk, to William Allen Haverinen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haverinen of South Paris, Me.

title: Wounded Knee
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D.  The uneasy calm was suddenly shattered by rifle fire. The gunfight between Indian insurgents at Wounded Knee and Government forces began late Thursday night and lasted until the following afternoon, when the Indians asked for a ceasefire. One of their number had been killed and another wounded in the action, in which United States marshals used gas for the first time. No casualties among the Government forces were reported.

title: CHIP SHOTS
description: Dressed to a tee:

title: SKYLAB TO STUDY SUN'S MYSTERIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Mysteries of the sun and of the human body will share major scientific attention next month during the first sojourn of astronauts in an American orbiting space laboratory.

title: Brooklyn Museum Patrons Stage Ball
description: Twentyfive years of devotion to the cultural develop. ment of Brooklyn were noted last night when a formal Silver Jubilee Ball took place in the Brooklyn Museum's Auditorium Court, to mark the founding of the museum's Community Committee. The ball is held annually and is regarded as the Brooklyn sodal event of the year.

title: Statistics
description: WASHINGTONStand up and be counted, the voice on soul radio stations across the country urged ghetto residents during the 1970 census. But there were many who never heard the or failed to heed it.

title: Prison Gamblers Organize
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., April 28 (UPI)Gamblers are becoming organized within the walls of the state prison. The current issue of The San Quentin News reports the formation of a chapter of Gamblers Anonymous, an international organization whose aim is to rehabilitate gamblers.

title: Yeats writing about himself to himself
description: The book commonly known as the Autobiography of William Butler Yeats is divided into several segments written at intervals over period of 25 years. The first, Reveries Over Childhood and Youth, covers the period from 1865 to 1886 and was written in 1914. When it first appeared in 1916, Yeats's friend George Russell (AE) remarked that there was no reason for believing that the boy described in it would became a poet. After its publication, Yeats wrote a continuation of the narrative covering the years from 1887 to 1897. He put it aside in 1917, and that manuscript, written ... for my own eye alone, forms the most important part of the current Memoirs, under the title AutobiographyFirst Draft. In 1918, Yeats returned to the task of describing his life between the ages of 22 and 32; it was published in 1922 as The Trembling of the Veil, and it is a very different piece of writing from the draft published in Memoirs.

title: Fordham Will Honor Bach and the 7 Blocks
description: John Bach, Arthur O'Connor, and the Seven Blocks of Granite will be inducted into the Fordham Athletic Hall of Fame at the 39th annual Block F Dinner sponsored by the Fordham University Ram Club at the Statler Hilton Hotel May 12.

title: Bridge
description: If one of your opponents plays slowly, the laws permit you to draw inferences at your own risk from his hesitancy. A new dimension was added to this concept in a recent New York tournament, when Ron Rubin of Maplewood, N. J., one of the most talented young experts in the metropolitan area, was able to draw an inference from the slow play of an opponent at a different table.

title: Schooner Awaits Destiny
description: During a colorful career that spanned more than a century, the coastal schooner Alice S. Wentworth, like hundreds of her type, carried coal up the Hudson River, oysters from Long Island, Sound to New York's South Street docks, farm machinery from Boston to Maine and deck loads of Maine lumber on her return voyages.

title: Letters
description: I can accept the assertions that Hitler and Stalin were probably insane, but I am drawn up short by the statement in Dr. Willard Gaylin's article (In matters mental or emotional, What's normal? April 1), that it is conceivable that Abraham Lincoln was a manicdepressive psychotic, as has been suggested by some historians.

title: DEFENSE DEBATE GROWS IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, April 28  The students have gone back to school surprisingly quietly, after nearly a month of preEaster strikes and agitation focusing on the draft law.

title: U.S. & Soviet Union
description: MOSCOWThe Senators came away talking about a consummate political pro. They were impressed by the evident candor and sincerity of the man. He told a few jokes. He knew his business well. He got down to brass tacks. And he gave them plenty of his time, which was flattering.

title: Monmouth: A Battlefield Park Is Delayed
