description: FREEHOLD  Passing motorists see only a stretch of Central Jersey farmland, but state history buffs recognize the cornfields and orchards off Routes 33 and 9 in Monmouth County as the site of not only one of the longest oneday battles in the Revolutionary War but also where the last major engagement in the North was fought.

title: THE WATER COMPANY
description: A colordrenched splash of shore winners for fashionminded amphibians.

title: American Paintings in The Picnic Spirit
description: GUY PENE du BOIS spoke of the picnic spirit, Van Wyck Brooks of the confident years. We still speak of the Gilded Age, though no longer perhaps with quite the same meaning which that term had for Mark Twain. However we may characterize the period that embraces the last decades of the 19th century and the first decade or so of the 20th, it seems to embodyso far as American painting is concernedan era of leisured optimism and esthetic comfort that now looks almost paleolithic in its distance from the ambitions and anxieties and desperations of the age that followed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I cannot share the views expressed in the article entitled Model Apartments Achieve a New Elegance [April 15].

title: Why Is the Little Guy Out of Market?
description: Inflationary concerns, stiffening commission fees and international financial uncertainties are among the widely cited factors presently keeping the small investors neutral if not adverse toward investing in the stock market.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: AS the script of Save the Tiger went from studio to studio looking for a home, it was called, at various times, antiAmerican, anarchistic and communistic. Now Stephen Farber in his article on March 25th, calls Tiger a NixonEra Movie. I'm sure Mr. Farber doesn't know that Save the Tiger has been denied advertising in the paper and TV station in Oklahoma City because the family that controls both media found Tiger objectionable when they screened the picture before it opened. So it seeens Tiger is a victim of the Nixon Era rather than a subject.

title: Elections Expected Tuesday as Planned
description: The elections for New York City's 32 decentralized school boards are expected to be held Tuesday, despite a State Court or Appeals ruling that has threatened to postpone them.

title: Barbara Livingston to Be Bride May 26
description: HAWORTH, N.J., April 28  Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Farrell Livingston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ellen Livingston, to Stanley Macfarlane Brock, He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Blackwell Brock Jr. of Birmingham, Ala.

title: 12 New Michigan Eruptions Force 67th Family to Flee
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mich., April 28Two fresh gas eruptions late yesterday have forced the evacuation of another family and the sealing off of another half square mile of this area, which has been beleaguered by the mysterious development of 150 potholes and gasbearing geysers since April 18.

title: Letters: How Much Room in Vermont?
description: To the Editor: In regard to the story, Skiers and Cows: Is There Room for Both in Vermont? by Dinah B, Witchel (Travel Section, Feb. 25), I should like to note that the town of Stratton Mountain had to spend $250,000not $500,000 in upgrading its sewagedisposal system. It should also be pointed out that Stratton did not suddenly find itself embroiled in months of hearings, as the article implied; the situation had been brewing for years.

title: Blind L.I. Artist Prepares Spring Show
description: AMAGANSETT, L.I.Last June, three months after her 70th birthday, Lucia Wilcox, one of the bestknown painters of the region and one of its most admired cooks, went blind as a result of an epithelial carcinoma in her nasal cavity. She spent 13 weeks in the Neurological Institute at ColumbiaPresbyterian Hospital in New York undergoing intensive radiation therapy for her inoperable tumor.

title: InterParliamentary Union Votes to Admit North Korea
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, April 28 (UPI)North Korea was approved for admission to the InterParliamentary Union today.

title: Margin Is 5 Lengths La Troienne Goes to La Prevoyante
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28The spring meeting at Churchill Downs started today with an attractive racing program witnessed by a crowd of 22,428, record for opening day.

title: Agaunar Captures $17,500 Trot to Raise Her Career Earnings to $508,269
description: WESTBURY, L. I,, April 28Agaunar raised her career earn ings over the halfmillion dol lar mark with an upset victor; in the $17,500 Laurelton Tro tonight at Roosevelt Raceway

title: Spending to Rise
description: Americans are expected to increase their spending on pleasure boats from less than $500 million in factory values in 1971 to over $900 million in 1976.

title: The thalidomide babies are growing up
description: LONDON. In 1960, two years after their marriage, Barbara and Michael Spanswick found themselves depressed over their problems in starting a family. A baby boy born to Barbara died three days after birth that year. Subsequently, Barbara had a miscarriage. Nervous and upset, she obtained a prescription from her doctor for a tranquilizer, which was dispensed free of charge under Britain's National Health Service.

title: Third Ave. El Reaches the End of Its Long, Noisy, Blighted, Nostalgic Line
description: The last remnant of the Third Avenue El, which in its prime blighted neighborhoods and sped passengers from South Ferry to the Westchester County line, joined the past yesterday.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, April 28Investigators here are considering the possibility that an Arab, who yesterday shot to death an Italian employe of El Al Israel airlines, killed the wrong man.

title: Graham Marsh Leading By Shot in Japan Golf
description: NAGOYA, Japan, April 28 (AP)  Graham Marsh of Australia shot a threeunderpar 67 today and took a onestroke lead with a threeround total of 200 in the $113,000 Chunichi Crowns International golf tournament. Masashi (Jumbo) Ozaki of Japan, who had led after rounds of 64 and 68 on the 6,530yard, ptr 70 Wagon Country Club course, slumped to a 71 and dropped to a fourthplace tie with Ireneo Legaspi of the Philippines at 203. Legaspi shot a 67.

title: Miss Jan Ellen Cornell Engaged to Mark Gold
description: Dr. and Mrs. Albert Cornell of New York and Centerport, L. I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Jan Ellen Cornell, to Mark Richard Gold. He is the son of Mrs. Abraham J. Gold of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Gold. A wedding in June is planned.

title: No. Bugs at Water Gate Inn
description: RICHWOOD, W. Va., April, 28 (AP)The Water Gate Inn here, mindful of recent news from Washington, advertises itself as containing no bugging, not even a bedbug.

title: TAX RECORD SUIT CONTINUES HERE
description: State Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine has reserved decision in a case involving public disclosure of realestate taxassessment records here.

title: HighSchool Merger in Doubt
description: MIDLAND PARK  A scheduled fall merger of high school students from two northwest Bergen County towns remains uncertain, despite approval by the State Board of Education.

title: And Now ... The Year of Europe.
description: Henry Kissinger charts a new course for United StatesEuropean diplomacyor is it just grandiose rhetoric? Leonid Brezhnev assures visiting American Senators he's letting Soviet Jews, emigrate (picture below)or is it just the charm treatment? Opinions differ, but the Year of Europe heralded by the Nixon Administration, has obviously begun.

title: HARVARD VICTOR IN COMPTON CUP
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 28 The unbeaten Harvard and Northeastern crews, which have a date in two weeks at the Eastern Sprint Championships, were winners this morning on the placid Charles River. The Harvard eight, with a sophomore, Alan Shealy, at stroke, trounced the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Princeton to win the Compton Cup for the 11th year in a row.

title: Sparta's Objective Is to Remain Rural
description: SPARTAThe roads that lead into Sparta are filled with the sounds and smells of nature. In this part of New Jersey  in Sussex County, at the northwestern corner of the statehouses are far apart and huge trees sit high on rolling hills, for much of the land remains undeveloped. For The Talk the 11,500 resiof dents of this town Sparta of 38.9 square miles, the primary goal is to remain rural, to prevent the largescale development of homes, industry and commerce.

title: PENTECOSTAL UNIT REPORTS GROWTH
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28The International Church of the Foursquare Gospel, marking its, golden anniversary this year, reports that it is growing more rapidly than in the days of its flamboyant and energetic woman founder, the evangelist Aimee Semple McPherson.

title: NEW WRINKLES
description: Fresh faces for an old favorite: 1. Puckerstriped, straightlegged slacks by Corbin ale $27.50 at Bloomingdale's.

title: Miss Jordan Becomes Bride
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 28 Miss Pamela Smith Jordan, daughter of Mrs. William E. Jordan of Garden City, L. and the late Mr. Jordan, and Lieut. William Christian Conkle, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan J. Conkle of Toledo, Ohio, were married here today. The ceremony was performed in St. Andrew's Chapel at the United States Naval Academy by Comdr. Robert Ecker, Chaplain Corps, U.S.N., assisted by the Rev. Charles E. Erb of the Garden City (L. I.) Community Church.

title: Bicentennial: A New Impetus?
description: TRENTONGovernor Cahill is expected to appoint 10 New Jersey residents to the State Bicentennial Commission within the next few weeks.

title: Change at the F.B.I.
description: All the dismal circumstances surrounding the resignation of L. Patrick Gray 3d as acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation point up the needdeplorably neglected by this Administration  of keeping the bureau totally divorced from politics. Even without the gross departures from standard F.B.I. practice fostered by Watergate, the political miasma that has enveloped this essential law enforcement agency since the death J. Edgar Hoover undermined the professionalism and morale he had spent a lifetime instilling.

title: NIXON LOSES GROUND IN POLL ON HONESTY
description: Louis Harris, the pollster, said yesterday that 63 per cent of Americans feel the White House has not been frank and honest on the Watergate affair, and has withheld important information about it. Nine per cent disagreed with that assessment, and the rest had opinion, he said.

title: Governorship
description: TRENTONAccording to the famous bugged conversations of the Mafia in the late 1960's, Brendan T. Byrne was a prosecutor in New Jersey who couldn't be bought at a time when the mob boasted it had scores of public officials in the bag.

title: U.S. Driver Tries Grand Prix
description: BARCELONA, Spain, April 2ROnce more an American team has dared to drive into the world of European racing. Understandably it is here with humility and patience, expecting no quick victories.

title: RecordingsCall Me SchwannAs in Catalogue
description: YES, Vivaldi, there is a Schwann. William Schwann, to be exact: originator and guiding force behind the indispensable record and tape guide. How did a young piano and organ virtuoso born 60 years ago in Illinois become the publisher of the worldfamous recordlover's bible?

title: Pop
description: FRED ASTAIRE 19351940: Songs from Top Hat, Follow the Fleet, Swing Time, Shall We Dance, Carefree, Second Chorus. Box Office Records.

title: Chess: When All Is Hopeless, Resign (But When Is It Hopeless?)
description: Though it's painfully true that you can't win by resigning, the problem of when to resign doesn't always have a simple solution.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The complex of chemicals called hormones regulate all manner of body functionsthey can thwart or induce the creation of life, separate the men from the boys and even beef up the front four of a football team by stimulating the players' growth. In the same manner hormones have been used for the last 20 years to put more weight on animals.

title: Pan Am Takes a Tentative First Step to End Overbooking
description: PAN AMERICAN WORLD AIRWAYS has proposed a plan to the Civil Aeronautics Board that the airline says is a first step toward overcoming the problem of overbookinga practice that results in passengers being bumped from flights on which they have reservationsduring peak holiday periods. The plan, which would require purchasers to pay in full for tickets when they are ordered and includes a 25 per cent penalty for purchasers who fail to take their flights, will probably be acted upon by the C.A.B. in about three weeks.

title: Lilienthal Is Doubtful About Energy Crisis
description: CHATTANOOGA, April 28 (AP)The nation faces an energy problem, but not an energy crisis, David E. Lilienthal, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, says.

title: Future Social Events
description: Pegasus Is Scratched

title: Lutherans to Meet On a New Charter
description: JERSEY CITYRepresentatives of 300 Lutheran congregations will take part in the annual meeting of the Lutheran Welfare Association of New Jersey next Saturday. It will be held at the Lutheran Home, 93 Nelson Avenue, starting at 10 A.M., and will he continued later at St. John's Lutheran Church on North Street.

title: Job Freeze Ordered For Police In Suffolk
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.  To make up an estimated deficit of $580,000 in the current county police budget caused by rising retirement costs, Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein has ordered a freeze in the hiring of all clerical and maintenance workers and a delay in the start of future cadet classes.

title: Camera World
description: THE Cosmopolitan Chapter of the Photographic Society of Amerida will hold their Annual Festival next Sunday (May 6) at the Hotel Commodore with a program that will start at 10 A.M. The morning will be devoted to a program entitled A Studio in A Suitcase, by Richard Stolarz; he will demonstrate how to photograph models. There will be a break for lunch from noon to 1:30, after which there will be the annual business meeting followed by two slide presentations: A Visit to Southern India, by John de Visser, and the Westchester International. Nature Exhibition. Admission will be free to members of the P.S.A. and $2 fornonmembers.

title: DRAIN IS RATIONED IN INDIAN REGION
description: NAGPUR, India, April 23Jamna Godesa, a 35yearold mother of five, stood in the long, slowmoving line at the ration shop hoolding her 9monthold daughter.

title: Manhattan's Tennis Team Set Back by Hunter, 5 to 4
description: Hunter College defeated Manhattan College, 54, yesterday in a Metropolitan College Tennis Conference match on the Manhattan court. John Wang and Steve Rosenfeld defeated Manhattan's Art Witt and John Kelly, 26 62 62, in the final doubles match.

title: Bridal in Capital For Ann Dwyer, Tufts Graduate
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Miss Ann Geraldine Dwyer and August Maffry Jr. were married here this afternoon in the St. Thomas Apostle Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Ralph J. Gallagher, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Marc Gervis, a Roman Catholic priest and the Rev. Roderick Welles, an Episcopal priest.

title: Tall Ships to Race Around the World
description: LONDON  Big ships under sail will try to beat the times set by the legendary clippers of the last century in an aroundtheworld race to take place in 1975.

title: Music
description: WITH the support of President Nixon, Senators Claiborne Pell and Jacob Javits recently introduced a bill, S. 795, that would authorize certain sums for the National Endowment for the Arts: $80million in 1974, $140million in 1975 and $200million in 1976. A similar disbursement would go to the Nations: Endowment for the Humanities.

title: CHILE COURT SHUTS A PARTY'S OFFICES
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 28 (UPI)The headquarters of the opposition Christian Democrat party was closed by court order today as part of an investigation into the slaying of a Communist construction worker during a politically motivated riot.

title: We Love You Renata But. . .
description: BOSTON

title: Sunfish Sailors In Martinique
description: The colorful bay of FortdeFrance in the lush French West Indies island of Martique is the slite of the fourth world Sunfish championships, whch began last Wednesday. The winner will not be known until after the sixth and final race this afternoon.

title: No. 1 Builder of Shopping Mall: A Shy Dynamo
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio Workmen perspiring during construction of a shopping center, racetrack or motel in Florida, Louisiana or Ohio these days occasionally look up at the sky with a frown or a hopeful glance. It is not unknown for a Learjet or Helio STOL Courier to swoop out of the clouds and deposit a thin, serious, darkhaired man in his midfifties just at the moment that a crucial building problem has cropped up.

title: City to Begin Celebrating Its 75th Jubilee Tomorrow
description: New York City begins celebrating its 75th anniversary as Greater New York tomorrow.

title: Los Angeles and Miami Beach hardly compare
description: Las Vegas is where you end up when you hit Los Angeles and bounce back. Since Tom Wolfe discovered the electrographic architecture of Las Vegas signs in 1966, journalists, architects and culture theorists, who already considered the sprawling vitality of Los Angeles attractive, have been dazzled by the much crasser and more spectacular Las Vegas. While generally overlooking North Las Vegas with its sad desertcity life and the streets of tired houses where the people who work in the big hotels and casinos live, they concentrate on the significant action along Fremont Street and Las Vegas Boulevardthe Strip. Since you can sleep, buy gas, get married, shoot craps, swim, eat, watch Jack Benny, and, most of all, spend a great deal of money on or just off these streets, Los Angeles and even Miami Beach hardly compare.

title: Canoe Sledding
description: The world's downhill canoe racing championships will be held at Squaw Mountain ski area on the shores of Moosehead Lake, Maine, next Saturday.

title: Courts
description: Courts in urban areas sag under heavy backlogs, in dirty crumbling buildings. Court administration, in the favorite phrase of the judiciary, remains largely in the horse and buggy era. Unqualified men can and do find their way to the bench. Judges who do an inadequate job run little risk of either censure or removal.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Too little of the true nature or cause of the food price rise has risen to the surface or been properly explained. Take, for instance, the socalled meat boycott.

title: Payoff or Ripoff?
description: Now do I love thee? Let me count the ways: salary, annual bonus, perquisites ... and performance shares.

title: Flatbush Shaped by History's Hand
description: Only the dead know Brooklyn, wrote Thomas Wolfe. And there's hardly a living soul that could find its geographic reaches on a map where it stops being Flatbush and begins to be Midwood or Flatlands or Rugby or Kensington or even Gravesend. It's clearly a state of mind, evoking cozy domesticity and the sanctity of the singlefamily dwelling. During World War I the whole country was singing a popular song called Nesting Time in Flatbush.

title: Boy, 10, Dies in a Fall
description: A 10yearold boy died yesterday afternoon when he fell from the roof of a fourstory building in Astoria, Queens, while trying to retrieve a ball from a fireescape landing. The police ideitified the boy as Richard Gericke, of 31.05 Crescent Street. He had been playing ball, with friends behind the building at 3145 Crescent.

title: Marvin McDonald, 78, Dies; Headed Atlanta Music Club
description: ATLANTA, April 28 (AP) Marvin McDonald, impresario and former manager of the Atlanta Music Club, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 78 years old.As manager of the Atlanta Music Club from 1930 to 1961, Mr. McDonald was instrumental in founding the AllState Concert Series for the city and in bringing the Metropolitan Opera to Atlanta for the first time since the depression. He also arranged Maria Callas's only appearance in Atlanta, in 1958.

title: Soviet Is Set Back as Salyut Flight Ends
description: MOSCOW, April 28The Soviet Union announced today the end of the flight of its orbital workshop Salyut 2, in effect conceding a serious setback to its manned space program.

title: 92 Shot Shatters Record for StakesSummer Guest 2d
description: For stouthearted patrons who had the nerve to back Hobeau Farm's Poker Night against Summer Guest and Numbered Account yesterday at Aqueduct, it didn't take mirror on the wall to see which filly was the fairest in the land.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city and the state both announced the appointment of lobbyists in Washington yesterday. Mayor Lindsay said that Jerome Sohns would be the new director of the city's Washington office. Mr. Sohn, a 36yearold native of Kansas City, Mo., has been acting director of the city's office in the capitol since the resignation of Noel H. Klores last November. Governor Rockefeller announced the appointment of Roger W. Hooker Jr., 31, to succeed Stephen A. Hopkins, who recently resigned, as the state's chief lobbyist with the Federal Government. Mr. Hooker has been a deputy secretary to the Governor.

title: DogShow Calendar
description: TODAY

title: Stifling Pasadena's Integration
description: A new school board with an antibusing majority is about to take office in Pasadena, Calif., where integration of the schools was achieved in 1970 through heavily increased busing. The new board is committed to abolishing forced busing, primarily because of its belief that busing has been the main reason for a decrease in white enrollment from 49 to 43.6 per cent in the lower grades and from 58.2 to 50.1 per cent in high and junior high schools.

title: The Package Tour: Together But Alone
description: THE package tour is the travel bargain of our timesthe IRT of tourism. Paid for at the outset in dollars, it is a simple and economical way for women (alone), women (older), women (in pairs), women (with children) and the occasional aging male (husband or widower) to see the world and feel secure. The packagd tour promises English spoken here and a minimum of fuss with hotel clerks, guides and the funny money that passes for currency out there.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive apnearance.,

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Sigmund Sommer, the builder, has entered negotiations with Bing & Bing, Inc., to acquire more than 20 of its residential properties in the city.

title: My son is hypnotized ... I have received the Knowledge
description: The spiritual delight members of the Divine Light Mission find in experiencing knowledge through the Guru Maharaj ji is not always shared by their families, who may know other truths and be pained by the separations these differences bring. The deeply emotional response of both groups to Khushwant Singh's article, The guru business, Do you know the aim of life? which appeared in this magazine on April 8, is reflected in the following letters to the editor.

title: Can't hate anybody and see God's face
description: My father's greatgreat grandmother lived to be a 125 years old, and walked in a slave coffle from Virginia to Eatonton, Ga. (which passes for the Walker ancestral home) with two babies on her hips. In the long autumn of her life she was called that old strong, sweet lookin' woman, or Strong Sweetie, by the dozens of black and nonblack children who grew up under her care. It is a relatively new idea to me that black women can be defeated, and when I think of Strong Sweetie and consider the life of Fannie Lou Hamer I understand why.

title: Dickson Tied for 54Hole Lead
description: DALLAS, April 28Dan Sikes, the pro golf tour's only lawyer, overtook Bob Dickson today to share the 54hole lead at 206, four under par, in the $150,000 Byron Nelson Classic.

title: Welfare Modest Concessions
description: Congress had long demanded stronger control over the use of Federal socialcare funds by state and local governments, and last February the Nixon administration responded by proposing a set of stiff restrictions for Federal support of day care, aid to the aged and other social service programs.

title: Police Post A Challenge To Woman
description: WEST ORANGE  Her friends and relatives call her Sissy. But, after all, what's in a name?

title: Calendar of Horse Show Events
description: TodaySweetbriar Farm, Sport Hill Road, Easton, Conn. Regular, green and junior working hunters; open jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Rep. Widnall: A Quiet Optimist
description: PARAMUSI'm an eternal optimist, though I've got to admit I get some depressing thoughts when I see all the troubles around the world, Representative William B. Widnall said one morning last week. I mean, who would want to be President, or mayor of a major city, or head of a college?

title: Stage: Yale Repertory Theater Presents Lear by Edward Bond
description: NEW HAVEN, April 28I write about violence as naturally as Jane Austen wrote about manners, says Edward Bond in the preface to his play Lear. It would be immoral not to write about violence. Bond's Lear, which received its American premiere last night at the Yale Repertory Theater, is an attempt to restore not only violence but also cruelty to King Lear, to show man as a harmful and hurt animal. Everyone is traitorous, even Cordelia.

title: Bruce L. Nourie And Mrs. Ronan Plan Marriage
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and Mrs. Ronan of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Monica Vinade Ronan, to Bruce Leo Nourie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Nourie of Little Compton, R.I., and Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: Doing His Own Bach Thing at Midnight
description: LIKE advertising copywriters who want to go off and create novels, musicians who are cogs in the concertworld machinery feel the desire to do their own thing. A current standardbearer in this attitude is Henry Schuman, an oboist who is one of the many expert Instrumentalists around town who play regularly in socalled pickup orchestras. As he unsentimentally puts it, Most of us make a living renting ourselves out. Often enough we sit in groups we're not too proud of.

title: Sirens Unheard in Closed Cars Are Growing Problem in Cities
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., April 28Fire Engine 53, its red lights flashing, siren screaming and horn blasting, was racing to a blaze recently when a latemodel car crashed into it at a busy intersection. The driver of the car told the police that his windows had been rolled up and his radio turned on and that he had not heard the siren or horn.

title: Europa Issues Are Changing
description: IRONICALLY, the Europa issues, a small semblance of the European unity that Harry Truman strove to foster, may also be passing into history.

title: WALL STREET
description: The gold bugs have been around forever. The market still has gas. Who understands gold anyway? And how can you worry about something you can't understand? The Money Game by Adam Smith, 1968.

title: Mrs. Pinto Has Child
description: A daughter was born April 16 to Mr. and Mrs. Anthony M. Pinto of New York at the Bay Ridge Hospital in Brooklyn. Mrs. Pinto is Loretta Di Franco, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera. The child has been named Lavinia.

title: U.S. Said to Bar Bugging On TeamstersMafia Link
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28 Two ranking officials of the Department of Justice eight weeks ago turned down a request by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to continue electronic surveilance that had begun to penetrate teamsters' union connections with the Mafia, according to Government sources.

title: Wreckage of Doctor's Plane Found Near Groton, Conn.
description: LEDYARD, Conn., April 28 (AP)The wreckage of a doctor's singleengine plane was found this afternoon in woods eight miles from the Trumbull Airport in Groton, the state police reported.

title: Art: A Melange of Modern
description: PARAMUSAn exhibit by members of the Modern Artists Guild is currently on view at the Bergen Community Museum. It will continue until May 13.

title: 30,000 Harp Seals Killed In Season by Canadians
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 28 (Reuters)The sealing season off Newfoundland's northeast coast has ended with Canadian ships reporting that they took little more than half this country's quota of 60,000 harp seals.

title: 11 SCHOOLS ADDED TO LIST OF CENSURED
description: ST. LOUIS, April 28 (UPI)Delegates to the 59th annual meeting of the American Association of University Professors voted today to add 11 institutions to the organization's censured list.

title: SHELL GAME
description: A young and breezy and casually inclined kind of a jacket and the rumpled look is as essential as its lower price tag. In the large photo: far left, a puckerstriped cotton madras coat with open patch pockets, center vent. By McGregor. $45. McGregor slacks. NikNik shirt. The awningstriped blazer, center, sports wide curving lapels, angled open patch pockets. Paul Ressler's twilled cotton coat is ventless. $25 at Franklin Simon. Floral print shirt by Career Club. Corduroy slacks: Cheap Jeans. Paris belt. Accentstitched cotton canvas suit, near left, is lined but otherwise unconstructed. The centervented coat fronts two snaps; pants are flared. By Peters. $55 at Lord & Taylor. Shirt by Geno. Girls' JerSea of Sweden.

title: Squadrons Help Chart Pollution in the Sound
description: MONTAUK, IA  Power squadron skippers are helping the New York Ocean Science Laboratory here chart the movements of eastern Long Island tidal waters. The longterm target of the research is to determine what happens to sewage and other materials dumped into Long Island Sound.

title: A New Path For Pickett?
description: WILSON PICKETT has been one of the great names in soul music for more than 10 years, and what that means, among other things, is that he has been a master of a particular formula.

title: Barbra Nightingale
description: IS THERE a doctor in the house? No, but there is a nurse, and she's none other than Barbra Streisand. Oh, then she's a singing nurse! No, she hasn't got time for such frivolity; she's far too busy tending her patients and fighting the hospital higherups. At least, that's what nurse Streisand will be doing in With or Without Roller Skates, a comedydrama which she will star in for Paramount next fall.

title: Donald C. Riley Is Dead; ExStatistical Official, 68
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Donald C. Riley, retired Government statistical official and a former executive of the American Statistical Association, died today at Fairfax (Va.) County Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Soviet Aide Leaves Norway
description: OSLO, Norway, April 28 (AP) Valery N. Erofeyev, an attach with the Soviet Embassy here, has left Norway, the Foreign Ministry announced today. Newspapers here reported yesterday that the police had said that Mr. Erofeyev had tried to recruit Norwegian spies.

title: 3 MILS' PITCIERS SUBDUE REDS, 10
description: CINCINNATI, April 28 (UPI) Willie Montanez's single with the bases loaded in the eighth inning gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 10 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight behind the twohit pitching of Dick Ruthven, Billy Wilson and Max Scarce.

title: Library Books Jazz Band for Concert
description: SHREWSBURY  The traditionally hushed atmosphere of a library reading room will be shattered next Sunday afternoon. That is when the Asbury Park High School Jazz Band will give a concert at the Eastern Branch of the Monmouth County Library on Route 35.

title: Pulse of Life
description: Spring peepers trill, willows come to leaf, red maples make the lowlands flush with their opening buds. Brooks are in spate and rivers are in flood. Migrant birds return, mate and begin nesting, and the mornings echo with their song.

title: Seaborg Hired by French
description: PARIS, April 28 (AP)  A French company of nuclear consultants has announced the appointment of Glenn T. Seaborg, former chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission and winner of the Nobel prize for chemistry in 1951, as director of its international scientific relations.

title: Admirers In Brooklyn To Honor Rabbi, 85
description: Old age challenged Rabbi Israel H. Levinthal and lost. It hurled heart attacks, cataracts and other infirmities at the gentle, fragile man and then backed off, leaving his keen mind and forceful vision to move unimpeded.

title: Public TV
description: WASHINGTONIs the Nixon Administration trying to destroy the statutory barriers against political control of the nation's taxsupported television stations and their network?

title: BOLDFACED
description: Paidabouts: 1. Rainbow shades satinplaid a whitegrounded jacket of polyester and cotton. Two buttons, open patch pockets, deep side vents. The colors: blue, red, green, orange, wine, yellow. $100. the applegreen satinplaided Swiss voile shirt, $30. White viscoseandlinen jeanstyle slacks, $30. All by Jaeger, at B. Altman & CO.

title: Rhodesia
description: SALISBURYThe recent conduct of the Rhodesian Government recalls the odd fate of that 19thcentury British politiciannotorious all his life for clumsinesswhose career was ended when he permitted himself to be run over by a railroad train that was going 12 miles an hour.

title: Anaya Outpoints Lara To Retain W.B.A. Title
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 28 (AP)Romeo Anaya of Mexico retained his World Boxing Association bantamweight title in his first defense tonight when he won a split decision from a countryman, Rogelio Lara, in a 15round bout at the Forum.

title: Home for Boys Is Rejected
description: PATERSON  A statefinanced pilot project, under which juvenile first offenders would have been accommodated in a halfway house situated in one of this city's few remaining middleclass residential sections, has been defeated by neighborhood opposition.

title: Economic Boom Is It Building for a Fall?
description: WASHINGTONThe boom in the national economy, while full of imbalances and defects and possibly even the seeds of its own destruction, has become sufficiently strong so that some serious talk has started of the need to rein it in.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: It has been pointed out to me that (whether true or not) my remarks about Senator Eugene McCarthyin the text of my review of the Wilfrid Sheed novel People Will Always Be Kindwere snotty and gratuitous. They were the remarks of a smartaleck, and I should like to apologize for them, without qualification.

title: Politburo
description: MOSCOWFriday was a bad day for those hapless souls who have to hang the massive, stylized portraits of the Soviet leadership on big buildings in Moscow for the annual May Day parade. Work crews struggled in the rain and got them part, way upthen pausedthen took them down again.

title: Western Officers Deplore Killings at German Borders
description: BERLIN, April 28 (AP)The three Western Allied commanders in Berlin protested today against the renewed reckless and inhumane use of firearms by East German border guards that apparently killed a wouldbe refugee yesterday.

title: Collectors Tell About Seashells
description: PARAMUS  The New York Shell Club held its first show here last week, and the thousands of seashells on display at the Bergen Community Museum ranged from 30inch giant clam to a surrealist oil painting of a spring oyster.

title: U.S. Wrestlers to Meet Soviet Team at Forum
description: The United States will get another crack at the Soviet Olympic championship wrestling team. The two rivals of the 1972 Olympic, as well as in the world championships of 1969 and 1970, will meet in the Felt Forum, June 1 at 8 p.m.

title: News Summary and Index
THE WEEK'S OPENINGS
description: THE WEEK'S OPENINGS

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: There is, to paraphrase Emily Dickinson, no frigate like a brook one has known since childhood.

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker
description: The number of people who love nature is astonishing. You see them in overalls sitting on the ground playing banjos and combing each other's hair. Their songs tell of glorious sunsets and of finding love on a glacier while the moon whispered of a full harvest.

title: Architecture
description: THE latest planning controversy of major magnitude in London is focused on Piccadilly Circus. It is of interest, not just for the future of Piccadilly, which occupies a curious place in the affection or disaffection of natives and visitors, but as confirmation of a significant change in British attitudes toward planning.

title: FEDERAL ART BILL FACES FUND FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Once the target of Congressional snickers over fancy toe dancers and longhaired fiddlers, the National Endowment for the Arts has discovered that there are perils, too, in being taken seriously.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Mrs. Laura. Alice Lane Is a Bride
description: Mrs. Laura Alice Lane and Edgar Morsman Masters were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

title: New York State's Barge Canal Becoming a 524 Mile Recreational Facility
description: The New York Barge Canal, which has flowed through the history of the state fora century and a half, is taking on a wider recreational role for boatmen. With its heyday over as a freight carriermore than 5 million tons at its peak in 1951 but half that 20 years laterthe canal is becoming a park system with facilities not only for boatmen, but also for fishermen, hikers and bicyclists.

title: Addicts Uncounted
description: The soldier going to South Vietnam today runs a far greater risk of becoming a heroin addict than a combat casualty, declared Representative Robert H. Steele in the spring of 1971. Shocking estimates of the number of GI junkiesas high as 78,000 menabounded.

title: Old Oyster Boat a Live Pearl
description: Anyone familiar with the lower reaches of the Connecticut River can answer this question: What runs on three cylinders, has a fire pump, a piano and a picnic table, is centrally heated and flies the Essex Yacht Club burgee?

title: Yanks Best Twins, 113 on 4 Homers
description: The New York Yankees finally roused themselves and shook a few memories out of that cold overcast yesterday when they hit four home runs and buried the Minnesota Twins, 113.

title: Watch on Drinkers Cuts Traffic Deaths
description: TRENTON  An experimental State Police program has produced solid evidence that strict control of drinking drivers will reduce traffic fatalities sharply.

title: Three Penthouses Merged Into KingSized Coop
description: FORT LEE, N. J.A developer of shopping centers on Long Island has created a kingsize apartment out of three adjacent penthouses here.

title: DeathPenalty Bills Languish
description: TRENTONWith an eye toward this year's legislative and governorship elections, and on the advice of Governor Cahill's Study Commission on Capital Punishment, a move to restore the death penalty in New Jersey has apparently been laid aside in the Assembly.

title: Mayoralty
description: The stage was set, There had been newspaper stories that Representative Mario Biaggi, a leading lawandorder Democratic candidate for Mayor, had invoked the Fifth Amendment to avoid answering questions before a grand jury. Mr. Biaggi had assured political supporters he had answered everything he was asked.

title: Correction
description: In Guy Davenport's review of For Whom the Cloche Tolls, by Angus Wilson and Philippe Jullian (April 15), the phrase ...a son so much of the times that he modeled his life on that of the arch Edwardian sybarite, Ronald Firbank.... mistakenly read, he modeled his wife....

title: Chamber Elects Illinoisan
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The United States Chamber of Commerce announced today the election of Edward B. Rust of Bloomington, Ill., as its 46th president. Mr. Rust is president of State Farm Insurance Companies.

title: Gerrit Vreeland Weds Miss Antoinette E. Carter
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., April 28 The marriage of Miss Antoinette Esterbrook Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Stuart Carter, to Gerrit Vreeland took place in the Presbyterian Church of Bridgehampton this afternoon. The Rev. Robert Battles performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Kenneth W. Vreeland of Far Hills, N. J., and the late Mr. Vreeland.

title: HARRY H. ENGEL
description: Harry H. Engel, retired vice president of the Bienenfeld Glass Works in Brooklyn, died yesterday in Miami, where he lived. His age was 75.

title: Coalition Seeking State Aid for Arts
description: TRENTON A recently formed coalition of nine regional arts councils is pressing the state for an annual funding of county and regional culturalart programs.

title: NIXON IS SECLUDED AS HE CONSIDERS WATERGATE MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 President Nixon was reported to be in virtual seclusion today at his mountaintop retreat at Camp David, Md., pondering his course of action amid the mounting Watergate bugging controversy.

title: Bike Patrol Lends Cyclists a Hand
description: On a sunny, spring day in Central Park recently, Pierre A. Dillard was trying with little success to adjust the seat of his 5yearold son's tiny bike when three teenagers suddenly approached.

title: Modern dance is getting hot
description: AILEY IS COMINGPoster in the window of Jackson, Mich., barbershop.

title: Mailbox: Tennis at 3 in the Morning
description: To the Editor: The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association must take steps to prevent the Easter Bowl from exploiting junior tennis players by starting their matches after midnight. Over the Easter weekend, many of these 12to18yearolds were playing up to 2 and 3 A.M.

title: Sports Week
description: BASEBALL

title: Farrell, Snyder Score In Finalsat Penn Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28Msgr. Farrell High, like Paramus Catholic on Friday, entered the schoolboy winners' circle at the Penn Relays for the first time today.

title: Japanese Ban Saccharin
description: TOKYO, April 28 (Reuters)The Japanese Welfare Ministry has announced a ban on the use of saccharin, except for certain special purposes, effective Nov. 1. The step is in line with policy of barring artificial food additives as much as possible, a spokesman said. Saccharin will henceforth be allowed only in medicine and food for diabetics and others who cannot take sugar.

title: $30 SPORTSUIT
description: High price tags needn't always go with high fashion, especially in summerweight fabrics. Naturalshaded twilled cotton and polyester is stitchtrimmed for a suit with patchpocketed, centervented jacket, pleatedfront trousers. By Europe Craft. $30 at Ohrbach's. Paul Harvey shirt.

title: Maine Ocean Races, Set
description: Two races have been added to this summer's Gulf of Maine ocean racing circuit, the group announced recently.

title: LEGISLATIVE NOTES
description: TRENTONIt may cause the horses to shiver, but New Jersey is moving toward yearround racing.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Knicks Get One Last Chance
description: BOSTON, April 28All the cherished conceptions about themselves, built up over a twoyear period by the New York Knicks, will he on, the line tomorrow at 2 P.M. when the Knicks and Boston Celtics play the seventh and deciding game of their National Basketball Association playoff series. It will he televised nationally (in New York on Channel 7).

title: Irene A. Stolfi Has Nuptials
description: Miss Irene Antoinette Stolfi, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Julius Stolfi of Brooklyn, was married in St. Anselm's Roman Catholic Church there yesterday afternoon to George Francis Burns 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burns Jr. of Manhasset, L. I. Msgr. Charles E. Diviney, Vicar General of the Diocese of Brooklyn, performed the ceremony. The Rev. John Weiss assisted.

title: LEGAL UNIT KILLED IN JACKSON, MISS.
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Community Service Association of Jackson, Miss., lost its fight for survival yesterday as Howard Phillips, acting director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, upheld a veto of the legal services project.

title: Jackson's Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  Between Leonid Brezhnev's promises to visiting American Senators last week and President Nixon's assurance that the Soviet head tax on wouldbe Jewish emigrants has been lifted, the supporters of the Jackson amendment in the Senate find themselves abruptly on the defensive.

title: The Time for Truth
description: From disclosures in recent days, the public is finally getting a picture of what was going on at the highest levels of, the American Government in 1972. To wit:

title: Open House Slated At Ancora Hospital
description: HAMMONTONThe Ancora Psychiatric Hospital will hold its 18th annual open house on Thursday.

title: An Attitude Comes to Full Flower
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. It takes only two hours to drive from Washington to this small city at the foot of the Shenandoah Mountains, but the change is enormous. This is Thomas Jefferson's home town, illuminated now by the blooms of dogwood and azalea. The 18th cenJury comes crowding in.

title: HOFFA PLANS BID FOR TEAMSTER JOB
description: WASHINGTON, April 28James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhod of Teamsters, disclosed today that he planned to run for president of his home local in Detroit next year.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: S.C.C.A. Group Here Opens Competition to Antique Cars
description: The New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America made some concessions to old age at its monthly meeting last Thursday night. It decided to include a class for antique cars in its Solo II competition.

title: THE NATURAILS
description: Always a standby favorite, tan turns up in new and livelier warm weather guises. I. Sporting stripes pipe the pockets of both coat and pants of a doubleknit Dacron unmatched suit. The cloverleaflapelled jacket is centervented. By Royce Casuals. $115 at Field Brothers. The shirt is by Byron Britton.

title: Willy Brandt
description: BONN  Everyday life in Western Europe is determined to an everincreasing extent by the European Economic Community. In this process each step toward closer integration of the economic, social and political destinies of our nations and states is at the same time an undertaking of challenging soberness. I do not have the impression that this is sufficiently appreciated on the other side of the Atlantic.

title: Charles H. Jewett 2d Dies; Partner in Brokerage Firm
description: Charles H. Jewett 2d, a partner in Jewett, Newman & Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, and a veteran floor broker, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

title: Hospitals
description: Nowhere does the clich about the urban crisis assume greater reality than in the pressures that focus relentlessly on the nation's hospital care for the poor and the medically indigent. Those pressures were everywhere in evidence last week as Dr. Joseph T. English, head of New York Cityls Health and Hospitals Corporationthe largest integrated civilian health care organization in the countryannounced that he was leaving the post.

title: 2 New Jersey Shows Return to the Calendar
description: Two major New Jersey horse shows that were canceled in 1972 will return to the schedule this year.

title: MAN SEIZED IN THEFT OF 8 CANDLESTICKS
description: A former, employe of the Brooklyn Museum was arrested yesterday in the theft of eight Georgian 17th and 18thcentury candlesticks on loan to the museum that were valued at $50,000.

title: JAPANESE GYMNASTS SHARE A.A.U. TITLE
description: BUFFALO, April 28 (AP)Yoshi Hayasaki, Yashiaki Takei and Jean Moore Rice were awarded gold medals tonight as the allround champions at the national Amateur Athletic Union senior gymnastics meet at Canisius College.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The price of cotton has reached its highest level on record and it appears likely that the large volume of cotton exports will push it even higher.

title: Trouble Lurks at the G.N.P. Gap
description: WASHINGTONOn page 95 of the Commerce Department's monthly publication, Business Conditions Digest, is a set of figures of major importance to Government policyvery much so in this Administration. Yet the figures are under considerable challenge by some economists as to their accuracy.

title: Mary O'Connor Bride
description: Miss Mary Eileen O'Connor and John Kevin Gallagher were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. James J. Haggerty, a cousin of the bride, in St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights, Queens. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. William J. O'Connor and the late Mr. O'Connor, a founder of the North Queens Home Owners Association. Mr. Gallagher is a son. of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Gallagher of Bayside, Queens. Mr. Gallagher is a retired lieutenant of the Police Department. The bridegroom is an assistant tax manager of Walston & Co.

title: UNMATCHED SUIT
description: A sport coat and slacks? An ensemble? Suit yourself.

title: Seton Hall Names Field To Honor Owen Carroll
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., April 28  The name of Seton Hall University's athletic field was changed to Owen T. Carroll Field at ceremonies today. The facility had been known as Setonia Field.

title: Legislature
description: We've got to take a stand on the drug issue. It's time to bite the bullet. I know this is a very tough bill. State Senator H. Douglas Barclay, Republican of Pulaski, was urging support for Governor Rockefeller's legislation dealing with traffickers in dangerous drugs as the Senate got ready to vote on the issue last week.

title: Maine Ocean Races, Set
description: Two races have been added to this summer's Gulf of Maine ocean racing circuit, the group announced recently.

title: Carl Kreitler, 59, Stockbroker, An ExColgate U. Trustee, Dies
description: Carl J. Kreitler, a senior vice president of Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith, Inc., and a leader in Colgate University alumni activities, died Friday in New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 59 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Back with memories and maturity
description: When, on Oct. 22, 1849, Flaubert and his friend Maxime Du Camp, a wealthy young literary dilettante and avid voyager, set out for their Journey to the Orient, they were following in the wake of wellknown predecessors  Chateaubriand, for instanceand indeed, of those many scholars and soldiers who had participated in Napoleon's memorable expedition. Their minds and imaginations were wellfilled with glamorous images of a world rich in legend which negated in every respect the dull, bourgeois world Flaubert most particularly hated.

title: Jersey Plans to Eliminate Perilous Parkway Stretch
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April, 28 (UPI)Extensive construction to eliminate the most hazardous stretch of the Garden State Parkway is scheduled to begin late this year, it was announced today.

title: Mackell
description: When Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell was indicted on charges of covering up a criminal investigation, he refused to resign, saying, I was elected by the people and I'm going to stay on the job. But last Monday, 12 days after his indictment, Mr. Mackell conceded that it had destroyed my ability to function as a District Attorney. Bowing to increasing pressure, he told Governor Rockefeller that he would step down. The Governor did not objecthe had said five days earlier that he was ready to begin proceedings to remove Mr. Mackell from office.

title: Written On Water
description: The only use of a river, said Thoreau, is not to float on it. It is the statement of a pure contemplative, and there have been so few contemplatives in literature, despite our troubled sense that contemplation is the essence of art, that when one comes along we are likely to feel caught in a crosscurrent of surprises shame at our own habitual inattention (for, as Thoreau says, how much virtue there is in simply seeing), and unease that seeing is so mute, that it floats one to the brimming edge of a pool that is powerless ever to spill over, to fall to further consequence.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: New Prison Chief Champions Reforms
description: TRENTON The announcement last Wednesday that William Fauver will be the new chief of New Jersey's prisons did not surprise those insiders who had watched him ease the tensions that had made Trenton State Prison a cauldron of frustration and violence.

title: Americans Get Advice On Conserving Energy
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)A Government consultant on energy problems has suggested that all Americans work in their shirtsleeves in summertime to reduce or eliminate airconditioning demands.

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TodayMinnesota, 2, at Yankee Stadium, 1:05 P.M.

title: Bruce Wins in Conflict Over Peking Staff
description: WASHINGTON, April 28David K. E. Bruce, who will lead the United States' liaison office in Peking, has won Dureaucratic battle in Washington to keep his mission's top jobs limited to State Department officers.

title: U.S, & Europe
description: PARISFor several years now the relationship between the United States and Western Europe has been one of periodic crisis. The coldwar preoccupation of earlier decades have been giving way to new problems of money, trade, agriculture. To the Europeans it seemed that while America was making gestures of reconciliation with the Communist powers she was allowing relations with her allies to deteriorate into bickering and recrimination. To Americans it seemed that Europe was seeking both the favored status of dependency and the privileges of selfsupporting adulthood.

title: U.S. Is Said to Contribute To Violence in Rhodesia
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 28 (UPI)Judith Todd, who with her father, the former Prime Minister of Rhodesia, was jailed in that country for five weeks, said this week that the United States has come down on the side of violence in her homeland.

title: Three novels: nightmares, conspirators and maniacs
description: Muriel Spark's new novel is, in effect, a witty, mysterious, illuminating dream; Muriel Spark's dream, but more or less ours too. It makes reality barely more fantastic than reality is.

title: Suffolk Shoots Aerial Tax Map
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.Suffolk County will no longer have to rely on a historically quaint but often entangled system of land description inherited from its villages' forefathers when its new tax map is completed.

title: The New Plays
description: THE ORPHAN, the New York Shakespeare Festival production of a play by David Rabe, got four mixed reviews (Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Gayer, UPI; Harris, CBSTV) and six negative reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Watts, Post; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wallach, Newsday; Klein, WNEWTV).

title: Rowing Results
description: Goes Trophy at Annapolis, Md. (Races at 1 miles  Varsity: 1, Navy, 8:57.0; 2, Syracuse, 9:00.5; 3, Cornell, 9:03.2. Junior Varsity:. 1, Cornell, 9:10.8; 2, Navy, A, 9:15.2; 3, Navy B, 9:25.0; 4, Syracuse, 9:25.7; 5, Navy C, 9:44.9. Freshmen: 1, Cornell, 8:39.6; 2, Navy, 8:40.0; 3, Syracuse, 8:59.8.

title: BLACK/WHITE
description: The colorsplashed shirts of past summers make way for a new elegance.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CHAVEZ AND UNION FIGHT FOR LIVES
description: COACHELLA, Calif., April 28 The red and black flags of the United Farm Workers Union are again flying along the hot, dusty roads, and the cry of huelga (strike) is again echoing across the lush California grape fields.

title: Which Flick Rates No. 14,684?
description: A FRIEND of mine, a theoretical mathematician with a taste for the absurd, has long felt that The New York Times film critics, in addition to criticizing films, sheuld rate them with some sort of quickreference numerical index. Nothing quite as simple as the stars, VV's and reels that are bestowed on films by various members of the competition, most of whom count only up to four before they run smack into sheer bliss. Rather my friend had in mind a system that could in some way reflect thehow did he put it?nuances of our reviews. To this end he has been working for years and he has now, with the help of a computer, devised a system that is, frankly, beyond my ken. Because a masterpiece under this system rates 14,684 (14,684 what he doesn't say, but it sounds like lira), and because (according to him) there is no such thing as a movie so unspeakable it could approach the infinity of zero (2 is as low as the ratings go), it is a system for, moviegoers who want a consumer's guide that is both dignified and demanding but not stuffy, the sort that might bring soulmates together, the way the shared appreciation of Vivaldi McG??vern, Antonioni, sex, a sense of humor, and stopping by a woods on snowy evenings brings together the more sensitive readers of the personals columns of The New York Review of Books.

title: REV. WILLIAM SPILMAN
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., April 28The Rev. William S. Spilman, curate of St. John's Episcopal Church here since 1960, died yesterday of a stroke in Huntington Hospital. his age was 45.

title: PAULA RAPP
description: Paula Rapp, an artist known for her collages in metal and paper, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived at 21618 40th Avenue in Bayside, Queens.

title: Stuck Does 113.7 m.p.h.
description: ADENAU, West Germany, April 28, (UPI)  West Germany's HansJoachim Stuck set an unofficial lap record today in final training runs for tomorrow's Formula Two auto race counting toward the European championship. He went 14.2 miles in 7 minutes 30.5 seconds for a speed of 113.7 miles an hour.

title: Free Breast Exams In Bergen May 712
description: WESTWOODFree breast and thermographic examinations will be given at six hospitals in Bergen County from May 7 through May 12..

title: CanadaPoland Grain Talks
description: WARSAW, April 28 (UPI) Canada and Poland have begun talks on a new longterm gram sales contract, Canada's Justices Minister, Otto Lang, said here today.

title: Canada Heralds Leader
description: THE 100th anniversary of the death of Joseph Howe, a gifted leader of Nova Scotia and a vigorous protagonist in the struggle over the establishment of the Canadian Confederation, is the occasion of a new commemorative from Canada.

title: Fight Continues Against GasTank Plan
description: TRENTON  The Hackensack Meadowlands Devel, opment Commission, having lost a threeyear court battle to prevent a Houston concern from constructing a second storage tank for liquefied natural gas, has organized a growing statewide coalition of civil and environmental groups to continue the fight.

title: Investing in the Averages
description: Even by the standards of the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton, the 700 pensionfund administrators who paid $375 each to gather there last January at a conference organized by Pensions magazine were an impressive group.

title: When it's the heat and the humidity
description: The dresses of summer. They are as cool as modern sculpture. They either swing free or just skim the body. And some can be belted if that's your mood. Here's a clutch of dresses that will get you through a city or suburban summer.

title: Olivares, a Featherweight, Stops Seeley in 2d Round
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Apri 28 (UPI)Ruben Olivares, the former world bantamweight champion from Mexico City, stopped Walter Seeley of Hempstefid, L. I., at 1 minute 24 seconds of the second round of a scheduled 10round featherweight bout tonight.

title: Party Pays Off Debts
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 28 (UPI)  Pennsylvania Democrats have learned that their party is operating in the black at the state level for the first time in at least a decade. The party treasurer said it had paid off more than $400,000 in political debts over the past 10 months.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: N.Y.U. NAMES SITE FOR A BENEFACTOR
description: New York University Medical Center yesterday honored the memory of one of its benefactors by naming its new center mall and entrance at 550 First Avenue at 31st Street, the Samuel D. Leidesdorf Plaza.

title: ANCIENT TITLE WINS $55,050 COAST RACE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 28 (UPI)  Favored Ancient Title held off Groshawk for a head victory today in the 33rd running of the $55,050 Inglewood Stakes for 3yearolds at Hollywood Park.

title: Dim Light on Books
description: Librarians are not usually known for their political activism, but on May 8 libraries across the country will dim their lights in protest against the Administration's meat.ax threat to books. Under the present budget proposal, the $140 millionayear Federal appropriation for library subsidies would be wiped out after July, 1973. Neither public libraries nor those in schools and colleges would henceforth get direct grants. Any subsequent aid would have to come out of general revenue sharing, but the vociferous claims on such funds by forces with much more political clout would leave slender hope for libraries.

title: Consumers Mailing Supermarket Bills To Nixon in Protest
description: NEWARK, April 29  More than one million supermarket register tapes will be mailed to the White House starting today to protest soaring food prices.

title: DANCER SYNDICATE TO BUY J. R. SKIPPER
description: Stanley Dancer announced yesterday his option to purchase with a syndicate the 3yearold pacer J. R. Skipper from Russ Miller of Dutton, Ontario, for $1million.

title: Nixon Aides' Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, April 29By his own careful accounting, there are but three loves in John Johnston Wilson's wellordered life: a woman named Alice, a dog named Vicki and the passionate practice of law. But not necessarily in that order, the chunky, pinkfaced, 71yearold attorney harumphed in his office here last week. Yet, whatever may be his more constant priorities within that rather narrow triangle, it seems reasonable to expect that in the next few weeks Mr. Wilson's newest clientsJohn D. Ehrliclunan and H. R. Haldeman, top aides to President Nixonmay reduce the woman, his wife for nearly half a century, and the dog, a precocious but nervous Boston Terrier, to clearly subordinate roles.

title: Cameron Beard, Banker, Served Annin Flag Corp.
description: NASHVILLE, April 29 (AP)Cameron R. Beard, a retired executive of the American Banker newspaper, died Friday in a hospital here following a stroke. He was 67 years old.

title: D.A. Moves on Behalf of Accused Policeman
description: The Queens prosecutor's office announced yesterday it would seek to reduce the charge against a policeman who shot to death a 10yearold boy from murder to criminally negligent homicide.

title: Israelis Hold Services For Jews Nazis Killed
description: JERUSALEM, April 29 (AP)  Israelis conducted memorial services throughout the country today for the six million Jews killed by the Nazis, and in speeches said that they would rely on themselves alone to safeguard the Jewish people.

title: Austria Booters Still Kicking
description: BUDAPEST, April 29 (AP)Austria kept alive its chance of qualifying for the World Cup soccer tournament by playing a 22 tie today with Hungary before 80,000 fans at Nep Stadium.

title: Bridge:
description: A statistical researcher with time to spare could draw some conclusions about rubberbridge play compared with duplicate by surveying a large number of deals in each category. Two quite unconnected results of such a survey could safely be predicted: the rubber  bridge player is less likely than the duplicate player to play doubled partscore contracts, and more likely to play five clubs or five diamonds.

title: P.O. W.'s Felt Their Mission Was to Resist
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29Everybody says we had nothing to do, but we did have something to do, we had an obligation to fulfill, Lieut. Col. Alan Lurie said recently. That was to follow the Code of Conduct, to resist the North Vietnamese attempts to exploit us. And that was fulltime job in that situation.

title: Dispute Over Indian Burial Worsens at Wounded Knee
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., April 29Government negotiators met with Indian factions tonight to try to relieve a crisis created by attempts of the American Indian Movement to bury a slain Apache on sacred Sioux ground.

title: Guerrillas Say They Foiled An Israeli Raid in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 29 (Reuters)Guerrillas said today that they had foiled an Israeli landing attempt at Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon.

title: Libyan Minister Resigns
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon April 29 (Reuters)Libya's Foreign Minister, Mansur Rashid Kikhia, has resigned, according to the Libyan radio, and there was speculation here that he might have fallen out with the head of state, Col Muammar elQaddafi, over political matters. Mr. Kikhia joined the Cabinet last July.

title: Gallup Poll Reports Kennedy Leading Agnew in Popularity
description: The results of a Gallup Poll released today show that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts leads Vice President Agnew by a wide margin in voter popularity. The survey gave the Massachusetts Democrat 51 per cent against 38 per cent for the Vice President.

title: Excerpts From Lindsay's Plan
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Lindsay's transportation message:

title: Hirohito Is 72
description: TOKYO, April 29 (AP)Emperor Hirohito celebrated his 72d birthday today, and thousands of Japanese visited the palace to cheer him. The, Emperor, wearing a cutaway suit, waved to the crowd from behind a bulletproof glass panel. Officials said that 24,000 people visited the palace. Many held small Japanese flags and shouted Banzai!  Long Life!

title: P.O.W.'s Felt Their Mission Was to Resist
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29Everybody says we had nothing to do, but we did have something to do, we had an obligation to fulfill, Lieut. Col. Alan Lurie said recently. That was to follow the Code of Conduct, to resist the North Vietnamese attempts to exploit us. And that was a fulltime job in that situation.

title: CANADAU.S. STEP VEXES TRAVELERS
description: Flying from Canada to the United States became a bit more difficult yesterday, and passengers faced with the new system did not seem to like It a bit.

title: Jews Here Honor Those Slain In Warsaw Ghetto Revolt in '43
description: The El Mole Rachamim, the Hebrew prayer for the dead (God, Full of Mercy)echoed in Times Square and in Temple EmanuEl yesterday as New York Jews honored those who died in the Warsaw ghetto uprising 30 years ago.

title: Japan's External Reserves Dropped Sharply in March
description: TOKYO, April 29 (Reuters)Japan's end of April external reserves dropped to $16.83billion from $18.1billion at the end of March, the Finance Ministry announced.

title: River Overflows in Maine
description: FORT KENT, Me., April 29 (AP)  Maine National Guardsmen were called out to aid floodcontrol efforts in this Canadian border town this evening as the Saint John River overflowed its bank, forcing the evacuation of at least 50 families.

title: White Plains: Downtown for All Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 29  Decades of planning and a generous dose of luck are transforming this old Westchester County seat of 50,000 residents into a glittering new city that serves as a downtown hub for a population of 400,000 and, as its numerous boosters contend, a model for suburban development in the future.

title: Gallagher Wins Twice at Net
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 29  Billy Gallagher of Larchmont, N.Y., the topseeded player, won the Concord Junior invitation tennis tournament today defeating Gary Adelman of Roslyn, L.I., 60, 76. Gallagher teamed with Steve Valelly of New York to beat Robert Glickman of Brooklyn and Larry Lefcort of Lawrence, L.I., 61, 63, for the doubles title.

title: SMITH CAPTURES, 6TH TENNIS FINAL
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, April 29 (AP)  Topseeded Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., overcame a tough challenge from John Alexander in the first set and came back strongly to defeat the sixthseeded Australian 57, 64, 62, in the final of the $50,000 Swedish pro tennis championships today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: American League
description: Monday, April 30, 1973

title: VOTING STILL SET ON SCHOOL UNITS
description: Community school boar candidates and their campaign workers went forward with lastminute campaign effort yesterday, distributing leaflet and telephoning voters all over the city, confident that the elections for the boards woud proceed as scheduled tomorrow.

title: 45Hour Rutgers Dance Earns $30,000
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 29They danced and they danced, and when they had finished at 5:30 tonight after 451/2 hours, 26 Rutgers couples had trotted out more than $30,000 for cancer research.

title: E. COE KERR JR., 58, ART DEALER, DIES
description: E. Coe Kerr Jr., a leading art dealer here, died Wednesday in Lisbon, where he was on a business trip. He was 58 years old and lived at 1120 Fifth Avenue and in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Mei Juao, 69, Is Dead; InternationalLaw Expert
description: TOKYO, April 29 (AP) China reported today the death of Mei Juao, who studied at Stanford University and the University of Chicago, and was regarded by the Communists as an authority on international law. He was 69 years old.

title: Mills of England Triumphs In A.A.U. OneHour Walk
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 29 (AP)Roger Mills of England won the national Amateur Athletic Union's senior onehour walking race today by covering eight miles 252 yards at the Lawrenceville school track.

title: Wadkins Takes Nelson Golf in Playoff
description: DALLAS, April 29  Lanny Wadkins came back in 31 for a spectacular 67 and a 72hole tie with Dan Sikes at 277, then beat the Florida lawyer on the first hole of a sudden death playoff today in the $150,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: Law Schools Now Attract More Women as Students
description: TRENTON, April 29 (AP)Marilyn Loftus Schauer, the state's topranking lawenforcement official, says she will never forget the sea of men on her first day of law, school 15 gears ago.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1973
description: SCHERNSDORF, East Germany, April 23The threemile shoreline of Scherwenz Lake just south of here is dotted with more than a hundred vacation cottagesall of them illegal, according to East German property regulations.

title: TRUCE VIOLATIONS DOWN IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 (AP)The Saigon command today reported 74 ceasefire violations across South Vietnam during the 24hour period ended at 6 A.M., the second lowest number since the truce went into effect three months ago.

title: U.S. Song Wins Tokyo Prize
description: TOKYO, April 29 (AP)An American song writer, Mickey Newbury, won the 3million yen ($11,320) grand prize of the Tokyo Music Festival international contest today for his Heaven Help the Child. In the field of 31 entries, Americans took three of the top seven prizes and Japan took two, the others going to Britain and Bulgaria.

title: Bronx Getting Coop Meat Market
description: A new $40million cooperative wholesale meat market, designed to take processors and distributors off the teeming streets of the West Village and South Bronx, is nearing completion in Hunts Point.

title: Bookstalls at Central Park Open Again
description: Two bookstalls at the southeast corner of Central Park opened yesterday for a second season and quickly drew the compulsive readers from among the pedestrians at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street.

title: GOING OUT
description: HOPPING GALLERY The second floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue at 75th Street (2494100), will be atremor with new music as the first of a series of four Composers Showcase concerts opens at 8:30 tonight. The Showcase, designed to encourage and advance contemporary music, is 16 years old and these concerts are part of the museum's sixth year of April and May evening events.

title: Drug Hoax
description: By a distressingly large margin, the State Senate has succumbed to political hysteria over drug abuse and voted to approve Governor Rockefeller's totally wrong headed response to this nagging problem. Ostensibly tough, the Governor's crackdown program for drug pushers with its mandatory minimum prison sentences actually threatens to hamstring effective law enforcement. The State Assembly, which will now take up the proposal, would be welladvised to reject it along with similar plans offered by others that contain the same basic flaws.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A vast new cooperative meat market, designed to take wholesalers off the crowded streets of the West Village and Brook Avenue in the Bronx, is nearing completion in Hunts Point. The project, in which 45 big dealers have already enlisted, is mostly financed by city on leaseback arrangement. The sixbuilding complex, on 38 acres, of freezers and cutting shops got under way last year after years of political stalling. It should be ready for occupancy in the fall.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Ends Visit
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka April 29The Indian Prime Minister, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, left Sri Lanka, formerly Ceylon, today after a threeday visit. At a news conference before her departure, she characterized India's relations with the United States as just fair, blaming misunderstandings during the Bangladesh crisis.

title: Michael Burke Quits
description: Michael Burke stepped down yesterday as chief executive in charge of the daytoday operation of the New York Yankees. He retains part ownership and will be a consultant. Details, Page 39.

title: A British Rock Invasion Is Led by King Crimson,
description: The Union Jack was fluttering over the Academy of Music on 14th Street on Friday and Saturday, underlining the continued affluence of the British rock'n'roll scene. On the two evenings four British rock groups appeared.

title: Piastre Value Lowered
description: SAIGON, April 29 (Reuters) South Vietnam has lowered the value of its currency to 485 piastres to the United States dollar from 475 piastres, effective Immediately.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dance: Ballet Theater Stages Swan Lake in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 29The American Ballet Theater ended its spring tour at the Kennedy Center's Opera House today with two performances of Swan Lake, both with Prince Siegfrieds new for this tour.

title: National League
description: Monday, April 30, 1973

title: WHALERS CRUSH JETS IN OPENER
description: BOSTON, April 29 (UPI)Tom Webster scored two goals and assisted on a third tonight as the New England Whalers trounced the Winnipeg Jets, 72, in the opening game of their World Hockey Association championship series. The Whalers broke open the game with four goals on only seven shots in the first period after spotting Winnipeg a 10 lead.

title: Man and Wife Die Upstate In Apparent MurderSuicide
description: LOCKPORT, N. Y., April 29 (AP)A Lockport man was found dead in a wrecked automobile early today and a short time later his wife was discovered at home dead apparently of strangulation. The police said they belived the man had killed his wife and committed suicide.

title: Arborists Plant Oak At Kilmer Birthplace
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 29 (UPI)A fivefoot red oak was planted this weekend in the front yard of the boardedup birthplace of Joyce Kilmer, the poet who wrote Trees.

title: GOVERNOR URGES VOTE ON DRUG BILL
description: Governor Rockefeller yesterday issued an unusual call for the Assembly to pass his drug penalty bill tomorrow, after Mayor Lindsay authorized several top police officers to go to Albany and oppose it as a destructive measure.

title: Genesco Financial Sets $50Million Financing
description: The Genesco Financial Corporation, wholly owned subsidiary of Genesco, Inc., has completed a $50million financing package with the Prudential Insurance Company of America, it was reported over the weekend.

title: American Confers With Hanoi Official Five Hours in Paris
description: PARIS, April 29 (Reuters)William H. Sullivan, the United States Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, and Nguyen Co Thach, the North Vietnamese Deputy Foreign Minister met for five and a half hours today in their second session of talks here in three days.

title: Troy Calls for Full Revelation Of Biaggi's Testimony to Jury
description: Mario Biaggi's campaign manager, Matthew J. Troy Jr., called upon the mayoral aspirant yesterday to divulge his entire grandjury testimony.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 30, 1973

title: Knicks Vanquish Celtics, 9478, And Gain N.B.A. Title Playoff
Personal Finance: On Tax Records
description: Now that April 15 and the tax jitters for most taxpayers have passed, there comes the dull but important task of scooping together all the records  bills, canceled checks, worksheets, copies of the tax form, copies of withholding statementsrequired in preparing your return.

title: DR. JOHN D. WALKER
description: HARTFORD, April 29 (AP)Dr. John Delaney Walker of Windsor, past president of the American Podiatry Association and the Connecticut Podiatry Association, died Friday at St. Francis Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Product Endorsements: A Rewarding Sideline for Hero Athletes
description: There they are, for the whole world to see: Hero athletes like Dave DeBusschere, dyeing his hair in the shower. Richie Scheinblum, announcing that he is now available for hair spray commercials because he recently had his bald spot covered by a hairweaving job. Jerry Lucas, giving his 32yearold head a Vitalis 60Second Workout.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Nation's Cities Brace for Major Financial Problems Resulting From Nixon Budget
