description: DETROIT, April 29Budget officials in cities across the country are combing through the thick blue volumes of President Nixon's budget proposal in an attempt to find out what impact its new regulations and changing directives will have on their own programs and plans.

title: Canadiens Outskate Slower Hawks, 83
description: MONTREAL April 29  The quiet Canadien cannons boomed again today, which wasn't surprising.

title: Law Students to Aid U.S. Drive Against Jersey Water Pollution
description: NEWARK, April 29  The United States Attorney for New Jersey and the Seton Hall University School of Law announced jointly today a legalfieldwork program under which advanced law students will take part in a steppedup campaign of enforcement of Federal laws against water pollution.

title: INSURANCE BILLS FOR HEALTH FADE
description: WASHINGTON, April 29National health insurance, an issue that burned brightly as the decade started, only to flicker and go out during last year's elections, is retreating even farther from the attention of Administration officials and Congressmen.

title: Troy Urges Full Revelation by Biaggi
description: Mario Biaggi's campaign manager, Matthew J. Troy Jr., called upon the mayoral aspirant yesterday to divulge his entire grandjury testimony.

title: Bonn Aide Leaves Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 29 (AP)West Germany's Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, left Jakarta for Bonn tonight after having attended a twoday conference of 23 West German diplomats in Asia and the Pacific region, at which they reviewed the principles of Bonn's policies in Asia with a view to adjusting them to new developments.

title: Uganda's Foreign Minister Resigns on Arvin's Advice
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 29 (UPI)The President of Uganda, Maj. Gen, Idi Amin, announced the resignation today of Foreign Minister Wanume Kibedi, reported by diplomatic analysts to have once been the second most powerful person in the country.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: EASTERN CONFERENCE FINALS

title: Job Outlook Ominous on Wall Street
description: James L. Kleiber is 28 years old, personable, wellgroomed and a man who admits to loving the securities business. On March 23, he involuntarily joined Wall Street's army of unemployed.

title: CARDIAC PATIENTS HOLD GYM SHOW
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, April 29  The effectiveness and merit of properly controlled exercise in the life of a victim of a heart attack could not be better described than what you are witnessing here this morning, declared Dr. Irving M. Levitas, director of rehabilitation medicine at Hackensack Hospital.

title: Books of The Times
description: Great intellectual structures crammed into a nutshell, I seem to want (the reviewer is forever trying to educate himself). So Viking Press's Modern Masters series continues to exert its fatal attraction. So far, it's batted about .600 in my head: More than half of the 19 volumes published to date have been firstrate, while the others have proved either wrongheaded or impenetrable. And now comes yet another compact, brightly colored package ... it's Albert Einstein wrapped up this time ... the most important thinker of the 20th century in a nutshell ... so the fool rushes in, hoping finally to comprehend certain subtleties that hays eluded him thus far. (Am I alone? We've come a long way since Sir Arthur Eddington, in response to being asked if it was true that only three people in the world understood the general theory of relativity, said, Who is the third? Still, are Einstein's ideas knowledge?)

title: SALES RISE 10.9% FOR CHAIN STORES
description: Chainstore sales in March made a creditable showing this year despite the fact that Easter did not come until late April, a survey of The New York Times showed yesterday.

title: OPTIMISM VOICED IN BOND MARKET
description: The bond market may continue to benefit this week from a stormy investment climate that has produced a major drop in stock prices and caused broad uncertainty.

title: Auto Makers Are Taking Pains To Clarify Letters on Defects
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 Automobile manufacturers have peen taking special pains in the last month to state the facts clearly, understandably and accurately in notifying owners of safety defects in their cars.

title: Redman Captures First L&W Race; Scheckter Second
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., April 29 Brian Redman, whose rich Lancashire accent would grace a British tourism commercial, survived a diabolical weekend of tempermental engines and a big sideways twitch of his unbalanced car to win the opening race of the L&M Championship for Formula 5000 cars today.

title: Pentagon Spends Millions To Save Ailing Companies
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Department of Defense over the last 15 years has used emergency authorization to award tens of millions of dollars in outright grants to defense contractors  decisions taken frequently without the ratification or even the knowledge of the Secretary of Defense.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Swore and Fired, Victim's Father Says
description: The stepfather of a 10yearold Queens boy who was shot and killed Saturday by a plainclothes policeman said yesterday that he and his son had been approached by a man with a gun who had sworn and fired at them without identifying himself.

title: Burke Resigns Active Role With Yanks But Remains an Owner and Consultant
description: Michael Burke, the man who induced the Columbia Broadcasting System to buy the Yankees in 1964 and then sell them to the present owners earlier this year, relinquished yesterday his his role in the operation of the club.

title: Pentagon Spends Millions To Save Ailing Companies
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Department of Defense over the last 15 years has used emergency authorization to award tens of millions of dollars in outright grants to defense contractors  decisions taken frequently without the ratification or even the knowledge of the Secretary of Defense.

title: Independents Called Target Of the Major Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, asserted today that major oil companies planned to eliminate competition from independent gasoline dealers by driving them out of business this summer.

title: SILAS SPITZER, 76, FOOD EDITOR, DEAD
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, LI., April 29Silas Spitzer, food editor since 1971 of Travel and Leisure magazine, died yesterday at his winter home in Quogue. He was 76 years old and had lived here for many years.

title: DELAY ON HOTEL IS LAID TO TITLE
description: A title search is said to be holding up the announcement of detailed plans for a proposed 2,020room hotel on Times Square.

title: Nations Cup Tour Replaces World Cup in U.S., Canada
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, April 29 (UPI)The World Cup ski circuit will stay entirely in Europe next year, the International Ski Federation (FIS) announced today.

title: PEARSONCAPTURES 4TH RACE IN ROW
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 29 (AP)  David Pearson held off Cale Yarborough in a racelong battle today and, posted his fourth straight NASCAR victory In the Virginia 500 Grand National race.

title: TWO NIXON AIDES EXPECTED TO SEE U.S. PROSECUTORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, and John D. Ehrlichman, President Nixon's top domestic adviser, will meet with Federal prosecutors this week to discuss their possible roles in the Watergate breakin and its subsequent coverup, sources close to the case said today.

title: Bertram Lederer Weds Miss Nussbaum
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., April 29Miss Margaret Sue Nussbaum and Bertram Max Lederer of Cambridge, Mass., were married here this morning at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Harvey E. Nussbaum. Rabbi Barry Hewitt Greene performed the ceremony.

title: Pravda Report of Brezhnev's Speech
description: MOSCOW; April 29Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from a policy statement in Pravda, the Soviet Communist party daily, summarizing a speech delivered Thursday by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader:

title: FOSS LEADS A TREK TO ROMANTIC ERA
description: Lukas Foss's marathons with the Brooklyn Philharmonia may be the salvation of Western music, as he seems to think, or they may be just big concerts with a slight touch of elephantiasis of the ego. There can be no doubt, however, that Mr. Foss's Romantic Marathon on Saturday evening at the Academy of Music offered a multitude of worthy performances of a multitude of worthy music.

title: Lyris Campanella Wed to David McKeon
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Lyris C. Campanella became the bride of David J. McKeon. The Rev. Edward O'Donnell performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: BLOOMFIELD, April 29The walls of Tom Fleming's room are, covered with medals, trophies and plaques. In the corner are six pairs of track shoes and on a cluttered desk, a diary.

title: Ellsberg Lawyers Weigh New Motion for Dismissal
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29 Defense attorneys in the Pentagon papers trial are considering a move tomorrow for dismissal of the case against Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. because of a report that the office of Dr. Ellsberg's former psychiatrist had been broken into by men associated with the Government.

title: Miss Ehret Wins Golf Playoff; Miss Creed, Miss Burfeindt 2d
description: BIRMINGHAM. Ala., April 29 (UPI)  Gloria Ehret, a nineyear pro who had not won Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament since 1966, sank a 15foot birdie putt today to defeat Clifford Ann Creed and Betty Burfeindt, the defender, in a suddendeath playoff in the Birmingham Classic.

title: Textile Talks to Resume Today In the Hope of Averting Strike
description: Negotiations are scheduled to be resumed today between District 65 of the Distributive Workers of America and employer groups in an effort to avert a strike that could cripple the garment industry here at the height of its busy summerwear season.

title: Crime and Compassion
description: BOSTON, April 29It is a country of one subject, preoccupied as it has not been for years. What is there in the collection of events labeled Watergate that so totally grips the American mind?

title: University That Discharged Him Honors Rebellious Scott Nearing
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29Dr. Scott Nearing did not get fed up with conventional society and drop out. More precisely, he was thrown out.

title: A.M.A. FAULTS RULING ON COUGH MEDICINES
description: CHICAGO, April 29 (UPI)Physicians may have to write their own cough medicine formulas because the Federal Government has ordered dozens of commercial cough remedies off the market, the Journal of the American Medical Association said today.

title: Companies Implementing Antibias Job Regulations
description: Recent court decisions enforcing laws requiring nondiscrimination are creating significant changes in company personnel policies and practices, according to a study released today by the Conference Board.

title: GERMAN AMERICAN SOCCER
description: LEAGUE

title: Concert
description: Since the music of Mozart does not give young pianists the opportunity to utilize the big techniques and thunderous sonorities they work so hard to develop, few of them reveal any particular empathy for his works.

title: Michael Burke Quits
description: Michael Burke stepped down yesterday as chief executive in charge of the daytoday operation of the New York Yankees. He retains part ownership and will be a consultant. Details, Page 39.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: 6 Killed at Mexican Road Race

title: Shoppers Cut Meat Purchases To Protest Static Prices Here
description: Shoppers in the New York area continued to fight high meat prices last week by curtailing their purchases, but so far the tactic has produced only some special sales, no lowering of meat prices in general.

title: COMDR. WILLIAM DEELY
description: Comdr. William 1 Deely, a Navy pediatrician assigned to Balboa Hospital in San Diego, Calif., drowned Saturday in Hawaii while vacationing with his wife, Eileen, and seven children. He was 35 years old.

title: Knicks Break Downand Smile
description: BOSTON, April 29All it took was the Knicks' finest defensive effort of the National Basketball Association season  82 regular games and 12 playoff conteststo bring chuckles of selfsatisfaction to Coach Red Holzman and his team after today's game at Boston Garden.

title: Scofflaw Office to Move
description: The City's Parking Violations Bureau will move its scofflaw office to separate, larger quarters at 51 Chambers Street on May 7 to accommodate what it described as the large number of people wishing to clear up outstanding parking summonses and thus qualify for having their car registrations renewed. The unit, formally known as the Office of Judgments and Executions, had been temporarily housed In the bureau's offices at 44 Court Street, Brooklyn. It will be open to the public from 9 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Monday through Friday.

title: Policy on Infinitesimals
description: The Food and Drug Administration has banned further use of the cattlefattening hormone DES on which livestock raisers have long relied to get the maximum gain in animal weight for a given quantity of feed. DES is a carcinogen and minute traces of it were found in animals on which it had been used. The Delaney amendment prohibits the use in foods of agents known to cause cancer, and that amendment has now been applied. The result in the not too distant future is likely to be more expensive beef, with estimates of the likely price increase ranging from 3.5 to 15 cents a pound.

title: Mr. Smith's Regime
description: LONDONRhodesia's Smith regime tends to regard any opposition as a threat to its existence. Leaders of the African people (95 per cent of the population) have been held in prisons and detention camps for years without trialone man, Daniel Madzimbamuto, is now entering his fourteenth year of detentionparties and newspapers have been banned and activities within the country are rigorously controlled by laws and regulations. One of the latest regulations makes it an offense, punishable by up to seven imprisonment, to spread rumors.

title: Passaic Parades for Its Centennia
description: PASSAIC, April 29This city began celebrating its centennial today with a parade in which thousands of people from neighboring communities participated.

title: L. HYLER CONNELL
description: L. Hyler Connell, a lawyer for the State Power Authority from 1956 to 1970 and executive secretary of the State Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board from 1952 to 1956, died Saturday at his home, 630 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon, N, Y. He was 69 years old.

title: KOOSMAN 4HITTER FOILS BRAVES, 10
JAMES T. LOREE, 85, EXRAIL EXECUTIVE
description: ALBANY, April 29James T. Loree, former vice president and general manager of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad, died yesterday at his home. He was 85 years old.

title: Lucille Cuccurullo, Teacher, Is Bride
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 29Miss Lucille Marie Cuccurullo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Cuccurullo of Cold Spring Harbor, was married here this afternoon to James William Wyckoff, son of Mrs. Edward Thomas Wyckoff of Huntington and the late Mr. Wyckoff. The Rev. Joseph MacGuiness performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Churn.

title: Horsemeat Shop Is Popular
description: BUFFALO, April 29 (AP)Buffalo shoppers have been hoofing it to Allco Enterprises, buying out Allco Enterprises' first 20,000pound supply of horsemeat in three days. The proprietor, Charles L. Saietta, said his newly opened shop would have a fresh 10,000?? supply for sale tomorrow.

title: Roundup: Wood Beats Red Sox, 50
description: Players have been known to laugh when the 6foot, 190pound Wilbur Wood ambles to the mound, but when the Chicago White Sox lefthander lofts his knuckleball, he usually gets the last laugh.

title: Britain's Battle of the Paycheck
description: LONDON, April 29After months of uncertainty over where the next strike was coming from, Britain appears to be ready to settle down to a period of relative industrial peace.

title: 3d Soldier in 3 Days Is Killed By Northern Ireland Gunmen
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 29  One British soldier was killed and one wounded by gunmen today in the Roman Catholic New Lodge Road area of Belfast. The soldier was the third to be killed by Irish Republican Army terrorists in three days.

title: Consumers, in Protest, Mailing Tapes From Supermarket Registers to Nixon
description: NEWARK, April 29More than one million supermarket register tapes will be mailed to the White House starting today to protest soaring food prices.

title: Georgia Recaptures 12 of 24 Who Escaped From Prison
description: BAINBRIDGE, Ga., April 29 (UPI)A force of 150 state and local law officers searched today for the remaining 12 convicts who escaped from the Decatur Correctional Institution last night. Twelve others who also escaped were recaptured later.

title: Shoppers Cut Meat Purchases To Protest Static Prices Here
description: Shoppers in the New York area continued to fight high meat prices last week by curtailing their purchases, but so, far the tactic has produced only some special sales, no lowering of meat prices in general.

title: Italian NeoFascists Are Linked To a Synagogue Fire in Padua
description: ROME, April 29A judicial inquiry into a synagogue fire in Padua has brought out evidence linking recent manisfestations of antiSemitism with the neoFascist party.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT TWINS, 63, 111

title: LINDSAY SUGGESTS PLAN FOR TRANSIT TO REDUCE FARES
description: A plan to roll back bus and subway fares to 25 cents, cut commuter fares by almost 30 per cent and, at the same time, provide for longrange financing of mass transit in the metropolitan area was unveiled yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Smokers in Park Back Free Marijuana for All
description: Several hundred people, most of them young and dressed in denim, rallied for free marijuana yesterday in Central Park, following a march from Washington Square.

title: Ballet
description: Tina Ramirez's Ballet Hispanico of New York is a company to keep your eye on. The troupe, formed in 1970 by Miss Ramirez, whose performing career until the early nineteensixties was in Spanish dancing, is an example of what a communityoriented organization can offer to a wide public.

title: MRS. PHILIP A. MEANS
description: Mrs. Louise Munroe Means, widow of Philip Ainsworth Means, an expert on Inca civilization, died Saturday at her home, 755 Park Avenue. She was 82 years old.

title: Turkish Authorities Report Breaking Up New Marxist Group
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 29 (Reuters)  The Istanbul martiallaw command announced today that it had captured 60 members of a newly formed Communist organization that it said was planning a guerrilla war in Turkey.

title: British Football
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: BLASTS CONTINUING ON MUNITIONS TRAIN
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 29 (AP)Bombs aboard a train carrying munitions continued to explode today, more than a day after a series of blasts turned a railyard into a square mile of flaming boxcars and flying shrapnel.

title: 5% OF CHICKEN LIVERS FOUND WITH ARSENIC
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI)Government tests show that about one out of every 20 broilerfryer chickens sold to consumers in the first three months of this year apparently had illegal residues of organic arsenic in their livers.

title: Filipino Stone Age Tribe Now Has 28, With 2d Baby
description: MANILA, April 29 (AP)The population of a southern Philippine mountain tribe that still lives in the Stone Age has grown to 28 with the birth of a baby girl, it was reported here today.

title: In Jet, $7.20, Is First In Coast Stake
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 29 (AP)Tri Jet broke from the extreme outside in a field of 11, took the lead around the far turn and drew away for a 3length victory today in the $39,450 Caballero Handicap at Hollywood Park, Laffit Pincay Jr. was aboard the winner.

title: Saudi Oil Town's Life Style Is Transplanted Houston
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi ArabiaAn American world of shade trees along residential streets, Little League baseball, parentteacher association meetings and sailboat races in the Persian Gulf lies within the chainlink fences around the ArabianAmerican oil company installations here. It is more than 9,000 nautical miles from here to Houston, and the big oil tankers that are constantly loading at the offshore terminals here can make the voyage in 18 days.

title: In Memory of Campus Activism
description: WASHINGTONThe apparent collapse of the student revolt, which just two years ago threatened to stop the Government, is an abrupt and significant development. Campuses claim they are back at work, newspapers talk inflation, energy shortages, scandal, checks and balances. Revolutionaries have lost their mystique. For example, as deplorable as Jane Fonda's conduct has been, one senses that the expressed outrage over her P.O.W. remarks is not deeply felt. The sentiment is genuine, but taking on a figure like Miss Fonda is like beating a dead horse. A public bored with revolutionary fantasy moves on to issues.

title: PEARSON CAPTURES 4TH RACE IN ROW
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 29 (AP)  David Pearson held off Cale Yarborough in a racelong battle today and posted his fourth straight NASCAR victory in the Virginia 500 Grand National race.

title: MailOrder Policies Planned
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the May Department Stores Company announced yesterday that Metropolitan Life would soon offer a supplementary hospital insurance plan to chargeaccount customers of the FamousBarr department stare in St. Louis. FamousBarr is owned by May. Metropolital Life said the arrangement marked its en(trance into selling insurance by direct mail.

title: Music: Three by Three
description: A new concert series entitled Three by Three, which got under way yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, fitted somewhere between what in art circles is called a group show and what in Olympic circles is called a marathon. Three young but already important recitalists shared the threehour program, and their efforts were taped live for broadcast on the National Public Radio Network.

title: Bomb Found at Beirut Field; Arabs Say They Planted It
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 29Authorities found an explosive device in a lavatory at the international airport last night and disarmed it about an hour before it was to go off.

title: Three Drown Upstate In Aftermath of Joke

description: LUXEMBOURG, April 29A row between French and West German farm ministers threat. ened to throw the European Common Market into a fresh crisis tonight as West Germany's Chancellor, Willy Brandt, arrived in Washington for talks with President Nixon.

title: Van Buren Horne Sold for U.S. Site
description: KINDERHOOK, N.Y., April 29Lindenwald, the home of Martin Van Buren, eighth President of the United States, was sold this week by its private owner to the National Park Foundation for conversion into a National Historic Site. The price for the house and 12 surrounding acres was $102,000.

title: Advertising: Alberto in Switch
description: As an advertiser, you've got to say this for the AlbertoCulver Company it's been through some of the best advertising agencies.

title: Biaggi's Headaches Found Splitting for Conservatives
description: The controversy over Representative Mario Biaggi's reported refusal to answer all questions before a Federal grand jury has produced a crisis in the Conservative party and the first major challenge of the leadership of J. Daniel Mahoney and Kieran O'Doherty, the brothers  in  law who, instead of arguing over politics, started a political party 11 years ago in their discussions around the kitchen table in Mr. Mahoney's Forest Hills apartment.

title: Shecky Greene's Owner Takes Derby Seriously
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29Speculation as to whether Shecky Greene, conceded to be one of the fastest sprinters of recent years, will race in the Kentucky Derby next Saturday was the main concern at Churchill Downs today. The colt is owned by Joe Kellman of Chicago and is trained by Lou Goldfine.

title: Knicks Are Mobbed By Fans at Airport
description: Several hundred fans mobbed the New York Knicks when they arrived at LaGuardia Airport last night after beating the Celtics, 9478, in Boston to reach the National Basketball Association title playoffs.

title: On Tightening Faucets
description: WASHINGTON, April 29You know how it is, you get the bags in the car, and the kids in the car, and you start the engine figuring you have just enough time to get to the airport unless one of the kids gets carsickand then your wife says I forgot! and runs back in the house.

title: TIGHTER CONTROLS SUGGESTED BY ASH
description: Roy L. Ash, director of the President's Office of Management and Budget, said yesterday that some tightening of controls might be necessary to restrain inflation under the Phase 3 economic stabilization program.

title: Barry Denenberg Weds Susan Davis
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., April 29Miss Susan Jane Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Davis Jr. of New York, was married here this afternoon to Barry Denenberg. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Denenberg of Dumont, N. J.

title: TWO NIXON AIDES EXPECTED TO SEE U.S. PROSECUTORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 29H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, and John D. Ehrlichman, President Nixon's top domestic adviser, will meet with Federal prosecutors this week to discuss their possible roles in the Watergate breakin and its subsequent coverup, sources close to the case said today.

title: GOVERNORS URGED TO ACT ON BUGGING
description: HURON, Ohio, April 29Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, sought support tonight from Democratic Governors for a $75,000 television campaign attacking the Nixon Administration for its handling of the Watergate case.

title: GILBERT DAVIDOFF
description: Gilbert Davidoff, assistant principal for administration of New Utrecht High School and headmaster of the Kamenitzer Yeshiva, both in Brooklyn, died in an automobile accident Friday in Woodmere. L.I. He Was 38 years old and lived in Brooklyn and Woodmero.

title: Carol Schwartzreich Is Married
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 29Miss Carol Schwartzreich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Slyvan Schwartzreich of Larchmant and Boca Raton, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Michael Roch Hillenbrand. He is the son of Mrs. Henry Melvin Hillenbrand of Oshkosh, Wis., and the late Dr. Hillenbrand, a pathologist.

title: U.S. Five Defeats Russians, 8365
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 29 (AP)The United Stales national basketball team, battling to atone for a disputed loss to the Russians in the 1972 Olympic final, defeated the Soviet five by a score of 8365 today in the opener of a sixgame series.

title: BREDINEV ASSURES PARTY POLICY UNIT ON TRADE WITH U.S.
description: MOSCOW, April 29Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has assured the Communist party that rapid expansion of trade with the West is in the national interest and would not be at the expense of lowering this country's guard against foreign military designs and alien ideologies.

title: D.A. Moves on Behalf of Accused Policeman
description: The Queens prosecutor's office announced yesterday it would seek to reduce the charge against a policeman who shot to death a 10yearold boy from murder to criminally negligent homicide.

title: U.S. Family's Struggle in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, April 29 In September, 1970, Herbert and Rose Weinberg left their comfortable home in Rock Island, Ill., and emigrated with their three children to Israel. They had, in their own words, everything going for them: Fluency in Hebrew, a place to live and enough money to smooth the transition.

title: Disposal of a Hals Stirs Controversy
description: The Brooklyn Museum's disposal of Fishergirl, a major painting by the 17thcentury Dutch master Frans Hals, has renewed the deaccessioning controversy aroused by the recent sales of paintings by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Pat Henning, Comedian, Dead; Won Emmy for Catered Affair
description: MIAMI, April 29 (AP)Pat Henning, the comedian  actor, died in his sleep yesterday at his home here. He was 62 years old.

title: ' Wedding in White' Views 40's Family:The Cast
description: William Fruet's "Wedding in White" is a good, tough, clear-eyed Canadian film about a working-class family and the sweet, dim-witted, 16-year-old daughter, Jeannie, who finds herself "in trouble" (the euphemism she favors) after a singularly quick and joyless seduction by her brother's best friend.The time is midway through World War II, when being in trouble meant instant disgrace, especially to a father like Jeannie's, a hard-working, hard-drinking, narrow-minded man who would say that boys will be boys but that the girls who do are whores. His solution: marry Jeannie off to his best friend Sandy, a robust Scot of about 60 who is a drunk."Wedding in White" is the sort of domestic drama that most playwrights and film makers botch, either because they determinedly explain away the characters as sociological phenomena, as in another Canadian film, "Go-in" Down the Road," or because they invest the characters with inclinations to doggedly banal self-analysis. People in plays like Robert Anderson's "I Never Sang for My Father" and Frank Gilroy's "The Subject Was Roses" tend to talk about themselves as if they were not there, and to conceptualize problems that in life, arguing by the kitchen sink, remain specific.Mr. Fruet, who wrote the screenplay for "Goin' Down the Road," directed "Wedding in White" and adapted the script from his stage play. The dialogue is so faultless that even the slang defines the era as much as the skirt lengths and the automobiles. "My dad would crown me if I did that," Jeannie says at one point. More important, never does the writer-director allow his characters to talk above their station, to describe the overview that we in the audience can see for ourselves."Wedding in White" is not really tragic, nor is it as bleak as it might sound. It is a closely observed chronicle of one family's life, moving and funny and a little scary, full of unexpected stoicism and the kind of boozy jocularity that can suddenly erupt into violence. It is also marvelously well acted.Donald Pleasence is Jeannie's dad, "a top-notch bowler and a triple-threat man at darts," who also manages to suggest the existence of evil in the most commonplace of personalities. Jeannie's mother is played by Doris Petrie, a Canadian actress of unaffected beauty and great discretion of gesture. Also, fine are Paul Bradley and Doug McGrath (the born losers of "Goin' Down the Road"), as, respectively, the soldier son and the best friend who so casually gets Jeannie into trouble.At the center of the film, looking oddly like a Jan van Eyck subject transplanted to a land of five-and-tens and drug stores, is Carol Kane, whose Jeannie is someone obviously destined to go through life with nothing ever fitting.When her father brings home a second-hand dress for her to wear to the wedding she doesn't want, Jeannie's first thought is to call her friend Dollie, as if she had just received a birthday present. The world, the passions of others, her clothes, even her masses of frizzy reddish hair, are too big for her, and her brain is too small."Wedding in White" opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie.

title: Overhaul for Kitty Hawk
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 (UPI)  The U.S.S. Kitty Hawk celebrated her 12th birthday today midway through an overhaul that will turn the supercarrier from an attack ship to one designed to defend America's sea lanes against submarines.

title: VARIED RATES URGED ON MORTGAGE LOANS
description: The Committee for Economic Development, a research group supported by industry, is recommending variablerate mortgages to make housing less vulnerable to swings in the economy.

title: In Japan, a Sober, Thoughtful Approach to Suicide
description: TOKYO, April 29  A 19yearold Japanese youth packed 17 pounds of books, in cluding an English dictionary into a knapsack one day las week, slung it on his back knotted a rope around his net and hanged himself.

title: Head Start Quietly Sets Fees For Enrolling Nonpoor Children
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) The Head Start program for needy preschool children has begun charging middleaclass parents for enrolling their children in the education program, it became known last week.

title: FITTIPALDI TAKES SPAIN GRAND PRIX
description: BARCELONA, Spain, April 29Just before he would have been forced to quit the race, Emerson Fittipaldi won the Spanish Grand Prix today by more than half a minute in a Lotus Ford.

title: MISSISSIPPI PEAK PASSES ST. LOUIS
description: The historic crest of the Mississippi River Moved steadily southward yesterday and the water began a slow fall at St. Louis, where the river crested overnight more than 13 feet above flood stage.

title: Law and Order
description: There are those who say that law and order are just code words for repression and bigotry. This is dangerous nonsense, President Nixon declared last month as he unveiled harsh new anticrime proposals. Law and order are code words for goodness and decency America.

description: ORLANDO, Fla.The driver pulled into the gas station here on Orange Blossom Trail near the Florida Turnpike.

description: Lynn Beck says she isn't the sort of tourist who is always looking for the familiar. Hamburgers on the Champs Elysee or CocaCola in the jungle aren't her idea of discoveries.

title: NICARAGUA QUAKE HAS LEFT TRAUMA
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 23Nicaragua is suffering from serious trauma four months after an earthquake destroyed this capital city, killing about 10,000 people.

title: Officer Swore and Fired, Victim's Father Says
description: The stepfather of a 10yearold Queens boy who was shot and killed Saturday by a plainclothes policeman said yesterday that he and his son had been approached by a man with a gun who had sworn and fired at them without identifying himself.

description: WASHINGTON, April 29 Key figured in Congress are convinced that Watergate will prove to be President Nixon's Waterloo in the struggle for supremacy between Republicans in the White House and Democrats on Capitol Hill.

title: Police Save Infant Offered for Sale To Pay for Drugs
description: A battered 3monthold girl was reported in critical condition at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday after having been rescued by a transit patrolman early Saturday morning from her father, who the police said, was trying to sell the screaming infant on the subway to collect enough money to buy narcotics.

description: VLADIMIR, U.S.S.R., April 29Inside: Bearded priests in rich raiment bearing an ornamented cross and bible, incense and ikons, and singing the chant, Christ Is Risen, to a packed church.

title: New Magazine to Follow Jewish Life
description: The American Jewish Committee, publisher of the influential monthly intellectual journal, Commentary, plans to put out a quarterly magazine, beginning in October, devoted to Jewish affairs around the world.

title: Rev. John Odou, Founded Catholic Converts' Group
description: The Rev. John E. Odou, founding director of the Convert Movement Our Apostolate, formerly the Convert Makers of America, which promotes the spreading of the Roman Catholic faith by the laity, died Tuesday in Oakland, Calif. He was 62 years old.

title: Mountain of Butter
description: Agriculture is one of the most intractable problems confronting the United States and its European allies as they strive for a revitalized partnership in the Year Europe. Both President Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger have expressed concern that European Community protectionism would nullify this country's comparative advantage in agricultural exports.

title: Ellsberg Lawyers Weigh New Motion for Dismissal
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29 Defense attorneys in the Pentagon papers trial are considering a move tomorrow for dismissal of the case against Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. because of a report that the office of Dr. Ellsberg's former psychiatrist had been broken into by men associated with the Government.

title: Red Smith
description: One measure of the stature of sports in the American scheme is the extent to which sporting terms arc employed away from the playing fields, Politicians talk earnestly about carrying the ball and playing the game because. they think this brings them down to the intellectual level of the voters and at the same time invests them with a healthy, sweaty, outdoor quality of cleanliness and vigor. It seems here that in recent days borrowing the language of the playground has become more popular than ever, possibly because the tenant now occupying the White House sets the example with his telephone calls to Roller Derby winners. At any rate, newspapers lately have fairly crawled with examples of sportspeak, to use the word coined by Bob Lipsyte, whose talent used to illumine these pages. Trouble is, four times out of five the men who use sportspeak are not much better informed than the distinguished historian who cornpared a victorious general to the pinchhitter who steps up to the plate and hits the ball over the fence for three bases. For example:

title: Record Orders for Tools And Construction Posted
description: Attesting to the strong upsurge in industrial activity, two major economic indicators new orders for machine tools and the rate of contracting for new constructionset records during the first quarter.

title: Sightseers on Boat Spot Body of a Woman in River
description: The body of an unidentified woman about 50 years old was taken from the East River yesterday afternoon by police who had been sent to the scene after passengers aboard a Circle Line sightseeing boat had spotted her first and informed the crew.

title: Stage: Whiskey Opens
description: Whiskey, the title of Terrence McNally's new comedy, is the name of the equine star of the longestrunning, most highly rated television series. Onstage at Theater at St. Clements, where the show opened last night, the famous horse is heard but not seen. The play is actually about Whiskey's cowboy family, The Lush Thrushes.
